303	A great deal of Alabama's economic growth since the 1990s has been due to the state's expanding automotive manufacturing industry.
303	Located in the state are Honda Manufacturing of Alabama, Hyundai Motor Manufacturing Alabama, Mercedes-Benz U.S.
303	International, and Toyota Motor Manufacturing Alabama, as well as their various suppliers.
303	Since 1993, the automobile industry has generated more than 67,800 new jobs in the state.
303	Alabama currently ranks 4th in the nation in automobile output.
303	Steel producers Nucor, SSAB, ThyssenKrupp, and U.S.
303	Steel have facilities in Alabama and employ over 10,000 people.
303	In May 2007, German steelmaker ThyssenKrupp selected Alabama for a $3.7 billion steel production plant, with the promise of 2,700 permanent jobs.
303	The Hunt Refining Company, a subsidiary of Hunt Consolidated, Inc., is based in Tuscaloosa and operates a refinery there.
303	The company also operates terminals in Mobile, Melvin, and Moundville.
303	JVC America, Inc.
303	Tuscaloosa.
303	Tourism An estimated 20 million tourists annually visit the state.
303	Over 100,000 of these are from other countries, including from Canada, the United Kingdom, Germany and Japan.
303	In 2006, 22.3 million tourists spent $8.3 billion providing an estimated 162,000 jobs in the state.
303	Healthcare UAB Hospital is the only Level I trauma center in Alabama.
303	UAB is the largest state government employer in Alabama, with a workforce of about 18,000.
303	Banking Alabama has the headquarters of Regions Financial Corporation, BBVA Compass, Superior Bancorp and the former Colonial Bancgroup.
303	Birmingham-based Compass Banchshares was acquired by Spanish-based BBVA in September 2007, although the headquarters of BBVA Compass remains in Birmingham.
303	In November 2006, Regions Financial completed its merger with AmSouth Bancorporation, which was also headquartered in Birmingham.
303	SouthTrust Corporation, another large bank headquartered in Birmingham, was acquired by Wachovia in 2004 for $14.3 billion.
303	The city still has major operations for Wachovia and its now post-operating bank Wells Fargo, which includes a regional headquarters, an operations center campus and a $400 million dollar data center.
303	Nearly a dozen smaller banks are also headquartered in the Birmingham, such as Superior Bancorp, ServisFirst and New South Federal Savings Bank.
303	Birmingham also serves as the headquarters for several large investment management companies, including Harbert Management Corporation.
303	Electronics Telecommunications provider AT&T, formerly BellSouth, also has a major presence in Alabama with several large offices in Birmingham.
303	The company has over 6,000 employees and more than 1,200 contract employees.
303	Many commercial technology companies are headquartered in Huntsville, such as the network access company ADTRAN, computer graphics company Intergraph, design and manufacturer of IT infrastructure Avocent, and telecommunications provider Deltacom.
303	Cinram manufactures and distributes 20th Century Fox DVDs and Blu-ray Discs out of their Huntsville plant.
303	Construction Rust International has grown to include Brasfield & Gorrie, BE&K, Hoar Construction and B.L.
303	Harbert International, which all routinely are included in the Engineering News-Record lists of top design, international construction, and engineering firms.
303	Rust International was acquired in 2000 by Washington Group International, which was in turn acquired by San-Francisco based URS Corporation in 2007.) Law and government State government The foundational document for Alabama's government is the Alabama Constitution, which was ratified in 1901.
303	At almost 800 amendments and 310,000 words, it is the world's longest constitution and is roughly forty times the length of the U.S.
303	Constitution.
303	There has been a significant movement to rewrite and modernize Alabama's constitution.
303	This movement is based upon the fact that Alabama's constitution highly centralizes power in Montgomery and leaves practically no power in local hands.
303	Any policy changes proposed around the state must be approved by the entire Alabama legislature and, frequently, by state referendum.
303	One criticism of the current constitution claims that its complexity and length were intentional to codify segregation and racism.
305	In Greek mythology, Achilles (, Akhilleus,) was a Greek hero of the Trojan War and the central character and greatest warrior of Homer's Iliad.
305	Achilles was a demigod; his mother was the nymph Thetis, and his father, Peleus, was the king of the Myrmidons.
305	Achilles’ most notable feat during the Trojan War was the slaying of the Trojan hero Hector outside the gates of Troy.
305	Although the death of Achilles is not presented in the Iliad, other sources concur that he was killed near the end of the Trojan War by Paris, who shot him in the heel with an arrow.
305	Later legends (beginning with a poem by Statius in the 1st century AD) state that Achilles was invulnerable in all of his body except for his heel.
305	Because of his death from a small wound in the heel, the term Achilles' heel has come to mean a person's point of weakness.
305	Etymology  Achilles' name can be analyzed as a combination of  (akhos) "grief" and  (Laos) "a people, tribe, nation, etc."
305	In other words, Achilles is an embodiment of the grief of the people, grief being a theme raised numerous times in the Iliad (frequently by Achilles).
305	Achilles' role as the hero of grief forms an ironic juxtaposition with the conventional view of Achilles as the hero of kleos (glory, usually glory in war).
305	Laos has been construed by Gregory Nagy, following Leonard Palmer, to mean a corps of soldiers, a muster.
305	With this derivation, the name would have a double meaning in the poem: When the hero is functioning rightly, his men bring grief to the enemy, but when wrongly, his men get the grief of war.
305	The poem is in part about the misdirection of anger on the part of leadership.
305	The name Achilleus was a common and attested name among the Greeks soon after the 7th century BC.
305	It was also turned into the female form Ἀχιλλεία (Achilleía) attested in Attica in the 4th century BC (IG II² 1617) and, in the form Achillia, on a stele in Halicarnassus as the name of a female gladiator fighting an "Amazon".
305	Roman gladiatorial games often referenced classical mythology, and this seems to reference Achilles' fight with Penthesilea but gives it an extra twist of Achilles being "played" by a woman.
305	Birth  Achilles was the son of the nymph Thetis and Peleus, the king of the Myrmidons.
305	Zeus and Poseidon had been rivals for the hand of Thetis until Prometheus, the fore-thinker, warned Zeus of a prophecy that Thetis would bear a son greater than his father.
305	For this reason, the two gods withdrew their pursuit, and had her wed  Peleus.
305	As with most mythology, there is a tale which offers an alternative version of these events: in Argonautica (iv.760) Zeus' sister and wife Hera alludes to Thetis' chaste resistance to the advances of Zeus, that Thetis was so loyal to Hera's marriage bond that she coolly rejected him.
305	Thetis, although a daughter of the sea-god Nereus, was also brought up by Hera, further explaining her resistance to the advances of Zeus.
305	According to the Achilleid, written by Statius in the 1st century AD, and to no surviving previous sources, when Achilles was born Thetis tried to make him immortal, by dipping him in the river Styx.
305	However, he was left vulnerable at the part of the body by which she held him, his heel (see Achilles heel, Achilles' tendon).
305	It is not clear if this version of events was known earlier.
305	In another version of this story, Thetis anointed the boy in ambrosia and put him on top of a fire, to burn away the mortal parts of his body.
305	She was interrupted by Peleus and abandoned both father and son in a rage.
305	However, none of the sources before Statius makes any reference to this general invulnerability.
305	To the contrary, in the Iliad Homer mentions Achilles being wounded: in Book 21 the Paeonian hero Asteropaeus, son of Pelagon, challenged Achilles by the river Scamander.
305	He cast two spears at once, one grazed Achilles' elbow, "drawing a spurt of blood".
305	Also, in the fragmentary poems of the Epic Cycle in which we can find description of the hero's death, Cypria (unknown author), Aithiopis by Arctinus of Miletus, Little Iliad by Lesche of Mytilene, Iliou persis by Arctinus of Miletus, there is no trace of any reference to his general invulnerability or his famous weakness (heel); in the later vase paintings presenting Achilles' death, the arrow (or in many cases, arrows) hit his body.
305	Peleus entrusted Achilles to Chiron the Centaur, on Mt.
305	Pelion, to be reared.
305	Achilles in the Trojan War  The Rage of Achilles, by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo The first two lines of the Iliad read: : Sing, Goddess, of the rage of Peleus' son Achilles, the accursed rage that brought great suffering to the Achaeans.
305	Achilles' consuming rage is at times wavering, but at other times he cannot be cooled.
305	The humanization of Achilles by the events of the war is an important theme of the narrative.
305	According to the Iliad, Achilles arrived at Troy with 50 ships, each carrying 50 Myrmidons (Book 2).
305	He appointed five leaders (each leader commanding 500 Myrmidons): Menesthius, Eudorus, Peisander, Phoenix and Alcimedon (Book 16).
305	Telephus  When the Greeks left for the Trojan War, they accidentally stopped in Mysia, ruled by King Telephus.
305	In the resulting battle, Achilles gave Telephus a wound that would not heal; Telephus consulted an oracle, who stated that "he that wounded shall heal".
305	Guided by the oracle, he arrived at Argos, where Achilles healed him in order that he might become their guide for the voyage to Troy.
305	According to other reports in Euripides' lost play about Telephus, he went to Aulis pretending to be a beggar and asked Achilles to heal his wound.
305	Achilles refused, claiming to have no medical knowledge.
305	Alternatively, Telephus held Orestes for ransom, the ransom being Achilles' aid in healing the wound.
305	Odysseus reasoned that the spear had inflicted the wound; therefore, the spear must be able to heal it.
305	Pieces of the spear were scraped off onto the wound and Telephus was healed.
305	Troilus  According to the Cypria (the part of the Epic Cycle that tells the events of the Trojan War before Achilles' Wrath), when the Achaeans desired to return home, they were restrained by Achilles, who afterwards attacked the cattle of Aeneas, sacked neighboring cities and killed Troilus.
305	According to Dares Phrygius' Account of the Destruction of Troy, the Latin summary through which the story of Achilles was transmitted to medieval Europe, Troilus was a young Trojan prince, the youngest of King Priam's (or sometimes Apollo) and Hecuba's five legitimate sons.
305	Despite his youth, he was one of the main Trojan war leaders.
305	Prophecies linked Troilus' fate to that of Troy and so he was ambushed in an attempt to capture him.
305	Yet Achilles, struck by the beauty of both Troilus and his sister Polyxena, and overcome with lust, directed his sexual attentions on the youth – who refusing to yield found instead himself decapitated upon an altar-omphalos of Apollo.
305	Later versions of the story suggested Troilus was accidentally killed by Achilles in an over-ardent lovers' embrace.
305	In this version of the myth, Achilles' death therefore came in retribution for this sacrilege.
305	Ancient writers treated Troilus as the epitome of a dead child mourned by his parents.
305	Had Troilus lived to adulthood, the First Vatican Mythographer claimed Troy would have been invincible.
305	Achilles in the Iliad  Homer's Iliad is the most famous narrative of Achilles' deeds in the Trojan War.
305	Achilles' wrath is the central theme of the book.
305	The Homeric epic only covers a few weeks of the war, and does not narrate Achilles' death.
305	It begins with Achilles' withdrawal from battle after he is dishonored by Agamemnon, the commander of the Achaean forces.
305	Agamemnon had taken a woman named Chryseis as his slave.
305	Her father Chryses, a priest of Apollo, begged Agamemnon to return her to him.
305	Agamemnon refused and Apollo sent a plague amongst the Greeks.
305	The prophet Calchas correctly determined the source of the troubles but would not speak unless Achilles vowed to protect him.
305	Achilles did so and Calchas declared Chryseis must be returned to her father.
305	Agamemnon consented, but then commanded that Achilles' battle prize Briseis be brought to replace Chryseis.
305	Angry at the dishonor of having his plunder and glory taken away (and as he says later, because he loved Briseis), with the urging of his mother Thetis, Achilles refused to fight or lead his troops alongside the other Greek forces.
305	At this same time, burning with rage over Agamemnon's theft, Achilles prayed to Thetis to convince Zeus to help the Trojans gain ground in the war, so that he may regain his honor.
305	As the battle turned against the Greeks, thanks to the influence of Zeus, Nestor declared that the Trojans were winning because Agamemnon had angered Achilles, and urged the king to appease the warrior.
305	Agamemnon agreed and sent Odysseus and two other chieftains, Ajax and Phoenix, to Achilles with the offer of the return of Briseis and other gifts.
305	Achilles rejected all Agamemnon offered him, and simply urged the Greeks to sail home as he was planning to do.
305	The Trojans, led by Hector, subsequently pushed the Greek army back toward the beaches and assaulted the Greek ships.
305	With the Greek forces on the verge of absolute destruction, Patroclus led the Myrmidons into battle wearing Achilles' armor, though Achilles remained at his camp.
305	Patroclus succeeded in pushing the Trojans back from the beaches, but was killed by Hector before he could lead a proper assault on the city of Troy.
305	After receiving the news of the death of Patroclus from Antilochus, the son of Nestor, Achilles grieved over his beloved companion's death and held many funeral games in his honor.
305	His mother Thetis came to comfort the distraught Achilles.
305	She persuaded Hephaestus to make a new armor for him, in place of the armor that Patroclus had been wearing which was taken by Hector.
305	The new armor included the Shield of Achilles, described in great detail by the poet.
305	Enraged over the death of Patroclus, Achilles ended his refusal to fight and took the field killing many men in his rage but always seeking out Hector.
305	Achilles even engaged in battle with the river god Scamander who became angry that Achilles was choking his waters with all the men he killed.
305	The god tried to drown Achilles but was stopped by Hera and Hephaestus.
305	Zeus himself took note of Achilles' rage and sent the gods to restrain him so that he would not go on to sack Troy itself, seeming to show that the unhindered rage of Achilles could defy fate itself as Troy was not meant to be destroyed yet.
305	Finally, Achilles found his prey.
305	Achilles chased Hector around the wall of Troy tbe destroyed yet.
305	Finally, Achilles found his prey.
305	Achilles chased Hector around three times before Athena, in the form of Hector's favorite and dearest brother, Deiphobus, persuaded Hector to stop running and fight Achilles face to face.
305	After Hector realized the trick, he knew the battle was inevitable.
305	Wanting to go down fighting, he charged at Achilles with his only weapon, his sword, but missed.
305	Accepting his fate, Hector begged Achilles, not to spare his life, but to treat his body with respect after killing him.
305	Achilles told Hector it was hopeless to expect that of him, declaring that "my rage, my fury would drive me now to hack your flesh away and eat you raw – such agonies you have caused me".
305	Achilles then got his vengeance.
305	With the assistance of the god Hermes, Hector's father, Priam, went to Achilles' tent to plead with Achilles to permit him to perform for Hector his funeral rites.
305	Achilles relented and promised a truce for the duration of Hector's funeral.
305	The final passage in the Iliad is Hector's funeral, after which the doom of Troy was just a matter of time.
305	Penthesilea  Achilles, after his temporary truce with Priam, fought and killed the Amazonian warrior queen Penthesilea, but later grieved over her death.
305	At first, he was so distracted by her beauty, he did not fight as intensely as usual.
305	Once he realized that his distraction was endangering his life, he refocused and killed her.
305	As he grieved over the death of such a rare beauty, a notorious Greek jeerer by the name of Thersites laughed and mocked the great Achilles.
305	Memnon, and the fall of Achilles  Following the death of Patroclus, Achilles' closest companion was Nestor's son Antilochus.
305	When Memnon, king of Ethiopia slew Antilochus, Achilles once more obtained revenge on the battlefield, killing Memnon.
305	The fight between Achilles and Memnon over Antilochus echoes that of Achilles and Hector over Patroclus, except that Memnon (unlike Hector) was also the son of a goddess.
305	Many Homeric scholars argued that episode inspired many details in the Iliads description of the death of Patroclus and Achilles' reaction to it.
305	The episode then formed the basis of the cyclic epic Aethiopis, which was composed after the Iliad, possibly in the 7th century B.C.
305	The Aethiopis is now lost, except for scattered fragments quoted by later authors.
305	The death of Achilles, as predicted by Hector with his dying breath, was brought about by Paris with an arrow (to the heel according to Statius).
305	In some versions, the god Apollo guided Paris' arrow.
305	Some retellings also state that Achilles was scaling the gates of Troy and was hit with a poisoned arrow.
305	All of these versions deny Paris any sort of valor, owing to the common conception that Paris was a coward and not the man his brother Hector was, and Achilles remained undefeated on the battlefield.
305	His bones were mingled with those of Patroclus, and funeral games were held.
305	He was represented in the Aethiopis as living after his death in the island of Leuke at the mouth of the river Danube.
305	Another version of Achilles' death is that he fell deeply in love with one of the Trojan princesses, Polyxena.
305	Achilles asks Priam for Polyxena's hand in marriage.
305	Priam is willing because it would mean the end of the war and an alliance with the world's greatest warrior.
305	But while Priam is overseeing the private marriage of Polyxena and Achilles, Paris, who would have to give up Helen if Achilles married his sister, hides in the bushes and shoots Achilles with a divine arrow, killing him.
305	Achilles was cremated and his ashes buried in the same urn as those of Patroclus.
305	Paris was later killed by Philoctetes using the enormous bow of Heracles.
305	Fate of Achilles' armor  Achilles' armor was the object of a feud between Odysseus and Telamonian Ajax (Ajax the greater).
305	They competed for it by giving speeches on why they were the bravest after Achilles to their Trojan prisoners, who after considering both men came to a consensus in favor of Odysseus.
305	Furious, Ajax cursed Odysseus, which earned the ire of Athena.
305	Athena temporarily made Ajax so mad with grief and anguish that he began killing sheep, thinking them his comrades.
305	After a while, when Athena lifted his madness and Ajax realized that he had actually been killing sheep, Ajax was left so ashamed that he committed suicide.
305	Odysseus eventually gave the armor to Neoptolemus, the son of Achilles.
305	A relic claimed to be Achilles' bronze-headed spear was for centuries preserved in the temple of Athena on the acropolis of Phaselis, Lycia, a port on the Pamphylian Gulf.
305	The city was visited in 333 BC by Alexander the Great, who envisioned himself as the new Achilles and carried the Iliad with him, but his court biographers do not mention the spear, which he would indeed have touched with excitement.
305	But it was being shown in the time of Pausanias in the 2nd century AD.
305	Achilles and Patroclus  The exact nature of Achilles' relationship with Patroclus has been a subject of dispute in both the classical period and modern times.
305	In the Iliad, it appears to be the model of a deep and loyal friendship, but commentators from classical antiquity to the present have often interpreted the relationship through the lens of their own cultures.
305	In 5th-century BC Athens, the intense bond was often viewed in light of the Greek custom of paiderasteia.
305	In Plato's Symposium, the participants in a dialogue about love assume that Achilles and Patroclus were a couple; Phaedrus argues that Achilles was the younger and more beautiful one so he was the beloved and Patroclus was the lover.
305	But ancient Greek had no words to distinguish heterosexual and homosexual, and it was assumed that a man could both desire handsome young men and have sex with women.
305	Although epic decorum excluded explicit sexuality, the Iliad indicates that Achilles had sexual relations with women, with no direct evidence of sexual behaviors with Patroclus.
305	Worship of Achilles in antiquity  There was an archaic heroic cult of Achilles on the White Island, Leuce, in the Black Sea off the modern coasts of Romania and Ukraine, with a temple and an oracle which survived into the Roman period.
305	In the lost epic  Aithiopis, a continuation of the Iliad attributed to Arktinus of Miletos,  Achilles’ mother Thetis returned to mourn  him and removed his ashes from the pyre and took them to Leuce at the mouths of the Danube.
305	There the Achaeans raised a tumulus for him and celebrated funeral games.
305	Pliny's Natural History mentions a tumulus that is no longer evident (Insula Akchillis tumulo eius viri clara), on the island consecrated to him, located at a distance of fifty Roman miles from Peuce by the Danube Delta, and the temple there.
305	Pausanias has been told that the island is "covered with forests and full of animals, some wild, some tame.
305	In this island there is also Achilles’ temple and his statue".
305	Ruins of a square temple 30 meters to a side, possibly that dedicated to Achilles, were discovered by Captain Kritzikly in 1823, but there has been no modern archeological work done on the island.
305	Pomponius Mela tells that Achilles is buried in the island named Achillea, between Boristhene and Ister.
305	The Greek geographer Dionysius Periegetus of Bithynia, who lived at the time of Domitian, writes that the island was called Leuce "because the wild animals which live there are white.
305	It is said that there, in Leuce island, reside the souls of Achilles and other heroes, and that they wander through the uninhabited valleys of this island; this is how Jove rewarded the men who had distinguished themselves through their virtues, because through virtue they had acquired everlasting honor".
305	The Periplus of the Euxine Sea gives the following details: "It is said that the goddess Thetis raised this island from the sea, for her son Achilles, who dwells there.
305	Here is his temple and his statue, an archaic work.
305	This island is not inhabited, and goats graze on it, not many, which the people who happen to arrive here with their ships, sacrifice to Achilles.
305	In this temple are also deposited a great many holy gifts, craters, rings and precious stones, offered to Achilles in gratitude.
305	One can still read inscriptions in Greek and Latin, in which Achilles is praised and celebrated.
305	Some of these are worded in Patroclus’ honor, because those who wish to be favored by Achilles, honor Patroclus at the same time.
305	There are also in this island countless numbers of sea birds, which look after Achilles’ temple.
305	Every morning they fly out to sea, wet their wings with water, and return quickly to the temple and sprinkle it.
305	And after they finish the sprinkling, they clean the hearth of the temple with their wings.
305	Other people say still more, that some of the men who reach this island, come here intentionally.
305	They bring animals in their ships, destined to be sacrificed.
305	Some of these animals they slaughter, others they set free on the island, in Achilles’ honor.
305	But there are others, who are forced to come to this island by sea storms.
305	As they have no sacrificial animals, but wish to get them from the god of the island himself, they consult Achilles’ oracle.
305	They ask permission to slaughter the victims chosen from among the animals that graze freely on the island, and to deposit in exchange the price which they consider fair.
305	But in case the oracle denies them permission, because there is an oracle here, they add something to the price offered, and if the oracle refuses again, they add something more, until at last, the oracle agrees that the price is sufficient.
305	And then the victim doesn’t run away any more, but waits willingly to be caught.
305	So, there is a great quantity of silver there, consecrated to the hero, as price for the sacrificial victims.
305	To some of the people who come to this island, Achilles appears in dreams, to others he would appear even during their navigation, if they were not too far away, and would instruct them as to which part of the island they would better anchor their ships".
305	Densuşianu) The heroic cult of Achilles on Leuce island was widespread in antiquity, not only along the sea lanes of the Pontic Sea but also in maritime cities whose economic interests were tightly connected to the riches of the Black Sea.
305	Achilles from Leuce island was venerated as Pontarches the lord and master of the Pontic Sea, the protector of sailors and navigation.
305	Sailors went out of their way to offer sacrifice.
305	To Achilles of Leuce  were dedicated a number of important commercial port cities of the Greek waters: Achilleion in Messenia (Stephanus Byzantinus), Achilleios in Laconia (Pausanias, III.25,4) Nicolae Densuşianu (Densuşianu 1913) even though he recognized Achilles in the name of Aquileia and in the north arm of the Danube delta, the arm of Chilia ("Achileii"), though his conclusion, that Leuce had sovereign rights over Pontos, evokes modern rather than archaic sea-law."
305	Leuce had also a reputation as a place of healing.
305	Pausanias (III.19,13) reports that the Delphic Pythia sent a lord of Croton to be cured of a chest wound.
305	Ammianus Marcellinus (XXII.8) attributes the healing to waters (aquae) on the island.
305	Worship of Achilles in modern times: The Achilleion in Corfu  In the region of Gastouri (Γαστούρι) to the south of the city of Corfu Greece, Empress of Austria Elisabeth of Bavaria also known as Sissi built in 1890 a summer palace with Achilles as its central theme and it is a monument to platonic romanticism.
305	The palace, naturally, was named after Achilles: Achilleion (Αχίλλειον).
305	This elegant structure abounds with paintings and statues of Achilles both in the main hall and in the lavish gardens depicting the heroic and tragic scenes of the Trojan war.
305	Other stories  Some post-Homeric sources claim that in order to keep Achilles safe from the war, Thetis (or, in some versions, Peleus) hides the young man at the court of Lycomedes, king of Skyros.
305	There, Achilles is disguised as a girl and lives among Lycomedes' daughters, perhaps under the name "Pyrrha" (the red-haired girl).
305	With Lycomedes' daughter Deidamia, whom in the account of Statius he rapes, Achilles there fathers a son, Neoptolemus (also called Pyrrhus, after his father's possible alias).
305	According to this story, Odysseus learns from the prophet Calchas that the Achaeans would be unable to capture Troy without Achilles' aid.
305	Odysseus goes to Skyros in the guise of a peddler selling women's clothes and jewelry and places a shield and spear among his goods.
305	When Achilles instantly takes up the spear, Odysseus sees through his disguise and convinces him to join the Greek campaign.
305	In another version of the story, Odysseus arranges for a trumpet alarm to be sounded while he was with Lycomedes' women; while the women flee in panic, Achilles prepares to defend the court, thus giving his identity away.
305	In book 11 of Homer's Odyssey, Odysseus sails to the underworld and converses with the shades.
305	One of these is Achilles, who when greeted as "blessed in life, blessed in death", responds that he would rather be a slave to the worst of masters than be king of all the dead.
305	But Achsponds that he would rather be a slave to the worst oilles then asks Odysseus of his son's exploits in the Trojan war, and when Odysseus tells of Neoptolemus' heroic actions, Achilles is filled with satisfaction.
305	This leaves the reader with an ambiguous understanding of how Achilles felt about the heroic life.
305	Achilles was worshipped as a sea-god in many of the Greek colonies on the Black Sea, the location of the mythical "White Island" which he was said to inhabit after his death, together with many other heroes.
305	The kings of the Epirus claimed to be descended from Achilles through his son, Neoptolemus.
305	Alexander the Great, son of the Epirote princess Olympias, could therefore also claim this descent, and in many ways strove to be like his great ancestor.
305	He is said to have visited the tomb of Achilles at Achilleion while passing Troy.
305	In AD 216 the Roman Emperor Caracalla, while on his way to war against Parthia, emulated Alexander by holding games around Achilles' tumulus.
305	Achilles fought and killed the Amazon Helene.
305	Some also said he married Medea, and that after both their deaths they were united in the Elysian Fields of Hades – as Hera promised Thetis in Apollonius' Argonautica.
305	In some versions of the myth, Achilles has a relationship with his captive Briseis.
305	Achilles in Greek tragedy  The Greek tragedian Aeschylus wrote a trilogy of plays about Achilles, given the title Achilleis by modern scholars.
305	The tragedies relate the deeds of Achilles during the Trojan War, including his defeat of Hector and eventual death when an arrow shot by Paris and guided by Apollo punctures his heel.
305	Extant fragments of the Achilleis and other Aeschylean fragments have been assembled to produce a workable modern play.
305	The first part of the Achilleis trilogy, The Myrmidons, focused on the relationship between Achilles and chorus, who represent the Achaean army and try to convince Achilles to give up his quarrel with Agamemnon; only a few lines survive today.
305	In Plato's Symposium, Phaedrus points out that Aeschylus portrayed Achilles as the lover and Patroclus as the beloved; Phaedrus argues that this is incorrect because Achilles, being the younger and more beautiful of the two, was the beloved, who loved his lover so much that he chose to die to revenge him.
305	The tragedian Sophocles also wrote The Lovers of Achilles, a play with Achilles as the main character.
305	Only a few fragments survive.
305	Achilles in Greek philosophy  The philosopher Zeno of Elea centered one of his paradoxes on an imaginary footrace between "swift-footed" Achilles and a tortoise, by which he attempted to show that Achilles could not catch up to a tortoise with a head start, and therefore that motion and change were impossible.
305	As a student of the monist Parmenides and a member of the Eleatic school, Zeno believed time and motion to be illusions.
305	Achilles in later art  *Achilles is portrayed as a former hero who has become lazy and devoted to the love of Patroclus, in William Shakespeare's Troilus and Cressida.
305	Achilles appears in Dante's Inferno.
305	Achilles is one of the beings who empower DC Comics hero Captain Marvel, giving him courage and later invulnerability.
305	Achilles is a central character in David Malouf's novel Ransom (2009).
305	Achilles is a major character in P.
305	C.
305	Cast's sixth Goddess Summoning novel Warrior Rising.
305	The novel centers on his relationship with Polyxena.
305	Achilles is a major character in Madeline Miller's debut novel, The Song of Achilles (2011), which won the 2012 Orange Prize for Fiction.
305	The novel explores the relationship between Patroclus and Achilles from boyhood to the fateful events of the Iliad.
305	In the animated television series Class of the Titans, one of the seven heroes, Archie, is descended from Achilles and has inherited both his vulnerable heel and part of his invincibility.
305	"Achilles in the Trench" is a famous poem by Patrick Shaw-Stewart.
305	"The Shield of Achilles" is a notable work of W.H.
305	Auden.
305	Achilles is central and playable character in KOEI's Warriors: Legends of Troy.
305	The role of Achilles has been played in film by: * Piero Lulli in Ulysses (1955) * Stanley Baker in Helen of Troy (1956) * Riley Ottenhof in Something about Zeus (1958) * Arturo Dominici in La Guerra di Troia (1962) * Gordon Mitchell in The Fury of Achilles (1962) * Derek Jacobi [voice] in Achilles (Channel Four Television) by Barry Purves (1995) * Steve Davislim in La Belle Hélène (TV, 1996) * Richard Trewett in the miniseries The Odyssey (TV, 1997) * Joe Montana in Helen of Troy (TV, 2003) * Brad Pitt in Troy (2004) Achilles has frequently been mentioned in music: * Achilles is a hardcore band.
305	"Achilles" is an oratorio by German composer Max Bruch (1885).
305	"Achilles, Agony & Ecstasy In Eight Parts", by Manowar (The Triumph of Steel, 1992).
305	Achilles Heel is an album by Pedro the Lion.
305	"Achilles Last Stand", by Led Zeppelin (Presence, 1976).
305	"Achilles' Revenge" is a song by Warlord.
305	"Achilles' Wrath" is a concert piece by Sean O'Loughlin.
305	Achilles is referred to in Bob Dylan's song "Temporary Like Achilles".
305	Namesakes  * The name of Achilles has been used for at least nine Royal Navy warships since 1744.
305	A 60-gun ship of that name served at the Battle of Belleisle in 1761 while a 74-gun ship served at the Battle of Trafalgar.
305	Other battle honours include Walcheren 1809.
305	An armored cruiser of that name served in the Royal Navy during the First World War and was scrapped in 1921.
305	HMNZS Achilles was a Leander class cruiser which served with the Royal New Zealand Navy in World War II.
305	It became famous for its part in the Battle of the River Plate, alongside  and .
305	In addition to earning the battle honour 'River Plate', HMNZS Achilles also served at Guadalcanal 1942–43 and Okinawa in 1945.
305	The ship was sold to the Indian Navy in 1948 but when she was scrapped parts of the ship were saved and preserved in New Zealand.
305	Capois La Mort, a slave who fought in the Haitian Revolution, was nicknamed the Black Achilles because of his heroic performance during the last battle against the French.
305	Prince Achileas-Andreas of Greece and Denmark, the grandson of the deposed Greek king, Constantine II.
305	The character Achilles in Ender's Shadow, by Orson Scott Card.
305	Achilles shares his namesake's cunning mind and ruthless attitude.
305	In the Star Trek univett Card.
305	Achilles shares rse, the Achilles Class is an advanced type of Federation battleship brought into service at the outbreak of the Dominion War, though not seen in any of the canon Star Trek TV series.
305	Achilles armor and valour is included in Titan Quest and TQ Immortal Throne.
305	Achilles is the name of the main character's mentor in the game Assassin's Creed III Notes
307	Abraham Lincoln (February 12, 1809 – April 15, 1865) was the 16th President of the United States, serving from March 1861 until his assassination in April 1865.
307	Lincoln led the United States through its greatest constitutional, military, and moral crises—the American Civil War—preserving the Union, abolishing slavery, strengthening the national government and modernizing the economy.
307	Reared in a poor family on the western frontier, Lincoln was self-educated, and became a country lawyer, a Whig Party leader, Illinois state legislator during the 1830s, and a one-term member of the United States House of Representatives during the 1840s.
307	After a series of debates in 1858 that gave national visibility to his opposition to the expansion of slavery, Lincoln lost a Senate race to his arch-rival, Stephen A.
307	Douglas.
307	Lincoln, a moderate from a swing state, secured the Republican Party presidential nomination in 1860.
307	With almost no support in the South, Lincoln swept the North and was North and was United Spresident in 1860.
307	His election was the signal for seven southern slave states to declare their secession from the Union and form the Confederacy.
307	The departure of the Southerners gave Lincoln's party firm control of Congress, but no formula for compromise or reconciliation was found.
307	Lincoln explained in his second inaugural address: "Both parties deprecated war, but one of them would make war rather than let the Nation survive, and the other would accept war rather than let it perish, and the war came."
307	When the North enthusiastically rallied behind the national flag after the Confederate attack on Fort Sumter on April 12, 1861, Lincoln concentrated on the military and political dimensions of the war effort.
307	His goal was now to reunite the nation.
307	As the South was in a state of insurrection, Lincoln exercised his authority to suspend habeas corpus, arresting and temporarily detaining thousands of suspected secessionists without trial.
307	Lincoln averted British recognition of the Confederacy by skillfully handling the Trent affair in late 1861.
307	His efforts toward the abolition of slavery include issuing his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, encouraging the border states to outlaw slavery, and helping push through Congress the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which finally freed all the slaves nationwide in December 1865.
307	Lincoln closely supervised the war effort, especially the selection of top generals, including commanding general Ulysses S.
307	Grant.
307	Lincoln brought leaders of the major factions of his party into his cabinet and pressured them to cooperate.
307	Under Lincoln's leadership, the Union set up a naval blockade that shut down the South's normal trade, took control of the border slave states at the start of the war, gained control of communications with gunboats on the southern river systems, and tried repeatedly to capture the Confederate capital at Richmond, Virginia.
307	Each time a general failed, Lincoln substituted another until finally Grant succeeded in 1865.
307	An exceptionally astute politician deeply involved with power issues in each state, Lincoln reached out to War Democrats and managed his own re-election in the 1864 presidential election.
307	As the leader of the moderate faction of the Republican party, Lincoln found his policies and personality were "blasted from all sides": Radical Republicans demanded harsher treatment of the South, War Democrats desired more compromise, Copperheads despised him, and irreconcilable secessionists plotted his death.
307	Politically, Lincoln fought back with patronage, by pitting his opponents against each other, and by appealing to the American people with his powers of oratory.
307	His Gettysburg Address of 1863 became the most quoted speech in American history.
307	It was an iconic statement of America's dedication to the principles of nationalism, republicanism, equal rights, liberty, and democracy.
307	At the close of the war, Lincoln held a moderate view of Reconstruction, seeking to reunite the nation speedily through a policy of generous reconciliation in the face of lingering and bitter divisiveness.
307	Six days after the surrender of Confederate commanding general Robert E.
307	Lee, however, Lincoln was assassinated by actor and Confederate sympathizer John Wilkes Booth.
307	Lincoln's death was the first assassination of a U.S.
307	Lincoln has been consistently ranked by scholars and the public as one of the three greatest U.S.
307	George Washington and Franklin D.
307	Roosevelt, and by the public, Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton.
307	Family and childhood Early life Abraham Lincoln was born February 12, 1809, the second child of Thomas Lincoln and Nancy Lincoln (née Hanks), in a one-room log cabin on the Sinking Spring Farm in Hardin County, Kentucky (now LaRue County).
307	He is descended from Samuel Lincoln, who arrived in Hingham, Massachusetts, from Norfolk, England, in the 17th century.
307	Lincoln's paternal grandfather and namesake, Abraham, had moved his family from Virginia to Kentucky, where he was ambushed and killed in an Indian raid in 1786, with his children, including Lincoln's father Thomas, looking on.
307	Thomas was left to make his own way on the frontier.
307	Lincoln's mother, Nancy, was the daughter of Lucy Hanks, and was born in what is now Mineral County, West Virginia, then part of Virginia.
307	Lucy moved with Nancy to Kentucky.
307	Nancy Hanks married Thomas, who became a respected citizen.
307	He bought and sold several farms, including Knob Creek Farm.
307	The family attended a Separate Baptists church, which had restrictive moral standards and opposed alcohol, dancing, and slavery.
307	Thomas enjoyed considerable status in Kentucky—where he sat on juries, appraised estates, served on country slave patrols, and guarded prisoners.
307	By the time his son Abraham was born, Thomas owned two 600 acre farms, several town lots, livestock, and horses.
307	He was among the richest men in the county.
307	However, in 1816, Thomas lost all of his land in court cases because of faulty property titles.
307	The family moved north across the Ohio River to free (i.e., non-slave) territory and made a new start in what was then Perry County but is now Spencer County, Indiana.
307	Lincoln later noted that this move was "partly on account of slavery" but mainly due to land title difficulties.
307	In Indiana, when Lincoln was nine, his mother Nancy died of milk sickness in 1818.
307	After the death of Lincoln's mother, his older sister, Sarah, took charge of caring for him until their father remarried in 1819; Sarah later died in her 20s while giving birth to a stillborn son.
307	Thomas Lincoln's new wife was the widow Sarah Bush Johnston, the mother of three children.
307	Lincoln became very close to his stepmother, and referred to her as "Mother".
307	As a pre-teen, he did not like the hard labor associated with frontier life.
307	Some in his family, and in the neighborh did not like the harood, for a time considered him to be lazy.
307	As he grew into his teens, he willingly took responsibility for all chores expected of him as one of the boys in the household and became an adept axeman in his work building rail fences.
307	He attained a reputation for brawn and audacity after a very competitive wrestling match to which he was challenged by the renowned leader of a group of ruffians, "the Clary's Grove boys".
307	Lincoln also agreed with the customary obligation of a son to give his father all earnings from work done outside the home until age 21.
307	In later years, Lincoln occasionally loaned his father money.
307	Lincoln became increasingly distant from his father, in part because of his father's lack of education.
307	While young Lincoln's formal education consisted approximately of a year's worth of classes from several itinerant teachers, he was mostly self-educated and was an avid reader and often sought access to any new books in the village.
307	He read and reread the King James Bible, Aesop's Fables, Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress, Defoe's Robinson Crusoe, and Franklin's Autobiography.
307	In 1830, fearing a milk sickness outbreak along the Ohio River, the Lincoln family moved west, where they settled on public land in Macon County, Illinois, another free, non-slave state.
307	In 1831, Thomas relocated the family to a new homestead in Coles County, Illinois.
307	It was then that, as an ambitious 22-year-old who was now old enough to make his own decisions, Lincoln struck out on his own.
307	Canoeing down the Sangamon River, Lincoln ended up in the village of New Salem in Sangamon County.
307	In the spring of 1831, hired by New Salem businessman Denton Offutt and accompanied by friends, he took goods by flatboat from New Salem to New Orleans via the Sangamon, Illinois, and Mississippi rivers.
307	After arriving in New Orleans—and witnessing slavery firsthand—he walked back home.
307	Marriage and children Lincoln's first romantic interest was Ann Rutledge, whom he met when he first moved to New Salem; by 1835, they were in a relationship but not formally engaged.
307	She died at the age of 22 on August 25, 1835, most likely of typhoid fever.
307	In the early 1830s, he met Mary Owens from Kentucky when she was visiting her sister.
307	Late in 1836, Lincoln agreed to a match with Mary if she returned to New Salem.
307	Mary did return in November 1836, and Lincoln courted her for a time; however, they both had second thoughts about their relationship.
307	On August 16, 1837, Lincoln wrote Mary a letter suggesting he would not blame her if she ended the relationship.
307	She never replied and the courtship ended.
307	In 1840, Lincoln became engaged to Mary Todd, who was from a wealthy slave-holding family in Lexington, Kentucky.
307	They met in Springfield, Illinois, in December 1839 and were engaged the following December.
307	A wedding set for January 1, 1841, was canceled when the two broke off their engagement at Lincoln's initiative.
307	They later met again at a party and married on November 4, 1842, in the Springfield mansion of Mary's married sister.
307	While preparing for the nuptials and feeling anxiety again, Lincoln, when asked where he was going, replied, "To hell, I suppose."
307	In 1844, the couple bought a house in Springfield near Lincoln's law office.
307	Mary Todd Lincoln kept house, often with the help of a relative or hired servant girl.
307	Robert Todd Lincoln was born in 1843 and Edward Baker Lincoln (Eddie) in 1846.
307	Lincoln "was remarkably fond of children", and the Lincolns were not considered to be strict with their children.
307	Edward died on February 1, 1850, in Springfield, probably of tuberculosis.
307	"Willie" Lincoln was born on December 21, 1850, and died on February 20, 1862.
307	The Lincolns' fourth son, Thomas "Tad" Lincoln, was born on April 4, 1853, and died of heart failure at the age of 18 on July 16, 1871.
307	Robert was the only child to live to adulthood and have children.
307	His last descendant, grandson Robert Todd Lincoln Beckwith, died in 1985.
307	The deaths of their sons had profound effects on both parents.
307	Later in life, Mary struggled with the stresses of losing her husband and sons, and Robert Lincoln committed her temporarily to a mental health asylum in 1875.
307	Abraham Lincoln suffered from "melancholy", a condition which now is referred to as clinical depression.
307	Lincoln's father-in-law was based in Lexington, Kentucky; he and others of the Todd family were either slave owners or slave traders.
307	Lincoln was close to the Todds, and he and his family occasionally visited the Todd estate in Lexington.
307	He was an affectionate, though often absent, husband and father of four children.
307	Early career and militia service In 1832, at age 23, Lincoln and a partner bought a small general store on credit in New Salem, Illinois.
307	Although the economy was booming in the region, the business struggled and Lincoln eventually sold his share.
307	That March he began his political career with his first campaign for the Illinois General Assare.
307	That March he began his politicalembly.
307	He had attained local popularity and could draw crowds as a natural raconteur in New Salem, though he lacked an education, powerful friends, and money, which may be why he lost.
307	He advocated navigational improvements on the Sangamon River.
307	Before the election, Lincoln served as a captain in the Illinois Militia during the Black Hawk War.
307	Following his return, Lincoln continued his campaign for the August 6 election for the Illinois General Assembly.
307	At 6 ft, he was tall and "strong enough to intimidate any rival".
307	At his first speech, when he saw a supporter in the crowd being attacked, Lincoln grabbed the assailant by his "neck and the seat of his trousers" and threw him.
307	Lincoln finished eighth out of 13 candidates (the top four were elected), though he received 277 of the 300 votes cast in the New Salem precinct.
307	Lincoln served as New Salem's postmaster and later as county surveyor, all the while reading voraciously.
307	He then decided to become a lawyer and began teaching himself law by reading Blackstone's Commentaries on the Laws of England and other law books.
307	Of his learning method, Lincoln stated: "I studied with nobody".
307	His second campaign in 1834 was successful.
307	He won election to the state legislature; though he ran as a Whig, many Democrats favored him over a more powerful Whig opponent.
307	Admitted to the bar in 1836, he moved to Springfield, Illinois, and began to practice law under John T.
307	Stuart, Mary Todd's cousin.
307	Lincoln became an able and successful lawyer with a reputation as a formidable adversary during cross-examinations and closing arguments.
307	He partnered with Stephen T.
307	Logan from 1841 until 1844, when he began his practice with William Herndon, whom Lincoln thought "a studious young man".
307	He served four successive terms in the Illinois House of Representatives as a Whig representative from Sangamon County.
307	In the 1835–36 legislative session, he voted to expand suffrage to white males, whether landowners or not.
307	He was known for his "free soil" stance of opposing both slavery and abolitionism.
307	He first articulated this in 1837, saying, "[The] Institution of slavery is founded on both injustice and bad policy, but the promulgation of abolition doctrines tends rather to increase than abate its evils."
307	He closely followed Henry Clay in supporting the American Colonization Society program of making the abolition of slavery practical by helping the freed slaves to settle in Liberia in Africa.
307	Congressman Lincoln From the early 1830s, Lincoln was a steadfast Whig and professed to friends in 1861 to be, "an old line Whig, a disciple of Henry Clay".
307	The party, including Lincoln, favored economic modernization in banking, protective tariffs to fund internal improvements including railroads, and espoused urbanization as well.
307	In 1846, Lincoln was elected to the U.S.
307	House of Representatives, where he served one two-year term.
307	He was the only Whig in the Illinois delegation, but he showed his party loyalty by participating in almost all votes and making speeches that echoed the party line.
307	Lincoln, in collaboration with abolitionist Congressman Joshua R.
307	Giddings, wrote a bill to abolish slavery in the District of Columbia with compensation for the owners, enforcement to capture fugitive slaves, and a popular vote on the matter.
307	He abandoned the bill when it failed to garner sufficient Whig supporters.
307	On foreign and military policy, Lincoln spoke out against the Mexican–American War, which he attributed to President Polk's desire for "military glory—that attractive rainbow, that rises in showers of blood".
307	Lincoln also supported the Wilmot Proviso, which, if it had been adopted, would have banned slavery in any U.S.
307	Mexico.
307	Lincoln emphasized his opposition to Polk by drafting and introducing his Spot Resolutions.
307	The war had begun with a Mexican slaughter of American soldiers in territory disputed by Mexico and the U.S.; Polk insisted that Mexican soldiers had "invaded our territory and shed the blood of our fellow-citizens on our own soil".
307	Lincoln demanded that Polk show Congress the exact spot on which blood had been shed and prove that the spot was on American soil.
307	Congress never enacted the resolution or even debated it, the national papers ignored it, and it resulted in a loss of political support for Lincoln in his district.
307	One Illinois newspaper derisively nicknamed him "spotty Lincoln".
307	Lincoln later regretted some of his statements, especially his attack on the presidential war-making powers.
307	Realizing Clay was unlikely to win the presidency, Lincoln, who had pledged in 1846 to serve only one term in the House, supported General Zachary Taylor for the Whig nomination in the 1848 presidential election.
307	Taylor won and Lincoln hoped to be appointed Commissioner of the General Land Office, but that lucrative patronage job went to an Illinois rival, Justin Butterfield, considered by the administration to be a highly skilled lawyer, but in Lincoln's view, an "old fossil".
307	The administration offered him the consolation prize of secretary or governor of the Oregon Territory.
307	This distant territory was a Democratic stronghold, and acceptance of the post would have effectively ended his legal and political career in Illinois, so he declined and resumed his law practice.
307	Prairie lawyer Lincoln returned to practicing law in Springfield, handling "every kind of business that could come before a prairie lawyer".
307	Twice a year for 16 years, 10 weeks at a time, he appeared in county seats in the midstate regf> Twice a year for 16 years, 10 weeks ion when the county courts were in session.
307	Lincoln handled many transportation cases in the midst of the nation's western expansion, particularly the conflicts arising from the operation of river barges under the many new railroad bridges.
307	As a riverboat man, Lincoln initially favored those interests, but ultimately represented whoever hired him.
307	His reputation grew, and he appeared before the Supreme Court of the United States, arguing a case involving a canal boat that sank after hitting a bridge.
307	In 1849, he received a patent for a flotation device for the movement of boats in shallow water.
307	The idea was never commercialized, but Lincoln is the only president to hold a patent.
307	In 1851, he represented the Alton & Sangamon Railroad in a dispute with one of its shareholders, James A.
307	Barret, who had refused to pay the balance on his pledge to buy shares in the railroad on the grounds that the company had changed its original train route.
307	Lincoln successfully argued that the railroad company was not bound by its original charter in existence at the time of Barret's pledge; the charter was amended in the public interest to provide a newer, superior, and less expensive route, and the corporation retained the right to demand Barret's payment.
307	The decision by the Illinois Supreme Court has been cited by numerous other courts in the nation.
307	Lincoln appeared before the Illinois Supreme Court in 175 cases, in 51 as sole counsel, of which 31 were decided in his favor.
307	From 1853 to 1860, another of Lincoln's largest clients was the Illinois Central Railroad.
307	Lincoln's most notable criminal trial occurred in 1858 when he defended William "Duff" Armstrong, who was on trial for the murder of James Preston Metzker.
307	The case is famous for Lincoln's use of a fact established by judicial notice in order to challenge the credibility of an eyewitness.
307	After an opposing witness testified seeing the crime in the moonlight, Lincoln produced a Farmers' Almanac showing the moon was at a low angle, drastically reducing visibility.
307	Based on this evidence, Armstrong was acquitted.
307	Lincoln rarely raised objections in the courtroom; but in an 1859 case, where he defended a cousin, Peachy Harrison, who was accused of stabbing another to death, Lincoln angrily protested the judge's decision to exclude evidence favorable to his client.
307	Instead of holding Lincoln in contempt of court as was expected, the judge, a Democrat, reversed his ruling, allowing the evidence and acquitting Harrison.
307	Republican politics 1854–60 Slavery and a "House Divided" By the 1850s, slavery was still legal in the southern United States, but had been generally outlawed in the northern states, such as Illinois.
307	Lincoln disapproved of slavery, and the spread of slavery to new U.S.
307	He returned to politics to oppose the pro-slavery Kansas–Nebraska Act (1854); this law repealed the slavery-restricting Missouri Compromise (1820).
307	Senior Senator Stephen A.
307	Douglas of Illinois had incorporated popular sovereignty into the Act.
307	Douglas' provision, which Lincoln opposed, specified settlers had the right to determine locally whether to allow slavery in new U.S.
307	Congress.
307	Eric Foner (2010) contrasts the abolitionists and anti-slavery Radical Republicans of the Northeast who saw slavery as a sin, with the conservative Republicans who thought it was bad because it hurt white people and blocked progress.
307	Foner argues that Lincoln was a moderate in the middle, opposing slavery primarily because it violated the republicanism principles of the Founding Fathers, especially the equality of all men and democratic self-government as expressed in the Declaration of Independence.
307	On October 16, 1854, in his "Peoria Speech", Lincoln declared his opposition to slavery, which he repeated en route to the presidency.
307	Speaking in his Kentucky accent, with a very powerful voice, he said the Kansas Act had a "declared indifference, but as I must think, a covert real zeal for the spread of slavery.
307	I cannot but hate it.
307	I hate it because of the monstrous injustice of slavery itself.
307	I hate it because it deprives our republican example of its just influence in the world ..."
307	In late 1854, Lincoln ran as a Whig for the U.S.
307	Senate seat from Illinois.
307	At that time, senators were elected by the state legislature.
307	After leading in the first six rounds of voting in the Illinois assembly, his support began to dwindle, and Lincoln instructed his backers to vote for Lyman Trumbull, who defeated opponent Joel Aldrich Matteson.
307	The Whigs had been irreparably split by the Kansas–Nebraska Act.
307	Lincoln wrote, "I think I am a Whig, but others say there are no Whigs, and that I am an abolitionist, even though I do no more than oppose the extension of slavery."
307	Drawing on remna.co.uk |date= 2010-03-05|accessdatnts of the old Whig party, and on disenchanted Free Soil, Liberty, and Democratic Party members, he was instrumental in forging the shape of the new Republican Party.
307	At the 1856 Republican National Convention, Lincoln placed second in the contest to become the party's candidate for vice president.
307	In 1857–1858, Douglas broke with President James Buchanan, leading to a fight for control of the Democratic Party.
307	Some eastern Republicans even favored the reelection of Douglas for the Senate in 1858, since he had led the opposition to the Lecompton Constitution, which would have admitted Kansas as a slave state.
307	In March 1857, the Supreme Court issued its decision in Dred Scott v.
307	Sandford; Chief Justice Roger B.
307	Taney opined that blacks were not citizens, and derived no rights from the Constitution.
307	Lincoln denounced the decision, alleging it was the product of a conspiracy of Democrats to support the Slave Power.
307	Lincoln argued, "The authors of the Declaration of Independence never intended 'to say all were equal in color, size, intellect, moral developments, or social capacity', but they 'did consider all men created equal—equal in certain inalienable rights, among which are life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness'."
307	After the state Republican party convention nominated him for the U.S.
307	Senate in 1858, Lincoln delivered his House Divided Speech, drawing on : "A house divided against itself cannot stand.
307	I believe this government cannot endure permanently half slave and half free.
307	I do not expect the Union to be dissolved—I do not expect the house to fall—but I do expect it will cease to be divided.
307	It will become all one thing, or all the other."
307	The speech created an evocative image of the danger of disunion caused by the slavery debate, and rallied Republicans across the North.
307	The stage was then set for the campaign for statewide election of the Illinois legislature which would, in turn, select Lincoln or Douglas as its U.S.
307	Lincoln–Douglas debates and Cooper Union speech The Senate campaign featured the seven Lincoln–Douglas debates of 1858, the most famous political debates in American history.
307	The principals stood in stark contrast both physically and politically.
307	Lincoln warned that "The Slave Power" was threatening the values of republicanism, and accused Douglas of distorting the values of the Founding Fathers that all men are created equal, while Douglas emphasized his Freeport Doctrine, that local settlers were free to choose whether to allow slavery or not, and accused Lincoln of having joined the abolitionists.
307	The debates had an atmosphere of a prize fight and drew crowds in the thousands.
307	Lincoln stated Douglas' popular sovereignty theory was a threat to the nation's morality and that Douglas represented a conspiracy to extend slavery to free states.
307	Douglas said that Lincoln was defying the authority of the U.S.
307	Supreme Court and the Dred Scott decision.
307	Though the Republican legislative candidates won more popular votes, the Democrats won more seats, and the legislature re-elected Douglas to the Senate.
307	Despite the bitterness of the defeat for Lincoln, his articulation of the issues gave him a national political reputation.
307	In May 1859, Lincoln purchased the Illinois Staats-Anzeiger, a German-language newspaper which was consistently supportive; most of the state's 130,000 German Americans voted Democratic but there was Republican support that a German-language paper could mobilize.
307	On February 27, 1860, New York party leaders invited Lincoln to give a speech at Cooper Union to a group of powerful Republicans.
307	Lincoln argued that the Founding Fathers had little use for popular sovereignty and had repeatedly sought to restrict slavery.
307	Lincoln insisted the moral foundation of the Republicans required opposition to slavery, and rejected any "groping for some middle ground between the right and the wrong".
307	Despite his inelegant appearance—many in the audience thought him awkward and even ugly—Lincoln demonstrated an intellectual leadership that brought him into the front ranks of the party and into contention for the Republican presidential nomination.
307	Journalist Noah Brooks reported, "No man ever before made such an impression on his first appeal to a New York audience."
307	Historian Donald described the speech as a "superb political move for an unannounced candidate, to appear in one rival's (William H.
307	Seward) own state at an event sponsored by the second rival's (Salmon P.
307	Chase) loyalists, while not mentioning either by name during its delivery."
307	In response to an inquiry about his presidential intentions, Lincoln said, "The taste is in my mouth a little."
307	Presidential nomination and campaign On May 9–10, 1860, the Illinois Republican State Convention was held in Decatur.
307	Lincoln's followers organized a campaign team led by David Davis, Norman Judd, Leonard Swett, and Jesse DuBois, and Lincoln received his first endorsement to run for the presidency.
307	Exploiting the embellished legend of his frontier days with his father, Lincoln's supporters adopted the label of "The Rail Candidate".
307	On May 18, at the Republican National Convention in Chicago, Lincoln's friends promised and manipulated and won the nomination on the third ballot, beating candidates such as William H.
307	Seward and Salmon P.
307	Chase.
307	A former Democrat, Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, was nominated for Vice President to balance the ticket.
307	Lincoln's success depended on his reputation as a moderate on the slavery issue, and his strong support for Whiggish programs of internal improvements and the protective tariff.
307	On the third ballot Pennsylvania put him over the top.
307	Pennsylvania iron interests were reassured by his support for protective tariffs.
307	Lincoln's managers had been adroitly focused on this delegation as well as thep.
307	Lincoln's managers had been  others, while following Lincoln's strong dictate to "Make no contracts that bind me".
307	Most Republicans agreed with Lincoln that the North was the aggrieved party, as the Slave Power tightened its grasp on the national government with the Dred Scott decision and the presidency of James Buchanan.
307	Throughout the 1850s, Lincoln doubted the prospects of civil war, and his supporters rejected claims that his election would incite secession.
307	Meanwhile, Douglas was selected as the candidate of the Northern Democrats.
307	Delegates from 11 slave states walked out of the Democratic convention, disagreeing with Douglas' position on popular sovereignty, and ultimately selected John C.
307	Breckinridge as their candidate.
307	As Douglas and the other candidates went through with their campaigns, Lincoln was the only one of them who gave no speeches.
307	Instead, he monitored the campaign closely and relied on the enthusiasm of the Republican Party.
307	The party did the leg work that produced majorities across the North, and produced an abundance of campaign posters, leaflets, and newspaper editorials.
307	There were thousands of Republican speakers who focused first on the party platform, and second on Lincoln's life story, emphasizing his childhood poverty.
307	The goal was to demonstrate the superior power of "free labor", whereby a common farm boy could work his way to the top by his own efforts.
307	The Republican Party's production of campaign literature dwarfed the combined opposition; a Chicago Tribune writer produced a pamphlet that detailed Lincoln's life, and sold 100,000 to 200,000 copies.
307	Presidency 1860 election and secession On November 6, 1860, Lincoln was elected the 16th president of the United States, beating Democrat Stephen A.
307	Douglas, John C.
307	Breckinridge of the Southern Democrats, and John Bell of the new Constitutional Union Party.
307	He was the first president from the Republican Party.
307	Winning entirely on the strength of his support in the North and West, no ballots were cast for him in 10 of the 15 Southern slave states, and he won only two of 996 counties in all the Southern states.
307	Lincoln received 1,866,452 votes, Douglas 1,376,957 votes, Breckinridge 849,781 votes, and Bell 588,789 votes.
307	Turnout was 82.2 percent, with Lincoln winning the free Northern states, as well as California and Oregon.
307	Douglas won Missouri, and split New Jersey with Lincoln.
307	Bell won Virginia, Tennessee, and Kentucky, and Breckinridge won the rest of the South.
307	Although Lincoln won only a plurality of the popular vote, his victory in the electoral college was decisive: Lincoln had 180 and his opponents added together had only 123.
307	There were fusion tickets in which all of Lincoln's opponents combined to support the same slate of Electors in New York, New Jersey, and Rhode Island, but even if the anti-Lincoln vote had been combined in every state, Lincoln still would have won a majority in the Electoral College.
307	As Lincoln's election became evident, secessionists made clear their intent to leave the Union before he took office the next March.
307	On December 20, 1860, South Carolina took the lead by adopting an ordinance of secession; by February 1, 1861, Florida, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, and Texas followed.
307	Six of these states then adopted a constitution and declared themselves to be a sovereign nation, the Confederate States of America.
307	The upper South and border states (Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Kentucky, Missouri, and Arkansas) listened to, but initially rejected, the secessionist appeal.
307	President Buchanan and President-elect Lincoln refused to recognize the Confederacy, declaring secession illegal.
307	The Confederacy selected Jefferson Davis as its provisional President on February 9, 1861.
307	There were attempts at compromise.
307	The Crittenden Compromise would have extended the Missouri Compromise line of 1820, dividing the territories into slave and free, contrary to the Republican Party's free-soil platform.
307	Lincoln rejected the idea, saying, "I will suffer death before I consent ...
307	" Lincoln, however, did tacitly support the proposed Corwin Amendment to the Constitution, which passed Congress before Lincoln came into office and was then awaiting ratification by the states.
307	That proposed amendment would have protected slavery in states where it already existed and would have guaranteed that Congress would not interfere with slavery without Southern consent.
307	A few weeks before the war, Lincoln sent a letter to every governor informing them Congress had passed a joint resolution to amend the Constitution.
307	Lincoln was open to the possibility of a constitutional convention to make further amendments to the Constitution.
307	En route to his inauguration by train, Lincoln addressed crowds and legislatures across the North.
307	The president-elect then evaded possible assassins in Baltimore, who were uncovered by Lincoln's head of security, Allan Pinkerton.
307	On February 23, 1861, he arrived in disguise in Washington, D.C., which was placed under substantial military guard.
307	Lincoln directed his inaugural address to the South, proclaiming once again that he had no intention, or inclination, to abolish slavery in the Southern states: The President ended his address with an appeal to the people of the South: "We are not enemies, but friends.
307	We must not be enemies ...
307	The mystic chords of memory, stretching from every battlefield, and patriot grave, to every living heart and hearthstone, all over this broad land, will yet swell the chorus of the Union, when again touched, as surely they will be, by the better angels of our nature."
307	The failure of the Peace Conference of 1861 signaled that legislative compromise was implausible.
307	By March 1861, no leaders of the insurrection had proposed rejoining the Union on any terms.
307	Meanwhile, Lincoln and nearly every Republican leader agreed that the dismantling of the Union could not be tolerated.
307	Beginning of the war The commander of Fort Sumter, South Carolina, Major Robert Anderson, sent a request for provisions to Washington, and the execution of Lincoln's order to meet that request was seen by the secessionists as an act of war.
307	On April 12, 1861, Confederate forces fired on Union troops at Fort Sumter, forcing them to surrender, and began the war.
307	Historian Allan Nevins argued that the newly inaugurated Lincoln made three miscalculations: underestimating the gravity of the crisis, exaggerating the strength of Unionist sentiment in the South, and not realizing the Southern Unionists were insisting there be no invasion.
307	William Tecumseh Sherman talked to Lincoln during inauguration week and was "sadly disappointed" at his failure to realize that "the country was sleeping on a volcano" and that the South was preparing for war.
307	Donald concludes that, "His repeated efforts to avoid collision in the months between inauguration and the firing on Ft.
307	Sumter showed he adhered to his vow not to be the first to shed fraternal blood.
307	But he also vowed not to surrender the forts.
307	The only resolution of these contradictory positions was for the confederates to fire the first shot; they did just that."
307	On April 15, Lincoln called on all the states to send detachments totaling 75,000 troops to recapture forts, protect Washington, and "preserve the Union", which, in his view, still existed intact despite the actions of the seceding states.
307	This call forced the states to choose sides.
307	Virginia declared its secession and was rewarded with the Confederate capital, despite the exposed position of Richmond so close to Union lines.
307	North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas also voted for secession over the next two months.
307	Secession sentiment was strong in Missouri and Maryland, but did not prevail; Kentucky tried to be neutral.
307	Troops headed south towards Washington to protect the capital in response to Lincoln's call.
307	On April 19, secessionist mobs in Baltimore that controlled the rail links attacked Union troops traveling to the capital.
307	George William Brown, the Mayor of Baltimore, and other suspected Maryland politicians were arrested and imprisoned, without a warrant, as Lincoln suspended the writ of habeas corpus.
307	John Merryman, a leader in the secessionist group in Maryland, petitioned Chief Justice Roger B.
307	Taney to issue a writ of habeas corpus, saying holding Merryman without a hearing was unlawful.
307	Taney issued the writ, thereby ordering Merryman's release, but Lincoln ignored it.
307	Then and throughout the war, Lincoln came under heavy, often vituperative attack from antiwar Democrats, called Copperheads.
307	Assuming command for the Union in the war After the fall of Fort Sumter, Lincoln realized the importance of taking immediate executive control of the war and making an overall strategy to put down the rebellion.
307	Lincoln encountered an unprecedented political and military crisis, and he responded as commander-in-chief, using unprecedented powers.
307	He expanded his war powers, and imposed a blockade on all the Confederate shipping ports, disbursed funds before appropriation by Congress, and after suspending habeas corpus, arrested and imprisoned thousands of suspected Confederate sympathizers.
307	Lincoln was supported by Congress and the northern public for these actions.
307	In addition, Lincoln had to contend with reinforcing strong Union sympathies in the border slave states and keeping the war from becoming an international conflict.
307	The war effort was the source of continued disparagement of Lincoln, and dominated his time and attention.
307	From the start, it was clear that bipartisan support would be essential to success in the war effort, and any manner of compromise alienated factions on both sides of the aisle, such as the appointment of Republicans and Democrats to command positions in the Union Army.
307	Copperheads criticized Lincoln for refusing to compromise on the slavery issue.
307	Conversely, the Radical Republicans criticized him for moving too slowly in abolishing slavery.
307	On August 6, 1861, Lincoln signed the Confiscation Act that authorized judiciary proceedings to confiscate and free slaves who were used to support the Confederate war effort.
307	In practice the law had little effect, but it did signal political support for abolishing slavery in the Confederacy In late August 1861, General John C.
307	Frémont, the 1856 Republican presidential nominee, issued, without consulting Washington, a proclamation of martial law in Missouri.
307	He declared that any citizen found bearing arms could be court-martialed and shot, and that slaves of persons aiding the rebellion would be freed.
307	Frémont was already under a cloud with charges of negligence in his command of the Department of the West compounded with allegations of fraud and corruption.
307	Lincoln overruled Frémont's proclamation.
307	Lincoln believed that Fremont's emancipation was political; neither militarily necessary nor legal.
307	Union enlistments from Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri increased by over 40,000 troops.
307	The Trent Affa increased by over 40,000 troir of late 1861 threatened war with Great Britain.
307	The U.S.
307	Navy illegally intercepted a British merchant ship, the Trent, on the high seas and seized two Confederate envoys; Britain protested vehemently while the U.S.
307	Lincoln resolved the issue by releasing the two men and war was successfully averted with Britain.
307	Lincoln's foreign policy approach had been initially hands off, due to his inexperience; he left most diplomacy appointments and other foreign policy matters to his Secretary of State, William Seward.
307	Seward's initial reaction to the Trent affair, however, was too bellicose, so Lincoln also turned to Senator Charles Sumner, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and an expert in British diplomacy.
307	To learn technical military terms, Lincoln borrowed and studied Henry Halleck's book, Elements of Military Art and Science from the Library of Congress.
307	Lincoln painstakingly monitored the telegraphic reports coming into the War Department in Washington, D.C.
307	He kept close tabs on all phases of the military effort, consulted with governors, and selected generals based on their past success (as well as their state and party).
307	In January 1862, after many complaints of inefficiency and profiteering in the War Department, Lincoln replaced Simon Cameron with Edwin Stanton as War Secretary.
307	Stanton was one of many conservative Democrats (he supported Breckenridge in the 1860 election) who became anti-slavery Republicans under Lincoln's leadership.
307	In terms of war strategy, Lincoln articulated two priorities: to ensure that Washington was well-defended, and to conduct an aggressive war effort that would satisfy the demand in the North for prompt, decisive victory; major Northern newspaper editors expected victory within 90 days.
307	Twice a week, Lincoln would meet with his cabinet in the afternoon, and occasionally Mary Lincoln would force him to take a carriage ride because she was concerned he was working too hard.
307	Lincoln learned from his chief of staff General Henry Halleck, a student of the European strategist Jomini, of the critical need to control strategic points, such as the Mississippi River; he also knew well the importance of Vicksburg and understood the necessity of defeating the enemy's army, rather than simply capturing territory.
307	General McClellan After the Union defeat at the First Battle of Bull Run and the retirement of the aged Winfield Scott in late 1861, Lincoln appointed Major General George B.
307	McClellan general-in-chief of all the Union armies.
307	McClellan, a young West Point graduate, railroad executive, and Pennsylvania Democrat, took several months to plan and attempt his Peninsula Campaign, longer than Lincoln wanted.
307	The campaign's objective was to capture Richmond by moving the Army of the Potomac by boat to the peninsula and then overland to the Confederate capital.
307	McClellan's repeated delays frustrated Lincoln and Congress, as did his position that no troops were needed to defend Washington.
307	Lincoln insisted on holding some of McClellan's troops in defense of the capital; McClellan, who consistently overestimated the strength of Confederate troops, blamed this decision for the ultimate failure of the Peninsula Campaign.
307	Lincoln removed McClellan as general-in-chief and appointed Henry Wager Halleck in March 1862, after McClellan's "Harrison's Landing Letter", in which he offered unsolicited political advice to Lincoln urging caution in the war effort.
307	McClellan's letter incensed Radical Republicans, who successfully pressured Lincoln to appoint John Pope, a Republican, as head of the new Army of Virginia.
307	Pope complied with Lincoln's strategic desire to move toward Richmond from the north, thus protecting the capital from attack.
