307	However, lacking requested reinforcements from McClellan, now commanding the Army of the Potomac, Pope was soundly defeated at the Second Battle of Bull Run in the summer of 1862, forcing the Army of the Potomac to defend Washington for a second time.
307	The war also expanded with naval operations in 1862 when the CSS Virginia, formerly the USS Merrimack, damaged or destroyed three Union vessels in Norfolk, Virginia, before being engaged and damaged by the USS Monitor.
307	Lincoln closely reviewed the dispatches and interrogated naval officers during their clash in the Battle of Hampton Roads.
307	Despite his dissatisfaction with McClellan's failure to reinforce Pope, Lincoln was desperate, and restored him to command of all forces around Washington, to the dismay of all in his cabinet but Seward.
307	Two days after McClellan's return to command, General Robert E.
307	Lee's forces crossed the Potomac River into Maryland, leading to the Battle of Antietam in September 1862.
307	The ensuing Union victory was among the bloodiest in American history, but it enabled Lincoln to announce that he would issue an Emancipation Proclamation in January.
307	Having composed the Proclamation some time earlier, Lincoln had waited for a military victory to publish it to avoid it being perceived as the product of desperation.
307	McClellan then resisted the President's demand that he pursue Lee's retreating and exposed army, while his counterpart General Don Carlos Buell likewise refused orders to move the Army of the Ohio against rebel forces in eastern Tennessee.
307	As a result, Lincoln replaced Buell with William Rosecrans; and, after the 1862 midterm elections, he replaced McClellan with Republican Ambrose Burnside.
307	Both of these replacements were political moderates and prospectively more supportive of the Commander-in-Chief.
307	Burnside, against the advice of the president, prematurely launched an offensive across the Rappahannock River and was stunningly defeated by Lee at Fredericksburg in December.
307	Not only had Burnside been defeated on the battlefield, but his soldiers were disgruntled and undisciplined.
307	Desertions during 1863 were in the thousands and they increased after Fredericksburg.
307	Lincoln brought in Joseph Hooker, despite his record of loose talk about the need for a military dictatorship.
307	The mid-term elections in 1862 brought the Republicans severe losses due to sharp disfavor with the administration over its failure to deliver a speedy end to the war, as well as rising inflation, new high taxes, rumors of corruption, the suspension of habeas corpus, the military draft law, and fears that freed slaves would undermine the labor market.
307	The Emancipation Proclamation announced in September gained votes for the Repubne the labor market.
307	The Emancipatlicans in the rural areas of New England and the upper Midwest, but it lost votes in the cities and the lower Midwest.
307	While Republicans were discouraged, Democrats were energized and did especially well in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, and New York.
307	The Republicans did maintain their majorities in Congress and in the major states, except New York.
307	The Cincinnati Gazette contended that the voters were "depressed by the interminable nature of this war, as so far conducted, and by the rapid exhaustion of the national resources without progress".
307	In the spring of 1863, Lincoln was optimistic about upcoming military campaigns to the point of thinking the end of the war could be near if a string of victories could be put together; these plans included Hooker's attack on Lee north of Richmond, Rosecrans' on Chattanooga, Grant's on Vicksburg, and a naval assault on Charleston.
307	Hooker was routed by Lee at the Battle of Chancellorsville in May, but continued to command his troops for some weeks.
307	He ignored Lincoln's order to divide his troops, and possibly force Lee to do the same in Harper's Ferry, and tendered his resignation, which Lincoln accepted.
307	He was replaced by George Meade, who followed Lee into Pennsylvania for the Gettysburg Campaign, which was a victory for the Union, though Lee's army avoided capture.
307	At the same time, after initial setbacks, Grant laid siege to Vicksburg and the Union navy attained some success in Charleston harbor.
307	After the Battle of Gettysburg, Lincoln clearly understood that his military decisions would be more effectively carried out by conveying his orders through his War Secretary or his general-in-chief on to his generals, who resented his civilian interference with their own plans.
307	Even so, he often continued to give detailed directions to his generals as Commander-in-Chief.
307	Emancipation Proclamation Lincoln understood that the Federal government's power to end slavery was limited by the Constitution, which before 1865, committed the issue to individual states.
307	He argued before and during his election that the eventual extinction of slavery would result from preventing its expansion into new U.S.
307	At the beginning of the war, he also sought to persuade the states to accept compensated emancipation in return for their prohibition of slavery.
307	Lincoln believed that curtailing slavery in these ways would economically expunge it, as envisioned by the Founding Fathers, under the constitution.
307	President Lincoln rejected two geographically limited emancipation attempts by Major General John C.
307	Frémont in August 1861 and by Major General David Hunter in May 1862, on the grounds that it was not within their power, and it would upset the border states loyal to the Union.
307	On June 19, 1862, endorsed by Lincoln, Congress passed an act banning slavery on all federal territory.
307	In July 1862, the Second Confiscation Act was passed, which set up court procedures that could free the slaves of anyone convicted of aiding the rebellion.
307	Although Lincoln believed it was not within Congress's power to free the slaves within the states, he approved the bill in deference to the legislature.
307	He felt such action could only be taken by the Commander-in-Chief using war powers granted to the president by the Constitution, and Lincoln was planning to take that action.
307	In that month, Lincoln discussed a draft of the Emancipation Proclamation with his cabinet.
307	In it, he stated that "as a fit and necessary military measure, on January 1, 1863, all persons held as slaves in the Confederate states will thenceforward, and forever, be free."
307	Privately, Lincoln concluded at this point that the slave base of the Confederacy had to be eliminated.
307	However Copperheads argued that emancipation was a stumbling block to peace and reunification.
307	Republican editor Horace Greeley of the highly influential New York Tribune fell for the ploy, and Lincoln refuted it directly in a shrewd letter of August 22, 1862.
307	The President said the primary goal of his actions as president (he used the first person pronoun and explicitly refers to his "official duty") was preserving the Union: The Emancipation Proclamation, issued on September 22, 1862, and put into effect on January 1, 1863, declared free the slaves in 10 states not then under Union control, with exemptions specified for areas already under Union control in two states.
307	Lincoln spent the next 100 days preparing the army and the nation for emancipation, while Democrats rallied their voters in the 1862 off-year elections by warning of the threat freed slaves posed to northern whites.
307	Once the abolition of slavery in the rebel states became a military objective, as Union armies advanced south, more slaves were liberated until all three million of them in Confederate territory were freed.
307	Lincoln's comment on the signing of the Proclamation was: "I never, in my life, felt more certain that I was doing right, than I do in signing this paper."
307	For some time, Lincoln continued earlier plans to set up colonies for the newly freed slaves.
307	He commented favorably on colonization in the Emancipation Proclamation, but all attempts at such a massive undertaking failed.
307	A few days after Emancipation was announced, 13 Republican governors met at the War Governors' Conference; they supported the president's Proclamation, but suggested the removal of General George B.
307	McClellan as commander of the Union Army.
307	Using former slaves in the military was official government policy after the issuance of the Emancipation Proclamation.
307	By the spring of 1863, he was ready to recruit black troops in more than token numbers.
307	In a letter to Andrew Johnson, th was ready to recruit blace military governor of Tennessee, encouraging him to lead the way in raising black troops, Lincoln wrote, "The bare sight of 50,000 armed and drilled black soldiers on the banks of the Mississippi would end the rebellion at once".
307	By the end of 1863, at Lincoln's direction, General Lorenzo Thomas had recruited 20 regiments of blacks from the Mississippi Valley.
307	Frederick Douglass once observed of Lincoln: "In his company, I was never reminded of my humble origin, or of my unpopular color".
307	Gettysburg Address With the great Union victory at the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863, and the defeat of the Copperheads in the Ohio election in the fall, Lincoln maintained a strong base of party support and was in a strong position to redefine the war effort, despite the New York City draft riots.
307	The stage was set for his address at the Gettysburg battlefield cemetery.
307	Defying Lincoln's prediction that "the world will little note, nor long remember what we say here," the Address became the most quoted speech in American history.
307	The Gettysburg Address was delivered at the dedication of the Soldiers' National Cemetery in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, on the afternoon of Thursday, November 19, 1863.
307	In 272 words, and three minutes, Lincoln asserted the nation was born not in 1789, but in 1776, "conceived in Liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal."
307	He defined the war as an effort dedicated to these principles of liberty and equality for all.
307	The emancipation of slaves was now part of the national war effort.
307	He declared that the deaths of so many brave soldiers would not be in vain, that slavery would end as a result of the losses, and the future of democracy would be assured, that "government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the earth."
307	Lincoln concluded that the Civil War had a profound objective: a new birth of freedom in the nation.
307	General Grant Meade's failure to capture Lee's army as it retreated from Gettysburg, and the continued passivity of the Army of the Potomac, persuaded Lincoln that a change in command was needed.
307	General Ulysses S.
307	Grant's victories at the Battle of Shiloh and in the Vicksburg campaign impressed Lincoln and made Grant a strong candidate to head the Union Army.
307	Responding to criticism of Grant after Shiloh, Lincoln had said, "I can't spare this man.
307	He fights."
307	With Grant in command, Lincoln felt the Union Army could relentlessly pursue a series of coordinated offensives in multiple theaters, and have a top commander who agreed on the use of black troops.
307	Nevertheless, Lincoln was concerned that Grant might be considering a candidacy for President in 1864, as McClellan was.
307	Lincoln arranged for an intermediary to make inquiry into Grant's political intentions, and being assured that he had none, submitted to the Senate Grant's promotion to commander of the Union Army.
307	He obtained Congress's consent to reinstate for Grant the rank of Lieutenant General, which no officer had held since George Washington.
307	Grant waged his bloody Overland Campaign in 1864.
307	This is often characterized as a war of attrition, given high Union losses at battles such as the Battle of the Wilderness and Cold Harbor.
307	Even though they had the advantage of fighting on the defensive, the Confederate forces had "almost as high a percentage of casualties as the Union forces".
307	The high casualty figures of the Union alarmed the North; Grant had lost a third of his army, and Lincoln asked what Grant's plans were, to which the general replied, "I propose to fight it out on this line if it takes all summer."
307	The Confederacy lacked reinforcements, so Lee's army shrank with every costly battle.
307	Grant's army moved south, crossed the James River, forcing a siege and trench warfare outside Petersburg, Virginia.
307	Lincoln then made an extended visit to Grant's headquarters at City Point, Virginia.
307	This allowed the president to confer in person with Grant and William Tecumseh Sherman about the hostilities, as Sherman coincidentally managed a hasty visit to Grant from his position in North Carolina.
307	Lincoln and the Republican Party mobilized support for the draft throughout the North, and replaced his losses.
307	Lincoln authorized Grant to target the Confederate infrastructure—such as plantations, railroads, and bridges—hoping to destroy the South's morale and weaken its economic ability to continue fighting.
307	Grant's move to Petersburg resulted in the obstruction of three railroads between Richmond and the South.
307	This strategy allowed Generals Sherman and Philip Sheridan to destroy plantations and towns in Virginia's Shenandoah Valley.
307	The damage caused by Sherman's March to the Sea through Georgia in 1864 was limited to a 60 mi swath, but neither Lincoln nor his commanders saw destruction as the main goal, but rather defeat of the Confederate armies.
307	As Neely (2004) concludes, there was no effort to engage in "total war" against civilians, as in World War II.
307	Confederate general Jubal Anderson Early began a series of assaults in the North that threatened the Capital.
307	During Early's raid on Washington, D.C.
307	Lincoln was watching the combat from an exposed position; Captain Oliver Wendell Holmes shouted at him, "Get down, you damn fool, before you get shot!"
307	After repeated calls on Grant to defend Washington, Sheridan was appointed and the threat from Early was dispatched.
307	As Grant continued to wear down Lee's forces, efforts to discuss peace began.
307	Confederate Vice President Stephens led a group to meet with Lincoln, Seward, and others at Hampton Roads.
307	Lincoln refused to allow any negotiation with the Confederacy as a coequal; his sole objective was an agreement to end the fighting and the meetings produced no results.
307	On April 1, 1865, Grant successfully outflanked Lee's forces in the Battle of Five Forks and nearly encircled Petersburg, and the Confederate government evacuated Richmond.
307	Days later, when that city fell, Lincoln visited the vanquished Confederate capital; as he walked through the city, white Southerners were stone-fad the vanquished Confederate capced, but freedmen greeted him as a hero.
307	On April 9, Lee surrendered to Grant at Appomattox and the war was effectively over.
307	Lincoln was a master politician, bringing together—and holding together—all the main factions of the Republican Party, and bringing in War Democrats such as Edwin M.
307	Stanton and Andrew Johnson as well.
307	Lincoln spent many hours a week talking to politicians from across the land and using his patronage powers—greatly expanded over peacetime—to hold the factions of his party together, build support for his own policies, and fend off efforts by Radicals to drop him from the 1864 ticket.
307	At its 1864 convention, the Republican Party selected Andrew Johnson, a War Democrat from the Southern state of Tennessee, as his running mate.
307	To broaden his coalition to include War Democrats as well as Republicans, Lincoln ran under the label of the new Union Party.
307	When Grant's 1864 spring campaigns turned into bloody stalemates and Union casualties mounted, the lack of military success wore heavily on the President's re-election prospects, and many Republicans across the country feared that Lincoln would be defeated.
307	Sharing this fear, Lincoln wrote and signed a pledge that, if he should lose the election, he would still defeat the Confederacy before turning over the White House:  Lincoln did not show the pledge to his cabinet, but asked them to sign the sealed envelope.
307	While the Democratic platform followed the "Peace wing" of the party and called the war a "failure", their candidate, General George B.
307	McClellan, supported the war and repudiated the platform.
307	Lincoln provided Grant with more troops and mobilized his party to renew its support of Grant in the war effort.
307	Sherman's capture of Atlanta in September and David Farragut's capture of Mobile ended defeatist jitters; the Democratic Party was deeply split, with some leaders and most soldiers openly for Lincoln.
307	By contrast, the National Union Party was united and energized as Lincoln made emancipation the central issue, and state Republican parties stressed the perfidy of the Copperheads.
307	Lincoln was re-elected in a landslide, carrying all but three states, and receiving 78 percent of the Union soldiers' vote.
307	On March 4, 1865, Lincoln delivered his second inaugural address.
307	In it, he deemed the high casualties on both sides to be God's will.
307	Historian Mark Noll concludes it ranks "among the small handful of semi-sacred texts by which Americans conceive their place in the world".
307	Lincoln said: Reconstruction Reconstruction began during the war, as Lincoln and his associates anticipated questions of how to reintegrate the conquered southern states, and how to determine the fates of Confederate leaders and freed slaves.
307	Shortly after Lee's surrender, a general had asked Lincoln how the defeated Confederates should be treated, and Lincoln replied, "Let 'em up easy."
307	In keeping with that sentiment, Lincoln led the moderates regarding Reconstruction policy, and was opposed by the Radical Republicans, under Rep.
307	Thaddeus Stevens, Sen.
307	Charles Sumner and Sen.
307	Benjamin Wade, political allies of the president on other issues.
307	Determined to find a course that would reunite the nation and not alienate the South, Lincoln urged that speedy elections under generous terms be held throughout the war.
307	His Amnesty Proclamation of December 8, 1863, offered pardons to those who had not held a Confederate civil office, had not mistreated Union prisoners, and would sign an oath of allegiance.
307	As Southern states were subdued, critical decisions had to be made as to their leadership while their administrations were re-formed.
307	Of special importance were Tennessee and Arkansas, where Lincoln appointed Generals Andrew Johnson and Frederick Steele as military governors, respectively.
307	In Louisiana, Lincoln ordered General Nathaniel P.
307	Banks to promote a plan that would restore statehood when 10 percent of the voters agreed to it.
307	Lincoln's Democratic opponents seized on these appointments to accuse him of using the military to ensure his and the Republicans' political aspirations.
307	On the other hand, the Radicals denounced his policy as too lenient, and passed their own plan, the Wade-Davis Bill, in 1864.
307	When Lincoln vetoed the bill, the Radicals retaliated by refusing to seat representatives elected from Louisiana, Arkansas, and Tennessee.
307	Lincoln's appointments were designed to keep both the moderate and Radical factions in harness.
307	To fill Chief Justice Taney's seat on the Supreme Court, he named the choice of the Radicals, Salmon P.
307	Chase, who Lincoln believed would uphold the emancipation and paper money policies.
307	After implementing the Emancipation Proclamation, which did not apply to every state, Lincoln increased pressure on Congress to outlaw slavery throughout the entire nation with a constitutional amendment.
307	Lincoln declared that such an amendment would "clinch the whole matter".
307	By December 1863 a proposed constitutional amendment that would outlaw slavery absolutely was brought to Congress for passage.
307	This first attempt at an amendment failed to pass, falling short of the required two-thirds majority on June 15, 1864, in the House of Representatives.
307	Passage of the proposed amendment became part of the Republican/Unionist platform in the election of 1864.
307	After a long debate in the House, a second attempt passed Congress on January 31, 1865, and was sent to the state legislatures for ratification.
307	Upon ratification, it became the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution on December 6, 1865.
307	As the war drew to a close, Lincoln's presidential Reconstruction for the South was in flux; having believed the federal government had limited responsibility to the millions of freedmen.
307	He signed into law Senator Charles Sumner's Freedman's Bureau bill that set up a temporary federal agency designed to meet the immediate material needs of former slaves.
307	The law assigned land for a lease of three years with the ability to purchase title for the freedmen.
307	Lincoln stated that his Louisiana plan did not apply to all states under Reconstruction.
307	Shortly before his assassination, Lincoln announced he had a new plan for southern Reconstruction.
307	Discussions with his cabinet revealed Lincoln planned short-term military control over southern states, until readmission under the control of southern Unionists.
307	Redefining the republic and republicanism The successful reunification of the states had consequences for the name of the country.
307	The term "the United States" has historically been used, sometimes in the plural ("these United States"), and other times in the singular, without any particular grammatical consistency.
307	The Civil War was a significant force in the eventual dominance of the singular usage by the end of the 19th century.
307	In recent years, historians such as Harry Jaffa, Herman Belz, John Diggins, Vernon Burton and Eric Foner have stressed Lincoln's redefinition of republican values.
307	As early as the 1850s, a time when most political rhetoric focused on the sanctity of the Constitution, Lincoln redirected emphasis to the Declaration of Independence as the foundation of American political values—what he called the "sheet anchor" of republicanism.
307	The Declaration's emphasis on freedom and equality for all, in contrast to the Constitution's tolerance of slavery, shifted the debate.
307	As Diggins concludes regarding the highly influential Cooper Union speech of early 1860, "Lincoln presented Americans a theory of history that offers a profound contribution to the theory and destiny of republicanism itself."
307	His position gained strength because he highlighted the moral basis of republicanism, rather than its legalisms.
307	Nevertheless, in 1861, Lincoln justified the war in terms of legalisms (the Constitution was a contract, and for one party to get out of a contract all the other parties had to agree), and then in terms of the national duty to guarantee a republican form of government in every state.
307	Burton (2008) argues that Lincoln's republicanism was taken up by the Freedmen as they were emancipated.
307	In March 1861, in his First Inaugural Address, Lincoln explored the nature of democracy.
307	He denounced secession as anarchy, and explained that majority rule had to be balanced by constitutional restraints in the American system.
307	He said "A majority held in restraint by constitutional checks and limitations, and always changing easily with deliberate changes of popular opinions and sentiments, is the only true sovereign of a free people."
307	Other enactments Lincoln adhered to the Whig theory of the presidency, which gave Congress primary responsibility for writing the laws while the Executive enforced them.
307	Lincoln only vetoed four bills passed by Congress; the only important one was the Wade-Davis Bill with its harsh program of Reconstruction.
307	He signed the Homestead Act in 1862, making millions of acres of government-held land in the West available for purchase at very low cost.
307	The Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act, also signed in 1862, provided government grants for agricultural colleges in each state.
307	The Pacific Railway Acts of 1862 and 1864 granted federal support for the construction of the United States' First Transcontinental Railroad, which was completed in 1869.
307	The passage of the Homestead Act and the Pacific Railway Acts was made possible by the absence of Southern congressmen and senators who had opposed the measures in the 1850s.
307	Other important legislation involved two measures to raise revenues for the Federal government: tariffs (a policy with long precedent), and a new Federal income tax.
307	In 1861, Lincoln signed the second and third Morrill Tariff, the first having become law under James Buchanan.
307	Also in 1861, Lincoln signed the Revenue Act of 1861, creating the first U.S.
307	This created a flat tax of 3 percent on incomes above $800 ($ in current dollar terms), which was later changed by the Revenue Act of 1862 to a progressive rate structure.
307	Lincoln also presided over the expansion of the federal government's economic influence in several other areas.
307	The creation of the system of national banks by the National Banking Act provided a strong financial network in the country.
307	It also established a national currency.
307	In 1862, Congress created, with Lincoln's approval, the Department of Agriculture.
307	In 1862, Lincoln sent a senior general, John Pope, to put down the "Sioux Uprising" in Minnesota.
307	Presented with 303 execution warrants for convicted Santee Dakota who were accused of killing innocent farmers, Lincoln conducted his own personal review of each of these warrants, eventually approving 39 for execution (one was later reprieved).
307	President Lincoln had planned to reform federal Indian policy.
307	In the wake of Grant's casualties in his campaign against Lee, Lincoln had considered yet another executive call for a military draft, but it was never issued.
307	In response to rumors of one, however, the editors of the New York World and the Journal of Commerce published a false draft proclamation which created an opportunity for the editors and others employed at the publications to corner the gold market.
307	Lincoln's reaction was to send the strongest of messages to the media about such behavior; he ordered the military to seize the two papers.
307	The seizure lasted for two days.
307	Lincoln is largely responsible for the institution of the Thanksgiving holiday in the United States.
307	Before Lincoln's presidency, Thanksgiving, while a regional holiday in New England since the 17th century, had been proclaimed by the federal government only sporadically and on irregular dates.
307	The last such proclamation had been during James Madison's presidency 50 years before.
307	In 1863, Lincoln declared the final Thursday in November of that year to be a day of Thanksgiving.
307	In June 1864, Lincoln approved the Yosemite Grant enacted by Congress, which provided unprecedented federal protection for the area now known as Yosemite National Park.
307	Judicial appointments Supreme Court appointments * Noah Haynes Swayne – 1862 * Samuel Freeman Miller – 1862 * David Davis – 1862 * Stephen Johnson Field – 1863 * Salmon Portland Chase – 1864 (Chief Justice) Lincoln's declared philosophy on court nominations was that "we cannot ask a man what he will do, and if we should, and he should answer us, we should despise him for it.
307	Therefore we must take a man whose opinions are known."
307	Lincoln made five appointments to the United States Supreme Court.
307	Noah Haynes Swayne, nominated January 21, 1862 and appointed January 24, 1862, was chosen as an anti-slavery lawyer who was committed to the Union.
307	Samuel Freeman Miller, nominated and appointed on July 16, 1862, supported Lincoln in the 1860 election and was an avowed abolitionist.
307	David Davis, Lincoln's campaign manager in 1860, nominated December 1, 1862 and appointed December 8, 1862, had also served as a judge in Lincoln's Illinois court circuit.
307	Stephen Johnson Field, a previous California Supreme Court justice, was nominated March 6, 1863 and appointed March 10, 1863, and provided geographic balance, as well as political balance to the court as a Democrat.
307	Finally, Lincoln's Treasury Secretary, Salmon P.
307	Chase, was nominated as Chief Justice, and appointed the same day, on December 6, 1864.
307	Lincoln believed Chase was an able jurist, would support Reconstruction legislation, and that his appointment united the Republican Party.
307	Other judicial appointments Lincoln appointed 32 federal judges, including four Associate Justices and one Chief Justice to the Supreme Court of the United States, and 27 judges to the United States district courts.
307	Lincoln appointed no judges to the United States circuit courts during his time in office.
307	States admitted to the Union West Virginia, admitted to the Union June 20, 1863, contained the former north-westernmost counties of Virginia that seceded from Virginia after that commonwealth declared its secession from the Union.
307	As a condition for its admission, West Virginia's constitution was required to provide for the gradual abolition of slavery.
307	Nevada, which became the third State in the far-west of the continent, was admitted as a free state on October 31, 1864.
307	Assassination John Wilkes Booth was a well-known actor and a Confederate spy from Maryland; though he never joined the Confederate army, he had contacts with the Confederate secret service.
307	In 1864, Booth formulated a plan (very similar to one of Thomas N.
307	Conrad previously authorized by the Confederacy) to kidnap Lincoln in exchange for the release of Confederate prisoners.
307	After attending an April 11, 1865, speech in which Lincoln promoted voting rights for blacks, an incensed Booth changed his plans and became determined to assassinate the president.
307	Learning that the President, First Lady, and head Union general Ulysses S.
307	Grant would be attending Ford's Theatre, Booth formulated a plan with co-conspirators to assassinate Vice President Andrew Johnson, Secretary of State William H.
307	Seward and General Grant.
307	Without his main bodyguard, Ward Hill Lamon, Lincoln left to attend the play Our American Cousin on April 14.
307	Grant along with his wife chose at the last minute to travel to Philadelphia instead of attending the play.
307	Lincoln's bodyguard, John Parker, left Ford's Theater during intermission to join Lincoln's coagt; Lincoln's bodyguard, John Pchman for drinks in the Star Saloon next door.
307	The now unguarded President sat in his state box in the balcony.
307	Seizing the opportunity, Booth crept up from behind and at about 10:13 pm, aimed at the back of Lincoln's head and fired at point-blank range, mortally wounding the President.
307	Major Henry Rathbone momentarily grappled with Booth, but Booth stabbed him and escaped.
307	After being on the run for 10 days, Booth was tracked down and found on a farm in Virginia, some 70 mi south of Washington, D.C.
307	After a brief fight with Union troops, Booth was killed by Sergeant Boston Corbett on April 26.
307	An Army surgeon, Doctor Charles Leale, was sitting nearby at the theater and immediately assisted the President.
307	He found the President unresponsive, barely breathing and with no detectable pulse.
307	Having determined that the President had been shot in the head, and not stabbed in the shoulder as originally thought, he made an attempt to clear the blood clot, after which the President began to breathe more naturally.
307	The dying man was taken across the street to Petersen House.
307	After being in a coma for nine hours, Lincoln died at 7:22 am on April 15.
307	Presbyterian minister Phineas Densmore Gurley, then present, was asked to offer a prayer, after which Secretary of War Stanton saluted and said, "Now he belongs to the ages."
307	Lincoln's flag-enfolded body was then escorted in the rain to the White House by bareheaded Union officers, while the city's church bells rang.
307	President Johnson was sworn in at 10:00 am, less than 3 hours after Lincoln's death.
307	The late President lay in state in the East Room, and then in the Capitol Rotunda from April 19 through April 21.
307	For his final journey with his son Willie, both caskets were transported in the executive coach "United States" and for three weeks the Lincoln Special funeral train decorated in black bunting bore Lincoln's remains on a slow circuitous waypoint journey from Washington D.C.
307	Springfield, Illinois stopping at many cities across the North for large-scale memorials attended by hundreds of thousands, as well as many people who gathered in informal trackside tributes with bands, bonfires and hymn singing or silent reverence with hat in hand as the railway procession slowly passed by.
307	Religious and philosophical beliefs As a young man, Lincoln was clearly a religious skeptic, or, in the words of a biographer, even an iconoclast.
307	Later in life, Lincoln's frequent use of religious imagery and language might have reflected his own personal beliefs or might have been a device to appeal to his audiences, who were mostly evangelical Protestants.
307	He never joined a church, although he frequently attended with his wife, but he was deeply familiar with the Bible, quoted it and praised it.
307	In the 1840s Lincoln subscribed to the Doctrine of Necessity, a belief that asserted the human mind was controlled by some higher power.
307	In the 1850s, Lincoln acknowledged "providence" in a general way, and rarely used the language or imagery of the evangelicals; he regarded the republicanism of the Founding Fathers with an almost religious reverence.
307	When he suffered the death of his son Edward, Lincoln more frequently acknowledged his own need to depend on God.
307	The death of his son Willie in February 1862 may have caused Lincoln to look toward religion for answers and solace.
307	After Willie's death, Lincoln considered why, from a divine standpoint, the severity of the war was necessary.
307	He wrote at this time that God "could have either saved or destroyed the Union without a human contest.
307	Yet the contest began.
307	And having begun He could give the final victory to either side any day.
307	Yet the contest proceeds."
307	On the day Lincoln was assassinated, he reportedly told his wife Mary at Ford's Theatre he desired to visit the Holy Land.
307	Historical reputation In surveys of scholars ranking Presidents since the 1940s, Lincoln is consistently ranked in the top three, often #1.
307	A 2004 study found that scholars in the fields of history and politics ranked Lincoln number one, while legal scholars placed him second after Washington.
307	Of all the presidential ranking polls conducted since 1948, Lincoln has been rated at the very top in the majority of polls: Schlesinger 1948, Schlesinger 1962, 1982 Murray Blessing Survey, Chicago Tribune 1982 poll, Schlesinger 1996, CSPAN 1996, Ridings-McIver 1996, Time 2008, and CSPAN 2009.
307	Generally, the top three presidents are rated as 1) Lincoln; 2) George Washington; and 3) Franklin D.
307	Roosevelt, although Lincoln and Washington, and Washington and Roosevelt, occasionally are reversed.
307	President Lincoln's assassination made him a national martyr and endowed him with a recognition of mythic proportion.
307	Lincoln was viewed by abolitionists as a champion for human liberty.
307	Republicans linked Lincoln's name to their party.
307	Many, though not all, in the South considered Lincoln as a man of outstanding ability.
307	Schwartz argues that Lincoln's reputation grew slowly in the late 19th century until the Progressive Era (1900–1920s) when he emerged as one of the most venerated heroes in American history, with even white Southerners in agreement.
307	The high point came in 1922 with the dedication of the Lincoln Memorial on the Mall in Washington.
307	In the New Deal era liberals honored Lincoln not so much as the self-made man or the great war president, but as the advocate of the common man who doubtless would have supported the welfare state.
307	In the Cold War years, Lincoln's image shifted to emphasize the symbol of freedom who brought hope to those oppressed by communist regimes.
307	By the 1970s Lincoln had become a hero to political conservatives for his intense nationalism, support for business, his insistence on stopping the spread of human bondage, his acting in terms of Lockean and Burkean principles on behalf of both liberty and tradition, and his devotion to the principles of the Founding Fathers.
307	As a Whig activist, Lincoln was a spokesman for business interests, favoring high tariffs, banks, internal improvements, and railroads in opposition to the agrarian Democrats.
307	William C.
307	Harris found that Lincoln's "reverence for the Founding Fathers, the Constitution, the laws under it, and the preservation of the Republic and its institutions undergirded and strengthened his conservatism.".
307	James G.
307	Randall emphasizes his tolerance and especially his moderation "in his preference for orderly progress, his distrust of dangerous agitation, and his reluctance toward ill digested schemes of reform."
307	Randall concludes that, "he was conservative in his complete avoidance of that type of so-called 'radicalism' which involved abuse of the South, hatred for the slaveholder, thirst for vengeance, partisan plotting, and ungenerous demands that Southern institutions be transformed overnight by outsiders."
307	By the late 1960s, liberals, such as historian Lerone Bennett, were having second thoughts, especially regarding Lincoln's views on racial issues.
307	Bennett won wide attention when he called Lincoln a white supremacist in 1968.
307	He noted that Lincoln used ethnic slurs, told jokes that ridiculed blacks, insisted he opposed social equality, and proposed sending freed slaves to another country.
307	Defenders, such as authors Dirck and Cashin, retorted that he was not as bad as most politicians; and that he was a "moral visionary" who deftly advanced the abolitionist cause, as fast as politically possible.
307	The emphasis shifted away from Lincoln-the-emancipator to an argument that blacks had freed themselves from slavery, or at least were responsible for pressuring the government on emancipation.
307	Historian Barry Schwartz wrote in 2009 that Lincoln's image suffered "erosion, fading prestige, benign ridicule," in the late 20th century.
307	On the other hand, Donald opined in his 1996 biography that Lincoln was distinctly endowed with the personality trait of negative capability, defined by the poet John Keats and attributed to extraordinary leaders who were "content in the midst of uncertainties and doubts, and not compelled toward fact or reason."
307	Memorials Lincoln appears on the penny and the $5 bill, and on many postage stamps.
307	He has been memorialized in many town, city, and county names, including the capital of Nebraska.
307	The most famous and most visited memorials are the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C.; Lincoln's sculpture on Mount Rushmore; Ford's Theatre and Petersen House (where he died) in Washington and the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, located in Springfield, Illinois, not far from Lincoln's Tomb.
307	Barry Schwartz, a sociologist who has examined America's cultural memory, argues that in the 1930s and 1940s, the memory of Abraham Lincoln  was practically sacred and provided the nation with "a moral symbol inspiring and guiding American life."
307	During the Great Depression, he argues,  Lincoln served "as a means for seeing the world's disappointments, for making its sufferings not so much explicable as meaningful."
307	Franklin D.
307	Roosevelt, preparing America for war, used the words of the Civil War president to clarify the threat posed by  Germany and Japan.
307	Americans asked, "What would Lincoln do?"
307	However, he also finds that since World War II, Lincoln's symbolic power has lost relevance, and this "fading hero is symptomatic of fading confidence in national greatness."
307	He suggested that postmodernism and multiculturalism have diluted greatness as a concept.
308	Aristotle (, Aristotélēs) (384 BC – 322 BC) was a Greek philosopher and polymath, a student of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great.
308	His writings cover many subjects, including physics, metaphysics, poetry, theater, music, logic, rhetoric, linguistics, politics, government, ethics, biology, and zoology.
308	Together with Plato and Socrates (Plato's teacher), Aristotle is one of the most important founding figures in Western philosophy.
308	Aristotle's writings were the first to create a comprehensive system of Western philosophy, encompassing morality, aesthetics, logic, science, politics, and metaphysics.
308	Aristotle's views on the physical sciences profoundly shaped medieval scholarship, and their influence extended well into the Renaissance, although they were ultimately replaced by Newtonian physics.
308	In the zoological sciences, some of his observations were confirmed to be accurate only in the 19th century.
308	His works contain the earliest known formal study of logic, which was incorporated in the late 19th century into modern formal logic.
308	In metaphysics, Aristotelianism had a profound influence on philosophical and theological thinking in the Islamic and Jewish traditions in the Middle Ages, and it continues to influence Christian theology, especially the scholastic tradition of the Catholic Church.
308	Aristotle was well known among medieval Muslim intellectuals and revered as  المعلم الأول - "The First Teacher".
308	His ethics, though always influential, gained reneweالمعلم الأول - "The First Teacher".
308	Hid interest with the modern advent of virtue ethics.
308	All aspects of Aristotle's philosophy continue to be the object of active academic study today.
308	Though Aristotle wrote many elegant treatises and dialogues (Cicero described his literary style as "a river of gold"), it is thought that the majority of his writings are now lost and only about one-third of the original works have survived.
308	Life Aristotle, whose name means "the best purpose," was born in Stagira, Chalcidice, in 384 BC, about 55 km east of modern-day Thessaloniki.
308	His father Nicomachus was the personal physician to King Amyntas of Macedon.
308	Although there is little information on Aristotle' childhood, he probably did spend some time then in the Macedonian palace, making his first connections with the Macedonian monarchy.
308	At about the age of eighteen, he went to Athens to continue his education at Plato's Academy.
308	Aristotle remained at the academy for nearly twenty years before leaving Athens in 348/47 BC.
308	The traditional story about his departure reports that he was disappointed with the direction the academy took after control passed to Plato's nephew Speusippus upon his death, although it is possible that he feared anti-Macedonian sentiments and left before Plato had died.
308	He then traveled with Xenocrates to the court of his friend Hermias of Atarneus in Asia Minor.
308	While in Asia, Aristotle traveled with Theophrastus to the island of Lesbos, where together they researched the botany and zoology of the island.
308	Aristotle married Hermias's adoptive daughter (or niece) Pythias.
308	She bore him a daughter, whom they named Pythias.
308	Soon after Hermias' death, Aristotle was invited by Philip II of Macedon to become the tutor to his son Alexander in 343 BC.
308	Aristotle was appointed as the head of the royal academy of Macedon.
308	During that time he gave lessons not only to Alexander, but also to two other future kings: Ptolemy and Cassander.
308	Aristotle encouraged Alexander toward eastern conquest, and his attitude towards Persia was unabashedly ethnocentric.
308	In one famous example, he counsels Alexander to be "a leader to the Greeks and a despot to the barbarians, to look after the former as after friends and relatives, and to deal with the latter as with beasts or plants".
308	By 335 BC he had returned to Athens, establishing his own school there known as the Lyceum.
308	Aristotle conducted courses at the school for the next twelve years.
308	While in Athens, his wife Pythias died and Aristotle became involved with Herpyllis of Stagira, who bore him a son whom he named after his father, Nicomachus.
308	According to the Suda, he also had an eromenos, Palaephatus of Abydus.
308	It is during this period in Athens from 335 to 323 BC when Aristotle is believed to have composed many of his works.
308	Aristotle wrote many dialogues, only fragments of which survived.
308	The works that have survived are in treatise form and were not, for the most part, intended for widespread publication, as they are generally thought to be lecture aids for his students.
308	His most important treatises include Physics, Metaphysics, Nicomachean Ethics, Politics, De Anima (On the Soul) and Poetics.
308	Aristotle not only studied almost every subject possible at the time, but made significant contributions to most of them.
308	In physical science, Aristotle studied anatomy, astronomy, embryology, geography, geology, meteorology, physics and zoology.
308	In philosophy, he wrote on aesthetics, ethics, government, metaphysics, politics, economics, psychology, rhetoric and theology.
308	He also studied education, foreign customs, literature and poetry.
308	His combined works constitute a virtual encyclopedia of Greek knowledge.
308	It has been suggested that Aristotle was probably the last person to know everything there was to be known in his own time.
308	Near the end of Alexander's life, Alexander began to suspect plots against himself, and threatened Aristotle in letters.
308	Aristotle had made no secret of his contempt for Alexander's pretense of divinity, and the king had executed Aristotle's grandnephew Callisthenes as a traitor.
308	A widespread tradition in antiquity suspected Aristotle of playing a role in Alexander's death, but there is little evidence for this.
308	Upon Alexander's death, anti-Macedonian sentiment in Athens once again flared.
308	Eurymedon the hierophant denounced Aristotle for not holding the gods in honor.
308	Aristotle fled the city to his mother's family estate in Chalcis, explaining, "I will not allow the Athenians to sin twice against philosophy," a reference to Athens's prior trial and execution of Socrates.
308	He died in Euboea of natural causes within the year (in 322 BC).
308	Aristotle named chief executor his student Antipater and left a will in which he asked to be buried next to his wife.
308	Thought Logic With the Prior Analytics, Aristotle is credited with the earliest study of formal logic, and his conception of it was the dominant form of Western logic until 19th century advances in mathematical logic.
308	Kant stated in the Critique of Pure Reason that Aristotle's theory of logic completely accounted for the core of deductive inference.
308	History Aristotle "says that 'on the subject of reasoning' he 'had nothing else on an earlier date to speak of'".
308	However, Plato reports that syntax was devised before him, by Prodicus of Ceos, who was concerned by the correct use of words.
308	Logic seems to have emerged from dialectics; the earlier philosophers made frequent use of concepts like reductio ad absurdum in their discussions, but never truly understood the logical implications.
308	Even Plato had difficulties with logic; although he had a reasonable conception of a deductive system, he could never actually construct one and relied instead on his dialectic.
308	Plato believed that deduction would simply follow from premises, hence he focused on maintaining solid premises so that the conclusion would logically follow.
308	Consequently, Plato realized that a method for obtaining conclusions would be most beneficial.
308	He never succeeded in devising such a method, but his best attempt was published in his book Sophist, where he introduced his division method.
308	Analytics and the Organon What we today call Aristotelian logic, Aristotle himself would have labeled "analytics".
308	The term "logic" he reserved to mean dialectics.
308	Most of Aristotle's work is probably not in its original form, since it was most likely edited by students and later lecturers.
308	The logical works of Aristotle were compiled into six books in about the early 1st century AD: #Categories #On Interpretation #Prior Analytics #Posterior Analytics #Topics #On Sophistical Refutations The order of the books (or the teachings from which they are composed) is not certain, but this list was derived from analysis of Aristotle's writings.
308	It goes from the basics, the analysis of simple terms in the Categories, the analysis of propositions and their elementary relations in On Interpretation, to the study of more complex forms, namely, syllogisms (in the Analytics) and dialectics (in the Topics and Sophistical Refutations).
308	The first three treatises form the core of the logical theory stricto sensu: the grammar of the language of logic and the correct rules of reasoning.
308	There is one volume of Aristotle's concerning logic not found in the Organon, namely the fourth book of Metaphysics.
308	Aristotle's scientific method Like his teacher Plato, Aristotle's philosophy aims at the universal.
308	Aristotle, however, finds the universal in particular things, which he calls the essence of things, while Plato finds that the universal exists apart from particular things, and is related to them as their prototype or exemplar.
308	For Aristotle, therefore, philosophic method implies the ascent from the study of particular phenomena to the knowledge of essences, while for Plato philosophic method means the descent from a knowledge of universal Forms (or ideas) to a contemplation of particular imitations of these.
308	For Aristotle, "form" still refers to the unconditional basis of phenomena but is "instantiated" in a particular substance (see Universals and particulars, below).
308	In a certain sense, Aristotle's method is both inductive and deductive, while Plato's is essentially deductive from a priori principles.
308	In Aristotle's terminology, "natural philosophy" is a branch of philosophy examining the phenomena of the natural world, and includes fields that would be regarded today as physics, biology and other natural sciences.
308	In modern times, the scope of philosophy has become limited to more generic or abstract inquiries, such as ethics and metaphysics, in which logic plays a major role.
308	Today's philosophy tends to exclude empirical study of the natural world by means of the scientific method.
308	In contrast, Aristotle's philosophical endeavors encompassed virtually all facets of intellectual inquiry.
308	In the larger sense of the word, Aristotle makes philosophy coextensive with reasoning, which he also would describe as "science".
308	Note, however, that his use of the term science carries a different meaning than that covered by the term "scientific method".
308	For Aristotle, "all science (dianoia) is either practical, poetical or theoretical" (Metaphysics 1025b25).
308	By practical science, he means ethics and politics; by poetical science, he means the study of poetry and the other fine arts; by theoretical science, he means physics, mathematics and metaphysics.
308	If logic (or "analytics") is regarded as a study preliminary to philosophy, the divisions of Aristotelian philosophy would consist of: (1) Logic; (2) Theoretical Philosophy, including Metaphysics, Physics and Mathematics; (3) Practical Philosophy and (4) Poetical Philosophy.
308	In the period between his two stays in Athens, between his times at the Academy and the Lyceum, Aristotle conducted most of the scientific thinking and research for which he is renowned today.
308	In fact, most of Aristotle's life was devoted to the study of the objects of natural science.
308	Aristotle's metaphysics contains observations on the nature of numbers but he made no original contributions to mathematics.
308	He did, however, perform original research in the natural sciences, e.g., botany, zoology, physics, astronomy, chemistry, meteorology, and several other sciences.
308	Aristotle's writings on science are largely qualitative, as opposed to quantitative.
308	Beginning in the 16th century, scientists began applying mathematics to the physical sciences, and Aristotle's work in this area was deemed hopelessly inadequate.
308	His failings were largely due to the absence of concepts like mass, velocity, force and inadequate.
308	Hitemperature.
308	He had a conception of speed and temperature, but no quantitative understanding of them, which was partly due to the absence of basic experimental devices, like clocks and thermometers.
308	His writings provide an account of many scientific observations, a mixture of precocious accuracy and curious errors.
308	For example, in his History of Animals he claimed that human males have more teeth than females.
308	In a similar vein, John Philoponus, and later Galileo, showed by simple experiments that Aristotle's theory that a heavier object falls faster than a lighter object is incorrect.
308	On the other hand, Aristotle refuted Democritus's claim that the Milky Way was made up of "those stars which are shaded by the earth from the sun's rays," pointing out (correctly, even if such reasoning was bound to be dismissed for a long time) that, given "current astronomical demonstrations" that "the size of the sun is greater than that of the earth and the distance of the stars from the earth many times greater than that of the sun, then ...
308	" In places, Aristotle goes too far in deriving 'laws of the universe' from simple observation and over-stretched reason.
308	Today's scientific method assumes that such thinking without sufficient facts is ineffective, and that discerning the validity of one's hypothesis requires far more rigorous experimentation than that which Aristotle used to support his laws.
308	Aristotle also had some scientific blind spots.
308	He posited a geocentric cosmology that we may discern in selections of the Metaphysics, which was widely accepted up until the 16th century.
308	From the 3rd century to the 16th century, the dominant view held that the Earth was the rotational center of the universe.
308	Since he was perhaps the philosopher most respected by European thinkers during and after the Renaissance, these thinkers often took Aristotle's erroneous positions as given, which held back science in this epoch.
308	However, Aristotle's scientific shortcomings should not mislead one into forgetting his great advances in the many scientific fields.
308	For instance, he founded logic as a formal science and created foundations to biology that were not superseded for two millennia.
308	Moreover, he introduced the fundamental notion that nature is composed of things that change and that studying such changes can provide useful knowledge of underlying constants.
308	Geology As quoted from Charles Lyell's Principles of Geology: He [Aristotle] refers to many examples of changes now constantly going on, and insists emphatically on the great results which they must produce in the lapse of ages.
308	He instances particular cases of lakes that had dried up, and deserts that had at length become watered by rivers and fertilized.
308	He points to the growth of the Nilotic delta since the time of Homer, to the shallowing of the Palus Maeotis within sixty years from his own time ...
308	He alludes ...
308	Eolian islands, previous to a volcanic eruption.
308	The changes of the earth, he says, are so slow in comparison to the duration of our lives, that they are overlooked; and the migrations of people after great catastrophes, and their removal to other regions, cause the event to be forgotten.He says [12th chapter of his Meteorics] 'the distribution of land and sea in particular regions does not endure throughout all time, but it becomes sea in those parts where it was land, and again it becomes land where it was sea, and there is reason for thinking that these changes take place according to a certain system, and within a certain period.'
308	The concluding observation is as follows: 'As time never fails, and the universe is eternal, neither the Tanais, nor the Nile, can have flowed for ever.
308	The places where they rise were once dry, and there is a limit to their operations, but there is none to time.
308	So also of all other rivers; they spring up and they perish; and the sea also continually deserts some lands and invades others The same tracts, therefore, of the earth are not some always sea, and others always continents, but every thing changes in the course of time.'
308	Physics Five elements Aristotle proposed a fifth element, aether, in addition to the four proposed earlier by Empedocles.
308	Earth, which is cold and dry; this corresponds to the modern idea of a solid.
308	Water, which is cold and wet; this corresponds to the modern idea of a liquid.
308	Air, which is hot and wet; this corresponds to the modern idea of a gas.
308	Fire, which is hot and dry; this corresponds to the modern ideas of plasma and heat.
308	Aether, which is the divine substance that makes up the heavenly spheres and heavenly bodies (stars and planets).
308	Each of the four earthly elements has its natural place.
308	All that is earthly tends toward the center of the universe, i.e., the center of the Earth.
308	Water tends toward a sphere surrounding the center.
308	Air tends toward a sphere surrounding the water sphere.
308	Fire tends toward the lunar sphere (in which the Moon orbits).
308	When elements are moved out of their natural place, they naturally move back towards it.
308	This is "natural motion"—motion requiring no extrinsic cause.
308	So, for example, in water, earthy bodies sink while air bubbles rise up; in air, rain falls and flame rises.
308	Outside all the other spheres, the heavenly, fifth element, manifested in the stars and planets, moves in the perfection of circles.
308	Motion Aristotle defined motion as the actuality of a potentiality as such.
308	Aquinas suggested that the passage be understood literally; that motion can indeed be understood as the active fulfillment of a potential, as a transition toward a potentially possible state.
308	Because actuality and potentiality are normally opposites in Aristotle, other commentators either suggest that the wording which has come down to us is erroneous, or that the addition of the "as such" to the definition is critical to understanding it.
308	Causality, The Four Causes Aristotle suggested that the reason for anything coming about can be attributed to four different types of simultaneously active causal factors: *Material cause describes the material out of which something is composed.
308	Thus the material cause of a table is wood, and the material cause of a car is rubber and steel.
308	It is not about action.
308	It does not mean one domino knocks over another domino.
308	The formal cause is its form, i.e., the arrans not mean ogement of that matter.
308	It tells us what a thing is, that any thing is determined by the definition, form, pattern, essence, whole, synthesis or archetype.
308	It embraces the account of causes in terms of fundamental principles or general laws, as the whole (i.e., macrostructure) is the cause of its parts, a relationship known as the whole-part causation.
308	Plainly put the formal cause is the idea existing in the first place as exemplar in the mind of the sculptor, and in the second place as intrinsic, determining cause, embodied in the matter.
308	Formal cause could only refer to the essential quality of causation.
308	A more simple example of the formal cause is the blueprint or plan that one has before making or causing a human made object to exist.
308	The efficient cause is "the primary source", or that from which the change or the ending of the change first starts.
308	It identifies 'what makes of what is made and what causes change of what is changed' and so suggests all sorts of agents, nonliving or living, acting as the sources of change or movement or rest.
308	Representing the current understanding of causality as the relation of cause and effect, this covers the modern definitions of "cause" as either the agent or agency or particular events or states of affairs.
308	More simply again that which immediately sets the thing in motion.
308	So take the two dominos this time of equal weighting, the first is knocked over causing the second also to fall over.
308	This is effectively efficient cause.
308	The final cause is its purpose, or that for the sake of which a thing exists or is done, including both purposeful and instrumental actions and activities.
308	The final cause or telos is the purpose or end that something is supposed to serve, or it is that from which and that to which the change is.
308	This also covers modern ideas of mental causation involving such psychological causes as volition, need, motivation or motives, rational, irrational, ethical, and all that gives purpose to behavior.
308	Additionally, things can be causes of one another, causing each other reciprocally, as hard work causes fitness and vice versa, although not in the same way or function, the one is as the beginning of change, the other as the goal.
308	Thus Aristotle first suggested a reciprocal or circular causality as a relation of mutual dependence or influence of cause upon effect).
308	Moreover, Aristotle indicated that the same thing can be the cause of contrary effects; its presence and absence may result in different outcomes.
308	Simply it is the goal or purpose that brings about an event (not necessarily a mental goal).
308	Taking our two dominos, it requires someone to intentionally knock the dominos over as they cannot fall themselves.
308	Aristotle marked two modes of causation: proper (prior) causation and accidental (chance) causation.
308	All causes, proper and incidental, can be spoken as potential or as actual, particular or generic.
308	The same language refers to the effects of causes, so that generic effects assigned to generic causes, particular effects to particular causes, operating causes to actual effects.
308	Essentially, causality does not suggest a temporal relation between the cause and the effect.
308	Optics Aristotle held more accurate theories on some optical concepts than other philosophers of his day.
308	The earliest known written evidence of a camera obscura can be found in Aristotle's documentation of such a device in 350 BC in Problemata.
308	Aristotle's apparatus contained a dark chamber that had a single small hole, or aperture, to allow for sunlight to enter.
308	Aristotle used the device to make observations of the sun and noted that no matter what shape the hole was, the sun would still be correctly displayed as a round object.
308	In modern cameras, this is analogous to the diaphragm.
308	Aristotle also made the observation that when the distance between the aperture and the surface with the image increased, the image was magnified.
308	Chance and spontaneity According to Aristotle, spontaneity and chance are causes of some things, distinguishable from other types of cause.
308	Chance as an incidental cause lies in the realm of accidental things.
308	It is "from what is spontaneous" (but note that what is spontaneous does not come from chance).
308	For a better understanding of Aristotle's conception of "chance" it might be better to think of "coincidence": Something takes place by chance if a person sets out with the intent of having one thing take place, but with the result of another thing (not intended) taking place.
308	For example: A person seeks donations.
308	That person may find another person willing to donate a substantial sum.
308	However, if the person seeking the donations met the person donating, not for the purpose of collecting donations, but for some other purpose, Aristotle would call the collecting of the donation by that particular donator a result of chance.
308	It must be unusual that something happens by chance.
308	In other words, if something happens all or most of the time, we cannot say that it is by chance.
308	There is also more specific kind of chance, which Aristotle names "luck", that can only apply to human beings, since it is in the sphere of moral actions.
308	According to Aristotle, luck must involve choice (and thus deliberation), and only humans are capable of deliberation and choice.
308	"What is not capable of action cannot do anything by chance".
308	Metaphysics Aristotle defines metaphysics as "the knowledge of immaterial being," or of "being in the highest degree of abstraction."
308	He refers to metaphysics as "first philosophy", as well as "the theologic science."
308	Substance, potentiality and actuality Aristotle examines the concepts of substance and essence (ousia) in his Metaphysics (Book VII), and he concludes that a particular substance is a combination of both matter and form.
308	In book VIII, he distinguishes the matter of the substance as the substratum, or the stuff of which it is composed.
308	For example, the matter of a house is the bricks, stones, timbers etc., or whatever constitutes the potential house, while the form of the substance is the actual house, namely 'covering for bodies and chattels' or any other differentia (see also predicables) that let us define something as a house.
308	The formula that gives the components is the account of the matter, and the formula that gives the differentia is the account of the form.
308	With regard to the change (kinesis) and its causes now, as he defines in his Physics and On Generation and Corruption 319b-320a, he distinguishes the coming to be from: # growth and diminution, which is change in quantity; # locomotion, which is change in space; and # alteration, which is change in quality.
308	The coming to be is a change where nothing persists of which the resultant is a property.
308	In that particular change he introduces the concept of potentiality (dynamis) and actuality (entelecheia) in association with the matter and the form.
308	Referring to potentiality, this is what a thing is capable of doing, or being acted upon, if the conditions are right and it is not prevented thing is cby something else.
308	For example, the seed of a plant in the soil is potentially (dynamei) plant, and if is not prevented by something, it will become a plant.
308	Potentially beings can either 'act' (poiein) or 'be acted upon' (paschein), which can be either innate or learned.
308	For example, the eyes possess the potentiality of sight (innate – being acted upon), while the capability of playing the flute can be possessed by learning (exercise – acting).
308	Actuality is the fulfillment of the end of the potentiality.
308	Because the end (telos) is the principle of every change, and for the sake of the end exists potentiality, therefore actuality is the end.
308	Referring then to our previous example, we could say that an actuality is when a plant does one of the activities that plants do.
308	"For that for the sake of which a thing is, is its principle, and the becoming is for the sake of the end; and the actuality is the end, and it is for the sake of this that the potentiality is acquired.
308	For animals do not see in order that they may have sight, but they have sight that they may see."
308	In summary, the matter used to make a house has potentiality to be a house and both the activity of building and the form of the final house are actualities, which is also a final cause or end.
308	Then Aristotle proceeds and concludes that the actuality is prior to potentiality in formula, in time and in substantiality.
308	With this definition of the particular substance (i.e., matter and form), Aristotle tries to solve the problem of the unity of the beings, for example, "what is it that makes a man one"?
308	Since, according to Plato there are two Ideas: animal and biped, how then is man a unity?
308	However, according to Aristotle, the potential being (matter) and the actual one (form) are one and the same thing.
308	Universals and particulars Aristotle's predecessor, Plato, argued that all things have a universal form, which could be either a property, or a relation to other things.
308	When we look at an apple, for example, we see an apple, and we can also analyze a form of an apple.
308	In this distinction, there is a particular apple and a universal form of an apple.
308	Moreover, we can place an apple next to a book, so that we can speak of both the book and apple as being next to each other.
308	Plato argued that there are some universal forms that are not a part of particular things.
308	For example, it is possible that there is no particular good in existence, but "good" is still a proper universal form.
308	Bertrand Russell is a contemporary philosopher who agreed with Plato on the existence of "uninstantiated universals".
308	Aristotle disagreed with Plato on this point, arguing that all universals are instantiated.
308	Aristotle argued that there are no universals that are unattached to existing things.
308	According to Aristotle, if a universal exists, either as a particular or a relation, then there must have been, must be currently, or must be in the future, something on which the universal can be predicated.
308	Consequently, according to Aristotle, if it is not the case that some universal can be predicated to an object that exists at some period of time, then it does not exist.
308	In addition, Aristotle disagreed with Plato about the location of universals.
308	As Plato spoke of the world of the forms, a location where all universal forms subsist, Aristotle maintained that universals exist within each thing on which each universal is predicated.
308	So, according to Aristotle, the form of apple exists within each apple, rather than in the world of the forms.
308	Biology and medicine In Aristotelian science, most especially in biology, things he saw himself have stood the test of time better than his retelling of the reports of others, which contain error and superstition.
308	He dissected animals but not humans; his ideas on how the human body works have been almost entirely superseded.
308	Empirical research program Aristotle is the earliest natural historian whose work has survived in some detail.
308	Aristotle certainly did research on the natural history of Lesbos, and the surrounding seas and neighbouring areas.
308	The works that reflect this research, such as History of Animals, Generation of Animals, and Parts of Animals, contain some observations and interpretations, along with sundry myths and mistakes.
308	The most striking passages are about the sea-life visible from observation on Lesbos and available from the catches of fishermen.
308	His observations on catfish, electric fish (Torpedo) and angler-fish are detailed, as is his writing on cephalopods, namely, Octopus, Sepia (cuttlefish) and the paper nautilus (Argonauta argo).
308	His description of the hectocotyl arm was about two thousand years ahead of its time, and widely disbelieved until its rediscovery in the 19th century.
308	He separated the aquatic mammals from fish, and knew that sharks and rays were part of the group he called Selachē (selachians).
308	Another good example of his methods comes from the Generation of Animals in which Aristotle describes breaking open fertilized chicken eggs at intervals to observe when visible organs were generated.
308	He gave accurate descriptions of ruminants' four-chambered fore-stomachs, and of the ovoviviparous embryological development of the hound shark Mustelus mustelus.
308	Classification of living things Aristotle's classification of living things contains some elements which still existed in the 19th century.
308	What the modern zoologist would call vertebrates and invertebrates, Aristotle called 'animals with blood' and 'animals without blood' (he was not to know that complex invertebrates do make use of hemoglobin, but of a different kind from vertebrates).
308	Animals with blood were divided into live-bearing (humans and mammals), and egg-bearing (birds and fish).
308	Invertebrates ('animals without blood') are insects, crustacea (divided into non-shelled – cephalopods – and shelled) and testacea (molluscs).
308	In some respects, this incomplete classification is better than that of Linnaeus, who crowded the invertebrata together into two groups, Insecta and Vermes (worms).
308	For Charles Singer, "Nothing is more remarkable than [Aristotle's] efforts to [exhibit] the relationships of living things as a scala naturae" Aristotle's History of Animals classified organisms in relation to a hierarchical "Ladder of Life" (scala naturae), placing them according to complexity of structure and function so that higher organisms showed greater vitality and ability to move.
308	Aristotle believed that intellectual purposes, i.e., final causes, guided all natural processes.
308	Such a teleological view gave Aristotle cause to justify his observed data as an expression of formal design.
308	Noting that "no animal has, at the same time, both tusks and horns," and "a single-hooved animal with two horns I have never seen," Aristotle suggested that Nature, giving no animal both horns and tusks, was staving off vanity, and giving creatures faculties only to such a degree as they are necessary.
308	Noting that ruminants had multiple stomaures faculties onlychs and weak teeth, he supposed the first was to compensate for the latter, with Nature trying to preserve a type of balance.
308	In a similar fashion, Aristotle believed that creatures were arranged in a graded scale of perfection rising from plants on up to man, the scala naturae or Great Chain of Being.
308	His system had eleven grades, arranged according "to the degree to which they are infected with potentiality", expressed in their form at birth.
308	The highest animals laid warm and wet creatures alive, the lowest bore theirs cold, dry, and in thick eggs.
308	Aristotle also held that the level of a creature's perfection was reflected in its form, but not preordained by that form.
308	Ideas like this, and his ideas about souls, are not regarded as science at all in modern times.
308	He placed emphasis on the type(s) of soul an organism possessed, asserting that plants possess a vegetative soul, responsible for reproduction and growth, animals a vegetative and a sensitive soul, responsible for mobility and sensation, and humans a vegetative, a sensitive, and a rational soul, capable of thought and reflection.
308	Aristotle, in contrast to earlier philosophers, but in accordance with the Egyptians, placed the rational soul in the heart, rather than the brain.
308	Notable is Aristotle's division of sensation and thought, which generally went against previous philosophers, with the exception of Alcmaeon.
308	Successor: Theophrastus Aristotle's successor at the Lyceum, Theophrastus, wrote a series of books on botany—the History of Plants—which survived as the most important contribution of antiquity to botany, even into the Middle Ages.
308	Many of Theophrastus' names survive into modern times, such as carpos for fruit, and pericarpion for seed vessel.
308	Rather than focus on formal causes, as Aristotle did, Theophrastus suggested a mechanistic scheme, drawing analogies between natural and artificial processes, and relying on Aristotle's concept of the efficient cause.
308	Theophrastus also recognized the role of sex in the reproduction of some higher plants, though this last discovery was lost in later ages.
308	Influence on Hellenistic medicine After Theophrastus, the Lyceum failed to produce any original work.
308	Though interest in Aristotle's ideas survived, they were generally taken unquestioningly.
308	It is not until the age of Alexandria under the Ptolemies that advances in biology can be again found.
308	The first medical teacher at Alexandria, Herophilus of Chalcedon, corrected Aristotle, placing intelligence in the brain, and connected the nervous system to motion and sensation.
308	Herophilus also distinguished between veins and arteries, noting that the latter pulse while the former do not.
308	Though a few ancient atomists such as Lucretius challenged the teleological viewpoint of Aristotelian ideas about life, teleology (and after the rise of Christianity, natural theology) would remain central to biological thought essentially until the 18th and 19th centuries.
308	Ernst Mayr claimed that there was "nothing of any real consequence in biology after Lucretius and Galen until the Renaissance."
308	Aristotle's ideas of natural history and medicine survived, but they were generally taken unquestioningly.
308	Psychology Aristotle's psychology, given in his treatise On the Soul (peri psyche, often known by its Latin title De Anima), posits three kinds of soul ("psyches"): the vegetative soul, the sensitive soul, and the rational soul.
308	Humans have a rational soul.
308	This kind of soul is capable of the same powers as the other kinds: Like the vegetative soul it can grow and nourish itself; like the sensitive soul it can experience sensations and move locally.
308	The unique part of the human, rational soul is its ability to receive forms of other things and compare them.
308	For Aristotle, the soul (psyche) was a simpler concept than it is for us today.
308	By soul he simply meant the form of a living being.
308	Since all beings are composites of form and matter, the form of living beings is that which endows them with what is specific to living beings, e.g.
308	Aristotle considers types of movement).
308	Practical philosophy Ethics Aristotle considered ethics to be a practical rather than theoretical study, i.e., one aimed at becoming good and doing good rather than knowing for its own sake.
308	He wrote several treatises on ethics, including most notably, the Nicomachean Ethics.
308	Aristotle taught that virtue has to do with the proper function (ergon) of a thing.
308	An eye is only a good eye in so much as it can see, because the proper function of an eye is sight.
308	Aristotle reasoned that humans must have a function specific to humans, and that this function must be an activity of the psuchē (normally translated as soul) in accordance with reason (logos).
308	Aristotle identified such an optimum activity of the soul as the aim of all human deliberate action, eudaimonia, generally translated as "happiness" or sometimes "well being".
308	To have the potential of ever being happy in this way necessarily requires a good character (ēthikē aretē), often translated as moral (or ethical) virtue (or excellence).
308	Aristotle taught that to achieve a virtuous and potentially happy character requires a first stage of having the fortune to be habituated not deliberately, but by teachers, and experience, leading to a later stage in which one consciously chooses to do the best things.
308	When the best people come to live life this way their practical wisdom (phronesis) and their intellect (nous) can develop with each other towards the highest possible human virtue, the wisdom of an accomplished theoretical or speculative thinker, or in other words, a philosopher.
308	Politics In addition to his works on etcom |date=14 August 2010 |hics, which address the individual, Aristotle addressed the city in his work titled Politics.
308	Aristotle considered the city to be a natural community.
