336	A simple illustration of such cause and effect is the case of experiencing the effects of what I cause: if I cause suffering, then as a natural consequence I will experience suffering; if I cause happiness, then as a natural consequence I will experience happiness.
336	In Buddhism, karma (Pāli kamma) is strictly distinguished from vipāka, meaning "fruit" or "result".
336	Karma is categorized within the group or groups of cause (Pāli hetu) in the chain of cause and effect, where it comprises the elements of "volitional activities" (Pali sankhara) and "action" (Pali bhava).
336	Any action is understood to create "seeds" in the mind that sprout into the appropriate results (Pāli vipaka) when they meet the right conditions.
336	Most types of karmas, with good or bad results, will keep one in the wheel of samsāra; others will liberate one to nirvāna.
336	Buddhism relates karma directly to motives behind an action.
336	Motivation usually makes the difference between "good" and "bad", but motivation also includes the aspect of ignorance; so a well-intended action from an ignorant mind can easily be "bad" in that it creates unpleasant results for the "actor."
336	In Buddhism, karma is not the only cause of all that happens.
336	As taught in the early texts, the commentarial tradition classified causal mechanisms governing the universe in five categories, known as Niyama Dhammas: * Kamma Niyama — Consequences of one's actions * Utu Niyama — Seasonal changes and climate * Biija Niyama — Laws of heredity * Citta Niyama — Will of mind * Dhamma Niyama — Nature's tendency to produce a perfLaws of heredity * Citta Niyama — Wiect type Jainism The fundamental principles of Jainism revolve around the concept of altruism, not only for humans but for all sentient beings.
336	Jainism preaches the view of Ahimsa – to live and let live, thereby not harming sentient beings, i.e.
336	It also considers all living things to be equal.
336	The first Thirthankar, Rishabh introduced the concept of altruism for all living beings, from extending knowledge and experience to others to donation, giving oneself up for others, non-violence and compassion for all living things.
336	Jainism prescribes a path of non-violence to progress the soul to this ultimate goal.
336	Jains believe that to attain enlightenment and ultimately liberation, one must practice the following ethical principles (major vows) in thought, speech and action.
336	The degree to which these principles are practiced is different for householders and monks.
336	They are: # Non-violence (Ahimsa); # Truthfulness (Satya); # Non-stealing (Asteya); # Celibacy (Brahmacharya); # Non-possession or non-materialism (Aparigraha); A major characteristic of Jain belief is the emphasis on the consequences of not only physical but also mental behaviors.
336	One's unconquered mind with anger, pride (ego), deceit, greed and uncontrolled sense organs are the powerful enemies of humans.
336	Anger spoils good relations, pride destroys humility, deceit destroys peace and greed destroys everything.
336	Jainism recommends conquering anger by forgiveness, pride (ego) by humility, deceit by straight-forwardness and greed by contentment.
336	The principle of non-violence seeks to minimize karmas which limit the capabilities of the soul.
336	Jainism views every soul as worthy of respect because it has the potential to become Siddha (Param-atma – "highest soul").
336	Because all living beings possess a soul, great care and awareness is essential in one's actions.
336	Jainism emphasizes the equality of all life, advocating harmlessness towards all, whether the creatures are great or small.
336	This policy extends even to microscopic organisms.
336	Jainism acknowledges that every person has different capabilities and capacities to practice and therefore accepts different levels of compliance for ascetics and householders.
336	The "great vows" (mahavrata) are prescribed for monks and "limited vows" (anuvrata) are prescribed for householders.
336	In other words, the house-holders are encouraged to practice the five cardinal principles of non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, celibacy and non-possessiveness with their current practical limitations while the monks have to observe them very strictly.
336	With consistent practice, it will be possible to overcome the limitations gradually, accelerating the spiritual progress.
336	Christianity Altruism is central to the teachings of Jesus found in the Gospel, especially in the Sermon on the Mount and the Sermon on the Plain.
336	From biblical to medieval Christian traditions, tensions between self-affirmation and other-regard were sometimes discussed under the heading of "disinterested love", as in the Pauline phrase "love seeks not its own interests."
336	In his book Indoctrination and Self-deception, Roderick Hindery tries to shed light on these tensions by contrasting them with impostors of authentic self-affirmation and altruism, by analysis of other-regard within creative individuation of the self, and by contrasting love for the few with love for the many.
336	Love confirms others in their freedom, shuns propaganda and masks, assures others of its presence, and is ultimately confirmed not by mere declarations from others, but by each person's experience and practice from within.
336	As in practical arts, the presence and meaning of love becomes validated and grasped not by words and reflections alone, but in the making of the connection.
336	St Thomas Aquinas in the Summa Theologica, II:II Quaestio 25, Article 4 states that we should love our neighbour more than our ourselves.
336	His interpretation of the Pauline phrase is that we should seek the common good more than the private good, but this is because the common good is a more desirable good for the individual.
336	St Thomas interprets 'You should love your neighbour as yourself' from Leviticus 19 and Matthew 22 as meaning that love for ourselves is the exemplar of love for others.
336	However, he thinks we should love God more than ourselves and our neighbours, and more than our bodily life—since the ultimate purpose of loving our neighbour is to share in eternal beatitude: a more desirable thing than bodily well being.
336	In coining the word Altruism, as stated above, Comte was probably opposing this Thomistic doctrine, which is present in some theological schools within Catholicism.
336	Many biblical authors draw a strong connection between love of others and love of God.
336	John 4 states that for one to love God one must love his fellowman, and that hatred of one's fellowman is the same as hatred of God.
336	Thomas Jay Oord has argued in several books that altruism is but one possible form of love.
336	An altruistic action is not always a loving action.
336	Oord defines altruism as acting for the other's good, and he agrees with feminists who note that sometimes love requires acting for one's own good when the other's demands undermine overall well-being.
336	German philosopher Max Scheler distinguishes two ways in which the strong can help the weak.
336	One way is a sincere expression of Christian love, "motivated by a powerful feeling of security, strength, and inner salvation, of the invincible fullness of one’s own life and existence".
336	Another way is merely "one of the many modern substitutes for love, ...
336	" At its worst, Scheler says, "love for the small, the poor, the weak, and the oppressed is really disguised hatred, repressed envy, an impulse to detract, etc., directed against the opposite phenomena: wealth, strength, power, largesse."
336	Islam and Sufism In Sufism, the concept 'īṯār' (altruism) is the notion of 'preferring others to oneself'.
336	For Sufis, this means devotion to others through complete forgetfulness of one's own concerns.
336	The importance lies in sacrifice for the sake of the greater good; Islam considers those practicing īṯār as abiding by the highest degree of nobility.
336	This is similar to the notion of chivalry, but unlike that European concept, in i'thar attention is focused on everything in existence.
336	A constant concern for Allah (i.e.
336	God) results in a careful attitude towards people, animals, and other things in this world.
336	This concept was emphasized by Sufi mystics like Rabia al-Adawiyya who paid attention to the difference between dedication to Allah (i.e.
336	God) and dedication to people.
336	Thirteenth-century Turkish sufi poet Yunus Emre explained this philosophy as "Yaratılanı severiz, Yaratandan ötürü" or We love the creature, because of The Creator.
336	For many Muslims, i'thar must be practiced as a religious obligation during specific Islamic holidays.
336	However, i'thar is also still an Islamic ideal to which all Muslims should strivc Islamic holidays.
336	However, i'thar is ale to adhere at all times.
336	Judaism Judaism defines altruism as the desired goal of creation.
336	The famous Rabbi Abraham Isaac Kook stated that love is the most important attribute in humanity.
336	This is defined as bestowal, or giving, which is the intention of altruism.
336	This can be altruism towards humanity that leads to altruism towards the creator or God.
336	Kabbalah defines God as the force of giving in existence.
336	Rabbi Moshe Chaim Luzzatto in particular focused on the 'purpose of creation' and how the will of God was to bring creation into perfection and adhesion with this upper force.
336	Modern Kabbalah developed by Rabbi Yehuda Ashlag, in his writings about the future generation, focuses on how society could achieve an altruistic social framework.
336	Ashlag proposed that such a framework is the purpose of creation, and everything that happens is to raise humanity to the level of altruism, love for one another.
336	Ashlag focused on society and its relation to divinity.
336	Sikhism Altruism is essential to the Sikh religion.
336	The central faith in Sikhism is that the greatest deed any one can do is to imbibe and live the godly qualities like love, affection, sacrifice, patience, harmony, truthfulness.
336	The fifth Nanak, Guru Arjun Dev Sacrificed his life to uphold 22 Carats of pure truth, the greatest gift to humanity, the Guru Granth.
336	The Ninth Nanak, Guru Tegh Bahadur Sacrificed his head to protect weak and defenseless people against atrocity.
336	In the late 17th century, Guru Gobind Singh Ji (the tenth guru in Sikhism), was in war with the Moghul rulers to protect the people of different faiths, when a fellow Sikh, Bhai Kanhaiya, attended the troops of the enemy.
336	He gave water to both friends and foes who were wounded on the battlefield.
336	Some of the enemy began to fight again and some Sikh warriors were annoyed by Bhai Kanhaiya as he was helping their enemy.
336	Sikh soldiers brought Bhai Kanhaiya before Guru Gobind Singh Ji, and complained of his action that they considered counterproductive to their struggle on the battlefield.
336	"What were you doing, and why?"
336	Guru.
336	"I was giving water to the wounded because I saw your face in all of them," replied Bhai Kanhaiya.
336	The Guru responded, "Then you should also give them ointment to heal their wounds.
336	You were practicing what you were coached in the house of the Guru."
336	It was under the tutelage of the Guru that Bhai Kanhaiya subsequently founded a volunteer corps for altruism.
336	This volunteer corps still to date is engaged in doing good to others and trains new volunteering recruits for doing the same.
336	Hinduism Advaita Vedanta differs from the view that karma is a law of cause and effect but instead additionally hold that karma is mediated by the will of a personal supreme god.
336	This view of karma is in contradiction to Buddhism, Jainism and other Indian religions that do view karma as a law of cause and effect.
336	Swami Sivananda, an Advaita scholar, reiterates the same views in his commentary synthesising Vedanta views on the Brahma Sutras, a Vedantic text.
336	In his commentary on Chapter 3 of the Brahma Sutras, Sivananda notes that karma is insentient and short-lived, and ceases to exist as soon as a deed is executed.
336	Hence, karma cannot bestow the fruits of actions at a future date according to one's merit.
336	Furthermore, one cannot argue that karma generates apurva or punya, which gives fruit.
336	Since apurva is non-sentient, it cannot act unless moved by an intelligent being such as a god.
336	It cannot independently bestow reward or punishment.
336	Philosophy There exists a wide range of philosophical views on man's obligations or motivations to act altruistically.
336	Proponents of ethical altruism maintain that individuals are morally obligated to act altruistically.
336	The opposing view is ethical egoism, which maintains that moral agents should always act in their own self-interest.
336	Both ethical altruism and ethical egoism contrast with utilitarianism, which is the view that every individual's well-being (including one's own) is of equal moral importance.
336	A related concept in descriptive ethics is psychological egoism, the thesis that humans always act in their own self-interest and that true altruism is impossible.
336	Rational egoism is the view that rationality consists in acting in one's self-interest (without specifying how this affects one's moral obligations).
339	Ayn Rand (; born Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum;  – March 6, 1982) was a Russian-American novelist, philosopher, playwright, and screenwriter.
339	She is known for her two best-selling novels, The Fountainhead and Atlas Shrugged, and for developing a philosophical system she called Objectivism.
339	Born and educated in Russia, Rand moved to the United States in 1926.
339	She worked as a screenwriter in Hollywood and had a play produced on Broadway in 1935–1936.
339	After two early novels that were initially less successful, she achieved fame with her 1943 novel The Fountainhead.
339	In 1957, she published her best-known work, the novel Atlas Shrugged.
339	Afterward she turned to nonfiction to promote her philosophy, publishing her own magazines and releasing several collections of essays until her death in 1982.
339	Rand advocated reason as the only means of acquiring knowledge and rejected faith and religion.
339	She supported rational and ethical egoism, and rejected ethical altruism.
339	In politics, she condemned the initiation of force as immoral and  opposed collectivism and statism as well as anarchism, instead supporting a minarchist limited government and laissez-faire capitalism, which she believed was the only social system that protected individual rights.
339	In art, Rand promoted romantic realism.
339	She was sharply critical of most philosophers and philosophical traditions known to her, except for some Aristotelians and classical liberals.
339	Rand's fiction was poorly received by many literary critics, and academia generally ignored or rejected her philosophy.
339	The Objectivist movement attempts to spread her ideas, both to the public and in academic settings.
339	She has been a significant influence among libertarians and American conservatives.
339	Life Early life Rand was born Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum () on February 2, 1905, to a bourgeois family living in Saint Petersburg.
339	She was the eldest of the three daughters of Zinovy Zakharovich Rosenbaum and his wife, Anna Borisovna (née Kaplan), largely non-observant Jews.
339	Zinovy Rosenbaum was a successful pharmacist, eventually owning a pharmacy and the building in which it was located.
339	Rand found school unchallenging, and said she began writing screenplays at the age of eight and novels at the age of ten.
339	She was twelve at the time of the February Revolution of 1917, during which she favored Alexander Kerensky over Tsar Nicholas II.
339	The subsequent October Revolution and the rule of the Bolsheviks under Vladimir Lenin disrupted the comfortable life the family had previously enjoyed.
339	Her father’s pharmacy business was confiscated and the family displaced.
339	They fled to the Crimea, which was initially under control of the White Army during the Russian Civil War.
339	She later recalled that while in high school she determined that she was an atheist and that she valued reason above any other human virtue.
339	After graduating from high school in the Crimea at 16, Rand returned with her family to Petrograd (the new name for Saint Petersburg), where they faced desperate conditions, on occasion nearly starving.
339	After the Russian Revolution, universities were opened to women, allowing Rand to be in the first group of women to enroll at Petrograd State University, where she studied in the department of social pedagogy, majoring in history.
339	At the university she was introduced to the writings of Aristotle and Plato, who would be her greatest influence and counter-influence, respectively.
339	A third figure whose philosophical works she studied heavily was Friedrich Nietzsche.
339	Able to read French, German and Russian, Rand also discovered the writers Fyodor Dostoevsky, Victor Hugo, Edmond Rostand, and Friedrich Schiller, who became her perennial favorites.
339	Along with many other "bourgeois" students, Rand was purged from the university shortly before graduating.
339	However, after complaints from a group of visiting foreign scientists, many of the purged students were allowed to complete their work and graduate, which Rand did in October 1924.
339	She subsequently studied for a year at the State Technicum for Screen Arts in Leningrad.
339	For one of her assignments, she wrote an essay about the Polish actress Pola Negri, which became her first published work.
339	By this time she had decided her professional surname for writing would be Rand, possibly as a Cyrillic contraction of her birth surname, and she adopted the first name Ayn, either from a Finnish name or from the Hebrew word  (ayin, meaning "eye").
339	Arrival in America  In the fall of 1925, Rand was granted a visa to visit American relatives.
339	Rand was so impressed with the skyline of Manhattan upon her arrival in New York Harbor that she cried what she later called "tears of splendor".
339	Intent on staying in the United States to become a screenwriter, she lived for a few months with relatives in Chicago, one of whom owned a movie theater and allowed her to watch dozens of films for free.
339	She then set out for Hollywood, California.
339	Initially, Rand struggled in Hollywood and took odd jobs to pay her basic living expenses.
339	A chance meeting with famed director Cecil B.
339	DeMille led to a job as an extra in his film, The King of Kings, and to subsequent work as a junior screenwriter.
339	While working on The King of Kings, she met an aspiring young actor, Frank O'Connor; the two were married on April 15, 1929.
339	Rand became an American citizen in 1931.
339	Taking various jobs during the 1930s to support her writing, Rand worked for a time as the head of the costume department at RKO Studios.
339	She made several attempts to bring her parents and sisters to the United States, but they were unable to acquire permission to emigrate.
339	Early fiction Rand's first literary success came with the sale of her screenplay Red Pawn to Universal Studios in 1932, although it was never produced.
339	This was followed by the courtroom drama Night of January 16th, first produced by E.E.
339	Clive in Hollywood in 1934 and then successfully reopened on Broadway in 1935.
339	Each night the "jury" was selected from members of the audience, and one of the two different endings, depending on the jury's "verdict", would then be pe and one of the two different endings, depending on the jury's "verdictrformed.
339	In 1941, Paramount Pictures produced a movie version of the play.
339	Rand did not participate in the production and was highly critical of the result.
339	Rand's first novel, the semi-autobiographical We the Living, was published in 1936.
339	Set in Soviet Russia, it focused on the struggle between the individual and the state.
339	In a 1959 foreword to the novel, Rand stated that We the Living "is as near to an autobiography as I will ever write.
339	It is not an autobiography in the literal, but only in the intellectual sense.
339	The plot is invented, the background is not..."
339	Initial sales were slow and the American publisher let it go out of print, although European editions continued to sell.
339	After the success of her later novels, Rand was able to release a revised version in 1959 that has since sold over three million copies.
339	Without Rand's knowledge or permission, the novel was made into a pair of Italian films, Noi vivi and Addio, Kira, in 1942.
339	Rediscovered in the 1960s, these films were re-edited into a new version which was approved by Rand and re-released as We the Living in 1986.
339	Her novella Anthem was written during a break from the writing of her next major novel, The Fountainhead.
339	It presents a vision of a dystopian future world in which totalitarian collectivism has triumphed to such an extent that even the word 'I' has been forgotten and replaced with 'we'.
339	It was published in England in 1938, but Rand initially could not find an American publisher.
339	As with We the Living, Rand's later success allowed her to get a revised version published in 1946, which has sold more than 3.5 million copies.
339	The Fountainhead and political activism During the 1940s, Rand became politically active.
339	Both she and her husband worked full-time in volunteer positions for the 1940 presidential campaign of Republican Wendell Willkie.
339	This work led to Rand's first public speaking experiences, including fielding the sometimes hostile questions from New York City audiences who had just viewed pro-Willkie newsreels, an experience she greatly enjoyed.
339	This activity also brought her into contact with other intellectuals sympathetic to free-market capitalism.
339	She became friends with journalist Henry Hazlitt and his wife, and Hazlitt introduced her to the Austrian School economist Ludwig von Mises.
339	Despite her philosophical differences with them, Rand strongly endorsed the writings of both men throughout her career, and both of them expressed admiration for her.
339	Once Mises referred to Rand as "the most courageous man in America", a compliment that particularly pleased her because he said "man" instead of "woman".
339	Rand also developed a friendship with libertarian writer Isabel Paterson.
339	Rand questioned the well-informed Paterson about American history and politics long into the night during their numerous meetings and gave Paterson ideas for her only nonfiction book, The God of the Machine.
339	Rand's first major success as a writer came with The Fountainhead in 1943, a romantic and philosophical novel that she wrote over a period of seven years.
339	The novel centers on an uncompromising young architect named Howard Roark and his struggle against what Rand described as "second-handers"—those who attempt to live through others, placing others above self.
339	It was rejected by twelve publishers before finally being accepted by the Bobbs-Merrill Company on the insistence of editor Archibald Ogden, who threatened to quit if his employer did not publish it.
339	While completing the novel, Rand was prescribed the amphetamine Benzedrine to fight fatigue.
339	The drug helped her to work long hours to meet her deadline for delivering the finished novel, but when the book was done, she was so exhausted that her doctor ordered two weeks' rest.
339	Her continued use of the drug for approximately three decades may have contributed to what some of her later associates described as volatile mood swings.
339	The Fountainhead eventually became a worldwide success, bringing Rand fame and financial security.
339	In 1943, Rand sold the rights for a film version to Warner Bros., and she returned to Hollywood to write the screenplay.
339	Finishing her work on that screenplay, she was hired by producer Hal Wallis as a screenwriter and script-doctor.
339	Her work for Wallis included the screenplays for the Oscar-nominated Love Letters and You Came Along.
339	This role gave Rand time to work on other projects, including a planned nonfiction treatment of her philosophy to be called The Moral Basis of Individualism.
339	Although the planned book was never completed, a condensed version was published as an essay titled "The Only Path to Tomorrow", in the January 1944 edition of Reader's Digest magazine.
339	While working in Hollywood, Rand extended her involvement with free-market and anti-communist activism.
339	She became involved with the Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals, a Hollywood anti-Communist group, and wrote articles on the group's behalf.
339	She also joined the anti-Communist American Writers Association.
339	A visit by Isabel Paterson to meet with Rand's California associates led to a final falling out between the two when Paterson made comments that Rand saw as rude to valued political allies.
339	In 1947, during the Second Red Scare, Rand testified as a "friendly witness" before the United States House Un-American Activities Committee.
339	Her testimony described the disparity between her personal experiences in the Soviet Union and the portrayal of it in the 1944 film Song of Russia.
339	Rand argued that the film grossly misrepresented conditions in the Soviet Union, portraying life there as being much better and happier than it actually was.
339	She wanted to also criticize the lauded 1946 film The Best Years of Our Lives for what she interpreted as its negative presentation of the business world, but she was not allowed to testify about it.
339	When asked after the hearings about her feelings on the effectiveness of the investigations, Rand described the process as "futile".
339	After several delays, the film version of The Fountainhead was released in 1949.
339	Although it used Rand's screenplay with minimal alterations, she "disliked the movie from beginning to end", complaining about its editing, acting, and other elements.
339	Atlas Shrugged and Objectivism In the years following the publication of The Fountainhead, Rand received numerous letters from readers, some of whom it profoundly influenced.
339	In 1951 Rand moved from Los Angeles to New York City, where she gathered a group of these admirers around her.
339	This group (jokingly designated "The Collective") included future Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, a young psychology student named Nathan Blumenthal (later Nathaniel Branden) and his wife Barbara, and Barbara's cousin Leonard Peikoff.
339	At first the group was an informal gathering of friends who met with Rand on weekends at her apartment to discuss philosophy.
339	Later she began allowing them to read the drafts of her new novel, Atlas Shrugged, as the manuscript pages were written.
339	In 1954 Rand's close relationship with the younger Nathaniel Branden turned into a romantic affair, with the consent of their spouses.
339	Atlas Shrugged, published in 1957, was Rand's magnum opus.
339	Rand described the theme of the novel as "the role of the mind in man's existence—and, as a corollary, the demonstration of a new moral philosophy: the morality of rational self-interest."
339	It advocates the core tenets of Rand's philosophy of Objectivism and expresses her concept of human achievement.
339	The plot involves a dystopian United States in which the most creative industrialists, scientists and artists go on strike and retreat to a mountainous hideaway where they build an independent free economy.
339	The novel's hero and leader of the strike, John Galt, describes the strike as "stopping the motor of the world" by withdrawing the minds of the individuals most contributing to the nation's wealth and achievement.
339	With this fictional strike, Rand intended to illustrate that without the efforts of the rational and productive, the economy would collapse and society would fall apart.
339	The novel includes elements of romance, mystery, and science fiction, and it contains Rand's most extensive statement of Objectivism in any of her works of fiction, a lengthy monologue delivered by Galt.
339	Despite many negative reviews, Atlas Shrugged became an international bestseller, and in an interview with Mike Wallace, Rand declared herself "the most creative thinker alive".
339	After completing the novel, Rand fell into a severe depression.
339	Atlas Shrugged was Rand's last completed work of fiction; a turning point in her life, it marked the end of Rand's career as a novelist and the beginning of her role as a popular philosopher.
339	In 1958 Nathaniel Branden established Nathaniel Branden Lectures, later incorporated as the Nathaniel Branden Institute (NBI), to promote Rand's philosophy.
339	Collective members gave lectures for NBI and wrote articles for Objectivist periodicals that she edited.
339	Rand later published some of these articles in book form.
339	Critics, including some former NBI students and Branden himself, have described the culture of NBI as one of intellectual conformity and excessive reverence for Rand, with some describing NBI or the Objectivist movement itself as a cult or religion.
339	Rand expressed opinions on a wide range of topics, from literature and music to sexuality and facial hair, and some of her followers mimicked her preferences, wearing clothes to match characters from her novels and buying furniture like hers.
339	Rand was unimpressed with many of the NBI students and held them to strict standards, sometimes reacting coldly or angrily to those who disagreed with her.
339	However, some former NBI students believe the extent of these behaviors has been exaggerated, with the problem being concentrated among Rand's closest followers in New York.
339	Later years Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Rand developed and promoted her Objectivist philosophy through her nonfiction works and by giving talks to students at institutions such as Yale, Princeton, Columbia,  Harvard, and MIT.
339	She received an honorary doctorate from Lewis & Clark College in 1963.
339	She also began delivering annual lectures at the Ford Hall Forum, responding afterward to questions from the audience.
339	During these speeches and Q&A sessions, she often took controversial stances on political and social issues of the day.
339	These included supporting abortion rights, opposing the Vietnam War and the military draft (but condemning many draft dodgers as "bums"), supporting Israel in the Arab-Israeli War of 1973 against Palestinians and Arabs as "civilized men fighting savages", saying European colonists had the right to take land from American Indians, and calling homosexuality "immoral" and "disgusting", while also advocating the repeal of all laws against it.
339	She also endorsed several Republican candidates for President of the United States, most strongly Barry Goldwater in 1964, whose candidacy she promoted in several articles for The Objectivist Newsletter.
339	In 1964 Nathaniel Branden began an affair with the young actress Patrecia Scott, whom he later married.
339	Nathaniel and Barbara Branden kept the affair hidden from Rand.
339	When she learned of it in 1968, though her romantic relationship with Branden had already ended, Rand terminated her relationship with both Brandens, which led to the closure of NBI.
339	Rand published an article in The Objectivist repudiating Nathaniel Branden for dishonesty and other "irrational behavior in his private life".
339	Branden later apologized in an interview to "every student of Objectivism" for "perpetuating the Ayn Rand mystique" and for "contributing to that dreadful atmosphere of intellectual repressiveness that pervades the Objectivist movement."
339	In subsequent years, Rand and several more of her closest associates parted company.
339	Rand underwent surgery for lung cancer in 1974 after decades of heavy smoking.
339	In 1976 she retired from writing her newsletter and, despite her initial objections, was persuaded to allow Evva Pryor, a consultant from her attorney's office, to sign her up for Social Security and Medicare.
339	During the late 1970s her activities within the Objectivist movement declined, especially after the death of her husband on November 9, 1979.
339	One of her final projects was work on a never-completed television adaptation of Atlas Shrugged.
339	Rand died of heart failure on March 6, 1982, at her home in New York City, and was interred in the Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.
339	Rand's funeral was attended by some of her prominent followers, including Alan Greenspan.
339	A six-foot floral arrangement in the shape of a dollar sign was placed near her casket.
339	In her will, Rand named Leonard Peikoff the heir to her estate.
339	Philosophy Rand called her philosophy "Objectivism", describing its essence as "the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute."
339	She considered Objectivism a systematic philosophy and laid out positions on metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, political philosophy and esthetics.
339	In metaphysics, Rand supported philosophical realism, and opposed anything she regarded as mysticism or supernaturalism, including all forms of religion.
339	In epistemology, she considered all knowledge to be based on sense perception, the validity of which she considered axiomatic, and reason, which she described as "the faculty that identifies and integrates the material provided by man's senses".
339	She rejected all claims of non-perceptual or a priori knowledge, including "'instinct,' 'intuition,' 'revelation,' or any form of 'just knowing.'" In her Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, Rand presented a theory of concept formation and endorsed the rejection of the analytic–synthetic dichotomy.
339	In ethics, Rand argued for rational egoism (rational self-interest), as the guiding moral principle.
339	She said the individual should "exist for his own sake, neither sacrificing himself to others nor sacrificing others to himself".
339	She referred to egoism as "the virtue of selfishness" in her book of that title, in which she presented her solution to the is-ought problem by describing a meta-ethical theory that based morality in the needs of "man's survival qua man".
339	She condemned ethical altruism as incompatible with the requirements of human life and happiness, and held that the initiation of force was evil and irrational, writing in Atlas Shrugged that "Force and mind are opposites".
339	Rand's political philosophy emphasized individual rights (including property rights), and she considered laissez-faire capitalism the only moral social system because in her view it was the only system based on the protection of those rights.
339	She opposed statism, which she understood to include theocracy, absolute monarchy, Nazism, fascism, communism, democratic socialism, and dictatorship.
339	Rand believed that rights should be enforced by a constitutionally limited government.
339	Although her political views are often classified as conservative or libertarian, she preferred the term "radical for capitalism".
339	She worked with conservatives on political projects, but disagreed with them over issues such as religion and ethics.
339	She denounced libertarianism, which she associated with anarchism.
339	She rejected anarchism as a naïve theory based in subjectivism that could only lead to collectivism in practice.
339	Rand's esthetics defined art as a "selective re-creation of reality according to an artist's metaphysical value-judgments".
339	According to Rand, art allows philosophical concepts to be presented in a concrete form that can be easily grasped, thereby fulfilling a need of human consciousness.
339	As a writer, the art form Rand focused on most closely was literature, where she considered Romanticism to be the approach that most accurately reflected the existence of human free will.
339	She described her own approach to literature as "romantic realism".
339	Rand acknowledged Aristotle as her greatest influence and remarked that in the history of philosophy she could only recommend "three A's"—Aristotle, Aquinas, and Ayn Rand.
339	Indeed her debt to Aristotle was so great that in a 1959 interview with Mike Wallace, when asked where her philosophy came from, she responded: "Out of my own mind, with the sole acknowledgement of a debt to Aristotle who is the only philosopher who ever influenced me.
339	I devised the rest of my philosophy myself."
339	However, she also found early inspiration in Friedrich Nietzsche, and scholars have found indications of his influence in early notes from Rand's journals, in passages from the first edition of We the Living (which Rand later revised), and in her overall writing style.
339	However, by the time she wrote The Fountainhead, Rand had turned against Nietzsche's ideas, and the extent of his influence on her even during her early years is disputed.
339	Among the philosophers Rand held in particular disdain was Immanuel Kant, whom she referred to as a "monster", although philosophers George Walsh and Fred Seddon have argued that she misinterpreted Kant and exaggerated their differences.
339	Rand said her most important contributions to philosophy were her "theory of concepts, [her] ethics, and [her] discovery in politics that evil—the violation of rights—consists of the initiation of force".
339	She believed epistemology was a foundational branch of philosophy and considered the advocacy of reason to be the single most significant aspect of her philosophy, stating, "I am not primarily an advocate of capitalism, but of egoism; and I am not primarily an advocate of egoism, but of reason.
339	If one recognizes the supremacy of reason and applies it consistently, all the rest follows."
339	Reception and legacy Reviews During Rand's lifetime, her work evoked both extreme praise and condemnation.
339	Rand's first novel, We the Living, was admired by the literary critic H.L.
339	Mencken, her Broadway play Night of January 16th was both a critical and popular success, and The Fountainhead was hailed by a reviewer in The New York Times as "masterful".
339	Rand's novels were derided by some critics when they were first published as being long and melodramatic.
339	However, they became bestsellers largely through word of mouth.
339	The first reviews Rand received were for Night of January 16th.
339	Reviews of the production were largely positive, but Rand considered even positive reviews to be embarrassing because of significant changes made to her script by the producer.
339	Rand believed that her first novel, We the Living, was not widely reviewed, but Rand scholar Michael S.
339	Berliner says "it was the most reviewed of any of her works", with approximately 125 different reviews being published in more than 200 publications.
339	Overall these reviews were more positive than the reviews she received for her later work.
339	Her 1938 novella Anthem received little attention from reviewers, both for its first publication in England and for subsequent re-issues.
339	Rand's first bestseller, The Fountainhead, received far fewer reviews than We the Living, and reviewers' opinions were mixed.
339	There was a positive review in The New York Times that Rand greatly appreciated.
339	The reviewer called Rand "a writer of great power" who wrote "brilliantly, beautifully and bitterly", and stated that "you will not be able to read this masterful book without thinking through some of the basic concepts of our time".
339	There were other positive reviews, but Rand dismissed most of them as either not understanding her message or as being from unimportant publications.
339	Some negative reviews focused on the length of the novel, such as one that called it "a whale of a book" and another that said "anyoquot;/> such as one that called it "a ne who is taken in by it deserves a stern lecture on paper-rationing".
339	Other negative reviews called the characters unsympathetic and Rand's style "offensively pedestrian".
339	Rand's 1957 novel Atlas Shrugged was widely reviewed, and many of the reviews were strongly negative.
339	In the National Review, conservative author Whittaker Chambers called the book "sophomoric" and "remarkably silly".
339	He described the tone of the book as "shrillness without reprieve" and accused Rand of supporting a Godless system (which he related to that of the Soviets), claiming "From almost any page of Atlas Shrugged, a voice can be heard, from painful necessity, commanding: 'To a gas chamber—go!
339	Atlas Shrugged received positive reviews from a few publications, including praise from the noted book reviewer John Chamberlain, but Rand scholar Mimi Reisel Gladstein later wrote that "reviewers seemed to vie with each other in a contest to devise the cleverest put-downs", calling it "execrable claptrap" and "a nightmare"; they said it was "written out of hate" and showed "remorseless hectoring and prolixity".
339	Author Flannery O'Connor wrote in a letter to a friend that "The fiction of Ayn Rand is as low as you can get re fiction.
339	I hope you picked it up off the floor of the subway and threw it in the nearest garbage pail."
339	Rand's nonfiction received far fewer reviews than her novels had.
339	The tenor of the criticism for her first nonfiction book, For the New Intellectual, was similar to that for Atlas Shrugged, with philosopher Sidney Hook likening her certainty to "the way philosophy is written in the Soviet Union", and author Gore Vidal calling her viewpoint "nearly perfect in its immorality".
339	Her subsequent books got progressively less attention from reviewers.
339	On the 100th anniversary of Rand's birth in 2005, Edward Rothstein, writing for The New York Times, referred to her fictional writing as quaint utopian "retro fantasy" and programmatic neo-Romanticism of the misunderstood artist, while criticizing her characters' "isolated rejection of democratic society".
339	In 2007, book critic Leslie Clark described her fiction as "romance novels with a patina of pseudo-philosophy".
339	In 2009, GQs critic columnist Tom Carson described her books as "capitalism's version of middlebrow religious novels" such as Ben-Hur and the Left Behind series.
339	Popular interest In 1991, a survey conducted for the Library of Congress and the Book-of-the-Month Club asked club members what the most influential book in the respondent's life was.
339	Rand's Atlas Shrugged was the second most popular choice, after the Bible.
339	Rand's books continue to be widely sold and read, with 25 million copies sold as of 2007 and another 500,000 sold and 300,000 donated by the Ayn Rand Institute in 2008.
339	Although Rand's influence has been greatest in the United States, there has been international interest in her work.
339	Rand's work continues to be among the top sellers among books in India.
339	Rand's contemporary admirers included fellow novelists, such as Ira Levin, Kay Nolte Smith and L.
339	Neil Smith, and later writers such as Erika Holzer and Terry Goodkind have been influenced by her.
339	Other artists who have cited Rand as an important influence on their lives and thought include comic book artist Steve Ditko and musician Neil Peart of Rush.
339	Rand provided a positive view of business, and in response business executives and entrepreneurs have admired and promoted her work.
339	John Allison of BB&T and Ed Snider of Comcast Spectacor have funded the promotion of Rand's ideas, while Mark Cuban, owner of the Dallas Mavericks, and John P.
339	Mackey, CEO of Whole Foods, among others, have said they consider Rand crucial to their success.
339	Rand and her works have been referred to in a variety of media: on television shows including animated sitcoms, live-action comedies, dramas, and game shows, as well as in movies and video games.
339	She, or characters based on her, figure prominently (in positive and negative lights) in literary and science fiction novels by prominent American authors.
339	Nick Gillespie, editor in chief of Reason, has remarked that "Rand's is a tortured immortality, one in which she's as likely to be a punch line as a protagonist..."
339	"jibes at Rand as cold and inhuman, run through the popular culture".
339	Two movies have been made about Rand's life.
339	A 1997 documentary film, Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life, was nominated for the Academy Award for Documentary Feature.
339	The Passion of Ayn Rand, a 1999 television adaptation of the book of the same name, won several awards.
339	Rand's image also appears on a U.S.
339	Nick Gaetano.
339	Political influence Although she rejected the labels "conservative" and "libertarian", Rand has had continuing influence on right-wing politics and libertarianism.
339	Jim Powell, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, considers Rand one of the three most important women (along with Rose Wilder Lane and Isabel Paterson) of modern American libertarianism, and David Nolan, one of the founders of the Libertarian Party, stated that "without Ayn Rand, the libertarian movement would not exist".
339	In his history of the libertarian movement, journalist Brian Doherty described her as "the most influential libertarian of the twentieth century to the public at large", and biographer Jennifer Burns referred to her as "the ultimate gateway drug to life on the right".
339	She faced intense opposition from William F.
339	Buckley, Jr.
339	National Review magazine.
339	They published numerous criticisms in the 1950s and 1960s by Whittaker Chambers, Garry Wills, and M.
339	Stanton Evans.
339	Nevertheless, her influence among conservatives forced Buckley and other National Review contributors to reconsider how traditional notions of virtue and Christianity could be integrated with support for capitalism.
339	The political figures who cite Rand as an influence are usually conservatives (often members of the United States Republican Party), despite Rand taking some positions that are atypical for conservatives, such as being pro-choice and an atheist.
339	A 1987 article in The New York Times referred to h--DASHBot--> |der as the Reagan administration's "novelist laureate".
339	Republican Congressmen and conservative pundits have acknowledged her influence on their lives and recommended her novels.
339	The late-2000s financial crisis spurred renewed interest in her works, especially Atlas Shrugged, which some saw as foreshadowing the crisis, and opinion articles compared real-world events with the plot of the novel.
339	During this time, signs mentioning Rand and her fictional hero John Galt appeared at Tea Party protests.
339	There was also increased criticism of her ideas, especially from the political left, with critics blaming the economic crisis on her support of selfishness and free markets, particularly through her influence on Alan Greenspan.
339	For example, Mother Jones remarked that "Rand's particular genius has always been her ability to turn upside down traditional hierarchies and recast the wealthy, the talented, and the powerful as the oppressed", while The Nation alleged similarities between the "moral syntax of Randianism" and fascism.
339	Academic reaction During Rand's lifetime her work received little attention from academic scholars.
339	When the first academic book about Rand's philosophy appeared in 1971, its author declared writing about Rand "a treacherous undertaking" that could lead to "guilt by association" for taking her seriously.
339	A few articles about Rand's ideas appeared in academic journals before her death in 1982, many of them in The Personalist.
339	One of these was "On the Randian Argument" by libertarian philosopher Robert Nozick, who argued that her meta-ethical argument is unsound and fails to solve the is–ought problem posed by David Hume.
339	Some responses to Nozick by other academic philosophers were also published in The Personalist arguing that Nozick misstated Rand's case.
339	Academic consideration of Rand as a literary figure during her life was even more limited.
339	Academic Mimi Gladstein was unable to find any scholarly articles about Rand's novels when she began researching her in 1973, and only three such articles appeared during the rest of the 1970s.
339	Since Rand's death, interest in her work has gradually increased.
339	Historian Jennifer Burns has identified "three overlapping waves" of scholarly interest in Rand, the most recent of which is "an explosion of scholarship" since the year 2000.
339	However, few universities currently include Rand or Objectivism as a philosophical specialty or research area, with many literature and philosophy departments dismissing her as a pop culture phenomenon rather than a subject for serious study.
339	Gladstein, Chris Matthew Sciabarra, Allan Gotthelf, Edwin A.
339	Locke and Tara Smith have taught her work in academic institutions.
339	Sciabarra co-edits the Journal of Ayn Rand Studies, a nonpartisan peer-reviewed journal dedicated to the study of Rand's philosophical and literary work.
339	In 1987 Gotthelf helped found the Ayn Rand Society with George Walsh and David Kelley, and has been active in sponsoring seminars about Rand and her ideas.
339	Smith has written several academic books and papers on Rand's ideas, including Ayn Rand's Normative Ethics: The Virtuous Egoist, a volume on Rand's ethical theory published by Cambridge University Press.
339	Rand's ideas have also been made subjects of study at Clemson and Duke universities.
339	Scholars of English and American literature have largely ignored her work, although attention to her literary work has increased since the 1990s.
339	Rand scholars Douglas Den Uyl and Douglas B.
339	Rasmussen, while stressing the importance and originality of her thought, describe her style as "literary, hyperbolic and emotional".
339	Philosopher Jack Wheeler says that despite "the incessant bombast and continuous venting of Randian rage", Rand's ethics are "a most immense achievement, the study of which is vastly more fruitful than any other in contemporary thought."
339	In the Literary Encyclopedia entry for Rand written in 2001, John David Lewis declared that "Rand wrote the most intellectually challenging fiction of her generation".
339	In a 1999 interview in the Chronicle of Higher Education, Sciabarra commented, "I know they laugh at Rand", while forecasting a growth of interest in her work in the academic community.
339	Philosopher Michael Huemer has argued that very few people find Rand's ideas convincing, especially her ethics, which he believes is difficult to interpret and may lack logical coherence.
339	He attributes the attention she receives to her being a "compelling writer", especially as a novelist.
339	Thus, Atlas Shrugged outsells not only the works of other philosophers of classical liberalism as Ludwig von Mises, Friedrich Hayek, or Frederic Bastiat, but also Rand's own non-fiction works.
339	Political scientist Charles Murray, while praising Rand's literary accomplishments, criticizes her claim that her only "philosophical debt" was to Aristotle, instead asserting that her ideas were derivative of previous thinkers such as John Locke and Friedrich Nietzsche.
339	According to Murray, "By insisting that Objectivism had sprung full blown from her own mind, with just a little help from Aristotle, Rand was being childish, as well as out of touch with reality."
339	Although Rand maintained that Objectivism was an integrated philosophical system, philosopher Robert H.
339	Bass has argued that her central ethical ideas are inconsistent and contradictory to her central political ideas.
339	Objectivist movement In 1985, Rand's heir Leonard Peikoff established the Ayn Rand Institute, a nonprofit organization dedicated to promoting Rand's ideas and works.
339	In 1990, philosopher David Kelley founded the Institute for Objectivist Studies, now known as The Atlas Society.
339	In 2001 historian John McCaskey organized the Anthem Foundation for Objectivist Scholarship, which provides grants for scholarly work on Objectivism in academia.
339	The charitable foundation of BB&T Corporation has also given grants for teaching Rand's ideas or works.
339	The University of Texas at Austin, the University of Pittsburgh, and University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill are among the schools that have received grants.
339	In some cases these grants have been controversial due to their requiring research or teaching related to Rand.
339	Selected works
340	Alain Connes (; born 1 April 1947) is a French mathematician, currently Professor at the Collège de France, IHÉS, The Ohio State University and Vanderbilt University.
340	Work Alain Connes is one of the leading specialists on operator algebras.
340	In his early work on von Neumann algebras in the 1970s, he succeeded in obtaining the almost complete classification of injective factors.
340	Following this he made contributions in operator K-theory and index theory, which culminated in the  Baum-Connes conjecture.
340	He also introduced cyclic cohomology in the early 1980s as a first step in the study of noncommutative differential geometry.
340	Connes has applied his work in areas of mathematics and theoretical physics, including number theory, differential geometry and particle physics.
340	Awards and honours Connes was awarded the Fields Medal in 1982, the Crafoord Prize in 2001 and the gold medal of the CNRS in 2004.
340	He is a member of the French Academy of Sciences and several foreign academies and societies, including the Danish Academy of Sciences, Norwegian Academy of Sciences, Russian Academy of Sciences, and US National Academy of Sciences.
340	Books * Alain Connes and Matilde Marcolli: Noncommutative Geometry, Quantum Fields and Motives, Colloquium Publications, American Mathematical Society, 2007, ISBN 978-0821842102 * Alain Connes, Andre Lichnerowicz, Marcel Paul Schutzenberger, Jennifer Gage (translator): Triangle of Thought, American Mathematical Society, 2001, ISBN 978-0821826140 * Jean-Pierre Changeux, Alain Connes, M.
340	B.
340	DeBevoise (translator): Conversations on Mind, Matter, and Mathematics, Princeton University Press, 1998, ISBN 978-0691004051 * Alain Connes: Noncommutative Geometry, Academic Press, 1994, ISBN 978-0121858605
344	Allan Dwan (April 3, 1885 – December 28, 1981) was a pioneering Canadian-born American motion picture director, producer and screenwriter.
344	Early life Born Joseph Aloysius Dwan in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, Dwan moved with his family to the United States when he was 11 years old.
344	At the University of Notre Dame, he trained as an engineer and began working for a lighting company in Chicago.
344	However, he had a strong interest in the fledgling motion picture industry and when Essanay Studios offered him the opportunity to become a scriptwriter, he took the job.
344	At that time, some of the East Coast movie makers began to spend winters in California where the climate allowed them to continue productions requiring warm weather.
344	Soon, a number of movie companies worked there year-round and, in 1911, Dwan began working part-time in Hollywood.
344	While still in New York, in 1917 he was the founding president of the East Coast chapter of the Motion Picture Directors Association.
344	Career Dwan operated Flying A Studios in La Mesa, California from August, 1911 to July, 1912.
344	Flying A was one of the first motion pictures studios in California history.
344	On August 12, 2011, a plaque was unveiled on the Wolff building at Third Ave and La Mesa Bl commemorating Dwan and the Flying A Studios origins in La Mesa, California.
344	After making a series of westerns and comedies, Dwan directed fellow Canadian Mary Pickford in several very successful movies as well as her husband, Douglas Fairbanks, notably in the acclaimed 1922 Robin Hood.
344	Following the introduction of the talkies, in 1937 he directed child-star Shirley Temple in Heidi and Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm the following year.
344	Dwan also helped launch the career of two other very successful Hollywood directors, Victor Fleming, who went on to direct The Wizard of Oz and Gone With the Wind, and Marshall Neilan, who became an actor, director, writer and producer.
344	Over his long and successful career spanning over 50 years, he directed over 400 motion pictures, many of them highly acclaimed, such as the 1949 box office smash, Sands of Iwo Jima.
344	He directed his last movie in 1961.
344	He died in Los Angeles at the age of ninety-six, and is interred in the San Fernando Mission Cemetery, Mission Hills, California.
344	Allan Dwan has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame at 6263 Hollywood Boulevard.
344	Partial filmography as director *The Gold Lust (1911) *The Restless Spirit (1913) *Back to Life (1913) *Bloodhounds of the North (1913) *The Lie (1914) *The Honor of the Mounted (1914) *Remember Mary Magdelen (1914) *Discord and Harmony (1914) *The Embezzler (1914) *The Lamb, the Woman, the Wolf (1914) *The End of the Feud (1914) *The Tragedy of Whispering Creek (1914) *The Unlawful Trade (1914) *The Forbidden Room (1914) *The Hopes of Blind Alley (1914) *Richelieu (1914) * Wildflower (1914) *A Small Town Girl (1915) *David Harum (1915) *A Girl of Yesterday (1915) *The Pretty Sister of Jose (1915) *Manhattan Madness (1916) *The Habit of Happiness (1916) *Fairbanks Fine Arts (1916) *Fairbanks Fragments (1916–1918) also screenwriter *Accusing Evidence (1916) *An Innocent Magdalene (1916) *A Modern Musketeer (1917) *Headin' South (1918) *Mr.
344	Fix-It (1918) *Robin Hood (1922) *Stage Struck (1925) *Tin Gods (1926) *The Joy Girl (1927) *The Iron Mask (1929) *Tide of Empire (1929) *The Far Call (1929) *What a Widow!
344	Counsel's Opinion (1933) *Heidi (1937) *Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm (1938) *The Three Musketeers (1939) *The Gorilla (1939) *Young People (1940) *Look Who's Laughing (1941) also producer *Friendly Enemies (1942) *Around the World (1943) also producer *Up in Mabel's Room (1944) *Abroad with Two Yanks (1944) *Getting Gertie's Garter (1945) also screenwriter *Brewster's Millions (1945) *Driftwood (1947) *Calendar Girl (1947) *Northwest Outpost (1947) also associate producer *Sands of Iwo Jima (1949) *[47) *The Wild Blue Yonder *I Dream of Jeanie (1952) *Montana Belle (1952) *Silver Lode (1954) *Passion (1954) *Cattle Queen of Montana (1954) *Tennessee's Partner (1955) *Pearl of the South Pacific (1955) *Escape to Burma (1955) *Slightly Scarlet (1956) *Hold Back the Night (1956) *The Restless Breed (1957) *The River's Edge (1957) *Enchanted Island (1958)
358	Algeria ( ), officially The People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, is a country in North Africa on the Mediterranean coast.
358	Its capital and most populous city is Algiers.
358	Algeria is a semi presidential republic, it consists of 48 provinces and 1541 communes.
358	With a population exceeding 37 million, it is the 34th most populated country on Earth.
358	With an economy based on oil resources, manufacturing has suffered, in what is called Dutch disease.
358	Sonatrach, the national oil company, is the largest company in Africa.
358	Algeria has the second largest army with the largest defense budget in Africa.
358	Algeria had a peaceful Nuclear Program by the 1990s.
358	With a total area of , Algeria is the tenth-largest country in the world and the largest in Africa, and in the Mediterranean.
358	The country is bordered in the northeast by Tunisia, in the east by Libya, in the west by Morocco, in the southwest by Western Sahara, Mauritania, and Mali, in the southeast by Niger, and in the north by the Mediterranean Sea.
358	Algeria is a member of the African Union, the Arab League, OPEC and the United Nations, and is a founding member of the Arab Maghreb Union.
358	The territory of today's Algeria was the home of many ancient prehistoric cultures, including Aterian and Capsian cultures.
358	Its area has known many empires and dynasties, including ancient Berber Numidians, Carthaginians, Romans, Vandals, Byzantines, Arab Umayyads, Berber Fatimids, Berber Almohads and later Turkish Ottomans.
358	Etymology The country's name derives from the city of Algiers.
358	The most common etymology links the city name to al-Jazā'ir (الجزائر, "The Islands"), a truncated form of the city's older name Jazā'ir Banī Mazghanna (جزائر بني مزغنة, "Islands of the Mazghanna Tribe"), employed by medieval geographers such as al-Idrisi.
358	Others  trace it to Ldzayer, the Maghrebi Arabic and Berber for "Algeria" possibly related to the Zirid Dynasty King Ziri ibn-Manad and founder of the city of Algiers.
358	History Ancient history At Ain Hanech region (Saïda Province), early remnants (200,000 BC) of hominid occupation in North Africa were found.
358	Neanderthal tool makers produced hand axes in the Levalloisian and Mousterian styles (43,000 BC) similar to those in the Levant.
358	Algeria was the site of the highest state of development of Middle Paleolithic Flake tool techniques.
358	Tools of this era, starting about 30,000 BC, are called Aterian (after the archeological site of Bir el Ater, south of Annaba).
358	The earliest blade industries in North Africa are called Iberomaurusian (located mainly in Oran region).
358	This industry appears to have spread throughout the coastal regions of the Maghreb b region).
358	This industry appears to have spread throughout the coastetween 15,000 and 10,000 BC.
358	Neolithic civilization (animal domestication and agriculture) developed in the Saharan and Mediterranean Maghrib between 6000 and 2000 BC.
358	This life, richly depicted in the Tassili n'Ajjer paintings, predominated in Algeria until the classical period.
358	The amalgam of peoples of North Africa coalesced eventually into a distinct native population that came to be called Berbers, who are the indigenous peoples of northern Africa.
358	From their principal center of power at Carthage, the Carthaginians expanded and established small settlements along the North African coast; by 600 BC, a Phoenician presence existed at Tipasa, east of Cherchell, Hippo Regius (modern Annaba) and Rusicade (modern Skikda).
358	These settlements served as market towns as well as anchorages.
358	As Carthaginian power grew, its impact on the indigenous population increased dramatically.
358	Berber civilization was already at a stage in which agriculture, manufacturing, trade, and political organization supported several states.
358	Trade links between Carthage and the Berbers in the interior grew, but territorial expansion also resulted in the enslavement or military recruitment of some Berbers and in the extraction of tribute from others.
358	By the early 4th century BC, Berbers formed the single largest element of the Carthaginian army.
358	In the Revolt of the Mercenaries, Berber soldiers rebelled from 241 to 238 BC after being unpaid following the defeat of Carthage in the First Punic War.
358	They succeeded in obtaining control of much of Carthage's North African territory, and they minted coins bearing the name Libyan, used in Greek to describe natives of North Africa.
358	The Carthaginian state declined because of successive defeats by the Romans in the Punic Wars.
358	In 146 BC the city of Carthage was destroyed.
358	As Carthaginian power waned, the influence of Berber leaders in the hinterland grew.
358	By the 2nd century BC, several large but loosely administered Berber kingdoms had emerged.
358	Two of them were established in Numidia, behind the coastal areas controlled by Carthage.
358	West of Numidia lay Mauretania, which extended across the Moulouya River in modern day Morocco to the Atlantic Ocean.
358	The high point of Berber civilization, unequaled until the coming of the Almohads and Almoravids more than a millennium later, was reached during the reign of Massinissa in the 2nd century BC.
358	After Masinissa's death in 148 BC, the Berber kingdoms were divided and reunited several times.
358	Massinissa's line survived until 24 AD, when the remaining Berber territory was annexed to the Roman Empire.
358	For several centuries Algeria was ruled by the Romans, who founded many colonies in the region.
358	Like the rest of North Africa, Algeria was one of the breadbaskets of the empire, exporting cereals and other agricultural products.
358	The Vandals of Geiseric moved into North Africa in 429, and by 435 controlled coastal Numidia.
358	They did not make any significant settlement on the land.
358	The region was later recaptured by the Eastern Roman Empire, which ruled it until the Muslim Conquest in the 7th century.
358	Middle Ages When Muslim Arabs arrived in Algeria in the mid-7th century, a large number of locals converted to the new faith.
358	After the fall of the Umayyad Arab Dynasty in 751, numerous local Berber dynasties emerged.
358	Amongst those dynasties were the Aghlabids, Almohads, Abdalwadid, Zirids, Rustamids, Hammadids, Almoravids and the Fatimids.
358	Berber Kutama of the Petite Kabylie to its cause, the Shia Fatimids overthrew the Rustamids, and conquered Egypt, leaving Algeria and Tunisia to their Zirid vassals.
358	When the latter rebelled, the Shia Fatimids sent in the Banu Hilal and Banu Sulaym Arabian tribes who unexpectedly defeated the Zirids.
358	The Berber people controlled much of the Maghreb region throughout the Middle Ages.
358	The Berbers were made up of several tribes.
358	The two main branches were the Botr and Barnès tribes, who were divided into tribes, and again into sub-tribes.
358	Each region of the Maghreb contained several tribes (for example, Sanhadja, Houaras, Zenata, Masmouda, Kutama, Awarba, and Berghwata).
358	All these tribes were independent and made territorial decisions.
358	Several Berber dynasties emerged during the Middle Ages in Maghreb, Sudan, Andalusia, Sicily, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Egypt, and other nearby lands.
358	Ibn Khaldun provides a table summarizing the Zirid, Banu Ifran, Maghrawa, Almoravid, Hammadid, Almohad, Merinid, Abdalwadid, Wattasid, Meknassa and Hafsid dynasties.
358	In the early 16th century, Spain constructed fortified outposts (presidios) on or near the Algerian coast.
358	Spain took control of Mers el Kebir in 1505; Oran in 1509; and Tlemcen, Mostaganem, and Ténès, in 1510.
358	In the same year, the merchants of Algiers ceded one of the rocky islets in their harbor to Spain, which built a fort on it.
358	The presidios in North Africa turned out to be a costly and largely ineffective military endeavor that did not guarantee access for Spain's merchant fleet.
358	Ottoman Algeria In 1516 the Muslim privateer brothers Aruj and Hayreddin Barbarossa, who operated successfully under the Hafsids, moved their base of operations to Algiers.
358	When Aruj was killed in 1518 during his invasion of Tlemcen, Hayreddin succeeded him as military commander of Algiers.
358	The Ottoman sultan gave him the title of beylerbey and a contingent of some 2,000 janissaries.
358	With the aid of this force, Hayreddin subdued the coastal region between Constantine and Oran (although the city of Oran remained in Spanish hands until 1791).
358	The next beylerbey was Hayreddin's son Hasan, who assumed the position in 1544.
358	Until 1587 the area was governed by officers who served terms with no fixed limits.
358	Subsequently, with the institution of a regular Ottoman administration, governors with the title of pasha ruled for three-year terms.
358	The pasha was assisted by janissaries, known in Algeria as the ojaq and led by an agha.
358	Discontent among the ojaq rose in the mid-1600s because they were not paid regularly, and they repeatedly revolted against the pasha.
358	As a result, the agha charged the pasha with corruption and incompetence and seized power in 1659.
358	Plague had repeatedly struck the cities of North Africa.
358	Algiers lost from 30,000 to 50,000 inhabitants to the plague in 1620–21, and suffered high fatalities in 1654–57, 1665, 1691, and 1740–42.
358	In 1671, the taifa rebelled, killed the agha, and placed one of its own in power.
358	The new leader received the title of dey.
358	After 1689, the right to select the dey passed to the divan, a council of some sixty notables.
358	It was at first dominated by theojaq; but by the 18th century, it had become the dey's instrument.
358	In 1710, the dey persuaded the sultan to recognize him and his successors as regent, replacing the pasha in that role.
358	Although Algiers remained a part of the Ottoman Empire, the Ottoman government ceased to have effective influence there.
358	The dey was in effect a constitutional autocrat.
358	The dey was elected for a life term, but in the 159 years (1671–1830) that the system survived, fourteen of the twenty-nine deys were assassinated.
358	Despite usurpation, military coups, and occasional mob rule, the day-to-day operation of government was remarkably orderly.
358	Although the regency patronized the tribal chieftains, it never had the unanimous allegiance of the countryside, where heavy taxation frequently provoked unrest.
358	Autonomous tribal states were tolerated, and the regency's authority was seldom applied in the Kabylie.
358	Privateers era   The Barbary pirates preyed on Christian and other non-Islamic shipping in the western Mediterranean Sea.
358	The pirates often took the passengers and crew on the ships and sold them or used them as slaves.
358	They also did a brisk business in ransoming some of the captives.
358	According to Robert Davis, from the 16th to 19th century, pirates captured 1 million to 1.25 million Europeans as slaves.
358	They often made raids, called Razzias, on European coastal towns to capture Christian slaves to sell at slave markets in North Africa and the Ottoman Empire.
358	In 1544, Hayreddin captured the island of Ischia, taking 4,000 prisoners, and enslaved some 9,000 inhabitants of Lipari, almost the entire population.
358	In 1551, Turgut Reis enslaved the entire population of the Maltese island of Gozo, between 5,000 and 6,000, sending the captives to Libya.
358	In 1554, pirates sacked Vieste in southern Italy and took an estimated 7,000 captives as slaves.
358	In 1558, Barbary corsairs captured the town of Ciutadella (Minorca), destroyed it, slaughtered the inhabitants and took 3,000 survivors as slaves to Istanbul.
358	Barbary pirates often attacked the Balearic Islands, and in response, the residents built many coastal watchtowers and fortified churchesd.
358	The threat was so severe that residents abandoned the island of Formentera.
358	Between 1609 to 1616, England lost 466 merchant ships to Barbary pirates.
358	In the 19th century, the pirates forged affiliations with Caribbean powers, paying a "license tax" in exchange for safe harbor of their vessels.
358	One American slave reported that the Algerians had enslaved 130 American seamen in the Mediterranean and Atlantic from 1785 to 1793.
358	Piracy on American vessels in the Mediterranean resulted in the United States initiating the First (1801–1805) and Second Barbary Wars (1815).
358	Following those wars, Algeria was weaker, and Europeans, with an Anglo-Dutch fleet commanded by the British Lord Exmouth, attacked Algiers.
358	After a nine-hour bombardment, they obtained a treaty from the Dey that reaffirmed the conditions imposed by Decatur (US navy) concerning the demands of tributes.
358	In addition, the Dey agreed to end the practice of enslaving Christians.
358	French Algeria On the pretext of a slight to their coot;Fan Affair" which wansul, the French invaded and captured Algiers in 1830.
358	The conquest of Algeria by the French was long and resulted in considerable bloodshed.
358	A combination of violence and disease epidemics caused the indigenous Algerian population to decline by nearly one-third from 1830 to 1872.
358	The population of Algeria, which stood at about 1.5 million in 1830, reached nearly 11 million in 1960.
358	French policy was predicated on "civilizing" the country, although its literacy rate of 50% in 1830, according to some Algerian historians, exceeded that of France.
358	Algeria's social fabric suffered during the occupation: literacy plummeted.
358	During this period, a small but influential French-speaking indigenous elite was formed, made up of Berbers mostly from Kabyles.
358	In the French policy of "divide to reign," its government favored the Kabyles.
358	About 80% of Indigenous Schools were constructed for Kabyles.
358	From 1848 until independence, France administered the whole Mediterranean region of Algeria as an integral part and département of the nation.
358	One of France's longest-held overseas territories, Algeria became a destination for hundreds of thousands of European immigrants, who became known as colons and later, as pieds-noirs.
358	Between 1825 and 1847, 50,000 French people emigrated to Algeria.
358	These settlers benefited from the French government's confiscation of communal land from tribal peoples, and the application of modern agricultural techniques that increased the amount of arable land.
358	Gradually, dissatisfaction among the Muslim population, which lacked political and economic status in the colonial system, gave rise to demands for greater political autonomy, and eventually independence, from France.
358	Tensions between the two population groups came to a head in 1954, when the first violent events of what was later called the Algerian War began.
358	Historians have estimated that between 30,000 and 150,000 Harkis and their dependents were killed by the Front de Libération Nationale (FLN) or by lynch mobs in Algeria.
358	The FLN used terrorist attacks in Algeria and France as part of its war, and the French conducted severe reprisals and repression.
358	The war concluded in 1962, when Algeria gained complete independence following the March 1962 Evian agreements and the July 1962 self-determination referendum.
358	Independence Algeria's first president was the FLN leader Ahmed Ben Bella.
358	Morocco's claim to portions of western Algeria led to the Sand War in 1963.
358	Ben Bella was overthrown in 1965 by Houari Boumédienne, his former ally and defense minister.
358	Under Ben Bella, the government had become increasingly socialist and authoritarian; Boumédienne continued this trend.
358	But, he relied much more on the army for his support, and reduced the sole legal party to a symbolic role.
358	He collectivised agriculture and launched a massive industrialization drive.
358	Oil extraction facilities were nationalized.
358	This was especially beneficial to the leadership after the international 1973 oil crisis.
358	In the 1960s and 1970s under President Houari Boumediene, Algeria pursued a programme of industrialisation within a state-controlled socialist economy.
358	Boumediene's successor, Chadli Bendjedid, introduced some liberal economic reforms.
358	He promoted a policy of Arabisation in Algerian society and public life.
358	Teachers of Arabic, brought in from other Muslim countries, spread radical Islamic thought in schools and sowed the seeds of political Islamism.
358	The Algerian economy became increasingly dependent on oil, leading to hardship when the price collapsed during the 1980s oil glut.
358	Economic recession caused by the crash in world oil prices resulted in Algerian social unrest during the 1980s; by the end of the decade, Bendjedid introduced a multi-party system.
358	Political parties developed, such as the Front Islamique du Salut (FIS), a broad coalition of Islamist groups.
358	Civil War and aftermath In December 1991 the Front Islamique du Salut dominated the first of two rounds of legislative elections.
358	Fearing the election of an Islamist government, the authorities intervened on 11 January 1992, cancelling the elections.
358	Bendjedid resigned and a High Council of State was installed to act as Presidency.
358	It banned the FIS, triggering a civil insurgency between its armed wing, the Armed Islamic Group, and the national armed forces, in which more than 100,000 persons are thought to have died.
358	The Armed Islamic Group declared a ceasefire in October 1997.
358	Algeria held elections in 1999, which wt;faco" /> Algeria heere won by President Abdelaziz Bouteflika.
358	He worked to restore political stability to the country  and announced a 'Civil Concord' initiative, approved in a referendum, under which many political prisoners were pardoned, and several thousand members of armed groups were granted exemption from prosecution under a limited amnesty, in force until 13 January 2000.
358	The AIS disbanded and levels of insurgent violence fell rapidly.
358	The Groupe Salafiste pour la Prédication et le Combat (GSPC), a splinter group of the Group Islamic Armée, continued a terrorist campaign against the Government.
358	Bouteflika was re-elected in the April 2004 presidential election after campaigning on a programme of national reconciliation.
358	The programme comprised economic, institutional, political and social reform to modernise the country, raise living standards, and tackle the causes of alienation.
358	It also included a second amnesty initiative, the Charter for Peace and National Reconciliation, which was approved in a referendum in September 2005.
358	It offered amnesty to most guerrillas and Government security forces.
358	In November 2008, the Algerian Constitution was amended following a vote in Parliament, removing the two-term limit on Presidential incumbents.
358	This change enabled Bouteflika to stand for re-election in the 2009 presidential elections, and he was re-elected in April 2009.
358	During his election campaign and following his re-election, Bouteflika promised to extend the programme of national reconciliation and a $150-billion spending programme to create three million new jobs, the construction of one million new housing units, and to continue public sector and infrastructure modernisation programmes.
358	A continuing series of protests throughout the country started on 28 December 2010, inspired by similar protests across the Middle East and North Africa.
358	On 24 February 2011, the government lifted Algeria's 19-year-old state of emergency.
358	The government enacted legislation dealing with political parties, the electoral code, and the representation of women in elected bodies.
358	In April 2011, Bouteflika promised further constitutional and political reform.
358	Geography  Algeria is the largest country in Africa, the Arab world, and the Mediterranean Basin.
358	Its southern part includes a significant portion of the Sahara.
358	To the north, the Tell Atlas form with the Saharan Atlas, further south, two parallel sets of reliefs in approaching eastbound, and between which are inserted vast plains and highlands.
358	Both Atlas tend to merge in eastern Algeria.
358	The vast mountain ranges of Aures and Nememcha occupy the entire northeastern Algeria and are delineated by the Tunisian border.
358	The highest point is Mount Tahat ( m).
358	Algeria lies mostly between latitudes 19° and 37°N (a small area is north of 37°), and longitudes 9°W and 12°E.
358	Most of the coastal area is hilly, sometimes even mountainous, and there are a few natural harbours.
358	The area from the coast to the Tell Atlas is fertile.
358	South of the Tell Atlas is a steppe landscape ending with the Saharan Atlas; farther south, there is the Sahara desert.
358	The Ahaggar Mountains (), also known as the Hoggar, are a highland region in central Sahara, southern Algeria.
358	They are located about 1500 km south of the capital, Algiers, and just west of Tamanghasset.
358	Algiers, Oran, Constantine, Tizi Ouzou and Annaba are Algeria's main cities.
