358	Climate and hydrology  In this region, midday desert temperatures can be hot year round.
358	After sunset, however, the clear, dry air permits rapid loss of heat, and the nights are cool to chilly.
358	Enormous daily ranges in temperature are recorded.
358	The highest official temperature was  at In Salah.
358	Rainfall is fairly plentiful along the coastal part of the Tell Atlas, ranging from 400 to annually, the amount of precipitation increasing from west to east.
358	Precipitation is heaviest in the northern part of eastern Algeria, where it reaches as much as 1000 mm in some years.
358	Farther inland, the rainfall is less plentiful.
358	Prevailing winds that are easterly and north-easterly in summer change to westerly and northerly in winter and carry with them a general increase in precipitation from September through December, a decrease in the late winter and spring months, and a near absence of rainfall during the summer months.
358	Algeria also has ergs, or sand dunes, between mountains.
358	Among these, in the summer time when winds are heavy and gusty, temperatures can get up to 110 °F.
358	Fauna and Flora  The varied vegetation of Algeria includes coastal, mountainous and grassy desert-like regions which all support a wide range of wildlife.
358	Many of the creatures comprising the Algerian wildlife live in close proximity to civilization.
358	The most commonly seen animals include the wild boars, jackals, and gazelles, although it is not uncommon to spot fennecs (foxes), and jerboas.
358	Algeria also has a few panther, leopard and cheetah populations, but these are seldom seen.
358	A variety of bird species makes the country an attraction for bird watchers.
358	The forests are inhabited by boars and jackals.
358	Barbary macaques are the sole native monkey.
358	Snakes, monitor lizards, and numerous other reptiles can be found living among an array of rodents throughout the semi arid regions of Algeria.
358	Many animals are now extinct, among which the Barbary lions and bears.
358	In the north, some of the native flora includes Macchia scrub, olive trees, oaks, cedars and other conifers.
358	The mountain regions contain large forests of evergreens (Aleppo pine, juniper, and evergreen oak) and some deciduous trees.
358	Fig, eucalyptus, agave, and various palm trees grow ind some deciduous trees.
358	The grape vine is indigenous to the coast.
358	In the Sahara region, some oases have palm trees.
358	Acacias with wild olives are the predominant flora in the remainder of the Sahara.
358	Camels are used extensively; the desert also abounds with poisonous and nonpoisonous snakes, scorpions, and numerous insects.
358	Politics  Algeria is an authoritarian regime, according to the Democracy Index 2010.
358	The Freedom of the Press 2009 report gives it rating "Not Free".
358	Elected politicians are considered to have relatively little sway over Algeria.
358	Instead, a group of unelected civilian and military "décideurs", known as "le pouvoir" ("the power"), actually rule the country, even deciding who should be president.
358	The most powerful man may be Mohamed Mediène, head of the military intelligence.
358	In recent years, many of these generals have died or retired.
358	After the death of General Larbi Belkheir, Bouteflika put loyalists in key posts, notably at Sonatrach, and secured constitutional amendments that make him re-electable indefinitely.
358	The head of state is the president of Algeria, who is elected for a five-year term.
358	The president was formerly limited to two five-year terms, but a constitutional amendment passed by the Parliament on 11 November 2008 removed this limitation.
358	Algeria has universal suffrage at 18 years of age.
358	The President is the head of the army, the Council of Ministers the High Security Council.
358	He appoints the Prime Minister who is also the head of government.
358	The Algerian parliament is bicameral; the lower house, the People's National Assembly, has 462 members who are directly elected for five-year terms, while the upper house, the Council of the Nation, has 144 members serving six-year terms, of which 96 members are chosen by local assemblies and 48 are appointed by the president.
358	According to the constitution, no political association may be formed if it is "based on differences in religion, language, race, gender, profession or region".
358	In addition, political campaigns must be exempt from the aforementioned subjects.
358	Parliamentary elections were last held in May 2012, and were judged to be largely free by international monitors, though local groups alleged fraud and irregularities.
358	In the elections, the FLN won 221 seats, the military-backed National Rally for Democracy won 70, and the Islamist Green Algeria Alliance won 47.
358	Foreign relations In October 2009, Algeria cancelled a weapons deal with France over the possibility of inclusion of Israeli parts in them.
358	Tensions between Algeria and Morocco in relation to the Western Sahara have been an obstacle to tightening the Arab Maghreb Union, nominally established in 1989, but which has carried little practical weight.
358	Military The military of Algeria consists of the People's National Army (ANP), the Algerian National Navy (MRA), and the Algerian Air Force (QJJ), plus the Territorial Air Defense Force.
358	It is the direct successor of the Armée de Libération Nationale (ALN), the armed wing of the nationalist National Liberation Front which fought French colonial occupation during the Algerian War of Independence (1954–62).
358	Total military personnel include 147,000 active, 150,000 reserve, and 187,000 paramilitary staff (2008 estimate).
358	Service in the military is compulsory for men aged 19–30, for a total of 18 months (six training and 12 in civil projects).
358	The total military expenditure in 2006 was estimated variously at 2.7% of GDP (3,096 million), or 3.3% of GDP.
358	In 2007, the Algerian Air Force signed a deal with Russia to purchase 49 MiG-29SMT and 6 MiG-29UBT at an estimated cost of $1.9 billion.
358	It also agreed to return old aircraft purchased from the former USSR.
358	Russia is also building two 636-type diesel submarines for Algeria.
358	Provinces and districts  Algeria is divided into 48 provinces (wilayas), 553 districts (daïras) and 1,541 municipalities (baladiyahs).
358	Each province, district, and municipality is named after its seat, which is usually the largest city.
358	The administrative divisions have changed several times since independence.
358	When introducing new provinces, the numbers of old provinces are kept, hence the non-alphabetical order.
358	With their official numbers, currently (since 1983) they are: Economy Algeria is classified as an upper middle income country by the World Bank.
358	The economy remains dominated by the state, a legacy of the country's socialist post-independence development model.
358	In recent years the Algerian Government has halted the privatization of state-owned industries and imposed restrictions on imports and foreign involvement in its economy.
358	Algeria has struggled to develop industries outside of hydrocarbons in part because of high costs and an inert state bureaucracy.
358	The government's efforts to diversify the economy by attracting foreign and domestic investment outside the energy sector have done little to reduce high youth unemployment rates or to address housing shortages.
358	The country is facing a number of short-term and medium-term problems, including the need to diversify the economy, strengthen political, economic and financial reforms, improve the business climate and reduce inequalities amongst regions.
358	A wave of economic protests in February and March 2011 prompted the Algerian Government to offer more than $23 billion in public grants and retroactive salary and benefit increases.
358	Public spending has increased by 27% annually during the past five years.
358	The 2010–14 public-investment programme will cost US$ 286 billion, 40% of which  will go to human development.
358	The Algerian economy grew by 2.6% in 2011, driven by public spending, in particular in the construction and public-works sector, and by growing internal demand.
358	If hydrocarbons are excluded, growth has been estimated at 4.8%.
358	Growth of 3.1% is expected in 2012, rising to 4.2% in 2013.
358	The rate of inflation was 3.9% and the budget deficit 3% of GDP.
358	The current-account surplus is estimated at 9.3% of GDP and at the end of December 2011, official reserves were put at US$ 182.2 billion.
358	Inflation, the lowest in the region, has remained stable at 4% on average between 2003 and 2007.
358	In 2011 Algeria announced a budgetary surplus of $26.93 billion, 62.46% increase in comparison to 2010 surplus.
358	In general, the country exported $73.39 billion worth of commodities while it imported $46.45 billion.
358	Thanks to strong hydrocarbon revenues, Algeria has a cushion of $173 billion in foreign currency reserves and a large hydrocarbon stabilization fund.
358	In addition, Algeria's external debt is extremely low at about 2% of GDP.
358	The economy remains very dependent on hydrocarbon wealth, and, despite high foreign exchange reserves (US$178 billion, equivalent to three years of imports), current expenditure growth makes Algeria's budget more vulnerable to the risk of prolonged lower hydrocarbon revenues.
358	In 2011, the agricultural sector and services recorded growth of 10% and 5.3%, respectively.
358	About 14% of the labor force are employed in the agricultural sector.
358	Fiscal policy in 2011 remained expansionist and made it possible to maintain the pace of public investment and to contain the strong demand for jobs and housing.
358	Algeria has not joined the WTO, despite several years of negotiations.
358	In March 2006, Russia agreed to erase $4.74 billion of Algeria's Soviet-era debt during a visit by Russian President Vladimir Putin to the country, the first by a Russian leader in half a century.
358	In return, Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika agreed to buy $7.5 billion worth of combat planes, air-defense systems and other arms from Russia, according to the head of Russia's state arms exporter Rosoboronexport.
358	Hydrocarbons Algeria, whose economy is reliant on petroleum, has been an OPEC member since 1969.
358	Its crude oil production stands at around 1.1 million barrels/day, but it is also a major gas producer and exporter, with important links to Europe.
358	Hydrocarbons have long been the backbone of the economy, accounting for roughly 60% of budget revenues, 30% of GDP, and over 95% of export earnings.
358	Algeria has the 10th-largest reserves of natural gas in the world and is the sixth-largest gas exporter.
358	The U.S.
358	Energy Information Administration reported that in 2005, Algeria had 160 Tcuft of proven natural-gas reserves.
358	It also ranks 16th in oil reserves.
358	Non-hydrocarbon growth for 2011 was projected at 5%.
358	To cope with social demands, the authorities raised expenditure, especially on basic food support, employment creation, support for SMEs, and higher salaries.
358	High hydrocarbon prices have improved the current account and the already large international reserves position.
358	Income from oil and gas rose in 2011 as a result of continuing high oil prices, though the trend in production volume is downwards.
358	Production from the oil and gas sector in terms of volume, continues to decline, dropping from 43.2 million tonnes to 32 million tonnes between 2007 and 2011.
358	Nevertheless, the sector accounted for 98% of the total volume of exports in 2011 and 70% of budgetary receipts, or USD 71.4 billion.
358	The Algerian national oil company is Sonatrach, which plays a key role in all aspects of the oil and natural gas sectors in Algeria.
358	All foreign operators must work in partnership with Sonatrach, which usually has majority ownership in production-sharing agreements.
358	Labour market Despite a decline in total unemployment, youth and women unemployment is high.
358	Unemployment particularly affects the young, with a jobless rate of 21.5% among the 15-24 age group.
358	The overall rate of unemployment was 10% in 2011, but remained higher among young people, with a rate of 21.5% for those aged between 15 and 24.
358	The government strengthened in 2011 the job programmes introduced in 1988, in particular in the framework of the  programme to aid those seeking work (Dispositif d'Aide à l'Insertion Professionnelle).
358	Tourism  The development of the tourism sector in Algeria had previously been hampered by a lack of facilities, but since 2004 a broad tourism development strategy has been implemented resulting in many hotels of a high modern standard being built.
358	There are several UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Algeria including Al Qal'a of Beni Hammad, the first capital of the Hammadid empire; Tipasa, a Phoenician and later Roman town; and Djémila and Timgad, both Roman ruins; M'Zab Valley, a limestone valley containing a large urbanized oasis; also the Casbah of Algiers is an important citadel.
358	The only natural World Heritage Sites is the Tassili n'Ajjer, a mountain range.
358	Transport  The Algerian road network is the most dense of the African continent, its length is estimated at 180,000 km of highways, with a rate of more than 3 756 structures and coating of 85%.
358	This network should be complemented by a major highway infrastructure being completed, the East-West Highway.
358	It is a 3-way 1 216 km, linking the city of Annaba in the extreme east to the city of Tlemcen in the far West.
358	Algeria is also crossed by the Trans-Sahara Highway, which is now totally paved.
358	This road is pushed forward by the Algerian Government to increase trade between the six countries crossed (Algeria, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Chad and Tunisia).
358	Demographics  As of a January 2010 estimate, Algeria's population was 34.9 million, who are mainly Arab-Berber ethnically.
358	At the outset of the 20th century, its population was approximately four million.
358	About 90% of Algerians live in the northern, coastal area; the inhabitants of the Sahara desert are mainly concentrated in oases, although some 1.5 million remain nomadic or partly nomadic.
358	More than 25% of Algerians are under the age of 15.
358	Women make up 70% of the country's lawyers and 60% of its judges, and also dominate the field of medicine.
358	Increasingly, women are contributing more to household income than men.
358	Sixty percent of university students are women, according to university researchers.
358	USCRI estimates that 95,700 refugees and asylum-seekers have sought refuge in Algeria.
358	This includes roughly 90,000 from Western Sahara and 4,100 from Palestine.
358	Between 90,000 and 165,000 Sahrawis from Western Sahara live in the Sahrawi refugee camps, in western Algerian Sahara desert.
358	Chinese migrant workers lived in Algeria.
358	The largest concentration of Algerian migrants outside Algeria is in France, which has reportedly over 1.7 million Algerians of up to the 2nd generation.
358	Ethnic groups  The Berbers are the indigenous ethnic group of Algeria and are believed to be the ancestral stock on which elements from the Phoenicians, Romans, Byzantines, Arabs, Turks as well as other ethnic groups have contributed to the ethnic makeup of Algeria.
358	Descendants of Andalusian refugees are also present in the population of Algiers and other cities.
358	The overwhelming majority of Algerians are Berbers in origins, but a  majority identifies with an Arabic-based culture.
358	Berbers are divided into many groups with varying languages.
358	The largest of these are the Kabyles, who live in the Kabylie region east of Algiers, the Chaoui of North-East Algeria, the Tuaregs in the southern desert and the Shenwa people of North Algeria.
358	There is also a minority of about 600,000 to 2 million Algerian Turks, descendants of Turks who came to the region during the Ottoman rule in North Africa.
358	Today's Turkish descendants are often called Kouloughlis, meaning descendants of Turkish men and native Algerian women.
358	During the colonial period, there was a large (15.2% in 1962) European population who became known as Pieds-Noirs.
358	They were primarily of  French origin, but there were also Spanish colonists in the west of the country, Italians and Maltese in the east, and other Europeans such as Greeks in smaller numbers.
358	Almost all of this population left during the war of independence or immediately after its end.
358	Languages  Modern Standard Arabic is the official language.
358	Algerian Arabic (Darja) is the language used by the majority of the population.
358	The dialectic variant was also influenced by the French language.
358	Berber is spoken by one fourth of the population and has been recognized as a "national language" by the constitutional amendment since 8 May 2002.
358	The Kabyle language, the predominant Berber language, is taught and is partially co-official (with a few restrictions) in parts of Kabylie.
358	Although French has no official status, Algeria is the second largest Francophone country in the world in terms of speakers and French is still widely used in the government, the culture, the media (newspapers) and the education system (since primary school) due to Algeria's colonial history.
358	It can be regarded as being the de facto co-official language of Algeria.
358	In 2008, 11.2 million Algerians could read and write in French.
358	Algeria emerged as a bilingual state after 1962.
358	Colloquial Algerian Arabic is spoken by about 72% of the population and Berb01-17}} Colloquial Algerian Arabic is spoken by about 72% of the popuer by 27-30%.
358	Religion  Islam is the predominant religion with 99% of the population.
358	Almost all Algerian Muslims follow Sunni Islam, with the exception of some 200,000 Ibadis in the M'zab Valley in the region of Ghardaia.
358	There are an estimated 10,000 Christians in Algeria as of 2008.
358	Nearly all of Algeria's Jewish community emigrated following the country's independence, although a very small number of Algerian Jews continue to live in Algiers.
358	Cities  Below is a list of the most important Algerian cities: Culture Modern Algerian literature, split between Arabic, Kabyle and French, has been strongly influenced by the country's recent history.
358	Famous novelists of the 20th century include Mohammed Dib, Albert Camus, Kateb Yacine and Ahlam Mosteghanemi while Assia Djebar is widely translated.
358	Among the important novelists of the 1980s were Rachid Mimouni, later vice-president of Amnesty International, and Tahar Djaout, murdered by an Islamist group in 1993 for his secularist views.
358	Malek Bennabi and Frantz Fanon are noted for their thoughts on decolonization; Augustine of Hippo was born in Tagaste (modern-day Souk Ahras); and Ibn Khaldun, though born in Tunis, wrote the Muqaddima while staying in Algeria.
358	The works of the Sanusi family in pre-colonial times, and of Emir Abdelkader and Sheikh Ben Badis in colonial times, are widely noted.
358	The Latin author Apuleius was born in Madaurus (Mdaourouch), in what later became Algeria.
358	Contemporary Algerian cinema is various in terms of genre, exploring a wider range of themes and issues.
358	There has been a transition from cinema which focused on the war of independence to films more concerned with the everyday lives of Algerians.
358	Art  Algerian painters, like Mohamed Racim or Baya, attempted to revive the prestigious Algerian past prior to French colonization, at the same time that they have contributed to the preservation of the authentic values of Algeria.
358	In this line, Mohamed Temam,Abdelkhader Houamel have also returned through this art, scenes from the history of the country, the habits and customs of the past and the country life.
358	Other new artistic currents including the one of M'hamed Issiakhem, Mohammed Khadda and Bachir Yelles, appeared on the scene of Algerian painting, abandoning figurative classical painting to find new pictorial ways, in order to adapt Algerian paintings to the new realities of the country through its struggle and its aspirations.
358	Mohammed Khadda and M'hamed Issiakhem have been notable in recent years.
358	Literature  The historic roots of Algerian literature goes back to the Numidian era, when Apuleius wrote The Golden Ass, the only Latin novel to survive in its entirety.
358	This period had also known Augustine of Hippo, Nonius Marcellus and Martianus Capella among many others.
358	The Middle Ages have known many Arabic writers who revolutionized the Arab world literature with authors like Ahmad al-Buni and Ibn Manzur and Ibn Khaldoun who wrote the Muqaddimah while staying in Algeria, and many others.
358	Albert Camus was an Algerian-born French pied-noir author.
358	In 1957 he was awarded the Nobel Prize in literature.
358	Today Algeria contains, in its literary landscape, big names having not only marked the Algerian literature, but also the universal literary heritage in Arabic and French.
358	As a first step, Algerian literature was marked by works whose main concern was the assertion of the Algerian national entity, there is the publication of novels as the Algerian trilogy of Mohammed Dib, or even Nedjma of Kateb Yacine novel which is often regarded as a monumental and major work.
358	Other known writers will contribute to the emergence of Algerian literature whom include Mouloud Feraoun, Malek Bennabi, Malek Haddad, Moufdi Zakaria, Ibn Badis, Mohamed Laïd Al-Khalifa, Mouloud Mammeri, Frantz Fanon, and Assia Djebar.
358	In the aftermath of the independence, several new authors emerged on the Algerian literary scene, they will attempt through their works to expose a number of social problems, among them there are Rachid Boudjedra, Rachid Mimouni, Leila Sebbar, Tahar Djaout and Tahir Wattar.
358	Currently, a part of Algerian writers tends to be defined in a literature of shocking expression, due to the terrorism that occurred during the 1990s, the other party is defined in a different style of literature who staged an individualistic conception of the human adventure.
358	Among the most noted recent works, there is the writer, the swallows of Kabul and the attack of Yasmina Khadra, the oath of barbarians of Boualem Sansal, memory of the flesh of Ahlam Mosteghanemi and the last novel by Assia Djebar nowhere in my father's House.
358	Music  Chaâbi music is a typically Algerian musical genre characterized by specific rhythms and of Qacidate (Popular poems) inypically Algeria Arabic dialect.
358	The undisputed master of this music is El Hadj M'Hamed El Anka.
358	The Constantinois Malouf style is saved by musician from whom Mohamed Tahar Fergani is one of the best performers.
358	Folk music styles include Bedouin music, characterized by the poetic songs based on long kacida (poems); Kabyle music, based on a rich repertoire that is poetry and old tales passed through generations; Shawiya music, a folklore from diverse areas of the Aurès Mountains.Rahaba music style is unique to the Aures.
358	Souad Massi is a becoming famous Algerian singer of traditional songs.
358	Other Algerian singers of the diaspora include Manel Filali in Germany and Kenza Farah in France.
358	Tergui music is sung in Tuareg languages generally, Tinariwen had a world wide success.
358	Finally, the staïfi music is born in Sétif and remains a unique style of its kind.
358	Modern music is available in several facets, Raï music is a style typical of Western Algeria.
358	Rap, relatively recent style in Algeria, is experiencing significant growth.
358	Sports  Games already existed during antiquity.
358	In the Aures, people played several games such As El Kherdba or El khergueba (chess variant).
358	Playing cards, checkers and chess games are part of Algerian culture.
358	Racing (fantasia) and the rifle shooting are part of cultural recreation of the Algerians.
358	The first Algerian, Arab and African gold medalist is Boughera El Ouafi in 1928 Olympics of Amsterdam in the Marathon.
358	The second Algerian Medalist was Alain Mimoun in 1956 Summer Olympics in Melbourne.
358	Several men and women were champions in athletics in the 1990s including Noureddine Morceli, Hassiba Boulmerka, Nouria Merah-Benida, and Taoufik Makhloufi, all specialized in middle distance running.
358	Football is the most popular sport in Algeria.
358	Several names are engraved in the history of the sport, including Lakhdar Belloumi, Rachid Mekhloufi, Hassen Lalmas, Rabah Madjer, Salah Assad and Djamel Zidane.
358	The Algeria national football team qualified for the 1982 FIFA World Cup, 1986 FIFA World Cup and 2010 FIFA World Cup.
358	In addition, several football clubs have won continental and international trophies as the club ES Sétif or JS Kabylia.
358	The Algerian Football Federation is an association of Algeria football clubs organizing national competitions and international matches of the selection of Algeria national football team.
358	Cuisine Algerian cuisine is rich and diverse.
358	The country was considered as the "granary of Rome".
358	It offers a component of dishes and varied dishes, depending on the region and according to the seasons.
358	This cuisine uses cereals as the main products, since they are always produced with abundance in the country.
358	There is not a dish where cereals are not present.
358	Algerian cuisine varies from one region to another, according to seasonal vegetables.
358	It can be prepared using meat, fish and/or vegetables.
358	Among the dishes known, couscous, the chorba, the Rechta, the Chakhchoukha, the Berkoukes, the Shakshouka, the Mthewem, the Chtitha, the Mderbel, the Dolma, the Brik or Bourek, the Garantita, Lham'hlou, etc.
358	Merguez sausage is very used in Algeria, but it differs, depending on the region and on the added spices.
358	The cakes are marketed and can the found in cities either in Algeria or in Europe or North America.
358	However, traditional cakes made at home have a vast directory of revenue, according to the habits and customs of each family.
358	Among these cakes, there are Tamina, Chrik, Garn logzelles, Griouech, Kalb el-louz, Makroud, Mbardja, Mchewek, Samsa, Tcharak, Baghrir, Khfaf, Zlabia, Aarayech, Ghroubiya, Mghergchette.
358	The Algerian pastry also contains Tunisian or French cakes and it is marketed.
358	The bread may be cooked such as Kessra or Khmira or Harchaya, chopsticks and so-called washers Khoubz dar or Matloue.
358	Health In 2002, Algeria had inadequate numbers of physicians (1.13 per 1,000 people), nurses (2.23 per 1,000 people), and dentists (0.31 per 1,000 people).
358	Access to "improved water sources" was limited to 92% of the population in urban areas and 80% of the population in rural areas.
358	Some 99% of Algerians living in urban areas, but only 82% of those living in rural areas, had access to "improved sanitation".
358	According to the World Bank, Algeria is making progress toward its goal of "reducing by half the number of people without sustainable access to improved drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015".
358	Given Algeria's young population, policy favors preventive health care and clinics over hospitals.
358	In keeping with this policy, the government maintains an immunization program.
358	However, poor sanitation and unclean water still cause tuberculosis, hepatitis, measles, typhoid fever, cholera and dysentery.
358	The poor generally receive health care free of charge.
358	Health records have been maintained in Algeria since 1882 and began adding Muslims living in the South to their Vital record database in 1905 during French rule.
358	Education  Since the 1970s, in a centralized system that was designed to significantly reduce the rate of illiteracy, the Algerian Government introduced a decree by which the school became compulsory for all children aged between 6 and 15 years who have the ability to track their learning through the 20 facilities built since independence, now the literacy rate is around 78.7%.
358	Since 1972, Arabic is used as the language of instruction during the first nine years of schooling.
358	From the third year, French is taught and it is also the language of instruction for science classes.
358	The students can also learn English, Italian, Spanish and German.
358	In 2008, new programs at the elementary appeared, therefore the compulsory schooling does not start at the age of six anymore, but at the age of five.
358	Apart from the 122 private, learning at school, the Universities of the State are free of charge.
358	After nine years of primary school, students can go to the high school or to an educational institution.
358	The school offers two programs: general or technical.
358	At the end of the third year of secondary sc.
358	The school offers twhool, students pass the exam of the Bachelor's degree, which allows once it is successful to pursue graduate studies in universities and institutes.
358	Education is officially compulsory for children between the ages of six and 15.
358	In 2008, the illiteracy rate for people over 10 was 22.3%, 15.6% for men and 29.0% for women.
358	The province with the lowest rate of illiteracy was Algiers Province at 11.6%, while the province with the highest rate was Djelfa Province at 35.5%.
358	Algeria has 26 universities and 67 institutions of higher education, which must accommodate a million Algerians and 80,000 foreign students in 2008.
358	The University of Algiers, founded in 1879, is the oldest, it offers education in various disciplines (law, medicine, science and letters).
358	Even if some of them offer instruction in Arabic like areas of law and the economy, most of the other sectors as science and medicine continue to be provided in French and English.
358	Among the most important universities, there are the University of sciences and technology Houari Boumediene, the University of Mentouri Constantine, Oran Es-Senia University.
358	Best universities of qualifications remain the University of Tlemcen and Batna Hadj Bereket, they occupy the 26th and 45th row in Africa, which is a very bad standing.
359	This is a list of characters in Ayn Rand's novel Atlas Shrugged.
359	Major characters The following are major characters from the novel.
359	Protagonists ays on Ayn Rand's Atlas Shrugged or A Dagny Taggart Dagny Taggart is the protagonist of the novel.
359	She is Vice-President in Charge of Operations for Taggart Transcontinental, under her brother, James Taggart.
359	However, due to James' incompetence, it is Dagny who is responsible for all the workings of the railroad.
359	Dagny has three romantic relationships, each with a man of ability: Francisco d'Anconia, Hank Rearden, and John Galt.
359	Galt marks the pinnacle of everything Dagny seeks in the world and is the kind of man alluded to in her youth when she imagines a man standing off in the distance, at the end of a great set of railroad tracks and all her struggles.
359	The essential drama of Dagny's character is her struggle to reconcile the life she lives and the railroad which she loves with the moral code of those who wish to destroy it.
359	She believes these destroyers simply want to heap burdens upon her for the sake of others, which she has the ability to carry.
359	Like Hank, she believes they want to live, but are too stupid and incompetent to realize how their duties and altruistic projects impede that goal.
359	It is not until she sees the man most important to her in the world - John Galt - strapped to a torture machine, about to be killed by the looters (who recognize, too, that he is the only man who can save them from economic collapse), that she realizes that the moral code of the looters is one of death: they recognize what is good and necessary for life, but wish to destroy it anyway.
359	She is a typical Randian heroine, similar to Dominique Francon (The Fountainhead) or Kira Argounova (We the Living).
359	Francisco d'Anconia Francisco d'Anconia is one of the central characters in Atlas Shrugged, and owner by inheritance of the world's largest copper mining empire.
359	He is a childhood friend, and the first love of Dagny Taggart.
359	A child prodigy of exceptional talents, Francisco was dubbed the "climax" of the d'Anconia line, an already prestigious family of skilled industrialists.
359	He attended Patrick Henry University and was a classmate of John Galt and Ragnar Danneskjöld and student of both Hugh Akston and Robert Stadler.
359	He began working at a young age, while still in school, proving that he could have made a successful career on his own merits without the aid of his family's wealth and power.
359	Francisco is one of the strikers and is slowly destroying the d'Anconia empire to put it out of the raiders' reach.
359	His actions were designed both to "trap" looters into relying upon his worthless ventures in order to disrupt their schemes and to try to show the inevitable consequences of looting.
359	He adopted the persona of a worthless playboy, by which he is known to the world, as an effective cover.
359	However, he is forced to give up Dagny, knowing that she would not be ready to join the strikers.
359	He remains deeply in love with her throughout the book, while also being a good and loyal friend of her other two lovers, Hank Rearden and John Galt.
359	His full name is given as Francisco Domingo Carlos Andres Sebastián d'Anconia.
359	John Galt The enigmatic John Galt is the primary male hero of Atlas Shrugged.
359	He initially appears as an unnamed menial worker for Taggart Transcontinental, who often dines with Eddie Willers in the employee's cafeteria, and leads Eddie to reveal important information about Dagny Taggart and Taggart Transcontinental.
359	Only Eddie's side of their conversations is given in the novel.
359	Eddie tells him which suppliers and contractors Dagny is most dependent on; these men are consistently the next to disappear.
359	Later in the novel, the reader discovers this worker's true identity.
359	Before working for Taggart Transcontinental, Galt worked as an engineer for the Twentieth Century Motor Company.
359	While there, he invented his generator that produces electricity from static electricity in the environment.
359	His Prototype may or may not have been completed when he left due to the management deciding on a communistic pay system.
359	This Prototype was found by Dagny when she and Hank Rearden made a trip to the long-closed Twentieth Century Motor factory.
359	Dagny would hire Quenten Daniels to try to figure out how the machine worked.
359	Galt would take over the radio airwaves during Mr.
359	Thompson's much heralded speech at the end of the book and give his long soliloquy.
359	Henry "Hank" Rearden Henry (also known as "Hank") is one of the central characters in Atlas Shrugged.
359	Like many of Rand's capitalist characters, he is a self-made man.
359	He owns the most important steel company in the United States.
359	He invents Rearden Metal, an alloy stronger than steel (with similar properties to stainless steel).
359	He lives in Philadelphia with his wife Lillian, his brother Philip, and his elderly mother, all of whom he supports.
359	Hank Rearden knows something is wrong with the world but he is unable to define the problem.
359	His friend, Francisco d'Anconia, helps him understand and by this mechanism the reader is also prepared to understand the secret when it is revealed explicitly in Galt's Speech.
359	Rearden also serves to illustrate Rand's theory of sex.
359	Lillian Rearden cannot appreciate Hank Rearden's virtues, and she is portrayed as being disgusted by sex.
359	Dagny Taggart clearly does appreciate Rearden's virtues, and this appreciation evolves into sexual desire.
359	Rearden is torn because he accepts the premises of the traditional view of sex as a lower instinct, but he responds sexually to Dagny, who represents his highest values.
359	Rearden struggles to resolve this internal conflict, and in doing so, illustrates Rand's sexual theory.
359	Eddie Willers Edwin "Eddie" Willers is the Special Assistant to the Vice-President in Charge of Operations at Taggart Transcontinental.
359	He grew up with Dagny Taggart.
359	His father and grandfather worked for the Taggarts, and he followed in their footsteps.
359	He is completely loyal to Dagny and to Taggart Transcontinental.
359	He is also secretly in love with Dagny.
359	Willers is generally assumed to represent the common man: someone who does not possess the Promethean creative ability of The Strikers, but matches them in moral courage and is capable of appreciating and making use of their creations.
359	After Dagny shifts her attention and loyalty to saving the captive Galt, he does everything he can to keep the railroad running as the country falls apart.
359	When the train he is riding on breaks down, he tries in vain to repair it as the passengers and crew abandon him, then collapses sobbing on the tracks.
359	Ragnar Danneskjöld One of the original strikers, he is now world famous as a pirate.
359	Ragnar attended Patrick Henry University and became friends with John Galt and Francisco d'Anconia while studying under Hugh Akston and Robert Stadler.
359	Danneskjöld seizes relief ships that are being sent from the United States to The People's States of Europe.
359	As the novel progresses, Danneskjöld begins to become active in American waters.
359	Danneskjöld's action is to restore to other creative people the money, in gold, which was unjustly taken away from them—specifically, their income tax payments.
359	He explains this is not altruism; his motivation is to ensure that once those espousing Galt's philosophy are restored to their rightful place in society, they will have enough capital to rebuild the world.
359	Kept in the background for much of the book, Danneskjöld makes a personal appearance when he risks his life to meet Hank Rearden in the night and hand him a bar of gold as an "advance payment" to encourage Rearden to persevere in his increasingly difficult situation.
359	Danneskjöld is married to the actress Kay Ludlow; their re in his increasingrelationship is kept hidden from the outside world, which only knows of Ludlow as a film star who retired and dropped out of sight.
359	It is mentioned that some of the strikers have strong reservations about his way of "conducting the common struggle."
359	According to Barbara Branden, who was closely associated with Rand at the time the book was written, there were sections written describing Danneskjöld's adventures at sea, which were cut from the final published text.
359	In a 1974 comment at a lecture, Ayn Rand admitted that Danneskjöld's name was a tribute to Victor Hugo.
359	The hero of Hugo's novel, Hans of Iceland, becomes the first of the Counts of Danneskjöld.
359	In the published book, Danneskjöld is always seen through the eyes of others (Dagny Taggart or Hank Rearden), except for a brief paragraph in the very last chapter.
359	Antagonists James Taggart The President of Taggart Transcontinental and the book's most important antagonist.
359	Taggart is an expert influence peddler who is, however, incapable of making operational decisions on his own.
359	He relies on his sister, Dagny Taggart, to actually run the railroad, but nonetheless opposes her in almost every endeavor.
359	In a sense, he is the antithesis of Dagny.
359	As the novel progresses, the moral philosophy of the looters is revealed: it is a code of stagnation.
359	The goal of this code is to not exist, to not move forward, to become a zero.
359	Taggart struggles to remain unaware that this is his goal.
359	He maintains his pretense that he wants to live, and becomes horrified whenever his mind starts to grasp the truth about himself.
359	This contradiction leads to the recurring absurdity of his life: the desire to destroy those on whom his life depends, and the horror that he will succeed at this.
359	In the final chapters of the novel, he suffers a complete mental breakdown upon realizing that he can no longer deceive himself in this respect.
359	Lillian Rearden The unsupportive wife of Hank Rearden.
359	They have been married eight years as the novel begins.
359	Lillian is a frigid moocher who seeks to destroy her husband.
359	She compares being Rearden's wife with owning the world's most powerful horse.
359	Since she cannot comfortably ride a horse that goes too fast, she must bridle it down to her level, even if that means it will never reach its full potential and its power will be grievously wasted.
359	Lillian tolerates sex with her husband only because she is "realistic" enough to know he is just a brute who requires satisfaction of his brute instincts.
359	She indicates that she abhors Francisco d'Anconia, because she believes he is a sexual adventurer.
359	As her motives become more clear, Lillian is found to share the sentiments of many other moochers and their worship of destruction.
359	Her actions are explained as the desire to destroy achievement in the false belief that such an act bestows a greatness to the destroyer equal to the accomplishment destroyed.
359	She seeks, then, to ruin Rearden in an effort to prove her own value.
359	Lillian achieves her goal to destroy Rearden's business, when she passes on information to James Taggart about her husband's affair.
359	This information is used to persuade Rearden to sign the Gift Certificate (which delivers all the property rights of Rearden Metal to the looters) and thereby destroys his business.
359	Lillian discovers that she can accomplish her goal to destroy the business but she can neither achieve the greatness she desires nor her goal to destroy Hank's character.
359	She uses James Taggart for sex as victory and revenge against Hank and Dagny.
359	This does give her the satisfaction she desires and she continues to manipulate Hank until he finally leaves her and joins Galt's strikers.
359	Dr.
359	Floyd Ferris Ferris is a biologist who works as "co-ordinator" at the State Science Institute.
359	He uses his position there to deride reason and productive achievement, and publishes a book entitled Why Do You Think You Think?
359	He clashes on several occasions with Hank Rearden, and twice attempts to blackmail Rearden into giving up Rearden Metal.
359	He is also one of the group of looters who tries to get Rearden to agree to the Steel Unification Plan.
359	Ferris hosts the demonstration of the Project X weapon, and is the creator of the Ferris Persuader, a torture machine.
359	When John Galt is captured by the looters, Ferris uses the device on Galt, but it breaks down before extracting the information Ferris wants from Galt.
359	Ferris represents the group which uses brute force on the heroes to achieve the ends of the looters.
359	Dr.
359	Robert Stadler A former professor at Patrick Henry University, mentor to Francisco d'Anconia, John Galt and Ragnar Danneskjöld.
359	He has since become a sell-out, one who had great promise but squandered it for social approval, to the detriment of the free.
359	He works at the State Science Institute where all his inventions are perverted for use by the military, including the instrument of his demise: Project X (Xylophone).
359	The character was, in part, modeled on J.
359	Robert Oppenheimer, whom Rand had interviewed for an earlier project, and his part in the creation of nuclear weapons.
359	To his former student Galt, Stadler represents the epitome of human evil, as the "man who knew better" but chose not to act for the good.
359	He is based on Plato.
359	Wesley Mouch The incompetent and treacherous lobbyist whom Hank Rearden reluctantly employs in Washington, who rises to prominence and authority throughout the novel through trading favours and disloyalty.
359	In return for betraying Hank by helping broker the Equalization of Opportunity Bill (which, by restricting the number of businesses each person may own to one, forces Hank to divest most of his companies), he is given a senior position at the Bureau of Economic Planning and National Resources.
359	Later in the novel he becomes its Top Co-ordinator, a position that eventually becomes Economic Dictator of the country.
359	Secondary characters The following secondary characters also appear in the novel.
359	Hugh Akston is identified as "One of the last great advocates of reason."
359	He was a renowned philosopher and the head of the Department of Philosophy at Patrick Henry University, where he taught Francisco d'Anconia, John Galt, and Ragnar Danneskjöld.
359	He was, along with Robert Stadler, a father figure to these three.
359	Akston's name is so hallowed that a young lady, on hearing that Francisco had studied under him, is shocked.
359	She thought he must have been one of those great names from an earlier century.
359	He now works as a cook in a roadside diner, and proves extremely skillful at that.
359	When Dagny tracks him down, and before she discovers his true identity, he rejects her enthusiastic offer to manage the dining car services for Taggart Transcontinental.
359	He is based on Aristotle.
359	Jeff Allen is a tramp who stows away on a Taggart train during one of Dagny's cross-country trips.
359	Instead of throwing him out, she allows him to ride as her guest.
359	It is from Allen that she learns the full story behind the collapse of the Twentieth Century Motor Company (Rand's extensive metaphor for the inherent flaws of communism), as well as a hint of John Galt's true background.
359	Calvin Atwood is owner of Atwood Light and Power Company and joins Galt's strike.
359	Cherryl Brooks is a dime store shopgirl who marries James Taggart after a chance encounter in her store the night the John Galt Line was falsely deemed hames Taggart ais greatest success.
359	She marries him thinking he is the heroic person behind Taggart Transcontinental.
359	Cherryl is at first harsh towards Dagny, having believed Jim Taggart's descriptions of his sister, until she questions employees of the railroad.
359	Upon learning that her scorn had been misdirected, Cherryl puts off apologizing to Dagny out of shame until the night before she commits suicide, when she confesses to Dagny that when she married Jim, she thought he had the heroic qualities that she had looked up to - she thought she was marrying someone like Dagny.
359	She eventually commits suicide, unable to live with her worthless husband, and unable to escape.
359	Mayor Bascom is the mayor of Rome, Wisconsin, who reveals part of the history of the Twentieth Century Motor Company.
359	Bill Brent is the chief dispatcher for the Colorado Division of Taggart Transcontinental, who tries to prevent the Taggart Tunnel disaster.
359	Dr.
359	Blodgett is the scientist who pulls the lever to demonstrate Project X.
359	Orren Boyle is the head of Associated Steel antithesis of Hank Rearden and a friend of James Taggart.
359	He is an investor in the San Sebastián Mines.
359	He disappears from the story after having a nervous breakdown following the failed 'unification' of the steel industry.
359	Laura Bradford is an actress and Kip Chalmers's mistress.
359	Kip Chalmers is a Washington man who has decided to run for election as Legislator from California.
359	On the way to his campaign, the Taggart Transcontinental train that is carrying him encounters a split rail, resulting in the destruction of its diesel engine.
359	His demands lead to a coal-burning steam engine being attached to his train in its stead and used to pull it through an eight-mile tunnel.
359	The result is the suffocation of all passengers and the destruction of the Taggart Tunnel.
359	Emma Chalmers, Kip Chalmers's mother, gains some influence after his death.
359	Known as "Kip's Ma," she starts a soybean-growing project in Louisiana and commandeers thousands of railcars to move the harvest.
359	As a result, the year's wheat crop from Minnesota never reaches the rest of the country, but instead rots in storage; also, the soybean crop is lost, having been reaped too early.
359	Dan Conway is the middle-aged president of the Phoenix-Durango railroad.
359	Running a railroad is just about the only thing he knows.
359	When the Anti-dog-eat-dog Rule is used to drive his business out of Colorado, he loses the will to fight, and resigns himself to a quiet life of books and fishing.
359	Ken Danagger owns Danagger Coal in Pennsylvania.
359	He helps Hank Rearden illegally make Rearden Metal, then later decides to quit and join Galt's strike moments before Dagny arrives to try to persuade him otherwise.
359	Quentin Daniels is an enterprising engineer hired by Dagny Taggart to reconstruct John Galt's motor.
359	Partway through this process, Quentin withdraws his effort for the same reasons John Galt himself had.
359	Dagny's pursuit of Quentin leads her to Galt's Gulch.
359	Sebastian d'Anconia was the 16th (or 17th) Century founder of the d'Anconia dynasty.
359	Escaped from Spain because of expressing his opinions too freely and coming in conflict with the Inquisition, leaving behind a palace and his beloved.
359	Started a small mine in South America, which became the beginning of a mining empire and a new fortune (and a new palace).
359	Eventually sent for his beloved who had waited for him many years.
359	He is the role model which Francisco d'Anconia looks to, as Dagny Taggart looks to Nathaniel Taggart.
359	Francisco remarks that their respective ancestors would have liked each other.
359	Balph Eubank is called "the literary leader of the age", despite the fact that he has never sold more than three thousand copies of his books.
359	He complains that it is disgraceful that artists are treated as peddlers, and that there should be a law limiting the sales of books to ten thousand copies.
359	He is a misogynist who thinks it disgusting that Dagny Taggart is a railroad president.
359	The Fishwife is one of the strikers, who earns her living by providing the fish for Hammond’s grocery market; she is described as having "dark, disheveled hair and large eyes", and is a writer.
359	Galt says she "wouldn't be published outside.
359	She believes that when one deals with words, one deals with the mind."
359	According to Barbara Branden in her book The Passion of Ayn Rand, "The Fishwife is Ayn's Hitchcock-like appearance in Atlas Shrugged."
359	So says too Leonard Peikoff.
359	Lawrence Hammond runs Hammond Cars in Colorado, one of the few companies in existence that still produces top-quality vehicles.
359	He eventually quits and joins the strike.
359	Richard Halley is Dagny Taggart's favorite composer, who mysteriously disappeared after the evening of his greatest triumph.
359	Halley spent years as a struggling and unappreciated composer.
359	At age 24, his opera Phaethon was performed for the first time, to an audience who booed and heckled it.
359	After 19 years, Phaethon was performed again, but this time it was received to the greatest ovation the opera house had ever heard.
359	The following day, Halley retired, sold the rights to his music, and disappeared.
359	It is later revealed that he has joined the strike and settled in Galt's Gulch.
359	Mrs.
359	William Hastings is the widow of the chief engineer at the Twentieth Century Motor Company.
359	Her husband quit shortly after Galt did and joined the strike some years later.
359	Her lead allows Dagny to find Hugh Akston.
359	Dr.
359	Thomas Hendricks is a famous brain surgeon who developed a new method of preventing strokes.
359	He joined Galt's strike when the American medical system was put under government control.
359	Tinky Holloway is one of the "looters" and is frequently referred to and quoted by other characters in the story, but he has only one major appearance: during the Washington meeting with Hank Rearden.
359	Lee Hunsacker is in charge of a company called Amalgamated Service when takes over the Twentieth Century Motor Company.
359	He files a lawsuit that eventually leads to Midas Mulligan and Judge Narragansett joining the strike.
359	A failed businessman, he laments constantly that no-one ever gave him a chance.
359	Gwen Ives is Hank Rearden's secretary.
359	Owen Kellogg is Assistant to the Manager of the Taggart Terminal in New York.
359	He catches Dagny Taggart's eye as one of the few competent men on staff.
359	After seeing the sorry state of the Ohio Division, she decides to make him its new Superintendent.
359	However, as soon as she returns to New York, Kellogg informs her that he is quitting his job.
359	Owen Kellogg eventually reaches, and settles in, Galt's Gulch.
359	Fred Kinnan is a labor leader and member of the looter cabal.
359	Unlike the others, however, Kinnan is straightforward and honest about his purpose.
359	Kinnan is the only one to openly state the true motivations of himself and his fellow conspirators.
359	At the end of Galt's 3 hour speech, he expresses admiration for the man, as he says what he means.
359	Despite this, Kinnan admits that he is one of the people Galt is out to destroy.
359	Paul Larkin is an unsuccessful, middle-aged businessman, a friend of the Rearden family.
359	He meets with the other Looters to wssful, middle-aork out a plan to bring Rearden down.
359	James Taggart knows he is friends with Hank Rearden and challenges his loyalty, and Larkin assures Taggart that he will go along with them.
359	Eugene Lawson heads the Community Bank of Madison, then gets a job with the government when it his bank goes bankrupt.
359	One of the looter's cabal, he is a collectivist who abhors production and money-making.
359	Mort Liddy is a hack composer who writes trite scores for movies and modern symphonies to which no one listens.
359	He believes melody is a primitive vulgarity.
359	He is one of Lillian Rearden's friends and a member of the cultural elite.
359	Clifton Locey is a friend of Jim Taggart who takes the position of vice-president of operation when Dagny Taggart quits.
359	Pat Logan is the engineer on the first run of the John Galt Line.
359	He later strikes.
359	Kay Ludlow is a beautiful actress and the wife of Ragnar Danneskjöld.
359	Dick McNamara is a contractor who finished the San Sebastian Line.
359	Dagny Taggart plans to hire him to lay the new Rearden Metal track for the Rio Norte Line, but before she does so, he mysteriously disappears.
359	She later discovers that he has joined the strike and settled in Galt's Gulch.
359	Cuffy Meigs is the Director of Unification for the railroad business.
359	He carries a pistol and a lucky rabbit's foot, and he dresses in a military uniform, and has been described as "impervious to thought".
359	Meigs seizes control of Project X and accidentally destroys it, demolishing the country's last railroad bridge across the Mississippi River and killing himself, his men, and Dr.
359	Stadler.
359	Dave Mitchum is a state-hired superintendent of the Colorado Division of Taggart Transcontinental.
359	He is partially responsible for the Taggart Tunnel disaster.
359	Chick Morrison holds the position of "Morale Conditioner" in the government.
359	He quits when society begins to collapse and flees to a stronghold in Tennessee.
359	His fellow looters consider it unlikely that he will survive.
359	Horace Bussby Mowen is the president of the Amalgamated Switch and Signal Company, Inc.
359	Connecticut.
359	He is a businessman who sees nothing wrong with the moral code that is destroying society and would never dream of saying he is in business for any reason other than the good of society.
359	Dagny Taggart hires Mowen to produce switches made of Rearden Metal.
359	He is reluctant to build anything with this unproven technology, and has to be cajoled into accepting the contract.
359	When pressured by public opinion, he discontinues production of the switches, forcing Dagny to find an alternative source.
359	Midas Mulligan is a wealthy banker who mysteriously disappeared in protest after he was given a court order to lend money to an incompetent applicant.
359	When the order came down he liquidated his entire business, paid off his depositors, and joined Galt's strike.
359	He is the legal owner of the land where Galt's Gulch is located.
359	Mulligan's birth name was Michael, but he had it legally changed after a news article called him "Midas" in a derogatory fashion, which Mulligan took as a compliment.
359	Judge Narragansett is an American jurist who ruled in favor of Midas Mulligan during the case brought against him by the incompetent loan applicant.
359	When Narragansett's ruling was reversed on appeal, he retired and joined the strike.
359	At the end of the novel, he is seen editing the United States Constitution, crossing out the contradicting amendments of it and adding an amendment to prohibit Congress from passing laws that restrain freedom of trade.
359	Ben Nealy is a railroad contractor whom Dagny Taggart hires to replace the track on the Rio Norte Line with Rearden Metal.
359	Nealy is incompetent, but Dagny can find no one better in all the country.
359	Nealy believes that anything can get done with enough muscle power.
359	He sees no role for intelligence in human achievement.
359	He relies on Dagny and Ellis Wyatt to run things, and resents them for doing it, because it appears to him like they are just bossing people around.
359	Betty Pope is a wealthy socialite who is having a meaningless sexual affair with James Taggart.
359	She is deliberately crude in a way that casts ridicule on her high social position.
359	Dr.
359	Potter holds some undefined position with the State Science Institute.
359	He is sent to try to obtain the rights to Rearden Metal.
359	Dr.
359	Simon Pritchett is the prestigious head of the Department of Philosophy at Patrick Henry University and is considered the leading philosopher of the age.
359	He believes that man is nothing but a collection of chemicals, reason is a superstition, it is futile to seek meaning in life, and the duty of a philosopher is to show that nothing can be understood.
359	Rearden's mother, whose name is not mentioned, lives with Rearden at his home in Philadelphia.
359	She is involved in charity work, and berates Rearden whenever she can.
359	She dotes on her weak son Philip Rearden.
359	Philip Rearden is the younger brother of Hank Rearden.
359	He lives in his brother's home in Philadelphia and is completely dependent on him.
359	He is resentful of his brother's charity.
359	Dwight Sanders owns Sanders Aircraft, a producer of high-quality airplanes, and joins the strike.
359	Bertram Scudder is an editorial writer for the magazine The Future.
359	He typically bashes business and businessmen, but he never says anything specific in his articles, relying on innuendo, sneers, and denunciation.
359	He wrote a hatchet job on Hank Rearden called The Octopus.
359	He is also vocal in support of the Equalization of Opportunity Bill.
359	Scudder claims that the most important thing in life is "brother love" but seems to have nothing but hatred for those around him.
359	He loses his job after Dagny Taggart reveals her affair with Hank Rearden over air on his radio show.
359	Claude Slagenhop is president of political organization Friends of Global Progress and one of Lillian Rearden's friends.
359	He believes that ideas are just air, that this is no time for talk, but for action.
359	Global Progress is a sponsor of the Equalization of Opportunity Bill.
359	Gerald and Ivy Starnes are the two surviving children of Jed Starnes; together with their since-deceased brother Eric, they instituted a communistic payment-and-benefits program at Twentieth Century Motors which drove the company into bankruptcy.
359	Gerald, a dying alcoholic, and Ivy, a pseudo-Buddhist ascetic, continue to insist that the plan was perfect and that the failure of their father's company was entirely due to the workers.
359	Eric was a weak, attention-seeking man with a pathological desire to be loved.
359	He committed suicide after the woman he loved married another man.
359	Gerald is a vain, frivolous incompetent who claims to be altruistic while throwing lavish parties using money that should be paid to his employees.
359	Ivy meanwhile is described as "pure evil", a sadist who revels in the poverty of others but has no desire for money or power herself.
359	Andrew Stockton runs the Stockton Foundry in Stockton, Colorado.
359	When he joins the strike, he opens a foundry in Galt's Gulch.
359	Nathaniel Taggart was the founder of Taggart Transcontinental.
359	He built his railroad without any government handouts, and ran the business for no other reason than to turn a profit.
359	He began as a penniless adventurer and ended up as one of the wealthiest men in the country.
359	He never earned money by force or fraud, and never apologized for becoming wealthy and successful.
359	He was one of the most hated men of his time.
359	Dagny is often inspired by looking at a statue of Nat Taggart at the railroad headquarters.
359	Mr.
359	Thompson is the "Head of the State" for the United States.
359	He is not particularly intelligent and has a very undistinguished look.
359	He knows politics, however, and is a master of public relations and back-room deals.
359	Rand's notes indicate that she modeled him on President Harry S.
359	Truman, and that she deliberately decided not to call him "President of the United States&quotn, and ; as this title has "honorable connotations" which the character does not deserve.
359	Lester Tuck is the press agent for Kip Chalmers.
359	Clem Weatherby is a government representative on the board of directors of Taggart Transcontinental.
359	Dagny considers him the least bad of the government representatives, since he does have some real knowledge on the running of trains.
359	She notices, however, that he is the least appreciated by his own bosses.
359	The Wet Nurse (Tony) is a young bureaucrat sent by the government to watch over Rearden’s mills.
359	Though he starts out as a cynical follower of the looters’ code, his experience at the mills transforms him, and he comes to respect and admire the producers.
359	He is shot attempting to inform Hank Rearden about a government plot, but does succeed in warning Rearden just before he dies.
359	Ellis Wyatt is the head of Wyatt Oil.
359	He has almost single-handedly revived the economy of Colorado by discovering a new process for extracting more oil from what were thought to be exhausted oil wells.
359	When first introduced, he is aggressive towards Dagny, whom he does not yet know and whom he blames for what are, in fact, her brother's policies which directly threaten his business.
359	When the government passes laws and decrees which make it impossible for him to continue, he sets all his oil wells on fire, leaving a jeering note: "I am leaving it as I found it.
359	Take over.
359	It's yours."
359	One particular burning well that resists all efforts to extinguish it becomes known as "Wyatt's Torch".
359	Later Dagny meets him in Galt's Gulch.
359	Notes
569	Anthropology is the "science of humanity."
569	It has origins in the humanities, the natural sciences, and the social sciences.
569	The term "anthropology" is from the Greek anthrōpos (), "man", understood to mean humankind or humanity, and -logia (-λογία), "discourse" or "study."
569	Since the work of Franz Boas and Bronisław Malinowski in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, anthropology has been distinguished from other social sciences by its emphasis on in-depth examination of context, cross-cultural comparisons, and the importance it places on participant-observation, or long-term, experiential immersion in the area of research.
569	Cultural anthropology in particular has emphasized cultural relativity,  holism and the use of findings to frame cultural critiques.
569	This has been particularly prominent in the United States, from Boas's arguments against 19th-century racial ideology, through Margaret Mead's advocacy for gender equality and sexual liberation, to current criticisms of post-colonial oppression and promotion of multiculturalism.
569	Ethnography is one of its primary methods as well as the text that is generated from anthropological fieldwork.
569	In the United States, the discipline is traditionally divided into four sub-fields: cultural anthropology, archaeology, linguistic anthropology, and biological anthropology.
569	In Europe, the discipline originated as ethnology and was originally defined as the study of social organization in non-state societies.
569	It was later renamed social anthropology.
569	It is now generally referred to as socio-cultural anthropology in most of Europe, the commonwealth, and in the parts of the world that were influenced by the European tradition.
569	Disciplines In the United States, anthropology is traditionally divided into four fields: biological or physical anthropology, social anthropology or cultural anthropology, archaeology and anthropological linguistics.
569	These fields frequently overlap, but tend to use different methodologies and techniques.
569	In Great Britain and the Commonwealth countries, the British tradition of Social Anthropology tends to dominate.
569	In some European countries, all cultural anthropology is known as ethnology (a term coined and defined by Adam F.
569	Kollár in 1783).
569	Anthropologists study topics including the origin and evolution of Homo sapiens, the organization of human social and cultural relations, human physical traits, human behavior, the variations among different groups of humans, how the evolutionary past of Homo sapiens has influenced its social organization and culture, and so forth.
569	Anthropology originated in the colonial encounter between Western people and colonized non-Western people, as Europeans tried to understand the origins of observable cultural diversity.
569	Today anthropology is a global discipline, and anthropologists study all types of societies.
569	Anthropology is one of the few places where humanities, social, and natural sciences are forced to confront one another.
569	As such, anthropology has been central in the development of several new (late 20th century) interdisciplinary fields such as cognitive science, global studies, and various ethnic studies.
569	According to Clifford Geertz, "anthropology is perhaps the last of the great nineteenth-century conglomerate disciplines still for the most part organizationally intact.
569	Long after natural history, moral philosophy, philology, and political economy have dissolved into their specialized successors, it has remained a diffuse assemblage of ethnology, human biology, comparative linguistics, and prehistory, held together mainly by the vested interests, sunk costs, and administrative habits of academia, and by a romantic image of comprehensive scholarship."
569	Sociocultural anthropology has been heavily influenced by structuralist and postmodern theories, as well as a shift toward the analysis of modern societies.
569	During the 1970s and 1990s, there was an epistemological shift away from the positivist traditions that had largely informed the discipline.
569	During this shift, enduring questions about the nature and production of knowledge came to occupy a central place in cultural and social anthropology.
569	In contrast, archaeology and biological anthropology remained largely positivist.
569	Due to this difference in epistemology, the four sub-fields of anthropology have lacked cohesion over the last several decades.
569	Sociocultural anthropology Cultural anthropology is also called socio-cultural anthropology or social anthropology (especially in the United Kingdom).
569	Cultural anthropology is the comparative study of the manifold ways in which people make sense of the world around them, while social anthropology is the study of the relationships among persons and groups.
569	Cultural anthropology is more akin to philosophy, literature and the arts, while social anthropology to sociology and history.
569	Anthropological inquiry is guided by cultural relativism, the attempt to understand other societies in terms of their own cultural symbols and values.
569	Accepting other cultures in their own terms prevents reductionism in cross-cultural comparison.
569	This project has become the field of ethnography.
569	Ethnography can refer to both a methodology and a product of research, namely a monograph or book.
569	As methodology, ethnography is based upon long-term fieldwork within a community or other research site.
569	Participant observation is one of the foundational methods of social and cultural anthropology.
569	Ethnology involves the systematic comparison of different cultures.
569	The process of participant-observation can be especially helpful to understanding a culture from an emic (or insiders) point of view.
569	The study of kinship and social organization is a central focus of cultural anthropology, as kinship is a human universal.
569	Cultural anthropology also covers economic and political organization, law and conflict resolution, patterns of consumption and exchange, material culture, technology, infrastructure, gender relations, ethnicity, childrearing and socialization, religion, myth, symbols, values, etiquette, worldview, sports, music, nutrition, recreation, games, food, festivals, and language (which is also the object of study in linguistic anthropology).
569	Comparison across cultures is a key element of sociocultural anthropology's method, including the industrialized (or de-industrialized) West.
569	Cultures in the more traditional standard cross-cultural sample of small scale societies are: See also the List of indigenous peoples.
569	Biological anthropology Biological Anthropology and Physical Anthropology are synonymous terms to describe anthropological research focused on the study of humans and non-human primates in their biological, evolutionary, and demographic dimensions.
569	It examines the biological and social factors that have affected the evolution of humans and other primates, and that generate, maintain or change contemporary genetic and physiological variation.
569	Archaeological anthropology Archaeology is the study of the human past through its material remains.
569	Artifacts, faunal remains, and human altered landscapes are evidence of the cultural and material lives of past societies.
569	Archaeologists examine these material remains in order to deduce patterns of past human behavior and cultural practices.
569	Ethnoarchaeology is a type of archaeology that studies the practices and material remains of living human groups in order to gain a better understanding of the evidence left behind by past human groups, who are presumed to have lived in similar ways.
569	Linguistic anthropology Linguistic anthropology (also called anthropological linguistics) seeks to understand the processes of human communications, verbal and non-verbal, variation in language across time and space, the social uses of language, and the relationship between language and culture.
569	It is the branch of anthropology that brings linguistic methods to bear on anthropological problems, linking the analysis of linguistic forms and processes to the interpretation of sociocultural processes.
569	Linguistic anthropologists often draw on related fields including sociolinguistics, pragmatics, cognitive linguistics, semiotics, discourse analysis, and narrative analysis.
569	Key topics by field: Socio-cultural anthropology Anthropology of art, media, music, dance & film Anthropology of art  One of the central problems in the anthropology of art concerns the universality of 'art' as a cultural phenomenon.
569	Several anthropologists have noted that the Western categories of 'painting', 'sculpture', or 'literature', conceived as independent artistic activities, do not exist, or exist in a significantly different form, in most non-Western contexts.
569	To surmount this difficulty, anthropologists of art have focused on formal features in objects which, without exclusively being 'artistic', have certain evident 'aesthetic' qualities.
569	Boas' Primitive Art, Claude Lévi-Strauss' The Way of the Masks (1982) or Geertz's 'Art as Cultural System' (1983) are some examples in this trend to transform the anthropology of 'art' into an anthropology of culturally-specific 'aesthetics'.
569	Media anthropology  Anthropology of media (also anthropology of mass media, media anthropology) emphasizes ethnographic studies as a means of understanding producers, audiences, and other cultural and social aspects of mass media.
569	The types of ethnographic contexts explored range from contexts of media production (e.g., ethnographies of newsrooms in newspapers, journalists in the field, film production) to contexts of media reception, following audiences in their everyday responses to media.
569	Other types include cyber anthropology, a relatively new area of internet research, as well as ethnographies of other areas of research which happen to involve media, such as development work, social movements, or health education.
569	This is in addition to many classic ethnographic contexts, where media such as radio, the press, new media and television have started to make their presences felt since the early 1990s.
569	Musical anthropology  Ethnomusicology is an academic field encompassing various approaches to the study of music (broadly defined) that emphasize its cultural, social, material, cognitive, biological, and other dimensions or contexts instead of or in addition to its isolated sound component or any particular repertoire.
569	Visual anthropology  Visual anthropology  is concerned, in part, with the study and production of ethnographic photography, film and, since the mid-1990s, new media.
569	While the term is sometimes used interchangeably with ethnographic film, visual anthropology also encompasses the anthropological study of visual representation, including areas such as performance, museums, art, and the production and reception of mass media.
569	Visual representations from all cultures, such as sandpaintings, tattoos, sculptures and reliefs, cave paintings, scrimshaw, jewelry, hieroglyphics, paintings and photographs are included in the focus of visual anthropology.
569	Economic, Political Economic, Applied & Development anthropology  Economic anthropology  Economic anthropology attempts to explain human economic behavior in its widest historic, geographic and cultural scope.
569	It has a complex relationship with the discipline of economics, of which it is highly critical.
569	Its origins as a sub-field of anthropology begin with the British founder of Anthropology, Bronislaw Malinowski, and his French compatriot, Marcel Mauss, on the nature of gift-giving exchange (or reciprocity) as an alternative to market exchange.
569	Economic Anthropology remains, for the most part, focused upon exchange.
569	The school of thought derived from Marx and known as Political Economy focuses on production, in contrast.
569	Economic Anthropologists have abandoned the primitivist niche they were relegated to by economists, and have now turned to examine corporations, banks, and the global financial system from an anthropological perspective.
569	Political economy Political Economy in anthropology is the application of the theories and methods of Historical Materialism to the traditional concerns of anthropology, including, but not limited to, non-capitalist societies.
569	Political Economy introduced questions of history and colonialism to ahistorical anthropological theories of social structure and culture.
569	Three main areas of interest rapidly developed.
569	The first of these areas was concerned with the "pre-capitalist" societies that were subject to evolutionary "tribal" stereotypes.
569	Sahlins work on Hunter-gatherers as the 'original affluent society' did much to disapate that image.
569	The second area was concerned with the vast majority of the world's population at the time, the peasantry, many of whom were involved in complex revolutionary wars such as in Vietnam.
569	The third area was on colonialism, imperialism, and the creation of the capitalist world-system.
569	More recently, these Political Economists have more directly addressed issues of industrial (and post-industrial) capitalism around the world.
569	Applied anthropology  Applied Anthropology refers to the application of the method and theory of anthropology to the analysis and solution of practical problems.
569	It is a, “complex of related, research-based, instrumental methods which produce change or stability in specific cultural systems through the provision of data, initiation of direct action, and/or the formulation of policy”.
569	More simply, applied anthropology is the practical side of anthropological research; it includes researcher involvement and activism within the participating community.
569	It is closely related to Development anthropology (distinct from the more critical Anthropology of development).
569	Anthropology of development The anthropology of development  tends to view development from a critical perspective.
569	The kind of issues addressed and implications for the approach  involve asking why, if a key development goal is to alleviate poverty, is poverty increasing?
569	Why is there such a gap between plans and outcomes?
569	Why are those working in development so willing to disregard history and the lessons it might offer?
569	Why is development so externally driven rather than having an internal basis?
569	In short why does so much planned development fail?
569	Anthropology of Kinship, Feminism, Gender & Sexuality Kinship & family  Kinship can refer both to the study of the patterns of social relationships in one or more human cultures, or it can refer to the patterns of social relationships themselves.
569	Over its history, anthropology has developed a number of related concepts and terms, such as descent, descent groups, lineages, affines, cognates and even fictive kinship.
569	Broadly, kinship patterns may be considered to include people related both by descent (one's social relations during development), and also relatives by marriage.
569	Feminist anthropology  Feminist Anthrovelopment), and alspology is a four field approach to anthropology (archeological, biological, cultural, linguistic) that seeks to reduce male bias in research findings, anthropological hiring practices, and the scholarly production of knowledge.
569	Anthropology engages often with feminists from non-Western traditions, whose perspectives and experiences can differ from those of white European and American feminists.
569	Historically, such 'peripheral' perspectives have sometimes been marginalized and regarded as less valid or important than knowledge from the western world.
569	Feminist anthropologists have claimed that their research helps to correct this systematic bias in mainstream feminist theory.
569	Anthropology of gender & sexuality Medical, Psychological, Cognitive & Transpersonal Anthropology Medical anthropology  Medical anthropology is an interdisciplinary field which studies "human health and disease, health care systems, and biocultural adaptation".
569	Currently, research in medical anthropology is one of the main growth areas in the field of anthropology as a whole.
