579	Alien may refer to: Classifications * Alien (law), a non-citizen resident of a country * Extraterrestrial life, life which does not originate from the Earth * Introduced species, a species not native to its environment Alien franchise * Alien (film), a 1979 film by Ridley Scott ** Aliens (film), a 1986 sequel by James Cameron ** Alien (franchise), the film franchise, including other sequels ** Alien (creature in Alien franchise) ** Alien (soundtrack) ** Aliens (soundtrack) * Aliens (novel series) * Aliens (comic book) * List of Alien and Predator games Music * Alien (album), by Strapping Young Lad * Alien (band), a 1980s Swedish rock group * The Aliens (Scottish band), a 2005–present rock group * The Aliens (Australian band), a 1970s new wave group * "Alien" (song), by Pennywise * "Alien" (Third Day song) * "Alien", a song by Bush on the album Sixteen Stone * "Alien", a song by Erasure on the album Loveboat * "Alien", a song by Japan on the album Quiet Life * "Alien", a song by Lamb on the album Fear of Fours * "Alien", a song by Nerina Pallot on the album Dear Frustrated Superstar * "Alien", a song by Thriving Ivory on their self-titled album * "Alien", a song by Tokio Hotel on the album Humanoid * "My Alien", a song by Simple Plan on the album No Pads, No Helmets...
579	Just Balls Technology * Alien (software), a Linux program * AliEn (ALICE Environment), a grid framework * Alien Technology, a manufacturer of RFID technology Other uses * Alien (shipping company), a Russian company * Alien (literary concept) * Aliens (1902 novel), by Mary Tappan Wright * The Alien (film), an incomplete 1960s Indian-American film * The Alien (Animorphs), the eighth book in the Animorphs series * Aliens (Kaypro video game), a text-only clone of Space Invaders written for the CP/M operating system * Alien Sun (born 1974), Singaporean actress * Alien, a perfume by Thierry Mugler * Aliens, a newsletter of the IUCN Invasive Species Specialist Group
580	An astronomer is a scientist who studies celestial bodies such as moons, planets, stars, nebulae, and galaxies); the physics, chemistry, and evolution of such objects; and phenomena that originate outside the atmosphere of Earth (such as supernovae explosions, gamma ray bursts, and cosmic background radiation).
580	A related but distinct subject, cosmology, is concerned with studying the universe as a whole.
580	Historically, astronomy was more concerned with the classification and description of phenomena in the sky, while astrophysics attempted to explain these phenomena and the differences between them using physical laws.
580	Today, that distinction has mostly disappeared and the terms "astronomer" and "astrophysicist" are interchangeable.
580	Professional astronomers are highly educated individuals who typically have a PhD in physics or astronomy and are employed by research institutions or universities.
580	They spend the majority of their time working on research, although they quite often have other duties such as teaching, builf their tiding instruments, or aiding in the operation of an observatory.
580	The number of professional astronomers in the United States is actually quite small.
580	The American Astronomical Society, which is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America, has approximately 7,700 members.
580	This number includes scientists from other fields such as physics, geology, and engineering, whose research interests are closely related to astronomy.
580	The International Astronomical Union comprises almost 10,145 members from 70 different countries who are involved in astronomical research at the PhD level and beyond.
580	While the number of professional astronomers worldwide is not much larger than the population of a small town, there is a huge community of amateur astronomers.
580	Most cities have amateur astronomy clubs that meet on a regular basis and often host star parties in their communities.
580	The Astronomical Society of the Pacific is the largest general astronomical society in the world, comprising both professional and amateur astronomers as well as educators from 70 different nations.
580	Like any hobby, most people who think of themselves as amateur astronomers may devote a few hours a month to stargazing and reading the latest developments in research.
580	However, amateurs span the range from so-called "armchair astronomers" to the very ambitious, who own science-grade telescopes and instruments with which they are able to make their own discoveries and assist professional astronomers in research.
580	Modern astronomers Contrary to the classical image of an old astronomer peering through a telescope through the dark hours of the night, it is very rare for a modern professional astronomer to use an eyepiece on a larger telescope.
580	It is far more common to use a charge-coupled device camera to record a long, deep exposure, allowing a more sensitive image to be created because the light is added over time.
580	Before CCDs, photographic plates were a common method of observation.
580	Modern astronomers spend relatively little time at telescopes - most spend a few weeks per year observing, and the rest of their time reducing the data (changing it from raw data to processed images) and analyzing it.
580	Many astronomers work entirely from astronomical survey or space observatory data.
580	Others work with radio telescopes like the Very Large Array, which is entirely automated, although it is maintained by telescope operators.
580	Some astronomers do not work with data at all, but instead use computational simulations or analytical models to provide analysis of observed phenomena or make predictions for observational astronomers.
580	Astronomers who serve as faculty spend much of their time teaching undergraduate and graduate classes.
580	Most universities also have outreach programs including public telescope time and sometimes planetariums as a public service to encourage interest in the field.
584	Amoeboids are single-celled life-forms characterized by an irregular shape.
584	"Amoeboid" and "amœba" are often used interchangeably even by biologists, and especially refer to a creature moving by using pseudopodia.
584	Most references to "amoebas" or "amoebae" are to amoeboids in general rather than to the specific genus Amoeba.
584	The genus Amoeba and amoeboids in general both derive their names from the ancient Greek word for change.
584	Structure Amoeboids move using pseudopodia, which are bulges of cytoplasm.
584	Amoebas breathe using their entire cell membrane that is constantly immersed in water.
584	Excess water can cross into the cytosol.
584	Amoebas have a contractile vacuole to expel excess water.
584	Food sources vary in amoeboids.
584	They may consume bacteria or vacuole to expel excother protists.
584	Some are detritivores and eat dead organic material.
584	They extend a pair of pseudopodia around food.
584	They fuse to make a food vacuole which then fuses with a lysosome to add digestive chemicals.
584	Undigested food is expelled at the cell membrane.
584	Amoebas use pseudopodia to move and feed.
584	They are powered by flexibe microfilaments near the membrane.
584	Microfilaments are at least 50% of the cytoskeleton.
584	The other parts are more stiff and are composed of intermediate filaments and microtubules.
584	These are not used in amoeboid movement, but are stiff skeletons on which organelles are supported or can move on.
584	The shells of amoebas are often composed of calcium.
584	The proteins or materials are synthesised in the cell and exported just outside the cell membrane.
584	Multicellular amoebas: Slime molds Amoebas seem to have connections with two phyla (now defunct) composed of multicellular organisms of the lineage of fungus-like protists, the so-called slime molds.
584	These two defunct phyla were the Myxomycota (i.e., plasmodial slime molds, now classified in the taxon Myxogastria), and Acrasiomycota (i.e.
584	Acrasida and Dictyosteliida).
584	These two phyla use amoeboid movement in their feeding stage.
584	The former is basically a giant multinucleate amoeba, while the latter lives solitary until food runs out; in which a colony of these functions as a unit.
584	Myxomycete slime molds use amoeboid gametes, as well.
584	Diversity They have appeared in a number of different groups.
584	Some cells in multicellular animals may be amoeboid, for instance human white blood cells, which consume pathogens.
584	Many protists also exist as individual amoeboid cells, or take such a form at some point in their life-cycle.
584	The most famous such organism is Amoeba proteus; the name amoeba is variously used to describe its close relatives, other organisms similar to it, or the amoeboids in general.
584	Classification As amoebas themselves are polyphyletic and subject to some imprecision in definition, the term "amoeboid" does not provide identification of an organism, and is better understood as description of locomotion.
584	When used in the broader sense, the term can include many different groups.
584	One source includes 97 different genera.
584	Others include far fewer.
584	Older classification In older classification systems, amoeboids, under the taxon name Sarcodina, had been divided into several morphological categories based on the form and structure of their pseudopods.
584	Amoeboids with pseudopods supported by regular arrays of microtubules were called actinopods, whereas those that weren't were called rhizopods, which were further subdivided into lobose, filose, and reticulose amoebae.
584	In contrast to "rhizopods", where most of their morphologies can be mapped to modern classification systems, "actinopods" appear to be extensively polyphyletic.
584	Actinopods are divided into radiolaria and heliozoa (itself a polyphyletic grouping).
584	Finally, there was also a strange group of giant marine amoeboids, the xenophyophores, that did not fall into any of these categories.
584	Modern classification More modern classifications are based upon cladistics.
584	It has been stated that most amoeboid are now grouped in Amoebozoa or Rhizaria.
584	However, in contexts where "amoeboid" is defined more loosely, there are many amoeboid species that are in the Excavata clade.
584	Phylogenetic analyses place these genera into the following groups (not all of these are considered amoeboid (or "amoebas") by all sources): Pathogenic interactions with other organisms Some amoeboids can infect other organisms pathogenically (causing disease): *Entamoeba histolytica is the cause of amoebiasis, or amoebic dysentery.
584	Naegleria fowleri (the "brain-eating amoeba") is a fresh-water-native species that can be fatal to humans if introduced through the nose.
584	Acanthamoeba can cause amoebic keratitis and encephalitis in humans.
584	Balamuthia mandrillaris is the cause of (often fatal) granulomatous amoebic meningoencephalitis
586	The American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII, ;) is a character-encoding scheme originally based on the English alphabet.
586	ASCII codes represent text in computers, communications equipment, and other devices that use text.
586	Most modern character-encoding schemes are based on ASCII, though they support many additional characters.
586	ASCII developed from telegraphic codes.
586	Its first commercial use was as a seven-bit teleprinter code promoted by Bell data services.
586	Work on the ASCII standard began on October 6, 1960, with the first meeting of the American Standards Association's (ASA) X3.2 subcommittee.
586	The first edition of the standard was published during 1963, a major revision during 1967, and the most recent update during 1986.
586	Compared to earlier telegraph codes, the proposed Bell code and ASCII were both ordered for more convenient sorting (i.e., alphabetization) of lists, and added features for devices other than teleprinters.
586	ASCII includes definitions for 128 characters: 33 are non-printing control characters (many now obsolete) that affect how text and space are processed and 95 printable characters, including the space (which is considered an invisible graphic).
586	The IANA prefers the name US-ASCII to avoid ambiguity.
586	ASCII was the most commonly used character encoding on the World Wide Web until December 2007, when it was surpassed by UTF-8.
586	History The American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) was developed under the auspices of a committee of the American Standards Association, called the X3 committee, by its X3.2 (later X3L2) subcommittee, and later by that subcommittee's X3.2.4 working group.
586	The ASA became the United States of America Standards Institute or USASI and ultimately the American National Standards Institute.
586	The X3.2 subcommittee designed ASCII based on the earlier teleprinter encoding systems.
586	Like other character encodings, ASCII specifies a correspondence between digital bit patterns and character symbols (i.e.
586	This allows digital devices to communicate with each other and to process, store, and communicate character-oriented information such as written language.
586	Before ASCII was developed, the encodings in use included 26 alphabetic characters, 10 nI was developeumerical digits, and from 11 to 25 special graphic symbols.
586	To include all these, and control characters compatible with the Comité Consultatif International Téléphonique et Télégraphique (CCITT) International Telegraph Alphabet No.
586	ITA2) standard, Fieldata, and early EBCDIC, more than 64 codes were required for ASCII.
586	The committee debated the possibility of a shift key function (like the Baudot code), which would allow more than 64 codes to be represented by six bits.
586	In a shifted code, some character codes determine choices between options for the following character codes.
586	It allows compact encoding, but is less reliable for data transmission; an error in transmitting the shift code typically makes a long part of the transmission unreadable.
586	The standards committee decided against shifting, and so ASCII required at least a seven-bit code.
586	The committee considered an eight-bit code, since eight bits (octets) would allow two four-bit patterns to efficiently encode two digits with binary coded decimal.
586	However, it would require all data transmission to send eight bits when seven could suffice.
586	The committee voted to use a seven-bit code to minimize costs associated with data transmission.
586	Since perforated tape at the time could record eight bits in one position, it also allowed for a parity bit for error checking if desired.
586	Eight-bit machines (with octets as the native data type) that did not use parity checking typically set the eighth bit to 0.
586	The code itself was patterned so that most control codes were together, and all graphic codes were together, for ease of identification.
586	The first two columns (32 positions) were reserved for control characters.} The "space" character had to come before graphics to make sorting easier, so it became position 20hex; for the same reason, many special signs commonly used as separators were placed before digits.
586	The committee decided it was important to support upper case 64-character alphabets, and chose to pattern ASCII so it could be reduced easily to a usable 64-character set of graphic codes.
586	Lower case letters were therefore not interleaved with upper case.
586	To keep options available for lower case letters and other graphics, the special and numeric codes were arranged before the letters, and the letter "A" was placed in position 41hex to match the draft of the corresponding British standard.
586	The digits 0–9 were arranged so they correspond to values in binary prefixed with 011, making conversion with binary-coded decimal straightforward.
586	Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters.
586	Thus #, $ and % were placed to correspond to 3, 4, and 5 in the adjacent column.
586	The parentheses could not correspond to 9 and 0, however, because the place corresponding to 0 was taken by the space character.
586	Since many European typewriters placed the parentheses with 8 and 9, those corresponding positions were chosen for the parentheses.
586	The @ symbol was not used in continental Europe and the committee expected it would be replaced by an accented À in the French variation, so the @ was placed in position 40hex next to the letter A.
586	The control codes felt essential for data transmission were the start of message (SOM), end of address (EOA), end of message (EOM), end of transmission (EOT), "who are you?"
586	WRU), "are you?"
586	RU), a reserved device control (DC0), synchronous idle (SYNC), and acknowledge (ACK).
586	These were positioned to maximize the Hamming distance between their bit patterns.
586	With the other special characters and control codes filled in, ASCII was published as ASA X3.4-1963, leaving 28 code positions without any assigned meaning, reserved for future standardization, and one unassigned control code.
586	There was some debate at the time whether there should be more control characters rather than the lower case alphabet.
586	The indecision did not last long: during May 1963 the CCITT Working Party on the New Telegraph Alphabet proposed to assign lower case characters to columns 6 and 7, and International Organization for Standardization TC 97 SC 2 voted during October to incorporate the change into its draft standard.
586	The X3.2.4 task group voted its approval for the change to ASCII at its May 1963 meeting.
586	Locating the lowercase letters in columns 6 and 7 caused the characters to differ in bit pattern from the upper case by a single bit, which simplified case-insensitive character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers.
586	The X3 committee made other changes, including other new characters (the brace and vertical line characters), renaming some control characters (SOM became start of header (SOH)) and moving or removing others (RU was removed).
586	ASCII was subsequently updated as USASI X3.4-1967, then USASI X3.4-1968, ANSI X3.4-1977, and finally, ANSI X3.4-1986 (the first two are occasionally retronamed ANSI X3.4-1967, and ANSI X3.4-1968).
586	The X3 committee also addressed how ASCII should be transmitted (least significant bit first), and how it should be recorded on perforated tape.
586	They proposed a 9-track standard for magnetic tape, and attempted to deal with some forms of punched card formats.
586	ASCII itself was first used commercially during 1963 as a seven-bit teleprinter code for American Telephone & Telegraph's TWX (TeletypeWriter eXchange) network.
586	TWX originally used the earlier five-bit Baudot code, which was also used by the competing Telex teleprinter system.
586	Bob Bemer introduced features such as the escape sequence.
586	His British colleague Hugh McGregor Ross helped to popularize this work—according to Bemer, "so much so that the code that was to become ASCII was first called the Bemer-Ross Code in Europe".
586	Because of his extensive work on ASCII, Bemer has been called "the father of ASCII."
586	On March 11, 1968, U.S.
586	President Lyndon B.
586	Johnson mandated that all computers purchased by the United States federal government support ASCII, stating: I have also approved recommendations of the Secretary of Commerce regarding standards for recording the Standard Cproved recommendations of thode for Information Interchange on magnetic tapes and paper tapes when they are used in computer operations.
586	All computers and related equipment configurations brought into the Federal Government inventory on and after July 1, 1969, must have the capability to use the Standard Code for Information Interchange and the formats prescribed by the magnetic tape and paper tape standards when these media are used.
586	Other international standards bodies have ratified character encodings such as ISO/IEC 646 that are identical or nearly identical to ASCII, with extensions for characters outside the English alphabet and symbols used outside the United States, such as the symbol for the United Kingdom's pound sterling (£).
586	Almost every country needed an adapted version of ASCII, since ASCII suited the needs of only the USA and a few other countries.
586	For example, Canada had its own version that supported French characters.
586	Other adapted encodings include ISCII (India), VISCII (Vietnam), and YUSCII (Yugoslavia).
586	Although these encodings are sometimes referred to as ASCII, true ASCII is  defined strictly only by ANSI standard.
586	ASCII was incorporated into the Unicode character set as the first 128 symbols, so the ASCII characters have the same numeric codes in both sets.
586	This allows UTF-8 to be backward compatible with ASCII, a significant advantage.
586	ASCII control characters ASCII reserves the first 32 codes (numbers 0–31 decimal) for control characters: codes originally intended not to represent printable information, but rather to control devices (such as printers) that make use of ASCII, or to provide meta-information about data streams such as those stored on magnetic tape.
586	For example, character 10 represents the "line feed" function (which causes a printer to advance its paper), and character 8 represents "backspace".
586	RFC 2822 refers to control characters that do not include carriage return, line feed or white space as non-whitespace control characters.
586	Except for the control characters that prescribe elementary line-oriented formatting, ASCII does not define any mechanism for describing the structure or appearance of text within a document.
586	Other schemes, such as markup languages, address page and document layout and formatting.
586	The original ASCII standard used only short descriptive phrases for each control character.
586	The ambiguity this caused was sometimes intentional (where a character would be used slightly differently on a terminal link than on a data stream) and sometimes accidental (such as what "delete" means).
586	Probably the most influential single device on the interpretation of these characters was the Teletype Model 33 ASR, which was a printing terminal with an available paper tape reader/punch option.
586	Paper tape was a very popular medium for long-term program storage until the 1980s, less costly and in some ways less fragile than magnetic tape.
586	In particular, the Teletype Model 33 machine assignments for codes 17 (Control-Q, DC1, also known as XON), 19 (Control-S, DC3, also known as XOFF), and 127 (Delete) became de facto standards.
586	Because the keytop for the O key also showed a left-arrow symbol (from ASCII-1963, which had this character instead of underscore), a noncompliant use of code 15 (Control-O, Shift In) interpreted as "delete previous character" was also adopted by many early timesharing systems but eventually became neglected.
586	The use of Control-S (XOFF, an abbreviation for transmit off) as a "handshaking" signal warning a sender to stop transmission because of impending overflow, and Control-Q (XON, "transmit on") to resume sending, persists to this day in many systems as a manual output control technique.
586	On some systems Control-S retains its meaning but Control-Q is replaced by a second Control-S to resume output.
586	Code 127 is officially named "delete" but the Teletype label was "rubout".
586	Since the original standard did not give detailed interpretation for most control codes, interpretations of this code varied.
586	The original Teletype meaning, and the intent of the standard, was to make it an ignored character, the same as NUL (all zeroes).
586	This was useful specifically for paper tape, because punching the all-ones bit pattern on top of an existing mark would obliterate it.
586	Tapes designed to be "hand edited" could even be produced with spaces of extra NULs (blank tape) so that a block of characters could be "rubbed out" and then replacements put into the empty space.
586	As video terminals began to replace printing ones, the value of the "rubout" character was lost.
586	DEC systems, for example, interpreted "Delete" to mean "remove the character before the cursor" and this interpretation also became common in Unix systems.
586	Most other systems used "Backspace" for that meaning and used "Delete" to mean "remove the character at the cursor".
586	That latter interpretation is the most common now.
586	Many more of the control codes have been given meanings quite different from their original ones.
586	The "escape" character (ESC, code 27), for example, was intended originally to allow sending other control characters as literals instead of invoking their meaning.
586	This is the same meaning of "escape" encountered in URL encodings, C language strings, and other systems where certain characters have a reserved meaning.
586	Over time this meaning has been co-opted and has eventually been changed.
586	In modern use, an ESC sent to the terminal usually indicates the start of a command sequence, usually in the form of a so-called "ANSI escape code" (or, more properly, a "Control Sequence Introducer") beginning with ESC followed by a "[" (left-bracket) character.
586	An ESC sent from the terminal is most often used as an out-of-band character used to terminate an operation, as in the TECO and vi text editors.
586	In graphical user interface (GUI) and windowing systems, ESC generally causes an application to abort its current operation or to exit (terminate) altogether.
586	The inherent ambiguity of many control characters, combined with their historical usage, created problems when transferring "plain text" files between systems.
586	The best example of this is the newline problem on various operating systems.
586	Teletype machines required that a line of text be terminated with both "Carriage Return" (which moves the printhead to the beginning of the line) and "Line Feed" (which advances the paper one line without moving the printhead).
586	The name "Carriage Return" comes from the fact that on a manual typewriter the carriage holding the paper moved while the position where the keys struck the ribbon remained stationary.
586	The entire carriage had to be pushed (returned) to the right in order to position the left margin of the paper for the next line.
586	DEC operating systems (OS/8, RT-11, RSX-11, RSTS, TOPS-10, etc.) used both characters to mark the end of a line so that the console device (originally Teletype machines) would work.
586	By the time so-called "glass TTYs" (later called CRTs or terminals) came along, the convention was so well established that backward compatibility necessitated continuing the convention.
586	Whetion was son Gary Kildall cloned RT-11 to create CP/M he followed established DEC convention.
586	Until the introduction of PC-DOS in 1981, IBM had no hand in this because their 1970s operating systems used EBCDIC instead of ASCII and they were oriented toward punch-card input and line printer output on which the concept of "carriage return" was meaningless.
586	IBM's PC-DOS (also marketed as MS-DOS by Microsoft) inherited the convention by virtue of being a clone of CP/M, and Windows inherited it from MS-DOS.
586	Unfortunately, requiring two characters to mark the end of a line introduces unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character when encountered alone.
586	To simplify matters plain text data streams, including files, on Multics used line feed (LF) alone as a line terminator.
586	Unix and Unix-like systems, and Amiga systems, adopted this convention from Multics.
586	The original Macintosh OS, Apple DOS, and ProDOS, on the other hand, used carriage return (CR) alone as a line terminator; however, since Apple replaced it with the Unix-based OS X operating system, they now use line feed (LF) as well.
586	Computers attached to the ARPANET included machines running operating systems such as TOPS-10 and TENEX using CR-LF line endings, machines running operating systems such as Multics using LF line endings, and machines running operating systems such as OS/360 that represented lines as a character count followed by the characters of the line and that used EBCDIC rather than ASCII.
586	The Telnet protocol defined an ASCII "Network Virtual Terminal" (NVT), so that connections between hosts with different line-ending conventions and character sets could be supported by transmitting a standard text format over the network; it used ASCII, along with CR-LF line endings, and software using other conventions would translate between the local conventions and the NVT.
586	The File Transfer Protocol adopted the Telnet protocol, including use of the Network Virtual Terminal, for use when transmitting commands and transferring data in the default ASCII mode.
586	This adds complexity to implementations of those protocols, and to other network protocols, such as those used for E-mail and the World Wide Web, on systems not using the NVT's CR-LF line-ending convention.
586	Older operating systems such as TOPS-10, along with CP/M, tracked file length only in units of disk blocks and used Control-Z (SUB) to mark the end of the actual text in the file.
586	For this reason, EOF, or end-of-file, was used colloquially and conventionally as a three-letter acronym (TLA) for Control-Z instead of SUBstitute.
586	For a variety of reasons, the end-of-text code, ETX aka Control-C, was inappropriate and using Z as the control code to end a file is analogous to it ending the alphabet, a very convenient mnemonic aid.
586	An historic common, and still prevalent, convention uses the ETX aka Control-C code convention to interrupt and halt a program via an input data stream, usually from a keyboard.
586	In C library and Unix conventions, the null character is used to terminate text strings; such null-terminated strings can be known in abbreviation as ASCIZ or ASCIIZ, where here Z stands for "zero".
586	ASCII control code chart ASCII printable characters Codes 20hex to 7Ehex, known as the printable characters, represent letters, digits, punctuation marks, and a few miscellaneous symbols.
586	There are 95 printable characters in total.
586	Code 20hex, the space character, denotes the space between words, as produced by the space-bar of a keyboard.
586	Since the space character is considered an invisible graphic (rather than a control character) and thus would not normally be visible, it is represented here by Unicode character U+2420 "␠"; Unicode characters U+2422 "␢" and U+2423 "␣" are also available for use when a visible representation of a space is necessary.
586	Code 7Fhex corresponds to the non-printable "Delete" (DEL) control character and is therefore omitted from this chart; it is covered in the previous section's chart.
586	Earlier versions of ASCII used the up-arrow instead of the caret (5Ehex) and the left-arrow instead of the underscore (5Fhex).
586	Aliases A June 1992 RFC and the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority registry of character sets recognize the following case-insensitive aliases for ASCII as suitable for use on the Internet: * ANSI_X3.4-1968 (canonical name) * iso-ir-6 * ANSI_X3.4-1986 * ISO_646.irv:1991 * ASCII (with ASCII-7 and ASCII-8 variants) * ISO646-US * US-ASCII (preferred MIME name) * us * IBM367 * cp367 * csASCII Of these, the IANA encourages use of the name "US-ASCII" for Internet uses of ASCII.
586	One often finds this in the optional "charset" parameter in the Content-Type header of some MIME messages, in the equivalent "meta" element of some HTML documents, and in the encoding declaration part of the prologue of some XML documents.
586	Variants As computer technology spread throughout the world, different standards bodies and corporations developed many variations of ASCII to facilitate the expression of non-English languages that used Roman-based alphabets.
586	One could class some of these variations as "ASCII extensions", although some misuse that term to represent all variants, including those that do not preserve ASCII's character-map in the 7-bit range.
586	The PETSCII code Commodore International used for their 8-bit systems is probably unique among post-1970 codes in being based on ASCII-1963, instead of the more common ASCII-1967, such as found on the ZX Spectrum computer.
586	Atari and Galaksija computers also used ASCII variants.
586	From early in its development, ASCII was intended to be just one of several national variants of an international character code standard, ultimately published as ISO/IEC 646 (1972), which would share most characters in common but assign other locally useful characters to several code points reserved for "national use."
586	However, the four years that elapsed between the publication of ASCII-1963 and ISO's first acceptance of an international recommendation during 1967 caused ASCII's choices for the national use characters to seem to be de facto standards for the world, causing confusion and incompatibility once other countries did begin to make their own assignments to these code points.
586	ISO/IEC 646, like ASCII, was a 7-bit character set.
586	It did not make any additional codes available, so the same code points encoded different characters in different countries.
586	Escape codes were defined to indicate which national variant applied to a piece of text, but they were rarely used, so it was often impossible to know what variant to work with and therefore which character a code represented, and in general text-processing systems could cope with only one variant anyway.
586	Because the bracket and brace characters of ASCII were assigned to "national use" code points that were used for accented letters in other national variants of ISO/IEC 646, a German, French, or Swedish, etc.
586	ISO/IEC 646, rather than ASCII, had to write, and thus read, something such as ä aÄiÜ='Ön'; ü instead of { a[i]='\n'; } C trigraphs were created to solve this problem for ANSI C, although their late introduction and inconsistent implementation in compilers limited their use.
586	Eventually, as 8-, 16-, and 32-bit computers began to replace 18- and 36-bit computers as the norm, it became common to use an 8-bit byte to store each character in memory, providing an opportunity for extended, 8-bit, relatives of ASCII.
586	In most cases these developed as true extensions of ASCII, leaving the original character-mapping intact, but adding additional character definitions after the first 128 (i.e., 7-bit) characters.
586	Most early home computer systems developed their own 8-bit character sets containing line-drawing and game glyphs, and often filled in some or all of the control characters from 0-31 with more graphics.
586	The IBM PC defined code page 437, which replaced the control-characters with graphic symbols such as smiley faces, and mapped additional graphic characters to the upper 128 positions.
586	Operating systems such as DOS supported these code-pages, and manufacturers of IBM PCs supported them in hardware.
586	Digital Equipment Corporation developed the Multinational Character Set (DEC-MCS) for use in the popular VT220 terminal, this was one of the first extensions designed more for international languages than for block graphics.
586	The Macintosh defined Mac OS Roman and Postscript also defined a set, both of these contained both international letters and typographic punctuation marks instead of graphics, more like modern character sets.
586	The ISO/IEC 8859 standard (derived from the DEC-MCS) finally provided a standard that most systems copied (at least as accurately as they copied ASCII, but with many substitutions).
586	A popular further extension designed by Microsoft, Windows-1252 (often mislabeled as ISO-8859-1), added the typographic punctuation marks needed for attractive text printing.
586	ISO-8859-1, Windows-1252, and the original 7-bit ASCII were the most common character encodings until the late 2000s, nowadays UTF-8 is becoming more common.
586	Unicode Unicode and the ISO/IEC 10646 Universal Character Set (UCS) have a much wider array of characters, and their various encoding forms have begun to supplant ISO/IEC 8859 and ASCII rapidly in many environments.
586	While ASCII is limited to 128 characters, Unicode and the UCS support more characters by separating the concepts of unique identification (using natural numbers called code points) and encoding (to 8-, 16- or 32-bit binary formats, called UTF-8, UTF-16 and UTF-32).
586	To allow backward compatibility, the 128 ASCII and 256 ISO-8859-1 (Latin 1) characters are assigned Unicode/UCS code points that are the same as their codes in the earlier standards.
586	Therefore, ASCII can be considered a 7-bit encoding scheme for a very small subset of Unicode/UCS, and ASCII (when prefixed with 0 as the eighth bit) is valid UTF-8.
586	Order ASCII-code order is also called ASCIIbetical order.
586	Collation of data is sometimes done in this order rather than "standard" alphabetical order (collating sequence).
586	The main deviations in ASCII order are: * All uppercase come before lowercase letters, for example, "Z" before "a" * Digits and many punctuation marks come before letters, for example, "4" precedes "one" * Numbers are sorted naïvely as strings, for example, "10" precedes "2" An intermediate order — readily implemented — converts uppercase letters to lowercase before comparing ASCII values.
586	Naïve number sorting can be averted by zero-filling all numbers (e.g.
586	"02" will sort before "10" as expected), although this is an external fix and has nothing to do with the ordering itself.
590	Austin is the capital of the U.S.
590	Texas.
590	Austin may also refer to: Geographical locations In the United States *Austin, Arkansas *Austin, Colorado *Austin, Chicago, Illinois *Austin, Indiana *Austin, Minnesota *Austin, Nevada *Austin, Oregon *Austin County, Texas (note that Austin, Texas, is located in Travis County, Texas) In Canada *Austin, Manitoba *Austin, Ontario *Austin, Quebec *Austin Island, Nunavut In Australia *Austin, Western Australia People *Austin (name) Schools *Austin College, Sherman, Texas *University of Texas at Austin, flagship institution of the University of Texas System *Austin Peay State University, Clarksville, Tennessee Religion *Austin, a contracted form of Augustine of Hippo and Augustine of Canterbury *An adjective for the Augustinians Business *Austin Automobile Company, short-lived American automobile company *Austin (brand), a brand owned by the Kellogg Company *Austin Motor Company, British car manufacturer *American Austin Car Company, short-lived American automobile maker Entertainment *"Austin" (song), a single by Blake Shelton *Austin, a kangaroo Beanie Baby produced by Ty, Inc.
590	Austin the kangaroo from the children's television series The Backyardigans Other uses *USS Austin, three ships *Austin Station (disambiguation), various public transportation stations
593	The bouncing ball animation (below) consists of these six frames.
593	This animation moves at 10 frames per second.
593	Animation is the rapid display of a sequence of images to create an illusion of movement.
593	The most common method of presenting animation is as a motion picture or video program, although there are other methods.
593	This type of presentation is usually accomplished with a camera and a projector or a computer viewing screen which can rapidly cycle through images in a sequence.
593	Animation can be made with either hand rendered art, computer generated imagery, or three-dimensional objects, e.g.
593	The position of each object in any particular image relates to the position of that object in the previous and following images so that the objects each appear to fluidly move independently of one another.
593	The viewing device displays these images in rapid succession, usually 24, 25, or 30 frames per second.
593	Etymology  From Latin animātiō, "the act of bringing to life"; from animō ("to animate" or "give life to") + -ātiō ("the act of").
593	History  Early examples of attempts to capture the phenomenon of motion drawing can be found in paleolithic cave paintings, where animals are depicted with multiple legs in superimposed positions, clearly attempting to convey the perception of motion.
593	A 5,000 year old earthen bowl found in Iran in Shahr-i Sokhta has five images of a goat painted along the sides.
593	This has been claimed to be an example of early animation.
593	However, since no equipment existed to show the images in motion, such a series of images cannot be called animation in a true sense of the word.
593	A Chinese zoetrope-type device had been invented in 180 AD.
593	The phenakistoscope, praxinoscope, and the common flip book were early popular animation devices invented during the 19th century.
593	These devices produced the appearance of movement from sequential drawings using technological means, but animation did not really develop much further until the advent of cinematography.
593	The cinématographe was a projector,printer,and camera in one machine that allowed moving pictures to be shown successfully on a screen which was invented by history's earliest film makers Auguste and Louis Lumière in 1894.
593	There is no single person who can be considered the "creator" of film animation, as there were several people working on projects which could be considered animation at about the same time.
593	Georges Méliès was a creator of special-effect films; he was generally one of the first people to use animation with his technique.
593	He discovered a technique by accident which was to stop the camera rolling to change something in the scene, and then continue rolling the film.
593	This idea was later known as stop-motion animation.
593	Méliès discovered this technique accidentally when his camera broke down while shooting a bus driving by.
593	When he had fixed the camera, a hearse happened to be passing by just as Méliès restarted rolling the film, his end result was that he had managed to make a bus transform into a hearse.
593	This was just one of the great contributors to animation in the early years.
593	The earliest surviving stop-motion advertising film was an English short by Arthur Melbourne-Cooper called Matches: An Appeal (1899).
593	Developed for the Bryant and May Matchsticks company, it involved stop-motion animation of wired-together matches writing a patriotic call to action on a blackboard.
593	J.
593	Stuart Blackton was possibly the first American film-maker to use the techniques of stop-motion and hand-drawn animation.
593	Introduced to film-making by Edison, he pioneered these concepts at the turn of the 20th century, with his first copyrighted work dated 1900.
593	Several of his films, among them The Enchanted Drawing (1900) and Humorous Phases of Funny Faces (1906) were film versions of Blackton's "lightning artist" routine, and utilized modified versions of Méliès' early stop-motion techniques to make a series of blackboard drawings appear to move and reshape themselves.
593	Humorous Phases of Funny Faces' is regularly cited as the first true animated film, and Blackton is considered the first true animator.
593	Another French artist, Émile Cohl, began drawing cartoon strips and created a film in 1908 called Fantasmagorie.
593	The film largely consisted of a stick figure moving about and encountering all manner of morphing objects, such as a wine bottle that transforms into a flower.
593	There were also sections of live action where the animator’s hands would enter the scene.
593	The film was created by drawing each frame on paper and then shooting each frame onto negative film, which gave the picture a blackboard look.
593	This makes Fantasmagorie the first animated film created using what came to be known as traditional (hand-drawn) animation.
593	The author of the first puppet-animated film (i.e.
593	The Beautiful Lukanida (1912)) was the Russian-born (ethnically Polish) director Wladyslaw Starewicz, known as Ladislas Starevich.
593	Following the successes of Blackton and Cohl, many other artists began experimenting with animation.
593	One such artist was Winsor McCay, a successful newspaper cartoonist, who created detailed animations that required a team of artists and painstaking attention for detail.
593	Each frame was drawn on paper; which invariably required backgrounds and characters to be redrawn and animated.
593	Among McCay'paper; which invariably res most noted films are Little Nemo (1911), Gertie the Dinosaur (1914) and The Sinking of the Lusitania (1918).
593	The production of animated short films, typically referred to as "cartoons", became an industry of its own during the 1910s, and cartoon shorts were produced to be shown in movie theaters.
593	The most successful early animation producer was John Randolph Bray, who, along with animator Earl Hurd, patented the cel animation process which dominated the animation industry for the rest of the decade.
593	El Apóstol (Spanish: "The Apostle") was a 1917 Argentine animated film utilizing cutout animation, and the world's first animated feature film.
593	Unfortunately, a fire that destroyed producer Frederico Valle's film studio incinerated the only known copy of El Apóstol, and it is now considered a lost film.
593	Computer animation has become popular since Toy Story (1995), the first animated film completely made using this technique.
593	In 2008, the animation market was worth US$68.4 billion.
593	Techniques  Traditional animation  Traditional animation (also called cel animation or hand-drawn animation) was the process used for most animated films of the 20th century.
593	The individual frames of a traditionally animated film are photographs of drawings, which are first drawn on paper.
593	To create the illusion of movement, each drawing differs slightly from the one before it.
593	The animators' drawings are traced or photocopied onto transparent acetate sheets called cels, which are filled in with paints in assigned colors or tones on the side opposite the line drawings.
593	The completed character cels are photographed one-by-one onto motion picture film against a painted background by a rostrum camera.
593	The traditional cel animation process became obsolete by the beginning of the 21st century.
593	Today, animators' drawings and the backgrounds are either scanned into or drawn directly into a computer system.
593	Various software programs are used to color the drawings and simulate camera movement and effects.
593	The final animated piece is output to one of several delivery media, including traditional 35 mm film and newer media such as digital video.
593	The "look" of traditional cel animation is still preserved, and the character animators' work has remained essentially the same over the past 70 years.
593	Some animation producers have used the term "tradigital" to describe cel animation which makes extensive use of computer technology.
593	Examples of traditionally animated feature films include Pinocchio (United States, 1940), Animal Farm (United Kingdom, 1954), and Akira (Japan, 1988).
593	Traditional animated films which were produced with the aid of computer technology include The Lion King (US, 1994) Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi (Spirited Away) (Japan, 2001), and Les Triplettes de Belleville (France, 2003).
593	Full animation refers to the process of producing high-quality traditionally animated films, which regularly use detailed drawings and plausible movement.
593	Fully animated films can be done in a variety of styles, from more realistically animated works such as those produced by the Walt Disney studio (Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin, Lion King) to the more 'cartoony' styles of those produced by the Warner Bros.
593	Many of the Disney animated features are examples of full animation, as are non-Disney works such as The Secret of NIMH (US, 1982), The Iron Giant (US, 1999), and Nocturna (Spain, 2007).
593	Limited animation involves the use of less detailed and/or more stylized drawings and methods of movement.
593	Pioneered by the artists at the American studio United Productions of America, limited animation can be used as a method of stylized artistic expression, as in Gerald McBoing Boing (US, 1951), Yellow Submarine (UK, 1968), and much of the anime produced in Japan.
593	Its primary use, however, has been in producing cost-effective animated content for media such as television (the work of Hanna-Barbera, Filmation, and other TV animation studios) and later the Internet (web cartoons).
593	Rotoscoping is a technique, patented by Max Fleischer in 1917, where animators trace live-action movement, frame by frame.
593	The source film can be directly copied from actors' outlines into animated drawings, as in The Lord of the Rings (US, 1978), or used in a stylized and expressive manner, as in Waking Life (US, 2001) and A Scanner Darkly (US, 2006).
593	Some other examples are: Fire and Ice (USA, 1983) and Heavy Metal (1981).
593	Live-action/animation is a technique, when combining hand-drawn characters into live action shots.
593	One of the earlier uses of it was Koko the Clown when Koko was drawn over live action footage.
593	Other examples would include Who Framed Roger Rabbit (USA, 1988), Space Jam (USA, 1996) and Osmosis Jones (USA, 2001).
593	Stop motion  Stop-motion animation is used to describe animation created by physically manipulating real-world objects and photographing them one frame of film at a time to create the illusion of movement.
593	There are many different types of stop-motion animation, usually named after the medium used to create the animation.
593	Computer software is widely available to create this type of animation.
593	Puppet animation typically involves stop-motion puppet figures interacting with each other in a constructed environment, in contrast to the real-world interaction in model animation.
593	The puppets generally have an armature inside of them to keep them still and steady as well as constraining them to move at particular joints.
593	Examples include The Tale of the Fox (France, 1937), The Nightmare Before Christmas (US, 1993), Corpse Bride (US, 2005), Coraline (US, 2009), the films of Jiří Trnka and the TV series Robot Chicken (US, 2005–present).
593	Puppetoon, created using techniques developed by George Pal, are puppet-animated films which typically use a different version of a puppet for different frames, rather than simply manipulating one existing puppet.
593	Clay animation, or Plasticine animation (often called claymation, which, however, is a trademarked name), uses figures made of clay or a similar malleable material to create stop-motion animation.
593	The figures may have an armature or wire frame inside of them, similar to the related puppet animation (below), that can be manipulated to pose the figures.
593	Alternatively, the figures may be made entirely of clay, such as in the films of Bruce Bickford, where clay creatures morph into a variety of different shapes.
593	Examples of clay-animated wckford, whereorks include The Gumby Show (US, 1957–1967) Morph shorts (UK, 1977–2000), Wallace and Gromit shorts (UK, as of 1989), Jan Švankmajer's Dimensions of Dialogue (Czechoslovakia, 1982), The Trap Door (UK, 1984).
593	Films include Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit, Chicken Run and The Adventures of Mark Twain.
593	Cutout animation is a type of stop-motion animation produced by moving 2-dimensional pieces of material such as paper or cloth.
593	Examples include Terry Gilliam's animated sequences from Monty Python's Flying Circus (UK, 1969–1974); Fantastic Planet (France/Czechoslovakia, 1973) ; Tale of Tales (Russia, 1979), The pilot episode of the TV series (and sometimes in episodes) of South Park (US, 1997).
593	Silhouette animation is a variant of cutout animation in which the characters are backlit and only visible as silhouettes.
593	Examples include The Adventures of Prince Achmed (Weimar Republic, 1926) and Princes et princesses (France, 2000).
593	Model animation refers to stop-motion animation created to interact with and exist as a part of a live-action world.
593	Intercutting, matte effects, and split screens are often employed to blend stop-motion characters or objects with live actors and settings.
593	Examples include the work of Ray Harryhausen, as seen in films such Jason and the Argonauts (1963), and the work of Willis O'Brien on films such as King Kong (1933 film).
593	Go motion is a variant of model animation which uses various techniques to create motion blur between frames of film, which is not present in traditional stop-motion.
593	The technique was invented by Industrial Light & Magic and Phil Tippett to create special effects scenes for the film The Empire Strikes Back (1980).
593	Another example is the dragon named Vermithrax from Dragonslayer (1981 film).
593	Object animation refers to the use of regular inanimate objects in stop-motion animation, as opposed to specially created items.
593	Graphic animation uses non-drawn flat visual graphic material (photographs, newspaper clippings, magazines, etc.) which are sometimes manipulated frame-by-frame to create movement.
593	At other times, the graphics remain stationary, while the stop-motion camera is moved to create on-screen action.
593	Brickfilm A sub genre of object animation involving using Lego or other similar brick toys to make an animation.
593	These have had a recent boost in popularity with the advent of video sharing sites like YouTube, and the availability of cheap cameras, and animation software.
593	Pixilation involves the use of live humans as stop motion characters.
593	This allows for a number of surreal effects, including disappearances and reappearances, allowing people to appear to slide across the ground, and other such effects.
593	Examples of pixilation include The Secret Adventures of Tom Thumb and Angry Kid shorts.
593	Computer animation  Computer animation encompasses a variety of techniques, the unifying factor being that the animation is created digitally on a computer.
593	This animation takes less time than previous traditional animation.
593	D animation  2D animation figures are created and/or edited on the computer using 2D bitmap graphics or created and edited using 2D vector graphics.
593	This includes automated computerized versions of traditional animation techniques such as of, interpolated morphing, onion skinning and interpolated rotoscoping.
593	D animation has many applications, including analog computer animation, Flash animation and PowerPoint animation.
593	Cinemagraphs are still photographs in the form of an animated GIF file of which part is animated.
593	D animation  3D animation is digitally modeled and manipulated by an animator.
593	The animator starts by creating an external 3D mesh to manipulate.
593	A mesh is a geometric configuration that gives the visual appearance of form to a 3D object or 3D environment.
593	The mesh may have many vertices which are the geometric points which make up the mesh; it is given an internal digital skeletal structure called an armature that can be used to control the mesh with weights.
593	This process is called rigging and can be programmed with movement with keyframes.
593	Other techniques can be applied, such as mathematical functions (ex.
593	These techniques fall under the category of 3D dynamics.
593	Terms  * Cel-shaded animation is used to mimic traditional animation using CG software.
593	Shading looks stark, with less blending colors.
593	Examples include, Skyland (2007, France), Appleseed Ex Machina (2007, Japan), The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker (2002, Japan) * Machinima – Films created by screen capturing in video games and virtual worlds.
593	Motion capture is used when live-action actors wear special suits that allow computers to copy their movements into CG characters.
593	Examples include Polar Express (2004, USA), Beowulf (2007, USA), A Christmas Carol (2009, USA), The Adventures of Tintin (2011, USA) * Photo-realistic animation is used primarily for animation that attempts to resemble real life, using advanced rendering that makes detailed skin, plants, water, fire, clouds, etc.
593	Examples include Up (2009, USA), Kung-Fu Panda (2008, USA), Ice Age (2002, USA).
593	D animation techniques tend to focus on image manipulation while 3D techniques usually build virtual worlds in which characters and objects move and interact.
593	D animation can create images that seem real to the viewer.
593	Other animation techniques  * Final line advection animation, a technique that gives the artists and animators a lot more influence and control over the final product as everything is done within the same department; "In Paperman, we didn’t have a cloth department and we didn’t have a hair department.
593	Here, folds in the fabric, hair silhouettes and the like come from of the commited design decision-making that comes with the 2D drawn process.
593	Our animators can change things, actually erase away the CG underlayer if they want, and change the profile of the arm.
593	And they can design all the fabric in that Milt Kahl kind-of way, if they want to."
593	Drawn on film animation: a technique where footage is produced by creating the images directly on film stock, for example by Norman McLaren, Len Lye and Stan Brakhage.
593	Paint-on-glass animation: a technique for making animated films by manipulating slow drying oil paints on sheets of glass, for example by Aleksandr Petrov.
593	Erasure animation: a technique using tradition 2D medium, photographed over time as the artist manipulates the image.
593	For example, William Kentridge is famous for his charcoal erasure films, and s the image.
593	For example, WiPiotr Dumała for his auteur technique of animating scratches on plaster.
593	Pinscreen animation: makes use of a screen filled with movable pins, which can be moved in or out by pressing an object onto the screen.
593	The screen is lit from the side so that the pins cast shadows.
593	The technique has been used to create animated films with a range of textural effects difficult to achieve with traditional cel animation.
593	Sand animation: sand is moved around on a back- or front-lighted piece of glass to create each frame for an animated film.
593	This creates an interesting effect when animated because of the light contrast.
593	Flip book: a flip book (sometimes, especially in British English, called a flick book) is a book with a series of pictures that vary gradually from one page to the next, so that when the pages are turned rapidly, the pictures appear to animate by simulating motion or some other change.
593	Flip books are often illustrated books for children, but may also be geared towards adults and employ a series of photographs rather than drawings.
593	Flip books are not always separate books, but may appear as an added feature in ordinary books or magazines, often in the page corners.
593	Software packages and websites are also available that convert digital video files into custom-made flip books.
593	Zoetrope: a device that produces the illusion of motion from a rapid succession of static pictures.
593	The term zoetrope is from the Greek words ζωή (zoē), meaning "alive, active", and τροπή (tropē), meaning "turn", with "zoetrope" taken to mean "active turn" or "wheel of life".
593	Other styles, techniques and approaches  * Animatronics & Audio-Animatronics * Animutation - a style of animation invented by Neil Cicierega at age 13.
593	This style of animation is usually characterized by random images of pop culture in sequence with foreign music.
593	The animation style is strange, weird, random, but from a creator's point of view, very easy to implement.
593	Professionalism is not required in the Animutation style.
593	Character animation * Chuckimation * Puppetry * Multi-sketching * Special effects animation * Stop motion Awards As with any other form of media, animation too has instituted awards for excellence in the field.
593	The original awards for animation were given out by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for animated shorts from the year 1932, during the 5th Academy Awards function.
593	The first winner of the Academy Award was the short Flowers and Trees, a production by Walt Disney Productions and United Artists.
593	However, the Academy Award for a feature length animated motion picture was only instituted for the year 2001, and awarded during the 74th Academy Awards in 2002.
593	It was won by the movie Shrek, produced by DreamWorks and Pacific Data Images.
593	Since then, Disney/Pixar have produced the most number of movies either to win or be nominated for the award.
593	The list of both awards can be obtained here: *Academy Award for Best Animated Feature *Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film Several other countries have instituted an award for best animated feature film as part of their national film awards: BAFTA Award for Best Animated Film (since 2006), César Award for Best Animated Film (since 2011), Goya Award for Best Animated Film (since 1989), Japan Academy Prize for Animation of the Year (since 2007).
593	Also since 2007, the Asia Pacific Screen Award for Best Animated Feature Film has been awarded at the Asia Pacific Screen Awards.
593	Since 2009, the European Film Awards have awarded the European Film Award for Best Animated Film.
593	The Annie Award is another award given out for excellence in the field of animation.
593	Unlike the Academy Awards, the Annie Awards are only received due to achievements in the field of animation and not for any other field of technical and artistic endeavor.
593	They were re-organized in 1992, to create a new field for Best Animated feature.
593	The 1990s were dominated by Walt Disney, however newer studios, led by Pixar, have now begun to consistently vie for this award.
593	The list of awardees is as follows:  *Annie Award for Best Animated Feature
594	Apollo (Attic, Ionic, and Homeric Greek: , Apollōn (gen.: ); Doric: , Apellōn; Arcadocypriot: , Apeilōn; Aeolic: , Aploun; ) is one of the most important and complex of the Olympian deities in ancient Greek and Roman religion, Greek and Roman mythology, and Greco–Roman Neopaganism.
594	The ideal of the kouros (a beardless, athletic youth), Apollo has been variously recognized as a god of light and the sun, truth and prophecy, healing, plague, music, poetry, and more.
594	Apollo is the son of Zeus and Leto, and has a twin sister, the chaste huntress Artemis.
594	Apollo is known in Greek-influenced Etruscan mythology as Apulu.
594	As the patron of Delphi (Pythian Apollo), Apollo was an oracular god—the prophetic deity of the Delphic Oracle.
594	Medicine and healing are associated with Apollo, whether through the god himself or mediated through his son Asclepius, yet Apollo was also seen as a god who could bring ill-health and deadly plague.
594	Amongst the god's custodial charges, Apollo became associated with dominion over colonists, and as the patron defender of herds and flocks.
594	As the leader of the Muses (Apollon Musegetes) and director of their choir, Apollo functioned as the patron god of music and poetry.
594	Hermes created the lyre for him, and the instrument became a common attribute of Apollo.
594	Hymns sung to Apollo were called paeans.
594	In Hellenistic times, especially during the 3rd century BCE, as Apollo Helios he became identified among Greeks with Helios, Titan god of the sun, and his sister Artemis similarly equated with Selene, Titan goddess of the moon.
594	In Latin texts, on the other hand, Joseph Fontenrose declared himself unable to find any conflation of Apollo with Sol among the Augustan poets of the 1st century, not even in the conjurations of Aeneas and Latinus in Aeneid XII (161–215).
594	Apollo and Helios/Sol remained separate beings in literary and mythological texts until the 3rd century CE.
594	Etymology The etymology of Apollo is uncertain.
594	The spelling Ἀπόλλων had almost superseded all other forms by the beginning of the common era, but the Doric form Απέλλων is more archaic, derived from an earlier *Απέλjων.
594	The name is certainly cognate with the Doric month name Απέλλαιος and the Doric festival απελλαι.
594	Several instances of popular etymology are attested from ancient authors.
594	Thus, the Greeks most often associated Apollo's name with the Greek verb ἀπόλλυμι (apollymi), "to destroy".
594	Plato in Cratylus connects the name with  (apolysis), "redeem", with  (apolousis), "purification", and with  ([h]aploun), "simple", in particular in reference to the Thessalian form of the name, , and finally with  (aeiballon), "ever-shooting".
594	Hesychius connects the name Apollo with the Doric απέλλα (apella), which means "assembly", so that Apollo would be the god of political life, and he also gives the explanation σηκός (sekos), "fold", in which case Apollo would be the god of flocks and herds.
594	Following the tradition of these Ancient Greek folk etymologies, in the Doric dialect the word  originally meant wall, fence from animals and later assembly within the agora.
594	In the Ancient Macedonian language  (pella) means stone, and some toponyms are derived from this word:  (Pelα}} (pella) means stone, and some toponyms are derived from this word:  ([la:capital of Ancient Macedonia),  (Pellini-Pallini).
594	A number of non-Greek etymologies have been suggested for the name, The form Apaliunas (d) is attested as a god of Wilusa in a treaty between Alaksandu of Wilusa and the Hittite great king Muwatalli II c.
594	BCE.
594	Alaksandu could be Paris-Alexander of Ilion", whose name is Greek.
594	The Hittite testimony reflects an early form ', which may also be surmised from comparison of Cypriot Απειλων with Doric Απελλων.
594	A Luwian etymology suggested for Apaliunas makes Apollo "The One of Entrapment", perhaps in the sense of "Hunter".
594	Among the proposed etymologies is the Hurrian and Hittite divinity, Aplu, who was widely invoked during the "plague years".
594	Aplu, it is suggested, comes from the Akkadian Aplu Enlil, meaning "the son of Enlil", a title that was given to the god Nergal, who was linked to Shamash, Babylonian god of the sun.
594	Greco-Roman epithets Apollo, like other Greek deities, had a number of epithets applied to him, reflecting the variety of roles, duties, and aspects ascribed to the god.
594	However, while Apollo has a great number of appellations in Greek myth, only a few occur in Latin literature, chief among them Phoebus ( ; Φοίβος, Phoibos, literally "radiant"), which was very commonly used by both the Greeks and Romans in Apollo's role as the god of light.
594	As sun-god and god of light, Apollo was also known by the epithets Aegletes ( ; Αἰγλήτης, Aiglētēs, from αἴγλη, "light of the sun"), Helius ( ; Ἥλιος, Helios, literally "sun"), Phanaeus ( ; Φαναῖος, Phanaios, literally "giving or bringing light"), and Lyceus ( ; Λύκειος, Lukeios, from Proto-Greek *λύκη, "light").
594	The meaning of the epithet "Lyceus" later became associated Apollo's mother Leto, who was the patron goddess of Lycia (Λυκία) and who was identified with the wolf (λύκος), earning him the epithets Lycegenes ( ; Λυκηγενής, Lukēgenēs, literally "born of a wolf" or "born of Lycia") and Lycoctonus ( ; Λυκοκτόνος, Lukoktonos, from λύκος, "wolf", and κτείνειν, "to kill").
594	As god of the sun, the Romans referred to Apollo as Sol ( ; literally "sun" in Latin).
594	In association with his birthplace, Mount Cynthus on the island of Delos, Apollo was called Cynthius ( ; Κύνθιος, Kunthios, literally "Cynthian"), Cynthogenes ( ; Κύνθογενης, Kunthogenēs, literally "born of Cynthus"), and Delius ( ; Δήλιος, Delios, literally "Delian").
594	As Artemis's twin, Apollo had the epithet Didymaeus ( ; Διδυμαιος, Didumaios, from δίδυμος, "twin").
594	Apollo was worshipped as Actiacus ( ; Ἄκτιακός, Aktiakos, literally "Actian"), Delphinius ( ; Δελφίνιος, Delphinios, literally "Delphic"), and Pythius ( ; Πύθιος, Puthios, from Πυθώ, Pūthō, the area around Delphi), after Actium (Ἄκτιον) and Delphi (Δελφοί) respectively, two of his principal places of worship.
594	An etiology in the Homeric hymns associated the epithet "Delphinius" with dolphins.
594	He was worshipped as Acraephius ( ; Ἀκραιφιος, Akraiphios, literally "Acraephian") or Acraephiaeus ( ; Ἀκραιφιαίος, Akraiphiaios, literally "Acraephian") in the Boeotian town of Acraephia (Ἀκραιφία), reputedly founded by his son Acraepheus; and as Smintheus ( ; Σμινθεύς, Smintheus, "Sminthian"—that is, "of the town of Sminthos or Sminthe") near the Troad town of Hamaxitus.
594	The epithet "Smintheus" has historically been confused with σμίνθος, "mouse", in association with Apollo's role as a god of disease.
594	For this he was also known as Parnopius ( ; Παρνόπιος, Parnopios, from πάρνοψ, "locust") and to the Romans as Culicarius ( ; from Latin culicārius, "of midges").
594	In Apollo's role as a healer, his appellations included Acesius ( ; Ἀκέσιος, Akesios, from ἄκεσις, "healing"), Acestor ( ; Ἀκέστωρ, Akestōr, literally "healer"), Paean ( ; Παιάν, Paiān, from παίειν, "to touch"), and Iatrus ( ; Ἰατρός, Iātros, literally "physician").
594	Acesius was the epithet of Apollo worshipped in Elis, where he had a temple in the agora.
594	The Romans referred to Apollo as Medicus ( ; literally "physician" in Latin) in this respect.
594	A temple was dedicated to Apollo Medicus at Rome, probably next to the temple of Bellona.
594	As a protector and founder, Apollo had the epithets Alexicacus ( ; Ἀλεξίκακος, Alexikakos, literally "warding off evil"), Apotropaeus ( ; Ἀποτρόπαιος, Apotropaios, from ἀποτρέπειν, "to avert"), and Epicurius ( ; Ἐπικούριος, Epikourios, from ἐπικουρέειν, "to aid"), and Archegetes ( ; Ἀρχηγέτης, Arkhēgetēs, literally "founder"), Clarius ( ; Κλάριος, Klārios, from Doric κλάρος, "allotted lot"), and Genetor ( ; Γενέτωρ, Genetōr, literally "ancestor").
594	To the Romans, he was known in this capacity as Averruncus ( ; from Latin āverruncare, "to avert").
594	He was also called Agyieus ( ; Ἀγυιεύς, Aguīeus, from ἄγυια, "street") for his role in protecting roads and homes; and as Nomius ( ; Νόμιος, Nomios, literally "pastoral") and Nymphegetes ( ; Νυμφηγέτης, Numphēgetēs, from Νύμφη, "Nymph", and ἡγέτης, "leader") in his role as a protector of shepherds and pastoral life.
594	In his role as god of prophecy and truth, Apollo had the epithets Manticus ( ; Μαντικός, Mantikos, literally "prophetic"), Leschenorius ( ; Λεσχηνόριος, Leskhēnorios, from λεσχήνωρ, "converser"), and Loxias ( ; Λοξίας, Loxias, from λέγειν, "to say").
594	The epithet "Loxias" has historically been associated with λοξός, "ambiguous".
594	In this respect, the Romans called him Coelispex ( ; from Latin coelum, "sky", and specere, "to look at").
594	The epithet Iatromantis ( ; Ἰατρομάντις, Iātromantis, from ὶατρός, "physician", and μάντις, "prophet") refers to both his role as a god of healing and of prophecy.
594	As god of music and arts, Apollo had the epithet Musagetes ( ; Doric Μουσαγέτας, Mousāgetās) or Musegetes ( ; Μουσηγέτης, Mousēgetēs, from Μούσα, "Muse", and ἡγέτης, "leader").
594	As a god of archery, Apollo was known as Aphetor ( ; Ἀφήτωρ, Aphētōr, from ὰφίημι, "to let loose") or Aphetorus ( ; Ἀφητόρος, Aphētoros, of the same origin), Argyrotoxus ( ; Ἀργυρότοξος, Argurotoxos, literally "with silver bow"), Hecaërgus ( ; Ἑκάεργος, Hekaergos, literally "far-shooting"), and Hecebolus ( ; Ἑκηβόλος, Hekēbolos, literally "far-shooting").
594	The Romans referred to Apollo as Articenens ( ; "bow-carrying").
594	Apollo was called Ismenius ( ; Ἰσμηνιός, Ismēnios, literally "of Ismenus") after Ismenus, the son of Amphion and Niobe, whom he struck with an arrow.
594	Celtic epithets and cult titles Apollo was worshipped throughout the Roman Empire.
594	In the traditionally Celtic lands he was most often seen as a healing and sun god.
594	He was often equated with Celtic gods of similar character.
594	Apollo Atepomarus ("the great horseman" or "possessing a great horse").
594	Apollo was worshipped at Mauvières (Indre).
594	Horses were, in the Celtic world, closely linked to the sun.
594	Apollo Belenus ('bright' or 'brilliant').
594	This epithet was given to Apollo in parts of Gaul, Northern Italy and Noricum (part of modern Austria).
594	Apollo Belenus was a healing and sun god.
594	Apollo Cunomaglus ('hound lord').
594	A title given to Apollo at a shrine in Wiltshire.
594	Apollo Cunomaglus may have been a god of healing.
594	Cunomaglus himself may originally have been an independent healing god.
594	Apollo Grannus.
594	Grannus was a healing spring god, later equated with Apollo.
594	Apollo Maponus.
594	A god known from inscriptions in Britain.
594	This may be a local fusion of Apollo and Maponus.
594	Apollo Moritasgus ('masses of sea water').
594	An epithet for Apollo at Alesia, where he was worshipped as god of healing and, possibly, of physicians.
594	Apollo Vindonnus ('clear light').
594	Apollo Vindonnus had a temple at Essarois, near Châtillon-sur-Seine in Burgundy.
594	He was a god of healing, especially of the eyes.
594	Apollo Virotutis ('benefactor of mankind?').
594	Apollo Virotutis was worshipped, among other places, at Fins d'Annecy (Haute-Savoie) and at Jublains (Maine-et-Loire).
594	Origins The cult centers of Apollo in Greece, Delphi and Delos, date from the 8th century BCE.
594	The Delos sanctuary was primarily dedicated to Artemis, Apollo's twin sister.
594	At Delphi, Apollo was venerated as the slayer of Pytho.
594	For the Greeks, Apollo was all the Gods in one and through the centuries he acquired different functions which could originate from different gods.
594	In archaic Greece he was the prophet, the oracular god who in older times was connected with "healing".
594	In classical Greece he was the god of light and of music, but in popular religion he had a strong function to keep away evil.
594	Walter Burkert discerned three components in the prehistory of Apollo worship, which he termed "a Dorian-northwest Greek component, a Cretan-Minoan component, and a Syro-Hittite component."
594	From his eastern-origin Apollo brought the art of inspection from "symbols and omina" (σημεία και τέρατα : semeia kai terata), and of the observation of the omens of the days.
594	The inspiration oracular-cult was probably introduced from Anatolia.
594	The ritualism belonged to Apollo from the beginning.
594	The Greeks created the legalism, the supervision of the orders of the gods, and the demand for moderation and harmony.
594	Apollo became the god of shining youth, the protector of music, spiritual-life, moderation and perceptible order.
594	The improvement of the old Anatolian god, and his elevation to an intellectual sphere, may be considered an achievement of the Greek people.
594	Healer and god-protector from evil The function of Apollo as a "healer" is connected with Paean (Παιών-Παιήων), the physician of the Gods in the Iliad, who seems to come from a more primitive religion.
594	Paeοn is probably connected with the Mycenean Pa-ja-wo, but the etymology is the only evidence.
594	He did not have a separate cult, but he was the personification of the holy magic-song sung by the magicians that was supposed to cure disease.
594	Later the Greeks knew the original meaning of the relevant song "paean" (παιάν).
594	The magicians were also called "seer-doctors" (ιατρομάντεις), and they used an ecstatic prophetic art which was used exactly by the god Apollo at the oracles.
594	In the Iliad, Apollo is the healer under the gods, but he is also the bringer of disease and death with his arrows, similar to the function of the terrible Vedic god of disease Rudra.
594	He sends a terrible plague (λοιμός) to the Achaeans.
594	The god who sends a disease can also prevent from it, therefore when it stops they make a purifying ceremony and offer him an "hecatomb" to ward off evil.
594	When the oath of his priest appeases, they pray and with a song they call their own god, the beautiful Paean.
594	Some common epithets of Apollo as a healer are "paion" (παιών:touching), "epikourios" (επικουρώ:help), "oulios" (ουλή:cured wound), and "loimios" (λοiμός:plague).
594	In classical times, his strong function in popular religion was to keep away evil, and was therefore called "apotropaios" (αποτρέπω:to divert) and "alexikakos" (αλέξω-κακό:defend, throw away the evil).
594	In later writers, the word, usually spelled "Paean", becomes a mere epithet of Apollo in his capacity as a god of healing.
594	Homer illustrated Paeon the god, and the song both of apotropaic thanksgiving or triumph.
594	Such songs were originally addressed to Apollo, and afterwards to other gods: to Dionysus, to Apollo Helios, to Apollo's son Asclepius the healer.
594	About the 4th century BCE, the paean became merely a formula of adulation; its object was either to implore protection against disease and misfortune, or to offer thanks after such protection had been rendered.
594	It was in this way that Apollo had become recognised as the god of music.
594	Apollo's role as the slayer of the Python led to his association with battle and victory; hence it became the Roman custom for a paean to be sung by an army on the march and before entering into battle, when a fleet left the harbour, and also after a victory had been won.
594	Dorian origin The connection with Dorians and their initiation festival apellai is reinforced by the month Apellaios in northwest Greek calendars, but it can explain only the Doric type of the name, which is connected with the Ancient Macedonian word "pella" (Pella), stone.
594	Stones played an important part in the  Macedonian word "pella&quotcult of the god, especially in the oracular shrine of Delphi (Omphalos).
594	The "Homeric hymn" represents Apollo as a Northern intruder.
594	His arrival must have occurred during the "dark ages" that followed the destruction of the Mycenaean civilization, and his conflict with Gaia (Mother Earth) was represented by the legend of his slaying her daughter the serpent Python.
594	The earth deity had power over the ghostly world, and it is believed that she was the deity behind the oracle.
594	The older tales mentioned two dragons who were perhaps intentionally conflated.
594	A female dragon named Delphyne (δελφύς:womb), who is obviously connected with Delphi and Apollo Delphinios, and a male serpent Typhon (τύφειν:smoke), the adversary of Zeus in the Titanomachy, who the narrators confused with Python.
594	Python was the good daemon (αγαθός δαίμων) of the temple as it appears in Minoan religion, but she was represented as a dragon, as often happens in Northern European folklore as well as in the East.
594	Apollo and his sister Artemis can bring death with their arrows.
594	The conception that diseases and death come from invisible shots sent by supernatural beings, or magicians is common in Germanic and Norse mythology.
594	In Greek mythology Artemis was the leader ( ηγεμόνη : hegemone) of the nymphs, who had similar functions with the Nordic Elves.
594	The "elf-shot" originally indicated disease or death attributed to the elves, but it was later attested denoting arrow-heads which were used by witches to harm people, and also for healing rituals.
594	The Vedic Rudra has some similar functions with Apollo.
594	The terrible god is called "The Archer", and the bow is also an attribute of Shiva.
594	Rudra could bring diseases with his arrows, but he was able to free people of them, and his alternative Shiba, is a healer physician god.
594	However the Indo-European component of Apollo, does not explain his strong relation with omens, exorcisms, and with the oracular cult.
594	Minoan origin It seems an oracular cult existed in Delphi from the Mycenaean ages.
