594	In historical times, the priests of Delphi were called Labryaden, "the double-axe men", which indicates Minoan origin.
594	The double-axe (λάβρυς:labrys) was the holy symbol of the Cretan labyrinth.
594	The Homeric hymn adds that Apollo appeared as a dolphin and carried Cretan priests to Delphi, where they evidently transferred their religious practices.
594	Apollo Delphinios was a sea-god especially worshiped in Crete and in the islands, and his name indicates his connection with Delphi and the holy serpent Delphyne (womb).
594	Apollo's sister Artemis, who was the Greek goddess of hunting, is identified with Britomartis (Diktynna), the Minoan "Mistress of the animals".
594	In her earliest depictions she is accompanied by the "Mister of the animals", a male god of hunting who had the bow as his attribute.
594	We don't know his original name, but it seems that he was absorbed by the more powerful Apollo, who stood by the "Mistress of the animals", becoming her brother.
594	The old oracles in Delphi seem to be connected with a local tradition of the priesthood, and there is not clear evidence that a kind of inspiration-prophecy existed in the temple.
594	This led some scholars to the conclusion that Pythia carried on the rituals in a consistent procedure through many centuries, according to the local tradition.
594	In that regard, the mythical seeress Sibyl of Anatolian origin, with her ecstatic art, looks unrelated to the oracle itself.
594	However, the Greek tradition is referring to the existence of vapours and chewing of laurel-leaves, which seem to be confirmed by recent studies.
594	Plato describes the priestesses of Delphi and Dodona as frenzied women, obsessed by "mania" (μανία:frenzy), a Greek word connected with "mantis" (μάντις:prophet).
594	Frenzied women like Sibyls from whose lips the god speaks are recorded in the Near East as Mari in the second millennium BC.
594	Although Crete had contacts with Mari from 2000 BC, there is no evidence that the ecstatic prophetic art existed during the Minoan and Mycenean ages.
594	It is more probable that this art was introduced later from Anatolia and regenerated an existing oracular cult that was local to Delphi and dormant in several areas of Greece.
594	Anatolian origin A non-Greek origin of Apollo has long been assumed in scholarship.
594	The name of Apollo's mother Leto has Lydian origin, and she was worshipped on the coasts of Asia Minor.
594	The inspiration oracular cult was probably introduced into Greece from Anatolia, which is the origin of Sibyl, and where existed some of the oldest oraculare from Anatolia, which is the origin of Sibyl, and where exis shrines.
594	Omens, symbols, purifications, and exorcisms appear in old Assyro-Babylonian texts, and these rituals were spread into the empire of the Hittites.
594	In a Hittite text is mentioned that the king invited a Babylonian priestess for a certain "purification".
594	A similar story is mentioned by Plutarch.
594	He writes that the Cretan- seer Epimenides, purified Athens after the pollution brought by the Alcmeonidae, and that the seer's expertise in sacrifices and reform of funeral practices were of great help to Solon in his reform of the Athenian state.
594	The story indicates that Epimenides was probably heir to the shamanic religions of Asia, and proves together with the Homeric hymn, that Crete had a resisting religion up to the historical times.
594	It seems that these rituals were dormant in Greece, and they were reinforced when the Greeks migrated to Anatolia.
594	Homer pictures Apollo on the side of the Trojans, fighting against the Achaeans, during the Trojan War.
594	He is pictured as a terrible god, less trusted by the Greeks than other gods.
594	The god seems to be related to Appaliunas, a tutelary god of Wilusa (Troy) in Asia Minor, but the word is not complete.
594	The stones found in front of the gates of Homeric Troy were the symbols of Apollo.
594	The Greeks gave to him the name αγυιεύς agyieus as the protector god of public places and houses who wards off evil, and his symbol was a tapered stone or column.
594	However, while usually Greek festivals were celebrated at the full moon, all the feasts of Apollo were celebrated at the seventh day of the month, and the emphasis given to that day (sibutu) indicates a Babylonian origin.
594	The Late Bronze Age (from 1700 to 1200 BCE) Hittite and Hurrian Aplu was a god of plague, invoked during plague years.
594	Here we have an apotropaic situation, where a god originally bringing the plague was invoked to end it.
594	Aplu, meaning the son of, was a title given to the god Nergal, who was linked to the Babylonian god of the sun Shamash.
594	Homer interprets Apollo as a terrible god (δεινός θεός) who brings death and disease with his arrows, but who can also heal, possessing a magic art that separates him from the other Greek gods.
594	In Iliad, his priest prays to Apollo Smintheus, the mouse god who retains an older agricultural function as the protector from field rats.
594	All these functions, including the function of the healer-god Paean, who seems to have Mycenean origin, are fused in the cult of Apollo.
594	Oracular cult Unusually among the Olympic deities, Apollo had two cult sites that had widespread influence: Delos and Delphi.
594	In cult practice, Delian Apollo and Pythian Apollo (the Apollo of Delphi) were so distinct that they might both have shrines in the same locality.
594	Apollo's cult was already fully established when written sources commenced, about 650 BCE.
594	Apollo became extremely important to the Greek world as an oracular deity in the archaic period, and the frequency of theophoric names such as Apollodorus or Apollonios and cities named Apollonia testify to his popularity.
594	Oracular sanctuaries to Apollo were established in other sites.
594	In the 2nd and 3rd century CE, those at Didyma and Clarus pronounced the so-called "theological oracles", in which Apollo confirms that all deities are aspects or servants of an all-encompassing, highest deity.
594	"In the 3rd century, Apollo fell silent.
594	Julian the Apostate (359 - 61) tried to revive the Delphic oracle, but failed."
594	Oracular shrines Apollo had a famous oracle in Delphi, and other notable ones in Clarus and Branchidae.
594	His oracular shrine in Abae in Phocis, where he bore the toponymic epithet Abaeus (, Apollon Abaios) was important enough to be consulted by Croesus.
594	His oracular shrines include: * Abae in Phocis * Bassae in the Peloponnese * At Clarus, on the west coast of Asia Minor; as at Delphi a holy spring which gave off a pneuma, from which the priests drank.
594	In Corinth, the Oracle of Corinth came from the town of Tenea, from prisoners supposedly taken in the Trojan War.
594	At Khyrse, in Troad, the temple was built for Apollon Smintheus * In Delos, there was an oracle to the Delian Apollo, during summer.
594	The Hieron (Sanctuary) of Apollo adjacent to the Sacred Lake, was the place where the god was said to have been born.
594	In Delphi, the Pythia became filled with the pneuma of Apollo, said to come from a spring inside the Adyton.
594	In Didyma, an oracle on the coast of Anatolia, south west of Lydian (Luwian) Sardis, in which priests from the lineage of the Branchidae received inspiration by drinking from a healing spring located in the temple.
594	Was believed to have been founded by Branchus, son or lover of Apollo.
594	In Hierapolis Bambyce, Syria (modern Manbij), according to the treatise De Dea Syria, the sanctuary of the Syrian Goddess contained a robed and bearded image of Apollo.
594	Divination was based on spontaneous movements of this image.
594	At Patara, in Lycia, there was a seasonal winter oracle of Apollo, said to have been the place where the god went from Delos.
594	As at Delphi the oracle at Patara was a woman.
594	In Segesta in Sicily Oracles were also given by sons of Apollo.
594	In Oropus, north of Athens, the oracle Amphiaraus, was said to be the son of Apollo; Oropus also had a sacred spring.
594	Labadea, 20 mi east of Delphi, Trophonius, another son of Apollo, killed his brother and fled to the cave where he was also afterwards consulted as an oracle Mythology Birth When Zeus' wife Hera discovered that Leto was pregnant and that Zeus was the father, she banned Leto from giving birth on "terra firma".
594	In her wanderings, Leto found the newly created floating island of Delos, which was neitirma".
594	In her wanderings, Leto found the newly her mainland nor a real island.
594	She gave birth there and was accepted by the people, offering them her promise that her son would be always favourable toward the city.
594	Afterwards, Zeus secured Delos to the bottom of the ocean.
594	This island later became sacred to Apollo.
594	It is also stated that Hera kidnapped Eileithyia, the goddess of childbirth, to prevent Leto from going into labor.
594	The other gods tricked Hera into letting her go by offering her a necklace, nine yards (8 m) long, of amber.
594	Mythographers agree that Artemis was born first and then assisted with the birth of Apollo, or that Artemis was born one day before Apollo, on the island of Ortygia and that she helped Leto cross the sea to Delos the next day to give birth to Apollo.
594	Apollo was born on the seventh day () of the month Thargelion —according to Delian tradition—or of the month Bysios—according to Delphian tradition.
594	The seventh and twentieth, the days of the new and full moon, were ever afterwards held sacred to him.
594	Youth Four days after his birth, Apollo killed the chthonic dragon Python, which lived in Delphi beside the Castalian Spring.
594	This was the spring which emitted vapors that caused the oracle at Delphi to give her prophecies.
594	Hera sent the serpent to hunt Leto to her death across the world.
594	To protect his mother, Apollo begged Hephaestus for a bow and arrows.
594	After receiving them, Apollo cornered Python in the sacred cave at Delphi.
594	Apollo killed Python but had to be punished for it, since Python was a child of Gaia.
594	Hera then sent the giant Tityos to kill Leto.
594	This time Apollo was aided by his sister Artemis in protecting their mother.
594	During the battle Zeus finally relented his aid and hurled Tityos down to Tartarus.
594	There he was pegged to the rock floor, covering an area of 9 acre, where a pair of vultures feasted daily on his liver.
594	Trojan War Apollo shot arrows infected with the plague into the Greek encampment during the Trojan War in retribution for Agamemnon's insult to Chryses, a priest of Apollo whose daughter Chryseis had been captured.
594	He demanded her return, and the Achaeans complied, indirectly causing the anger of Achilles, which is the theme of the Iliad.
594	In the Iliad, when Diomedes injured Aeneas, Apollo rescued him.
594	First, Aphrodite tried to rescue Aeneas but Diomedes injured her as well.
594	Aeneas was then enveloped in a cloud by Apollo, who took him to Pergamos, a sacred spot in Troy.
594	Apollo aided Paris in the killing of Achilles by guiding the arrow of his bow into Achilles' heel.
594	One interpretation of his motive is that it was in revenge for Achilles' sacrilege in murdering Troilus, the god's own son by Hecuba, on the very altar of the god's own temple.
594	Admetus When Zeus struck down Apollo's son Asclepius with a lightning bolt for resurrecting Hippolytus from the dead (transgressing Themis by stealing Hades's subjects), Apollo in revenge killed the Cyclopes, who had fashioned the bolt for Zeus.
594	Apollo would have been banished to Tartarus forever, but was instead sentenced to one year of hard labor as punishment, due to the intercession of his mother, Leto.
594	During this time he served as shepherd for King Admetus of Pherae in Thessaly.
594	Admetus treated Apollo well, and, in return, the god conferred great benefits on Admetus.
594	Apollo helped Admetus win Alcestis, the daughter of King Pelias and later convinced the Fates to let Admetus live past his time, if another took his place.
594	But when it came time for Admetus to die, his parents, whom he had assumed would gladly die for him, refused to cooperate.
594	Instead, Alcestis took his place, but Heracles managed to "persuade" Thanatos, the god of death, to return her to the world of the living.
594	Niobe Niobe, the queen of Thebes and wife of Amphion, boasted of her superiority to Leto because she had fourteen children (Niobids), seven male and seven female, while Leto had only two.
594	Apollo killed her sons, and Artemis her daughters.
594	Apollo and Artemis used poisoned arrows to kill them, though according to some versions of the myth, a number of the Niobids were spared (Chloris, usually).
594	Amphion, at the sight of his dead sons, either killed himself or was killed by Apollo after swearing revenge.
594	A devastated Niobe fled to Mount Sipylos in Asia Minor and turned into stone as she wept.
594	Her tears formed the river Achelous.
594	Zeus had turned all the people of Thebes to stone and so no one buried the Niobids until the ninth day after their death, when the gods themselves entombed them.
594	Consorts and children Love affairs ascribed to Apollo are a late development in Greek mythology.
594	Their vivid anecdotal qualities have made favorites some of them of painters since the Renaissance, so that they stand out more prominently in the modern imagination.
594	Female lovers Daphne was a nymph, daughter of the river god Peneus, who had scorned Apollo.
594	The myth explains the connection of Apollo with δάφνη (daphnē), the laurel whose leaves his priestess employed at Delphi.
594	In Ovid's Metamorphoses, Phoebus Apollo chaffs Cupid for toying with a weapon more suited to a man, whereupon Cupid wounds him with a golden dart; simultaneously, however, Cupid shoots a leaden arrow into Daphne, causing her to be repulsed by Apollo.
594	Following a spirited chase by Apollo, Daphne prays to her father, Peneus, for help, and he changes her into the laurel tree, sacred to Apollo.
594	Artemis Daphnaia, who had her temple among the Lacedemonians, at a place called Hypsoi in Antiquity, on the slopes of Mount Cnacadion near the Spartan frontier, had her own sacred laurel trees.
594	At Eretria the identity of an excavated 7th and 6th century temple to Apollo Daphnephoros, "Apollo, laurel-bearer", or "carrying off Daphne", a "place where the citizens are to take the oath", is identified in inscriptions.
594	Leucothea was daughter of Orchamus and sister of Clytia.
594	She fell in love with Apollo who disguised himself as Leucothea's mother to gain entrance to her chambers.
594	Clytia, jealous of her sister because she wanted Apollo for herself, told Orchamus the truth, betraying her sister's trust and confidence in her.
594	Enraged, Orchamus ordered Leucothea to be buried alive.
594	Apollo refused to forgive Clytia for betraying his beloved, and a grieving Clytia wilted and slowly died.
594	Apollo changed her into an incense plant, either heliotrope or sunflower, which follows the sun every day.
594	Marpessa was kidnapped by Idas but was loved by Apollo as well.
594	Zeus made her choose between them, and she chose Idas on the grounds that Apollo, being immortal, would tire of her when she grew old.
594	Castalia was a nymph whom Apollo loved.
594	She fled from him and dove into the spring at Delphi, at the base of Mt.
594	Parnassos, which was then named after her.
594	Water from this spring was sacred; it was used to clean the Delphian temples and inspire the priestesses.
594	In the last oracle is mentioned that the "water which could speak", has been lost for ever.
594	By Cyrene, Apollo had a son named Aristaeus, who became the patron god of cattle, fruit trees, hunting, husbandry and bee-keeping.
594	He was also a culture-hero and taught humanity dairy skills, the use of nets and traps in hunting, and how to cultivate olives.
594	Hecuba, was the wife of King Priam of Troy, and Apollo had a son with her named Troilus.
594	An oracle prophesied that Troy would not be defeated as long as Troilus reached the age of twenty alive.
594	He was ambushed and killed by Achilleus.
594	Cassandra, was daughter of Hecuba and Priam, and Troilus' half-sister.
594	Apollo fell in love with Cassandra and promised her the gift of prophecy to seduce her, but she rejected him afterwards.
594	Enraged, Apollo indeed gifted her with the ability to know the future, with a curse that she could only see the future tragedies and that no one would ever believe her.
594	Coronis, was daughter of Phlegyas, King of the Lapiths.
594	Pregnant with Asclepius, Coronis fell in love with Ischys, son of Elatus.
594	A crow informed Apollo of the affair.
594	When first informed he disbelieved the crow and turned all crows black (where they were previously white) as a punishment for spreading untruths.
594	When he found out the truth he sent his sister, Artemis, to kill Coronis (in other stories, Apollo himself had killed Coronis).
594	As a result he also made the crow sacred and gave them the task of announcing important deaths.
594	Apollo rescued the baby and gave it to the centaur Chiron to raise.
594	Phlegyas was irate after the death of his daughter and burned the Temple of Apollo at Delphi.
594	Apollo then killed him for what he did.
594	In Euripides' play Ion, Apollo fathered Ion by Creusa, wife of Xuthus.
594	Creusa left Ion to die in the wild, but Apollo asked Hermes to save the child and bring him to the oracle at Delphi, where he was raised by a priestess.
594	Acantha, was the spirit of the acanthus tree, and Apollo had one of his other liaisons with her.
594	Upon her death, Apollo transformed her into a sun-loving herb.
594	According to the Biblioteca, the "library" of mythology mis-attributed to Apollodorus, he fathered the Corybantes on the Muse Thalia.
594	Consorts and children: extended list # Acacallis ## Amphithemis (Garamas) ## Naxos, eponym of the island Naxos ## Phylacides ## Phylander # Acantha # Aethusa ## Eleuther # Aganippe ## Chios # Alciope ## Linus (possibly) # Amphissa / Isse, daughter of Macareus # Anchiale / Acacallis ## Oaxes # Areia, daughter of Cleochus / Acacallis / Deione ## Miletus # Astycome, nymph ## Eumolpus (possibly) # Arsinoe, daughter of Leucippus ## Asclepius (possibly) ## Eriopis # Babylo ## Arabus # Bolina # Calliope, Muse ## Orpheus (possibly) ## Linus (possibly) ## Ialemus # Cassandra # Castalia # Celaeno, daughter of Hyamus / Melaina / Thyia ## Delphus # Chione / Philonis / Leuconoe ## Philammon # Chrysorthe ## Coronus # Chrysothemis ## Parthenos # Coronis ## Asclepius # Coryceia ## Lycorus (Lycoreus) # Creusa ## Ion # Cyrene ## Aristaeus ## Idmon (possibly) ## Autuchus # Danais, Cretan nymph ## The Curetes # Daphne # Dia, daughter of Lycaon ## Dryops # Dryope ## Amphissus # Euboea (daughter of Macareus of Locris) ## Agreus # Evadne, daughter of Poseidon ## Iamus # Gryne # Hecate ## Scylla (possibly) # Hecuba ## Troilus ## Hector (possibly) # Hestia (wooed her unsuccessfully) # Hypermnestra, wife of Oicles ## Amphiaraus (possibly) # Hypsipyle # Hyria (Thyria) ## Cycnus # Lycia, nymph or daughter of Xanthus ## Eicadius ## Patarus # Manto ## Mopsus # Marpessa # Melia ## Ismenus ## Tenerus # Ocyrhoe # Othreis ## Phager # Parnethia, nymph ## Cynnes # Parthenope ## Lycomedes # Phthia ## Dorus ## Laodocus ## Polypoetes # Prothoe # Procleia ## Tenes (possibly) # Psamathe ## Linus, not the same as the singer Linus # Rhoeo ## Anius # Rhodoessa, nymph ## Ceos, eponym of the island Ceos # Rhodope ## Cicon, eponym of the tribe Cicones # Sinope ## Syrus # Stilbe ## Centaurus ## Lapithes ## Aineus # Syllis / Hyllis ## Zeuxippus # Thaleia, Muse / Rhetia, nymph ## The Corybantes # Themisto, daughter of Zabius of Hyperborea ## Galeotes ## Telmessus (?) # Thero ## Chaeron # Urania, Muse ## Linus (possibly) # Urea, daughter of Poseidon ## Ileus (Oileus?) # Wife of Erginus ## Trophonius (possibly) # Unknown consorts ## Acraepheus, eponym of the city Acraephia ## Chariclo (possibly) ## Erymanthus ## Marathus, eponym of Marathon ## Megarus ## Melaneus ## Oncius ## Phemonoe ## Pisus, founder of Pisa in Etruria ## Younger Muses ### Cephisso ### Apollonis ### Borysthenis Male lovers Hyacinth or Hyacinthus was one of Apollo's male lovers.
594	He was a Spartan prince, beautiful and athletic.
594	The pair was practicing throwing the discus when a discus thrown by Apollo was blown off course by the jealous Zephyrus and struck Hyacinthus in the head, killing him instantly.
594	Apollo is said to be filled with grief: out of Hyacinthus' blood, Apollo created a flower named after him as a memorial to his death, and his tears stained the flower petals with άί άί, meaning alas.
594	The Festival of Hyacinthus was a celebration of Sparta.
594	Another male lover was Cyparissus, a descendant of Heracles.
594	Apollo gave him a tame deer as a companion but Cyparissus accidentally killed it with a javelin as it lay asleep in the undergrowth.
594	Cyparissus asked Apollo to let his tears fall forever.
594	Apollo granted the request by turning him into the Cypress named after him, which was said to be a sad tree because the sap forms droplets like tears on the trunk.
594	Other male lovers of Apollo include: * Admetus * Atymnius, otherwise known as a beloved of Sarpedon * Branchus (alternately, a son of Apollo) * Carnus * Clarus * Hippolytus of Sicyon (not the same as Hippolytus) * Hymenaios * Iapis * Leucates, who threw himself off a rock when Apollo attempted to carry him off * Phorbas (probably the son of Triopas) * Potnieus Apollo's lyre Hermes was born on Mount Cyllene in Arcadia.
594	The story is told in the Homeric Hymn to Hermes.
594	His mother, Maia, had been secretly impregnated by Zeus.
594	Maia wrapped the infant in blankets but Hermes escaped while she was asleep.
594	Hermes ran to Thessaly, where Apollo was grazing his cattle.
594	The infant Hermes stole a number of his cows and took them to a cave in the woods near Pylos, covering their tracks.
594	In the cave, he found a tortoise and killed it, then removed the insides.
594	He used one of the cow's intestines and the tortoise shell and made the first lyre.
594	Apollo complained to Maia that her son had stolen his cattle, but Hermes had already replaced himself in the blankets she had wrapped him in, so Maia refused to believe Apollo's claim.
594	Zeus intervened and, claiming to have seen the events, sided with Apollo.
594	Hermes then began to play music on the lyre he had invented.
594	Apollo, a god of music, fell in love with the instrument and offered to allow exchange of the cattle for the lyre.
594	Hence, Apollo then became a master of the lyre.
594	Apollo in the Oresteia In Aeschylus' Oresteia trilogy, Clytemnestra kills her husband, King Agamemnon because he had sacrificed their daughter Iphigenia to proceed forward with the Trojan war, and Cassandra, a prophetess of Apollo.
594	Apollo gives an order through the Oracle at Delphi that Agamemnon's son, Orestes, is to kill Clytemnestra and Aegisthus, her lover.
594	Orestes and Pylades carry out the revenge, and consequently Orestes is pursued by the Erinyes (Furies, female personifications of vengeance).
594	Apollo and the Furies argue about whether the matricide was justified; Apollo holds that the bond of marriage is sacred and Orestes was avenging his father, whereas the Erinyes say that the bond of blood between mother and son is more meaningful than the bond of marriage.
594	They invade his temple, and he says that the matter should be brought before Athena.
594	Apollo promises to protect Orestes, as Orestes has become Apollo's supplicant.
594	Apollo advocates Orestes at the trial, and ultimately Athena rules with Apollo.
594	Other stories Apollo killed the Aloadae when they attempted to storm Mt.
594	Olympus.
594	Callimachus sang that Apollo rode on the back of a swan to the land of the Hyperboreans during the winter months.
594	Apollo turned Cephissus into a sea monster.
594	Another contender for the birthplace of Apollo is the Cretan islands of Paximadia.
594	Musical contests Pan Once Pan had the audacity to compare his music with that of Apollo, and to challenge Apollo, the god of the kithara, to a trial of skill.
594	Tmolus, the mountain-god, was chosen to umpire.
594	Pan blew on his pipes, and with his rustic melody gave great satisfaction to himself and his faithful follower, Midas, who happened to be present.
594	Then Apollo struck the strings of his lyre.
594	Tmolus at once awarded the victory to Apollo, and all but Midas agreed with the judgment.
594	He dissented, and questioned the justice of the award.
594	Apollo would not suffer such a depraved pair of ears any longer, and caused them to become the ears of a donkey.
594	Marsyas Apollo has ominous aspects aside from his plague-bringing, death-dealing arrows: Marsyas was a satyr who challenged Apollo to a contest of music.
594	He had found an aulos on the ground, tossed away after being invented by Athena because it made her cheeks puffy.
594	The contest was judged by the Muses.
594	After they each performed, both were deemed equal until Apollo decreed they play and sing at the same time.
594	As Apollo played the lyre, this was easy to do.
594	Marsyas could not do this, as he only knew how to use the flute and could not sing at the same time.
594	Apollo was declared the winner because of this.
594	Apollo flayed Marsyas alive in a cave near Celaenae in Phrygia for his hubris to challenge a god.
594	He then nailed Marsyas' shaggy skin to a nea] in Phrygia]rby pine-tree.
594	Marsyas' blood turned into the river Marsyas.
594	Another variation is that Apollo played his instrument (the lyre) upside down.
594	Marsyas could not do this with his instrument (the flute), and so Apollo hung him from a tree and flayed him alive.
594	Cinyras Apollo also had a lyre-playing contest with Cinyras, his son, who committed suicide when he lost.
594	Roman Apollo The Roman worship of Apollo was adopted from the Greeks.
594	As a quintessentially Greek god, Apollo had no direct Roman equivalent, although later Roman poets often referred to him as Phoebus.
594	There was a tradition that the Delphic oracle was consulted as early as the period of the kings of Rome during the reign of Tarquinius Superbus.
594	On the occasion of a pestilence in the 430s BCE, Apollo's first temple at Rome was established in the Flaminian fields, replacing an older cult site there known as the "Apollinare".
594	During the Second Punic War in 212 BCE, the Ludi Apollinares ("Apollonian Games") were instituted in his honor, on the instructions of a prophecy attributed to one Marcius.
594	In the time of Augustus, who considered himself under the special protection of Apollo and was even said to be his son, his worship developed and he became one of the chief gods of Rome.
594	After the battle of Actium, which was fought near a sanctuary of Apollo, Augustus enlarged Apollo's temple, dedicated a portion of the spoils to him, and instituted quinquennial games in his honour.
594	He also erected a new temple to the god on the Palatine hill.
594	Sacrifices and prayers on the Palatine to Apollo and Diana formed the culmination of the Secular Games, held in 17 BCE to celebrate the dawn of a new era.
594	Festivals The chief Apollonian festivals were the Boedromia, Carneia, Carpiae, Daphnephoria, Delia, Hyacinthia, Metageitnia, Pyanepsia, Pythia and Thargelia.
594	Attributes and symbols Apollo's most common attributes were the bow and arrow.
594	Other attributes of his included the kithara (an advanced version of the common lyre), the plectrum and the sword.
594	Another common emblem was the sacrificial tripod, representing his prophetic powers.
594	The Pythian Games were held in Apollo's honor every four years at Delphi.
594	The bay laurel plant was used in expiatory sacrifices and in making the crown of victory at these games.
594	The palm tree was also sacred to Apollo because he had been born under one in Delos.
594	Animals sacred to Apollo included wolves, dolphins, roe deer, swans, cicadas (symbolizing music and song), hawks, ravens, crows, snakes (referencing Apollo's function as the god of prophecy), mice and griffins, mythical eagle–lion hybrids of Eastern origin.
594	As god of colonization, Apollo gave oracular guidance on colonies, especially during the height of colonization, 750–550 BCE.
594	According to Greek tradition, he helped Cretan or Arcadian colonists found the city of Troy.
594	However, this story may reflect a cultural influence which had the reverse direction: Hittite cuneiform texts mention a Minor Asian god called Appaliunas or Apalunas in connection with the city of Wilusa attested in Hittite inscriptions, which is now generally regarded as being identical with the Greek Ilion by most scholars.
594	In this interpretation, Apollo's title of Lykegenes can simply be read as "born in Lycia", which effectively severs the god's supposed link with wolves (possibly a folk etymology).
594	In literary contexts, Apollo represents harmony, order, and reason—characteristics contrasted with those of Dionysus, god of wine, who represents ecstasy and disorder.
594	The contrast between the roles of these gods is reflected in the adjectives Apollonian and Dionysian.
594	However, the Greeks thought of the two qualities as complementary: the two gods are brothers, and when Apollo at winter left for Hyperborea, he would leave the Delphic oracle to Dionysus.
594	This contrast appears to be shown on the two sides of the Borghese Vase.
594	Apollo is often associated with the Golden Mean.
594	This is the Greek ideal of moderation and a virtue that opposes gluttony.
594	Apollo in the arts Apollo is a common theme in Greek and Roman art and also in the art of the Renaissance.
594	The earliest Greek word for a statue is "delight" (άγαλμα: agalma), and the sculptors tried to create forms which would inspire such guiding vision.
594	Greek art puts into Apollo the highest degree of power and beauty that can be imagined.
594	The sculptors derived this from observations on human beings, but they also embodied in concrete form, issues beyond the reach of ordinary thought.
594	The naked bodies of the statues are associated with the cult of the body that was essentially a religious activity.
594	The muscular frames and limbs combined with slim waists indicate the Greek desire for health, and the physical capacity which was necessary in the hard Greek environment.
594	The statues of Apollo embody beauty, balance and inspire awe before the beauty of the world.
594	The evolution of the Greek sculpture can be observed in his depictions from the almost static formal Kouros type in early archaic period, to the representation of motion in a relative harmonious whole in late archaic period.
594	In classical Greece the emphasis is not given to theaic period in Greece|late a illusive imaginative reality represented by the ideal forms, but to the analogies and the interaction of the members in the whole, a method created by Polykleitos.
594	Finally Praxiteles seems to be released from any art and religious conformities, and his masterpieces are a mixture of naturalism with stylization.
594	Art and Greek philosophy The evolution of the Greek art seems to go parallel with the Greek philosophical conceptions, which changed from the natural-philosophy of Thales to the metaphysical theory of Pythagoras.
594	Thales searched for a simple material-form directly perceptible by the senses, behind the appearances of things, and his theory is also related to the older animism.
594	This was paralleled in sculpture by the absolute representation of vigorous life, through unnaturally simplified forms.
594	Pythagoras believed that behind the appearance of things, there was the permanent principle of mathematics, and that the forms were based on a transcendental mathematical relation.
594	The forms on earth, are imperfect imitations ( εικών, ikon :image) of the celestial world of numbers.
594	His ideas had a great influence on post-Archaic art, and the Greek architects and sculptors were always trying to find the mathematical relation, that would lead to the esthetic perfection.
594	In classical Greece, Anaxagoras asserted that a divine reason (mind) gave order to the seeds of the universe, and Plato extended the Greek belief of ideal forms to his metaphysical theory of forms (ideai: ideas).
594	The forms on earth are imperfect duplicates of the intellectual celestial ideas.
594	The Greek words "ida" ( οίδα:know) and "idos" (είδος:species) have the same root as the word "idea" (ιδέα), indicating how the Greek mind moved from the gift of the senses, to the principles beyond the senses.
594	The artists in Plato's time moved away from his theories and art tends to be a mixture of naturalism with stylization.
594	The Greek sculptors considered the senses more important, and the proportions were used to unite the sensible with the intellectual.
594	Archaic sculpture Kouros (male youth) is the modern term given to those representations of standing male youths which first appear in the archaic period in Greece.
594	This type served certain religious needs and was first proposed for what was previously thought to be depictions of Apollo.
594	The first statues are certainly still and formal.
594	The formality of their stance seems to be related with the Egyptian precedent, but it was accepted for a good reason.
594	The sculptors had a clear idea of what a young man is, and embodied the archaic smile of good manners, the firm and springy step, the balance of the body, dignity, and youthful happiness.
594	When they tried to depict the most abiding qualities of men, it was because men had common roots with the unchanging gods.
594	The adoption of a standard recognizable type for a long time, is probably because nature gives preference in survival of a type which has long be adopted by the climatic conditions, and also due to the general Greek belief that nature expresses itself in ideal forms that can be imagined and represented.
594	These forms expressed immortality.
594	Apollo was the immortal god of ideal balance and order; his shrine in Delphi has the inscription: "Nothing in excess".
594	In the first large-scale depictions during the early archaic period (640–580 BC), the artists tried to draw one's attention to look into the interior of the face and the body which were not represented as lifeless masses, but as being full of life.
594	The Greeks maintained, until late in their civilization, an almost animistic idea that the statues are in some sense alive.
594	This embodies the belief that the image was somehow the god or man himself.
594	A fine example is the statue of the Sacred gate Kouros which was found at the cemetery of Dipylon in Athens (Dipylon Kouros).
594	The statue is the "thing in itself", and his slender face with the deep eyes express an intellectual eternity.
594	According to the Greek tradition the Dipylon master was named Daedalus, and in his statues the limbs were freed from the body, giving the impression that the statues could move.
594	It is considered that he created also the New York kouros, which is the oldest fully preserved statue of Kouros type, and seems to be the incarnation of the god himself.
594	The animistic idea as the representation of the imaginative reality, is sanctified in the Homeric poems and in Greek myths, in stories of the god Hephaestus (Phaistos) and the mythic Daedalus (the builder of the labyrinth) that made images which moved of their own accord.
594	This kind of art goes back to the Minoan period, when its main theme was the representation of motion in a specific moment.
594	These free-standing statues were usually marble, but also the form rendered in limestone, bronze, ivory and terracotta.
594	The earliest examples of life-sized statues of Apollo, may be two figures from the Ionic sanctuary on the island of Delos.
594	Such statues were found across the Greek speaking world, the preponderance of these were found at the sanctuaries of Apollo with more than one hundred from the sanctuary of Apollo Ptoios, Boeotia alone.
594	The last stage in the development of the Kouros type is the late archaic period (520–485 BC), in which the Greek sculpture attained a full knowledge of human anatomy and used to create a relative harmonious whole.
594	Ranking from the very few bronzes survived to us is the masterpiece bronze Piraeus Apollo.
594	It was found in Piraeus, the harbour of Athens.
594	The statue originally held the bow in its left hand, and a cup of pouring libation in its right hand.
594	It probably comes from north-eastern Peloponnesus.
594	The emphasis is given in anatomy, and it is one of the first attempts to represent a kind of motion, and beauty relative to proportions, which appear mostly in post-Archaic art.
594	The statue throws some light on an artistic centre which, with an independently developed harder, simpler, and heavier style, restricts Ionian influence in Athens.
594	Finally, this is the germ from which the art of Polykleitos was to grow two or three generations later.
594	Classical Sculpture In the next century which is the beginning of the Classical period, it was considered that beauty in visible things as in everything else, consisted of symmetry and proportions.
594	The artists tried also to represent motion in a specific moment (Myron), which may be considered as the reappearance of the dormant Minoan element.
594	Anatomy and geometry are fused in one, and each does something to the other.
594	The Greek sculptors tried to clarify it by looking for mathematical proportions, just as they sought some reality behind appearances.
594	Polykleitos in his Canon wrote that beauty consists in the proportion not of the elements ( materials), but of the parts, that is the interrelation of parts with one another and with the whole.
594	It seems that he was influenced by the theories of Pythagoras.
594	The famous Apollo of Mantua and its variants are early forms of the Apollo Citharoedus statue type, in which the god holds the cithara in his left arm.
594	The type is represented by neo-Attic Imperial Roman copies of the late 1st or early 2nd century, modelled upon a supposed Greek bronze original made in the second quarter of the 5th century BCE, in a style similar to works of Polykleitos but more archaic.
594	The Apollo held the cythara against his extended left arm, of which in the Louvre example, a fragment of one twisting scrolling horn upright remains against his biceps.
594	Though the proportions were always important in Greek art, the appeal of the Greek sculptures eludes any explanation by proportion alone.
594	The statues of Apollo were thought to incarnate his living presence, and these representations of illusive imaginative reality had deep roots in the Minoan period, and in the beliefs of the first Greek speaking people who entered the region during the bronze-age.
594	Just as the Greeks saw the mountains, forests, sea and rivers as inhabited by concrete beings, so nature in all of its manifestations possesses clear form, and the form of a work of art.
594	Spiritual life is incorporated in matter, when it is given artistic form.
594	Just as in the arts the Greeks sought some reality behind appearances, so in mathematics they sought permanent principles which could be applied wherever the conditions were the same.
594	Artists and sculptors tried to find this ideal order in relation with mathematics, but they believed that this ideal order revealed itself not so much to the dispassionate intellect, as to the whole sentient self.
594	Things as we see them, and as they really are, are one, that each stresses the nature of the other in a single unity.
594	Pediments and Friezes In the archaic pediments and friezes of the temples, the artists had a problem to fit a group of figures into an isosceles triangle with acute angles at the base.
594	The Siphnian Treasury in Delphi was one of the first Greek buildings utilizing the solution to put the dominating form in the middle, and to complete the descending scale of height with other figures sitting or kneeling.
594	The pediment shows the story of Heracles stealing Apollo's tripod that was strongly associated with his oracular inspiration.
594	Their two figures hold the centre.
594	In the pediment of the temple of Zeus in Olympia, the single figure of Apollo is dominating the scene.
594	These representations rely on presenting scenes directly to the eye for their own visible sake.
594	They care for the schematic arrangements of bodies in space, but only as parts in a larger whole.
594	While each scene has its own character and completeness it must fit into the general sequence to which it belongs.
594	In these archaic pediments the sculptors use empty intervals, to suggest a passage to and fro a busy battlefield.
594	The artists seem to have been dominated by geometrical pattern and order, and this was improved when classical art brought a greater freedom and economy.
594	Hellenistic Greece-Rome Apollo as a handsome beardless young man, is often depicted with a kithara (as Apollo Citharoedus) or bow in his hand, or reclining on a tree (the Apollo Lykeios and Apollo Sauroctonos types).
594	The Apollo Belvedere is a marble sculpture that was rediscovered in the late 15th century; for centuries it epitomized the ideals of Classical Antiquity for Europeans, from the Renaissance through the 19th century.
594	The marble is a Hellenistic or Roman copy of a bronze original by the Greek sculptor Leochares, made between 350 and 325 BCE.
594	The life-size so-called "Adonis" found in 1780 on the site of a villa suburbana near the Via Labicana in the Roman suburb of Centocelle is identified as an Apollo by modern scholars.
594	In the late 2nd century CE floor mosaic from El Djem, Roman Thysdrus, he is identifiable as Apollo Helios by his effulgent halo, though now even a god's divine nakedness is concealed by his cloak, a mark of increasing conventions of modesty in the later Empire.
594	Another haloed Apollo in mosaic, from Hadrumentum, is in the museum at Sousse.
594	The conventions of this representation, head tilted, lips slightly parted, large-eyed, curling hair cut in locks grazing the neck, were developed in the 3rd century BCE to depict Alexander the Great.
594	Some time after this mosaic was executed, the earliest depictions of Christ would also be beardless and haloed.
594	Modern reception Apollo has often featured in postclassical art and literature.
594	Percy Bysshe Shelley composed a "Hymn of Apollo" (1820), and the god's instruction of the Muses formed the subject of Igor Stravinsky's Apollon musagète (1927–1928).
594	In discussion of the arts, a distinction is sometimes made between the Apollonian and Dionysian impulses where the former is concerned with imposing intellectual order and the latter with chaotic creativity.
594	Friedrich Nietzsche argued that a fusion of the two was most desirable.
594	Carl Jung's Apollo archetype represents what he saw as the disposition in people to over-intellectualise and maintain emotional distance.
595	Andre Kirk Agassi (; born April 29, 1970, in Las Vegas, Nevada) is an American retired professional tennis player and former World No.
595	Generally considered by critics and fellow players to be one of the greatest tennis players of all time, Agassi has been called the best service returner in the history of the game.
595	Described by the BBC upon his retirement as "perhaps the biggest worldwide star in the sport's history", Agassi compiled performances that, along with his unorthodox apparel and attitude, saw him cited as one of the most charismatic players in the history of the game.
595	As a result, he is credited for helping to revive the popularity of tennis during the 1990s.
595	In singles tennis, Agassi is an eight-time Grand Slam champion who competed in 15 Grand Slam finals and a 1996 Olympic gold medalist.
595	His four Australian Open titles are an Open Era record (shared with Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer).
595	He is one of four male singles players to achieve the Career Grand Slam (all four Grand Slam championships) in the Open Era and one of seven in history, the first of two to achieve the Career Golden Slam (Career Grand Slam and Olympic gold medal), and the only man to win the Career Golden Slam and the ATP Tour World Championships (won in 1990): a distinction dubbed as a "Career Super Slam" by Sports Illustrated.
595	Agassi was the first male player to win all four Grand Slams on three different surfaces (hard, clay and grass), and the last American male to win the French Open (1999) and the Australian Open (2003).
595	He also won 17 ATP Masters Series titles and was part of a winning Davis Cup team in 1990 and 1992.
595	Agassi was troubled by personal issues during the mid-to-late 1990s and sank to world no.
595	Agassi, however, returned to world no.
595	During his 20-plus year tour career, Agassi was known by the nickname "The Punisher".
595	After suffering from sciatica caused by two bulging discs in his back, a spondylolisthesis (vertebral displacement) and a bone spur that interfered with the nerve, Agassi retired from professional tennis on September 3, 2006, after losing in the third round of the US Open.
595	He is the founder of the Andre Agassi Charitable Foundation, which has raised over $60 million for at-risk children in Southern Nevada.
595	In 2001, the Foundation opened the Andre Agassi College Preparatory Academy in Las Vegas, a K-12 public charter school for at-risk children.
595	He has been married to fellow tennis star Steffi Graf since 2001.
595	Early life Agassi was born in Las Vegas, Nevada, to Emmanuel "Mike" Agassi and Elizabeth "Betty" Agassi (née Dudley).
595	His father, a former Olympic boxer for Iran, is of Armenian and Assyrian descent and changed the family name to Agassi after his migration to the United States.
595	Andre Agassi's mother, Betty, is a breast cancer survivor.
595	He has three older siblings – Rita (last wife to Pancho Gonzales), Philip and Tami.
595	In a passage from the book Open, Agassi details how his father made him play a match for money with football legend Jim Brown, in 1979, when Agassi was 9 years old.
595	Brown was at a Vegas tennis club complaining to the owner about a money match that was canceled.
595	Agassi's father stepped in and told Brown that he could play his son and he would put up his house for the wager.
595	Brown countered with a $10,000 bet, but after he was warned by the club owner not to take the bet because he would lose and be embarrassed, Brown agreed with Mike Agassi that they would set the amount after he and Andre played two sets.
595	Brown lost those sets, 3–6, 3–6, declined the 10K wager, and offered to play the third set for $500.
595	He lost 2–6.
595	At age 13, Andre was sent to Nick Bollettieri's Tennis Academy in Florida.
595	He was meant to stay for only 3 months because that was all his father could afford.
595	After thirty minutes of watching Agassi play, Bollettieri called Mike and said: "Take your check back.
595	He's here for free," claiming that Agassi had more natural talent than anyone else he had seen.
595	Agassi dropped out of school in the ninth grade.
595	International tennis career biography 1986–1993 He turned professional at the age of 16 and competed in his first tournament at La Quinta, California.
595	He won his first match against John Austin, but then lost his second match to Mats Wilander.
595	By the end of the year, Agassi was ranked world no.
595	He won his first top-level singles title in 1987 at the Sul American Open in Itaparica and ended the year ranked world no.
595	He won six additional tournaments in 1988 (Memphis, U.S.
595	Men's Clay Court Championships, Forest Hills WCT, Stuttgart Outdoor, Volvo International and Livingston Open), and, by December of that year, he had surpassed US$1 million in career prize money after playing in just 43 tournaments—the fastest anyone in history had reached that level.
595	During the year, he set the open-era record for most consecutive victories by a male teenager, a record that stood for 17 years until Rafael Nadal broke it in 2005.
595	His year-end ranking was world no.
595	Ivan Lendl and top-ranked Mats Wilander.
595	Both the Association of Tennis Professionals and Tennis magazine named Agassi the Most Improved Player of the Year for 1988.
595	In addition to not playing the Australian Open (which later became his best Grand Slam event) for the first eight years of his career, Agassi chose not to play at Wimbledon from 1988 through 1990 and publicly stated that he did not wish to play there because of the event's traditionalism, particularly its "predominantly white" dress code to which players at the event are required to conform.
595	Strong performances on the tour meant that Agassi was quickly tipped as a future Grand Slam champion.
595	While still a teenager, he reached the semifinals of both the French Open and the US Open in 1988 and made the US Open semifinals in 1989.
595	He began the 1990s, however, with a series of near-misses.
595	He reached his first Grand Slam final in 1990 at the French Open, where he was favored before losing in four sets to Andrés Gómez.
595	He reached his second Grand Slam final of the year at the US Open, defeating defending champion Boris Becker in the semifinals.
595	His opponent in the final was Pete Sampras; a year earlier, Agassi had crushed Sampras, after which he told his coach that he felt bad for Sampras because he was never going to make it as a pro.
595	Agassi lost the US Open final to Sampras in three sets.
595	The rivalry between these two American players became the dominant rivalry in tennis over the rest of the decade.
595	Also in 1990, Agassi helped the United States win its first Davis Cup in 8 years and won his only Tennis Masters Cup, beating reigning Wimbledon champion Stefan Edberg in the final.
595	In 1991, Agassi reached his second consecutive French Open final, where he faced fellow Bollettieri Academy alumnus Jim Courier.
595	Courier emerged the victor in a five-set final.
595	Agassi decided to play at Wimbledon in 1991, leading to weeks of speculation in the media about the clothes he would wear.
595	He eventually emerged for the first round in a completely white outfit.
595	He reached the quarterfinals on that occasion, losing in five sets to David Wheaton.
595	Agassi's Grand Slam tournament breakthrough came at Wimbledon, not at the French Open or the US Open, where he had previously enjoyed success.
595	In 1992, he defeated Goran Ivanišević in a five-set final.
595	Along the way, Agassi overcame two former Wimbledon champions: Boris Becker and John McEnroe.
595	No other baseliner would triumph at Wimbledon until Lleyton Hewitt ten years later.
595	Agassi was named the BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year in 1992.
595	Agassi once again played on the United States' Davis Cup winning team in 1992.
595	It was their second Davis cup title in three years.
595	Agassi win the only doubles title of his career, at the Cincinnati Masters, partnered with Petr Korda.
595	Agassi missed ms title of his career, at the uch of the early part of that year with injuries.
595	Although he made the quarterfinals in his Wimbledon title defense, he lost to eventual champion and world no.
595	Pete Sampras in five sets.
595	Agassi lost in the first round at the US Open to Thomas Enqvist and required wrist surgery late in the year.
595	With new coach Brad Gilbert on board, Agassi began to employ more of a tactical, consistent approach, which fueled his resurgence.
595	He started slowly in 1994, losing in the first week at the French Open and Wimbledon.
595	Nevertheless, he emerged during the hard-court season, winning the Canadian Open.
595	His comeback culminated at the 1994 US Open with a five-set fourth-round victory against compatriot Michael Chang.
595	He then became the first man to capture the US Open as an unseeded player, beating Michael Stich in the final.
595	In 1996, Agassi shaved his balding head, breaking with his old "image is everything" style.
595	He competed in the 1995 Australian Open (his first appearance at the event) and won, beating Sampras in a four-set final.
595	Agassi and Sampras met in five tournament finals in 1995, all on hardcourt, with Agassi winning three.
595	Agassi won three Masters Series events in 1995 (Cincinnati, Key Biscayne, and the Canadian Open) and seven titles total.
595	He compiled a career-best 26-match winning streak during the summer hard-court circuit, which ended when he lost the US Open final to Sampras.
595	Agassi reached the world no.
595	April 1995.
595	He held that ranking until November, for a total of 30 weeks.
595	In terms of win/loss record, 1995 was Agassi's best year.
595	He won 73 matches and lost 9.
595	Agassi was also once again a key player on the United States' Davis Cup winning team—the third and final Davis Cup title of Agassi's career.
595	Agassi, as he failed to reach any Grand Slam final.
595	He suffered two early-round losses at the hands of compatriots Chris Woodruff and Doug Flach at the French Open and Wimbledon, respectively, and lost to Chang in straight sets in the Australian and US Open semifinals.
595	At the time, Agassi blamed the Australian Open loss on the windy conditions, but later said in his biography that he had lost the match on purpose, as he did not want to play Boris Becker, whom he would have faced in that final.
595	The high point for Agassi was winning the men's singles gold medal at the Olympic Games in Atlanta, beating Sergi Bruguera of Spain in the final.
595	Agassi also successfully defended his singles titles in Cincinnati and Key Biscayne.
595	Agassi's career.
595	His wrist injury resurfaced, and he played only 24 matches during the year.
595	He later confessed that he started using crystal methamphetamine at that time, allegedly on the urging of a friend.
595	He failed an ATP drug test, but wrote a letter claiming the same friend had spiked a drink.
595	The ATP dropped the failed drug test as a warning.
595	In his autobiography, Agassi admitted that the letter was a lie.
595	He quit the drug soon after.
595	At this time Agassi was also in a failing marriage with actress Brooke Shields and had lost interest in the game.
595	He won no top-level titles, and his ranking sank to world no.
595	November 10, 1997, prompting many to believe that his run as one of the sport's premier competitors was over and that he would never again win any significant championships.
595	In 1998, Agassi began a rigorous conditioning program and worked his way back up the rankings by playing in Challenger Series tournaments, a circuit for pro players ranked outside the world's top 50.
595	He also played classic matches in this period against Pete Sampras and Patrick Rafter.
595	In 1998, Agassi won five titles and leapt from world no.
595	At Wimbledon, he had an early loss in the second round to Tommy Haas.
595	He won five titles in ten finals and was runner-up at the Masters Series tournament in Key Biscayne, losing to Marcelo Ríos, who became world no.
595	Agassi entered the history books in 1999 when he came back from two sets to love down to beat Andrei Medvedev in a five-set French Open final, becoming, at the time, only the fifth male player (joining Rod Laver, Fred Perry, Roy Emerson and Don Budge—these have since been joined by a sixth, Roger Federer and a seventh, Rafael Nadal) to win all four Grand Slam singles titles during his career.
595	Only Laver, Agassi, Federer and Nadal have achieved this feat during the open era.
595	This win also made him the first (of only three, the second being Roger Federer and the third being Rafael Nadal) male player in history to have won all four Grand Slam titles on three different surfaces (clay, grass and hard courts), a tribute to his adaptability, as the other four men won their Grand Slam titles on clay and grass courts.
595	Agassi also became the first (of only two, the second being Rafael Nadal) male player to win the Career Golden Slam, consisting of all four Grand Slam tournaments plus an Olympic gold medal.
595	Agassi followed his 1999 French Open victory by reaching the Wimbledon final, where he lost to Sampras in straight sets.
595	He rebounded from his Wimbledon defeat by winning the US Open, beating Todd Martin in five sets (rallying from a two sets to one deficit) in the final.
595	Agassi ended 1999 as the world no.
595	Sampras's record of six consecutive year-ending top rankings (1993–1998).
595	This was the only time Agassi ended the year at no.
595	He began the next year by capturing his second Australian Open title, beating Sampras in a five-set semifinal and Yevgeny Kafelnikov in a four-set final.
595	He was the first male player to have reached four consecutive Grand Slam finals since Rod Laver achieved the Grand Slam in 1969.
595	At the time, Agassi was also only the fourth player since Laver to be the reigning champion of three of four Grand Slam events, missing only the Wimbledon title.
595	Agassi reach the semifinals at Wimbledon, where he lost in five sets to Rafter in a match considered by many to be one of the best ever at Wimbledon.
595	At the inaugural Tennis Masters Cup in Lisbon, Agassi reached the final after defeating Marat Safin in the semifinals to end the Russian's hopes to become the youngest world no.
595	Agassi then lost to Gustavo Kuerten in the final, allowing Kuerten to be crowned year-end world no.
595	Agassi opened 2001 by successfully defending his Australian Open title with a straight-sets final win over Arnaud Clément.
595	En route, he beat a cramping Rafter in five sets in front of a sell-out crowd in what turned out to be the Aussie's last Australian Open.
595	At Wimbledon, they met again in the semifinals, where Agassi lost another close match to Rafter, 8–6 in the fifth set.
595	In the quarterfinals at the US Open, Agassi lost a 3 hour, 33 minute epic match with Sampras, 7–6, 6–7, 6–7, 6–7, with no breaks of serve during the 48-game match.
595	Despite the setback, Agassi finished 2001 ranked world no.
595	He also was the oldest player (age 31) to finish in the top three since 32-year old Connors finished at world no.
595	Agassi, as injury forced him to skip the Australian Open, where he was a two-time defending champion.
595	The last duel between Agassi and Sampras came in the final of the US Open, which Sampras won in four sets and left Sampras with a 20–14 edge in their 34 career meetings.
595	The match was the last of Sampras's career.
595	Agassi's US Open finish, along with his Masters Series victories in Key Biscayne, Rome and Madrid, helped him finish 2002 as the oldest year-end world no.
595	In 2003, Agassi won the eighth (and final) Grand Slam title of his career at the Australian Open, where he beat Rainer Schüttler in straight sets in the final.
595	In March, he won his sixth career and third consecutive Key Biscayne title, in the process surpassing his wife, Steffi Graf, who was a five-time winner of the event.
595	The final was his 18th straight win in that tournament, which broke the previous record of 17 set by Sampras from 1993–1995.
595	Agassi's winning streak continued to 20 after winning his first two matches at the 2004 edition of that tournament before bowing to Agustín Calleri.) With the victory, Agassi became the youngest (19 years old) and oldest (32) winner of the Key Biscayne tournament.
595	On April 28, 2003, he recaptured the world no.
595	Xavier Malisse at the Queen's Club Championships to become the oldest top-ranked male player since the ATP rankings began at 33 years and 13 days.
595	He had held the world no.
595	Lleyton Hewitt took it back on May 12, 2003.
595	Agassi then recaptured the world no.
595	June 16, 2003, which he held for 12 weeks until September 7, 2003.
595	During his career, Agassi held the world no.
595	Agassi's ranking slipped when injuries forced him to withdraw from many events.
595	He did manage to reach the US Open semifinals, where he lost to Juan Carlos Ferrero and surrendered his world no.
595	Ferrero.
595	At the year-end Tennis Masters Cup, Agassi lost in the final to Federer and finished the year ranked world no.
595	At age 33, he was the oldest player to rank in the top 5 since Connors, at age 35, was world no.
595	In 2004, Agassi began the year with a five-set loss in the semifinals of the Australian Open to Marat Safin; the loss ended Agassi's 26-match winning streak at the event, a record that still stands.
595	He won the Masters series event in Cincinnati to bring his career total to 59 top-level singles titles and a record 17 ATP Masters Series titles, having already won seven of the nine ATP Masters tournament—all except the tournaments in Monte Carlo and Hamburg.
595	At 34, he became the second-oldest singles champion in Cincinnati tournament history (the tournament began in 1899), surpassed only by Ken Rosewall, who won the title in 1970 at age 35.
595	He finished the year ranked world no.
595	Connors was world no.
595	Agassi also became only the sixth male player during the open era to reach 800 career wins with his first-round victory over Alex Bogomolov in Countrywide Classic in Los Angeles.
595	Agassi's 2005 began with a quarterfinal loss to Federer at the Australian Open.
595	Agassi had several other deep runs at tournaments, but had to withdraw from several events due to injury.
595	He lost to Jarkko Nieminen in the first round of the French Open.
595	He won his fourth title in Los Angeles and reached the final of the Rogers Cup, before falling to world no.
595	Rafael Nadal.
595	Agassi's 2005 was defined by an improbable run to the US Open final.
595	After beating Răzvan Sabău and Ivo Karlović in straight sets and Tomáš Berdych in four sets, Agassi won three consecutive five-set matches to advance to the final.
595	The most notable of these matches was his quarterfinal victory over James Blake, where he rallied from two sets down to win 7–6 in the fifth set.
595	His other five-set victims were Xavier Malisse in the fourth round and Robby Ginepri in the semifinals.
595	In the final, Agassi faced Federer, who was seeking his second consecutive US Open title and his sixth Grand Slam title in two years.
595	Federer defeated Agassi in four sets, although Agassi gave him a scare when Agassi was up a break in the third set after splitting the first two sets.
595	Before the a scare when Agassi was up a break in the 2005 Tennis Masters Cup in Shanghai, Agassi rolled his ankle in a racquetball accident and tore several ligaments.
595	He was unable to walk for weeks.
595	He nevertheless committed to the tournament, in which he was seeded third, and played Nikolay Davydenko in his first round-robin match.
595	Agassi's movement was noticeably hindered, particularly on his backhand return of serve, and he lost in straight sets.
595	He then withdrew from the tournament.
595	Agassi finished 2005 ranked world no.
595	Connors for the most times ranked in the top 10 at year's end.
595	In 2005, Agassi left Nike after 17 years and signed an endorsement deal with Adidas.
595	A major reason for Agassi leaving Nike was because Nike refused to donate to Agassi's charities, and Adidas was more than happy to do so.
595	Agassi had a poor start to 2006.
595	He was still recovering from an ankle injury and also suffering from back and leg pain and lack of match play.
595	Agassi withdrew from the Australian Open because of the ankle injury, and his back injury and other pains forced him to withdraw from several other events, eventually skipping the entire clay-court season, including the French Open.
595	This caused his ranking to drop out of the top 10 for the last time.
595	Agassi returned for the grass-court season, playing a tune-up, and then Wimbledon.
595	He was defeated in the third round by world no.
595	Rafael Nadal.
595	Against conventions, Agassi, the losing player, was interviewed on court after the match.
595	At Wimbledon, Agassi announced his plans to retire following the US Open.
595	Agassi played only two events during the summer hard-court season, with his best result being a quarterfinal loss at the Countrywide Classic in Los Angeles to Fernando González of Chile.
595	As a result, he was unseeded at the US Open.
595	Agassi had a short, but dramatic, run in his final US Open.
595	Because of extreme back pain, Agassi was forced to receive anti-inflammatory injections after every match.
595	After a tough four-set win against Andrei Pavel, Agassi faced eighth-seeded Marcos Baghdatis in the second round, who had earlier advanced to the 2006 Australian Open final and Wimbledon semifinals.
595	Agassi won in five tough sets as the younger Baghdatis succumbed to muscle cramping in the final set.
595	In his last match, Agassi fell to 112th-ranked big-serving Benjamin Becker of Germany in four sets.
595	Agassi received a four-minute standing ovation from the crowd after the match and delivered a retirement speech.
595	Earnings Agassi earned more than US$ 30 million in prize-money during his career, fifth only to Federer, Nadal, Sampras and Djokovic to date.
595	He also earned more than US$25 million a year through endorsements during his career, fourth in all sports at the time.
595	Post-retirement Since retiring after the 2006 US Open, Agassi has participated in a series of charity tournaments and continues his work with his own charity.
595	On September 5, 2007, he was a surprise guest commentator for the Andy Roddick/Roger Federer US Open quarter-final.
595	He played an exhibition match at Wimbledon, teaming with his wife, Steffi Graf, to play with Tim Henman and Kim Clijsters.
595	He played World Team Tennis for the Philadelphia Freedoms in the summer of 2009 and played at the Outback Champions Series event for the first time.
595	He played the Cancer Treatment Centers of America Tennis Championships at Surprise, Arizona, where he reached the final before bowing to eventual champion Todd Martin.
595	On the way to the final, Agassi beat Mikael Pernfors in the quarter-finals and Wayne Ferreira in the semi-finals.
595	He also announced that he will not be playing the tour on a full-time basis, and played the tournament as a favor to long-time friend Jim Courier.
595	At the 2009 French Open, Agassi was on hand to present Roger Federer, who completed his Career Grand Slam by winning the tournament and joined Agassi as one of six men to complete the Career Grand Slam, with the trophy.
595	Playing style Throughout his career Agassi was known for his powerful and precise groundstokes.
595	His phenomenal hand-eye coordination allowed Agassi to take the ball early and redirect it to any part of the court.
595	This relentless aggressive baseliner style put many opponents on the defence and earned Agassi the nickname "The Punisher".
595	While he lacked a dominant serve, Agassi had one of the best serve returns in the history of tennis, often hitting aggressive shots or even winners.
595	While he was growing up, his father and Nick Bollettieri trained him in this way.
595	Personal and family life Agassi was married to Brooke Shields from 1997 to 1999.
595	He married Steffi Graf on October 22, 2001; four days later, their son, Jaden Gil, was born.
595	Their daughter, Jaz Elle, was born in October 2003.
595	Long-time trainer Gil Reyes has been called one of Agassi's closest friends; some have described him as being a "father figure" to Agassi.
595	In 2012, Agassi and Reyes introduced their own line of fitness equipment, BILT By Agassi and Reyes.
595	In December 2008, Agassi's childhood friend and former business manager, Perry Rogers, sued Graf for $50,000 in management fees he claimed that she owed him.
595	Agassi's autobiography, Open (written with assistance from J.
595	R.
595	Moehringer), was published in November 2009.
595	In it, Agassi admitted that he used and tested positive for methamphetamine in 1997.
595	In response to this revelation, Roger Federer declared himself shocked and disappointed.
595	In an exclusive interview with CBS, Agassi justified himself and asked for understanding, saying that  "It was a period in my life where I needed help."
595	He also revealed that he had always hated tennis during his career because of the constant pressure it exerted on him.
595	He also revealed he thought Pete Sampras was "robotic".
595	The book reached No.
595	New York Times Best Seller list and received favorable reviews.
595	It won the Autobiography category of the 2010 British Sports Book Awards.
595	Politics Agassi has donated more than $100,000 to Democratic candidates.
595	However, on September 1, 2010, when he appeared on daily WNYC public radio program "The Brian Lehrer Show," he stated that he is a registered Independent.
595	Philanthropy Agassi founded the Andre Agassi Charitable Association in 1994, which assists Las Vegas' young people.
595	He was awarded the ATP Arthur Ashe Humanitarian award in 1995 for his efforts to help disadvantaged youth.
595	He is regularly cited as the most charitable and socially involved player in professional tennis.
595	It has also been claimed that he may be the most charitable athlete of his generation.
595	Agassi's charities help in assisting children reach their athletic potential.
595	His Boys & Girls Club sees 2,000 children throughout the year and boasts a world-class junior tennis team.
595	It also has a basketball program (the Agassi Stars) and a rigorous system that encourages a mix of academics and athletics.
595	In 2001, Agassi opened the Andre Agassi College Preparatory Academy in Las Vegas, a tuition-free charter school for at-risk children in the area.
595	In 2009, the graduating class had 100 percent graduation rate and expected a 100 percent college acceptance rate.
595	Among other child-related programs that Agassi supports through his Andre Agassi Charitable Foundation is Clark County's only residential facility for abused and neglected children, Child Haven.
595	In 1997, Agassi donated funding to Child Haven for a six-room classroom building now named the Agassi Center for Education.
595	His foundation also provided $720,000 to assist in the building of the Andre Agassi Cottage for Medically Fragile Children.
595	This 20-bed facility opened in December 2001, and accommodates developmentally delayed or handicapped children and children quarantined for infectious diseases.
595	In 2007 Agassi, Muhammad Ali, Lance Armstrong, Warrick Dunn, Jeff Gordon, Mia Hamm, Tony Hawk, Andrea Jaeger, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, Mario Lemieux, Alonzo Mourning and Cal Ripken, Jr.
595	Athletes for Hope, which helps professional athletes get involved in charitable causes and aims to inspire all people to volunteer and support their communities.
595	Recognition In 2010, Sports Illustrated named Agassi the 7th greatest male player of all time.
595	On July 9, 2011, Agassi was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame at a ceremony in Newport, Rhode Island.

595	Records in bold indicate peer-less achievements.

595	ATP Player of the Year: 1999.
