595	Wimbledon: The Record Breakers (2005) Starring: Andre Agassi, Boris Becker; Standing Room Only, DVD Release Date: August 16, 2005, Run Time: 52 minutes, .
595	Video games  * Andre Agassi Tennis for the SNES, Sega Genesis, Sega Game Gear, Master System, and Mobile phone * Agassi Tennis Generation for PS2 and GBA * Smash Court Pro Tournament for PS2 * Top Spin 4 (On cover of game) for Xbox 360, PlayStation 3 and Wii
597	The Austroasiatic (Austro-Asiatic) languages, in recent classifications synonymous with Mon–Khmer, are a large language family of continental Southeast Asia, also scattered throughout India, Bangladesh, and the southern border of China.
597	The name Austroasiatic comes from the Latin words for "south" and "Asia", hence "South Asia".
597	Among these languages, only Khmer, Vietnamese, and Mon have a long-established recorded history, and only Vietnamese and Khmer have official status (in Vietnam and Cambodia, respectively).
597	The rest of the languages are spoken by minority groups.
597	Ethnologue identifies 168 Austroasiatic languages.
597	These form thirteen established families (plus perhaps Shompen, which is poorly attested, as a fourteenth), which have traditionally been grouped into two, as Mon–Khmer and Munda.
597	However, recent classifications have abandoned Mon–Khmer as a taxon, either reducing it in scope or making it synonymous with the larger family (Diffloth 2005, Sidwell 2009).
597	Austroasiatic languages have a disjunct distribution across India, Bangladesh and Southeast Asia, separated by regions where other languages are spoken.
597	They appear to be the autochthonous languages of Southeast Asia, with the neighboring Indic, Tai, Dravidian, Austronesian, and Tibeto-Burman languages being the result of later migrations (Sidwell & Blench, 2011).
597	Morphology The Austroasiatic languages are well known for having a "sesquisyllabic" pattern, with basic nouns and verbs consisting of a reduced minor syllable plus a full syllable.
597	Many of them also have infixes.
597	Proto-language Much work has been done on the reconstruction of Proto-Mon–Khmer in Harry L.
597	Shorto's Mon–Khmer Comparative Dictionary.
597	Little work has been done on the Munda languages, which are not well documented; with their demotion from a primary branch, Proto-Mon–Khmer becomes synonymous with Proto-Austroasiatic.
597	Sidwell (2005) reconstructs the consonant inventory of Proto-Mon–Khmer as follows: This is identical to earlier reconstructions except for.
597	Katuic languages, which Sidwell has specialized in.
597	Sidwell (2011) suggests that the likely homeland of Austroasiatic is the middle Mekong, in the area of the Bahnaric and Katuic languages (approximately where modern Laos, Thailand, and Cambodia come together), and that the family is not as old as frequently assumed, dating to perhaps 4000 BCE.
597	Classification Linguists traditionally recognize two primary divisions of Austroasiatic: the Mon–Khmer languages of Southeast Asia, Northeast India and the Nicobar Islands, and the Munda languages of East and Central India and parts of Bangladesh.
597	However, no evidence for this classification has ever been published.
597	Each of the families that is written in boldface type below is accepted as a valid clade.
597	By contrast, the relationships between these families within Austroasiatic is debated.
597	In addition to the traditional classification, two recent proposals are given, neither of which accept traditional "Mon–Khmer" as a valid unit.
597	However, little of the data used for competing classifications has ever been published, and therefore cannot be evaluated by peer review.
597	In addition, there are suggestions that additional branches of Austroasiatic might be preserved in substrata of Acehnese in Sumatra (Diffloth), the Chamic languages of Vietnam, and the Land Dayak languages of Borneo (Adelaar 1995).
597	Sidwell (2009, 2011) Sidwell (2009a), in a lexicostatistical comparison of 36 languages which are well-known enough to exclude loan words, finds little evidence for internal branching, though he did find an area of increased contact between the Bahnaric and Katuic languages, such that languages of all branches apart from the geographically distant Munda and Nicobarese show greater similarity to Bahnaric and Katuic the closer they are to those branches, without any noticeable innovations common to Bahnaric and Katuic.
597	He therefore takes the conservative view that the thirteen branches of Austroasiatic should be treated as equidistant on current evidence.
597	Sidwell & Blench (2011) discuss this proposal in more detail, and note that there is good evidence for a Khasi–Palaungic node, which could also possibly be closely related to Khmuic.
597	If this would the case, Sidwell & Bl/SE%20Asia/SR09/Sidwell%20Blench%20offprint.pdf</rench suggest that Khasic may have been an early offshoot of Palaungic that had spread westward.
597	Sidwell & Blench (2011) suggest Shompen as an additional branch, and believe that a Vieto-Katuic connection is worth investigating.
597	In general, however, the family is thought to have diversified too quickly for a deeply nested structure to have developed, since Proto-Austroasiatic speakers were believed to have radiated out from the central Mekong River valley relatively quickly.
597	Gérard Diffloth (2005) Diffloth compares reconstructions of various clades, and attempts to classify them based on shared innovations, though like other classifications the evidence has not been published.
597	As a schematic, we have: Or in more detail, * Munda languages (India) * Koraput: 7 languages *Core Munda languages :* Kharian–Juang: 2 languages :*North Munda languages :: Korku :: Kherwarian: 12 languages * Khasi–Khmuic languages (Northern Mon–Khmer) * Khasian: 3 languages of eastern India and Bangladesh *Palaungo-Khmuic languages :* Khmuic: 13 languages of Laos and Thailand :*Palaungo-Pakanic languages :: Pakanic or Palyu: 4 or 5 languages of southern China and Vietnam :: Palaungic: 21 languages of Burma, southern China, and Thailand * Nuclear Mon–Khmer languages * Khmero-Vietic languages (Eastern Mon–Khmer) :* Vieto-Katuic languages ?
597	Vietic: 10 languages of Vietnam and Laos, including the Vietnamese language, which has the most speakers of any Austroasiatic language.
597	These are the only Austroasiatic languages to have highly developed tone systems.
597	Katuic: 19 languages of Laos, Vietnam, and Thailand.
597	Khmero-Bahnaric languages ::* Bahnaric: 40 languages of Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia.
597	Khmeric languages ::: The Khmer dialects of Cambodia, Thailand, and Vietnam.
597	Pearic: 6 languages of Cambodia.
597	Nico-Monic languages (Southern Mon–Khmer) :* Nicobarese: 6 languages of the Nicobar Islands, a territory of India.
597	Asli-Monic languages :: Aslian: 19 languages of peninsular Malaysia and Thailand.
597	Monic: 2 languages, the Mon language of Burma and the Nyahkur language of Thailand.
597	This family tree is consistent with recent studies of migration of Y-Chromosomal haplogroup O2a1-M95.
597	However, the dates obtained from DNA studies are several times older than that given by linguists.
597	The route map of the people with haplogroup O2a1-M95, speaking this language can be seen in this link.
597	Ilia Peiros (2004) Peiros is a lexicostatistic classification, based on percentages of shared vocabulary.
597	This means that a language may appear to be more distantly related than it actually is due to language contact.
597	Indeed, when Sidwell (2009a) replicated Peiros's study with languages known well enough to account for loans, he did not find the internal (branching) structure below.
597	Nicobarese *Munda–Khmer **Munda **Mon–Khmer ***Khasi ***Nuclear Mon–Khmer ****Mangic (Mang + Palyu) (perhaps in Northern MK) ****Vietic (perhaps in Northern MK) ****Northern Mon–Khmer *****Palaungic *****Khmuic ****Central Mon–Khmer *****Khmer dialects *****Pearic *****Asli-Bahnaric ******Aslian ******Mon–Bahnaric *******Monic *******Katu–Bahnaric ********Katuic ********Bahnaric Diffloth (1974) Diffloth's widely cited original classification, now abandoned by Diffloth himself, is used in Encyclopædia Britannica and—except for the breakup of Southern Mon–Khmer—in Ethnologue.
597	Munda **North Munda *** Korku ***Kherwarian **South Munda ***Kharia–Juang ***Koraput Munda *Mon–Khmer **Eastern Mon–Khmer ***Khmer (Cambodian) ***Pearic ***Bahnaric ***Katuic ***Vietic (includes Vietnamese) **Northern Mon–Khmer ***Khasi (Meghalaya, India) ***Palaungic ***Khmuic **Southern Mon–Khmer ***Mon ***Aslian (Malaya) ***Nicobarese (Nicobar Islands) Writing systems Other than Latin-based alphabets, many Austroasiatic languages are written with the ancient Khmer alphabet, Thai alphabet and Lao alphabet.
597	Chữ Nôm *Khmer alphabet *Ol Chiki alphabet (Santali alphabet) *Sorang Sompeng alphabet (Sora alphabet) *Varang Kshiti (Ho alphabet)
599	Afroasiatic (Afro-Asiatic), also known as Hamito-Semitic (Chamito-Semitic), is a large language family, including 300 or so living languages.
599	Afroasiatic languages are spoken predominantly in the Middle East, North Africa, the Horn of Africa, and parts of the Sahel.
599	More than 300 million people speak an Afroasiatic language.
599	The most widely spoken Afroasiatic language is Arabic (including literary Arabic and the spoken colloquial varieties), with about 200 to 230 million native speakers, spoken mostly in the Middle East and parts of North Africa.
599	Berber (including all its varieties) is spoken in Morocco, Algeria, Libya, Tunisia, northern Mali, and northern Niger by about 25 to 35 million people.
599	Other widely spoken Afroasiatic languages are Hausa, the dominant language of northern Nigeria and southern Niger, spoken as a first language by 25 million people and used as a lingua franca by another 20 million across the Sahel; Amharic and Oromo of Ethiopia, with 25 million speakers apiece; Somali, spoken by 15 million people in Greater Somalia; and Srew, spoken by about seven million people worldwide.
599	In addition to languages spoken today, Afroasiatic includes several important ancient languages, such as Ancient Egyptian, Akkadian and Biblical Hebrew.
599	Etymology The Afroasiatic language family was originally referred to as "Hamito-Semitic", a term introduced in the 1860s by the German scholar Karl Richard Lepsius.
599	The name was later popularized by Friedrich Müller in his Grundriss der Sprachwissenschaft (Wien 1876-88).
599	The term "Afroasiatic" (often now spelled as "Afro-Asiatic") was later coined by Maurice Delafosse (1914).
599	However, it did not come into general use until Joseph Greenberg (1963) formally proposed its adoption.
599	In doing so, Greenberg sought to emphasize the fact that Afroasiatic was the only language family that was represented transcontinentally, in both Africa and Asia.
599	Individual scholars have also called the family "Erythraean" (Tucker 1966) and "Lisramic" (Hodge 1972).
599	In lieu of "Hamito-Semitic", the Russian linguist Igor Diakonoff later suggested the term "Afrasian", meaning "half African, half Asiatic", in reference to the geographic distribution of the phylum's constituent languages.
599	The term "Hamito-Semitic" remains in use in the academic traditions of some European countries.
599	Distribution and branches The Afroasiatic language family is usually considered to include the following branches: * Berber * Chadic * Cushitic * Egyptian * Omotic * Semitic While there is general agreement on these six families, there are some points of disagreement among linguists who study Afroasiatic.
599	In particular: * The Omotic language branch is the most controversial member of Afroasiatic, since the grammatical formatives which most linguists have given greatest weight in classifying languages in the family "are either absent or distinctly wobbly" (Hayward 1995).
599	Greenberg (1963) and others considered it a subgroup of Cushitic, while others have raised doubts about it being part of Afroasiatic at all (e.g.
599	Theil 2006).
599	The Afroasiatic identity of Ongota is also broadly questioned, as is its position within Afroasiatic among those who accept it, due to the "mixed" appearance of the language and a paucity of research and data.
599	Harold Fleming (2006) proposes that Ongota constitutes a separate branch of Afroasiatic.
599	Bonny Sands (2009) believes the most convincing proposal is by Savà and Tosco (2003), namely that Ongota is an East Cushitic language with a Nilo-Saharan substratum.
599	In other words, the Ongota people would appear to have once spoken a Nilo-Saharan language but then shifted to speaking a Cushitic language, while retaining some characteristics of their earlier Nilo-Saharan language.
599	Beja is sometimes listed as a separate branch of Afroasiatic but is more often included in the Cushitic branch, which has a high degree of internal diversity.
599	Whether the various branches of Cushitic actually form a language family is sometimes questioned, but not their inclusion in Afroasiatic itself.
599	There is no consensus on the interrelationships of the five non-Omotic branches of Afroasiatic (see "Subgrouping" below).
599	This situation is not unusual, even among long-established language families: there are also many disagreements concerning the internal classification of the Indo-European languages, for instance.
599	Meroitic has been proposed as an unclassified Afroasiatic language, as it shares the phonotactics characteristic of the family, but there is not enough evidence to secure a classification.
599	Classification history In the 9th century, the Hebrew grammarian Judah ibn Quraysh of Tiaret in Algeria was the first to link two branches of Afroasiatic together; he perceived a relationship between Berber and Semitic.
599	He knew of Semitic through his study of Arabic, Hebrew, and Aramaic.
599	In the course of the 19th century, Europeans also began suggesting such relationships.
599	In 1844, Theodor Benfey suggested a language family consisting of Semitic, Berber, and Cushitic (calling the latter "Ethiopic").
599	In the same year, T.N.
599	Newman suggested a relationship between Semitic and Hausa, but this would long remain a topic of dispute and uncertainty.
599	Friedrich Müller named the traditional "Hamito-Semitic" family in 1876 in his Grundriss der Sprachwissenschaft.
599	He defined it as consisting of a Semitic group plus a "Hamitic" group containing Egyptian, Berber, and Cushitic; he excluded the Chadic group.
599	These classifications relied in part on non-linguistic anthropological and racial arguments that have largely been discredited (see Hamitic hypothesis).
599	Leo Reinisch (1909) proposed linking Cushitic and Chadic, while urging a more distant affinity to Egyptian and Semitic, thus foreshadowing Greenberg, but his suggestion found little resonance.
599	Marcel Cohen (1924) rejected the idea of a distinct Hamitic subgroup and included Hausa (a Chadic language) in his comparative Hamito-Semitic vocabulary.
599	Joseph Greenberg (1950) strongly confirmed Cohen's rejection of "Hamitic", added (and sub-classified) the Chadic branch, and proposed the new name "Afroasiatic" for the family.
599	Nearly all scholars have accepted Greenberg's classification.
599	In 1969, Harold Fleming proposed that what had previously been known as Western Cushitic is an independent branch of Afroasiatic, suggesting for it the new name Omotic.
599	This proposal and name have met with widespread acceptance.
599	Several scholars, including Harold Fleming and Robert Hetzron, have since questioned the traditional inclusion of Beja in Cushitic.
599	Subgrouping Little agreement exists on the subgrouping of the five or six branches of Afroasiatic: Semitic, Egyptian, Berber, Chadic, Cushitic, and Omotic.
599	However, Christopher Ehret (1979), Harold Fleming (1981), and Joseph Greenberg (1981) all agree that the Omotic branch split from the rest first.
599	Otherwise: * Paul Newman (1980) groups Berber with Chadic and Egyptian with Semitic, while questioning the inclusion of Omotic in Afroasiatic.
599	Rolf Theil (2006) concurs with the exclusion of Omotic, but does not otherwise address the structure of the family.
599	Harold Fleming (1981) divides non-Omotic Afroasiatic, or "Erythraean", into three groups, Cushitic, Semitic, and Chadic-Berber-Egyptian.
599	He later added Semitic and Beja to Chadic-Berber-Egyptian and tentatively proposed Ongota as a new third branch of Erythraean.
599	He thus divided Afroasiatic into two major branches, Omotic and Erythraean, with Erythraean consisting of three sub-branches, Cushitic, Chadic-Berber-Egyptian-Semitic-Beja, and Ongota.
599	Like Harold Fleming, Christopher Ehret (1995: 490) divides Afroasiatic into two branches, Omotic and Erythrean.
599	He divides Omotic into two branches, North Omotic and South Omotic.
599	He divides Erythrean into Cushitic, comprising Beja, Agaw, and East-South Cushitic, and North Erythrean, comprising Chadic and "Boreafrasian."
599	According to his classification, Boreafrasian consists of Egyptian, Berber, and Semitic.
599	Vladimir Orel and Olga Stolbova (1995) group Berber with Semitic and Chadic with Egyptian.
599	They split up Cushitic into five or more independent branches of Afroasiatic, viewing Cushitic as a Sprachbund rather than a language family.
599	Igor M.
599	Diakonoff (1996) subdivides Afroasiatic in two, grouping Berber, Cushitic, and Semitic together as East-West Afrasian (ESA), and Chadic with Egyptian as North-South Afrasian (NSA).
599	He excludes Omotic from Afroasiatic.
599	Lionel Bender (1997) groups Berber, Cushitic, and Semitic together as "Macro-Cushitic".
599	He regards Chadic and Omotic as the branches of Afroasiatic most remote from the others.
599	Alexander Militarev (2000), on the basis of lexicostatistics, groups Berber with Chadic and both more distantly with Semitic, as against Cushitic and Omotic.
599	He places Ongota in South Omotic.
599	Position among the world's languages Afroasiatic is one of the four language families of Africa identified by Joseph Greenberg in his book The Languages of Africa (1963).
599	It is the only one that extends outside of Africa, via the Semitic branch.
599	There are no generally accepted relations between Afroasiatic and any other language family.
599	However, several proposals grouping Afroasiatic with one or more other language families have been made.
599	The best-known of these are the following: * Hermann Möller (1906) argued for a relation between Semitic and the Indo-European languages.
599	This proposal was accepted by some linguists (e.g.
599	Holger Pedersen and Louis Hjelmslev) but has little currency today.
599	For a fuller account, see Indo-Semitic languages.) * Apparently influenced by Möller (a colleague of his at the University of Copenhagen), Holger Pedersen included Hamito-Semitic (the term replaced by Afroasiatic) in his proposed Nostratic macro-family (cf.
599	Pedersen 1931:336–338), which also included the Indo-European, Finno-Ugric, Samoyed, Turkish, Mongolian, Manchu, and Yukaghir languages.
599	This inclusion was retained by subsequent Nostraticists, starting with Vladislav Illich-Svitych and Aharon Dolgopolsky.
599	Joseph Greenberg (2000–2002) did not reject a relationship of Afroasiatic to these other languages, but he considered it more distantly related to them than they were to each other, grouping instead these other languages in a separate macro-family, which he called Eurasiatic, and to which he added Chukotian, Gilyak, Korean, Japanese-Ryukyuan, Eskimo–Aleut, and Ainu.
599	Most recently, Sergei Starostin's school has accepted Eurasiatic as a subgroup of Nostratic, with Afroasiatic, Dravidian, and Kartvelian in Nostratic outside of Eurasiatic.
599	An even larger Borean group would contain Nostratic as well as Dené-Caucasian and Austric.
599	Date of Afroasiatic The earliest written evidence of an Afroasiatic language is an Ancient Egyptian inscription of c.
599	BC (5,400 years ago).
599	Symbols on Gerzean pottery resembling Egyptian hieroglyphs date back to c.
599	BC, suggesting a still earlier possible date.
599	This gives us a minimum date for the age of Afroasiatic.
599	However, Ancient Egyptian is highly divergent from Proto-Afroasiatic (Trombetti 1905: 1–2), and considerable time must have elapsed in between them.
599	Estimates of the date at which the Proto-Afroasiatic language was spoken vary widely.
599	They fall within a range between approximately 7500 BC (9,500 years ago) and approximately 16,000 BC (18,000 years ago).
599	According to Igor M.
599	Diakonoff (1988: 33n), Proto-Afroasiatic was spoken c.
599	BC.
599	According to Christopher Ehret (2002: 35–36), Proto-Afroasiatic was spoken c.
599	BC at the latest and possibly as early as c.
599	BC.
599	These dates are older than dates associated with most other proto-languages.
599	Afroasiatic Urheimat The term Afroasiatic Urheimat (Urheimat meaning "original homeland" in German) refers to the 'hypothetical' place where Proto-Afroasiatic speakers lived in a single linguistic community, or complex of communities, before this original language dispersed geographically and divided into distinct languages.
599	Afroasiatic languages are today primarily spoken in the Middle East, North Africa, the Horn of Africa, and parts of the Sahel.
599	There is no agreement on when and where this Urheimat existed, though the language is generally believed to have originated somewhere in or near the region stretching from the Levant/Near East to the area between the Eastern Sahara and the Horn of Africa, including Egypt, Ethiopia and Sudan.
599	Similarities in grammar and syntax Widespread (though not universal) features of the Afroasiatic languages include: * A set of emphatic consonants, variously realized as glottalized, pharyngealized, or implosive.
599	VSO typology with SVO tendencies.
599	A two-gender system in the singular, with the feminine marked by the sound /t/.
599	All Afroasiatic subfamilies show evidence of a causative affix s.
599	Semitic, Berber, Cushitic (including Beja), and Chadic support possessive suffixes.
599	Morphology in which words inflect by changes within the root (vowel changes or gemination) as well as with prefixes and suffixes.
599	One of the most remarkable shared features among the Afroasiatic languages is the prefixing verb conjugation (see table above), with a distinctive pattern of prefixes beginning with /ʔ t n y/, and in particular a pattern whereby third-singular masculine /y-/ is opposed to third-singular feminine and second-singular /t-/.
599	Tonal languages appear in the Omotic, Chadic, and Cushitic branches of Afroasiatic, according to Ehret (1996).
599	The Semitic, Berber, and Egyptian branches do not use tones phonemically.
599	Shared vocabulary Following are some examples of Afroasiatic cognates, including ten pronouns, three nouns, and three verbs.
599	Source: Christopher Ehret, Reconstructing Proto-Afroasiatic (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1995).
599	Note: Ehret does not make use of Berber in his etymologies, stating (1995: 12): "the kind of extensive reconstruction of proto-Berber lexicon that might help in sorting through alternative possible etymologies is not yet available."
599	The Berber cognates here are taken from previous version of table in this article and need to be completed and referenced.
599	Abbreviations: NOm 'North Omotic', SOm   'South Omotic'.
599	MSA 'Modern South Arabian', PSC   'Proto-Southern Cushitic', PSom-II 'Proto-Somali, stage 2'.
599	Symbols: Following Ehret (1995: 70), a caron ˇ over a vowel indicates rising tone, a circumflex ^ over a vowel indicates falling tone.
599	V indicates a vowel of unknown timbre.
599	There are two etymological dictionaries of Afroasiatic, one by Christopher Ehret, and one by Vladimir Orel and Olga Stolbova.
599	The two dictionaries disagree on almost everything.
599	The following table contains the thirty roots or so (out of thousands) that represent a fragile consensus of present research.
599	Father Semitic, Berber, Chadic, Cushitic 2 (ʔa-)bVr Bull Semitic, Egyptian, Chadic, Cushitic 3 (ʔa-)dVm Red ; blood Semitic, Berber, Chadic, Cushitic 4 *(ʔa-)dVm Land, field, soil Semitic, Chadic.

599	Semitic, Chadic, Cushitic) is a very old loanword and does not belong here, as the horse was introduced in the region in the late fifth- early fourth millenary BP, after the split of Afroasiatic and even Semitic.
599	Etymological bibliography Some of the main sources for Afroasiatic etymologies include: * Cohen, Marcel.

600	Andorra (;,), officially the Principality of Andorra (), also called the Principality of the Valleys of Andorra, (), is a landlocked microstate in Southwestern Europe, located in the eastern Pyrenees mountains and bordered by Spain and France.
600	It is the sixth smallest nation in Europe, having an area of 468 km² and an estimated population of 85,000 in 2012.
600	Its capital, Andorra la Vella, is the highest capital city in Europe, at an elevation of 1023 m above sea level.
600	The official language is Catalan, although Spanish, Portuguese, and French are also commonly spoken.
600	Created under a charter in 988, the present Principality was formed in 1278.
600	It is known as a principality as it is a monarchy headed by two co-princes – the Bishop of Urgell and the President of France.
600	Andorra is a prosperous country mainly because of its tourism industry, which services an estimated 10.2 million visitors annually, and also because of its status as a tax haven.
600	It is not a member of the European Union, but the euro is the de facto currency.
600	The people of Andorra have the 4th highest human life expectancy in the world — 82 years at birth.
600	History Tradition holds that Charles the Great (Charlemagne) granted a charter to the Andorran people in return for fighting against the Moors.
600	Overlordship of the territory was by the Count of Urgell and eventually by the bishop of the Diocese of Urgell.
600	In 988, Borrell II, Count of Urgell, gave the Andorran valleys to the Diocese of Urgell in exchange for land in Cerdanya.
600	Since then the Bishop of Urgell, based in Seu d'Urgell, has owned Andorra.
600	Before 1095, Andorra did not have any type of military protection and the Bishop of Urgell, who knew that the Count of Urgell wanted to reclaim the Andorran valleys, asked for help and protection from the Lord of Caboet.
600	In 1095, the Lord of Caboet and the Bishop of Urgell signed under oath a declaration of their co-sovereignty over Andorra.
600	Arnalda, daughter of Arnau of Caboet, married the Viscount of Castellbò and both became Viscounts of Castellbò and Cerdanya.
600	Years later their daughter, Ermessenda, married Roger Bernat II, the French Count of Foix.
600	They became Roger Bernat II and Ermessenda I, Counts of Foix, Viscounts of Castellbò and Cerdanya, and also co-sovereigns of Andorra (shared with the Bishop of Urgell).
600	In the 11th century, a dispute arose between the Bishop of Urgell and the Count of Foix.
600	The conflict was resolved in 1278 with the mediation of Aragon by the signing of the first paréage which provided that Andorra's sovereignty be shared between the count of Foix (whose title would ultimately transfer to the French head of state) and the Bishop of Urgell, in Catalonia.
600	This gave the principality its territory and political form.
600	Over the years, the co-title to Andorra passed to the kings of Navtical form.
600	Over the years, the co-tiarre.
600	After Henry of Navarre became King Henry IV of France, he issued an edict in 1607 that established the head of the French state and the Bishop of Urgell as co-princes of Andorra.
600	In 1812–13, the First French Empire annexed Catalonia and divided it in four départements, with Andorra being made part of the district of Puigcerdà (département of Sègre).
600	Andorra declared war on Imperial Germany during World War I, but did not actually take part in the fighting.
600	It remained in an official state of belligerency until 1958 as it was not included in the Treaty of Versailles.
600	In 1933, France occupied Andorra as a result of social unrest before elections.
600	On July 12, 1934, adventurer Boris Skossyreff issued a proclamation in Urgell, declaring himself "Boris I, King of Andorra", simultaneously declaring war on the Bishop of Urgell.
600	He was arrested by Spanish authorities on July 20 and ultimately expelled from Spain.
600	From 1936 to 1940, a French detachment was garrisoned in Andorra to prevent influences of the Spanish Civil War and Francoist Spain.
600	Francoist troops reached the Andorran border in the later stages of the war.
600	During World War II, Andorra remained neutral and was an important smuggling route between Vichy France and Spain.
600	Given its relative isolation, Andorra has existed outside the mainstream of European history, with few ties to countries other than France and Spain.
600	In recent times, however, its thriving tourist industry along with developments in transport and communications have removed the country from its isolation.
600	Its political system was modernised in 1993, when it became a member of the United Nations and the Council of Europe.
600	Politics Andorra is a parliamentary co-principality with the President of France and the Bishop of Urgell (Catalonia, Spain), as co-princes.
600	This peculiarity makes the President of France, in his capacity as Prince of Andorra, an elected reigning monarch, even though he is not elected by a popular vote of the Andorran people.
600	The politics of Andorra take place in a framework of a parliamentary representative democracy, whereby the Prime Minister of Andorra is the head of government, and of a pluriform multi-party system.
600	The current Prime Minister is Antoni Martí of the Democrats for Andorra (DA).
600	Executive power is exercised by the government.
600	Legislative power is vested in both  government and parliament.
600	The Parliament of Andorra is known as the General Council.
600	The General Council consists of between 28 and 42 Councillors, as the members of the legislative branch are called.
600	The Councillors serve for four-year terms and elections are held between the thirtieth and fortieth days following the dissolution of the previous Council.
600	The Councillors can be elected on two equal constituencies.
600	Half are elected in equal number from each of the seven administrative parishes and the other half of the Councillors are elected from a single national constituency.
600	Councillors hold their inauguration.
600	During this session, the Syndic General, who is the head of the General Council, and the Subsyndic General, his assistant, are elected.
600	Eight days later, the Council convenes once more.
600	During this session the Head of Government, the Prime Minister of Andorra, is chosen from among the Councillors.
600	Candidates for the prime-ministerial nomination can be proposed by a minimum of one-fifth of the Councillors.
600	The Council then elects the candidate with the absolute majority of votes to be Head of Government.
600	The Syndic General then notifies the Co-princes who in turn appoint the elected candidate as the Prime Minister of Andorra.
600	The General Council is also responsible for proposing and passing laws.
600	Bills may be presented to the Council as Private Members' Bills by three of the Local Parish Councils jointly or by at least one tenth of the citizens of Andorra.
600	The Council also approves the annual budget of the principality.
600	The government must submit the proposed budget for parliamentary approval at least two months before the previous budget expires.
600	If the budget is not approved by the first day of the next year, the previous budget is extended until a new one is approved.
600	Once any bill is approved, the Syndic General is responsible for presenting it to the Co-princes so that they may sign and enact it.
600	If the Head of Government is not satisfied with the Council, he may request that the Co-princes dissolve the Council and order new elections.
600	In turn, the Councillors have the power to remove the Head of Government from office.
600	After a motion of censure is approved by at least one-fifth of the Councillors, the Council will vote and if it receives the absolute majority of votes, the Prime Minister is removed.
600	Law and criminal justice The judiciary is composed of the Magistrates Court, the Criminal Law Court, the High Court of Andorra, and the Constitutional Court.
600	The High Court of Justice is composed of five judges: one appointed by the Head of Government, one each by the Coprinces, one by the Syndic General, and one by the Judges and Magistrates.
600	It is presided over by the member appointed by the Syndic General and the judges hold office for six-year terms.
600	The Magistrates and Judges are appointed by the High Court, and so is the President of the Criminal Law Court.
600	The High Court also appoints members of the Office of the Attorney General.
600	The Constitutional Court is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and reviewing all appeals of unconstitutionality against laws and treaties.
600	It is composed of four judges, one appointed by each of the Coprinces and two by the General Council.
600	They serve eight-year terms.
600	The Court is presided over by one of the Judges on a two-year rotation so that each judge at one point will be the leader of the Court.
600	Foreign relations, defence, and security Andorra does not have its own armed forces, although there is a small ceremonial Army.
600	Responsibility for defending the nation rests primarily with France and Spain.
600	However, in case of emergencies or natural disasters, the Sometent (an alarm) is called and all able-bodied men between 21 and 60 of Andorran nationality must serve.
600	This is why all Andorrans, and especially the head of each house (usually the eldest able-bodied man of a house), should by law, keep a rifle, even though the law also states that the police will offer a fire-arm in case of need.keep a rifle, even  Andorra is a full member of the United Nations (UN), the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), and has a special agreement with the European Union (EU).
600	Military Andorra has a small army, which has historically been raised or reconstituted at various dates, but has never in modern times amounted to a standing army.
600	The basic principle of Andorran defence is that all able-bodied men are available to fight if called upon by the sounding of the Sometent.
600	The duties of the Andorran Army are entirely ceremonial.
600	In the modern era, the army has consisted of a very small body of volunteers willing to undertake ceremonial duties.
600	Uniforms were handed down from generation to generation within families and communities.
600	Despite not being involved in any fighting, Andorra was technically the longest combatant in the First World War, as the country was left out of the Versailles Peace Conference, and technically remained at war with Germany from 1914 until 1939.
600	The army's role in internal security was largely taken over by the formation of the Police Corps of Andorra in 1931.
600	Brief civil disorder associated with the elections of 1933, led to assistance being sought from the French police, with a detachment resident in Andorra for two months under the command of René-Jules Baulard.
600	The Andorran Army was reformed in the following year, with eleven soldiers appointed to supervisory roles.
600	The force consisted of six Corporals, one for each parish (although there are currently seven parishes, there were only six until 1978), plus four junior staff officers to coordinate action, and a commander with the rank of Major.
600	It was the responsibility of the six corporals, each in his own parish, to be able to raise a fighting force from among the able-bodied men of the parish.
600	Today a small, 12-man ceremonial unit remains the only permanent section of the Andorran army, but all able-bodied men remain technically available for military service, with a requirement for each family to have access to a firearm.
600	The army has not fought for more than 700 years, and its main responsibility is to present the Andorran flag at official ceremonial functions.
600	According to Marc Forné Molné, Andorra's military budget is strictly from voluntary donations, and the availability of full-time voluntaries.
600	The myth that all members of the Andorran Army are ranked as officers, is popularly maintained in many works of reference.
600	In reality, all those serving in the permanent ceremonial reserve hold ranks as officers, or non-commissioned officers, because the other ranks are considered to be the rest of the able-bodied male population, who may still be called upon by the Sometent to serve, although such a call has not been made in modern times.
600	GIPA The Grup d'Intervenció Policia d'Andorra (GIPA) is a small special forces unit trained in counter-terrorism, and hostage recovery tasks.
600	Although it is the closest in style to an active military force, it is part of the Police Corps, and not the Army.
600	As terrorist and hostage situations are a rare threat to the nation, the GIPA is commonly assigned to prisoner escort duties, and at other times to routine policing.
600	Police Corps Andorra maintains a small, but modern and well-equipped internal police force with around 240 police officers, supported by civilian assistants.
600	The principal services supplied by the Corps are uniformed community policing, criminal detection, border control, and traffic policing.
600	There are also small specialist units including police dogs, mountain rescue, and bomb disposal.
600	Fire Brigade The Andorran Fire Brigade, with headquarters at Santa Coloma, operates from four modern fire stations, and has a staff of around 120 firefighters.
600	The service is equipped with 16 heavy appliances (fire tenders, turntable ladders, and specialist four-wheel drive vehicles), 4 light support vehicles (cars and vans), and 4 ambulances.
600	Historically, the families of the six ancient parishes of Andorra maintained local arrangements to assist each other in fighting fires.
600	The first fire pump purchased by the government was acquired in 1943.
600	The serious fires (which lasted for two days) in parts of the principality in December 1959 led to calls for a permanent fire service, and the Andorran Fire Brigade was formed on 21 April 1961.
600	The fire service maintains full-time cover with five fire crews on duty at any time - two at the brigade's headquarters in Santa Coloma, and one crew at each of the other three fire stations.
600	Geography Parishes Andorra consists of seven parishes: * Andorra la Vella * Canillo * Encamp * Escaldes-Engordany * La Massana * Ordino * Sant Julià de Lòria Physical geography Due to its location in the eastern Pyrenees mountain range, Andorra consists predominantly of rugged mountains, the highest being the Coma Pedrosa at 2942 m, and the average elevatiountains, the hn of Andorra is 1996 m.
600	These are dissected by three narrow valleys in a Y shape that combine into one as the main stream, the Gran Valira river, leaves the country for Spain (at Andorra's lowest point of 840 m).
600	Andorra's land area is 468 km2.
600	Phytogeographically, Andorra belongs to the Atlantic European province of the Circumboreal Region within the Boreal Kingdom.
600	According to the WWF, the territory of Andorra belongs to the ecoregion of Pyrenees conifer and mixed forests.
600	Climate Andorra has an alpine climate and continental climate.
600	Its higher elevation means there is, on average, more snow in winter, lower humidity, and it is slightly cooler in summer.
600	There are, on average, 300 days per year of sunshine.
600	Economy Tourism, the mainstay of Andorra's tiny, well-to-do economy, accounts for roughly 80% of GDP.
600	An estimated 10.2 million tourists visit annually, attracted by Andorra's duty-free status and by its summer and winter resorts.
600	Andorra's relative advantage has recently eroded as the economies of adjoining France and Spain have been opened up, providing broader availability of goods and lower tariffs.
600	The banking sector, with its tax haven status, also contributes substantially to the economy.
600	Agricultural production is limited—only 2% of the land is arable—and most food has to be imported.
600	Some tobacco is grown locally.
600	The principal livestock activity is domestic sheep raising.
600	Manufacturing output consists mainly of cigarettes, cigars, and furniture.
600	Andorra's natural resources include hydroelectric power, mineral water, timber, iron ore, and lead.
600	Andorra is not a member of the European Union, but enjoys a special relationship with it, such as being treated as an EU member for trade in manufactured goods (no tariffs) and as a non-EU member for agricultural products.
600	Andorra lacked a currency of its own and used both the French franc and the Spanish peseta in banking transactions until 31 December 1999, when both currencies were replaced by the EU's single currency, the euro.
600	Coins and notes of both the franc and the peseta remained legal tender in Andorra until 31 December 2002.
600	Andorra is negotiating to issue its own euro coins.
600	Andorra has one of the world's lowest unemployment rates at 2.9% reported for 2009.
600	Demography Population The population of Andorra is estimated to be 85,082 (July 2011).
600	The population has grown from 5,000 in 1900.
600	Andorran nationals are a plurality in the country (31,363 / 33%); other nationalities include Spaniards (27,300 / 23%), Portuguese (13,794 / 21%), French (5,213 / 17%), Britons (1,085) and Italians.
600	The main part of the population in Andorra is made up of citizens without Andorran nationality, who do not have the right to vote (suffrage) in communal elections.
600	Moreover, they are not allowed to be elected as president or to own more than 33% of the capital stock of a privately held company.
600	Languages The historic and official language is Catalan, a Romance language.
600	The Andorran government is keen to encourage the use of Catalan.
600	It funds a Commission for Catalan Toponymy in Andorra (Catalan: la Comissió de Toponímia d'Andorra), and provides free Catalan classes to assist immigrants.
600	Andorran television and radio stations use Catalan.
600	Because of immigration, historical links, and close geographic proximity, Spanish, Portuguese and French are also commonly spoken.
600	Most Andorran residents can speak one or more of these, in addition to Catalan.
600	English is less commonly spoken among the general population, though it is understood to varying degrees in the major tourist resorts.
600	Andorra is one of only three European countries (together with France and Monaco) that have never signed the Council of Europe Framework Convention on National Minorities.
600	According to the Observatori Social d'Andorra, the linguistic usage in Andorra are as follows: Religion The population of Andorra is predominantly (90%) Catholicirrans]sm|Roman Catholic.
600	Their patron saint is Our Lady of Meritxell.
600	Though it is not an official state religion, the constitution acknowledges a special relationship with the Catholic Church, offering some special privileges to that group.
600	The Muslim community is primarily made up of North African immigrants.
600	Other Christian denominations include the Anglican Church, the Reunification Church, the New Apostolic Church, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, and Jehovah's Witnesses.
600	There is a small community of Hindus and Bahá'ís.
600	Roughly 100 Jews live in Andorra.
600	History of the Jews in Andorra).
600	Statistics Largest cities Education Schools Children between the ages of 6 and 16 are required by law to have full-time education.
600	Education up to secondary level is provided free of charge by the government.
600	There are three systems of schools – Andorran, French and Spanish – which use Catalan, French and Spanish, respectively, as the main language of instruction.
600	Parents may choose which system their children attend.
600	All schools are built and maintained by Andorran authorities, but teachers in the French and Spanish schools are paid for the most part by France and Spain.
600	About 50% of Andorran children attend the French primary schools, and the rest attend Spanish or Andorran schools.
600	University of Andorra The Universitat d'Andorra (UdA) is the state public university and is the only university in Andorra.
600	It was established in 1997.
600	The University provides first-level degrees in nursing, computer science, business administration, and educational sciences, in addition to higher professional education courses.
600	The only two graduate schools in Andorra are the Nursing School and the School of Computer Science, the latter having a PhD programme.
600	Virtual Studies Centre The geographical complexity of the country as well as the small number of students prevents the University of Andorra from developing a full academic program, and it serves principally as a centre for virtual studies, connected to Spanish and French universities.
600	The Virtual Studies Centre (Centre d’Estudis Virtuals) at the University runs in the region of twenty degrees at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels in fields including tourism, law, Catalan philology, humanities, psychology, political sciences, audiovisual communication, telecommunications engineering, and East Asia studies.
600	The Centre also runs various postgraduate programs and continuing-education courses for professionals.
600	Healthcare Healthcare in Andorra is provided to all employed persons and their families by the government-run social security system, CASS (Caixa Andorrana de Seguretat Social), which is funded by employer and employee contributions in respect of salaries.
600	The cost of healthcare is covered by CASS at rates of 75% for out-patient expenses such as medicines and hospital visits, 90% for hospitalisation, and 100% for work-related accidents.
600	The remainder of the costs may be covered by private health insurance.
600	Other residents and tourists require full private health insurance.
600	The main hospital, Meritxell, is in Escaldes-Engordany.
600	There are also 12 primary health care centres in various locations around the Principality.
600	Transport Until the 20th century, Andorra had very limited transport links to the outside world, and development of the country was affected by its physical isolation.
600	Even now, the nearest major airports at Toulouse and Barcelona are both three hours' drive from Andorra.
600	Andorra has a road network of 279 km, of which 76 km is unpaved.
600	The two main roads out of Andorra la Vella are the CG-1 to the Spanish border, and the CG-2 to the French border via the Envalira Tunnel near El Pas de la Casa.
600	Bus services cover all metropolitan areas and many rural communities, with services on most major routes running half-hourly or more frequently during peak travel times.
600	There are frequent long-distance bus services from Andorra to Barcelona and Toulouse.
600	Bus services are mostly run by private companies, but some local ones are operated by the government.
600	There are no railways, ports, or airports for fixed-wing aircraft in Andorra.
600	There are, however, heliports in La Massana, Arinsal and Escaldes-Engordany with commercial helicopter services.
600	Nearby airports are located in Barcelona, Toulouse, Perpignan, Reus, and Girona.
600	The closest public airport is Perpignan - Rivesaltes Airport, which is 160 km away and has short-haul services to several destinations in the United Kingdom and France.
600	La Seu d'Urgell Airport, a small airfield 12 km south of Andorra currently used only by private aeroplanes, is being studied by the government as a possible future airport for public aviation services.
600	The nearest railway station is L'Hospitalet-près-l'Andorre 10 km east of Andorra which is on the
612	In mathematics and >       /* Definistatistics, the arithmetic mean, or simply the mean or average when the context is clear, is the central tendency of a collection of numbers taken as the sum of the numbers divided by the size of the collection.
612	The collection is often the sample space of an experiment.
612	The term "arithmetic mean" is preferred in mathematics and statistics because it helps distinguish it from other means such as the geometric and harmonic mean.
612	In addition to mathematics and statistics, the arithmetic mean is used frequently in fields such as economics, sociology, and history, though it is used in almost every academic field to some extent.
612	For example, per capita GDP gives an approximation of the arithmetic average income of a nation's population.
612	While the arithmetic mean is often used to report central tendencies, it is not a robust statistic, meaning that it is greatly influenced by outliers.
612	Notably, for skewed distributions, the arithmetic mean may not accord with one's notion of "middle", and robust statistics such as the median may be a better description of central tendency.
612	Definition Suppose we have sample space .
612	Then the arithmetic mean  is defined via the expression .
612	If the list is a statistical population, then the mean of that population is called a population mean.
612	If the list is a statistical sample, we call the resulting statistic a sample mean.
612	The arithmetic mean of a variable is often denoted by a bar, for example  (read "x bar") would be the mean of some sample space .
612	Motivating properties The arithmetic mean has several properties that make it useful, especially as a measure of central tendency.
612	These include: *If numbers  have mean X, then .
612	Since  is the distance from a given number to the mean, one way to interpret this property is as saying that the numbers to the left of the mean are balanced by the numbers to the right of the mean.
612	The mean is the only single number for which the residuals defined this way sum to zero.
612	If it is required to use a single number X as an estimate for the value of numbers , then the arithmetic mean does this best, in the sense of minimizing the sum of squares (xi − X)2 of the residuals.
612	It follows that the mean is also the best single predictor in the sense of having the lowest root mean squared error.) *For a normal distribution, the arithmetic mean is equal to both the median and the mode, other measures of central tendency.
612	Problems The arithmetic mean may be misinterpreted as the median to imply that most values are higher or lower than is actually the case.
612	If elements in the sample space increase arithmetically, when placed in some order, then the median and arithmetic average are equal.
612	For example, consider the sample space {1,2,3,4}.
612	The average is 2.5, as is the median.
612	However, when we consider a sample space that cannot be arranged into an arithmetic progression, such as {1,2,4,8,16}, the median and arithmetic average can differ significantly.
612	In this case the arithmetic average is 6.2 and the median is 4.
612	When one looks at the arithmetic average of a sample space, one must note that the average value can vary significantly from most values in the sample space.
612	There are applications of this phenomenon in many fields.
612	For example, since the 1980s in the United States median income has increased more slowly than the arithmetic average of income.
612	Researchers dealing with frequency data must also be careful when reporting summary statistics such as means or median.
612	Angles Particular care must be taken when using cyclic data such as phases or angles.
612	Naïvely taking the arithmetic mean of 1° and 359° yields a result of 180°.
612	This is incorrect for two reasons: *Firstly, angle measurements are only defined up to a factor of 360° (or 2π, if measuring in radians).
612	Thus one could as easily call these 1° and −1°, or 1° and 179° – each of which gives a different average.
612	Secondly, in this situation, 0° (equivalently, 360°) is geometrically a better average value: there is lower dispersion about it (the points are both 1° from it, and 179° from 180°, the putative average).
612	In general application such an oversight will lead to the average value artificially moving towards the middle of the numerical range.
612	A solution to this problem is to use the optimization formulation (viz, define the mean as the central point: the point about which one has the lowest dispersion), and redefine the difference as a modular distance (i.e., the distance on the circle: so the modular distance between 1° and 359° is 2°, not 358°).
615	The American Football Conference (AFC) is one of the two conferences of the National Football League (NFL).
615	This conference and its counterpart, the National Football Conference (NFC), currently contain 16 teams each, making up the 32 teams of the NFL.
615	The American Football Conference originated as the American Football League (AFL), with which the NFL combined in the AFL–NFL merger of 1970.
615	Ten AFC teams originally formed the AFL, while three others were NFL teams that were added to the AFC to equalize the number of franchises, and another three are more recent expansion teams (one, the Houston Texans, plays in the market from which one of the AFL's founding teams, now known as the Tennessee Titans, originated).
615	Current teams Since 2002, the AFC has 16 teams, organized into four divisions each with four teams: East, North, South, and West.
615	Season structure Each AFC team plays the other teams in its division twice (home and away) during the regular season, in addition to 10 other games assigned to their schedule by the NFL the previous May.
615	Two of these games are assigned on the basis of the team's final division standing in the previous season.
615	The remaining 8 games are split between the roster of two other NFL divisions.
615	This assignment shifts each year.
615	For instance, in the 2007 regular season, each team in the AFC West played one game against each team in both the AFC South and the NFC North.
615	In this way division competition consists of common opponents, with the exception of the 2 games assigned on the strength of each team's prior division standing.
615	AFC divisions that they are not scheduled to play) The NFC operates according to the same system.
615	At the end of each football season, there are playoff games involving the top six teams in the AFC (the four division champions by place standing and the top two remaining non-division-champion teams ("wild cards") by record).
615	The last two teams remaining play in the AFC Championship game with the winner receiving the Lamar Hunt Trophy.
615	The AFC champion plays the NFC champion in the Super Bowl.
615	After Super Bowl XLVI the AFC has won 19 Super Bowls to the 24 won by the NFC.
615	Since losing 13 consecutive Super Bowls in the 1980s and 1990s (XIX–XXXI), the AFC has won 9 of the last 15.
615	The coach of the team with the best record that lost in the AFC Divisional round is the coach of the Pro Bowl.
615	History The AFC was created after the NFL merged with the American Football League (AFL) in 1970.
615	All of the 10 former AFL teams along with the NFL's Cleveland Browns, Pittsburgh Steelers, and the then-Baltimore Colts joined the AFC.
615	The two AFL divisions  AFL East and AFL West were more or less intact.
615	Since the merger, five expansion teams have joined the AFC and two have left, thus making the current total 16.
615	When the Seattle Seahawks and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers joined the league in 1976, they were temporarily placed in the NFC and AFC respectively.
615	This arrangement lasted for one season only before the two teams switched conferences.
615	The Seahawks eventually returned to the NFC as a result of the 2002 realignment.
615	The expansion Jacksonville Jaguars joined the AFC in 1995.
615	Due to the relocation controversy of the Cleveland Browns, a new AFC franchise called the Baltimore Ravens was officially established in 1996 while the Browns were reactivated in 1999.
615	The Houston Texans were then added to the league in 2002, joining the AFC.
615	Between 2003 and 2012, the AFC had sent either the Indianapolis Colts, the New England Patriots, or the Pittsburgh Steelers to the Super Bowl, with two exceptions.
615	In the 2002 NFL season, the Oakland Raiders lost to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Super Bowl XXXVII, and in the 2012 NFL season, the Baltimore Ravens prevailed over New England in the conference championship to reach Super Bowl XLVII.
615	By contrast, the NFC sent a different team each year save for the 2011 NFL season, when the New York Giants made it to their second Super Bowl in that same time span, Super Bowl XLVI.
615	Logo The merged league created a new logo for the AFC that took elements of the old AFL logo, specifically the "A" and the six stars surrounding it.
615	The AFC logo basically remained unchanged from 1970 to 2009.
615	The 2010 NFL season introduced an updated AFC logo, with the most notable revision being the removal of two sNFL seasontars (leaving four representing the four divisions of the AFC), and moving the stars inside the letter, similar to the NFC logo.
615	Notes
617	Al Gore
620	Animal Farm is an allegorical novel by George Orwell, published in England on 17 August 1945.
620	According to Orwell, the book reflects events leading up to the Russian Revolution of 1917 and then on into the Stalin era in the Soviet Union.
620	Orwell, a democratic socialist, was a critic of Joseph Stalin and hostile to Moscow-directed Stalinism, especially after his experiences with the NKVD and the Spanish Civil War.
620	The Soviet Union, he believed, had become a brutal dictatorship, built upon a cult of personality and enforced by a reign of terror.
620	In a letter to Yvonne Davet, Orwell described Animal Farm as his novel "contre Stalin" and in his essay "Why I Write" (1946) he wrote that Animal Farm was the first book in which he had tried, with full consciousness of what he was doing, "to fuse political purpose and artistic purpose into one whole".
620	The original title was Animal Farm: A Fairy Story, though the subtitle was dropped by U.S.
620	Orwell's lifetime omitted it.
620	Other variations in the title include: A Satire and A Contemporary Satire.
620	Orwell suggested the title Union des républiques socialistes animales for the French translation, which recalled the French name of the Soviet Union, Union des républiques socialistes soviétiques, and which abbreviates to URSA, the Latin for "bear", a symbol of Russia.
620	Orwell wrote the book from November 1943–February 1944 when the wartime alliance with the Soviet Union was at its height and Stalin was held in high esteem in Britain among the people and intelligentsia, a fact that Orwell hated.
620	It was initially rejected by a number of British and American publishers, including one of Orwell's own, Victor Gollancz.
620	Its publication was thus delayed, though it became a great commercial success when it did finally appear partly because the Cold War so quickly followed World War II.
620	Time magazine chose the book as one of the 100 best English-language novels (1923 to 2005); it also featured at number 31 on the Modern Library List of Best 20th-Century Novels.
620	It won a Retrospective Hugo Award in 1996 and is also included in the Great Books of the Western World selection.
620	The novel addresses not only the corruption of the revolution by its leaders but also how wickedness, indifference, ignorance, greed, and myopia corrupt the revolution.
620	It portrays corrupt leadership as the flaw in revolution, rather than the act of revolution itself.
620	It also shows how potential ignorance and indifference to problems within a revolution could allow horrors to happen if a smooth transition to a people's government is not achieved.
620	Plot summary  Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'.
620	When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and consider it a duty to prepare for the Rebellion.
620	The animals revolt and drive, assume comman the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm".
620	They adopt Seven Commandments of Animalism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal".
620	Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly.
620	The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health.
620	Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately.
620	Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership.
620	When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader.
620	Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm.
620	Through a young pig named Squealer, Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea.
620	The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill.
620	When the animals find the windmill collapsed after a violent storm, Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it.
620	Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival.
620	Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man.
620	The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones.
620	Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill.
620	Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded.
620	Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill.
620	Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there.
620	Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts a futile rescue.
620	Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted.
620	He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care.
620	Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips, and wear clothes.
620	The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others".
620	Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and local farmers with whom he celebrates a new alliance.
620	He abolishes practices the revolutionary traditions and renames the farm "The Manor Farm".
620	The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing.
620	During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them.
620	Characters  Pigs  *Old Major – An aged prize Middle White boar provides the inspiration that fuels the Rebellion in the book.
620	He is an allegorical combination of Karl Marx, one of the creators of communism, and Lenin, the communist leader of the Russian Revolution and the early Soviet nation, in that he draws up the principles of the revolution.
620	His skull being put on revered public display recalls Lenin, whose embalmed body was put on display.
620	Napoleon – "A large, rather fierce-looking Berkshire boar, the only Berkshire on the farm, not much of a talker, but with a reputation for getting his own way".
620	An allegory of Joseph Stalin, Napoleon is the main villain of Animal Farm.
620	In the first French version of Animal Farm, Napoleon is called ', the French form of Caesar, although another translation has him as '.
620	Snowball – Napoleon's rival and original head of the farm after Jones' overthrow.
620	He is mainly based on Leon Trotsky, but also combines elements from Lenin.
620	Squealer – A small white fat porker who serves as Napoleon's right hand pig and minister of propaganda, holding a position similar to that of Molotov.
620	Minimus – A poetic pig who writes the second and third national anthems of Animal Farm after the singing of "Beasts of England" is banned.
620	The Piglets – Hinted to be the children of Napoleon and are the first generation of animals subjugated to his idea of animal inequality.
620	The young pigs – Four pigs who complain about Napoleon's takeover of the farm but are quickly silenced and later executed.
620	Pinkeye – A minor pig who is mentioned only once; he is the pig that tastes Napoleon's food to make sure it is not poisoned, in response to rumours about an assassination attempt on Napoleon.
620	Humans  *Mr Jones – The former owner of the farm, Jones is a very heavy drinker.
620	The animals revolt against him after he drinks so much that he does not feed or take care of them.
620	Mr Frederick – The tough owner of Pinchfield, a small but well-kept neighbouring farm, who briefly enters into an alliance with Napoleon.
620	Mr Pilkington – The easy-going but crafty and well-to-do owner of Foxwood, a large neighbouring farm overgrown with weeds.
620	Mr Whymper – A man hired by Napoleon for the public relations of Animal Farm to human society.
620	At first he is used to acquire needed goods for the farm such as dog biscuits and paraffin, but later used to procure luxuries like alcohol for the pigs.
620	Equines  *Boxer – Boxer is a loyal, kind, dedicated, and respectable cart-horse, although quite naive and gullible.
620	Clover – Boxer's companion, constantly caring for him; she also acts as a matriarch of sorts for the other horses and the other animals in general.
620	Mollie – Mollie is a self-centred, self-indulgent and vain young white mare who quickly leaves for another farm after the revolution.
620	Benjamin – Benjamin, a donkey, is one of the oldest animals.
620	He has the worst temper, but is also one of the wisest animals on the farm, and is one of the few who can actually read.
620	He is sceptical and pessimistic, his most-often-made statement being "Life will go on as it has always gone on—that is, badly."
620	The academic Morris Dickstein has suggested there is ' a touch of Orwell himself in this creature's timeless scepticism' and indeed, friends called Orwell 'Donkey George', 'after his grumbling donkey Benjamin, in Animal Farm.'
620	Other animals  *Muriel – A wise old goat who is friends with all of the animals on the farm.
620	She, like Benjamin and Snowball, is one of the few animals on the farm who can read.
620	The Puppies – Offspring of Jessie and Bluebell, taken away from them by Napoleon at birth and reared by Napoleon to be his security force.
620	Moses – An old raven who occasionally visits the farm, regaling its denizens with tales of a wondrous place beyond the clouds called Sugarcandy Mohe farm, regaling its denizens with tales of a wonuntain, where he avers that all animals go when they die—but only if they work hard.
620	Orwell portrays religion as 'the black raven of priestcraft—promising pie in the sky when you die, and faithfully serving whoever happens to be in power.
620	The raven 'was Mr.
620	Jones's especial pet, was a spy and a tale-bearer, but he was also a clever talker.'
620	Napoleon brings the raven back, (Ch.
620	IX) as Stalin brought back the Russian Orthodox Church.
620	The Sheep – They show limited understanding of the situations but nonetheless blindly support Napoleon's ideals.
620	The Hens – The hens are among the first to rebel against Napoleon.
620	The Cows – Their milk is stolen by the pigs, who learn to milk them, and is stirred into the pigs' mash every day while the other animals are denied such luxuries.
620	The Cat – Never seen to carry out any work, the cat is absent for long periods, and is forgiven because her excuses are so convincing and she "purred so affectionately that it was impossible not to believe in her good intentions".
620	She has no interest in the politics of the farm, and the only time she is recorded as having participated in an election, she is found to have actually "voted on both sides".
620	Composition and Publication Origin  George Orwell wrote the manuscript in 1943 and 1944 subsequent to his experiences during the Spanish Civil War, which he described in Homage to Catalonia (1938).
620	In the preface of a 1947 Ukrainian edition of Animal Farm, he explained how escaping the communist purges in Spain taught him "how easily totalitarian propaganda can control the opinion of enlightened people in democratic countries".
620	This motivated Orwell to expose and strongly condemn what he saw as the Stalinist corruption of the original socialist ideals.
620	Immediately prior to his writing, Orwell had quit the BBC.
620	He was also upset about a booklet for propagandists the Ministry of Information had put out.
620	The booklet included instructions on how to quell ideological fears of the Soviet Union, which included directions to claim that the Red Terror was a figment of Nazi imagination.
620	In that preface, Orwell also described what gave him the idea of setting the book on a farm: Efforts to find a publisher  Orwell encountered great difficulty getting the manuscript published, as it was feared that the book might upset the alliance between the US, UK and the Soviet Union.
620	Four publishers refused; one had initially accepted the work but declined after consulting the Ministry of Information.
620	Eventually Secker and Warburg published the first edition in 1945.
620	During World War II, it became apparent to Orwell that anti-Soviet literature was not something which most major publishing houses would touch — including his regular publisher Gollancz.
620	He also submitted the manuscript to Faber and Faber, where the poet T.
620	S.
620	Eliot (who was a director of the firm) rejected it; Eliot wrote back to Orwell praising its "good writing" and "fundamental integrity" but declared that they would only accept it for publication if they had some sympathy for the viewpoint "which I take to be generally Trotskyite".
620	Eliot said he found the view "not convincing", and contended that the pigs were made out to be the best to run the farm; he posited that someone might argue "what was needed ..
620	".
620	Orwell let André Deutsch, who was working for Nicholson & Watson in 1944, read the typescript, and Deutsch was convinced that Nicholson & Watson would want to publish it - but they did not, and "lectured Orwell on what they perceived to be errors in Animal Farm."
620	In his London Letter, 17 April 1944 for Partisan Review Orwell wrote that it was "now next door to impossible to get anything overtly anti-Russian printed.
620	Anti-Russian books do appear, but mostly from Catholic publishing firms and always from a religious or frankly reactionary angle."
620	The publisher Jonathan Cape, who had initially accepted Animal Farm, subsequently rejected his book after an official at the British Ministry of Information warned him off — although the civil servant who it is assumed gave the order was later found to be a Soviet spy.
620	Writing to Leonard Moore, a partner in the literary agency of Christy & Moore, publisher Jonathan Cape explained that the decision had been taken on the advice of a senior official in the Ministry of Information.
620	Such flagrant anti-Soviet bias was unacceptable: and the choice of pigs as the dominant class was thought to be especially offensive.
620	The 'important official' was, or so it may reasonably be assumed, a man named Peter Smollett, later unmasked as a Soviet agent.
620	Orwell was suspicious of Smollett/Smolka and he would be one of the names Orwell included in his list of Crypto-Communists and Fellow-Travellers sent to the Information Research Department in 1949.
620	Born Hans Peter Smolka in Vienna in 1912 he came to Britain in 1933 as an NKVD agent, codename 'Abo', became a naturalized British subject in 1938, changed his name, and after the outbreak of World War II joined the Ministry of Information where he organised pro-Soviet propaganda—he worked with Kim Philby in 1943-45.
620	Smollett's family have rejected the accusation that he was a spy.
620	The publisher wrote to Orwell, saying: Frederic Warburg too, faced pressures against publication, even from people in his own office, and from his wife Pamela, who felt that it was not the moment for ingratitude towards Stalin and the heroic Red Army]amela, who felt that it was ] who had played a major part in defeating Hitler.
620	A Russian translation was printed in the paper Posev, and in giving permission for a Russian translation of Animal Farm Orwell refused in advance all royalties.
620	A translation in Ukrainian, produced in Germany, was confiscated in large part by the American wartime authorities and handed over to the Soviet repatriation commission.
620	In October 1945 Orwell wrote to Fredric Warburg expressing interest in pursuing the chances that the political cartoonist David Low would illustrate Animal Farm.
620	Low had written a letter saying that he had had "a good time with ANIMAL FARM - an excellent bit of satire - it would illustrate perfectly."
620	Nothing came of this but an edition illustrated by the cartoonist Ralph Steadman was published by Secker & Warburg in 1995 to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the first edition of Animal Farm  in 1945.
620	"The Freedom of the Press"  Orwell originally wrote a preface which complains about British self-censorship and how the British people were suppressing criticism of the USSR, their World War II ally.
620	"The sinister fact about literary censorship in England is that it is largely voluntary....
620	Things are kept right out of the British press, not because the Government intervenes but because of a general tacit agreement that 'it wouldn't do' to mention that particular fact."
620	Although the first edition allowed space for the preface, it was not included, and as of June 2009 has not been published with most editions of the book.
620	Secker and Warburg published the first edition of Animal Farm in 1945 without any introduction.
620	However, the publisher had provided space for a preface in the author's proof composited from the manuscript.
620	For reasons unknown, no preface was supplied and all the page numbers needed to be redone at the last minute.
620	Years later, in 1972, Ian Angus found the original typescript titled "The Freedom of the Press", and Bernard Crick published it, together with his own introduction in The Times Literary Supplement on 15 September 1972 as "How the essay came to be written".
620	Orwell's essay criticised British self-censorship by the press, specifically the suppression of unflattering descriptions of Stalin and the Soviet government.
620	The same essay also appeared in the Italian 1976 Animal Farm edition, with another introduction by Crick, claiming to be the first edition with the preface.
620	Other publishers were still declining to publish it.
620	Critical Response  Contemporary reviews of the work were not universally positive.
620	Writing in the American New Republic magazine, George Soule expressed his disappointment in the book, writing it "puzzled and saddened me.
620	It seemed on the whole dull.
620	The allegory turned out to be a creaking machine for saying in a clumsy way things that have been said better directly."
620	Soule argued that the animals were not consistent enough to their real world inspirations, and said, "It seems to me that the failure of this book (commercially it is already assured of tremendous success) arises from the fact that the satire deals not with something the author has experienced, but rather with stereotyped ideas about a country which he probably does not know very well.
620	Tosco Fyvel, writing in Tribune, 24 August 1945, called the book " a gentle satire on a certain State and on the illusions of an age which may already be behind us."
620	Julian Symons responded to this on 7 September - "Should we not expect, in Tribune at least, acknowledgement of the fact that it is a satire not at all gentle upon a particular State - Soviet Russia?
620	It seems to me that a reviewer should have the courage to identify Napoleon with Stalin, and Snowball with Trotsky, and express an opinion favourable or unfavourable to the author, upon a political ground.
620	In a hundred years time perhaps, Animal Farm may be simply a fairy story, today it is a political satire with a good deal of point."
620	Animal Farm has been subject to much comment in the decades since these early remarks.
620	Analysis Animalism The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into 'a complete system of thought', which they formally name Animalism.
620	Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading).
620	Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society.
620	The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy.
620	Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend.
620	No animal shall wear clothes.
620	No animal shall sleep in a bed.
620	No animal shall drink alcohol.
620	No animal shall kill any other animal.
620	All animals are equal.
620	Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it).
620	The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets.
620	No animal shall drink alcohol to excess.
620	No animal shall kill any other animal without cause.
620	Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!"
620	This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits.
620	Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.
620	Significance and allegory In the Eastern Bloc both Animal Farm and later, also Nineteen Eighty-Four were on the list of forbidden books up until the end of communism in 1989, and were only available via clandestine Samizdat networks.
620	Orwell biographer Jeffrey Meyers has written, "virtually every detail has political significance in this grapher Jeffallegory."
620	Orwell himself wrote in 1946, "Of course I intended it primarily as a satire on the Russian revolution..[and] that kind of revolution (violent conspiratorial revolution, led by unconsciously power hungry people) can only lead to a change of masters [-] revolutions only effect a radical improvement when the masses are alert."
620	And in a preface for a 1947 Ukrainian edition he stated, "...
