624	It is technically part of the continental U.S., but is often not included in colloquial use; Alaska is not part of the contiguous U.S., often called "the Lower 48".
624	The capital city, Juneau, is situated on the mainland of the North American continent, but is not connected by road to the rest of the North American highway system.
624	The state is bordered by the Yukon Territory and British Columbia in Canada, to the east, the Gulf of Alaska and the Pacific Ocean to the south, the Bering Sea, Bering Strait, and Chukchi Sea to the west and the Arctic Ocean to the north.
624	Alaska's territorial waters touch Russia's territorial waters in the Bering Strait, as the Russian Big Diomede Island and Alaskan Little Diomede Island are only 3 mi apart.
624	With the extension of the Aleutian Islands into the eastern hemisphere, it is technically both the westernmost and easternmost state in the United States, as well as also being the northernmost.
624	Alaska is the largest state in the United States in land area at 586412 sqmi, over twice the size of Texas, the next largest state.
624	Alaska is larger than all but 18 sovereign countries.
624	Counting territorial waters, Alaska is larger than the combined area of the next three largest states: Texas, California, and Montana.
624	It is also larger than the combined area of the 22 smallest U.S.
624	Regions There are no officially defined borders demarcating the various regions of Alaska, but there are six widely accepted regions: South Central The most populous region of Alaska, containing Anchorage, the Matanuska-Susitna Valley and the Kenai Peninsula.
624	Rural, mostly unpopulated areas south of the Alaska Range and west of the Wrangell Mountains also fall within the definition of Southcentral, as well as the Prince William Sound area and the communities of Cordova and Valdez.
624	Southeast Also referred to as the Panhandle or Inside Passage, this is the region of Alaska closest to the rest of the United States.
624	As such, this was where most of the initial non-indigenous settlement occurred in the years following the Alaska Purchase.
624	The region is dominated by the Alexander Archipelago as well as the Tongass National Forest, the largest national forest in the United States.
624	It contains the state capital, Juneau, the former capital, Sitka, and Ketchikan, at one time Alaska's largest city.
624	The Alaska Marine Highway provides a vital surface transportation link throughout the area, as only three communities (Haines, Hyder and Skagway) enjoy direct connections to the contiguous North American road system.
624	Interior The largest region of Alaska, much of the interior is uninhabited wilderness.
624	Fairbanks is the only large city in the region.
624	Small towns and Native villages are scattered throughout, mostly along the highway and river systems.
624	Denali National Park and Preserve is located here, home to Mount McKinley (also widely known by its local name of Denali), the highest point in North America.
624	Southwest Southwest Alaska is a sparsely inhabited region stretching some 500 mi inland from the Bering Sea.
624	Most of the population lives along the coast.
624	Kodiak Island is also located in Southwest.
624	The massive Yukon–Kuskokwim Delta, one of the largest river deltas in the world, is here.
624	Portions of the Alaska Peninsula are considered part of Southwest, with the remaining portions included with the Aleutian Islands (see below).
624	North Slope The North Slope is mostly tundra peppered with small villages.
624	The area is known for its massive reserves of crude oil, and contains both the National Petroleum Reserve–Alaska and the Prudhoe Bay Oil Field.
624	Barrow, the northernmost city in the United States, is located here.
624	The Northwest Arctic area, anchored by Kotzebue and also containing the Kobuk River valley, is often regarded as being part of this region.
624	However, the respective Inupiat of the North Slope and of the Northwest Arctic seldom think of themselves as one.
624	Aleutian Islands More than 300 small, volcanic islands make up this chain, which stretches over 1200 mi into the Pacific Ocean.
624	The International Date Line was drawn west of 180° to keep the whole state, and thus the entire North American continent, within the same legal day.
624	However, because some of these islands fall in the Eastern Hemisphere, this makes Alaska the northernmost, easternmost and westernmost state in the union, with the southernmost state being Hawaii.
624	Two of the islands, Attu and Kiska, were occupied by Japanese forces during World War II.
624	Natural features With its myriad islands, Alaska has nearly 34000 mi of tidal shoreline.
624	The Aleutian Islands chain extends west from the southern tip of the Alaska Peninsula.
624	Many active volcanoes are found in the Aleutians and in coastal regions.
624	Unimak Island, for example, is home to Mount Shishaldin, which is an occasionally smoldering volcano that rises to 10000 ft above the North Pacific.
624	It is the most perfect volcanic cone on Earth, even more symmetrical than Japan's Mount Fuji.
624	The chain of volcanoes extends to Mount Spurr, west of Anchorage on the mainland.
624	Geologists have identified Alaska as part of Wrangellia, a large region consisting of multiple states and Canadian provinces in the Pacific Northwest which is actively undergoing continent building.
624	One of the world's largest tides occurs in Turnagain Arm, just south of Anchorage – tidal differences can be more than 35 ft.
624	Many sources say Turnagain has the second-greatest tides in North America, but several areas in Canada have larger tides.) Alaska has more than three million lakes.
624	Marshlands and wetland permafrost cover 188320 sqmi (mostly in northern, western and southwest flatlands).
624	Glacier ice covers some 16000 sqmi of land and 1200 sqmi of tidal zone.
624	The Bering Glacier complex near the southeastern border with Yukon covers 2250 sqmi alone.
624	With over 100,000, Alaska has half of the world's glaciers.
624	Land ownership According to an October 1998 report by the United States Bureau of Land Management, approximately 65% of Alaska is owned and managed by the U.S.
624	Of these, the Bureau of Land Management manages  87 e6acre, or 23.8% of the state.
624	The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
624	It is the world's largest wildlife refuge, comprising 16 e6acre.
624	Of the remaining land area, the state of Alaska owns 101 e6acre;  its entitlement under the Alaska Statehood Act.
624	A portion of that acreage is occasionally ceded to organized boroughs, under the statutory provisions pertaining to newly formed boroughs.
624	Smaller portions are set aside for rural subdivisions and other homesteading-related opportunities, though these are infrequently popular due to the often remote and roadless locations.
624	The University of Alaska, as a land grant university, also owns substantial acreage which it manages independently.
624	Another 44 e6acre are owned by 12 regional, and scores of local, Native corporations created under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act.
624	Regional Native corporation Doyon, Limited often promotes itself as the largest private landowner in Alaska in advertisements and other communications.
624	Provisions of ANCSA allowing the corporations' land holdings to be sold on the open market starting in 1991 were repealed before they could take effect.
624	Effectively, the corporations hold title (including subsurface title in many cases, a privilege denied to individual Alaskans) but cannot sell the land.
624	Individual Native allotments can be and are sold on the open market, however.
624	Various private interests own the remaining land, totaling about one percent of the state.
624	Alaska is, by a large margin, the state with the smallest percentage of private land ownership when Native corporation holdings are excluded.
624	Climate The climate in Southeast Alaska is a mid-latitude oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb) in the southern sections and a subarctic oceanic climate (Köppen Cfc) in the northern parts.
624	On an annual basis, Southeast is both the wettest and warmest part of Alaska with milder temperatures in the winter and high precipitation throughout the year.
624	Juneau averages over 50 in of precipitation a year, and Ketchikan averages over 150 in.
624	This is also the only region in Alaska in which the average daytime high temperature is above freezing during the winter months.
624	The climate of Anchorage and south central Alaska is mild by Alaskan standards due to the region's proximity to the seacoast.
624	While the area gets less rain than southeast Alaska, it gets more snow, and days tend to be clearer.
624	On average, Anchorage receives 16 in of precipitation a year, with around 75 in of snow, although there are areas in the south central which receive far more snow.
624	It is a subarctic climate (Köppen Dfc) due to its brief, cool summers.
624	The climate of Western Alaska is determined in large part by the Bering Sea and the Gulf of Alaska.
624	It is a subarctic oceanic climate in the southwest and a continental subarctic climate farther north.
624	The temperature is somewhat moderate considering how far north the area is.
624	This region has a tremendous amount of variety in precipitation.
624	An area stretching from the northern side of the Seward Peninsula to the Kobuk River valley is technically a desert, with portions receiving less than 10 in of precipitation annually.
624	On the other extreme, some locations between Dillingham and Bethel average around 100 in of precipitation.
624	The climate of the interior of Alaska is subarctic.
624	Some of the highest and lowest temperatures in Alaska occur around the area near Fairbanks.
624	The summers may have temperatures reaching into the 90s °F (the low to mid 30s °C), while in the winter, the temperature can fall below .
624	Precipitation is sparse in the Interior, often less than 10 in a year, but what precipitation falls in the winter tends to stay the entire winter.
624	The highest and lowest recorded temperatures in Alaska are both in the Interior.
624	The highest is 100 °F in Fort Yukon (which is just 8 mi inside the arctic circle) on June 27, 1915, making Alaska tied with Hawaii as the state with the lowest high temperature in the United States.
624	The lowest official Alaska temperature is  in Prospect Creek on January 23, 1971, one degree above the lowest temperature recorded in continental North America (in Snag, Yukon, Canada).
624	The climate in the extreme north of Alaska is Arctic (Köppen ET) with long, very cold winters and short, cool summers.
624	Even in July, the average low temperature in Barrow is 34 °F.
624	Precipitation is light in this part of Alaska, with many places averaging less than 10 in per year, mostly as snow which stays on the ground almost the entire year.
624	History Alaska natives Numerous indigenous people occupied Alaska for thousands of years before the arrival of European peoples to the area.
624	The Tlingit people developed a matrilineal society in what is today Southeast Alaska, along with parts of British Columbia and the Yukon.
624	Also in Southeast were the Haida, now well known for their unique arts.
624	The Tsimshian people came to Alaska from British Columbia in 1887, when President Grover Cleveland, and later the U.S.
624	Congress, granted them permission to settle on Annette Island and found the town of Metlakatla.
624	All three of these peoples, as well as other indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast, experienced smallpox outbreaks from the late 18th through the mid-19th century, with the most devastating epidemics arriving in the 1830s and 1860s.
624	The Aleutian Islands are still home to the Aleut people's seafaring society, although they were the first Native Alaskans to be exploited by Russians.
624	Western and Southwestern Alaska are home to the Yup'ik, while their cousins the Alutiiq lived in what is now Southcentral Alaska.
624	The Gwich’in people of the northern Interior region are primarily known today for their dependence on the caribou within the much-contested Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
624	The North Slope and Little Diomede Island are occupied by the widespread Inuit people.
624	Colonization Some researchers believe that the first Russian settlement in Alaska was established in 17th century.
624	According to this hypothesis, in 1648 several koches of Semyon Dezhnyov's expedition were thrown to Alaska by storm and founded this settlement.
624	This hypothesis is based on the message of Chukchi geographer Nikolai Daurkin who had visited Alaska in 1764–1765 and reported about a village on the Kheuveren river, populated by "bearded men" who "pray to the icons".
624	Some modern researchers associate Kheuveren with Koyuk River.
624	It is usually assumed that the first European boat to reach Alaska was the St.
624	Gabriel under the authority of the surveyor M.
624	S.
624	Gvozdev and assistant navigator I.
624	Fyodorov on August 21, 1732 during expedition of Siberian cossak A.
624	F.
624	Shestakov and Belorussian explorer D.
624	I.
624	Pavlutsky (1729—1735) Another European contact with Alaska occurred in 1741, when Vitus Bering led an expedition for the Russian Navy aboard the St.
624	Peter.
624	After his crew returned to Russia with sea otter pelts judged to be the finest fur in the world, small associations of fur traders began to sail from the shores of Siberia towards the Aleutian islands.
624	The first permanent European settlement was founded in 1784.
624	Between 1774 and 1800 Spain sent several expeditions to Alaska in order to assert its claim over the Pacific Northwest.
624	In 1789 a Spanish settlement and fort were built in Nootka Sound.
624	These expeditions gave names to places such as Valdez, Bucareli Sound, and Cordova.
624	Later, the Russian-American Company carried out an expanded colonization program during the early-to-mid-19th century.
624	Sitka, renamed New Archangel from 1804 to 1867, on Baranof Island in the Alexander Archipelago in what is now Southeast Alaska, became the capital of Russian America and remained the capital after the colony was transferred to the United States.
624	The Russians never fully colonized Alaska, and the colony was never very profitable.
624	William H.
624	Seward, the United States Secretary of State, negotiated the Alaska Purchase (also known as Seward's Folly) with the Russians in 1867 for $7.2 million.
624	Alaska was loosely governed by the military initially, and was administered as a district starting in 1884, with a governor appointed by the president of the United States, as well as a district court headquartered in Sitka.
624	For most of Alaska's first decade under the American flag, Sitka was the only community inhabited by American settlers.
624	They organized a "provisional city government," which was Alaska's first city government, but not in a legal sense.
624	Legislation allowing Alaskan communities to legally incorporate as cities did not come about until 1900, and home rule for cities was extremely limited or unavailable until statehood took effect.
624	U.S.
624	Territory Starting in the 1890s and stretching in some places to the early 1910s, gold rushes in Alaska and the nearby Yukon Territory brougrly 1910s, Sitka until 1906, was moved north to Juneau, and began to take shape with the construction of the Alaska Governor's Mansion that same year.
624	During World War II, the Aleutian Islands Campaign focused on the three outer Aleutian Islands – Attu, Agattu and Kiska – that were invaded by Japanese troops and occupied between June 1942 and August 1943.
624	Unalaska/Dutch Harbor became a significant base for the U.S.
624	Army Air Corps and Navy submariners.
624	The U.S.
624	Lend-Lease program involved the flying of American warplanes through Canada to Fairbanks and thence Nome; Soviet pilots took possession of these aircraft, ferrying them to fight the German invasion of the Soviet Union.
624	The construction of military bases contributed to the population growth of some Alaskan cities.
624	Statehood Statehood for Alaska was an important cause of James Wickersham early in his tenure as a congressional delegate.
624	Decades later, the statehood movement gained its first real momentum following a territorial referendum in 1946.
624	The Alaska Statehood Committee and Alaska's Constitutional Convention would soon follow.
624	Statehood supporters also found themselves fighting major battles against political foes, mostly in the U.S.
624	Congress but also within Alaska.
624	Statehood was approved by Congress on July 7, 1958.
624	Alaska was officially proclaimed a state on January 3, 1959.
624	On March 27, 1964, the massive "Good Friday Earthquake" killed 133 people and destroyed several villages and portions of large coastal communities, mainly by the resultant tsunamis and landslides.
624	It was the third most powerful earthquake in the recorded history of the world, with a moment magnitude of 9.2.
624	It was over one thousand times more powerful than the 1989 San Francisco earthquake.
624	The time of day (5:36 pm), time of year and location of the epicenter were all cited as factors in potentially sparing thousands of lives, particularly in Anchorage.
624	The 1968 discovery of oil at Prudhoe Bay and the 1977 completion of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline led to an oil boom.
624	Royalty revenues from oil have funded large state budgets from 1980 onward.
624	That same year, not coincidentally, Alaska repealed its state income tax.
624	In 1989, the Exxon Valdez hit a reef in the Prince William Sound, spilling over 11000000 USgal of crude oil over 1,100 miles (1,600 km) of coastline.
624	Today, the battle between philosophies of development and conservation is seen in the contentious debate over oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
624	Demographics The United States Census Bureau estimates that the population of Alaska was 731,449 on July 1, 2012, a 3.0% increase since the 2010 United States Census.
624	In 2010, Alaska ranked as the 47th state by population, ahead of North Dakota, Vermont, and Wyoming (and Washington, D.C.) Alaska is the least densely populated state, and one of the most sparsely populated areas in the world, at , with the next state, Wyoming, at .
624	Alaska is the largest U.S.
624	As of April 2012, the state's unemployment rate was 6.9%.
624	Race and ancestry According to the 2010 United States Census, Alaska had a population of 710,231.
624	In terms of race and ethnicity, the state was 66.7% White (64.1% Non-Hispanic White), 14.8% American Indian and Alaska Native, 5.4% Asian, 3.3% Black or African American, 1.0% Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander, 1.6% from Some Other Race, and 7.3% from Two or More Races.
624	Hispanics or Latinos of any race made up 5.5% of the population.
624	In 1960, the Census Bureau reported Alaska's population as 77.2% White, 3% Black, and 18.8% American Indian and Alaska Native.
624	As of 2011, 50.7% of Alaska's population younger than age 1 were minorities.
624	Languages According to the 2005–2007 American Community Survey, 84.7% of people over the age of five speak only English at home.
624	About 3.5% speak Spanish at home.
624	About 2.2% speak another Indo-European language at home and aboat home.
624	About 2ut 4.3% speak an Asian language at home.
624	And about 5.3% speak other languages at home.
624	A total of 5.2% of Alaskans speak one of the state's 22 indigenous languages, known locally as "native languages".
624	These languages belong to two major language families: Eskimo–Aleut and Na-Dene.
624	As the homeland of these two major language families of North America, Alaska has been described as the crossroads of the continent, providing evidence for the recent settlement of North America by way of the Bering land bridge.
624	Religion Alaska has been identified, along with Pacific Northwest states Washington and Oregon, as being the least religious in the U.S.
624	According to statistics collected by the Association of Religion Data Archives, about 39% of Alaska residents were members of religious congregations.
624	Evangelical Protestants had 78,070 members, Roman Catholics had 54,359, and mainline Protestants had 37,156.
624	After Catholicism, the largest single denominations are The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints with 30,169, and Southern Baptists with 22,959.
624	The large Eastern Orthodox (with 49 parishes and up to 50,000 followers) population is a result of early Russian colonization and missionary work among Alaska Natives.
624	In 1795, the First Russian Orthodox Church was established in Kodiak.
624	Intermarriage with Alaskan Natives helped the Russian immigrants integrate into society.
624	As a result, an increasing number of Russian Orthodox churches gradually became established within Alaska.
624	Alaska also has the largest Quaker population (by percentage) of any state.
624	In 2009 there were 6,000 Jews in Alaska (for whom observance of halakha may pose special problems).
624	Estimates for the number of Alaskan Muslims range from 2,000 to 5,000.
624	In 2010, the local Muslim community broke ground on the first mosque in the state.
624	Alaskan Hindus often share venues and celebrations with members of other religious communities including Sikhs and Jains.
624	Economy The 2007 gross state product was $44.9 billion, 45th in the nation.
624	Its per capita personal income for 2007 was $40,042, ranking 15th in the nation.
624	The oil and gas industry dominates the Alaskan economy, with more than 80% of the state's revenues derived from petroleum extraction.
624	Alaska's main export product (excluding oil and natural gas) is seafood, primarily salmon, cod, Pollock and crab.
624	Agriculture represents only a fraction of the Alaskan economy.
624	Agricultural production is primarily for consumption within the state and includes nursery stock, dairy products, vegetables, and livestock.
624	Manufacturing is limited, with most foodstuffs and general goods oducts, vegetableimported from elsewhere.
624	Employment is primarily in government and industries such as natural resource extraction, shipping, and transportation.
624	Military bases are a significant component of the economy in both Fairbanks and Anchorage.
624	Federal subsidies are also an important part of the economy, allowing the state to keep taxes low.
624	Its industrial outputs are crude petroleum, natural gas, coal, gold, precious metals, zinc and other mining, seafood processing, timber and wood products.
624	There is also a growing service and tourism sector.
624	Tourists have contributed to the economy by supporting local lodging.
624	Largest employers According to the Alaska Department of Labor and Workforce Development, the following were the state's largest private sector employers in 2010: Energy Alaska has vast energy resources.
624	Major oil and gas reserves are found in the Alaska North Slope (ANS) and Cook Inlet basins.
624	According to the Energy Information Administration, Alaska ranks second in the nation in crude oil production.
624	Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's North Slope is the highest yielding oil field in the United States and on North America, typically producing about 400000 oilbbl/d.
624	The Trans-Alaska Pipeline can transport and pump up to  of crude oil per day, more than any other crude oil pipeline in the United States.
624	Additionally, substantial coal deposits are found in Alaska's bituminous, sub-bituminous, and lignite coal basins.
624	The United States Geological Survey estimates that there are  of undiscovered, technically recoverable gas from natural gas hydrates on the Alaskan North Slope.
624	Alaska also offers some of the highest hydroelectric power potential in the country from its numerous rivers.
624	Large swaths of the Alaskan coastline offer wind and geothermal energy potential as well.
624	Alaska's economy depends heavily on increasingly expensive diesel fuel for heating, transportation, electric power and light.
624	Though wind and hydroelectric power are abundant and underdeveloped, proposals for state-wide energy systems (e.g.
624	File:Alaska Crude Oil Reserves.PNG|Alaska oil reserves peaked in 1978 and have declined 60% thereafter File:Alaska Crude  ReserveOil Production.PNG|Alaska oil production peaked in 1988 and has declined 65% since Permanent Fund The Alaska Permanent Fund is a constitutionally authorized appropriation of oil revenues, established by voters in 1976 to manage a surplus in state petroleum revenues from oil, largely in anticipation of same from the recently constructed Trans-Alaska Pipeline System.
624	The fund was originally proposed by Governor Keith Miller on the eve of the 1969 Prudhoe Bay lease sale, out of fear that the legislature would spend the entire proceeds of the sale (which amounted to $900 million) at once, and was later championed by Governor Jay Hammond and Kenai state representative Hugh Malone.
624	It has served as an attractive political prospect ever since, diverting revenues which would normally be deposited into the general fund.
624	The Alaska Constitution was written so as to discourage dedicating state funds for a particular purpose.
624	The Permanent Fund has become the rare exception to this, mostly due to the political climate of distrust existing during the time of its creation.
624	From its initial principal of $734,000, the fund has grown to $40 billion as a result of oil royalties and capital investment programs.
624	Most if not all the principal is invested conservatively outside Alaska.
624	This has led to frequent calls by Alaskan politicians for the Fund to make investments within Alaska, though such a stance has never really gained momentum.
624	Starting in 1982, dividends from the fund's annual growth have been paid out each year to eligible Alaskans, ranging from an initial $1,000.00 in 1982 (equal to three years' payout, as the distribution of payments was held up in a lawsuit over the distribution scheme) to $3,269.00 in 2008 (which included a one-time $1,200.00 "Resource Rebate").
624	Every year, the state legislature takes out 8 percent from the earnings, puts 3 percent back into the principal for inflation proofing, and the remaining 5 percent is distributed to all qualifying Alaskans.
624	To qualify for the Permanent Fund Dividend, one must have lived in the state for a minimum of 12 months, maintain constant residency subject to allowable absences, and not be subject to court judgments or criminal convictions which fall under various disqualifying classifications or may subject the payment amount to civil garnishment.
624	Cost of living The cost of goods in Alaska has long been higher than in the contiguous 48 states.
624	This has changed for the most part in Anchorage and to a lesser extent in Fairbanks, where the cost of living has dropped somewhat in the past five years.
624	Federal government employees, particularly United States Postal Service (USPS) workers and active-duty military members, receive a Cost of Living Allowance usually set at 25% of base pay because, while the cost of living has gone down, it is still one of the highest in the country.
624	The introduction of big-box stores in Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Juneau also did much to lower prices.
624	Wal-Mart opened their first Anchorage store in 1993, and debuted in Fairbanks in 2004.
624	The company currently has locations covering most of the population centers of Alaska, including Juneau, Ketchikan and Kodiak.
624	However, rural Alaska suffers from extremely high prices for food and consumer goods, compared to the rest of the country due to the relatively limited transportation infrastructure.
624	Many rural residents come into these cities and purchase food and goods in bulk from warehouse clubs like Costco and Sam's Club.
624	Some have embraced the free shipping offers of some online retailers to purchase items much more cheaply than they could in their own communities, if they are available at all.
624	Agriculture and fishing Due to the northern climate and short growing season, relatively little farming occurs in Alaska.
624	Most farms are in either the Matanuska Valley, about 40 mi northeast of Anchorage, or on the Kenai Peninsula, about 60 mi southwest of Anchorage.
624	The short 100-day growing season limits the crops that can be grown, but the long sunny summer days make for productive growing seasons.
624	The primary crops are potatoes, carrots, lettuce, and cabbage.
624	The Tanana Valley is another notable agricultural locus, especially Delta Junction area, about 100 mi southeast of Fairbanks, with a sizable concentration of farms growing agronomic crops; these farms mostly lie north and east of Fort Greely.
624	This area was largely set aside and developed under a state program spearheaded by Hammond during his second term as governor.
624	Delta-area crops consist predominately of barley and hay.
624	West of Fairbanks lies another concentration of small farms catering to restaurants, the hotel and tourist industry, and community supported agriculture.
624	Alaskan agriculture has experienced a surge in growth of market gardeners, small farms and farmers' markets in recent years, with the highest percentage increase (46%) in the nation in growth in farmers' markets in 2011, compared to 17% nationwide.
624	The peony industry has also taken off, as the growing season allows farmers to harvest during a gap in supply elsewhere in the world, thereby filling a niche in the flower market.
624	Alaska, with no counties, also lacks county fairs.
624	However, a small assortment of state and local fairs (with the Alaska State Fair in Palmer the largest), are held mostly in the late summer.
624	The fairs are mostly located in communities with historic or current agricultural activity, and feature local farmers exhibiting produce in addition to more high-profile commercial activities such as carnival rides, concerts and food.
624	"Alaska Grown" is used as an agricultural slogan.
624	Alaska has an abundance of seafood, with the primary fisheries in the Bering Sea and the North Pacific, and seafood is one of the few food items that is often cheaper within the state than outside it.
624	Many Alaskans take advantage of salmon seasons to harvest portions of their household diet while fishing for subsistence, as well as sport.
624	This includes fish taken by hook, net or wheel.
624	Hunting for subsistence, primarily caribou, moose, and Dall sheep is sno}}<till common in the state, particularly in remote Bush communities.
624	An example of a traditional native food is Akutaq, the Eskimo ice cream, which can consist of reindeer fat, seal oil, dried fish meat and local berries.
624	Alaska's reindeer herding is concentrated on Seward Peninsula where wild caribou can be prevented from mingling and migrating with the domesticated reindeer.
624	Most food in Alaska is transported into the state from "Outside", and shipping costs make food in the cities relatively expensive.
624	In rural areas, subsistence hunting and gathering is an essential activity because imported food is prohibitively expensive.
624	The cost of importing food to villages begins at 7¢ per pound (15¢/kg) and rises rapidly to 50¢ per pound ($1.10/kg) or more.
624	The cost of delivering a 1 USgal of milk is about $3.50 in many villages where per capita income can be $20,000 or less.
624	Fuel cost can exceed $8.00 per gallon.
624	Transportation Roads Alaska has few road connections compared to the rest of the U.S.
624	The state's road system covers a relatively small area of the state, linking the central population centers and the Alaska Highway, the principal route out of the state through Canada.
624	The state capital, Juneau, is not accessible by road, only a car ferry, which has spurred several debates over the decades about moving the capital to a city on the road system, or building a road connection from Haines.
624	The western part of Alaska has no road system connecting the communities with the rest of Alaska.
624	One unique feature of the Alaska Highway system is the Anton Anderson Memorial Tunnel, an active Alaska Railroad tunnel recently upgraded to provide a paved roadway link with the isolated community of Whittier on Prince William Sound to the Seward Highway about 50 mi southeast of Anchorage at Portage.
624	At  the tunnel was the longest road tunnel in North America until 2007.
624	The tunnel is the longest combination road and rail tunnel in North America.
624	Rail Built around 1915, the Alaska Railroad (ARR) played a key role in the development of Alaska through the 20th century.
624	It links north Pacific shipping through providing critical infrastructure with tracks that run from Seward to Interior Alaska by way of South Central Alaska, passing through Anchorage, Eklutna, Wasilla, Talkeetna, Denali, and Fairbanks, with spurs to Whittier, Palmer and North Pole.
624	The cities, towns, villages, and region served by ARR tracks are known statewide as "The Railbelt".
624	In recent years, the ever-improving paved highway system began to eclipse the railroad's importance in Alaska's economy.
624	The railroad, though famed for its summertime tour passenger service, played a vital role in Alaska's development, moving freight into Alaska while transporting natural resources southward (i.e., coal from the Usibelli coal mine near Healy to Seward and gravel from the Matanuska Valley to Anchorage).
624	The Alaska Railroad was one of the last railroads in North America to use cabooses in regular service and still uses them on some gravel trains.
624	It continues to offer one of the last flag stop routes in the country.
624	A stretch of about 60 mi of track along an area north of Talkeetna remains inaccessible by road; the railroad provides the only transportation to rural homes and cabins in the area; until construction of the Parks Highway in the 1970s, the railroad provided the only land access to most of the region along its entire route.
624	In northern Southeast Alaska, the White Pass and Yukon Route also partly runs through the state from Skagway northwards into Canada (British Columbia and Yukon Territory), crossing the border at White Pass Summit.
624	This line is now mainly used by tourists, often arriving by cruise liner at Skagway.
624	It featured in the 1983 BBC television series Great Little Railways.
624	The Alaska Rail network is not connected to Outside.
624	In 2000, the U.S.
624	Congress authorized $6 million to study the feasibility of a rail link between Alaska, Canada, and the lower 48.
624	Alaska Rail Marine provides car float service between Whittier and Seattle.
624	Marine transport Many cities, towns and villages in the state do not have road or highway access; the only modes of access involve travel by air, river, or the sea.
624	Alaska's well-developed state-owned ferry system (known as the Alaska Marine Highway) serves the cities of southeast, the Gulf Coast and the Alaska Peninsula.
624	The ferries transport vehicles as well as passengers.
624	The system also operates a ferry service from Bellingham, Washington and Prince Rupert, British Columbia in Canada through the Inside Passage to Skagway.
624	The Inter-Island Ferry Authority also serves as an important marine link for many communities in the Prince of Wales Island region of Southeast and works in concert with the Alaska Marine Highway.
624	In recent years, cruise lines have created a summertime tourism market, mainly connecting the Pacific Northwest to Southeast Alaska and, to a lesser degree, towns along Alaska's gulf coast.
624	The population of Ketchikan may rise by over 10,000 people on many days during the summer, as up to four large cruise ships at a time can dock, debarking thousands of passengers.
624	Air transport Cities not served by road, sea, or river can be reached only by air, foot, dogsled, or snowmachine accounting for Alaska's extremely well developed bush air services—an Alaskan novelty.
624	Anchorage itself, and to a lesser extent Fairbanks, are served by many majonks, are servr airlines.
624	Because of limited highway access, air travel remains the most efficient form of transportation in and out of the state.
624	Anchorage recently completed extensive remodeling and construction at Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport to help accommodate the upsurge in tourism (in 2000–2001, the latest year for which data is available, 2.4 million total arrivals to Alaska were counted, 1.7 million by air travel; 1.4 million were visitors).
624	Regular flights to most villages and towns within the state that are commercially viable are challenging to provide, so they are heavily subsidized by the federal government through the Essential Air Service program.
624	Alaska Airlines is the only major airline offering in-state travel with jet service (sometimes in combination cargo and passenger Boeing 737-400s) from Anchorage and Fairbanks to regional hubs like Bethel, Nome, Kotzebue, Dillingham, Kodiak, and other larger communities as well as to major Southeast and Alaska Peninsula communities.
624	The bulk of remaining commercial flight offerings come from small regional commuter airlines such as Era Aviation, PenAir, and Frontier Flying Service.
624	The smallest towns and villages must rely on scheduled or chartered bush flying services using general aviation aircraft such as the Cessna Caravan, the most popular aircraft in use in the state.
624	Much of this service can be attributed to the Alaska bypass mail program which subsidizes bulk mail delivery to Alaskan rural communities.
624	The program requires 70% of that subsidy to go to carriers who offer passenger service to the communities.
624	Many communities have small air taxi services.
624	These operations originated from the demand for customized transport to remote areas.
624	Perhaps the most quintessentially Alaskan plane is the bush seaplane.
624	The world's busiest seaplane base is Lake Hood, located next to Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport, where flights bound for remote villages without an airstrip carry passengers, cargo, and many items from stores and warehouse clubs.
624	Alaska has the highest number of pilots per capita of any U.S.
624	Other transport Another Alaskan transportation method is the dogsled.
624	In modern times (that is, any time after the mid-late 1920s), dog mushing is more of a sport than a true means of transportation.
624	Various races are held around the state, but the best known is the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, a 1150-mile (1850 km) trail from Anchorage to Nome (although the distance varies from year to year, the official distance is set at 1049 mi).
624	The race commemorates the famous 1925 serum run to Nome in which mushers and dogs like Togo and Balto took much-needed medicine to the diphtheria-stricken community of Nome when all other means of transportation had failed.
624	Mushers from all over the world come to Anchorage each March to compete for cash, prizes, and prestige.
624	The "Serum Run" is another sled dog race that more accurately follows the route of the famous 1925 relay, leaving from the community of Nenana (southwest of Fairbanks) to Nome.
624	In areas not served by road or rail, primary transportation in summer is by all-terrain vehicle and in winter by snowmobile or "snow machine," as it is commonly referred to in Alaska.
624	Data transport Alaska's internet and other data transport systems are provided largely through the two major telecommunications companies: GCI and Alaska Communications.
624	GCI owns and operates what it calls the Alaska United Fiber Optic system and as of late 2011 Alaska Communications advertised that it has "two fiber optic paths to the lower 48 and two more across Alaska.
624	In January 2011, it was reported that a $1 billion project to run connect Asia and rural Alaska was being planned, aided in part by $350 million in stimulus from the federal government.
624	Law and government State government Like all other U.S.
624	Alaska is governed as a republic, with three branches of government: an executive branch consisting of the Governor of Alaska and the other independently elected constitutional officers; a legislative branch consisting of the Alaska House of Representatives and Alaska Senate; and a judicial branch consisting of the Alaska Supreme Court and lower courts.
624	The state of Alaska employs approximately 15,000 employees statewide.
624	The Alaska Legislature consists of a 40-member House of Representatives and a 20-member Senate.
624	Senators serve four-year terms and House members two.
624	The Governor of Alaska serves four-year terms.
624	The lieutenant governor runs separately from the governor in the primaries, but during the general election, the nominee for governor and nominee for lieutenant governor run together on the same ticket.
624	Alaska's court system has four levels: the Alaska Supreme Court, the court of appeals, the superior courts and the district courts.
624	The superior and district courts are trial courts.
624	Superior courts are courts of general jurisdiction, while district courts only hear certain types of cases, including misdemeanor crimial jurisdinal cases and civil cases valued up to $100,000.
624	The Supreme Court and the Court Of Appeals are appellate courts.
624	The Court Of Appeals is required to hear appeals from certain lower-court decisions, including those regarding criminal prosecutions, juvenile delinquency, and habeas corpus.
624	The Supreme Court hears civil appeals and may in its discretion hear criminal appeals.
624	State politics Although Alaska entered the union as a Democratic state, since the early 1970s Alaska has been characterized as a Republican-leaning state.
624	Local political communities have often worked on issues related to land use development, fishing, tourism, and individual rights.
624	Alaska Natives, while organized in and around their communities, have been active within the Native corporations.
624	These have been given ownership over large tracts of land, which require stewardship.
624	Alaska was formerly the only state in which possession of one ounce or less of marijuana in one's home was completely legal under state law, though the federal law remains in force.
624	The state has an independence movement favoring a vote on secession from the United States, with the Alaskan Independence Party.
624	Six Republicans and four Democrats have served as governor of Alaska.
624	In addition, Republican Governor Wally Hickel was elected to the office for a second term in 1990 after leaving the Republican party and briefly joining the Alaskan Independence Party ticket just long enough to be reelected.
624	He subsequently officially rejoined the Republican party in 1994.
624	Taxes To finance state government operations, Alaska depends primarily on petroleum revenues and federal subsidies.
624	This allows it to have the lowest individual tax burden in the United States, and be one of only five states with no state sales tax, one of seven states that do not levy an individual income tax, and one of two states that has neither.
624	The Department of Revenue Tax Division  reports regularly on the state's revenue sources.
624	The Department also issues an annual summary of its operations, including new state laws that directly affect the tax division.
624	While Alaska has no state sales tax, 89 municipalities collect a local sales tax, from 1–7.5%, typically 3–5%.
624	Other local taxes levied include raw fish taxes, hotel, motel, and bed-and-breakfast 'bed' taxes, severance taxes, liquor and tobacco taxes, gaming (pull tabs) taxes, tire taxes and fuel transfer taxes.
624	A part of the revenue collected from certain state taxes and license fees (such as petroleum, aviation motor fuel, telephone cooperative) is shared with municipalities in Alaska.
624	Fairbanks has one of the highest property taxes in the state as no sales or income taxes are assessed in the Fairbanks North Star Borough (FNSB).
624	A sales tax for the FNSB has been voted on many times, but has yet to be approved, leading law makers to increase taxes dramatically on other goods such as liquor and tobacco.
624	In 2008 the Tax Foundation ranked Alaska as having the 4th most "business friendly" tax policy.
624	More "friendly" states were Wyoming, Nevada, and South Dakota.
624	Federal politics In presidential elections, the state's electoral college votes have been won by the Republican nominee in every election since statehood, except for 1964.
624	No state has voted for a Democratic presidential candidate fewer times.
624	Alaska supported Democratic nominee Lyndon B.
624	Johnson in the landslide year of 1964, and the 1960 and 1968 elections were close.
624	Since 1972, however, Republicans have carried the state by large margins.
624	In 2008, Republican John McCain defeated Democrat Barack Obama in Alaska, 59.49% to 37.83%.
624	McCain's running mate was Sarah Palin, the state's governor and the first Alaskan on a major party ticket.
624	The Alaska Bush, central Juneau, midtown and downtown Anchorage, and the areas surrounding the University of Alaska Fairbanks campus and Ester have been strongholds of the Democratic Party.
624	The Matanuska-Susitna Borough, the majority of Fairbanks (including North Pole and the military base), and South Anchorage typically have the strongest Republican showing.
624	As of 2004, well over half of all registered voters have chosen "Non-Partisan" or "Undeclared" as their affiliation, despite recent attempts to close primaries.
624	Because of its population relative to other U.S.
624	Alaska has only one member in the U.S.
624	House of Representatives.
624	This seat is currently being held by Republican Don Young, who was re-elected to his 21st consecutive term in 2012.
624	Alaska's At-large congressional district is currently the world's second-largest legislative constituency by area, behind only the Canadian territory of Nunavut.
624	In 2008, Governor Sarah Palin became the first Republican woman to run on a national ticket when she became John McCain's Vice Presidential running mate.
624	She continued to be a prominent national figure even after resigning from the governor's job in July 2009.
624	Alaska's United States Senators belong to Class 2 and Class 3.
624	In 2008, Democrat Mark Begich, mayor of Anchorage, defeated long-time Republican senator Ted Stevens.
624	Stevens had been convicted on seven felony counts of failing to report gifts on Senate financial discloser forms one week before the election.
624	The conviction was set aside in April 2009 after evidence of prosecutorial misconduct emerged.
624	Republican Frank Murkowski held the state's other senatorial position.
624	After being elected governor in 2002, he resigned from the Senate and appointed his daughter, State Representative Lisa Murkowski as his successor.
624	She won a full six-year term in 2004 and 2010.
624	Cities, towns and boroughs Alaska is not divided into counties, as most of the other U.S.
624	Many of the more densely populated parts of the state are part of Alaska's 16 boroughs, which function somewhat similarly to counties in other states.
624	However, unlike county-equivalents in the other 49 states, the boroughs do not cover the entire land area of the state.
624	The area not part of any borough is referred to as the Unorganized Borough.
624	The Unorganized Borough has no government of its own, but the U.S.
624	Census Bureau in cooperation with the state divided the Unorganized Borough into 11 census areas solely for the purposes of statistical analysis and presentation.
624	A recording district is a mechanism for administration of the public record in Alaska.
624	The state is divided into 34 recording districts which are centrally administered under a State Recorder.
624	All recording districts use the same acceptance criteria, fee schedule, etc., for accepting documents into the public record.
624	Whereas many U.S.
624	Alaska uses only two tiers—state/borough.
624	Owing to the low population density, most of the land is located in the Unorganized Borough which, as the name implies, has no intermediate borough government of its own, but is administered directly by the state government.
624	Currently (2000 census) 57.71% of Alaska's area has this status, with 13.05% of the population.
624	For statistical purposes the United States Census Bureau divides this territory into census areas.
624	Anchorage merged the city government with the Greater Anchorage Area Borough in 1975 to form the Municipality of Anchorage, containing the city proper and the communities of Eagle River, Chugiak, Peters Creek, Girdwood, Bird, and Indian.
624	Fairbanks has a separate borough (the Fairbanks North Star Borough) and municipality (the City of Fairbanks).
624	The state's most populous city is Anchorage, home to 278,700 people in 2006, 225,744 of whom live in the urbanized area.
624	The richest location in Alaska by per capita income is Halibut Cove ($89,895).
624	Yakutat City, Sitka, Juneau, and Anchorage are the four largest cities in the U.S.
624	Cities and census-designated places (by population) Alaska has a total of 355 cities and census-designated places.
624	The majority of these are located in the rural expanse of Alaska known as "The Bush" and are unccated in the ronnected to the contiguous North American road network.
624	The 100 largest cities and census-designated places in Alaska are listed below, in population order: : Key:  ---- Out of Alaska's 2010 Census population figure of 710,231, 20,429 people, or 2.88% of the population, do not live in an incorporated city or census-designated place.
624	Approximately 3/4 of that figure are people who live in urban and suburban neighborhoods on the outskirts of the city limits of Ketchikan, Kodiak, Palmer and Wasilla, in areas where census-designated places have not been created by the Census Bureau.
624	The remainder are scattered throughout Alaska, both within organized boroughs and in the Unorganized Borough.
624	Education The Alaska Department of Education and Early Development administers many school districts in Alaska.
624	In addition, the state operates a boarding school, Mt.
624	Edgecumbe High School in Sitka; and provides partial funding for other boarding schools, including Nenana Student Living Center in Nenana and The Galena Interior Learning Academy in Galena.
624	There are more than a dozen colleges and universities in Alaska.
624	Accredited universities in Alaska include the University of Alaska Anchorage, University of Alaska Fairbanks, University of Alaska Southeast, and Alaska Pacific University.
624	Alaska is the only state that has no institutions that are part of the NCAA Division I program.
624	The Alaska Department of Labor and Workforce Development operates AVTEC, Alaska's Institute of Technology.
624	Campuses in Seward and Anchorage offer 1 week to 11 month training programs in areas as diverse as Information Technology, Welding, Nursing, and Mechanics.
624	Alaska has had a problem with a "brain drain".
624	Many of its young people, including most of the highest academic achievers, leave the state after high school graduation and do not return.
624	The University of Alaska has attempted to combat this by offering partial four-year scholarships to the top 10% of Alaska high school graduates, via the Alaska Scholars Program.
624	Public health and public safety The Alaska State Troopers are Alaska's statewide police force.
624	They have a long and storied history, but were not an official organization until 1941.
624	Before the force was officially organized, law enforcement in Alaska was handled by various federal agencies.
624	Larger towns usually have their own local police and some villages rely on "Public Safety Officers" who have police training but do not carry firearms.
624	In much of the state, the troopers serve as the only police force available.
624	In addition to enforcing traffic and criminal law, wildlife Troopers enforce hunting and fishing regulations.
624	Due to the varied terrain and wide scope of the Troopers' duties, they employ a wide variety of land, air, and water patrol vehicles.
624	Many rural communities in Alaska are considered "dry," having outlawed the importation of alcoholic beverages.
624	Suicide rates for rural residents are higher than urban.
624	Domestic abuse and other violent crimes are also at high levels in the state; this is in part linked to alcohol abuse.
624	Alaska also has the highest rate of sexual assault in the nation.
624	The average age of sexually assaulted victims is 16 years old.
624	In four out of five cases, the suspects were relatives, friends or acquaintances.
624	Culture Some of Alaska's popular annual events are the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race that starts in Anchorage and ends in Nome, World Ice Art Championships in Fairbanks, the Alaska Hummingbird Festival in Ketchikan, the Sitka Whale Fest, and the Stikine River Garnet Fest in Wrangell.
624	The Stikine River features the largest springtime concentration of American Bald Eagles in the world.
624	The Alaska Native Heritage Center celebrates the rich heritage of Alaska's 11 cultural groups.
624	Their purpose is to enhance self-esteem among Native people and to encourage cross-cultural exchanges among all people.
624	The Alaska Native Arts Foundation promotes and markets Native art from all regions and cultures in the State, both on the internet; at its gallery in Anchorage, 500 West Sixth Avenue, and at the [http://www.alaskahouseny.org/index.aspx?ModuleID=1  Alaska House New York], 109 Mercer Street in SoHo.
624	Music Influences on music in Alaska include the traditional music of Alaska Natives as well as folk music brought by later immigrants from Russia and Europe.
624	Prominent musicians from Alaska include singer Jewel, traditional Aleut flautist Mary Youngblood, folk singer-songwriter Libby Roderick, Christian music singer/songwriter Lincoln Brewster, metal/post hardcore band 36 Crazyfists and the groups Pamyua and Portugal.
624	The Man.
624	There are many established music festivals in Alaska, including the Alaska Folk Festival, the Fairbanks Summer Arts Festival, the [http://anchoragefolkfestival.org/ Anchorage Folk Festival], the Athabascan Old-Time Fiddling Festival, the Sitka Jazz Festival, and the Sitka Summer Music Festival.
624	The most prominent orchestra in Alaska is the Anchorage Symphony Orchestra, though the Fairbanks Symphony Orchestra and Juneau Symphony are also notable.
624	The Anchorage Opera is currently the state's only professional opera company, though there are several volunteer and semi-professional organizations in the state as well.
624	The official state song of Alaska is "Alaska's Flag", which was adopted in 1955; it celebrates the flag of Alaska.
624	Alaska in film and on television Alaska's first independent picture all made on place was in the silent years.
624	The Chechahcos was produced by Alaskan businessman Austin E.
624	Lathrop and filmed in and around Anchorage.
624	It was released in 1924 by the Alaska Moving Picture Corporation and was the only film the company made.
624	One of the most prominent movies filmed in Alaska is MGM's Eskimo/Mala The Magnificent, starring Alaska Native Ray Mala.
624	In 1932 an expedition set out from MGM's studios in Hollywood to Alaska to film what was then billed as "The Biggest Picture Ever Made."
624	Upon arriving in Alaska, they set up "Camp Hollywood" in Northwest Alaska, where they lived during the duration of the filming.
624	Louis B.
624	Mayer spared no expense in spite of the remote location, going so far as to hire the chef from the Hotel Roosevelt in Hollywood to prepare meals.
624	When Eskimo premiered at the Astor Theatre in New York City, the studio received the largest amount of feedback in its history to that point.
624	Eskimo was critically acclaimed and released worldwide; as a result, Mala became an international movie star.
624	Eskimo won the first Oscar for Best Film Editing at the Academy Awards, and was also responsible for showcasing and preserving aspects of Inupiat culture on film.
624	The 1983 Disney movie Never Cry Wolf was at least partially shot in Alaska.
624	The 1991 film White Fang, starring Ethan Hawke, was filmed in and around Haines, Alaska.
624	Steven Seagal's 1994 On Deadly Ground, starring Michael Caine, was filmed in part at the Worthington Glacier near Valdez.
624	The 1999 John Sayles film Limbo, starring David Strathairn, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, and Kris Kristofferson, was filmed in Juneau.
624	The psychological thriller Insomnia, starring Al Pacino and Robin Williams, was shot in Canada, but was set in Alaska.
624	The 2007 film directed by Sean Penn, Into The Wild, was partially filmed and set in Alaska.
624	The film, which is based on the novel of the same name, follows the adventures of Christopher McCandless, who died in a remote abandoned bus along the Stampede Trail west of Healy in 1992.
624	Many films and television shows set in Alaska are not filmed there; for example, Northern Exposure, set in the fictional town of Cicely, Alaska, was actually filmed in Roslyn, Washington.
624	The 2007 horror feature 30 Days of Night is set in Barrow, but was filmed in New Zealand.
624	Many reality television shows are filmed in Alaska.
624	In 2011 the Anchorage Daily News found ten set in the state.
624	State symbols * State Motto: North to the Future * Nicknames: "The Last Frontier" or "Land of the Midnight Sun" or "Seward's Icebox" * State bird: Willow Ptarmigan, adopted by the Territorial Legislature in 1955.
624	It is a small (15–17 inches) Arctic grouse that lives among willows and on open tundra and muskeg.
624	Plumage is brown in summer, changing to white in winter.
624	The Willow Ptarmigan is common in much of Alaska.
624	State fish: King Salmon, adopted 1962.
624	State flower: wild/native Forget-me-not, adopted by the Territorial Legislature in 1917.
624	It is a perennial that is found throughout Alaska, from Hyder to the Arctic Coast, and west to the Aleutians.
624	State fossil: Woolly Mammoth, adopted 1986.
624	State gem: Jade, adopted 1968.
624	State insect: Four-spot skimmer dragonfly, adopted 1995.
624	State land mammal: Moose, adopted 1998.
624	State marine mammal: Bowhead Whale, adopted 1983.
624	State mineral: Gold, adopted 1968.
624	State song: "Alaska's Flag" * State sport: Dog Mushing, adopted 1972.
624	State tree: Sitka Spruce, adopted 1962.
624	State dog:  Alaskan Malamute, adopted 2010.
624	State soil: Tanana, adopted unknown.
624	Alaska Heritage Resources Survey The Alaska Heritage Resources Survey (AHRS) is a restricted inventory of all reported historic and prehistoric sites within the state of Alaska and is maintained by the Office of History and Archaeology.
624	The survey's inventory of cultural resources includes objects, structures, buildings, sites, districts, and travel ways, with a general provision that they are over 50 years old.
624	As of January 31, 2012 over 35,000 sites have been reported.
627	Agriculture, also called farming or husbandry, is the cultivation of animals, plants, fungi, and other life forms for food, fiber, biofuel and other products used to sustain human life.
627	Agriculture was the key development in the rise of sedentary human civilization, whereby farming of domesticated species created food surpluses that nurtured the development of civilization.
627	The study of agriculture is known as agricultural science.
627	Agriculture generally speaking refers to human activities, although it is also observed in certain species of ant and termite.
627	The word agriculture is the English adaptation of Latin agricultūra, from ager, ref> The word agricultu"a field", and cultūra, "cultivation" in the strict sense of "tillage of the soil".
627	Thus, a literal reading of the word yields "tillage of fields".
627	The history of agriculture dates back thousands of years, and its development has been driven and defined by greatly different climates, cultures, and technologies.
627	However, all farming generally relies on techniques to expand and maintain the lands that are suitable for raising domesticated species.
627	For plants, this usually requires some form of irrigation, although there are methods of dryland farming; pastoral herding on rangeland is still the most common means of raising livestock.
627	In the developed world, industrial agriculture based on large-scale monoculture has become the dominant system of modern farming, although there is growing support for sustainable agriculture (e.g.
627	Until the Industrial Revolution, the vast majority of the human population labored in agriculture.
627	Pre-industrial agriculture was typically subsistence agriculture in which farmers raised most of their crops for their own consumption instead of for trade.
627	A remarkable shift in agricultural practices has occurred over the past century in response to new technologies, and the development of world markets.
627	This also led to technological improvements in agricultural techniques, such as the Haber-Bosch method for synthesizing ammonium nitrate which made the traditional practice of recycling nutrients with crop rotation and animal manure less necessary.
627	Modern agronomy, plant breeding, and agrochemicals such as pesticides and fertilizers, and technological improvements have sharply increased yields from cultivation, but at the same time have caused widespread ecological damage and negative human health effects.
627	Selective breeding and modern practices in animal husbandry such as intensive pig farming have similarly increased the output of meat, but have raised concerns about animal cruelty and the health effects of the antibiotics, growth hormones, and other chemicals commonly used in industrial meat production.
627	The major agricultural products can be broadly grouped into foods, fibers, fuels, and raw materials.
627	In the 21st century, plants have been used to grow biofuels, biopharmaceuticals, bioplastics, and pharmaceuticals.
627	Specific foods include cereals, vegetables, fruits, and meat.
627	Fibers include cotton, wool, hemp, silk and flax.
627	Raw materials include lumber and bamboo.
627	Other useful materials are produced by plants, such as resins.
627	Biofuels include methane from biomass, ethanol, and biodiesel.
627	Cut flowers, nursery plants, tropical fish and birds for the pet trade are some of the ornamental products.
627	Regarding food production, the World Bank targets agricultural food production and water management as an increasingly global issue that is fostering an important and growing debate.
627	In 2007, one third of the world's workers were employed in agriculture.
627	The services sector has overtaken agriculture as the economic sector employing the most people worldwide.
627	Despite the size of its workforce, agricultural production accounts for less than five percent of the gross world product (an aggregate of all gross domestic products).
627	History  Agricultural practices such as irrigation, crop rotation, fertilizers, pesticides and animals were developed long ago, but have made great strides in the past century.
627	The history of agriculture has played a major role in human history, as agricultural progress has been a crucial factor in worldwide socio-economic change.
627	Division of labor in agricultural societies made commonplace specializations rarely seen in hunter-gatherer cultures.
627	So, too, are arts such as epic literature and monumental architecture, as well as codified legal systems.
627	When farmers became capable of producing food beyond the needs of their own families, others in their society were freed to devote themselves to projects other than food acquisition.
627	Historians and anthropologists have long argued that the development of agriculture made civilization possible.
627	The total world population probably never exceeded 15 million inhabitants before the development of agriculture.
627	Prehistoric origins  Forest gardening, a plant-based food production system, is thought to be the world's oldest agroecosystem.
627	Forest gardens originated in prehistoric times along jungle-clad river banks and in the wet foothills of monsoon regions.
627	In the gradual process of a family improving their immediate environment, useful tree and vine species were identified, protected and improved whilst undesirable species were eliminated.
627	Eventually superior foreign species were selected and incorporated into the family's garden.
627	Ancient history  The|isbn=978-9 Fertile Crescent of Western Asia, Egypt, and India were sites of the earliest planned sowing and harvesting of plants that had previously been gathered in the wild.
627	Independent development of agriculture occurred in northern and southern China, Africa's Sahel, New Guinea and several regions of America.
627	The eight so-called Neolithic founder crops of agriculture appear: first emmer wheat and einkorn wheat, then hulled barley, peas, lentils, bitter vetch, chick peas and flax.
627	By 7000 BC, small-scale agriculture reached Egypt.
627	From at least 7000 BC the Indian subcontinent saw farming of wheat and barley, as attested by archaeological excavation at Mehrgarh in Balochistan in what is present day Pakistan.
627	By 6000 BC, mid-scale farming was entrenched on the banks of the Nile.
627	This, as irrigation had not yet matured sufficiently.
627	About this time, agriculture was developed independently in the Far East, with rice, rather than wheat, as the primary crop.
627	Chinese and Indonesian farmers went on to domesticate taro and beans including mung, soy and azuki.
627	To complement these new sources of carbohydrates, highly organized net fishing of rivers, lakes and ocean shores in these areas brought in great volumes of essential protein.
627	Collectively, these new methods of farming and fishing inaugurated a human population boom that dwarfed all previous expansions and continues today.
627	By 5000 BC, the Sumerians had developed core agricultural techniques including large-scale intensive cultivation of land, monocropping, organized irrigation, and the use of a specialized labor force.
627	Domestication of wild aurochs and mouflon into cattle and sheep, respectively, ushered in the large-scale use of animals for food/fiber and as beasts of burden.
627	The shepherd joined the farmer as an essential provider for sedentary and seminomadic societies.
627	Maize, manioc, and arrowroot were first domesticated in America as far back as 5200 BC.
627	The potato, tomato, pepper, squash, several varieties of bean, tobacco, and several other plants were also developed in America, as was extensive terracing of steep hillsides in much of Andean South America.
627	The Greeks and Romans built on techniques pioneered by the Sumerians, but made few fundamentally new advances.
627	Southern Greeks struggled with very poor soils, yet managed to become a dominant society for years.
627	The Romans were noted for an emphasis on the cultivation of crops for trade.
627	In the same region, a parallel agricultural revolution occurred, resulting in some of the most important crops grown today.
627	In Mesoamerica wild teosinte was transformed through human selection into the ancestor of modern maize, more than 6000 years ago.
627	It gradually spread across North America and was the major crop of Native Americans at the time of European exploration.
627	Other Mesoamerican crops include hundreds of varieties of squash and beans.
627	Cocoa was also a major crop domesticated in Mexico and Central America.
627	The turkey, one of the most important meat birds, was probably domesticated in Mexico.
627	In the Andes region of South America the major domesticated crop was potatoes, domesticated perhaps 5000 years ago.
627	Large varieties of beans were domesticated, in South America, as well as animals, including llamas, alpacas, and guinea pigs.
627	Coca, still a major crop, was also domesticated in the Andes.
627	A minor center of domestication, the indigenous people of the Eastern U.S.
627	Sunflowers, tobacco, varieties of squash and Chenopodium, as well as crops no longer grown, including marshelder and little barley were domesticated.
627	Other wild foods may have undergone some selective cultivation, including wild rice and maple sugar.
627	The most common varieties of strawberry were domesticated from Eastern North America.
627	By 3500 BC, the simplest form of the plough was developed, called the ard.
627	Before this period, simple digging sticks or hoes were used.
627	These tools would have also been easier to transport, which was a benefit as people only stayed until the soil's nutrients were depleted.
627	However, through excavations in Mexico it has been found that the continuous cultivating of smaller pieces of land would also have been a sustaining practice.
627	Additional research in central Europe later revealed that agriculture was indeed practiced at this method.
627	For this method, ards were thus much more efficient than digging sticks.
627	Middle Ages  The Middle Ages saw significant improvements in the agricultural techniques and technology.
627	There was a steady clearing of woodlands and draining of wetlands for the increase of cropland throughout the period until about the year 1300.
627	Tools such as axes, adzes, and bill-hooks were improved, but most significant was the gradual evolution of the scratch plough from the classical Mediterranean world into the mouldboard plough capable of turning over the heavy soils of northern Europe.
627	The period saw a general move from a two field crop rotation to a three field crop rotation in which one field of three was left fallow every year.
627	Also, there was a general change from small patchworks of fields to one large open field divided into strips owned by various members of a community.
627	The use of watermills was common in the Middle Ages.
627	There was tremendous increase in windmills from the 12th to the 13th century; some tens of thousands were built.
627	Crops were wheat, rye, barley, and oats.
627	Peas, beans, and vetches became common from the 13th century onward as a fodder crop for animals and also for their nitrogen-fixation fertilizing properties.
627	Crop yields peaked in the 13th century, and according to Bruce Campbell and Mark Overton stayed more or less steady until the 18th century.
627	Though the limitations of Medieval farming were once thought to have provided a ceiling for the population growth in the Middle Ages, recent studies by Campbell and David Stone have shown that the technology of Medieval agriculture was always sufficient for the needs of the people under normal circumstances, and that it was only during exceptionally harsh times, such as the terrible weather of 1315–17, that the needs of the population could not be met.
627	Modern developments  After 1492, a global exchange of previously local crops and livestock breeds occurred.
627	Key crops involved in this exchange included the tomato, maize, potato, manioc, cocoa bean and tobacco going from the New World to the Old, and several varieties of wheat, spices, coffee, and sugar cane going from the Old World to the New.
627	The most important animal exportation from the Old World to the New were those of the horse and dog (dogs were already present in the pre-Columbian Americas but not in the numbers and breeds suited to farm work).
627	Although not usually food animals, the horse (including donkeys and ponies) and dog quickly filled essential production roles on western-hemisphere farms.
627	The potato became an important staple crop in northern Europe.
627	Since being introduced by Portuguese in the 16th century, maize and manioc have replaced traditional African crops as the continent's most important staple food crops.
627	By the early 19th century, agricultural techniques, implements, seed stocks and cultivar had so improved that yield per land unit was many times that seen in the Middle Ages.
627	Although there is a vast and interesting history of crop cultivation before the dawn of the 20th century, there is little question that the work of Charles Darwin and Gregor Mendel created the scientific foundation for plant breeding that led to its explosive impact over the past 150 years.
627	With the rapid rise of mechanization in the late 19th century and the 20th century, particularly in the form of the tractor, farming tasks could be done with a speed and on a scale previously impossible.
627	These advances have led to efficiencies enabling certain modern farms in the United States, Argentina, Israel, the United Kingdom, Germany, and a few other nations to output volumes of high-quality produce per land unit at what may be the practical limit.
627	The Haber-Bosch method for synthesizing ammonium nitrate represented a major breakthrough and allowed crop yields to overcome previous constraints.
627	In the past century agriculture has been characterized by enhanced productivity, the substitution of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides for labor, water pollution, and farm subsidies.
627	In recent years there has been a backlash against the external environmental effects of conventional agriculture, resulting in the organic movement.
627	The cereals rice, corn, and wheat provide 60% of human food supply.
627	Between 1700 and 1980, "the total area of cultivated land worldwide increased 466%" and yields increased dramatically, particularly because of selectively bred high-yielding varieties, fertilizers, pesticides, irrigation, and machinery.
627	For example, irrigation increased corn yields in eastern Colorado by 400 to 500% from 1940 to 1997.
627	However, concerns have been raised over the sustainability of intensive agriculture.
627	Intensive agriculture has become associated with decreased soil quality in India and Asia, and there has been increased concern over the effects of fertilizers and pesticides on the environment, particularly as population increases and food demand expands.
627	The monocultures typically used in intensive agriculture increase the number of pests, which are controlled through pesticides.
627	Integrated pest management (IPM), which "has been promoted for decades and has had some notable successes" has not significantly affected the use of pesticides because policies encourage the use of pesticides and IPM is knowledge-intensive.
627	Agricultural exploration expeditions, since the late 19th century, have been mounted to find new species and new agricultural practices in different areas of the world.
627	Two early examples of expeditions include Frank N.
627	Meyer's fruit- and nut-collecting trip to China and Japan from 1916 to 1918 and the Dorsett-Morse Oriental Agricultural Exploration Expedition to China, Japan, and Korea from 1929–1931 to collect soybean germplasm to support the rise in soybean agriculture in the United States.
627	Green Revolution  The Green Revolution refers to a series of research, development, and technology transfer initiatives, occurring between the 1940s and the late 1970s, that increased agriculture production around the world, beginning most markedly in the late 1960s.
627	The initiatives, led by Norman Borlaug, the "Father of the Green Revolution" credited with saving over a billion people from starvation, involved the development of high-yielding varieties of cereal grains, expansion of irrigation infrastructure, modernization of management techniques, distribution of hybridized seeds, synthetic fertilizers, and pesticides to farmers.
627	Synthetic nitrogen, along with mined rock phosphate, pesticides and mechanization, have greatly increased crop yields in the early 20th century.
627	Increased supply of grains has led to cheaper livestock as well.
627	Further, global yield increases were experienced later in the 20th century when high-yield varieties of common staple grains such as rice, wheat, and corn (maize) were introduced as a part of the Green Revolution.
627	The Green Revolution exported the technologies (including pesticides and synthetic nitrogen) of the developed world to the developing world.
627	Thomas Malthus famously predicted that the Earth would not be able to support its growing population, but technologies such as the Green Revolution have allowed the world to produce a surplus of food.
627	Although the "Green Revolution" significantly increased rice yields in Asia, yield increases have not occurred in the past 15–20 years.
627	The genetic "yield potential" has increased for wheat, but the yield potential for rice has not increased since 1966, and the yield potential for maize has "barely increased in 35 years".
627	It takes a decade or two for herbicide-resistant weeds to emerge, and insects become resistant to insecticides within about a decade.
627	Crop rotation helps to prevent resistances.
627	Contemporary agriculture  In the past century agriculture has been characterized by enhanced productivity, the use of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides, selective breeding, mechanization, water contamination, and farm subsidies.
627	Proponents of organic farming such as Sir Albert Howard argued in the early 20th century that the overuse of pesticides and synthetic fertilizers damages the long-term fertility of the soil.
627	While this feeling lay dormant for decades, as environmental awareness has increased in the 21st century there has been a movement towards sustainable agriculture by some farmers, consumers, and policymakers.
627	In recent years there has been a backlash against perceived external environmental effects of mainstream agriculture, particularly regarding water pollution, resulting in the organic movement.
627	One of the major forces behind this movement has been the European Union, which first certified organic food in 1991 and began reform of its Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) in 2005 to phase out commodity-linked farm subsidies, also known as decoupling.
627	The growth of organic farming has renewed research in alternative technologies such as integrated pest management and selective breeding.
627	Recent mainstream technological developments include genetically modified food.
627	In late 2007, several factors pushed up the price of grains consumed by humans as well as used to feed poultry and dairy cows and other cattle, causing higher prices of wheat (up 58%), soybean (up 32%), and maize (up 11%) over the year.
627	Food riots took place in several countries across the world.
627	Contributing factors included drought in Australia and elsewhere, increasing demand for grain-fed animal products from the growing middle classes of countries such as China and India, diversion of foodgrain to biofuel production and trade restrictions imposed by several countries.
627	An epidemic of stem rust on wheat caused by race Ug99 is currently spreading across Africa and into Asia and is causing major concern.
627	Approximately 40% of the world's agricultural land is seriously degraded.
627	In Africa, if current trends of soil degradation continue, the continent might be able to feed just 25% of its population by 2025, according to UNU's Ghana-based Institute for Natural Resources in Africa.
627	In 2009, the agricultural output of China was the largest in the world, followed by the European Union, India and the United States, according to the International Monetary Fund (see below).
627	Economists measure the total factor productivity of agriculture and by this measure agriculture in the United States is roughly 2.6 times more productive than it was in 1948.
