627	Six countries – the US, Canada, France, Australia, Argentina and Thailand – supply 90% of grain exports.
627	Water deficits, which are already spurring heavy grain imports in numerous middle-sized countries, including Algeria, Iran, Egypt, and Mexico, may soon do the same in larger countries, such as China or India.
627	Many governments have subsidized agriculture for a variety of political and economic reasons.
627	These agricultural subsidies are often linked to the production of certain commodities such as wheat, corn (maize), rice, soybeans, and milk.
627	The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) leads international efforts to defeat hunger and provides a neutral forum where nations meet as equals to negotiate agreements and debate food policy and the regulation of agriculture.
627	According to Dr.
627	Samuel Jutzi, director of FAO's animal production and health division, lobbying by "powerful" big food corporations has stopped reforms that would improve human health and the environment.
627	The "real, true issues are not being addressed by the political process because of the influence of lobbyists, of the true powerful entities," he said, speaking at the Compassion in World Farming annual forum.
627	For example, recent proposals for a voluntary code of conduct for the livestock industry that would have provided incentives for improving standards for health, and environmental regulations, such as the number of animals an area of land can support without long-term damage, were successfully defeated due to large food company pressure.
627	Agricultural safety  Agriculture remains a hazardous industry, and farmers worldwide remain at high risk of work-related injuries, lung disease, noise-induced hearing loss, skin diseases, as well as certain cancers related to chemical use and prolonged sun exposure.
627	On industrialized farms, injuries frequently involve the use of agricultural machinery.
627	The most common cause of fatal agricultural injuries in the United States is tractor rollovers, which can be prevented by the use of roll over protection structures which limit the risk of injury in case a tractor rolls over.
627	Pesticides and other chemicals used in farming can also be hazardous to worker health, and workers exposed to pesticides may experience illnesses or birth defects.
627	As an industry in which families commonly share in work and live on the farm itself, entire families can be at risk for injuries, illness, and death.
627	Agriculture is an especially dangerous industry for younger workers, accounting for nearly half of work-related fatalities in the United States between 1992 and 2000.
627	Common causes of fatal injuries among young farm worker include drowning, machinery and motor vehicle-related accidents.
627	To reduce the extent of farm-related youth injuries, the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) and the Marshfield Clinic Research Foundation have issued a set of guidelines known as [http://www.nagcat.org/nagcat/?page=guideline_search the North American Guidelines for Children's Agricultural Tasks (NAGCAT)] based on child development principles that matched children's abilities with the requirements of specific farm work.
627	These guidelines have proven effective at reducing work-related injury rates among youth, based on the results of a randomized control trial conducted by NIOSH.
627	Agricultural production systems  Crop cultivations systems  Cropping systems vary among farms depending on the available resources and constraints; geography and climate of the farm; government policy; economic, social and political pressures; and the philosophy and culture of the farmer.
627	Shifting cultivation (or slash and burn) is a system in which forests are burnt, releasing nutrients to support cultivation of annual and then perennial crops for a peing nutrients riod of several years.
627	Then the plot is left fallow to regrow forest, and the farmer moves to a new plot, returning after many more years (10–20).
627	This fallow period is shortened if population density grows, requiring the input of nutrients (fertilizer or manure) and some manual pest control.
627	Annual cultivation is the next phase of intensity in which there is no fallow period.
627	This requires even greater nutrient and pest control inputs.
627	Further industrialization lead to the use of monocultures, when one cultivar is planted on a large acreage.
627	Because of the low biodiversity, nutrient use is uniform and pests tend to build up, necessitating the greater use of pesticides and fertilizers.
627	Multiple cropping, in which several crops are grown sequentially in one year, and intercropping, when several crops are grown at the same time are other kinds of annual cropping systems known as polycultures.
627	In subtropical and arid environments, the timing and extent of agriculture may be limited by rainfall, either not allowing multiple annual crops in a year, or requiring irrigation.
627	In all of these environments perennial crops are grown (coffee, chocolate) and systems are practiced such as agroforestry.
627	In temperate environments, where ecosystems were predominantly grassland or prairie, highly productive annual cropping is the dominant farming system.
627	The last century has seen the intensification, concentration and specialization of agriculture, relying upon new technologies of agricultural chemicals (fertilizers and pesticides), mechanization, and plant breeding (hybrids and GMO's).
627	In the past few decades, a move towards sustainability in agriculture has also developed, integrating ideas of socio-economic justice and conservation of resources and the environment within a farming system.
627	This has led to the development of many responses to the conventional agriculture approach, including organic agriculture, urban agriculture, community supported agriculture, ecological or biological agriculture, integrated farming and holistic management, as well as an increased trend towards agricultural diversification.
627	Crop statistics  Important categories of crops include grains and pseudograins, pulses (legumes), forage, and fruits and vegetables.
627	Specific crops are cultivated in distinct growing regions throughout the world.
627	In millions of metric tons, based on FAO estimate.
627	Livestock production systems  Animals, including horses, mules, oxen, camels, llamas, alpacas, and dogs, are often used to help cultivate fields, harvest crops, wrangle other animals, and transport farm products to buyers.
627	Animal husbandry not only refers to the breeding and raising of animals for meat or to harvest animal products (like milk, eggs, or wool) on a continual basis, but also to the breeding and care of species for work and companionship.
627	Livestock production systems can be defined based on feed source, as grassland – based, mixed, and landless.
627	Grassland based livestock production relies upon plant material such as shrubland, rangeland, and pastures for feeding ruminant animals.
627	Outside nutrient inputs may be used, however manure is returned directly to the grassland as a major nutrient source.
627	This system is particularly important in areas where crop production is not feasible because of climate or soil, representing 30–40 million pastoralists.
627	Mixed production systems use grassland, fodder crops and grain feed crops as feed for ruminant and monogastic (one stomach; mainly chickens and pigs) livestock.
627	Manure is typically recycled in mixed systems as a fertilizer for crops.
627	Approximately 68% of all agricultural land is permanent pastures used in the production of livestock.
627	Landless systems rely upon feed from outside the farm, representing the de-linking of crop and livestock production found more prevalently in OECD member countries.
627	In the U.S., 70% of the grain grown is fed to animals on feedlots.
627	Synthetic fertilizers are more heavily relied upon for crop production and manure utilization becomes a challenge as well as a source for pollied upon for croplution.
627	Production practices  Tillage is the practice of plowing soil to prepare for planting or for nutrient incorporation or for pest control.
627	Tillage varies in intensity from conventional to no-till.
627	It may improve productivity by warming the soil, incorporating fertilizer and controlling weeds, but also renders soil more prone to erosion, triggers the decomposition of organic matter releasing CO2, and reduces the abundance and diversity of soil organisms.
627	Pest control includes the management of weeds, insects/mites, and diseases.
627	Chemical (pesticides), biological (biocontrol), mechanical (tillage), and cultural practices are used.
627	Cultural practices include crop rotation, culling, cover crops, intercropping, composting, avoidance, and resistance.
627	Integrated pest management attempts to use all of these methods to keep pest populations below the number which would cause economic loss, and recommends pesticides as a last resort.
627	Nutrient management includes both the source of nutrient inputs for crop and livestock production, and the method of utilization of manure produced by livestock.
627	Nutrient inputs can be chemical inorganic fertilizers, manure, green manure, compost and mined minerals.
627	Crop nutrient use may also be managed using cultural techniques such as crop rotation or a fallow period.
627	Manure is used either by holding livestock where the feed crop is growing, such as in managed intensive rotational grazing, or by spreading either dry or liquid formulations of manure on cropland or pastures.
627	Water management is where rainfall is insufficient or variable, which occurs to some degree in most regions of the world.
627	Some farmers use irrigation to supplement rainfall.
627	In other areas such as the Great Plains in the U.S.
627	Canada, farmers use a fallow year to conserve soil moisture to use for growing a crop in the following year.
627	Agriculture represents 70% of freshwater use worldwide.
627	Processing, distribution, and marketing  In the United States, food costs attributed to processing, distribution, and marketing have risen while the costs attributed to farming have declined.
627	This is related to the greater efficiency of farming, combined with the increased level of value addition (e.g.
627	From 1960 to 1980 the farm share was around 40%, but by 1990 it had declined to 30% and by 1998, 22.2%.
627	Market concentration has increased in the sector as well, with the top 20 food manufacturers accounting for half the food-processing value in 1995, over double that produced in 1954.
627	As of 2000 the top six US supermarket groups had 50% of sales compared to 32% in 1992.
627	Although the total effect of the increased market concentration is likely increased efficiency, the changes redistribute economic surplus from producers (farmers) and consumers, and may have negative implications for rural communities.
627	Crop alteration and biotechnology  Crop alteration has been practiced by humankind for thousands of years, since the beginning of civilization.
627	Altering crops through breeding practices changes the genetic make-up of a plant to develop crops with more beneficial characteristics for humans, for example, larger fruits or seeds, drought-tolerance, or resistance to pests.
627	Significant advances in plant breeding ensued after the work of geneticist Gregor Mendel.
627	His work on dominant and recessive alleles gave plant breeders a better understanding of genetics and brought great insights to the techniques utilized by plant breeders.
627	Crop breeding includes techniques such as plant selection with desirable traits, self-pollination and cross-pollination, and molecular techniques that genetically modify the organism.
627	Domestication of plants has, over the centuries increased yield, improved disease resistance and drought tolerance, eased harvest and improved the taste and nutritional value of crop plants.
627	Careful selection and breeding have had enormous effects on the characteristics of crop plants.
627	Plant selection and breeding in the 1920s and 1930s improved pasture (grasses and clover) in New Zealand.
627	Extensive X-ray and ultraviolet induced mutagenesis efforts (i.e.
627	The Green Revolution popularized the use of conventional hybridization to increase yield many folds by creating "high-yielding varieties".
627	For example, average yields of corn (maize) in the USA have increased from around 2.5 tons per hectare (t/ha) (40 bushels per acre) in 1900 to about 9.4 t/ha (150 bushels per acre) in 2001.
627	Similarly, worldwide average wheat yields have increased from less than 1 t/ha in 1900 to more than 2.5 t/ha in 1990.
627	South American average wheat yields are around 2 t/ha, African under 1 t/ha, Egypt and Arabia up to 3.5 to 4 t/ha with irrigation.
627	In contrast, the average wheat yield in countries such as France is over 8 t/ha.
627	Variations in yields are due mainly to variation in climate, genetics, and the level of intensive farming techniques (use of fertilizers, chemical pest control, growth control to avoid lodging).
627	Genetic engineering  Genetically Modified Organisms (GMO) are organisms whose genetic material has been altered by genetic engineering techniques generally known as recombinant DNA technology.
627	Genetic engineering has expanded the genes available to breeders to utilize in creating desired germlines for new crops.
627	After mechanical tomato-harvesters were developed in the early 1960s, agricultural scientists genetically modified tomatoes to be more resistant to mechanical handling.
627	More recently, genetic engineering is being employed in various parts of the world, to create crops with other beneficial traits.
627	New research on woodland strawberry genome was found to be short and easy to manipulate.
627	Researchers now have tools to improve strawberry flavors and aromas of cultivated strawberries as stated in a publication by Nature Genetics.
627	Herbicide-tolerant GMO crops  Roundup Ready seed has a herbicide resistant gene implanted into its genome that allows the plants to tolerate exposure to glyphosate.
627	Roundup is a trade name for a glyphosate-based product, which is a systemic, nonselective herbicide used to kill weeds.
627	Roundup Ready seeds allow the farmer to grow a crop that can be sprayed with glyphosate to control weeds without harming the resistant crop.
627	Herbicide-tolerant crops are used by farmers worldwide.
627	Today, 92% of soybean acreage in the US is planted with genetically modified herbicide-tolerant plants.
627	With the increasing use of herbicide-tolerant crops, comes an increase in the use of glyphosate-based herbicide sprays.
627	In some areas glyphosate resistant weeds have developed, causing farmers to switch to other herbicides.
627	Some studies also link widespread glyphosate usage to iron deficiencies in some crops, which is both a crop production and a nutritional quality concern, with potential economic and health implications.
627	Insect-resistant GMO crops  Other GMO crops used by growers include insect-resistant crops, which have a gene from the soil bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), which produces a toxin specific to insects.
627	These crops protect plants from damage by insects; one such crop is Starlink.
627	Another is cotton, which accounts for 63% of US cotton acreage.
627	Some believe that similar or better pest-resistance traits can be acquired through traditional breeding practices, and resistance to various pests can be gained through hybridization or cross-pollination with wild species.
627	In some cases, wild species are the primary source of resistance traits; some tomato cultivars that have gained resistance to at least 19 diseases did so through crossing with wild populations of tomatoes.
627	Costs and benefits of GMOs  Genetic engineers may someday develop transgenic plants which would allow for irrigation, drainage, conservation, sanitary engineering, and maintaining or increasing yields while requiring fewer fossil fuel derived inputs than conventional crops.
627	Such developments would be particularly important in areas which are normally arid and rely upon constant irrigation, and on large scale farms.
627	However, genetic engineering of plants has proven to be controversial.
627	Many issues surrounding food security and environmental impacts have risen regarding GMO practices.
627	For example, GMOs are questioned by some ecologists and economists concerned with GMO practices such as terminator seeds, which is a genetic modification that creates sterile seeds.
627	Terminator seeds are currently under strong international opposition and face continual efforts of global bans.
627	Another controversial issue is the patent protection given to companies that develop new types of seed using genetic engineering.
627	Since companies have intellectual ownership of their seeds, they have the power to dictate terms and conditions of their patented product.
627	Currently, ten seed companies control over two-thirds of the global seed sales.
627	Vandana Shiva argues that these companies are guilty of biopiracy by patenting life and exploiting organisms for profit Farmers using patented seed are restricted from saving seed for subsequent plantings, which forces farmers to buy new seed every year.
627	Since seed saving is a traditional practice for many farmers in both developing and developed countries, GMO seeds legally bind farmers to change their seed saving practices to buying new seed every year.
627	Locally adapted seeds are an essential heritage that has the potential to be lost with current hybridized crops and GMOs.
627	Locally adapted seeds, also called land races or crop eco-types, are important because they have adapted over time to the specific micro-climates, soils, other environmental conditions, field designs, and ethnic preference indigenous to the exact area of cultivation.
627	Introducing GMOs and hybridized commercial seed to an area brings the risk of cross-pollination with local land races Therefore, GMOs pose a threat to the sustainability of land races and the ethnic heritage of cultures.
627	Once seed contains transgenic material, it becomes subject to the conditions of the seed company that owns the patent of the transgenic material.
627	GMO regulation  Food security issues also coincide with food safety and food labeling concerns.
627	Currently a global treaty, the BioSafety Protocol, regulates the trade of GMOs.
627	The EU currently requires all GMO foods to be labeled, whereas the US does not require transparent labeling of GMO foods.
627	Since there are still questions regarding the safety and risks associated with GMO foods, some believe the public should have the freedom to choose and know what they are eating and require all GMO products to be labeled.
627	Environmental impact  Agriculture imposes external costs upon society through pesticides, nutrient runoff, excessive water usage, and assorted other problems.
627	A 2000 assessment of agriculture in the UK determined total external costs for 1996 of £2,343 million, or £208 per hectare.
627	A 2005 analysis of these costs in the USA concluded that cropland imposes approximately $5 to 16 billion ($30 to $96 per hectare), while livestock production imposes $714 million.
627	Both studies concluded that more should be done to internalize external costs, and neither included subsidies in their analysis, but noted that subsidies also influence the cost of agriculture to society.
627	Both focused on purely fiscal impacts.
627	The 2000 review included reported pesticide poisonings but did not include speculative chronic effects of pesticides, and the 2004 review relied on a 1992 estimate of the total impact of pesticides.
627	In 2010, the International Resource Panel of the United Nations Environment Programme published a report assessing the environmental impacts of consumption and production.
627	The study found that agriculture and food consumption are two of the most important drivers of environmental pressures, particularly habitat change, climate change, water use and toxic emissions.
627	Agriculture accounts for 70 per cent of withdrawals of freshwater resources.
627	However, increasing pressure being placed on water resources by industry, cities and the involving biofuels industry means that water scarcity is increasing and agriculture is facing the challenge of producing more food for the world's growing population with fewer water resources.
627	Scientists are also realising that water resources need to be allocated to maintain natural environmental services, such as protecting towns from flooding, cleaning ecosystems and supporting fish stocks.
627	In the book Out of Water: From abundance to scarcity and how to solve the world's water problems, authors Colin Chartres and Samyukta Varma of the International Water Management Institute lay down a six-point plan of action for addressing the global challenge of producing sufficient food for the world with dwindling water resources.
627	One of the actions they say is required is to ensure all water systems, such as lakes and rivers, have water allocated to environmental flow.
627	Livestock issues  A senior UN official and co-author of a UN report detailing this problem, Henning Steinfeld, said "Livestock are one of the most significant contributors to today's most serious environmental problems".
627	Livestock production occupies 70% of all land used for agriculture, or 30% of the land surface of the planet.
627	It is one of the largest sources of greenhouse gases, responsible for 18% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions as measured in CO2 equivalents.
627	By comparison, all transportation emits 13.5% of the CO2.
627	It produces 65% of human-related nitrous oxide (which has 296 times the global warming potential of CO2,2.
627	It also generates 64% of the ammonia emission.
627	Livestock expansion is cited as a key factor driving deforestation, in the Amazon basin 70% of previously forested area is now occupied by pastures and the remainder used for feedcrops.
627	Through deforestation and land degradation, livestock is also driving reductions in biodiversity.
627	Land transformation and degradation  Land transformation, the use of land to yield goods and services, is the most substantial way humans alter the Earth's ecosystems, and is considered the driving force in the loss of biodiversity.
627	Estimates of the amount of land transformed by humans vary from 39–50%.
627	Land degradation, the long-term decline in ecosystem function and productivity, is estimated to be occurring on 24% of land worldwide, with cropland overrepresented.
627	The UN-FAO report cites land management as the driving factor behind degradation and reports that 1.5 billion people rely upon the degrading land.
627	Degradation can be deforestation, desertification, soil erosion, mineral depletion, or chemical degradation (acidification and salinization).
627	Eutrophication  Eutrophication, excessive nutrients in aquatic ecosystems resulting in algal blooms and anoxia, leads to fish kills, loss of biodiversity, and renders water unfit for drinking and other industrial uses.
627	Excessive fertilization and manure application to cropland, as well as high livestock stocking densities cause nutrient (mainly nitrogen and phosphorus) runoff and leaching from agricultural land.
627	These nutrients are major nonpoint pollutants contributing to eutrophication of aquatic ecosystems.
627	Pesticides  Pesticide use has increased since 1950 to 2.5 million tons annually worldwide, yet crop loss from pests has remained relatively constant.
627	The World Health Organization estimated in 1992 that 3 million pesticide poisonings occur annually, causing 220,000 deaths.
627	Pesticides select for pesticide resistance in the pest population, leading to a condition termed the 'pesticide treadmill' in which pest resistance warrants the development of a new pesticide.
627	An alternative argument is that the way to 'save the environment' and prevent famine is by using pesticides and intensive high yield farming, a view exemplified by a quote heading the Center for Global Food Issues website: 'Growing more per acre leaves more land for nature'.
627	However, critics argue that a trade-off between the environment and a need for food is not inevitable, and that pesticides simply replace good agronomic practices such as crop rotation.
627	Climate change  Climate change has the potential to affect agriculture through changes in temperature, rainfall (timing and quantity), CO2, solar radiation and the interaction of these elements.
627	Extreme events, such as droughts and floods, are forecast to increase as climate change takes hold.
627	Agriculture is among sectors most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change; water supply for example, will be critical to sustain agricultural production and provide the increase in food output required to sustain the world's growing population.
627	Transformational approaches will be needed to manage natural resources in future.
627	For example, policies, practices and tools promoting climate-smart agriculture will be important, as will better use of scientific information on climate for assessing risks and vulnerability.
627	Planners and policy-makers will need to help create suitable policies that encourage funding for such agricultural transformation.
627	Agriculture can both mitigate or worsen global warming.
627	Some of the increase in CO2 in the atmosphere comes from the decomposition of organic matter in the soil, and much of the methane emitted into the atmosphere is caused by the decomposition of organic matter in wet soils such as rice paddies, as well as the normal digestive activities of farm animals.
627	Further, wet or anaerobic soils also lose nitrogen through denitrification, releasing the greenhouse gases nitric oxide and nitrous oxide.
627	Changes in management can reduce the release of these greenhouse gases, and soil can further be used to sequester some of the CO2 in the atmosphere.
627	Sustainability Some major organisations are hailing farming within agroecosystems as the way forward for mainstream agriculture.
627	Current farming methods have resulted in over-stretched water resources, high levels of erosion and reduced soil fertility.
627	According to a report by the International Water Management Institute and UNEP, there is not enough water to continue farming using current practices; therefore how we use critical water, land, and ecosystem resources to boost crop yields must be reconsidered.
627	The report suggested that we need to assign value to ecosystems, recognize environmental and livelihood tradeoffs, and balance the rights of a variety of users and interests.
627	We would also need to address inequities that result when such measures are adopted, such as the reallocation of water from poor to rich, the clearing of land to make way for more productive farmland, or the preservation of a wetland system that limits fishing rights.
627	Technological advancements help provide farmers with tools and resources to make farming more sustainable.
627	New technologies have given rise to innovations like conservation tillage, a farming process which helps prevent land loss to erosion, water pollution and enhances carbon sequestration.
627	International economics and market reports  Differences in economic development, population density and culture mean that the farmers of the world operate under very different conditions.
627	A US cotton farmer may receive US$230 in government subsidies per acre planted (in 2003), while farmers in Mali and other third-world countries do without.
627	When prices decline, the heavily subsidized US farmer is not forced to reduce his output, making it difficult for cotton prices to rebound, but his Mali counterpart may go broke in the meantime.
627	A livestock farmer in South Korea can calculate with a (highly subsidized) sales price of US$1300 for a calf produced.
627	A South American Mercosur country rancher calculates with a calf's sales price of US$120–200 (both 2008 figures).
627	With the former, scarcity and high cost of land is compensated with public subsidies, the latter compensates absence of subsidies with economics of scale and low cost of land.
627	In the Peoples Republic of China, a rural household's productive asset may be one hectare of farmland.
627	In Brazil, Paraguay and other countries where local legislature allows such purchases, international investors buy thousands of hectares of farmland or raw land at prices of a few hundred US$ per hectare.
627	To promote exports of agricultural products, many government agencies publish on the web economic studies and reports categorized by product and country.
627	Among these agencies include four of the largest exporters of agricultural products, such as the FAS of the United States Department of Agriculture, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC), Austrade, and NZTE .
627	The Federation of International Trade Associations publishes studies and reports by FAS and AAFC, as well as other non-governmental organizations on its website GlobalTrade.net.
627	List of countries by agricultural output  Below is a list of countries by agricultural output in 2011.
627	Energy and agriculture  Since the 1940s, agricultural productivity has increased dramatically, due largely to the increased use of energy-intensive mechanization, fertilizers and pesticides.
627	The vast majority of this energy input comes from fossil fuel sources.
627	Between 1950 and 1984, the Green Revolution transformed agriculture around the globe, with world grain production increasing by 250% as world population doubled.
627	Modern agriculture's heavy reliance on petrochemicals and mechanization has raised concerns that oil shortages could increase costs and reduce agricultural output, causing food shortages.
627	Modern or industrialized agriculture is dependent on fossil fuels in two fundamental ways: 1) direct consumption on the farm and 2) indirect consumption to manufacture inputs used on the farm.
627	Direct consumption includes the use of lubricants and fuels to operate farm vehicles and machinery; and use of gas, liquid propane, and electricity to power dryers, pumps, lights, heaters, and coolers.
627	American farms directly consumed about 1.2 exajoules (1.1 quadrillion BTU) in 2002, or just over 1 percent of the nation's total energy.
627	Indirect consumption is mainly oil and natural gas used to manufacture fertilizers and pesticides, which accounted for 0.6 exajoules (0.6 quadrillion BTU) in 2002.
627	The energy used to manufacture farm machinery is also a form of indirect agricultural energy consumption, but it is not included in USDA estimates of U.S.
627	Together, direct and indirect consumption by U.S.
627	Direct and indirect energy consumption by U.S.
627	"ncseonline.org"/> Food systems encompass not just agricultural production, but also off-farm processing, packaging, transporting, marketing, consumption, and disposal of food and food-related items.
627	Agriculture accounts for less than one-fifth of food system energy use in the United States.
627	In 2007, higher incentives for farmers to grow non-food biofuel crops combined with other factors (such as overdevelopment of former farm lands, rising transportation costs, climate change, growing consumer demand in China and India, and population growth) to cause food shortages in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Mexico, as well as rising food prices around the globe.
627	As of December 2007, 37 countries faced food crises, and 20 had imposed some sort of food-price controls.
627	Some of these shortages resulted in food riots and even deadly stampedes.
627	The biggest fossil fuel input to agriculture is the use of natural gas as a hydrogen source for the Haber-Bosch fertilizer-creation process.
627	Natural gas is used because it is the cheapest currently available source of hydrogen.
627	When oil production becomes so scarce that natural gas is used as a partial stopgap replacement, and hydrogen use in transportation increases, natural gas will become much more expensive.
627	If the Haber Process is unable to be commercialized using renewable energy (such as by electrolysis) or if other sources of hydrogen are not available to replace the Haber Process, in amounts sufficient to supply transportation and agricultural needs, this major source of fertilizer would either become extremely expensive or unavailable.
627	This would either cause food shortages or dramatic rises in food prices.
627	Mitigation of effects of petroleum shortages  In the event of a petroleum shortage (see peak oil for global concerns), organic agriculture can be more attractive than conventional practices that use petroleum-based pesticides, herbicides, or fertilizers.
627	Some farmers using modern organic-farming methods have reported yields as high as those available from conventional farming.
627	Organic farming may however be more labor-intensive and would require a shift of the workforce from urban to rural areas.
627	The reconditioning of soil to restore nutrients lost during the use of monoculture agriculture techniques also takes time.
627	It has been suggested that rural communities might obtain fuel from the biochar and synfuel process, which uses agricultural waste to provide charcoal fertilizer, some fuel and food, instead of the normal food vs fuel debate.
627	As the synfuel would be used on-site, the process would be more efficient and might just provide enough fuel for a new organic-agriculture fusion.
627	It has been suggested that some transgenic plants may some day be developed which would allow for maintaining or increasing yields while requiring fewer fossil-fuel-derived inputs than conventional crops.
627	The possibility of success of these programs is questioned by ecologists and economists concerned with unsustainable GMO practices such as terminator seeds.
627	While there has been some research on sustainability using GMO crops, at least one prominent multi-year attempt by Mon some researchsanto Company has been unsuccessful, though during the same period traditional breeding techniques yielded a more sustainable variety of the same crop.
627	Electrical energy efficiency on farms  Policy  Agricultural policy focuses on the goals and methods of agricultural production.
627	At the policy level, common goals of agriculture include: * Conservation * Economic stability * Environmental sustainability * Food quality: Ensuring that the food supply is of a consistent and known quality.
627	Food safety: Ensuring that the food supply is free of contamination.
627	Food security: Ensuring that the food supply meets the population's needs.
627	Poverty reduction
628	Aldous Leonard Huxley (26 July 1894 – 22 November 1963) was an English writer and one of the most prominent members of the famous Huxley family.
628	Best known for his novels including Brave New World and a wide-ranging output of essays, Huxley also edited the magazine Oxford Poetry, and published short stories, poetry, travel writing, film stories and scripts.
628	Huxley spent the later part of his life in the United States, living in Los Angeles from 1937 until his death.
628	Aldous Huxley was a humanist, pacifist, and satirist, and he was latterly interested in spiritual subjects such as parapsychology and philosophical mysticism.
628	He is also well known for advocating and taking psychedelics.
628	By the end of his life Huxley was widely acknowledged as one of the pre-eminent intellectuals of his time.
628	Early life  Aldous Huxley was born in Godalming, Surrey, England, in 1894.
628	He was the third son of the writer and schoolmaster Leonard Huxley and his first wife, Julia Arnold, who founded Prior's Field School.
628	Julia was the niece of poet and critic Matthew Arnold and the sister of Mrs.
628	Humphrey Ward.
628	Aldous was the grandson of Thomas Henry Huxley, the zoologist, agnostic and controversialist ("Darwin's Bulldog").
628	His brother Julian Huxley and half-brother Andrew Huxley also became outstanding biologists.
628	Aldous had another brother, Noel Trevelyan Huxley (1891–1914), who committed suicide after a period of clinical depression.
628	Huxley began his learning in his father's well-equipped botanical laboratory, then continued in a school named Hillside.
628	His teacher was his mother, who supervised him for several years until she became terminally ill.
628	After Hillside, he was educated at Eton College.
628	Huxley's mother died in 1908 when he was 14.
628	In 1911, he suffered an illness (keratitis punctata) which "left [him] practically blind for two to three years".
628	Aldous' near-blindness disqualified him from service in the First World War.
628	Once his eyesight recovered sufficiently, he was able to study English literature at Balliol College, Oxford.
628	In 1916 he edited Oxford Poetry and later graduated (B.A.) with first class honours.
628	His brother Julian wrote, I believe his blindness was a blessing in disguise.
628	For one thing, it put paid to his idea of taking up medicine as a career ...
628	His uniqueness lay in his universalism.
628	He was able to take all knowledge for his province.
628	Following his education at Balliol, Huxley was financially indebted to his father and had to earn a living.
628	He taught French for a year at Eton, where Eric Blair (later to become George Orwell) and Stephen Runciman were among his pupils, but was remembered as an incompetent and hopeless teacher who couldn’t keep discipline.
628	Nevertheless, Blair and others were impressed by his use of words.
628	For a short while in 1918, he was employed acquiring provisions at the Air Ministry.
628	Significantly, Huxley also worked for a time in the 1920s at the technologically advanced Brunner and Mond chemical plant in Billingham, Teesside, and the most recent introduction to his famous science fiction novel Brave New World (1932) states that this experience of "an ordered universe in a world of planless incoherence" was one source for the novel.
628	Career Huxley completed his first (unpublished) novel at the age of 17 and began writing seriously in his early 20s.
628	His first published novels were social satires, beginning with Crome Yellow (1921).
628	Bloomsbury set  During the First World War, Huxley spent much of his time at Garsington Manor, home of Lady Ottoline Morrell, working as a farm labourer.
628	Here he met several Bloomsbury figures including Bertrand Russell and Clive Bell.
628	Later, in Crome Yellow (1921) he caricatured the Garsington lifestyle.
628	In 1919 he married Maria Nys, a Belgian woman he met at Garsington; they had one son.
628	The family lived in Italy part of the time in the 1920s, where Huxley would visit his friend D.
628	H.
628	Lawrence.
628	Following Lawrence's death in 1930, Huxley edited Lawrence's letters (1933).
628	Works of this period included important novels on the dehumanising aspects of scientific progress, most famously Brave New World, and on pacifist themes (for example, Eyeless in Gaza).
628	In Brave New World Huxley portrays a society operating on the principles of mass production and Pavlovian conditioning.
628	Huxley was strongly influenced by F.
628	Matthias Alexander and included him as a character in Eyeless in Gaza.
628	Starting from this period, Huxley began to write and edit non-fiction works on pacifist issues, including Ends and Means, An Encyclopedia of Pacifism, and Pacifism and Philosophy, and was an active member of the Peace Pledge Union.
628	The U.S.
628	In 1937, Huxley moved to Hollywood, with his wife Maria, son Matthew, and friend Gerald Heard.
628	He lived in the U.S., mainly in southern California, until his death, but also for a time in Taos, New Mexico, where he wrote Ends and Means (published in 1937).
628	In this work he examines the fact that although most people in modern civilisation agree that they want a world of "liberty, peace, justice, and brotherly love", they have not been able to agree on how to achieve it.
628	Heard introduced Huxley to Vedanta (Upanishad-centered philosophy), meditation, and vegetarianism through the principle of ahimsa.
628	In 1938 Huxley befriended J.
628	Krishnamurti, whose teachings he greatly admired.
628	He also became a Vedantist in the circle of Hindu Swami Prabhavananda, and introduced Christopher Isherwood to this circle.
628	Not long after, Huxley wrote his book on widely held spiritual values and ideas, The Perennial Philosophy, which discussed the teachings of renowned mystics of the world.
628	Huxley's book affirmed a sensibility that insists there are realities beyond the generally accepted "five senses" and that there is genuine meaning for humans beyond both sensual satisfactions and sentimentalities.
628	Huxley became a close friend of Remsen Bird, president of Occidental College.
628	He spent much time at the college, which is in the Eagle Rock neighbourhood of Los Angeles.
628	The college appears as "Tarzana College" in his satirical novel After Many a Summer (1939).
628	The novel won Huxley that year's James Tait Black Memorial Prize for fiction.
628	Huxley also incorporated Bird into the novel.
628	During this period Huxley earned some Hollywood income as a writer.
628	In March 1938, his friend Anita Loos, a novelist and screenwriter, put him in touch with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer who hired Huxley for Madame Curie which was originally to star Greta Garbo and be directed by George Cukor.
628	The film was eventually completed by MGM in 1943 with a different director and cast.) Huxley received screen credit for Pride and Prejudice (1940) and was paid for his work on a number of other films, including Jane Eyre (1944).
628	His experience in Hollywood was not a success.
628	When he wrote a synopsis of Alice in Wonderland, Walt Disney rejected it on the grounds that "he could only understand every third word".
628	Huxley's leisurely development of ideas, it seemed, was not suitable for the movie moguls, who demanded fast, dynamic dialogue above all else.
628	For Dick Huemer, during the 1940s, Huxley went to the first of a five meetings' session to elaborate the script of Alice in Wonderland but never came again.
628	For author John Grant, although the movie's character the Caterpillar displays some characteristics familiar from Huxley's discussion of his experiments with hallucinogens, Huxley's contribution to the movie is nonexistent.
628	On 21 October 1949, Huxley wrote to George Orwell, author of Nineteen Eighty-Four, congratulating him on "how fine and how profoundly important the book is".
628	In his letter to Orwell, he predicted: Within the next generation I believe that the world's leaders will discover that infant conditioning and narco-hypnosis are more efficient, as instruments of government, than clubs and prisons, and that the lust for power can be just as completely satisfied by suggesting people into loving their servitude as by flogging them and kicking them into obedience.
628	Huxley had deeply felt apprehensions about the future the developed world might make for itself.
628	From these he put forward some warnings in his writings and talks.
628	In a 1958 televised interview conducted by journalist Mike Wallace, Huxley outlined several major concerns: the difficulties and dangers of world overpopulation; the tendency toward distieral major concerns: the difficulties and dangers nctly hierarchical social organization; the crucial importance of evaluating the use of technology in mass societies susceptible to wily persuasion; the tendency to promote modern politicians, to a naive public, as well-marketed commodities.
628	Post World War II  After the Second World War, Huxley applied for United States citizenship.
628	His application was continuously deferred on the grounds that he would not say he would take up arms to defend the U.S.
628	He claimed a philosophical, rather than a religious objection, and therefore was not exempt under the McCarran Act.
628	He withdrew his application.
628	Nevertheless, he remained in the country; and in 1959 he turned down an offer of a Knight Bachelor by the Macmillan government.
628	During the 1950s, Huxley's interest in the field of psychical research grew keener, and his later works are strongly influenced by both mysticism and his experiences with psychedelic drugs.
628	In October 1930, the English occultist Aleister Crowley dined with Huxley in Berlin, and to this day rumours persist that Crowley introduced Huxley to peyote on that occasion.
628	He was introduced to mescaline (the key active ingredient of peyote) by the psychiatrist Humphry Osmond in 1953, taking for his first time during the evening of May 5.
628	Through Dr.
628	Osmond, Huxley met millionaire Alfred Matthew Hubbard who would deal with LSD on a wholesale basis.
628	On 24 December 1955, Huxley took his first dose of LSD.
628	Indeed, Huxley was a pioneer of self-directed psychedelic drug use "in a search for enlightenment", famously taking 100 micrograms of LSD as he lay dying.
628	His psychedelic drug experiences are described in the essays The Doors of Perception (the title deriving from some lines in the book The Marriage of Heaven and Hell by William Blake), and Heaven and Hell.
628	Some of his writings on psychedelics became frequent reading among early hippies.
628	While living in Los Angeles, Huxley was a friend of Ray Bradbury.
628	According to Sam Weller's biography of Bradbury, the latter was dissatisfied with Huxley, especially after Huxley encouraged Bradbury to take psychedelic drugs.
628	Association with Vedanta  Beginning in 1939 and continuing until his death in 1963, Huxley had an extensive association with the Vedanta Society of Southern California, founded and headed by Swami Prabhavananda.
628	Together with Gerald Heard, Christopher Isherwood, and other followers he was initiated by the Swami and was taught meditation and spiritual practices.
628	In 1944 Huxley wrote the introduction to the "Bhagavad Gita: The Song of God", translated by Swami Prabhavanada and Christopher Isherwood, which was published by The Vedanta Society of Southern California.
628	From 1941 through 1960 Huxley contributed 48 articles to Vedanta and the West, published by the Society.
628	He also served on the editorial board with Isherwood, Heard, and playwright John van Druten from 1951 through 1962.
628	Huxley also occasionally lectured at the Hollywood and Santa Barbara Vedanta temples.
628	Two of those lectures have been released on CD: Knowledge and Understanding and Who Are We from 1955.
628	After the publication of The Doors of Perception, Huxley and the Swami disagreed about the meaning and importance of the LSD drug experience, which may have caused the relationship to cool, but Huxley continued to write articles for the Society's journal, lecture at the temple, and attend social functions.
628	Eyesight  With respect to details about the true quality of Huxley's eyesight at specific points in his life, there are differing accounts.
628	Around 1939, Huxley encountered the Bates Method for better eyesight, and a teacher, Margaret Corbett, who was able to teach him in the method.
628	In 1940, Huxley relocated from Hollywood to a 40 acre ranchito in the high desert hamlet of Llano, California, in northernmost Los Angeles County.
628	Huxley then said that his sight improved dramatically with the Bates Method and the extreme and pure natural lighting of the southwestern American desert.
628	He reported that for the first time in over 25 years, he was able to read without glasses and without strain.
628	He even tried driving a car along the dirt road beside the ranch.
628	He wrote a book about his successes with the Bates Method, The Art of Seeing, which was published in 1942 (US), 1943 (UK).
628	It was from this period, with the publication of the generally disputed theories contained in the latter book, that a growing degree of popular controversy arose over the subject of Huxley’s eyesight.
628	It was, and to a noticeable extent still is, widely held that, for most of his life, since the illness in his teens which left Huxley nearly blind, that his eyesight was exceedingly poor (despite the partial recovery which had enabled him to study at Oxford).
628	For instance, some ten years after publication of The Art of Seeing, in 1952, Bennett Cerf was present when Huxley spoke at a Hollywood banquet, wearing no glasses and apparently reading his paper from the lectern without difficulty: "Then suddenly he faltered—and the disturbing truth became obvious.
628	He wasn't reading his address at all.
628	He had learned it by heart.
628	To refresh his memory he brought the paper closer and closer to his eyes.
628	When it was only an inch or so away he still couldn't read it, and had to fish for a magnifying glass in his pocket to make the typing visible to him.
628	It was an agonising moment."
628	On the other hand, Huxley's second wife, Laura Archera Huxley, would later emphasise in her biographical account, This Timeless Moment: "One of the great achievements of his life: that of having regained his sight."
628	After revealing a letter she wrote to the Los Angeles Times disclaiming the label of Huxley as a "poor fellow who can hardly see" by Walter C.
628	Alvarez, she tempers this: "Although I feel it was an injustice to treat Aldous as though he were blind,she tempers this:  it is true there were many indications of his impaired vision.
628	For instance, although Aldous did not wear glasses, he would quite often use a magnifying lens."
628	Laura Huxley proceeds to elaborate a few nuances of inconsistency peculiar to Huxley's vision.
628	Her account, in this respect, is discernibly congruent with the following sample of Huxley's own words from The Art of Seeing.
628	"The most characteristic fact about the functioning of the total organism, or any part of the organism, is that it is not constant, but highly variable."
628	Nevertheless, the topic of Huxley’s eyesight continues to endure similar, significant controversy, regardless of how trivial a subject matter it might initially appear.
628	Personal life He married Maria Nys (10 September 1899 – 12 February 1955), a Belgian he met at Garsington, in 1919.
628	They had one child, Matthew Huxley (19 April 1920 – 10 February 2005), who had a career as an author, anthropologist, and prominent epidemiologist.
628	In 1955, Maria died of breast cancer.
628	In 1956 he married Laura Archera (1911–2007), also an author.
628	She wrote This Timeless Moment, a biography of Huxley.
628	In 1960 Huxley himself was diagnosed with laryngeal cancer, and in the years that followed, with his health deteriorating, he wrote the Utopian novel Island, and gave lectures on "Human Potentialities" at the Esalen Institute, which were fundamental to the forming of the Human Potential Movement.
628	Despite his interest in spirituality and mysticism, Huxley called himself an agnostic.
628	The most substantial collection of Huxley's few remaining papers (following the destruction of most in a fire) is at the Library of the University of California, Los Angeles.
628	Some are also at the Stanford University Library.
628	Death  On his deathbed, unable to speak, Huxley made a written request to his wife Laura for "LSD, 100 µg, intramuscular".
628	According to her account of his death in This Timeless Moment, she obliged with an injection at 11:45 am and a second one a few hours later; Huxley died aged 69, at 5:20 pm on 22 November 1963.
628	Media coverage of Huxley's passing was overshadowed by the assassination of President John F.
628	Kennedy, on the same day, as was the death of the British author C.
628	S.
628	Lewis, who also died on 22 November.
628	This coincidence was the inspiration for Peter Kreeft's book Between Heaven and Hell: A Dialog Somewhere Beyond Death with John F.
628	Kennedy, C.
628	S.
628	Lewis, & Aldous Huxley.
628	Huxley's ashes were interred in the family grave at the Watts Cemetery, home of the Watts Mortuary Chapel in Compton, a village near Guildford, Surrey, England.
628	Huxley's literary legacy continues to be represented by the literary agency headed by Georges Borchardt.
628	Awards  * 1939 James Tait Black Memorial Prize for After Many a Summer Dies the Swan.
628	Aldous Huxley American Academy of Arts and Letters Award of Merit for Brave New World.
628	Companion of Literature by the Royal Society of Literature.
628	Film adaptations of Huxley's work  * 1968 Point Counter Point BBC mini-series by Simon Raven.
628	The Devils (Ken Russell) adapted Huxley's The Devils of Loudun.

630	Congress * Anti-Dumping Agreement, General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) about anti-competitive dumping pricing practices * Assistant District Attorney, US government attorney position * Austrian Development Agency, development aid agency * Australian Digital Alliance, copyright advocacy group * Association of Drainage Authorities, membership body for those involved in water level management in the United Kingdom Science and engineering * ADA collider, the first electron–positron collider * Adenosine deaminase enzyme * Analog-to-digital converter/Digital-to-analog converter, seen as ADA or A/DA, conversion occurring in some electronic devices, often musical * Adangme language's ISO 639-2 code * Advanced Distribution Automation, the extension of intelligent control over an electrical power grid * After the Development of Agriculture, A.D.A., system of counting years, like A.D.
630	A.M.
630	Ada (food), Indian food made with rice, coconut powder mix, and sugar * Ada (ship), wooden Ketch, wrecked near Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia * USS Little Ada (1864), steamer captured by the Union Navy during the American Civil War ; Astronomy *523 Ada, minor planet orbiting the Sun ; Biology * Ada (orchid), genus of orchids * Ada aurantiaca, species of orchid and the type species of its genus * Ada keiliana, species of orchid ; Computer science * Ada (programming language), programming language based on Pascal * Ada (computer virus) * Apple Design Awards ; Enzymes, etc.
630	Adenosine deaminase, enzyme involved in purine metabolism * Ada (protein), enzyme induced by treatment of bacterial cells * Ada regulon, one of the Escherichia coli adaptive response proteins ; Meteorology * Cyclone Ada (disambiguation), two tropical cyclones named Ada ; Scientific and medical organizations * AdA (physics) or Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare (National Institute for Nuclear Physics), Italy * American Dental Association * American Diabetes Association * American Dietetic Association * American Dyslexia Association ; Air travel * Ada Air, regional airline based in Tirana, Albania * Ada International Airport or Saipan International Airport, Saipan Island, Northern Mariana Islands * Aerolínea de Antioquia, Colombian Airline * Airline Deregulation Act, 1978 US bill removing governmental control from commercial aviation * Adana Şakirpaşa Airport's IATA code
632	Aberdeen is a city in Scotland, United Kingdom.
632	Aberdeen may also refer to: Aberdeen, Scotland  Aberdeen, Scotland, is home of: * Aberdeen (HM Prison) * Aberdeen F.C.
632	Aberdeen railway station * University of Aberdeen Africa ;Sierra Leone * Aberdeen, Sierra Leone ;South Africa * Aberdeen, Eastern Cape Asia ;Hong Kong * Aberdeen, Hong Kong ;Sri Lanka * Aberdeen, Sri Lanka Australia * Aberdeen, New South Wales ** Aberdeen railway station, New South Wales * Aberdeen, Tasmania, place with a Scottish placename in Tasmania, Australia Europe * Aberdeen (UK Parliament constituency) 1832-1885 * Aberdeen Burghs (UK Parliament constituency) 1801-1832 * Aberdeen Central (Scottish Parliament constituency) * Aberdeen Central (UK Parliament constituency) North America ;Canada * Aberdeen, Kamloops, an area in the City of Kamloops, British Columbia * Aberdeen, Abbotsford, a neighbourhood in the City of Abbotsford, British Columbia * Aberdeen Parish, New Brunswick * Aberdeen, Nova Scotia, part of the Municipality of Inverness County, Nova Scotia * Aberdeen, Grey County, Ontario * Aberdeen, Saskatchewan * Aberdeen No.
632	Saskatchewan * Aberdeen, community in the township of Champlain, Prescott and Russell County, Ontario * Aberdeen Township, Quebec, until 1960 part of Sheen-Esher-Aberdeen-et-Malakoff, now part of Rapides-des-Joachims, Quebec ;United States of America * Aberdeen, Arkansas, place in Arkansas * Aberdeen, California * Aberdeen, Florida * Aberdeen, Georgia, place in Georgia * Aberdeen, Idaho * Aberdeen, Ohio County, Indiana * Aberdeen, Porter County, Indiana * Aberdeen, Maryland ** Aberdeen (Amtrak station) ** Aberdeen IronBirds, baseball team ** Aberdeen Proving Ground * Aberdeen, Mississippi * Aberdeen, Montana, place near Interstate 90 in Montana * Aberdeen Township, New Jersey * Aberdeen, North Carolina * Aberdeen, Ohio * Aberdeen, Pennsylvania, place in Pennsylvania * Aberdeen, South Dakota * Aberdeen, Washington * Aberdeen, West Virginia Other * Some members of the Marquess of Aberdeen and Temair house * Aberdeen (band), an American rock band * Aberdeen City (band), Boston based indie/alternative rock band.
632	Aberdeen (film), a film (2000) directed by Hans Petter Moland, starring Stellan Skarsgård and Lena Headey * Aberdeen Asset Management, an investment management group * Aberdeen Station (TransLink), SkyTrain station on the Canada Line in Richmond, British Columbia, Canada * Aberdeen Group, an IT-consulting firm * Aberdeen LLC, a server and storage server computer system manufacturer * Aberdeen (song) A song by alternative rock band Cage The Elephant
633	Algae ( or; singular alga, Latin for "seaweed") are a very large and diverse group of simple, typically autotrophic organisms, ranging from unicellular to multicellular forms, such as the giant kelps that grow to 65 meters in length.
633	Most are photosynthetic like plants, and "simple" because they lack the many distinct cell and organ types found in land plants.
633	The largest and most complex marine forms are called seaweeds.
633	Though the prokaryotic cyanobacteria are informally referred to as blue-green algae, this usage is incorrect  since they are regarded as bacteria.
633	The term algae is now restricted to eukaryotic organisms.
633	All true algae therefore have a nucleus enclosed within a membrane and plastids bound in one or more membranes.
633	Algae constitute a paraphyletic and polyphyletic group, as they do not include all the descendants of the last universal ancestor nor do they all descend from a common algal ancestor, although their plastids seem to have a single origin.
633	Diatoms are also examples of algae.
633	Algae exhibit a wide range of reproductive strategies, from simple, asexual cell division to complex forms of sexual reproduction.
633	Algae lack the various structures that characterize land plants, such as the leaf-like phyllids of bryophytes, rhizoids in nonvascular plants and the roots, leaves and other organs that are found in tracheophytes (vascular plants).
633	Many are phototrophic, although some groups contain members that are mixotrophic, deriving energy both from photosynthesis and uptake of organic carbon either by osmotrophy, myzotrophy, or phagotrophy.
633	Some unicellular species rely entirely on external energy sources and have limited or no photosynthetic apparatus.
633	Nearly all algae have photosynthetic machinery ultimately derived from cyanobacteria, and so produce oxygen as a by-product of photosynthesis, unlike other photosynthetic bacteria such as purple and green sulfur bacteria.
633	Fossilized filamentous algae from the Vindhya basin have been dated back to 1.6 to 1.7 billion years ago.
633	Etymology and study  The singular alga is the Latin word for a particular seaweed and retains that meaning in English.
633	The etymology is obscure.
633	Although some speculate that it is related to Latin algēre, "be cold", there is no known reason to associate seaweed with temperature.
633	A more likely source is alliga, "binding, entwining."
633	The Ancient Greek word for seaweed was φῦκος (fūkos or phykos), which could mean either the seaweed (probably red algae) or a red dye derived from it.
633	The Latinization, fūcus, meant primarily the cosmetic rouge.
633	The etymology is uncertain, but a strong candidate has long been some word related to the Biblical פוך (pūk), "paint" (if not that word itself), a cosmetic eye-shadow used by the ancient Egyptians and other inhabitants of the eastern Mediterranean.
633	It could be any color: black, red, green, blue.
633	Accordingly the modern study of marine and freshwater algae is called either phycology or algology, depending on whether the Greek or Latin root is used.
633	The name Fucus appears in a number of taxa.
633	Classification While cyanobacteria have been traditionally considered algae, recent works usually exclude them due to large differences such as the lack of membrane-bound organelles, the presence of a single circular chromosome, the presence of peptidoglycan in the cell walls, and ribosomes different in size and content from those of the Eukaryotes.
633	Rather than in chloroplasts, they conduct photosynthesis on specialized infolded cytoplasmic membranes called thylakoid membranes.
633	Therefore, they differ significantly from algae despite occupying similar ecological niches.
633	By modern definitions, algae are Eukaryotes and conduct photosynthesis within membrane-bound organelles called chloroplasts.
633	Chloroplasts contain circular DNA and are similar in structure to cyanobacteria, presumably representing reduced cyanobacterial endosymbionts.
633	The exact nature of the chloroplasts is different among separate lineages of algae, reflecting different endosymbiotic events.
633	The table below describes the composition of the three major groups of algae.
633	Their lineage relationships are shown in the figure in the upper right.
633	Many of these groups contain some members that are no longer photosynthetic.
633	Some retain plastids, but not chloroplasts, while others have lost plastids entirely.
633	Phylogeny based on plastid not nucleocytoplasmic genealogy: W.H.Harvey (1811—1866) was the first to divide algae into four divisions based on their pigmentation.
633	This is the first use of a biochemical criterion in plant systematics.
633	Harvey's four divisions are: red algae (Rhodophyta), brown algae (Heteromontophyta), green algae (Chlorophyta) and Diatomaceae.
633	Relationship to higher plants The first plants on earth probably evolved from shallow freshwater algae much like Chara some 400 million years ago.
633	These probably had an isomorphic alternation of generations and were probably filamentous.
633	Fossils of isolated land plant spores suggest land plants may have been around as long as 475 million years ago.
633	Morphology A range of algal morphologies are exhibited, and convergence of features in unrelated groups is common.
633	The only groups to exhibit three dimensional multicellular thalli are the reds and browns, and some chlorophytes.
633	Apical growth is constrained to subsets of these groups: the florideophyte reds, various browns, and the charophytes.
633	The form of charophytes is quite different to those of reds and browns, because have distinct nodes, separated by internode 'stems'; whorls of branches reminiscent of the horsetails occur at the nodes.
633	Conceptacles are another polyphyletic trait; they appear in the coralline algae and the Hildenbrandiales, as well as the browns.
633	Most of the simpler algae are unicellular flagellates or amoeboids, but colonial and non-motile forms have developed independently among several of the groups.
633	Some of the more common organizational levels, more than one of which may occur in the life cycle of a species, are * Colonial: small, regular groups of motile cells * Capsoid: individual non-motile cells embedded in mucilage * Coccoid: individual non-motile cells with cell walls * Palmelloid: non-motile cells embedded in mucilage * Filamentous: a string of non-motile cells connected together, sometimes branching * Parenchymatous: cells forming a thallus with partial differentiation of tissues In three lines even higher levels of organization have been reached, with full tissue differentiation.
633	These are the brown algae,—some of which may reach 50 m in length (kelps)—the red algae, and the green algae.
633	The most complex forms are found among the green algae (see Charales and Charophyta), in a lineage that eventually led to nd among the green algaethe higher land plants.
633	The point where these non-algal plants begin and algae stop is usually taken to be the presence of reproductive organs with protective cell layers, a characteristic not found in the other alga groups.
633	Physiology Many algae, particularly members of the characeae, have served as model experimental organisms to understand the mechanisms of the water permeability of membranes, osmoregulation, turgor regulation, salt tolerance, cytoplasmic streaming, and the generation of action potentials.
633	Symbiotic algae Some species of algae form symbiotic relationships with other organisms.
633	In these symbioses, the algae supply photosynthates (organic substances) to the host organism providing protection to the algal cells.
633	The host organism derives some or all of its energy requirements from the algae.
633	Examples are as follows.
633	Lichens Lichens are defined by the International Association for Lichenology to be "an association of a fungus and a photosynthetic symbiont resulting in a stable vegetative body having a specific structure."
633	The fungi, or mycobionts, are from the Ascomycota with a few from the Basidiomycota.
633	They are not found alone in nature but when they began to associate is not known.
633	One mycobiont associates with the same phycobiont species, rarely two, from the green algae, except that alternatively the mycobiont may associate with the same species of cyanobacteria (hence "photobiont" is the more accurate term).
633	A photobiont may be associated with many specific mycobionts or live independently; accordingly, lichens are named and classified as fungal species.
633	The association is termed a morphogenesis because the lichen has a form and capabilities not possessed by the symbiont species alone (they can be experimentally isolated).
633	It is possible that the photobiont triggers otherwise latent genes in the mycobiont.
633	Coral reefs  Coral reefs are accumulated from the calcareous exoskeletons of marine invertebrates of the order Scleractinia (stony corals).
633	As animals they metabolize sugar and oxygen to obtain energy for their cell-building processes, including secretion of the exoskeleton, with water and carbon dioxide as byproducts.
633	As the reef is the result of a favorable equilibrium between construction by the corals and destruction by marine erosion, the rate at which metabolism can proceed determines the growth or deterioration of the reef.
633	Dinoflagellates (algal protists) are often endosymbionts in the cells of marine invertebrates, where they accelerate host-cell metabolism by generating immediately available sugar and oxygen through photosynthesis using incident light and the carbon dioxide produced by the host.
633	Stony corals that are reef-building corals (hermatypic corals) require endosymbiotic algae from the genus Symbiodinium to be in a healthy condition.
633	The loss of Symbiodinium from the host is known as coral bleaching, a condition which leads to the deterioration of a reef.
633	Sea sponges Green algae live close to the surface of some sponges, for example, breadcrumb sponge (Halichondria panicea).
633	The alga is thus protected from predators; the sponge is provided with oxygen and sugars which can account for 50 to 80% of sponge growth in some species.
633	Life-cycle Rhodophyta, Chlorophyta and Heterokontophyta, the three main algal Phyla, have life-cycles which show tremendous variation with considerable complexity.
633	In general there is an asexual phase where the seaweed's cells are diploid, a sexual phase where the cells are haploid followed by fusion of the male and female gametes.
633	Asexual reproduction is advantageous in that it permits efficient population increases, but less variation is possible.
633	Sexual reproduction allows more variation, but is more costly.
633	Often there is no strict alternation between the sporophyte and also because there is often an asexual phase, which could include the fragmentation of the thallus.
633	Numbers The Algal Collection of the US National Herbarium (located in the National Museum of Natural History) consists of approximately 320,500 dried specimens, which, although not exhaustive (no exhaustive collection exists), gives an idea of the order of magnitude of the number of algal species (that number remains unknown).
633	Estimates vary widely.
633	For example, according to one standard textbook, in the British Isles the UK Biodiversity Steering Group Report estimated there to be 20000 algal species in the UK.
633	Another checklist reports only about 5000 species.
633	Regarding the difference of about 15000 species, the text concludes: "It will require many detailed field surveys before it is possible to provide a reliable estimate of the total number of species ..."
633	Regional and group estimates have been made as well:  *5000–5500 species of red algae worldwide *"some 1300 in Australian Seas" *400 seaweed species for the western coastline of South Africa, and 212 species from the coast of KwaZulu-Natal.
633	Some of these are duplicates as the range extends across both coasts, and the total recorded is probably about 500 species.
633	Most of these are listed in List of seaweeds of South Africa.
633	These exclude phytoplankton and crustose corallines.
633	California (US) *642 in the check-list of Britain and Ireland and so on, but lacking any scientific basis or reliable sources, these numbers have no more credibility than the British ones mentioned above.
633	Most estimates also omit microscopic algae, such as phytoplankton.
633	The most recent estimate suggests a total number of 72,500 algal species worldwide.
633	Distribution The topic of distribution of algal species has been fairly well studied since the founding of phytogeography in the mid-19th century AD.
633	Algae spread mainly by the dispersal of spores analogously to the dispersal of Plantae by seeds and spores.
633	Spores are everywhere in all parts of the Earth: the waters fresh and marine, the atmosphere, free-floating and in precipitation or mixed with dust, the humus and in other organisms, such as humans.
633	Whether a spore is to grow into an organism depends on the combination of the species and the environmental conditions of where the spore lands.
633	The spores of fresh-water algae are dispersed mainly by running water and wind, as well as by living carriers.
633	The bodies of water into which they are transported are chemically selective.
633	Marine spores are spread by currents.
633	Ocean water is temperature selective, resulting in phytogeographic zones, regions and provinces.
633	To some degree the distribution of algae is subject to floristic discontinuities caused by geographical features, such as Antarctica, long distances of ocean or general land masses.
633	It is therefore possible to identify species occurring by locality, such as "Pacific Algae" or "North Sea Algae".
633	When they occur out of their localities, it is usually possible to hypothesize a transport mechanism, such as the hulls of ships.
633	For example, Ulva reticulata and Ulva fasciata travelled from the mainland to Hawaii in this manner.
633	Mapping is possible for select species only: "there are many valid examples of confined distribution patterns."
633	For example, Clathromorphum is an arctic genus and is not mapped far south of there.
633	On the other hand, scientists regard the overall data as insufficient due to the "difficulties of undertaking such studies."
633	Locations Algae are prominent in bodies of water, common in terrestrial environments and are found in unusual environments, such as on snow and on ice.
633	Seaweeds grow mostly in shallow marine waters, under 100 m; however some have been recorded to a depth of 360 m.
633	The various sorts of algae play significant roles in aquatic ecology.
633	Microscopic forms that live suspended in the water column (phytoplankton) provide the food base for most marine food chains.
633	In very high densities (algal blooms) these algae may discolor the water and outcompete, poison, or asphyxiate other life forms.
633	Algae are variously sensitive to different factors, which has made them useful as biological indicators in the Ballantine Scale and its modification.
633	Uses Agar Agar, a gelatinous substance derived from red algae, has a number of commercial uses.
633	It is a good medium for bacteria.
633	Alginates Between 100,000 and 170,000 wet tons of Macrocystis are harvested annually in California for alginate extraction and abalone feed.
633	Energy source To be competitive and independent from fluctuating support from (local) policy on the long run, biofuels should equal or beat the cost level of fossil fuels.
633	Here, algae based fuels hold great promise, directly related to the potential to produce more biomass per unit area in a year than any other form of biomass.
633	The break-even point for algae-based biofuels is estimated to occur in about ten to fifteen years.
633	Fertilizer For centuries seaweed has been used as a fertilizer; George Owen of Henllys writing in the 16th century referring to drift weed in South Wales:This kind of ore they often gather and lay on great heapes, where it heteth and rotteth, and will have a strong and loathsome smell; when being so rotten they cast on the land, as they do their muck, and thereof springeth good corn, especially barley ...
633	After spring-tydes or great rigs of the sea, they fetch it in sacks on horse backes, and carie the same three, four, or five miles, and cast it on the lande, which doth very much better the ground for corn and grass.
633	Today, algae are used by humans in many ways; for example, as fertilizers, soil conditioners and livestock feed.
633	Aquatic and microscopic species are cultured in clear tanks or ponds and are either harvested or used to treat effluents pumped through the ponds.
633	Algaculture on a large scale is an important type of aquaculture in some places.
633	Maerl is commonly used as a soil conditioner.
633	Nutrition Naturally growing seaweeds are an important source of food, especially in Asia.
633	They provide many vitamins including: A, B1, B2, B6, niacin and C, and are rich in iodine, potassium, iron, magnesium and calcium.
633	In addition commercially cultivated microalgae, including both algae and cyanobacteria, are marketed as nutritional supplements, such as Spirulina, Chlorella and the Vitamin-C supplement, Dunaliella, high in beta-carotene.
633	Algae are national foods of many nations: China consumes more than 70 species, including fat choy, a cyanobacterium considered a vegetable; Japan, over 20 species; Ireland, dulse; Chile, cochayuyo.
633	Laver is used to make "laver bread" in Wales where it is known as bara lawr; in Korea, gim; in Japan, nori and aonori.
633	It is also used along the west coast of North America from California to British Columbia, in Hawaii and by the Māori of New Zealand.
633	Sea lettuce and badderlocks are a salad ingredient in Scotland, Ireland, Greenland and Iceland.
633	The oils from some algae have high levels of unsaturated fatty acids.
633	For example, Parietochloris incisa is very high in arachidonic acid, where it reaches up to 47% of the triglyceride pool.
633	Some varieties of algae favored by vegetarianism and veganism contain the long-chain, essential omega-3 fatty acids, Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA).
633	Fish oil contains the omega-3 fatty acids, but the original source is algae (microalgae in particular), which are eaten by marine life such as copepods and are passed up the food chain.
633	Algae has emerged in recent years as a popular source of omega-3 fatty acids for vegetarians who cannot get long-chain EPA and DHA from other vegetarian sources such as flaxseed oil, which only contains the short-chain Alpha-Linolenic acid (ALA).
633	Pollution control * Sewage can be treated with algae, reducing the need for greater amounts of toxic chemicals than are already used.
633	Algae can be used to capture fertilizers in runoff from farms.
633	When subsequently harvested, the enriched algae itself can be used as fertilizer.
633	Aquariums and ponds can be filtered using algae, which absorb nutrients from the water in a device called an algae scrubber, also known as an "ATS".
633	Agricultural Research Service scientists found that 60-90% of nitrogen runoff and 70-100% of phosphorus runoff can be captured from manure effluents using an algal turf scrubber (ATS).
633	Scientists developed the ATS, which are shallow, 100-foot raceways of nylon netting where algae colonies can form, and studied its efficacy for three years.
633	They found that algae can readily be used to reduce the nutrient runoff from agricultural fields and increase the quality of water flowing into rivers, streams, and oceans.
633	The enriched algae itself also can be used as a fertilizer.
633	Researchers collected and dried the nutrient-rich algae from the ATS and studied its potential as an organic fertilizer.
633	They found that cucumber and corn seedlings grew just as well using ATS organic fertilizer as they did with commercial fertilizers.
633	Pigments The natural pigments produced by algae can be used as an alternative to chemical dyes and coloring agents.
633	Stabilizing substances Carrageenan, from the red alga Chondrus crispus, is used as a stabilizer in milk products.
634	In statistics, analysis of variance (ANOVA) is a collection of statistical models, and their associated procedures, in which the observed variance in a particular variable is partitioned into components attributable to different sources of variation.
634	In its simplest form, ANOVA provides a statistical test of whether or not the means of several groups are all equal, and therefore generalizes t-test to more than two groups.
634	Doing multiple two-sample t-tests would result in an increased chance of committing a type I error.
634	For this reason, ANOVAs are useful in comparing three, or more means.
634	Background and terminology ANOVA is a particular form of statistical hypothesis testing heavily used in the analysis of experimental data.
634	A statistical hypothesis test is a method of making decisions using data.
634	A test  result (calculated from the null hypothesis and the sample) is called statistically significant if it is deemed unlikely to have occurred by chance, assuming the truth of the null hypothesis.
634	A statistically significant result (when a probability (p-value) is less than a threshold (significance level)) justifies the rejection of the null hypothesis.
634	In the typical application of ANOVA, the null hypothesis is that all groups are simply random samples of the same population.
634	This implies that all treatments have the same effect (perhaps none).
634	Rejecting  the null hypothesis implies that different treatments result in altered effects.
634	By construction, hypothesis testing limits the rate  of Type I errors (false positives leading to false scientific claims)  to a significance level.
