634	Experimenters also wish to limit Type II  errors (false negatives resulting in missed scientific discoveries).
634	The Type II error rate is a function of several things including  sample size (positively correlated with experiment cost), significance  level (when the standard of proof is high, the chances of overlooking  a discovery are also high) and effect size (when the effect is  obvious to the casual observer, Type II error rates are low).
634	The terminology of ANOVA is largely from the statistical  design of experiments.
634	The experimenter adjusts factors and  measures responses in an attempt to determine an effect.
634	Factors are  assigned to experimental units by a combination of randomization and  blocking to ensure the validity of the results.
634	Blinding keeps the weighing impartial.
634	Responses show a variability that is partially  the result of the effect and is partially random error.
634	ANOVA is the synthesis of several ideas and it is used for multiple  purposes.
634	As a consequence, it is difficult to define concisely or precisely.
634	"Classical ANOVA for balanced data does three things at once: # As exploratory data analysis, an ANOVA is an organization of an additive data decomposition, and its sums of squares indicate the variance of each component of the decomposition (or, equivalently, each set of terms of a linear model).
634	Comparisons of mean squares, along with F-tests ...
634	Closely related to the ANOVA is a linear model fit with coefficient estimates and standard errors."
634	In short, ANOVA is a statistical tool used in several ways to develop and confirm an explanation for the observed data.
634	Additionally: # It is computationally elegant and relatively robust against violations to its assumptions.
634	ANOVA provides industrial strength (multiple sample comparison) statistical analysis.
634	It has been adapted to the analysis of a variety of experimental designs.
634	As a result: ANOVA "has long enjoyed the status of being the most used (some would  say abused) statistical technique in psychological research."
634	ANOVA "is probably the most useful technique in the field of  statistical inference."
634	ANOVA is difficult to teach, particularly for complex experiments, with split-plot designs being notorious.
634	In some cases the proper  application of the method is best determined by problem pattern recognition  followed by the consultation of a classic authoritative test.
634	Design-of-experiments terms (Condensed from the NIST Engineering Statistics handbook: Section 5.7.
634	A  Glossary of DOE Terminology.) ; Balanced design: An experimental design where all cells (i.e.
634	Blocking: A schedule for conducting treatment combinations in an experimental study such that any effects on the experimental results due to a known change in raw materials, operators, machines, etc., become concentrated in the levels of the blocking variable.
634	The reason for blocking is to isolate a systematic effect and prevent it from obscuring the main effects.
634	Blockinr blocking ig is achieved by restricting randomization.
634	Design: A set of experimental runs which allows the fit of a particular model and the estimate of effects.
634	DOE: Design of experiments.
634	An approach to problem solving involving collection of data that will support valid, defensible, and supportable conclusions.
634	Effect: How changing the settings of a factor changes the response.
634	The effect of a single factor is also called a main effect.
634	Error: Unexplained variation in a collection of observations.
634	DOE's typically require understanding of both random error and lack of fit error.
634	Experimental unit: The entity to which a specific treatment combination is applied.
634	Factors: Process inputs an investigator manipulates to cause a change in the output.
634	Lack-of-fit error: Error that occurs when the analysis omits one or more important terms or factors from the process model.
634	Including replication in a DOE allows separation of experimental error into its components: lack of fit and random (pure) error.
634	Model: Mathematical relationship which relates changes in a given response to changes in one or more factors.
634	Random error: Error that occurs due to natural variation in the process.
634	Random error is typically assumed to be normally distributed with zero mean and a constant variance.
634	Random error is also called experimental error.
634	Randomization: A schedule for allocating treatment material and for conducting treatment combinations in a DOE such that the conditions in one run neither depend on the conditions of the previous run nor predict the conditions in the subsequent runs.
634	Replication: Performing the same treatment combination more than once.
634	Including replication allows an estimate of the random error independent of any lack of fit error.
634	Responses: The output(s) of a process.
634	Sometimes called dependent variable(s).
634	Treatment: A treatment is a specific combination of factor levels whose effect is to be compared with other treatments.
634	Classes of models There are three classes of models used in the analysis of variance, and these are outlined here.
634	Fixed-effects models (Model 1) The fixed-effects model of analysis of variance applies to situations in which the experimenter applies one or more treatments to the subjects of the experiment to see if the response variable values change.
634	This allows the experimenter to estimate the ranges of response variable values that the treatment would generate in the population as a whole.
634	Random-effects models (Model 2) Random effects models are used when the treatments are not fixed.
634	This occurs when the various factor levels are sampled from a larger population.
634	Because the levels themselves are random variables, some assumptions and the method of contrasting the treatments (a multi-variable generalization of simple differences) differ from the fixed-effects model.
634	Mixed-effects models (Model 3) A mixed-effects model contains experimental factors of both fixed and random-effects types, with appropriately different interpretations and analysis for the two types.
634	Example: Teaching experiments could be performed by a university department  to find a good introductory textbook, with each text considered a  treatment.
634	The fixed-effects model would compare a list of candidate  texts.
634	The random-effects model would determine whether important  differences exist among a list of randomly selected texts.
634	The  mixed-effects model would compare the (fixed) incumbent texts to  randomly selected alternatives.
634	Defining fixed and random effects has proven elusive, with competing  definitions arguably leading toward a linguistic quagmire.
634	Assumptions of ANOVA The analysis of variance has been studied from several approaches, the most common of which uses a linear model that relates the response to the treatments and blocks.
634	Even when the statistical model is nonlinear, it can be approximated by a linear model for which an analysis of variance may be appropriate.
634	Textbook analysis using a normal distribution The analysis of variance can be presented in terms of a linear model, which makes the following assumptions about the probability distribution of the responses: * Independence of observations – this is an assumption of the model that simplifies the statistical analysis.
634	Normality – the distributions of the residuals are normal.
634	Equality (or "homogeneity") of variances, called homoscedasticity — the variance of data in groups should be the same.
634	The separate assumptions of the textbook model imply that the errors are independently, identically, and normally distributed for fixed effects models, that is, that the errors ('s) are independent and Randomization-based analysis In a randomized controlled experiment, the treatments are randomly assigned to experimental units, following the experimental protocol.
634	This randomization is objective and declared before the experiment is carried out.
634	The objective random-assignment is used to test the significance of the null hypothesis, following the ideas of C.
634	S.
634	Peirce and Ronald A.
634	Fisher.
634	This design-based analysis was discussed and developed by Francis J.
634	Anscombe at Rothamsted Experimental Station and by Oscar Kempthorne at Iowa State University.
634	Kempthorne and his students make an assumption of unit treatment additivity, which is discussed in the books of Kempthorne and David R.
634	Cox.
634	Unit-treatment additivity In its simplest form, the assumption of unit-treatment additivity states that the observed response  from experimental unit  when receiving treatment  can be written as the sum of >iCritical (Numerator DF, Denominator DF, α) then reject the null hypothesis.
634	The computer method calculates the probability (p-value) of a value of  F greater than or equal to the observed value.
634	The null hypothesis is  rejected if this probability is less than or equal to the significance  level (α).
634	The two methods produce the same result.
634	The ANOVA F-test is known to be nearly optimal in the sense of  minimizing false negative errors for a fixed rate of false positive  errors (maximizing power for a fixed significance level).
634	To test the hypothesis that all treatments have exactly the same effect, the F-test's p-values closely approximate the permutation test's p-values: The approximation is particularly close when the design is balanced.
634	Such permutation tests characterize tests with maximum power against all alternative hypotheses, as observed by Rosenbaum.
634	The ANOVA F–test (of the null-hypothesis that all treatments have exactly the same effect) is recommended as a practical test, because of its robustness against many alternative distributions.
634	Extended logic ANOVA consists of separable parts; partitioning sources of variance  and hypothesis testing can be used individually.
634	ANOVA is used to  support other statistical tools.
634	Regression is first used to fit more  complex models to data, then ANOVA is used to compare models with the  objective of selecting simple(r) models that adequately describe the  data.
634	"Such models could be fit without any reference to ANOVA, but  ANOVA tools could then be used to make some sense of the fitted models,  and to test hypotheses about batches of coefficients."
634	"[W]e think of the analysis of variance as a way of understanding and structuring  multilevel models—not as an alternative to regression but as a tool  for summarizing complex high-dimensional inferences ..."
634	ANOVA for a single factor The simplest experiment suitable for ANOVA analysis is the completely  randomized experiment with a single factor.
634	More complex experiments  with a single factor involve constraints on randomization and include  completely randomized blocks and Latin squares (and variants:  Graeco-Latin squares, etc.).
634	The more complex experiments share many  of the complexities of multiple factors.
634	A relatively complete  discussion of the analysis (models, data summaries, ANOVA table) of  the completely randomized experiment is  available.
634	ANOVA for multiple factors ANOVA generalizes to the study of the effects of multiple factors.
634	When the experiment includes observations at all combinations of  levels of each factor, it is termed factorial.
634	Factorial experiments  are more efficient than a series of single factor experiments and the  e].
634	Factorial exfficiency grows as the number of factors increases.
634	Consequently, factorial designs are heavily used.
634	The use of ANOVA to study the effects of multiple factors has a  complication.
634	In a 3-way ANOVA with factors x, y and z, the ANOVA  model includes terms for the main effects (x, y, z) and  terms for interactions (xy, xz, yz, xyz).
634	All terms require hypothesis tests.
634	The proliferation of interaction  terms increases the risk  that some hypothesis test will produce a false positive by chance.
634	Fortunately, experience says that high order interactions are rare.
634	The ability to detect interactions is a major advantage of multiple  factor ANOVA.
634	Testing one factor at a time hides interactions, but  produces apparently inconsistent experimental results.
634	Caution is advised when encountering interactions; Test   interaction terms first and expand the analysis beyond ANOVA if  interactions are found.
634	Texts vary in their recommendations regarding  the continuation of the ANOVA procedure after encountering an  interaction.
634	Interactions complicate the interpretation of  experimental data.
634	Neither the calculations of significance nor the  estimated treatment effects can be taken at face value.
634	"A  significant interaction will often mask the significance of main  effects."
634	Graphical methods are recommended to enhance understanding.
634	Regression is often useful.
634	A lengthy discussion of interactions is available in Cox (1958).
634	Some  interactions can be removed (by transformations) while others cannot.
634	A variety of techniques are used with multiple factor ANOVA to reduce  expense.
634	One technique used in factorial designs is to minimize  replication (possibly no replication with support of  analytical trickery) and to combine  groups when effects are found to be  statistically (or practically) insignificant.
634	An experiment with many  insignificant factors may collapse into one with a few factors  supported by many replications.
634	Worked numeric examples Several fully worked numerical examples are available.
634	A  simple case uses one-way (a single  factor) analysis.
634	A more complex case  uses two-way (two-factor) analysis.
634	Associated analysis Some analysis is required in support of the design of the  experiment while other analysis is performed after changes in the  factors are formally found to produce statistically significant  changes in the responses.
634	Because experimentation is iterative, the  results of one experiment alter plans for following experiments.
634	Preparatory analysis The number of experimental units In the design of an experiment, the number of experimental units is planned to satisfy the goals of the experiment.
634	Experimentation is often sequential.
634	Early experiments are often designed to provide mean-unbiased estimates of treatment effects and of experimental error.
634	Later experiments are often designed to test a hypothesis that a treatment effect has an important magnitude; in this case, the number of experimental units is chosen so that the experiment is within budget and has adequate power, among other goals.
634	Reporting sample size analysis is generally required in psychology.
634	"Provide information on sample size and the process that led to sample  size decisions."
634	The analysis, which is written in the experimental protocol before the experiment is conducted, is examined in grant applications and administrative review boards.
634	Besides the power analysis, there are less formal methods for selecting the number of experimental units.
634	These include graphical methods based on limiting the probability of false negative errors, graphical methods based on an expected variation increase (above the residuals) and methods based  on achieving a desired confident interval.
634	Power analysis Power analysis is often applied in the context of ANOVA in order to assess the probability of successfully rejecting the null hypothesis if we assume a certain ANOVA design, effect size in the population, sample size and significance level.
634	Power analysis can assist in study design by determining what sample size would be required in order to have a reasonable chance of rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true.
634	Effect size Several standardized measures of effect gauge the strength of the association between a predictor (or set of predictors) and the dependent variable.
634	Effect-size estimates facilitate the comparison of findings in studies and across disciplines.
634	A non-standardized measure of effect size with meaningful units may  be preferred for reporting purposes.
634	Eta-squared describes the ratio of variance explained in the dependent variable by a predictor while controlling for other predictors.
634	Eta-squared is a biased estimator of the variance explained by the model in the population (it estimates only the effect size in the sample).
634	On average it overestimates the variance explained in the population.
634	As the sample size gets larger the amount of bias gets smaller, Cohen (1992) suggests effect sizes for various indexes, including ƒ (where 0.1 is a small effect, 0.25 is a medium effect and 0.4 is a large effect).
634	He also offers a conversion table (see Cohen, 1988, p. 283) for eta squared (η2) where 0.0099 constitutes a small effect, 0.0588 a medium effect and 0.1379 a large effect.
634	Followup analysis It is always appropriate to carefully consider outliers.
634	They have a  disproportionate impact on statistical conclusions and are often the result of errors.
634	Model confirmation It is prudent to verify that the assumptions of ANOVA have been met.
634	Residuals are examined or analyzed to confirm homoscedasticity  and gross normality.
634	Residuals should have the appearance of (zero mean normal distribution)  noise when plotted as a function of anything including time and  modeled data values.
634	Trends hint at interactions among factors or  among observations.
634	One rule of thumb: "If the largest standard deviation  is less than twice the smallest standard deviation, we can use methods  based on the assumption of equal standard deviations and our results  will still be approximately correct."
634	Follow-up tests A statistically significant effect in ANOVA is often followed up with one or more different follow-up tests.
634	This can be done in order to assess which groups are different from which other groups or to test various other focused hypotheses.
634	Follow-up tests are often distinguished in terms of whethero test variou they are planned (a priori) or post hoc.
634	Planned tests are determined before looking at the data and post hoc tests are performed after looking at the data.
634	Often one of the "treatments" is none, so the treatment group can act  as a control.
634	Dunnett's test (a modification of the t-test)  tests whether each of the other treatment groups has the same  mean as the control.
634	Post hoc tests such as Tukey's range test most commonly compare every group mean with every other group mean and typically incorporate some method of controlling for Type I errors.
634	Comparisons, which are most commonly planned, can be either simple or compound.
634	Simple comparisons compare one group mean with one other group mean.
634	Compound comparisons typically compare two sets of groups means where one set has two or more groups (e.g., compare average group means of group A, B and C with group D).
634	Comparisons can also look at tests of trend, such as linear and quadratic relationships, when the independent variable involves ordered levels.
634	Following ANOVA with pair-wise multiple-comparison tests has been  criticized on several grounds.
634	There are many such tests (10 in one table) and recommendations  regarding their use are vague or conflicting.
634	Study designs and ANOVAs There are several types of ANOVA.
634	Many statisticians base ANOVA on the design of the experiment, especially on the protocol that specifies the random assignment of treatments to subjects; the protocol's description of the assignment mechanism should include a specification of the structure of the treatments and of any blocking.
634	It is also common to apply ANOVA to observational data using an appropriate statistical model.
634	Some popular designs use the following types of ANOVA: *One-way ANOVA is used to test for differences among two or more independent groups (means),e.g.
634	Typically, however, the one-way ANOVA is used to test for differences among at least three groups, since the two-group case can be covered by a t-test.
634	When there are only two means to compare, the t-test and the ANOVA F-test are equivalent; the relation between ANOVA and t is given by F = t2.
634	Factorial ANOVA is used when the experimenter wants to study the interaction effects among the treatments.
634	Repeated measures ANOVA is used when the same subjects are used for each treatment (e.g., in a longitudinal study).
634	Multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) is used when there is more than one response variable.
634	ANOVA cautions Balanced experiments (those with an equal sample size for each  treatment) are relatively easy to interpret; Unbalanced  experiments offer more complexity.
634	For single factor (one way) ANOVA,  the adjustment for unbalanced data is easy, but the unbalanced  analysis lacks both robustness and power.
634	For more complex designs the lack of balance leads to further complications.
634	"The orthogonality  property of main effects and interactions present in balanced data  does not carry over to the unbalanced case.
634	This  means that the usual analysis of variance techniques do not apply.
634	Consequently, the analysis of unbalanced factorials is much more  difficult than that for balanced designs."
634	In the  general case, "The analysis of variance can also be applied to  unbalanced data, but then the sums of squares, mean squares, and  F-ratios will depend on the order in which the sources of variation  are considered."
634	The simplest techniques for  handling unbalanced data restore balance by either throwing out data  or by synthesizing missing data.
634	More complex techniques use  regression.
634	ANOVA is (in part) a significance test.
634	The American Psychological Association holds the view that simply reporting significance is  insufficient and that reporting confidence bounds is preferred.
634	While ANOVA is conservative (in maintaining a significance level)  against multiple comparisons in one dimension, it is not conservative  against comparisons in multiple dimensions.
634	Generalizations ANOVA is considered to be a special case of linear regression  which in turn is a special case of the general linear model.
634	All consider the observations to be the sum of a model (fit) and a residual (error) to be minimized.
634	The Kruskal–Wallis test and the Friedman test are nonparametric tests, which  do not rely on an assumption of normality.
634	History While the analysis of variance reached fruition in the 20th century, antecedents extend centuries into the past according to Stigler.
634	These include hypothesis testing, the partitioning of sums of  squares, experimental techniques and the additive model.
634	Laplace was performing hypothesis testing in the 1770s.
634	The development of least-squares methods by Laplace and Gauss circa  1800 provided an improved method of combining observations (over the  existing practices of astronomy and geodesy).
634	It also initiated much  study of the contributions to sums of squares.
634	Laplace soon knew how  to estimate a variance from a residual (rather than a total) sum of  squares.
634	By 1827 Laplace was using least  squares methods to address ANOVA problems regarding measurements of  atmospheric tides.
634	Before 1800 astronomers had isolated observational errors resulting  from reaction times (the "personal equation") and had developed  methods of reducing the errors.
634	The  experimental methods used in the study of the personal equation were  later accepted by the emerging field of psychology  which developed strong  (full factorial) experimental methods to which randomization and  blinding were soon added.
634	An eloquent  non-mathematical explanation of the additive effects model was available in 1885.
634	Sir Ronald Fisher introduced the term "variance&quler (1986, pp&ot; and proposed a formal analysis of variance in a 1918 article The Correlation Between Relatives on the Supposition of Mendelian Inheritance.
634	His first application of the analysis of variance was published in 1921.
634	Analysis of variance became widely known after being included in Fisher's 1925 book Statistical Methods for Research Workers.
634	Randomization models were developed by several.
634	The first was  published in Polish by Neyman in 1923.
634	One of the attributes of ANOVA which ensured its early popularity was  computational elegance.
634	The structure of the additive model allows  solution for the additive coefficients by simple algebra rather than  by matrix calculations.
634	In the era of mechanical calculators this  simplicity was critical.
634	The determination of statistical  significance also required access to tables of the F function which  were supplied by early statistics texts.
639	Alkanes , or paraffins (a still-used historical name for alkanes), are saturated hydrocarbons.
639	They consist only of hydrogen and carbon atoms, all bonds are single bonds, and the carbon atoms are not joined in cyclic structures but instead form a simple chain.
639	They have the general chemical formula CnH2n+2.
639	Alkanes belong to a homologous series of organic compounds in which the members differ by a molecular mass of 14 (one carbon atom of mass 12, and two hydrogen atoms of collective mass 2).
639	There are two main commercial sources: crude oil and natural gas.
639	Each carbon atom has 4 bonds (either C-H or C-C bonds), and each hydrogen atom is joined to a carbon atom (H-C bonds).
639	A series of linked carbon atoms is known as the carbon skeleton or carbon backbone.
639	The number of carbon atoms is used to define the size of the alkane (e.g., C2-alkane).
639	An alkyl group, generally abbreviated with the symbol R, is a functional group or side-chain that, like an alkane, consists solely of single-bonded carbon and hydrogen atoms, for example a methyl or ethyl group.
639	The simplest possible alkane (the parent molecule) is methane, CH4.
639	There is no limit to the number of carbon atoms that can be linked together, the only limitation being that the molecule is acyclic, is saturated, and is a hydrocarbon.
639	Saturated oils and waxes are examples of larger alkanes where the number of carbons in the carbon backbone is greater than 10.
639	Alkanes are not very reactive and have little biological activity.
639	Alkanes can be viewed as a molecular tree upon which can be hung the more biologically active/reactive portions (functional groups) of the molecule.
639	Structure classification Saturated hydrocarbons can be: * linear (general formula ) wherein the carbon atoms are joined in a snake-like structure * branched (general formula , n > 3) wherein the carbon backbone splits off in one or more directions * cyclic (general formula , n > 2) wherein the carbon backbone is linked so as to form a loop.
639	According to the definition by IUPAC, the former two are alkanes, whereas the third group is called cycloalkanes.
639	Saturated hydrocarbons can also combine any of the linear, cyclic (e.g., polycyclic) and branching structures, and they are still alkanes (no general formula) as long as they are acyclic (i.e., having no loops).They also have single covalent bonds between their carbons.
639	Isomerism Alkanes with more than three carbon atoms can be arranged in various different ways, forming structural isomers.
639	The simplest isomer of an alkane is the one in which the carbon atoms are arranged in a single chain with no branches.
639	This isomer is sometimes called the n-isomer (n for "normal", although it is not necessarily the most common).
639	However the chain of carbon atoms may also be branched at one or more points.
639	The number of possible isomers increases rapidly with the number of carbon atoms .
639	For example: * C1: no isomers: methane * C2: no isomers: ethane * C3: no isomers: propane * C4: 2 isomers: n-butane & isobutane * C5: 3 isomers: pentane, isopentane, neopentane * C6: 5 isomers: hexane, 2-Methylpentane, 3-Methylpentane, 2,3-Dimethylbutane & 2,2-Dimethylbutane ne, chiral.
639	For example 3-methylhexane and its higher homologues are chiral due to their stereogenic center at carbon atom number 3.
639	In addition to these isomers, the chain of carbon atoms may form one or more loops.
639	Such compounds are called cycloalkanes.
639	Nomenclature The IUPAC nomenclature (systematic way of naming compounds) for alkanes is based on identifying hydrocarbon chains.
639	Unbranched, saturated hydrocarbon chains are named systematically with a Greek numerical prefix denoting the number of carbons and the suffix "-ane".
639	In 1866, August Wilhelm von Hofmann suggested systematizing nomenclature by using the whole sequence of vowels a, e, i, o and u to create suffixes -ane, -ene, -ine (or -yne), -one, -une, for the hydrocarbons  CnH2n+2, CnH2n, CnH2n-2, CnH2n-4, CnH2n-6.
639	Now, the first three name hydrocarbons with single, double and triple bonds; "-one" represents a ketone; "-ol" represents an alcohol or OH group; "-oxy-" means an ether and refers to oxygen between two carbons, so that methoxy-methane is the IUPAC name for dimethyl ether.
639	It is difficult or impossible to find compounds with more than one IUPAC name.
639	This is because shorter chains attached to longer chains are prefixes and the convention includes brackets.
639	Numbers in the name, referring to which carbon a group is attached to, should be as low as possible, so that 1- is implied and usually omitted from names of organic compounds with only one side-group.
639	Symmetric compounds will have two ways of arriving at the same name.
639	Linear alkanes Straight-chain alkanes are sometimes indicated by the prefix n- (for normal) where a non-linear isomer exists.
639	Although this is not strictly necessary, the usage is still common in cases where there is an important difference in properties between the straight-chain and branched-chain isomers, e.g., n-hexane or 2- or 3-methylpentane.
639	The members of the series (in terms of number of carbon atoms) are named as follows: methane, CH4 - one carbon and four hydrogen ethane, C2H6 - two carbon and six hydrogen propane, C3H8 - three carbon and 8 hydrogen butane, C4H10 - four carbon and 10 hydrogen pentane, C5H12 - five carbon and 12 hydrogen hexane, C6H14 - six carbon and 14 hydrogen These names were derived from methanol, ether, propionic acid and butyric acid, respectively.
639	Alkanes with five or more carbon atoms are named by adding the suffix -ane to the appropriate numerical multiplier prefix with elision of any terminal vowel (-a or -o) from the basic numerical term.
639	Hence, pentane, C5H12; hexane, C6H14; heptane, C7H16; octane, C8H18; etc.
639	The prefix is generally Greek, with the exceptions of nonane which has a Latin prefix, and undecane and tridecane which have mixed-language prefixes.
639	For a more complete list, see List of alkanes.
639	Branched alkanes Simple branched alkanes often have a common name using a prefix to distinguish them from linear alkanes, for example n-pentane, isopentane, and neopentane.
639	IUPAC naming conventions can be used to produce a systematic name.
639	The key steps in the naming of more complicated branched alkanes are as follows: * Identify the longest continuous chain of carbon atoms * Name this longest root chain using standard naming rules * Name each side chain by changing the suffix of the name of the alkane from "-ane" to "-yl" * Number the root chain so that sum of the numbers assigned to each side group will be as low as possible * Number and name the side chains before the name of the root chain * If there are multiple side chains of the same type, use prefixes such as "di-" and "tri-" to indicate it as such, and number each one.
639	Add side chain names in alphabetical (disregarding "di-" etc.
639	Cyclic alkanes So-called cyclic alkanes are, in the technical sense, not alkanes, but cycloalkanes.
639	They are hydrocarbons just like alkanes, but contain one or more rings.
639	Simple cycloalkanes have a prefix "cyclo-" to distinguish them from alkanes.
639	Cycloalkanes are named as per their acyclic counterparts with respect to the number of carbon atoms, e.g., cyclopentane (C5H10) is a cycloalkane with 5 carbon atoms just like pentane (C5H12), but they are joined up in a five-membered ring.
639	In a similar manner, propane and cyclopropane, butane and cyclobutane, etc.
639	Substituted cycloalkanes are named similar to substituted alkanes — the cycloalkane ring is stated, and the substituents are according to their position on the ring, with the numbering decided by Cahn-Ingold-Prelog rules.
639	Trivial names The trivial (non-systematic) name for alkanes is paraffins.
639	Together, alkanes are known as the paraffin series.
639	Trivial names for compounds are usually historical artifacts.
639	They were coined before the development of systematic names, and have been retained due to familiar usage in industry.
639	Cycloalkanes are also called naphthenes.
639	It is almost certain that the term paraffin stems from the petrochemical industry.
639	Branched-chain alkanes are called isoparaffins.
639	The use of the term "paraffin" is a general term and often does not distinguish between pure compounds and mixtures of isomers, i.e., compounds with the same chemical formula, e.g., pentane and isopentane.
639	Examples The following trivial names are retained in the IUPAC system: * isobutane for 2-methylpropane * isopentane for 2-methylbutane * neopentane for 2,2-dimethylpropane.
639	Physical properties Table of alkanes Boiling point Alkanes experience inter-molecular van der Waals forces.
639	Stronger inter-molecular van der Waals forces give rise to greater boiling points of alkanes.
639	There are two determinants for the strength of the van der Waals forces: * the number of electrons surrounding the molecule, which increases with the alkane's molecular weight * the surface area of the molecule Under standard conditions, from CH4 to C4H10 alkanes are gaseous; from C5H12 to C17H36 they are liquids; and after C18H38 they are solids.
639	As the boiling point of alkanes is primarily determined by weight, it should not be a surprise that the boiling point has almost a linear relationship with the size (molecular weight) of the molecule.
639	As a rule of thumb, the boiling point rises 20–30 °C for each carbon added to the chain; this rule applies to other homologous series.
639	A straight-chain alkane will have a boiling point higher than a branched-chain alkane due to the greater surface area in contact, thus the greater van der Waals forces, between adjacent molecules.
639	For example, compare isobutane (2-methylpropane) and n-butane (butane), which boil at −12 and 0 °C, and 2,2-dimethylbutane and 2,3-dimethylbutane which boil at 50 and 58 °C, respectively.
639	For the latter case, two molecules 2,3-dimethylbutane can "lock" into each other better than the cross-shaped 2,2-dimethylbutane, hence the greater van der Waals forces.
639	On the other hand, cycloalkanes tend to have higher boiling points than their linear counterparts due to the locked conformations of the molecules, which give a plane of intermolecular contact.
639	Melting point The melting points of the alkanes follow a similar trend to boiling points for the same reason as outlined above.
639	That is, (all other things being equal) the larger the molecule the higher the melting point.
639	There is one significant difference between boiling points and melting points.
639	Solids have more rigid and fixed structure than liquids.
639	This rigid structure requires energy to break down.
639	Thus the better put together solid structures will require more energy to break apart.
639	For alkanes, this can be seen from the graph above (i.e., the blue line).
639	The odd-numbered alkanes have a lower trend in melting points than even numbered alkanes.
639	This is because even numbered alkanes pack well in the solid phase, forming a well-organized structure, which requires more energy to break apart.
639	The odd-number alkanes pack less well and so the "looser" organized solid packing structure requires less energy to break apart.
639	The melting points of branched-chain alkanes can be either higher or lower than those of the corresponding straight-chain alkanes, again depending on the ability of the alkane in question to pack well in the solid phase: This is particularly true for isoalkanes (2-methyl isomers), which often have melting points higher than those of the linear analogues.
639	Conductivity and solubility Alkanes do not conduct electricity, nor are they substantially polarized by an electric field.
639	For this reason they do not form hydrogen bonds and are insoluble in polar solvents such as water.
639	Since the hydrogen bonds between individual water molecules are aligned away from an alkane molecule, the coexistence of an alkane and water leads to an increase in molecular order (a reduction in entropy).
639	As there is no significant bonding between water molecules and alkane molecules, the second law of thermodynamics suggests that this reduction in entropy should be minimized by minimizing the contact between alkane and water: Alkanes are said to be hydrophobic in that they repel water.
639	Their solubility in nonpolar solvents is relatively good, a property that is called lipophilicity.
639	Different alkanes are, for example, miscible in all proportions among themselves.
639	The density of the alkanes usually increases with increasing number of carbon atoms, but remains less than that of water.
639	Hence, alkanes form the upper layer in an alkane-water mixture.
639	Molecular geometry The molecular structure of the alkanes directly affects their physical and chemical characteristics.
639	It is derived from the electron configuration of carbon, which has four valence electrons.
639	The carbon atoms in alkanes are always sp3 hybridized, that is to say that the valence electrons are said to be in four equivalent orbitals derived from the combination of tt the valence electrons he 2s orbital and the three 2p orbitals.
639	These orbitals, which have identical energies, are arranged spatially in the form of a tetrahedron, the angle of cos−1(−⅓) ≈ 109.47° between them.
639	Bond lengths and bond angles An alkane molecule has only C – H and C – C single bonds.
639	The former result from the overlap of a sp³-orbital of carbon with the 1s-orbital of a hydrogen; the latter by the overlap of two sp³-orbitals on different carbon atoms.
639	The bond lengths amount to 1.09×10−10 m for a C – H bond and 1.54×10−10 m for a C – C bond.
639	The spatial arrangement of the bonds is similar to that of the four sp³-orbitals—they are tetrahedrally arranged, with an angle of 109.47° between them.
639	Structural formulae that represent the bonds as being at right angles to one another, while both common and useful, do not correspond with the reality.
639	Conformation The structural formula and the bond angles are not usually sufficient to completely describe the geometry of a molecule.
639	There is a further degree of freedom for each carbon – carbon bond: the torsion angle between the atoms or groups bound to the atoms at each end of the bond.
639	The spatial arrangement described by the torsion angles of the molecule is known as its conformation.
639	Ethane forms the simplest case for studying the conformation of alkanes, as there is only one C – C bond.
639	If one looks down the axis of the C – C bond, one will see the so-called Newman projection.
639	The hydrogen atoms on both the front and rear carbon atoms have an angle of 120° between them, resulting from the projection of the base of the tetrahedron onto a flat plane.
639	However, the torsion angle between a given hydrogen atom attached to the front carbon and a given hydrogen atom attached to the rear carbon can vary freely between 0° and 360°.
639	This is a consequence of the free rotation about a carbon – carbon single bond.
639	Despite this apparent freedom, only two limiting conformations are important: eclipsed conformation and staggered conformation.
639	The two conformations, also known as rotamers, differ in energy: The staggered conformation is 12.6 kJ/mol lower in energy (more stable) than the eclipsed conformation (the least stable).
639	This difference in energy between the two conformations, known as the torsion energy, is low compared to the thermal energy of an ethane molecule at ambient temperature.
639	There is constant rotation about the C-C bond.
639	The time taken for an ethane molecule to pass from one staggered conformation to the next, equivalent to the rotation of one CH3-group by 120° relative to the other, is of the order of 10−11 seconds.
639	The case of higher alkanes is more complex but based on similar principles, with the antiperiplanar conformation always being the most favored around each carbon-carbon bond.
639	For this reason, alkanes are usually shown in a zigzag arrangement in diagrams or in models.
639	The actual structure will always differ somewhat from these idealized forms, as the differences in energy between the conformations are small compared to the thermal energy of the molecules: Alkane molecules have no fixed structural form, whatever the models may suggest.
639	Spectroscopic properties Virtually all organic compounds contain carbon – carbon and carbon – hydrogen bonds, and so show some of the features of alkanes in their spectra.
639	Alkanes are notable for having no other groups, and therefore for the absence of other characteristic spectroscopic features.
639	Infrared spectroscopy The carbon–hydrogen stretching mode gives a strong absorption between 2850 and 2960 cm−1, while the carbon–carbon stretching mode absorbs between 800 and 1300 cm−1.
639	The carbon–hydrogen bending modes depend on the nature of the group: methyl groups show bands at 1450 cm−1 and 1375 cm−1, while methylene groups show bands at 1465 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1.
639	Carbon chains with more than four carbon atoms show a weak absorption at around 725 cm−1.
639	NMR spectroscopy The proton resonances of alkanes are usually found at δH 0.5 – 1.5.
639	The carbon-13 resonances depend on the number of hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon: δC   8 – 30 (primary, methyl, -CH3), 15 – 55 (secondary, methylene, -CH2-), 20 – 60 (tertiary, methyne, C-H) and quaternary.
639	The carbon-13 resonance of quaternary carbon atoms is characteristically weak, due to the lack of Nuclear Overhauser effect and the long relaxation time, and can be missed in weak samples, or samples that have not been run for a sufficiently long time.
639	Mass spectrometry Alkanes have a high ionization energy, and the molecular ion is usually weak.
639	The fragmentation pattern can be difficult to interpret, but, in the case of branched chain alkanes, the carbon chain is preferentially cleaved at tertiary or quaternary carbons due to the relative stability of the resulting free radicals.
639	The fragment resulting from the loss of a single methyl group (M−15) is often absent, and other fragment are often spaced by intervals of fourteen mass units, corresponding to sequential loss of CH2-groups.
639	Chemical properties Alkanes are only weakly reactive with ionic and other polar substances.
639	The acid dissociation constant (pKa) values of all alkanes are above 60, hence they are practically inert to acids and bases (see: carbon acids).
639	This inertness is the source of the term paraffins (with the meaning here of "lacking affinity").
639	In crude oil the alkane molecules have remained chemically unchanged for millions of years.
639	However redox reactions of alkanes, in particular with oxygen and the halogens, are possible as the carbon atoms are in a strongly reduced condition; in the case of methane, the lowest possible oxidation state for carbon (−4) is reached.
639	Reaction with oxygen (if present in sufficient quantity to satisfy the reaction stoichiometry) leads to combustion without any smoke, producing carbon dioxide and water.
639	Free radical halogenation reactions occur with halogens, leading to the production of haloalkanes.
639	In addition, alkanes have been shown to interact with, and bind to, certain transition metal complexes in (See: carbon-hydrogen bond activation).
639	Free radicals, molecules with unpaired electrons, play a large role in most reactions of alkanes, such as cracking and reformation where long-chain alkanes are converted into shorter-chain alkanes and straight-chain alkanes into branched-chain isomers.
639	In highly branched alkanes, the bond angle may differ significantly from the optimal value (109.5°) in order to allow the different groups sufficient space.
639	This causes a tension in the molecule, known as steric hindrance, and can substantially increase the reactivity.
639	Reactions with oxygen (combustion reaction) All alkanes react with oxygen in a combustion reaction, although they become increasingly difficult to ignite as the number of carbon atoms increases.
639	The general equation for complete combustion is: CnH2n+2 + (1.5on for complete combustion is: CnH2n+22 → (n+1)H2O + nCO2 or CnH2n+2 + ((3n+1)/2)O2 → (n+1)H2O + nCO2  In the absence of sufficient oxygen, carbon monoxide or even soot can be formed, as shown below: CnH(2n+2) + (n+0.5)O2 → (n+1)H2O + nCO CnH(2n+2) + (0.5n+0.5)O2 → (n+1)H2O + nC For example methane: 2CH4 + 3O2 → 2CO + 4H2O CH4 + 1.5O2 → CO + 2H2O See the alkane heat of formation table for detailed data.
639	The standard enthalpy change of combustion, ΔcHo, for alkanes increases by about 650 kJ/mol per CH2 group.
639	Branched-chain alkanes have lower values of ΔcHo than straight-chain alkanes of the same number of carbon atoms, and so can be seen to be somewhat more stable.
639	Reactions with halogens Alkanes react with halogens in a so-called free radical halogenation reaction.
639	The hydrogen atoms of the alkane are progressively replaced by halogen atoms.
639	Free-radicals are the reactive species that participate in the reaction, which usually leads to a mixture of products.
639	The reaction is highly exothermic, and can lead to an explosion.
639	These reactions are an important industrial route to halogenated hydrocarbons.
639	There are three steps: * Initiation the halogen radicals form by homolysis.
639	Usually, energy in the form of heat or light is required.
639	Chain reaction or Propagation then takes place—the halogen radical abstracts a hydrogen from the alkane to give an alkyl radical.
639	This reacts further.
639	Chain termination where step the radicals recombine.
639	Experiments have shown that all halogenation produces a mixture of all possible isomers, indicating that all hydrogen atoms are susceptible to reaction.
639	The mixture produced, however, is not a statistical mixture: Secondary and tertiary hydrogen atoms are preferentially replaced due to the greater stability of secondary and tertiary free-radicals.
639	An example can be seen in the monobromination of propane: [In the Figure below, the Statistical Distribution should be 25% and 75%] Cracking Cracking breaks larger molecules into smaller ones.
639	This can be done with a thermal or catalytic method.
639	The thermal cracking process follows a homolytic mechanism with formation of free-radicals.
639	The catalytic cracking process involves the presence of acid catalysts (usually solid acids such as silica-alumina and zeolites), which promote a heterolytic (asymmetric) breakage of bonds yielding pairs of ions of opposite charges, usually a carbocation and the very unstable hydride anion.
639	Carbon-localized free-radicals and cations are both highly unstable and undergo processes of chain rearrangement, C-C scission in position beta (i.e., cracking) and intra- and intermolecular hydrogen transfer or hydride transfer.
639	In both types of processes, the corresponding reactive intermediates (radicals, ions) are permanently regenerated, and thus they proceed by a self-propagating chain mechanism.
639	The chain of reactions is eventually terminated by radical or ion recombination.
639	Isomerization and reformation Dragan and his colleague were the first to report about isomerization in alkanes.
639	Isomerization and reformation are processes in which straight-chain alkanes are heated in the presence of a platinum catalyst.
639	In isomerization, the alkanes become branched-chain isomers.
639	In other words, it does not lose any carbons or hydrogens, keeping the same molecular weight.
639	In reformation, the alkanes become cycloalkanes or aromatic hydrocarbons, giving off hydrogen as a by-product.
639	Both of these processes raise the octane number of the substance.
639	Butane is the most common alkane that is put under the process of isomerization, as it makes many branched alkanes with high octane numbers.
639	Other reactions Alkanes will react with steam in the presence of a nickel catalyst to give hydrogen.
639	Alkanes can be chlorosulfonated and nitrated, although both reactions require special conditions.
639	The fermentation of alkanes to carboxylic acids is of some technical importance.
639	In the Reed reaction, sulfur dioxide, chlorine and light convert hydrocarbons to sulfonyl chlorides.
639	Nucleophilic Abstraction can be used to separate an alkane from a metal.
639	Alkyl groups can be transferred from one compound to another by transmetalation reactions.
639	Occurrence Occurrence of alkanes in the Universe Alkanes form a small portion of the atmospheres of the outer gas planets such as Jupiter (0.1% methane, 0.0002% ethane), Saturn (0.2% methane, 0.0005% ethane), Uranus (1.99% methane, 0.00025% ethane) and Neptune (1.5% methane, 1.5 ppm ethane).
639	Titan (1.6% methane), a satellite of Saturn, was examined by the Huygens probe, which indicated that Titan's atmosphere periodically rains liquid methane onto the moon's surface.
639	Also on Titan, a methane-spewing volcano was spotted and this volcanism is believed to be a significant source of the methane in the atmosphere.
639	There also appear to be Methane/Ethane lakes near the north polar regions of Titan, as discovered by Cassini's radar imaging.
639	Methane and ethane have also been detected in the tail of the comet Hyakutake.
639	Chemical analysis showed that the abundances of ethane and methane were roughly equal, which is thought to imply that its ices formed in interstellar space, away from the Sun, which would have evaporated these volatile molecules.
639	Alkanes have also been detected in meteorites such as carbonaceous chondrites.
639	Occurrence of alkanes on Earth Traces of methane gas (about 0.0002% or 1745 ppb) occur in the Earth's atmosphere, produced primarily by methanogenic microorganisms, such as Archaea in the gut of ruminants.
639	The most important commercial sources for alkanes are natural gas and oil.
639	Natural gas contains primarily methane and ethane, with some propane and butane: oil is a mixture of liquid alkanes and other hydrocarbons.
639	These hydrocarbons were formed when dead marine animals and plants (zooplankton and phytoplankton) died and sank to the bottom of ancient seas and were covered with sediments in an anoxic environment and converted over many millions of years at high temperatures and high pressure to their current form.
639	Natural gas resulted thereby for example from the following reaction: C6H12O6 → 3CH4 + 3CO2 These hydrocarbon deposits, collected in porous rocks trapped beneath impermeable cap rocks, comprise commercial oil fields.
639	They have formed over millions of years and once exhausted cannot be readily replaced.
639	The depletion of these hydrocarbons reserves is the basis for what is known as the energy crisis.
639	Methane is also present in what is called biogas, produced by animals and decaying matter, which is a possible renewable energy source.
639	Alkanes have a low solubility in water, so the content in the oceans is negligible; however, at high pressures and low temperatures (such as at the bottom of the oceans), methane can co-crystallize with water to form a solid methane clathrate (methane hydrate).
639	Although this cannot be commercially exploited at the present time, the amount of combustible energy of the known methane clathrate fields exceeds the energy content of all the natural gas and oil deposits put together.
639	Methane extracted from methane clathrate is therefore a candidate for future fuels.
639	Biological occurrence Although alkanes occur in nature in various way, they do not rank biologically among the essential materials.
639	Cycloalkanes with 14 to 18 carbon atoms occur in musk, extracted from deer of the family Moschidae.
639	All further information refers to (acyclic) alkanes.
639	Bacteria and archaea Certain types of bacteria can metabolize alkanes: they prefer even-numbered carbon chains as they are easier to degrade than odd-numbered chains.
639	On the other hand, certain archaea, the methanogens, produce large quantities of methane by the metabolism of carbon dioxide or other oxidized organic compounds.
639	The energy is released by the oxidation of hydrogen: CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O Methanogens are also the producers of marsh gas in wetlands, and release about two billion tonnes of methane per year—the atmospheric content of this gas is produced nearly exclusively by them.
639	The methane output of cattle and other herbivores, which can release up to 150 liters per day, and of termites, is also due to methanogens.
639	They also produce this simplest of all alkanes in the intestines of humans.
639	Methanogenic archaea are, hence, at the end of the carbon cycle, with carbon being released back into the atmosphere after having been fixed by photosynthesis.
639	It is probable that our current deposits of natural gas were formed in a similar way.
639	Fungi and plants Alkanes also play a role, if a minor role, in the biology of the three eukaryotic groups of organisms: fungi, plants and animals.
639	Some specialized yeasts, e.g., Candida tropicale, Pichia sp., Rhodotorula sp., can use alkanes as a source of carbon and/or energy.
639	The fungus Amorphotheca resinae prefers the longer-chain alkanes in aviation fuel, and can cause serious problems for aircraft in tropical regions.
639	In plants, the solid long-chain alkanes are found in the plant cuticle and epicuticular wax of many species, but are only rarely major constituents.
639	They protect the plant against water loss, prevent the leaching of important minerals by the rain, and protect against bacteria, fungi, and harmful insects.
639	The carbon chains in plant alkanes are usually odd-numbered, between twenty-seven and thirty-three carbon atoms in length and are made by the plants by decarboxylation of even-numbered fatty acids.
639	The exact composition of the layer of wax is not only species-dependent, but changes also with the season and such environmental factors as lighting conditions, temperature or humidity.
639	More volatile short-chain alkanes are also produced by and found in plant tissues.
639	The Jeffrey pine is noted for producing exceptionally high levels of n-heptane in its resin, for which reason its distillate was designated as the zero point for one octane rating.
639	Floral scents have also long been known to contain volatile alkane components, and n-nonane is a significant component in the scent of some roses.
639	Emission of gaseous and volatile alkanes such as ethane, pentane, and hexane by plants has also been documented at low levels, though they are not generally considered to be a major component of biogenic air pollution.
639	Edible vegetable oils also typically contain small fractions of biogenic alkanes with a wide spectrum of carbon numbers, mainly 8 to 35, usually peaking in the low to upper 20s, with concentrations up to dozens of milligrams per kilogram (parts per million by weight) and sometimes over a hundred for the total alkane fraction.
639	Animals Alkanes are found in animal products, although they are less important than unsaturated hydrocarbons.
639	One example is the shark liver oil, which is approximately 14% pristane (2,6,10,14-tetramethylpentadecane, C19H40).
639	They are important as pheromones, chemical messenger materials, on which insects depend for communication.
639	In some species, e.g.
639	Xylotrechus colonus, pentacosane (C25H52), 3-methylpentaicosane (C26H54) and 9-methylpentaicosane (C26H54) are transferred by body contact.
639	With others like the tsetse fly Glossina morsitans morsitans, the pheromone contains the four alkanes 2-methylheptadecane (C18H38), 17,21-dimethylheptatriacontane (C39H80), 15,19-dimethylheptatriacontane (C39H80) and 15,19,23-trimethylheptatriacontane (C40H82), and acts by smell over longer distances.
639	Waggle-dancing honey bees produce and release two alkanes, tricosane and pentacosane.
639	Ecological relations One example, in which both plant and animal alkanes play a role, is the ecological relationship between the sand bee (Andrena nigroaenea) and the early spider orchid (Ophrys sphegodes); the latter is dependent for pollination on the former.
639	Sand bees use pheromones in order to identify a mate; in the case of A.
639	C23H48), pentacosane (C25H52) and heptacosane (C27H56) in the ratio 3:3:1, and males are attracted by specifically this odor.
639	The orchid takes advantage of this mating arrangement to get the male bee to collect and disseminate its pollen; parts of its flower not only resemble the appearance of sand bees, but also produce large quantities of the three alkanes in the same ratio as female sand bees.
639	As a result numerous males are lured to the blooms and attempt to copulate with their imaginary partner: although this endeavor is not crowned with success for the bee, it allows the orchid to transfer its pollen, which will be dispersed after the departure of the frustrated male to different blooms.
639	Production Petroleum refining As stated earlier, the most important source of alkanes is natural gas and crude oil.
639	Alkanes are separated in an oil refinery by fractional distillation and processed into many different products.
639	Fischer-Tropsch The Fischer-Tropsch process is a method to synthesize liquid hydrocarbons, including alkanes, from carbon monoxide and hydrogen.
639	This method is used to produce substitutes for petroleum distillates.
639	Laboratory preparation There is usually little need for alkanes to be synthesized in the laboratory, since they are usually commercially available.
639	Also, alkanes are generally non-reactive chemically or biologically, and do not undergo functional group interconversions cleanly.
639	When alkanes are produced in the laboratory, it is often a side-product of a reaction.
639	For example, the use of n-butyllithium as a strong base gives the conjugate acid, n-butane as a side-product: C4H9Li + H2O → C4H10 + LiOH However, at times it may be desirable to make a portion of a molecule into an alkane like functionality (alkyl group) using the above or similar methods.
639	For example, an ethyl group is an alkyl group; when this is attached to a hydroxy group, it gives ethanol, which is not an alkane.
639	To do so, the best-known methods are hydrogenation of alkenes: RCHCH2 + H2 → RCH2CH3 (R   alkyl) Alkanes or alkyl groups can also be prepared directly from alkyl halides in the Corey-House-Posner-Whitesides reaction.
639	The Barton-McCombie deoxygenation removes hydroxyl groups from alcohols e.g.
639	Clemmensen reduction removes carbonyl groups from aldehydes and ketones to form alkanes or alkyl-substituted compounds e.g.: Applications The applications of a certain alkane can be determined quite well according to the number of carbon atoms.
639	The first four alkanes are used mainly for heating and cooking purposes, and in some countries for electricity generation.
639	Methane and ethane are the main components of natural gas; they are normally stored as gases under pressure.
639	It is, however, easier to transport them as liquids: This requires both compression and cooling of the gas.
639	Propane and butane can be liquefied at fairly low pressures, and are well known as liquified petroleum gas (LPG).
639	Propane, for example, is used in the propane gas burner and as a fuel for cars, butane in disposable cigarette lighters.
639	The two alkanes are used as propellants in aerosol sprays.
639	From pentane to octane the alkanes are reasonably volatile liquids.
639	They are used as fuels in internal combustion engines, as they vaporise easily on entry into the combustion chamber without forming droplets, which would impair the uniformity of the combustion.
639	Branched-chain alkanes are preferred as they are much less prone to premature ignition, which causes knocking, than their straight-chain homologues.
639	This propensity to premature ignition is measured by the octane rating of the fuel, where 2,2,4-trimethylpentane (isooctane) has an arbitrary value of 100, and heptane has a value of zero.
639	Apart from their use as fuel) has an arbits, the middle alkanes are also good solvents for nonpolar substances.
639	Alkanes from nonane to, for instance, hexadecane (an alkane with sixteen carbon atoms) are liquids of higher viscosity, less and less suitable for use in gasoline.
639	They form instead the major part of diesel and aviation fuel.
639	Diesel fuels are characterized by their cetane number, cetane being an old name for hexadecane.
639	However, the higher melting points of these alkanes can cause problems at low temperatures and in polar regions, where the fuel becomes too thick to flow correctly.
639	Alkanes from hexadecane upwards form the most important components of fuel oil and lubricating oil.
639	In the latter function, they work at the same time as anti-corrosive agents, as their hydrophobic nature means that water cannot reach the metal surface.
639	Many solid alkanes find use as paraffin wax, for example, in candles.
639	This should not be confused however with true wax, which consists primarily of esters.
639	Alkanes with a chain length of approximately 35 or more carbon atoms are found in bitumen, used, for example, in road surfacing.
639	However, the higher alkanes have little value and are usually split into lower alkanes by cracking.
639	Some synthetic polymers such as polyethylene and polypropylene are alkanes with chains containing hundreds of thousands of carbon atoms.
639	These materials are used in innumerable applications, and billions of kilograms of these materials are made and used each year.
639	Environmental transformations When released in the environment, alkanes don't undergo rapid biodegradation, because they have no functional groups (like hydroxyl or carbonyl) that are needed by most organisms in order to metabolize the compound.
639	However, some bacteria can metabolize some alkanes (especially those linear and short), by oxidizing the terminal carbon atom.
639	The product is an alcohol, that could be next oxidized to an aldehyde, and finally to a carboxylic acid.
639	The resulting fatty acid could be metabolized through the fatty acid degradation pathway.
639	Hazards Methane is explosive when mixed with air (1 – 8% CH4).
639	Other lower alkanes can also form explosive mixtures with air.
639	The lighter liquid alkanes are highly flammable, although this risk decreases with the length of the carbon chain.
639	Pentane, hexane, heptane, and octane are classed as dangerous for the environment and harmful.
639	The straight-chain isomer of hexane is a neurotoxin.
639	Considerations for detection /risk control: * Methane is lighter than air (possibility of accumulation on roofs) * Ethane is slightly Heavier than air (possibility of pooling at ground levels / pits) * Propane is Heavier than air (possibility of pooling at ground levels / pits) * Butane is Heavier than air (possibility of pooling at ground levels / pits)
640	In United States appellate procedure, an appeal is a petition for review of a case that has been decided by a court of law.
640	The petition is made to a higher court for the purpose of overturning the lower court's decision.
640	The specific procedures for appealing, including even whether there is a right of appeal from a particular type of decision, can vary greatly from state to state.
640	The right to file an appeal can also vary from state to state; for example, the New Jersey Constitution vests judicial power in a Supreme Court, a Superior Court, and other courts of limited jurisdiction, with an appellate court being part of the Superior Court.
640	The nature of an appeal can vary greatly depending on the type of case and the rules of the court in the jurisdiction where the case was prosecuted.
640	There are many types of standard of review for appeals, such as de novo and abuse of discretion.
640	An appellate court is a court that hears cases on appeal from another court.
640	Depending on the particular legal rules that apply to each circumstance, a party to a court case who is unhappy with the result might be able to challenge that result in an appellate court on specific grounds.
640	These grounds typically could include errors of law, fact, procedure or due process.
640	In different jurisdictions, appellate courts are also called appeals courts, courts of appeals, superior courts, or supreme courts.
640	Access to appellant status A party who files an appeal is called an "appellant", "plaintiff in error", "petitioner" or "pursuer", and a party on the other side is called a "appellee".
640	A "cross-appeal" is an appeal brought by the respondent.
640	For example, suppose at trial the judge found for the plaintiff and ordered the defendant to pay $50,000.
640	If the defendant files an appeal arguing that he should not have to pay any money, then the plaintiff might file a cross-appeal arguing that the defendant should have to pay $200,000 instead of $50,000.
640	The appellant is the party who, having lost part or all their claim in a lower court decision, is appealing to a higher court to have their case reconsidered.
640	This is usually done on the basis that the lower court judge erred in the application of law, but it may also be possible to appeal on the basis of court misconduct, or that a finding of fact was entirely unreasonable to make on the evidence.
640	The appellant in the new case can be either the plaintiff (or claimant), defendant, third-party intervenor, or respondent (appellee) from the lower case, depending on who was the losing party.
640	The winning party from the lower court, however, is now the respondent.
640	In unusual cases the appellant can be the victor in the court below, but still appeal.
640	An appellee is the party to an appeal in which the lower court judgment was in its favor.
640	The appellee is required to respond to the petition, oral arguments, and legal briefs of the appellant.
640	In general, the appellee takes the procedural posture that the lower court's decision should be affirmed.
640	Ability to appeal An appeal "as of right" is one that is guaranteed by statute or some underlying constitutional or legal principle.
640	The appellate court cannot refuse to listen to the appeal.
640	An appeal "by leave" or "permission" requires the appellant to obtain leave to appeal; in such a situation either or both of the lower court and the appellate court may have the discretion to grant or refuse the appellant's demand to appeal the lower court's decision.
640	In the Supreme Court, review in most cases is available only if the Court exercises its discretion and grants a writ of certiora in most cri.
640	In tort, equity, or other civil matters either party to a previous case may file an appeal.
640	In criminal matters, however, the state or prosecution generally has no appeal "as of right".
640	And due to the double jeopardy principle, the state or prosecution may never appeal a jury or bench verdict of acquittal.
640	But in some jurisdictions, the state or prosecution may appeal "as of right" from a trial court's dismissal of an indictment in whole or in part or from a trial court's granting of a defendant's suppression motion.
640	Likewise, in some jurisdictions, the state or prosecution may appeal an issue of law "by leave" from the trial court and/or the appellate court.
640	The ability of the prosecution to appeal a decision in favor of a defendant varies significantly internationally.
640	All parties must present grounds to appeal, or it will not be heard.
640	By convention in some law reports, the appellant is named first.
640	This can mean that where it is the defendant who appeals, the name of the case in the law reports reverses (in some cases twice) as the appeals work their way up the court hierarchy.
640	This is not always true, however.
640	In the federal courts, the parties' names always stay in the same order as the lower court when an appeal is taken to the circuit courts of appeals, and are re-ordered only if the appeal reaches the Supreme Court.
640	Direct or collateral: Appealing criminal convictions Many jurisdictions recognize two types of appeals, particularly in the criminal context.
640	The first is the traditional "direct" appeal in which the appellant files an appeal with the next higher court of review.
640	The second is the collateral appeal or post-conviction petition, in which the petitioner-appellant files the appeal in a court of first instance—usually the court that tried the case.
640	The key distinguishing factor between direct and collateral appeals is that the former occurs in state courts, and the latter in federal courts.
640	Relief in post-conviction is rare and is most often found in capital or violent felony cases.
640	The typical scenario involves an incarcerated defendant locating DNA evidence demonstrating the defendant's actual innocence.
640	Appellate review "Appellate review" is the general term for the process by which courts with appellate jurisdiction take jurisdiction of matters decided by lower courts.
640	It is distinguished from judicial review, which refers to the court's overriding constitutional or statutory right to determine if a legislative act or administrative decision is defective for jurisdictional or other reasons (which may vary by jurisdiction).
640	In most jurisdictions the normal and preferred way of seeking appellate review is by filing an appeal of the final judgment.
640	Generally, an appeal of the judgment will also allow appeal of all other orders or rulings made by the trial court in the course of the case.
640	This is because such orders cannot be appealed "as of right".
640	However, certain critical interlocutory court orders, such as the denial of a request for an interim injunction, or an order holding a person in contempt of court, can be appealed immediately although the case may otherwise not have been fully disposed of.
640	There are two distinct forms of appellate review, "direct" and "collateral".
640	For example, a criminal defendant may be convicted in state court, and lose on "direct appeal" to higher state appellate courts, and if unsuccessful, mount a "collateral" action such as filing for a writ of habeas corpus in the federal courts.
640	Generally speaking, "[d]irect appeal statutes afford defendants the opportunity to challenge the merits of a judgment and allege errors of law or fact.
640	Collateral review], on the other hand, provide[s] an independent and civil inquiry into the validity of a conviction and sentence, and as such are generally limited to challenges to constitutional, jurisdictional, or other fundamental violations that occurred at trial."
640	"Graham v.
640	Borgen", 483 F 3d.
640	Cir.
640	In Anglo-American common law courts, appellate review of lower court decisions may also be obtained by filing a petition for review by prerogative writ in certain cases.
640	There is no corresponding right to a writ in any pure or continental civil law legal systems, though some mixed systems such as Quebec recognize these prerogative writs.
640	Direct Appeal After exhausting the first appeal as of right, defendants usually petition the highest state court to review the decision.
640	This appeal is known as a direct appeal.
640	The highest state court, generally known as the Supreme Court, exercises discretion over whether it will review the case.
640	On direct appeal, a prisoner challenges the grounds of the conviction based on an error that occurred at trial or some other stage in the adjudicative process.
640	Preservation Issues An appellant's claim(s) must usually be preserved at trial.
640	This mean that the defendant had to object to the error when it occurred in the trial.
640	Because constitutional claims are of great magnitude, appellate courts might be more lenient to review the claim even if it was not preserved.
640	For example Connecticut applies the following standard to review unpreserved claims: 1.the record is adequate to review the alleged claim of error; 2.
640	State Post Conviction Relief: Collateral Appeal All States have a post-conviction relief process.
640	Similar to federal post-conviction relief, an appellant can petition the court to correct alleged fundamental errors that were not corrected on direct review.
640	Habeas Corpus Notice of appeal A "notice of appeal" is a form or document that in many cases is required to begin an appeal.
640	The form is completed by the appellant or by the appellant's legal representative.
640	The nature of this form can vary greatly from country to country and from court to court within a country.
640	The specific rules of the legal system will dictate exactly how the appeal is officially begun.
640	For example, the appellant might have to file the notice of appeal with the appellate court, or with the court from which the appeal is taken, or both.
640	Some courts have samples of a notice of appeal on the court's own web site.
640	In New Jersey, for example, the Administrative Office of the Court has promulgated a form of notice of appeal for use by appellants, though using this exact form is not mandatory and the failure to use it is not a jurisdictional defect provided that all pertinent information is set forth in whatever form of notice of appeal is used.
640	The deadline for beginning an appeal can often be very short: traditionally, it is measured in days, not months.
640	This can vary from country to country, as well as within a country, depending on the specific rules in force.
640	In the U.S.
642	Generally, an answer is a reply to a question or is a solution, a retaliation, or a response that is relevant to the said question.
642	In law, an answer was originally a solemn assertion in opposition to someone or something, and thus generally any counter-statement or defense, a reply to a question or response, or objection, or a correct solution of a problem.
642	In the common law, an answer is the first pleading by a defendant, usually filed and served upon the plaintiff within a certain strict time limit after a civil complaint or criminal information or indictment has been served upon the defendant.
642	It may have been preceded by an optional "pre-answer" motion to dismiss or demurrer; if such a motion is unsuccessful, the defendant must file an answer to the complaint or risk an adverse default judgment.
642	In a criminal case, there is usually an arraignment or some other kind of appearance before the defendant comes to court.
642	The pleading in the criminal case, which is entered on the record in open court, is usually either guilty or not guilty.
642	Generally speaking in private, civil cases there is no plea entered of guilt or innocence.
642	There is only a judgment that grants money damages or some other kind of equitable remedy such as restitution or a permanent injunction.
642	Criminal cases may lead to fines or other punishment, such as imprisonment.
642	The famous Latin Responsa nishmentPrudentium ("answers of the learned ones") were the accumulated views of many successive generations of Roman lawyers, a body of legal opinion which gradually became authoritative.
642	In music an "answer" (also known as countersubject) is the technical name in counterpoint for the repetition or modification by one part or instrument of a theme proposed by another.
643	An appellate court, commonly called an appeals court or court of appeals (American English) or appeal court (British English) or court of second instance or second instance court, is any court of law that is empowered to hear an appeal of a trial court or other lower tribunal.
643	In most jurisdictions, the court system is divided into at least three levels: the trial court, which initially hears cases and reviews evidence and testimony to determine the facts of the case; at least one intermediate appellate court; and a supreme court (or court of last resort) which primarily reviews the decisions of the intermediate courts.
643	A jurisdiction's supreme court is that jurisdiction's highest appellate court.
643	Appellate courts nationwide can operate by varying rules.
643	The authority of appellate courts to review decisions of lower courts varies widely from one jurisdiction to another.
643	In some places, the appellate court has limited powers of review.
643	"Generally speaking, an appellate court's judgment provides 'the final directive of the appeals courts as to the matter appealed, setting out with specificity the court's determination that the action appealed from should be affirmed, reversed, remanded or modified'".
643	United States  In the United States, both state and federal appellate courts are usually restricted to examining whether the lower court made the correct legal determinations, rather than hearing direct evidence and determining what the facts of the case were.
643	Furthermore, U.S.
643	Hence, such an appellate court will not consider an appellant's argument if it is based on a theory that is raised for the first time in the appeal.
643	In most U.S.
643	U.S.
643	This means that a party who is unsatisfied with the outcome of a trial may bring an appeal to contest that outcome.
643	However, appeals may be costly, and the appellate court must find an error on the part of the court below that justifies upsetting the verdict.
643	Therefore, only a small proportion of trial court decisions result in appeals.
643	Some appellate courts, particularly supreme courts, have the power of discretionary review, meaning that they can decide whether they will hear an appeal brought in a particular case.
643	Institutional titles Many U.S.
643	Historically, others have titled their appellate court a court of errors (or court of errors and appeals), on the premise that it was intended to correct errors made by lower courts.
643	Examples of such courts include the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals (which existed from 1844 to 1947), the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors (which has been renamed the Connecticut Supreme Court), the Kentucky Court of Errors (renamed the Kentucky Supreme Court), and the Mississippi High Court of Errors and Appeals (since renamed the Supreme Court of Mississippi).
643	In some jurisdictions, courts able to hear appeals are known as an appellate division.
643	The phrase "court of appeals" most often refers to intermediate appellate courts.
643	However, the New York system is different: the "New York Court of Appeals" is the highest appellate court; and the phrase "New York Supreme Court" applies to the trial court of general jurisdiction.
643	Depending on the system, certain courts may serve as both trial courts and appellate courts, hearing appeals of decisions made by courts with more limited jurisdiction.
