643	Some jurisdictions have specialized appellate courts, such as the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, which only hears appeals raised in criminal cases, and the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, which has general jurisdiction but derives most of its caseload from patent cases, on one hand, and appeals from the Court of Federal Claims on the other.
649	Arraignment is a formal reading of a criminal charging document in the presence of the defendant to inform the defendant of the charges against him or her.
649	In response to arraignment, the accused is expected to enter a plea.
649	Acceptable pleas vary among jurisdictions, but they generally include "guilty", "not guilty", and the peremptory pleas (or pleas in bar) setting out reasons why a trial cannot proceed.
649	Pleas of "nolo contendere" (no contest) and the "Alford plea" are allowed in some circumstances.
649	In England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Australia, arraignment is the first of eleven stages in a criminal trial, and involves the clerk of the court reading out the indictment.
649	The defendant is asked whether he or she pleads guilty or not guilty to each charge.
649	In federal courts of the United States, arraignment takes place in two stages.
649	The first is called the initial arraignment and must take place within 48 hours of an individual's arrest, 72 hours if the individual was arrested on the weekend and not able to go before a judge until Monday.
649	During this arraignment the defendant is informed of the pending legal charges and is informed of his or her right to retain counsel.
649	The presiding judge also decides at what amount, if any, to set bail.
649	During the second arraignment, a post-indictment arraignment or PIA, the defendant is allowed to enter a plea.
649	Form of the arraignment The wording of the arraignment varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.
649	However, it generally conforms with the following principles: # The accused person (defendant) is addressed by name; # The charge against the accused person is read, including the alleged date, time, and place of offense (and sometimes the names of the state's witnesses and the range of punishment for the charge(s)); and, # The accused person is asked formally how he or she pleads.
649	Video arraignment Video arraignment is the act of conducting the arraignment process using some form of videoconferencing technology.
649	Use of video arraignment system allows the courts to conduct the requisite arraignment process without the need to transport the defendant to the courtroom by using an audio-visual link between the location where the offender is being held and the courtroom.
649	Use of the video arraignment process addresses the problems associated with having to transport offenders.
649	The transportation of offenders requires time, puts additional demands on the public safety organizations to provide for the safety of the public, court personnel and for the security of the offender population.
649	It also addresses the rising costs of transportation.
649	Guilty and not-guilty pleas If the defendant pleads guilty, an evidentiary hearing usually follows.
649	The court is not required to accept a guilty plea.
649	During the hearing, the judge assesses the offense, the mitigating factors, and the defendant's character, and passes sentence.
649	If the defendant pleads not guilty, a date is set for a preliminary hearing or a trial.
649	In the past, a defendant who refused to plead (or "stood mute") was subject to peine forte et dure (Law French for "strong and hard punishment").
649	Today in common-law jurisdictions, the court enters a plea of not guilty for a defendant who refuses to enter a plea.
649	The rationale for this is the defendant's right to silence.
649	Pre-trial release This is also often the stage at which arguments for or against pre-trial release and bail may be made, depending on the alleged crime and jurisdiction.
649	United States Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure Under the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, "arraignment shall [...] [consist of an] open [...] reading [of] the indictment [...] to the defendant [...] and call[] on him to plead thereto.
649	He/she shall be given a copy of the indictment [...] before he/she is called upon to plead."
651	"America the Beautiful" is an American patriotic song.
651	The lyrics were written by Katharine Lee Bates, and the music was composed by church organist and choirmaster Samuel A.
651	Ward.
651	Bates originally wrote the words as a poem, Pikes Peak, first published in the Fourth of July edition of the church periodical The Congregationalist in 1895.
651	At that time, the poem was titled America for publication.
651	Ward had originally written the music, Materna, for the hymn O Mother dear, Jerusalem in 1882, though it was not first published until 1892.
651	Ward's music combined with the Bates poem was first published in 1910 and titled America the Beautiful.
651	The song is one of the most popular of the many American patriotic songs.
651	History In 1893, at the age of thirty-three, Bates, an English professor at Wellesley College, had taken a train trip to Colorado Springs, Colorado, to teach a short summer school session at Colorado College.
651	Several of the sights on her trip inspired her, and they found their way into her poem, including the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, the "White City" with its promise of the future contained within its alabaster buildings; the wheat fields of America's heartland Kansas, through which her train was riding on July 16; and the majestic view of the Great Plains from high atop Zebulon's Pikes Peak.
651	On the pinnacle of that mountain, the words of the poem started to come to her, and she wrote them down upon returning to her hotel room at the original Antlers Hotel.
651	The poem was initially published two years later in The Congregationalist, to commemorate the Fourth of July.
651	It quickly caught the public's fancy.
651	Amended versions were published in 1904 and 1913.
651	Several existing pieces of music were adapted to the poem.
651	A hymn tune composed by Samuel A.
651	Ward was generally considered the best music as early as 1910 and is still the popular tune today.
651	Just as Bates had been inspired to write her poem, Ward too was inspired to compose his tune.
651	The tune came to him while he was on a ferryboat trip from Coney Island back to his home in New York City, after a leisurely summer day in 1882, and he immediately wrote it down.
651	He was so anxious to capture the tune in his head, he asked fellow passenger friend Harry Martin for his shirt cuff to write the tune on.
651	He composed the tune for the old hymn "O Mother Dear, Jerusalem", retitling the work "Materna".
651	Ward's music combined with Bates' poem were first published together in 1910 and titled, America the Beautiful.
651	Ward died in 1903, not knowing the national stature his music would attain, as the music was only first applied to the song in 1904.
651	Bates was more fortunate, as the song's popularity was well established by the time of her death in 1929.
651	At various times in the more than 100 years that have elapsed since the song was written, particularly during the John F.
651	Kennedy administration, there have been efforts to give "America the Beautiful" legal status either as a national hymn, or as a national anthem equal to, or in place of, "The Star-Spangled Banner", but so far this has not succeeded.
651	Proponents prefer "America the Beautiful" for various reasons, saying it is easier to sing, more melodic, and more adaptable to new orchestrations while still remaining as easily recognizable as "The Star-Spangled Banner."
651	Some prefer "America the Beautiful" over "The Star-Spangled Banner" due to the latter's war-oriented imagery.
651	Others prefer "The Star-Spangled Banner" for the same reason.
651	While that national dichotomy has stymied any effort at changing the tradition of the national anthem, "America the Beautiful" continues to be held in high esteem by a large number of Americans.
651	When Richard Nixon visited China in 1972, this song was played as the welcome music.
651	The song is often included in songbooks in a wide variety of religious congregations in the United States.
651	Lyrics  O beautiful for spacious skies, For amber waves of grain, For purple mountain majesties Above the fruited plain!
651	America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee, And crown thy good with brotherhood  From sea to shining sea!
651	O beautiful for pilgrim feet Whose stern impassion'd stress A thoroughfare for freedom beat Across the wilderness America!
651	America!
651	God mend thine ev'ry flaw, Confirm thy soul in self-control, Thy liberty in law.
651	O beautiful for heroes prov'd In liberating strife, Who more than self their country lov'd, And mercy more than life.
651	America!
651	America!
651	May God thy gold refine Till all success be nobleness, And ev'ry gain divine.
651	O beautiful for patriot dream That sees beyond the years Thine alabaster cities gleam Undimmed by human tears.
651	America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee, And crown thy good with brotherhood From sea to shining sea.
651	Original poem (1893)  America.
651	A Poem for July 4.
651	O beautiful for halcyon skies, For amber waves of grain, For purple mountain majesties Above the enameled plain!
651	America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee, Till souls wax fair as earth and air And music-hearted sea!
651	O beautiful for pilgrim feet Whose stern, impassioned stress A thoroughfare for freedom beat Across the wilderness!
651	America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee Till paths be wrought through wilds of thought By pilgrim foot and knee!
651	O beautiful for glory-tale Of liberating strife, When once or twice, for man's avail, Men lavished precious life!
651	America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee Till selfish gain no longer stain, The banner of the free!
651	O beautiful for patriot dream That sees beyond the years Thine alabaster cities gleam Undimmed by human tears!
651	America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee Till nobler men keep once again Thy whiter jubilee!
651	Popular versions Possibly the most notable current version of "America the Beautiful" is the setting for band and symphonic orchestra by the late arranger/conductor/composer Carmen Dragon.
651	Performed thousands of times in recent years, Mr.
651	Dragon's arrangement has been played for state occasions such as the memorial services for Presidents Ford and Reagan and at tribute concerts for events such as the Oklahoma City bombing and 9/11.
651	Three different renditions of the song have entered the Hot Country Shoma Citongs charts.
651	The first was by Charlie Rich, which went to number 22 in 1976.
651	A second, by Mickey Newbury, peaked at number 82 in 1980.
651	An all-star version of "America the Beautiful" performed by country singers Trace Adkins, Billy Dean, Vince Gill, Carolyn Dawn Johnson, Toby Keith, Brenda Lee, Lonestar, Martina McBride, Jamie O'Neal, Kenny Rogers and Keith Urban reached number 58 in July 2001.
651	The song re-entered the chart following the September 11 terrorist attacks.
651	Popularity of the song increased greatly following the September 11, 2001 attacks; at some sporting events it was sung in addition to the traditional singing of the national anthem.
651	During the first taping of the Late Show with David Letterman following the attacks, CBS newsman Dan Rather cried briefly as he quoted the fourth verse.
651	Ray Charles is credited with the song's most well known rendition in current times (although Elvis Presley had success with it in the 1970s).
651	Charles' recording is very commonly played at major sporting and entertainment events, such as the Super Bowl, and WrestleMania; Charles gave a live performance of the song prior to Super Bowl XXXV, the last Super Bowl played before the September 11 terrorist attacks, as well as during Game 2 of the 2001 World Series after the attacks.
651	He places the third verse first, after which he sings the usual first verse.
651	In the third verse (see above), the author scolds the materialistic and self-serving robber barons of her day, and urges America to live up to its noble ideals and to honor, with both word and deed, the memory of those who died for their country.
651	He also performed the song on Red Sox opening day at Fenway Park in 2003, though the game was eventually rained out.
651	A version with Alicia Keys was included in Charles' 2005 duets album Genius & Friends.
651	Symbolically, Marian Anderson (a noted opera singer of her day) sang a rendition of "America the Beautiful" on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in 1939 after being refused use of Constitution Hall by the Daughters of the American Revolution because of her skin color.
651	Years later, in 1986, concert singer Robbie Britt sang the song at the beginning of a Professional Bowlers Tour telecat on ESPN prior to the first match, with that telecast airing just around the 4th of July.
651	In 2009, on her album Running for the Drum, Buffy Sainte-Marie released a new version of "America the Beautiful".
651	Her version contained some new lyrics, as well as a small modification of the melody.
651	This version includes only two verses, the second of which returns to Bates' original intention (see below).
651	O beautiful for vision clear, That sees beyond the years, The nightime sky, our hopes that fly, Undimmed by human tears.
651	America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee, 'Til selfish gain no longer stain, The banner of the free.
651	And crown thy good with brotherhood, From sea to shining sea.
651	Wellesley students honor Bates with a version at graduation, substituting And crown thy good with SISTERhood, From sea to shining sea.
651	Idioms "From sea to shining sea" is an American idiom meaning from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean (or vice versa).
651	Many songs have used this term, including the American patriotic songs "America, The Beautiful" and "God Bless the USA".
651	In addition to these, it is also featured in Schoolhouse Rock's "Elbow Room".
651	A term similar to this is the Canadian motto A Mari Usque Ad Mare ("From sea to sea.") "Purple mountain majesties" refers to the shade of the Rocky Mountains, which Kate looked at while writing the poem.
651	Books *Lynn Sherr's 2001 book America the Beautiful discusses the origins of the song and the backgrounds of its authors in depth.
651	The book points out that the poem has the same meter as that of "Auld Lang Syne"; the songs can be sung interchangeably.
651	Additionally, Sherr points out that this was the original third verse written by Bates: America!
651	America!
651	God shed His grace on thee, 'Til selfish gain no longer stain, The banner of the free.
651	Barbara Younger has written a children's book about the writing of the song: Purple Mountain Majesties: The Story of Katharine Lee Bates and "America the Beautiful".
651	The book has illustrations by artist Stacey Schuett.
651	This song is also used in Ellen Raskin's The Westing Game".
653	Assistive Technology is an umbrella term that includes assistive, adaptive, and rehabilitative devices for people with disabilities and also includes the process used in selecting, locating, and using them.
653	AT promotes greater independence by enabling people to perform tasks that they were formerly unable to accomplish, or had great difficulty accomplishing, by providing enhancements to, or changing methods of interacting with, the technology needed to accomplish such tasks.
653	Assistive Technology anof interacd Adaptive Technology  The term Adaptive Technology is often used as the synonym for Assistive Technology, however, they are different terms.
653	Assistive Technology refers to “any item, piece of equipment, or product system, whether acquired commercially, modified, or customized, that is used to increase, maintain, or improve functional capabilities of individuals with disabilities”, while Adaptive Technology covers items that are specifically designed for persons with disabilities and would seldom be used by non-disabled persons.
653	In other words, “Assistive Technology is any object or system that increases or maintains the capabilities of people with disabilities”, while Adaptive Technology is “any object or system that is specifically designed for the purpose of increasing or maintaining the capabilities of people with disabilities”.
653	Consequently, Adaptive Technology is a subset of Assistive Technology.
653	Adaptive Technology often refers specifically to electronic and Information Technology access.
653	Mobility impairment and wheelchairs Wheelchairs are devices that can be manually propelled or electrically propelled and that include a seating system and are designed to be a substitute for the normal mobility that most people enjoy.
653	Wheelchairs and other mobility devices allow people to perform mobility related Activities of Daily Living which include Feeding, Toileting, Dressing Grooming and Bathing.
653	The devices comes in a number of variations where they can be propelled either by hand or by motors where the occupant uses electrical controls to manage motors and seating control actuators through a joystick or other input devices.
653	Often there are handles behind the seat for someone else to do the pushing or input devices for caregivers.
653	Wheelchairs are used by people for whom walking is difficult or impossible due to illness, injury, or disability.
653	People with both sitting and walking disability often need to use a wheelchair or walker.
653	Mobility impairment and walkers A walker or walking frame or Rollator is a tool for disabled people who need additional support to maintain balance or stability while walking.
653	It consists of a frame that is about waist high, approximately twelve inches deep and slightly wider than the user.
653	Walkers are also available in other sizes such as Pediatric or Bariatric.
653	Modern walkers are height adjustable.
653	The front two legs of the walker may or may not have wheels attached depending on the strength and abilities of the person using it.
653	It is also common to see caster wheels or glides on the back legs of a walker with wheels on the front.
653	Personal Emergency Response Systems Personal Emergency Response Systems (PERS), or Telecare (UK term), are a particular sort of Assistive Technology that use electronic sensors connected to an alarm system to help caregivers manage risk and help vulnerable people stay independent at home longer.
653	An example would be the systems being put in place for senior people such as fall detectors, thermometers (for hypothermia risk), flooding and unlit gas sensors (for people with mild dementia).
653	Notably, these alerts can be customized to the particular person's risks.
653	When the alert is triggered, a message is sent to a caregiver or contact center who can respond appropriately.
653	Accessibility software In human–computer interaction, computer accessibility (also known as Accessible computing) refers to the accessibility of a computer system to all people, regardless of disability or severity of impairment, examples include Web accessibility guidelines.
653	Another approach is for the user to present a token to the computer terminal, such as a smart card, that has configuration information to adjust the computer speed, text size, etc.
653	This is useful where users want to access public computer based terminals in Libraries, ATM, Information kiosks etc.
653	The concept is encompassed by the CEN EN 1332-4 Identification Card Systems - Man-Machine Interface.
653	This development of this standard has been supported in Europe by SNAPI and has been successfully incorporated into the Lasseo specifications, but with limited success due to the lack of interest from public computer terminal suppliers.
653	Assistive Technology for visual impairment Many people with serious visual impairments live independently, using a wide range of tools and techniques.
653	Examples of Assistive Technology for visually impairment include the Canadian currency tactile feature, which a system of raised dots in one corner, based on Braille cells but not standard Braille.
653	For general computer use access technology such as screen readers, screen magnifiers and refreshable Braille displays has been widely taken up along with  standalone reading aids that integrate a scanner, optical character recognition (OCR) software, and speech software in a single machine.
653	These function together without a separate PC.
653	Augmentative and alternative communication Augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) is an umbrella term that encompasses methods of communication for those with impairments or restrictions on the production or comprehension of spoken or written language.
653	AAC systems are extremely diverse and depend on the capabilities of the user.
653	They may be as basic as pictures on a board that the are used to request food, drink, or other care; or they can be advanced speech generating devices, based on speech synthesis, that are capable of storing hundreds of phrases and words.
653	Assistive Technology for Cognition Assistive Technology for Cognition (ATC) is the use of technology (usually high tech) to augment and assistive cognitive4, 5-39.
653	Systematic reviews of the field have found that the number of ATC are growing rapidly, but have focused on memory and planning, that there is emerging evidence for efficacy, that a lot of scope exists to develop new ATC.
653	Examples of ATC include: NeuroPage which prompt users about meetings, Wakamaru, which  provides companionship and reminds users to take medicine and calls for help if something is wrong, and telephone Reassurance systems.
653	Prosthesis A prosthesis, prosthetic, or prosthetic limb  is a device that replaces a missing body part.
653	It is part of the field of biomechatronics, the science of using mechanical devices with human muscle, skeleton, and nervous systems to assist or enhance motor control lost by trauma, disease, or defect.
653	Prostheses are typically used to replace parts lost by injury (traumatic) or missing from birth (congenital) or to supplement defective body parts.
653	Inside the body, artificial heart valves are in common use with artificial hearts and lungs seeing less common use but under active technology development.
653	Other medical devices and aids that can be considered prosthetics include hearing aids, artificial eyes, palatal obturator, gastric bands, and dentures.
653	Prosthetics are specifically not orthotics, although given certain circumstances a prosthetic might end up performing some or all of the same functionary benefits as an orthotic.
653	Prostheses are technically the complete finished item.
653	For instance, a C-Leg knee alone is not a prosthesis, but only a prosthetic part.
653	The complete prosthesis would consist of the stump attachment system — usually a "socket", and all the attachment hardware parts all the way down to and including the foot.
653	Keep this in mind as nomenclature is often interchanged.
653	Assistive Technology and sports Assistive Technology and sports is an area of technology design that is growing.
653	Assistive Technology is the array of new devices created to  enable sports enthusiasts who have disabilities to play.
653	Assistive Technology may be used in adaptive sports, where an existing sport is modified to enable players with a disability to participate; or, Assistive Technology may be used to invent completely new sports with athletes with disabilities exclusively in mind.
653	An increasing number of people with disabilities are participating in sports, leading to the development of new Assistive Technology.
653	Assistive Technology devices can be simple, or "low-tech", or they may use highly advanced technology, with some even using computers.
653	Assistive technology for sports may also be simple, or advanced.
653	Accordingly, Assistive Technology can be found in sports ranging from local community recreation to elite Paralympic games.
653	More complex Assistive Technology devices have been developed over time, and as a result, sports for people with disabilities "have changed from being a clinical therapeutic tool to an increasingly competition-oriented activity".
653	Computer accessibility One of the largest problems that affect patients with disabilities is discomfort with prosthesis.
653	A new computer program is used to create the most comfortable and useful prosthetics.
653	An experiment performed in Massachusetts utilized 20 patients with various sensors attached to their arms.
653	The patients tried different arm exercises, and the sensors recorded their movements.
653	All of the data helped engineers develop new engineering concepts that for prosthetics.
653	Alternatively, Assistive Technology may attempt to improve the ergonomics of the devices themselves such as  Dvorak and other alternative layouts, which offer more ergonomic layouts of the keys.
655	The abacus (plural abaci or abacuses), also called a counting frame, is a calculating tool used primarily in parts of Asia for performing arithmetic processes.
655	Today, abaci are often constructed as a bamboo frame with beads sliding on wires, but originally they were beans or stones moved in grooves in sand or on tablets of wood, stone, or metal.
655	The abacus was in use centuries before the adoption of the written modern numeral system and is still widely used by merchants, traders and clerks in Asia, Africa, and elsewhere.
655	The user of an abacus is called an abacist.
655	Etymology The use of the word abacus dates before 1387 AD, when a Middle English work borrowed the word from Latin to describe a sandboard abacus.
655	The Latin word came from Greek ἄβαξ abax "board strewn with sand or dust used for drawing geometric figures or calculating" (the exact shape of the Latin perhaps reflects the genitive form of the Greek word, ἄβακoς abakos).
655	Greek ἄβαξ itself is probably a borrowing of a Northwest Semitic, perhaps Phoenician, word akin to Hebrew ʾābāq (אבק), "dust" (since dust strewn on wooden boards to draw figures in).
655	The preferred plural of abacus is a subject of disagreement, with both abacuses and abaci in use.
655	Examples Mesopotamian The period 2700–2300 BC saw the first appearance of the Sumerian abacus, a table of successive columns which delimited the successive orders of magnitude of their sexagesimal number system.
655	Some scholars point to a character from the Babylonian cuneiform which may have been derived from a representation of the abacus.
655	It is the belief of Old Babylonian scholars such as Carruccio that Old Babylonians "may have used the abacus for the operations of addition and subtraction; however, this primitive device proved difficult to use for more complex calculations".
655	Egyptian The use of the abacus in Ancient Egypt is mentioned by the Greek historian Herodotus, who writes that the Egyptians manipulated the pebbles from right to left, opposite in direction to the Greek left-to-right method.
655	Archaeologists have found ancient disks of various sizes that are thought to have been used as counters.
655	However, wall depictions of this instrument have not been discovered, casting some doubt over the extent to which this instrument was used.
655	Persian During the Achaemenid Persian Empire, around 600 BC the Persians first began to use the abacus.
655	Under Parthian and Sassanian Iranian empires, scholars concentrated on exchanging knowledge and inventions by the countries around them – India, China, and the Roman Empire, when it is thought to be expanded over the other countries.
655	Greek The earliest archaeological evidence for the use of the Greek abacus dates to the 5th century BC.
655	The Greek abacus was a table of wood or marble, pre-set with small counters in wood or metal for mathematical calculations.
655	This Greek abacus saw use in Achaemenid Persia, the Etruscan civilization, Ancient Rome and, until the French Revolution, the Western Christian world.
655	A tablet found on the Greek island Salamis in 1846 AD (the Salamis Tablet), dates back to 300 BC, making it the oldest counting board discovered so far.
655	It is a slab of white marble 149 cm long, 75 cm wide, and  thick, on which are 5 groups of markings.
655	In the center of the tablet is a set of 5 parallel lines equally divided by a vertical line, capped with a semicircle at the intersection of the bottom-most horizontal line and the single vertical line.
655	Below these lines is a wide space with a horizontal crack dividing it.
655	Below this crack is another group of eleven parallel lines, again divided into two sections by a line perpendicular to them, but with the semicircle at the top of the intersection; the third, sixth and ninth of these lines are marked with a cross where they intersect with the vertical line.
655	Roman The normal method of calculation in ancient Rome, as in Greece, was by moving counters on a smooth table.
655	Originally pebbles (calculi) were used.
655	Later, and in medieval Europe, jetons were manufactured.
655	Marked lines indicated units, fives, tens etc.
655	Roman numeral system.
655	This system of 'counter casting' continued into the late Roman empire and in medieval Europe, and persisted in limited use into the nineteenth century.
655	Due to Pope Sylvester II's reintroduction of the abacus with very useful modifications, it became widely used in Europe once again during the 11th century Writing in the 1st century BC, Horace refers to the wax abacus, a board covered with a thin layer of black wax on which columns and figures were inscribed using a stylus.
655	One example of archaeological evidence of the Roman abacus, shown here in reconstruction, dates to the 1st century AD.
655	It has eight long grooves containing up to five beads in each and eight shorter grooves having either one or no beads in each.
655	The groove marked I indicates units, X tens, and so on up to millions.
655	The beads in the shorter grooves denote fives –five units, five tens etc., essentially in a bi-quinary coded decimal system, obviously related to the Roman numerals.
655	The short grooves on the right may have been used for marking Roman ounces.
655	Chinese The earliest known written documentation of the Chinese abacus dates to the 2nd century BC.
655	The Chinese abacus, known as the suànpán (算盤, lit.
655	"Counting tray"), is typically 20 cm tall and comes in various widths depending on the operator.
655	It usually has more than seven rods.
655	There are two beads on each rod in the upper deck and five beads each in the bottom for both decimal and hexadecimal computation.
655	The beads are usually rounded and made of a hardwood.
655	The beads are counted by moving them up or down towards the beam.
655	If you move them toward the beam, you count their value.
655	If you move away, you don't count their value.
655	The suanpan can be reset to the starting position instantly by a quick jerk along the horizontal axis to spin all the beads away from the horizontal beam at the center.
655	Suanpans can be used for functions other than counting.
655	Unlike the simple counting board used in elementary schools, very efficient suanpan techniques have been developed to do multiplication, division, addition, subtraction, square root and cube root operations at high speed.
655	There are currently schools teaching students how to use it.
655	In the famous long scroll Along the River During the Qingming Festival painted by Zhang Zeduan (1085–1145 AD) during the Song Dynasty (960–1297 AD), a suanpan is clearly seen lying beside an account book and doctor's prescriptions on the counter of an apothecary's (Feibao).
655	The similarity of the Roman abacus to the Chinese one suggests that one could have inspired the other, as there is some evidence of a trade relationship between the Roman Empire and China.
655	However, no direct connection can be demonstrated, and the similarity of the abaci may be coincidental, both ultimately arising from counting with five fingers per hand.
655	Where the Roman model (like most modern Japanese) has 4 plus 1 bead per decimal place, the standard suanpan has 5 plus 2, allowing use with a hexadecimal numeral system.
655	Instead of running on wires as in the Chinese and Japanese models, the beads of Roman model run in grooves, presumably making arithmetic calculations much slower.
655	Another possible source of the suanpan is Chinese counting rods, which operated with a decimal system but lacked the concept of zero as a place holder.
655	The zero was probably introduced to the Chinese in the Tang Dynasty (618-907 AD) when travel in the Indian Ocean and the Middle East would have provided direct contact with India, allowing them to acquire the concept of zero and the decimal point from Indian merchants and mathematicians.
655	Indian First century sources, such as the Abhidharmakosa describe the knowledge and use of abacus in India.
655	Around the 5th century, Indian clerks were already finding new wayns|Langer|2001|p=44}}&lts of recording the contents of the Abacus.
655	Hindu texts used the term shunya (zero) to indicate the empty column on the abacus.
655	Japanese In Japanese, the abacus is called soroban (, lit.
655	"Counting tray"), imported from China around 1600.
655	The 1/4 abacus, which is suited to decimal calculation, appeared circa 1930, and became widespread as the Japanese abandoned hexadecimal weight calculation which was still common in China.
655	The abacus is still manufactured in Japan today even with the proliferation, practicality, and affordability of pocket electronic calculators.
655	The use of the soroban is still taught in Japanese primary schools as part of mathematics, primarily as an aid to faster mental calculation.
655	Using visual imagery of a soroban, one can arrive at the answer in the same time as, or even faster than, is possible with a physical instrument.
655	Korean The Chinese abacus migrated from China to Korea around 1400 AD.
655	Koreans call it jupan (주판), supan (수판) or jusan (주산).
655	Native American Some sources mention the use of an abacus called a nepohualtzintzin in ancient Mayan culture.
655	This Mesoamerican abacus used a 5-digit base-20 system.
655	The word Nepōhualtzintzin comes from the Nahuatl and it is formed by the roots; Ne - personal -; pōhual or pōhualli - the account -; and tzintzin - small similar elements.
655	And its complete meaning was taken as: counting with small similar elements by somebody.
655	Its use was taught in the Calmecac to the temalpouhqueh, who were students dedicated to take the accounts of skies, from childhood.
655	Unfortunately the Nepōhualtzintzin and its teaching were among the victims of the conquering destruction, when a diabolic origin was attributed to them after observing the tremendous properties of representation, precision and speed of calculations.
655	This arithmetic tool was based on the vigesimal system (base 20).
655	For the Aztec the count by 20s was completely natural.
655	The amount of 4, 5, 13, 20 and other cyclees meant cycles.
655	The Nepōhualtzintzin was divided in two main parts separated by a bar or intermediate cord.
655	In the left part there were four beads, which in the first row have unitary values (1, 2, 3, and 4), and in the right side there are three beads with values of 5, 10, and 15 respectively.
655	In order to know the value of the respective beads of the upper rows, it is enough to multiply by 20 (by each row), the value of the corresponding account in the first row.
655	Altogether, there were 13 rows with 7 beads in each one, which made up 91 beads in each Nepōhualtzintzin.
655	This was a basic number to understand, 7 times 13, a close relation conceived between natural phenomena, the underworld and the cycles of the heavens.
655	One Nepōhualtzintzin (91) represented the number of days that a season of the year lasts, two Nepōhualtzitzin (182) is the number of days of the corn's cycle, from its sowing to its harvest, three Nepōhualtzintzin (273) is the number of days of a baby's gestation, and four Nepōhualtzintzin (364) completed a cycle and approximate a year (1 days short).
655	The Nepōhualtzintzin amounted to the rank from 10 to the 18 in floating point, which calculated stellar as well as infinitesimal amounts with absolute precision, meant that no round off was allowed, when translated into modern computer arithmetic.
655	The rediscovery of the Nepōhualtzintzin was due to the Mexican engineer David Esparza Hidalgo, who in his wanderings throughout Mexico found diverse engravings and paintings of this instrument and reconstructed several of them made in gold, jade, encrustations of shell, etc.
655	There have also been found very old Nepōhualtzintzin attributed to the Olmeca culture, and even some bracelets of Mayan origin, as well as a diversity of forms and materials in other cultures.
655	George I.
655	Sanchez, "Arithmetic in Maya", Austin-Texas, 1961 found another base 5, base 4 abacus in the Yucatán that also computed calendar data.
655	This was a finger abacus, on one hand 0 1,2, 3, and 4 were used; and on the other hand used 0, 1, 2 and 3 were used.
655	Note the use of zero at the beginning and end of the two cycles.
655	Sanchez worked with Sylvanus Morley, a noted Mayanist.
655	The quipu of the Incas was a system of knotted cords used to record numerical data, like advanced tally sticks – but not used to perform calculations.
655	Calculations were carried out using a yupana (Quechua for "counting tool"; see figure) which was still in use after the conquest of Peru.
655	The working principle of a yupana is unknown, but in 2001 an explanation of the mathematical basis of these instruments was proposed by Italian mathematician Nicolino De Pasquale.
655	By comparing the form of several yupanas, researchers found that calculations were based using the Fibonacci sequence 1, 1, 2, 3, 5 and powers of 10, 20 and 40 as place values for the different fields in the instrument.
655	Using the Fibonacci sequence would keep the number of grains within any one field at minimum.
655	Russian The Russian abacus, the schoty (счёты), usually has a single slanted deck, with ten beads on each wire (except one wire, usually positioned near the user, with four beads for quarter-ruble fractions).
655	Older models have another 4-bead wire for quarter-kopeks, which were minted until 1916.
655	The Russian abacus is often used vertically, with wires from left to right in the manner of a book.
655	The wires are usually bowed to bulge upward in the center, to keep the beads pinned to either of the two sides.
655	It is cleared when all the beads are moved to the right.
655	During manipulation, beads are moved to the left.
655	For easy viewing, the middle 2 beads on each wire (the 5th and 6th bead) usually are of a different colour from the other eight beads.
655	Likewise, the left bead of the thousands wire (and the million wire, if present) may have a different color.
655	As a simple, cheap e thousands wire (and the million wire, if present) may have a different coloand reliable device, the Russian abacus was in use in all shops and markets throughout the former Soviet Union, and the usage of it was taught in most schools until the 1990s.
655	Even the 1874 invention of mechanical calculator, Odhner arithmometer, had not replaced them in Russia and likewise the mass production of Felix arithmometers since 1924 did not significantly reduce their use in the Soviet Union.
655	Russian abacus began to lose popularity only after the mass production of microcalculators had started in the Soviet Union in 1974.
655	Today it is regarded as an archaism and replaced by the handheld calculator.
655	The Russian abacus was brought to France around 1820 by the mathematician Jean-Victor Poncelet, who served in Napoleon's army and had been a prisoner of war in Russia.
655	The abacus had fallen out of use in western Europe in the 16th century with the rise of decimal notation and algorismic methods.
655	To Poncelet's French contemporaries, it was something new.
655	Poncelet used it, not for any applied purpose, but as a teaching and demonstration aid.
655	School abacus Around the world, abaci have been used in pre-schools and elementary schools as an aid in teaching the numeral system and arithmetic.
655	In Western countries, a bead frame similar to the Russian abacus but with straight wires and a vertical frame has been common (see image).
655	It is still often seen as a plastic or wooden toy.
655	The type of abacus shown here is often used to represent numbers without the use of place value.
655	Each bead and each wire has the same value and used in this way it can represent numbers up to 100.
655	Renaissance abaci gallery Uses by the blind An adapted abacus, invented by Tim Cranmer, called a Cranmer abacus is still commonly used by individuals who are blind.
655	A piece of soft fabric or rubber is placed behind the beads so that they do not move inadvertently.
655	This keeps the beads in place while the users feel or manipulate them.
655	They use an abacus to perform the mathematical functions multiplication, division, addition, subtraction, square root and cubic root.
655	Although blind students have benefited from talking calculators, the abacus is still very often taught to these students in early grades, both in public schools and state schools for the blind.
655	The abacus teaches mathematical skills that can never be replaced with talking calculators and is an important learning tool for blind students.
655	Blind students also complete mathematical assignments using a braille-writer and Nemeth code (a type of braille code for mathematics) but large multiplication and long division problems can be long and difficult.
655	The abacus gives blind and visually impaired students a tool to compute mathematical problems that equals the speed and mathematical knowledge required by their sighted peers using pencil and paper.
655	Many blind people find this number machine a very useful tool throughout life.
655	Binary abacus The binary abacus is used to explain how computers manipulate numbers.
655	The abacus shows how numbers, letters, and signs can be stored in a binary system on a computer, or via ASCII.
655	The device consists of a series of beads on parallel wires arranged in three separate rows.
655	The beads represent a switch on the computer in either an 'on' or 'off' position.
656	An acid (from the Latin acidus/acēre meaning sour) is a substance which reacts with a base.
656	Commonly, acids can be identified as tasting sour, reacting with metals such as calcium, and bases like sodium carbonate.
656	Aqueous acids have a pH under 7, with acidity increasing the lower the pH.
656	Chemicals or substances having the property of an acid are said to be acidic.
656	Common examples of acids include acetic acid (in vinegar), sulfuric acid (used in car batteries), hydrochloric acid (used in the stomach for enzymes) and tartaric acid (used in baking).
656	As these three examples show, acids can be solutions, liquids, or solids.
656	Gases such as hydrogen chloride can be acids as well when dissolved in water.
656	Strong acids and some concentrated weak acids are corrosive, but there are exceptions such as carboranes and boric acid.
656	There are three common definitions for acids: the Arrhenius definition, the Brønsted-Lowry definition, and the Lewis definition.
656	The Arrhenius definition states that acids are substances which increase the concentration of hydronium ions (H3O+) in solution.
656	The Brønsted-Lowry definition is an expansion: an acid is a substance which can act as a proton donor.
656	Most acids encountered in everyday life are aqueous solutions, or can be dissolved in water, and these two definitions are most relevant.
656	The reason why pHs of acids are less than 7 is that the concentration of hydronium ions is greater than 10−7 moles per liter.
656	Since pH is defined as the negative logarithm of the concentration of hydronium ions, acids thus have pHs of less than 7.
656	By the Brønsted-Lowry definition, any compound which can easily be deprotonated can be considered an acid.
656	Examples include alcohols and amines which contain O-H or N-H fragments.
656	In chemistry, the Lewis definition of acidity is frequently encountered.
656	Lewis acids are electron-pair acceptors.
656	Examples of Lewis acids include all metal cations, and electron-deficient molecules such as boron trifluoride and aluminium trichloride.
656	Hydronium ions are acids according to all three definitions.
656	Interestingly, although alcohols and amines can be Brønsted-Lowry acids as mentioned above, they can also function as Lewis bases due to the lone pairs of electrons on their oxygen and nitrogen atoms.
656	Definitions and concepts Modern definitions are concerned with the fundamental chemical reactions common to all acids.
656	Arrhenius acids The Swedish chemist Svante Arrhenius attributed the properties of acidity to hydrogen ions (H+) or protons in 1884.
656	An Arrhenius acid is a substance that, when added to water, increases the concentration of H+ ions in the water.
656	Note that chemists often write H+(aq) and refer to the hydrogen ion when describing acid-base reactions but the free hydrogen nucleus, a proton, does not exist alone in water, it exists as the hydronium ion, H3O+.
656	Thus, an Arrhenius acid can also be described as a substance that increases the concentration of hydronium ions when added to water.
656	This definition stems from the equilibrium dissociation of water into hydronium and hydroxide (OH−) ions: H2O(l) + H2O(l)  H3O+(aq) + OH−(aq) In pure water the majority of molecules exist as H2O, but a small number of molecules are constantly dissociating and re-associating.
656	Pure water is neutral with respect to acidity or basicity because the concentration of hydroxide ions is always equal to the concentration of hydronium ions.
656	An Arrhenius base, on the other hand, is a molecule which increases the concentration of the hydroxide ion when dissolved in water.
656	Brønsted-Lowry acids While the Arrhenius concept is useful for describing many reactions, it is also quite limited in its scope.
656	In 1923 chemists Johannes Nicolaus Brønsted and Thomas Martin Lowry independently recognized that acid-base reactions involve the transfer of a proton.
656	A Brønsted-Lowry acid (or simply Brønsted acid) is a species that donates a proton to a Brønsted-Lowry base.
656	Brønsted-Lowry acid-base theory has several advantages over Arrhenius theory.
656	Consider the following reactions of acetic acid (CH3COOH), the organic acid that gives vinegar its characteristic taste (seen in the image to the right): +    +  Both theories easily describe the first reaction: CH3COOH acts as an Arrhenius acid because it acts as a source of H3O+ when dissolved in water, and it acts as a Brønsted acid by donating a proton to water.
656	In the second example CH3COOH undergoes the same transformation, in this case donating a proton to ammonia (NH3), but cannot be described using the Arrhenius definition of an acid because the reaction does not produce hydronium.
656	Brønsted-Lowry theory can also be used to describe molecular compounds, whereas Arrhenius acids must be ionic compounds.
656	Hydrogen chloride (HCl) and ammonia combine under several different conditions to form ammonium chloride, NH4Cl.
656	In aqueous solution HCl behaves as hydrochloric acid and exists as hydronium and chloride ions.
656	The following reactions illustrate the limitations of Arrhenius's definition: # H3O+(aq) + Cl−(aq) + NH3 → Cl−(aq) + NH4+(aq) + H2O # HCl(benzene) + NH3(benzene) → NH4Cl(s) # HCl(g) + NH3(g) → NH4Cl(s) As with the acetic acid reactions, both definitions work for the first example, where water is the solvent and hydronium ion is formed by the HCl solute.
656	The next two reactions do not involve the formation of ions but are still proton transfer reactions.
656	In the second reaction hydrogen chloride and ammonia (dissolved in benzene) react to form solid ammonium chloride in a benzene solvent and in the third gaseous HCl and NH3 combine to form the solid.
656	Lewis acids A third concept was proposed in 1923 by Gilbert N.
656	Lewis which includes reactions with acid-base characteristics that do not involve a proton transfer.
656	A Lewis acid is a species that accepts a pair of electrons from another species; in other words, it is an electron pair acceptor.
656	Brønsted acid-base reactions are proton transfer reactions while Lewis acid-base reactions are electron pair transfers.
656	All Brønsted acids are also Lewis acids, but not all Lewis acids are Brønsted acids.
656	Contrast the following reactions which could be described in terms of acid-base chemistry.
656	In the first reaction a fluoride ion, F−, gives up an electron pair to boron trifluoride to form the product tetrafluoroborate.
656	Fluoride "loses" a pair of valence electrons because the electrons shared in the B—F bond are located in the region of space between the two atomic nuclei and are therefore more distant from the fluoride nucleus than they are in the lone fluoride ion.
656	BF3 is a Lewis acid because it accepts the electron pair from fluoride.
656	This reaction cannot be described in terms of Brønsted theory because there is no proton transfer.
656	The second reaction can be described using either theory.
656	A proton is transferred from an unspecified Brønsted acid to ammonia, a Brønsted base; alternatively, ammonia acts as a Lewis base and transfers a lone pair of electrons to form a bond with a hydrogen ion.
656	The species that gains the electron pair is the Lewis acid; for example, the oxygen atom in H3O+ gains a pair of electrons when one of the H—O bonds is broken and the electrons shared in the bond become localized on oxygen.
656	Depending on the context, a Lewis acid may also be described as an oxidizer or an electrophile.
656	The Brønsted-Lowry definition is the most widely used definition; unless otherwise specified acid-base reactions are assumed to involve the transfer of a proton (H+) from an acid to a base.
656	Dissociation and equilibrium Reactions of acids are often generalized in the form HA  H+ + A−, where HA represents the acid and A− is the conjugate base.
656	Acid-base conjugate pairs differ by one proton, and can be interconverted by the addition or removal of a proton (protonation and deprotonation, respectively).
656	Note that the acid can be the charged species and the conjugate base can be neutral in which case the generalized reaction scheme could be written as HA+  H+ + A.
656	In solution there exists an equilibrium between the acid and its conjugate base.
656	The equilibrium constant K is an expression of the equilibrium concentrations of the molecules or the ions in solution.
656	Brackets indicate concentration, such that [H2O] means the concentration of H2O.
656	The acid dissociation constant Ka is generally used in the context of acid-base reactions.
656	The numerical value of Ka is equal to the concentration of the products divided by the concentration of the reactants, where the reactant is the acid (HA) and the products are the conjugate base and H+.
656	The stronger of two acids will have a higher Ka than the weaker acid; the ratio of hydrogen ions to acid will be higher for the stronger acid as the stronger acid has a greater tendency to lose its proton.
656	Because the range of possible values for Ka spans many orders of magnitude, a more manageable constant, pKa is more frequently used, where pKa = -log10 Ka.
656	Stronger acids have a smaller pKa than weaker acids.
656	Experimentally determined pKa at 25 °C in aqueous solution are often quoted in textbooks and reference material.
656	Nomenclature In the classical naming system, acids are named according to their anions.
656	That ionic suffix is dropped and replaced with a new suffix (and sometimes prefix), according to the table below.
656	For example, HCl has chloride as its anion, so the -ide suffix makes it take the form hydrochloric acid.
656	In the IUPAC naming system, "aqueous" is simply added to the name of the ionic compound.
656	Thus, for hydrogen chloride, the IUPAC name would be aqueous hydrogen chloride.
656	The prefc compound.
656	Thus, for hydrogen chloride, the ix "hydro-" is added only if the acid is made up of just hydrogen and one other element.
656	Classical naming system: Acid strength The strength of an acid refers to its ability or tendency to lose a proton.
656	A strong acid is one that completely dissociates in water; in other words, one mole of a strong acid HA dissolves in water yielding one mole of H+ and one mole of the conjugate base, A−, and none of the protonated acid HA.
656	In contrast a weak acid only partially dissociates and at equilibrium both the acid and the conjugate base are in solution.
656	Examples of strong acids are hydrochloric acid (HCl), hydroiodic acid (HI), hydrobromic acid (HBr), perchloric acid (HClO4), nitric acid (HNO3) and sulfuric acid (H2SO4).
656	In water each of these essentially ionizes 100%.
656	The stronger an acid is, the more easily it loses a proton, H+.
656	Two key factors that contribute to the ease of deprotonation are the polarity of the H—A bond and the size of atom A, which determines the strength of the H—A bond.
656	Acid strengths are also often discussed in terms of the stability of the conjugate base.
656	Stronger acids have a larger Ka and a more negative pKa than weaker acids.
656	Sulfonic acids, which are organic oxyacids, are a class of strong acids.
656	A common example is toluenesulfonic acid (tosylic acid).
656	Unlike sulfuric acid itself, sulfonic acids can be solids.
656	In fact, polystyrene functionalized into polystyrene sulfonate is a solid strongly acidic plastic that is filterable.
656	Superacids are acids stronger than 100% sulfuric acid.
656	Examples of superacids are fluoroantimonic acid, magic acid and perchloric acid.
656	Superacids can permanently protonate water to give ionic, crystalline hydronium "salts".
656	They can also quantitatively stabilize carbocations.
656	Chemical characteristics Monoprotic acids Monoprotic acids are those acids that are able to donate one proton per molecule during the process of dissociation (sometimes called ionization) as shown below (symbolized by HA): ::::HA(aq) + H2O(l)  H3O+(aq) + A−(aq)         Ka Common examples of monoprotic acids in mineral acids include hydrochloric acid (HCl) and nitric acid (HNO3).
656	On the other hand, for organic acids the term mainly indicates the presence of one carboxylic acid group and sometimes these acids are known as monocarboxylic acid.
656	Examples in organic acids include formic acid (HCOOH), acetic acid (CH3COOH) and benzoic acid (C6H5COOH).
656	Polyprotic acids Polyprotic acids, also known as polybasic acids, are able to donate more than one proton per acid molecule, in contrast to monoprotic acids that only donate one proton per molecule.
656	Specific types of polyprotic acids have more specific names, such as diprotic acid (two potential protons to donate) and triprotic acid (three potential protons to donate).
656	A diprotic acid (here symbolized by H2A) can undergo one or two dissociations depending on the pH.
656	Each dissociation has its own dissociation constant, Ka1 and Ka2.
656	H2A(aq) + H2O(l)  H3O+(aq) + HA−(aq)       Ka1 ::::HA−(aq) + H2O(l)  H3O+(aq) + A2−(aq)       Ka2 The first dissociation constant is typically greater than the second; i.e., Ka1 > Ka2.
656	For example, sulfuric acid (H2SO4) can donate one proton to form the bisulfate anion (HSO4−), for which Ka1 is very large; then it can donate a second proton to form the sulfate anion (SO42-), wherein the Ka2 is intermediate strength.
656	The large Ka1 for the first dissociation makes sulfuric a strong acid.
656	In a similar manner, the weak unstable carbonic acid (H2CO3) can lose one proton to form bicarbonate anion (HCO3−) and lose a second to form carbonate anion (CO32-).
656	Both Ka values are small, but Ka1 > Ka2 .
656	A triprotic acid (H3A) can undergo one, two, or three dissociations and has three dissociation constants, where Ka1 > Ka2 > Ka3.
656	H3A(aq) + H2O(l)  H3O+(aq) + H2A−(aq)        Ka1 ::::H2A−(aq) + H2O(l)  H3O+(aq) + HA2−(aq)       Ka2 ::::HA2−(aq) + H2O(l)  H3O+(aq) + A3−(aq)         Ka3 An inorganic example of a triprotic acid is orthophosphoric acid (H3PO4), usually just called phosphoric acid.
656	All three protons can be successively lost to yield H2PO4−, then HPO42-, and finally PO43-, the orthophosphate ion, usually just called phosphate.
656	An organic example of a triprotic acid is citric acid, which can successively lose three protons to finally form the citrate ion.
656	Even though the positions of the protons on the original molecule may be equivalent, the successive Ka values will differ since it is energetically less favorable to lose a proton if the conjugate base is more negatively charged.
656	Although the subsequent loss of each hydrogen ion is less favorable, all of the conjugate bases are present in solution.
656	The fractional concentration, α (alpha), for each species can be calculated.
656	For example, a generic diprotic acid will generate 3 species in solution: pecies can be calculated.
656	For example, H2A, HA-, and A2-.
656	The fractional concentrations can be calculated as below when given either the pH (which can be converted to the [H+]) or the concentrations of the acid with all its conjugate bases: A plot of these fractional concentrations against pH, for given K1 and K2, is known as a Bjerrum plot.
656	A pattern is observed in the above equations and can be expanded to the general n -protic acid that has been deprotonated i -times: \alpha_{H_{n-i} A^{i-} }=
657	Asphalt or or, also known as bitumen, is a sticky, black and highly viscous liquid or semi-solid form of petroleum.
657	It may be found in natural deposits or may be a refined product; it is a substance classed as a pitch.
657	Until the 20th century, the term asphaltum was also used.
657	The primary use of asphalt/bitumen is in road construction, where it is used as the glue or binder mixed with aggregate particles to create asphalt concrete.
657	Its other main uses are for bituminous waterproofing products, including production of roofing felt and for sealing flat roofs.
657	The terms asphalt and bitumen are often used interchangeably to mean both natural and manufactured forms of the substance.
657	In American English, asphalt (or asphalt cement) is the carefully refined residue from the distillation process of selected crude oils.
657	Outside the United States, the product is often called bitumen.
657	Geological terminology often prefers the term bitumen.
657	Common usage often refers to various forms of asphalt/bitumen as "tar", such as at the La Brea Tar Pits.
657	Another term, mostly archaic, refers to asphalt/bitumen as "pitch".
657	The pitch used in this mixture is sometimes found in natural deposits but usually made by the distillation of crude oil.
657	Naturally occurring asphalt/bitumen is sometimes specified by the term "crude bitumen".
657	Its viscosity is similar to that of cold molasses while the material obtained from the fractional distillation of crude oil [boiling at 525 C] is sometimes referred to as "refined bitumen".
657	Etymology The word asphalt is derived from the late Middle English, in turn from French asphalte, based on Late Latin asphalton, asphaltum, which is the latinisation of the Greek ἄσφαλτος (ásphaltos, ásphalton), a word meaning "asphalt/bitumen/pitch", which perhaps derives from α- "without" and σφάλλω, (sfallō), "make fall".
657	Note that in French, the term asphalte is used for naturally occurring bitumen-soaked limestone deposits, and for specialised manufactured products with fewer voids or greater bitumen content than the "asphaltic concrete" used to pave roads.
657	It is a significant fact that the first use of asphalt by the ancients was in the nature of a cement for securing or joining together various objects, and it thus seems likely that the name itself was expressive of this application.
657	Specifically Herodotus mentioned that bitumen was brought to Babylon to build its gigantic fortification wall.
657	From the Greek, the word passed into late Latin, and thence into French (asphalte) and English ("asphaltum" and "asphalt").
657	The expression "bitumen" originated in the Sanskrit, where we find the words jatu, meaning "pitch," and jatu-krit, meaning "pitch creating", "pitch producing" (referring to coniferous or resinous trees).
657	The Latin equivalent is claimed by some to be originally gwitu-men (pertaining to pitch), and by others, pixtumens (exuding or bubbling pitch), which was subsequently shortened to bitumen, thence passing via French into English.
657	From the same root is derived the Anglo Saxon word cwidu (mastix), the German word Kitt (cement or mastic) and the old Norse word kvada.
657	Neither of the terms asphalt or bitumen should be confused with tar or coal tars.
657	Modern usage  In British English, the word 'asphalt' is used to refer to a mixture of mineral aggregate and asphalt/bitumen (also called tarmac in common parlance).
657	The earlier word 'asphaltum' is now archaic and not commonly used.
657	In American English, 'asphalt' is equivalent to the British 'bitumen'.
657	However, 'asphalt' is also commonly used as a shortened form of 'asphalt concrete' (therefore equivalent to the British 'asphalt' or 'tarmac').
657	In Australian English, bitumen is often used as the generic term for road surfaces.
657	In Canadian English, the word bitumen is used to refer to the vast Canadian deposits of extremely heavy crude oil, while asphalt is used for the oil refinery product used to pave roads and manufacture roof shingles and various waterproofing products.
657	Diluted bitumen (diluted with naphtha to make it flow in pipelines) is known as dilbit in the Canadian petroleum industry, while bitumen "upgraded" to synthetic crude oil is known as syncrude and syncrude blended with bitumen as synbit.
657	Bitumen is still the preferred geological term for naturally occurring deposits of the solid or semi-solid form of petroleum.
657	Bituminous rock is a form of sandstone impregnated with bitumen.
657	The oil sands of Alberta, Canada are a similar material.
657	Chemistry The substance is completely soluble in carbon disulfide, and composed primarily of a mixture of highly condensed polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons; it is most commonly modelled as a colloid, with asphaltenes as the dispersed phase and [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/maltene maltenes] as the continuous phase (though there is some disagreement amongst chemists regarding its structure).
657	One writer stated although a "considerable amount of work has been done on the composition of asphalt, it is exceedingly difficult to separate individual hydrocarbon in pure form", and "it is almost impossible to separate and identify all the different molecules of asphalt, because the number of molecules with different chemical structure is extremely large".
657	Most natural bitumens contain sulfur and several heavy metals, such as nickel, vanadium, lead, chromium, mercury, arsenic, selenium, and other toxic elements.
657	Bitumens can provide good preservation of plants and animal fossils.
657	Asphalt/bitumen can sometimes be confused with "tar", which is a similar black, thermoplastic material produced by the destructive distillation of coal.
657	During the early  and mid-20th century when town gas was produced, tar was a readily available product and extensively used as the binder for road aggregates.
657	The addition of tar to macadam roads led to the word tarmac, which is now used in common parlance to refer to road-making materials.
657	However, since the 1970s, when natural gas succeeded town gas, asphalt/bitumen has completely overtaken the use of tar in these applications.
657	Other examples of this confusion include the La Brea Tar Pits and the Canadian tar sands.
657	Pitch is another term mistakenly used at times to refer to asphalt/bitumen, as in Pitch Lake.
657	Natural deposits of asphalt/bitumen include lakes such as the Pitch Lake in Trinidad and Tobago and Lake Bermudez in Venezuela, Gilsonite, the Dead Sea, asphalt/bitumen-impregnated sandstones known as bituminous rock and the similar "tar sands".
657	Asphalt/bitumen was mined at Ritchie Mines in Macfarlan in Ritchie County, West Virginia in the United States from 1852 to 1873.
657	Bituminous rock was mined at many locations in the United States for use as a paving material, primarily during the late 1800s.
657	Asphalt/bitumen can be separated from the other components in crude oil (such as naphtha, gasoline and diesel) by the process of fractional distillation, usually under vacuum conditions.
657	A better separation can be achieved by further processing of the heavier fractions of the crude oil in a de-asphalting unit, which uses either propane or butane in a supercritical phase to dissolve the lighter molecules which are then separated.
657	Further processing is possible by "blowing" the product: namely reacting it with oxygen.
657	This makes the product harder and more viscous.
657	Asphalt/bitumen is typically stored and transported at temperatures around 150°C (300°F).
657	Sometimes diesel oil or kerosene are mixed in before shipping to retain liquidity; upon delivery, these lighter materials are separated out of the mixture.
657	This mixture is often called "bitumen feedstock", or BFS.
657	Some dump trucks route the hot engine exhaust through pipes in the dump body to keep the material warm.
657	The backs of tippers carrying asphalt/bitumen, as well as some handling equipment, are also commonly sprayed with a releasing agent before filling to aid release.
657	Diesel oil is no longer used as a release agent due to environmental concerns.
657	History Geological origin Naturally occurring deposits of asphalt/bitumen are formed from the remains of ancient, microscopic algae (diatoms) and other once-living things.
657	These remains were deposited in the mud on the bottom of the ocean or lake where the organisms lived.
657	Under the heat (above 50 °C) and pressure of burial deep in the earth, the remains were transformed into materials such as asphalt/bitumen, kerogen, or petroleum.
657	Deposits at the La Brea Tar Pits are an example.
657	There are structural similarities between asphalt/bitumen and the organic matter in carbonaceous meteorites.
657	However, detailed studies have shown these materials to be distinct.
657	Ancient times The use of asphalt/bitumen for waterproofing and as an adhesive dates at least to the fifth millennium B.C.
657	Indus community of Mehrgarh, where it was used to line the baskets in which they gathered crops.
657	In the ancient Middle East, the Sumerians used natural asphalt/bitumen deposits for mortar between bricks and stones, to cement parts of carvings, such as eyes, into place, for ship caulking, and for waterproofing.
657	The Greek historian Herodotus said hot asphalt/bitumen was used as mortar in the walls of Babylon.
657	In some versions of the Book of Genesis in the Bible, the name of the substance used to bind the bricks of the Tower of Babel is translated as bitumen (see Gen 11:3), while other translations use the word pitch.
657	A one-kilometre tunnel beneath the river Euphrates at Babylon in the time of Queen Semiramis (ca.
657	B.C.) was reportedly constructed of burnt bricks covered with asphalt/bitumen as a waterproofing agent.
657	Asphalt/bitumen was used by ancient Egyptians to embalm mummies.
657	The Persian word for asphalt is moom, which is related to the English word mummy.
657	The Egyptians' primary source of asphalt/bitumen was the Dead Sea, which the Romans knew as Palus Asphaltites (Asphalt Lake).
657	Approximately 40 AD, Dioscorides described the Dead Sea material as Judaicum bitumen, and noted other places in the region where it could be found:  "The Judaicum Bitumen is better than others; that is reckoned the best, which doth shine like purple;The Judaicum, being of a strong scent & weightie, but the black and fowle is naught for it is adulterated with Pitch mixed with it.
657	It growes in Phoenice also, and in Sidon, & in Babylon, & in Zacynthum.
657	It is found also moyst swimming upon wells in the country of the Agrigentines of Sicilie, which they use for lamps instead of oyle, and which they call falsely Sicilian oyle, for it is a kinde of moyst Bitumen."
657	The Sidon bitumen is thought to refer to asphalt/bitumen found at Hasbeya.
657	Pliny refers also to asphalt/bitumen being found in Epirus.
657	It was a valuable strategic resource; the object of the first known battle for a hydrocarbon deposit, between the Seleucids and the Nabateans in 312 B.C.
657	In the ancient Far East, natural asphalt/bitumen was slowly boiled to get rid of the higher fractions, leaving a material of higher molecular weight which is thermoplastic and when layered on objects, became quite hard upon cooling.
657	This was used to cover objects that needed waterproofing, such as scabbards and other items.
657	Statuettes of household deities were also cast with this type of material in Japan, and probably also in China.
657	In North America, archaeological recovery has indicated asphalt/bitumen was sometimes used to adhere stone projectile points to  wooden shafts.
657	Early use in Europe The Greek fire, which composition was a military secret of the Byzantine navy, contained, among other things, asphalt/bitumen as a component.
657	Constantinople in 1453, Pierre Belon described in his work Observations in 1553 that pissasphalto a mixture of pitch and bitumen was used in Dubrovnik for tarring of ships from where it was exported to a market place in Venice where it could be bought by anyone.
657	An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine cites an early use of asphalt in France.
657	A pamphlet dated 1621, by "a certain Monsieur d'Eyrinys, states that he had discovered the existence (of asphaltum) in large quantities in the vicinity of Neufchatel", and that he proposed to use it in a variety of ways - "principally in the construction of air-proof granaries, and in protecting, by means of the arches, the water-courses in the city of Paris from the intrusion of dirt and filth", which at that time made the water unusable.
657	"He expatiates also on the excellence of this material for forming level and durable terraces" in palaces, "the notion of forming such terraces in the streets not one likely to cross the brain of a Parisian of that generation".
657	But it was generally  neglected in France until the revolution of 1830.
657	Then, in the 1830s, there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used "for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns, and in England, some use of it had been made of it for similar purposes".
657	Its rise in Europe was "a sudden phenomenon", after natural deposits were found "in France at Osbann (BasRhin), the Parc (l'Ain) and the Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome)", although it could also be made artificially.
657	One of the earliest uses in France was the laying of about 24,000 square yards of Seyssel asphalt at the Place de la Concorde in 1835.
657	Photography and art Asphalt/bitumen was used in early photographic technology.
657	In 1826 or 1827, it was used by French scientist Joseph Nicéphore Niépce to make the oldest surviving photograph from nature.
657	The asphalt/bitumen was thinly coated onto a pewter plate which was then exposed in a camera.
657	Exposure to light hardened the asphalt/bitumen and made it insoluble, so that when it was subsequently rinsed with a solvent only the sufficiently light-struck areas remained.
657	Many hours of exposure in the camera were required, making asphalt/bitumen impractical for ordinary photography, but from the 1850s to the 1920s it was in common use as a photoresist in the production of printing plates for various photomechanical printing processes.
657	Asphalt/bitumen was the nemesis of many artists during the 19th century.
657	Although widely used for a time, it ultimately proved unstable for use in oil painting, especially when mixed with the most common dilutents, such as linseed oil, varnish  and turpentine.
657	Unless thoroughly diluted, asphalt/bitumen never fully solidifies and will in time corrupt the other pigments with which it comes into contact.
657	The use of asphalt/bitumen as a glaze to set in shadow or mixed with other colours to render a darker tone resulted in the eventual deterioration of a good many paintings, those of Delacroix being just one notable example.
657	Perhaps the most famous example of the destructiveness of asphalt/bitumenjust one notable exa is Théodore Géricault's Raft of the Medusa (1818-1819), where his use of asphalt/bitumen caused the brilliant colors to degenerate into dark greens and blacks and the paint and canvas to buckle.
657	Early use in the United Kingdom Among the earlier uses of asphalt/bitumen in the United Kingdom was for etching.
657	William Salmon's Polygraphice (1673) provides a recipe for varnish used in etching, consisting of three ounces of virgin wax, two ounces of mastic, and one ounce of asphaltum.
657	By the fifth edition in 1685, he had included more asphaltum recipes from other sources.
657	The first British patent for the use of asphalt/bitumen was Cassell's patent asphalte or bitumen' in 1834.
657	Then on 25 November 1837, Richard Tappin Claridge patented the use of Seyssel asphalt (patent #7849), for use in asphalte pavement, having seen it employed in France and Belgium when visiting with Frederick Walter Simms, who worked with him on the introduction of asphalt to Britain.
657	Dr T.
657	Lamb Phipson claims that his father, Samuel Ryland Phipson, a friend of Claridge, was also "instrumental in introducing the asphalte pavement (in 1836)".
657	Indeed, mastic pavements had been previously employed at Vauxhall by a competitor of Claridge, but without success.
657	In 1838, Claridge obtained patents in Scotland on 27 March, and Ireland on 23 April, and in 1851 extensions were sought for all three patents, by the trustees of a company previously formed by Claridge.
657	This was Claridge's Patent Asphalte Company, formed in 1838 for the purpose of introducing to Britain "Asphalte in its natural state from the mine at Pyrimont Seysell in France", and "laid one of the first asphalt pavements in Whitehall".
657	Trials were made of the pavement in 1838 on the footway in Whitehall, the stable at Knightsbridge Barracks, "and subsequently on the space at the bottom of the steps leading from Waterloo Place to St.
657	James Park".
657	"The formation in 1838 of Claridge's Patent Asphalte Company (with a distinguished list of aristocratic patrons, and Marc and Isambard Brunel as, respectively, a trustee and consulting engineer), gave an enormous impetus to the development of a British asphalt industry".
657	"By the end of 1838, at least two other companies, Robinson's and the Bastenne company, were in production", with asphalt being laid as paving at les10.06.2">Miles,Brighton, Herne Bay, Canterbury, Kensington, the Strand, and a large floor area in Bunhill-row, while meantime Claridge's Whitehall paving "continue(d) in good order".
657	Indeed in 1838, there was a flurry of entrepreneurial activity over asphalt/bitumen, which had uses beyond paving.
657	For example, asphalt could also used for flooring, damp proofing in buildings, and for waterproofing of various types of pools and baths, with these latter themselves proliferating in the 19th century.
657	On the London stockmarket, there were various claims as to the exclusivity of asphalt quality from France, Germany and England.
657	And numerous patents were granted in France, with similar numbers of patent applications being denied in England due to their similarity to each other.
657	In England, "Claridge's was the type most used in the 1840s and 50s" In 1914, Claridge's Company entered into a joint venture to produce tar-bound macadam, with materials manufactured through a subsidiary company called Clarmac Roads Ltd.
657	Two products resulted, namely Clarmac, and Clarphalte, with the former being manufactured by Clarmac Roads and the latter by Claridge's Patent Asphalte Co., although Clarmac was more widely used.
657	However, the First World War  impacted financially on the Clarmac Company, which entered into liquidation in 1915.
657	The failure of Clarmac Roads Ltd had a flow-on effect to Claridge's Company, which was itself compulsorily wound up, ceasing operations in 1917, having invested a substantial amount of funds into the new venture, both at the outset, and in a subsequent attempt to save the Clarmac Company.
657	Early use in the United States  The first use of asphalt/bitumen in the New World was by indigenous peoples.
657	On the west coast, as early as the 13th century, the Tongva, Luiseño and Chumash peoples collected the naturally occurring asphalt/bitumen that seeped to the surface above underlying petroleum deposits.
657	All three used the substance as an adhesive.
657	It is found on many different artifacts of tools and ceremonial items.
657	For example, it was used on rattles to adhere gourds or turtle shells to rattle handles.
657	It was also used in decorations.
657	Small round shell beads were often set in asphaltum to provide decorations.
657	It was used as a sealant on baskets to make them watertight for carrying water.
657	Asphaltum was used also to seal the planks on ocean-going canoes.
657	Roads in the US have been paved with materials that include asphalt/bitumen since at least 1870, when a street in front of the Newark, NJ City Hall was paved.
657	In many cases, these early pavings were made from naturally occurring "bituminous rock".
657	In 1876, asphalt-based paving was used to pave Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, DC, in time for the celebration of the national centennial.
657	Asphalt/bitumen was also used for flooring, paving and waterproofing of baths and swimming pools during the early 20th century, following similar trends in Europe.
657	Modern use Rolled asphalt concrete  The largest use of asphalt/bitumen is for making asphalt concrete for road surfaces and accounts for approximately 85% of the asphalt consumed in the United States.
657	Asphalt concrete pavement material is commonly composed of 5% asphalt/bitumen cement and 95% aggregates (stone, sand, and gravel).
657	Due to its highly viscous nature, asphalt/bitumen cement must be heated so it can be mixed with the aggregates at the asphalt mixing plant.
657	There are about 4,000 asphalt concrete mixing plants in the U.S., and a similar number in Europe.
657	Asphalt concrete road surface is the most widely recycled material in the U.S., both by gross tonnage and by percentage.
657	According to an industry survey conducted by the Federal Highway Administration and the National Asphalt Pavement Association and released in 2011, more than 99% of the asphalt removed each year from road surfaces during widening and resurfacing projects is reused as part of new pavements, roadbeds, shoulders and embankments.
657	Roofing shingles account for most of the remaining asphalt/bitumen consumption.
657	Other uses include cattle sprays, fence-post treatments, and waterproofing for fabrics.
657	Asphalt concrete paving is widely used in airports around the world.
