666	Potassium While potash has been used since ancient times, it was not understood for most of its history to be a fundamentally different substance from sodium mineral salts.
666	Georg Ernst Stahl obtained experimental evidence which led him to suggest the fundamental difference of sodium and potassium salts in 1702, and Henri Louis Duhamel du Monceau was able to prove this difference in 1736.
666	The exact chemical composition of potassium and sodium compounds, and the status as chemical element of potassium and sodium, was not known then, and thus Antoine Lavoisier did include the alkali in his list of chemical elements in 1789.
666	Pure potassium was first isolated in 1807 in England by Sir Humphry Davy, who derived it from caustic potash (KOH, potassium hydroxide) by the use of electrolysis of the molten salt with the newly invented voltaic pile.
666	Potassium was the first metal that was isolated by electrolysis.
666	Later that same year, Davy reported extraction of sodium from the similar substance caustic soda (NaOH, lye) by a similar technique, demonstrating the elements, and thus the salts, to be different.
666	Rubidium Rubidium was discovered in 1861 in Heidelberg, Germany by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff, the first people to suggest finding new elements by spectrum analysis, in the mineral lepidolite through the use of a spectroscope.
666	Because of the bright red lines in its emission spectrum, they chose a name derived from the Latin word rubidus, meaning dark red.
666	Rubidium's discovery succeeded that of caesium, also discovered by Bunsen and Kirchhoff through spectroscopy.
666	Caesium In 1860, Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff discovered caesium in the mineral water from Dürkheim, Germany.
666	Due to the bright-blue lines in its emission spectrum, they chose a name derived from the Latin word caesius, meaning sky-blue.
666	Caesium was the first element to be discovered spectroscopically, only one year after the invention of the spectroscope by Bunsen and Kirchhoff.
666	Francium There were at least four erroneous and incomplete discoveries before Marguerite Perey of the Curie Institute in Paris, France discovered francium in 1939 by purifying a sample of actinium-227, which had been reported to have a decay energy of 220 keV.
666	However, Perey noticed decay particles with an energy level below 80 keV.
666	Perey thought this decay activity might have been caused by a previously unidentified decay product, one that was separated during purification, but emerged again out of the pure actinium-227.
666	Various tests eliminated the possibility of the unknown element being thorium, radium, lead, bismuth, or thallium.
666	The new product exhibited chemical properties of an alkali metal (such as coprecipitating with caesium salts), which led Perey to believe that it was element 87, caused by the alpha decay of actinium-227.
666	Perey then attempted to determine the proportion of beta decay to alpha decay in actinium-227.
666	Her first test put the alpha branching at 0.6%, a figure that she later revised to 1%.
666	It was the last element discovered in nature, rather than by synthesis.
666	Eka-francium The next element below francium (eka-francium) is very likely to be ununennium (Uue), element 119, although this is not completely certain due to relativistic effects.
666	The synthesis of ununennium was first attempted in 1985 by bombarding a target of einsteinium-254 with calcium-48 ions at the superHILAC accelerator at Berkeley, California.
666	No atoms were identified, leading to a limiting yield of 300 nb.
666	It is highly unlikely that this reaction will be able to create any atoms of ununennium in the near future, given the extremely difficult task of making sufficient amounts of 254Es, which is favoured for production of ultraheavy elements because of its large mass, relatively long half-life of 270 days, and availability in significant amounts of several micrograms, to make a large enough target to increase the sensitivity of the experiment to the required level; einsteinium has not been found in nature and has only been produced in laboratories.
666	However, given that ununennium is only the first period 8 element on the extended periodic table, it may well be discovered in the near future through other reactions; indeed, another attempt to synthesise ununennium by bombarding a berkelium target with titanium ions is under way at the GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research in Darmstadt, Germany.
666	Currently, none of the period 8 elements have been discovered yet, and it is also possible, due to drip instabilities, that only the lower period 8 elements, up to around element 128, are physically possible.
666	No attempts at synthesis have been made for any heavier alkali metals, such as unhexpentium, due to their extremely high atomic number.
666	Occurrence In the Solar System The Oddo-Harkins rule holds that elements with even atomic numbers are more common that those with odd atomic numbers, with the exception of hydrogen.
666	This rule argues that elements with odd atomic numbers have one unpaired proton and are more likely to capture another, thus increasing their atomic number.
666	In elements with even atomic numbers, protons are paired, with each member of the pair offsetting the spin of the other, enhancing stability.
666	All the alkali metals have odd atomic numbers and they are not as common as the elements with even atomic numbers adjacent to them (the noble gases and the alkaline earth metals) in the Solar System.
666	The heavier alkali metals are also less abundant than the lighter ones as the alkali metals from rubidium onward can only be synthesized in supernovae and not in stellar nucleosynthesis.
666	Lithium is also much less abundant than sodium and potassium as it is poorly synthesized in both Big Bang nucleosynthesis and in stars: the Big Bang could only produce trace quantities of lithium, beryllium and boron due to the absence of a stable nucleus with 5 or 8 nucleons, and stellar nucleosynthesis could only pass this bottleneck by the triple-alpha process, fusing three helium nuclei to form carbon, and skipping over those three elements.
666	On Earth The Earth formed from the same cloud of matter that formed the Sun, but the planets acquired different compositions during the formation and evolution of the solar system.
666	In turn, the natural history of the Earth caused parts of this planet to have differing concentrations of the elements.
666	The mass of the Earth is approximately 5.98 kg.
666	It is composed mostly of iron (32.1%), oxygen (30.1%), silicon (15.1%), magnesium (13.9%), sulfur (2.9%), nickel (1.8%), calcium (1.5%), and aluminium (1.4%); with the remaining 1.2% consisting of trace amounts of other elements.
666	Due to mass segregation, the core region is believed to be primarily composed of iron (88.8%), with smaller amounts of nickel (5.8%), sulfur (4.5%), and less than 1% trace elements.
666	The alkali metals, due to their high reactivity, do not occur naturally in pure form in nature.
666	They are lithophiles and therefore remain close to the Earth's surface because they combine readily with oxygen and so associate strongly with silica, forming relatively low-density minerals that do not sink down into the Earth's core.
666	Potassium, rubidium and caesium are also incompatible elements due to their low ionic radii.
666	Sodium and potassium are very abundant in earth, both being among the ten most common elements in Earth's crust; sodium makes up approximately 2.6% of the Earth's crust measured by weight, making it the sixth most abundant element overall and the most abundant alkali metal.
666	Potassium makes up approximately 1.5% of the Earth's crust and is the seventh most abundant element.
666	Sodium is found in many different minerals, of which the most common is ordinary salt (sodium chloride), which occurs in vast quantities dissolved in seawater.
666	Other solid deposits include halite, amphibole, cryolite, nitratine, and zeolite.
666	Lithium, due to its relatively low reactivity, can be found in seawater in large amounts; it is estimated that seawater is approximately 0.14 to 0.25 parts per million (ppm) or 25 micromolar.
666	Rubidium is approximately as abundant as zinc and more abundant than copper.
666	It occurs naturally in the minerals leucite, pollucite, carnallite, zinnwaldite, and lepidolite.
666	Caesium is more abundant than some commonly known elements, such as antimony, cadmium, tin, and tungsten, but is much less abundant than rubidium.
666	Francium-223, the only naturally occurring isotope of francium, is the product of the alpha decay of actinium-227 and can be found in trace amounts in uranium and thorium minerals.
666	In a given sample of uranium, there is estimated to be only one francium atom for every 1018 uranium atoms.
666	It has been calculated that there is at most 30 g of francium in the earth's crust at any time, due to its extremely short half-life of 22 minutes.
666	Production The production of pure alkali metals is difficult due to their extreme reactivity with commonly used substances, such as water.
666	The alkali metals are so reactive that they cannot be displaced by other elements and must be isolated through electrolysis.
666	Lithium salts have to be extracted from the water of mineral springs, brine pools, and brine deposits.
666	The metal is produced electrolytically from a mixture of fused lithium chloride and potassium chloride.
666	Potassium occurs in many minerals, such as sylvite (potassium chloride).
666	It is occasionally produced through separating the potassium from the chlorine in potassium chloride, but is more often produced through electrolysis of potassium hydroxide, found extensively in places such as Canada, Russia, Belarus, Germany, Israel, United States, and Jordan, in a method similar to how sodium was produced in the late 1800s and early 1900s.
666	It can also be produced from seawater.
666	Sodium occurs mostly in seawater and dried seabed, but is now produced through electrolysis of sodium chloride by lowering the melting point of the substance to below 700 °C through the use of a Downs cell.
666	Extremely pure sodium can be produced through the thermal decomposition of sodium azide.
666	For several years in the 1950s and 1960s, a by-product of the potassium production called Alkarb was a main source for rubidium.
666	Alkarb contained 21% rubidium while the rest was potassium and a small fraction of caesium.
666	Today the largest producers of caesium, for example the  Tanco Mine, Manitoba, Canada, produce rubidium as by-product from pollucite.
666	Today, a common method for separating rubidium from potassium and caesium is the fractional crystallization of a rubidium and caesium alum (Cs,Rb)Al(SO4)2·12H2O, which yields pure rubidium alum after approximately 30 different reactions.
666	The limited applications and the lack of a mineral rich in rubidium limits the production of rubidium compounds to 2 to 4 tonnes per year.
666	Caesium, however, is not produced from the above reaction.
666	Instead, the mining of pollucite ore is the main method of obtaining pure caesium, extracted from the ore mainly by three methods: acid digestion, alkaline decomposition, and direct reduction.
666	Francium-223, the only naturally occurring isotope of francium, is produced naturally as the product of the alpha decay of actinium-227.
666	Francium can be found in trace amounts in uranium and thorium minerals; it has been calculated that at most there are 30 g of francium in the earth's crust at any given time.
666	As a result of its extreme rarity in nature, most franciul |accessdate =26 Marcm is synthesized in the nuclear reaction 197Au + 18O → 210Fr + 5 n, yielding francium-209, francium-210, and francium-211.
666	The greatest quantity of francium ever assembled to date is about 300,000 neutral atoms, which were synthesized using the nuclear reaction given above.
666	Applications All of the discovered alkali metals excluding francium have many applications.
666	Lithium is often used in batteries, and lithium oxide can help process silica.
666	Lithium can also be used to make lubricating greases, air treatment, and aluminium production.
666	Pure sodium has many applications, including use in sodium-vapour lamps, which produce very efficient light compared to other types of lighting, and can help smooth the surface of other metals.
666	Sodium compounds have many applications as well, the most well-known compound being table salt.
666	Sodium is also used in soap as salts of fatty acids.
666	Potassium compounds are often used as fertilisers as potassium is an important element for plant nutrition.
666	Other potassium ions are often used to hold anions.
666	Potassium hydroxide is a very strong base, and is used to control the pH of various substances.
666	Rubidium and caesium are often used in atomic clocks.
666	Caesium atomic clocks are extraordinarily accurate; if a clock had been made at the time of the dinosaurs, it would be off by less than four seconds (after 80 million years).
666	For that reason, caesium atoms are used as the definition of the second.
666	Rubidium ions are often used in purple fireworks, and caesium is often used in drilling fluids in the petroleum industry.
666	Francium has no commercial applications, but because of francium's relatively simple atomic structure, among other things, it has been used in spectroscopy experiments, leading to more information regarding energy levels and the coupling constants between subatomic particles.
666	Studies on the light emitted by laser-trapped francium-210 ions have provided accurate data on transitions between atomic energy levels, similar to those predicted by quantum theory.
666	Biological role and precautions Lithium does not occur naturally in biological systems and has no biological role, but does have effects on the body when ingested.
666	Lithium carbonate is used as a mood stabiliser in psychiatry to treat bipolar disorder (manic-depression) in daily doses of about 0.5 to 2 grams, although there are side-effects.
666	Excessive ingestion of lithium causes drowsiness, slurred speech and vomiting, among other symptoms, and poisons the central nervous system, which is dangerous as the required dosage of lithium to treat bipolar disorder is only slightly lower than the toxic dosage.
666	Its biochemistry, the way it is handled by the human body and studies using rats and goats suggest that it is an essential trace element, although the natural biological function of lithium in humans has yet to be identified.
666	Sodium and potassium occur in all known biological systems, generally functioning as electrolytes inside and outside cells.
666	Sodium is an essential nutrient that regulates blood volume, blood pressure, osmotic equilibrium and pH; the minimum physiological requirement for sodium is 500 milligrams per day.
666	Sodium chloride (also known as common salt) is the principal source of sodium in the diet, and is used as seasoning and preservative, such as for pickling and jerky; most of it comes from processed foods.
666	The DRI for sodium is 1.5 grams per day, but most people in the United States consume more than 2.3 grams per day, the minimum amount that promotes hypertension; this in turn causes 7.6 million premature deaths worldwide.
666	Potassium is the major cation (positive ion) inside animal cells, while sodium is the major cation outside animal cells.
666	The concentration differences of these charged particles causes a difference in electric potential between the inside and outside of cells, known as the membrane potential.
666	The balance between potassium and sodium is maintained by ion pumps in the cell membrane.
666	The cell membrane potential created by potassium and sodium ions allows the cell to generate an action potential—a "spike" of electrical discharge.
666	The ability of cells to produce electrical discharge is critical for body functions such as neurotransmission, muscle contraction, and heart function.
666	Rubidium has no known biological role, but may help stimulate metabolism, and, similarly to caesium, replace potassium in the body causing potassium deficiency.
666	Caesium compounds are rarely encountered by most people, but most caesium compounds are mildly toxic because of chemical similarity of caesium to potassium, allowing the caesium to replace the potassium in the body, causing potassium deficiency.
666	Exposure to large amounts of caesium compounds can cause hyperirritability and spasms, but as such amounts would not ordinarily be encountered in natural sources, caesium is not a major chemical environmental pollutant.
666	The median lethal dose (LD50) value for caesium chloride in mice is 2.3 g per kilogram, which is comparable to the LD50 values of potassium chloride and sodium chloride.
666	Caesium chloride has been promoted as an alternative cancer therapy, but has been linked to the deaths of over 50 patients, on whom it was used as part of a scientifically unvalidated cancer treatment.
666	Radioisotopes of caesium require special precautions: the improper handling of caesium-137 gamma ray sources can lead to release of this radioisotope and radiation injuries.
666	Perhaps the best-known case is the Goiânia accident of 1987, in which an improperly-disposed-of radiation therapy system from an abandoned clinic in the city of Goiânia, Brazil, was scavenged from a junkyard, and the glowing caesium salt sold to curious, uneducated buyers.
666	This led to four deaths and serious injuries from radiation exposure.
666	Together with caesium-134, iodine-131, and strontium-90, caesium-137 was among the isotopes distributed by the Chernobyl disaster which constitute the greatest risk to health.
666	Francium has no biological role and is most likely to be toxic due to its extreme radioactivity, causing radiation poisoning, but since the greatest quantity of francium ever assembled to date is   about 300,000 neutral atoms, it is unlikely that most people will ever encounter francium.
666	Notes
670	An alphabet is a standard set of letters (basic written symbols or graphemes) which is used to write one or more languages based on the general principle that the letters represent phonemes (basic significant sounds) of the spoken language.
670	This is in contrast to other types of writing systems, such as syllabaries (in which each character represents a syllable) and logographies (in which each character represents a word, morpheme or semantic unit).
670	A true alphabet has letters for the vowels of a language as well as the consonants.
670	The first "true alphabet" in this sense is believed to be the Greek alphabet, which is a modified form of the Phoenician alphabet.
670	In other types of alphabet either the vowels are not indicated at all, as was the case in the Phoenician alphabet (such systems are known as abjads), or else the vowels are shown by diacritics or modification of consonants, as in the devanagari used in India and Nepal (these systems are known as abugidas or alphasyllabaries).
670	There are dozens of alphabets in use today, the most popular being the Latin alphabet (which was derived from the Greek).
670	Many languages use modified forms of the Latin alphabet, with additional letters formed using diacritical marks.
670	While most alphabets have letters composed of lines (linear writing), there are also exceptions such as the alphabets used in Braille, fingerspelling, and Morse code.
670	Alphabets are usually associated with a standard ordering of their letters.
670	This makes them useful for purposes of collation, specifically by allowing words to be sorted in alphabetical order.
670	It also means that their letters can be used as an alternative method of "numbering" ordered items, in such contexts as numbered lists.
670	Etymology The English word alphabet came into Middle English from the Late Latin word alphabetum, which in turn originated in the Greek ἀλφάβητος (alphabētos), from alpha and beta, the first two letters of the Greek alphabet.
670	Alpha and beta in turn came from the first two letters of the Phoenician alphabet, and originally meant ox and house respectively.
670	History Middle Eastern scripts The history of the alphabet started in ancient Egypt.
670	By the 27th century BC Egyptian writing had a set of some 24 hieroglyphs which are called uniliterals, to represent syllables that begin with a single consonant of their language, plus a vowel (or no vowel) to be supplied by the native speaker.
670	These glyphs were used as pronunciation guides for logograms, to write grammatical inflections, and, later, to transcribe loan words and foreign names.
670	In the Middle Bronze Age an apparently "alphabetic" system known as the Proto-Sinaitic script appears in Egyptian turquoise mines in the Sinai peninsula dated to circa the 15th century BC, apparently left by Canaanite workers.
670	In 1999, John and Deborah Darnell discovered an even earlier version of this first alphabet at Wadi el-Hol dated to circa 1800 BC and showing evidence of having been adapted from specific forms of Egyptian hieroglyphs that could be dated to circa 2000 BC, strongly suggesting that the first alphabet had been developed circa that time.
670	Based on letter appearances and names, it is believed to be based on Egyptian hieroglyphs.
670	This script had no characters representing vowels.
670	An alphabetic cuneiform script with 30 signs including three which indicate the following vowel was invented in Ugarit before the 15th century BC.
670	This script was not used after the destruction of Ugarit.
670	The South Arabian alphabet, a sister script to the Phoenician alphabet, is the script from which the Ge'ez alphabet (an abugida) is descended.
670	Vowelless alphabets, which are not true alphabets, are called abjads, currently exemplified in scripts including Arabic, Hebrew, and Syriac.
670	The omission of vowels was not a satisfactory solution and some "weak" consonants were used to indicate the vowel quality of a syllable (matres lectionis).
670	These had dual function since they were also used as pure consonants.
670	The Proto-Sinatic or Proto Canaanite script and the Ugaritic script were the first scripts with limited number of signs, in contrast to the other widely used writing systems at the time, Cuneiform, Egyptian hieroglyphs, and Linear B.
670	The Phoenician script was probably the first phonemic script and it contained only about two dozen distinct letters, making it a script simple enough for common traders to learn.
670	Another advantage of Phoenician was that it could be used to write down many different languages, since it recorded words phonemically.
670	The script was spread by the Phoenicians, across the Mediterranean.
670	In Greece, the script was modified to add the vowels, giving rise to the ancestor of all alphabets in the West.
670	The indication of the vowels is the same way as the indication of the consonants, therefore it was the first true alphabet.
670	The Greeks took letters which did not represent sounds that existed in Greek, and changed them to represent the vowels.
670	The vowels are significant in the Greek language, and the syllabical Linear B script which was used by the Mycenaean Greeks from the 16th century BC had 87 symbols including 5 vowels.
670	In its early years, there were many variants of the Greek alphabet, a situation which caused many different alphabets to evolve from it.
670	European alphabets The Greek alphabet, in its Euboean form, was carried over by Greek colonists to the Italian peninsula, where it gave rise to a variety of alphabets used to write the Italic languages.
670	One of these became the Latin alphabet, which was spread across Europe as the Romans expanded their empire.
670	Even after the fall of the Roman state, the alphabet survived in intellectual and religious works.
670	It eventually became used for the descendant languages of Latin (the Romance languages) and then for most of the other languages of Europe.
670	Some adaptations of the Latin alphabet are augmented with ligatures, such as æ in Old English and Icelandic and Ȣ in Algonquian; by borrowings from other alphabets, such as the thorn þ in Old English and Icelandic, which came from the Futhark runes; and by modifying existing letters, such as the eth ð of Old English and Icelandic, which is a modified d.
670	Other alphabets only use a subset of the Latin alphabet, such as Hawaiian, and Italian, which uses the letters j, k, x, y and w only in foreign words.
670	Another notable script is Elder Futhark, which is believed to have evolved out of one of the Old Italic alphabets.
670	Elder Futhark gave rise to a variety of alphabets known collectively as the Runic alphabets.
670	The Runic alphabets were used for Germanic languages from AD 100 to the late Middle Ages.
670	Its usage is mostly restricted to engravings on stone and jewelry, although inscriptions have also been found on bone and wood.
670	These alphabets have since been replaced with the Latin alphabet, except for decorative usage for which the runes remained in use until the 20th century.
670	The Old Hungarian script is a contemporary writing system of the Hungarians.
670	It was in use during the entire history of Hungary, albeit not as an official writing system.
670	From the 19th century it once again became more and more popular.
670	The Glagolitic alphabet was the initial script of the liturgical language Old Church Slavonic and became, together with the Greek uncial script, the basis of the Cyrillic script.
670	Cyrillic is one of the most widely used modern alphabetic scripts, and is notable for its use in Slavic languages and also for other languages within the former Soviet Union.
670	Cyrillic alphabets include the Serbian, Macedonian, Bulgarian, and Russian alphabets.
670	The Glagolitic alphabet is believed to have been created by Saints Cyril and Methodius, while the Cyrillic alphabet was invented by the Bulgarian scholar Clement of Ohrid, who was their disciple.
670	They feature many letters that appear to have been borrowed from or influenced by the Greek alphabet and the Hebrew alphabet.
670	Asian alphabets Beyond the logographic Chinese writing, many phonetic scripts are in existence in Asia.
670	The Arabic alphabet, Hebrew alphabet, Syriac alphabet, and other abjads of the Middle East are developments of the Aramaic alphabet, but because these writing systems are largely consonant-based they are often not considered true alphabets.
670	Most alphabetic scripts of India and Eastern Asia are descended from the Brahmi script, which is often believed to be a descendant of Aramaic.
670	In Korea, the Hangul alphabet was created by Sejong the Great Hangul is a unique alphabet: it is a featural alphabet, where many of the letters are designed from a sound's place of articulation (P to look like the widened mouth, L to look like the tongue pulled in, etc.); its design was planned by the government of the day; and it places individual letters in syllable clusters with equal dimensions, in the same way as Chinese characters, to allow for mixed-script writing (one syllable always takes up one type-space no matter how many letters get stacked into building that one sound-block).
670	Zhuyin (sometimes called Bopomofo) is a semi-syllabary used to phonetically transcribe Mandarin Chinese in the Republic of China.
670	After the later establishment of the People's Republic of China and its adoption of Hanyu Pinyin, the use of Zhuyin today is limited, but it's still widely used in Taiwan where the Republic of China still governs.
670	Zhuyin developed out of a form of Chinese shorthand based on Chinese characters in the early 1900s and has elements of both an alphabet and a syllabary.
670	Like an alphabet the phonemes of syllable initials are represented by individual symbols, but like a syllabary the phonemes of the sylble initials are represented by individual symbols, but lilable rime|syllable finals are not; rather, each possible final (excluding the medial glide) is represented by its own symbol.
670	For example, luan is represented as ㄌㄨㄢ (l-u-an), where the last symbol ㄢ represents the entire final -an.
670	While Zhuyin is not used as a mainstream writing system, it is still often used in ways similar to a romanization system—that is, for aiding in pronunciation and as an input method for Chinese characters on computers and cellphones.
670	European alphabets, especially Latin and Cyrillic, have been adapted for many languages of Asia.
670	Arabic is also widely used, sometimes as an abjad (as with Urdu and Persian) and sometimes as a complete alphabet (as with Kurdish and Uyghur).
670	Types The term "alphabet" is used by linguists and paleographers in both a wide and a narrow sense.
670	In the wider sense, an alphabet is a script that is segmental at the phoneme level—that is, it has separate glyphs for individual sounds and not for larger units such as syllables or words.
670	In the narrower sense, some scholars distinguish "true" alphabets from two other types of segmental script, abjads and abugidas.
670	These three differ from each other in the way they treat vowels: abjads have letters for consonants and leave most vowels unexpressed; abugidas are also consonant-based, but indicate vowels with diacritics to or a systematic graphic modification of the consonants.
670	In alphabets in the narrow sense, on the other hand, consonants and vowels are written as independent letters.
670	The earliest known alphabet in the wider sense is the Wadi el-Hol script, believed to be an abjad, which through its successor Phoenician is the ancestor of modern alphabets, including Arabic, Greek, Latin (via the Old Italic alphabet), Cyrillic (via the Greek alphabet) and Hebrew (via Aramaic).
670	Examples of present-day abjads are the Arabic and Hebrew scripts; true alphabets include Latin, Cyrillic, and Korean hangul; and abugidas are used to write Tigrinya, Amharic, Hindi, and Thai.
670	The Canadian Aboriginal syllabics are also an abugida rather than a syllabary as their name would imply, since each glyph stands for a consonant which is modified by rotation to represent the following vowel.
670	In a true syllabary, each consonant-vowel combination would be represented by a separate glyph.) All three types may be augmented with syllabic glyphs.
670	Ugaritic, for example, is basically an abjad, but has syllabic letters for.
670	These are the only time vowels are indicated.) Cyrillic is basically a true alphabet, but has syllabic letters for (я, е, ю); Coptic has a letter for.
670	Devanagari is typically an abugida augmented with dedicated letters for initial vowels, though some traditions use अ as a zero consonant as the graphic base for such vowels.
670	The boundaries between the three types of segmental scripts are not always clear-cut.
670	For example, Sorani Kurdish is written in the Arabic script, which is normally an abjad.
670	However, in Kurdish, writing the vowels is mandatory, and full letters are used, so the script is a true alphabet.
670	Other languages may use a Semitic abjad with mandatory vowel diacritics, effectively making them abugidas.
670	On the other hand, the Phagspa script of the Mongol Empire was based closely on the Tibetan abugida, but all vowel marks were written after the preceding consonant rather than as diacritic marks.
670	Although short a was not written, as in the Indic abugidas, one could argue that the linear arrangement made this a true alphabet.
670	Conversely, the vowel marks of the Tigrinya abugida and the Amharic abugida (ironically, the original source of the term "abugida") have been so completely assimilated into their consonants that the modifications are no longer systematic and have to be learned as a syllabary rather than as a segmental script.
670	Even more extreme, the Pahlavi abjad eventually became logographic.
670	See below.) Thus the primary classification of alphabets reflects how they treat vowels.
670	For tonal languages, further classification can be based on their treatment of tone, though names do not yet exist to distinguish the various types.
670	Some alphabets disregard tone entirely, especially when it does not carry a heavy functional load, as in Somali tirely, especially when it doeand many other languages of Africa and the Americas.
670	Such scripts are to tone what abjads are to vowels.
670	Most commonly, tones are indicated with diacritics, the way vowels are treated in abugidas.
670	This is the case for Vietnamese (a true alphabet) and Thai (an abugida).
670	In Thai, tone is determined primarily by the choice of consonant, with diacritics for disambiguation.
670	In the Pollard script, an abugida, vowels are indicated by diacritics, but the placement of the diacritic relative to the consonant is modified to indicate the tone.
670	More rarely, a script may have separate letters for tones, as is the case for Hmong and Zhuang.
670	For most of these scripts, regardless of whether letters or diacritics are used, the most common tone is not marked, just as the most common vowel is not marked in Indic abugidas; in Zhuyin not only is one of the tones unmarked, but there is a diacritic to indicate lack of tone, like the virama of Indic.
670	The number of letters in an alphabet can be quite small.
670	The Book Pahlavi script, an abjad, had only twelve letters at one point, and may have had even fewer later on.
670	Today the Rotokas alphabet has only twelve letters.
670	The Hawaiian alphabet is sometimes claimed to be as small, but it actually consists of 18 letters, including the ʻokina and five long vowels.) While Rotokas has a small alphabet because it has few phonemes to represent (just eleven), Book Pahlavi was small because many letters had been conflated—that is, the graphic distinctions had been lost over time, and diacritics were not developed to compensate for this as they were in Arabic, another script that lost many of its distinct letter shapes.
670	For example, a comma-shaped letter represented g, d, y, k, or j.
670	However, such apparent simplifications can perversely make a script more complicated.
670	In later Pahlavi papyri, up to half of the remaining graphic distinctions of these twelve letters were lost, and the script could no longer be read as a sequence of letters at all, but instead each word had to be learned as a whole—that is, they had become logograms as in Egyptian Demotic.
670	The alphabet in the Polish language contains 32 letters.
670	The largest segmental script is probably an abugida, Devanagari.
670	When written in Devanagari, Vedic Sanskrit has an alphabet of 53 letters, including the visarga mark for final aspiration and special letters for kš and jñ, though one of the letters is theoretical and not actually used.
670	The Hindi alphabet must represent both Sanskrit and modern vocabulary, and so has been expanded to 58 with the khutma letters (letters with a dot added) to represent sounds from Persian and English.
670	The largest known abjad is Sindhi, with 51 letters.
670	The largest alphabets in the narrow sense include Kabardian and Abkhaz (for Cyrillic), with 58 and 56 letters, respectively, and Slovak (for the Latin script), with 46.
670	However, these scripts either count di- and tri-graphs as separate letters, as Spanish did with ch and ll until recently, or uses diacritics like Slovak č.
670	The largest true alphabet where each letter is graphically independent is probably Georgian, with 41 letters.
670	Syllabaries typically contain 50 to 400 glyphs, and the glyphs of logographic systems typically number from the many hundreds into the thousands.
670	Thus a simple count of the number of distinct symbols is an important clue to the nature of an unknown script.
670	Alphabetical order Alphabets often come to be associated with a standard ordering of their letters, which can then be used for purposes of collation – namely for the listing of words and other items in what is called alphabetical order.
670	The basic ordering of the Latin alphabet (ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ), which is derived from the Northwest Semitic "Abgad" order, is well established, although languages using this alphabet have different conventions for their treatment of modified letters (such as the French é, à, and ô) and of certain combinations of letters (multigraphs).
670	In French, these are not considered to be additional letters for the purposes of collation.
670	However, in Icelandic, the accented letters such as á, í, and ö are considered to be distinct letters of the alphabet.
670	In Spanish, ñ is considered a separate letter, but accented vowels such as á and é are not.
670	The ll and ch were also considered single letters, but in 1994 the Real Academia Española changed collating order so that ll is between lk and lm in the dictionary and ch is between cg and ci, and in 2010 the tenth congress of the Association of Spanish Language Academies changed it so they were no longer letters at all In German, words starting with sch- (constituting the German phoneme) would be intercalated between words with initial sca- and sci- (all incidentally loanwords) instead of this graphic cluster appearing after the letter s, as though it were a single letter—a lexicographical policy which would be de rigueur in a dictionary of Albanian, i.e.
670	Nor is, in a dictionary of English, the lexical section with initial th- reserved a place after the letter t, but is inserted between te- and ti-.
670	German words with umlaut would further be alphabetized as if there were no umlaut at all—contrary to Turkish which allegedly adopted the German graphemes ö and ü, and where a word like tüfek, would come after tuz, in the dictionary.
670	An exception is the German phonebook where umlauts are sorted like ä = ae since names as Jäger appear also with the spelling Jaeger, and there's no telling them apart in the spoken language.
670	The Danish and Norwegian alphabets end with æ—ø—å, whereas the Icelandic, Swedish, Finnish and Estonian ones conventionally put å—ä—ö at the end.
670	It is unknown whether the earliest alphabets had a defined sequence.
670	Some alphabets today, such as the Hanuno'o script, are learned one letter at a time, in no particular order, and are not used for collation where a definite order is required.
670	However, a dozen Ugaritic tablets from the fourteenth century BC preserve the alphabet in two sequences.
670	One, the ABCDE order later used in Phoenician, has continued with minor changes in Hebrew, Greek, Armenian, Gothic, Cyrillic, and Latin; the other, HM|Armenian, Gothic, Cyrillic, and Ethiopic.
670	Both orders have therefore been stable for at least 3000 years.
670	The historical order was abandoned in Runic and Arabic, although Arabic retains the traditional abjadi order for numbering.
670	The Brahmic family of alphabets used in India use a unique order based on phonology: The letters are arranged according to how and where they are produced in the mouth.
670	This organization is used in Southeast Asia, Tibet, Korean hangul, and even Japanese kana, which is not an alphabet.
670	Names of letters The Phoenician letter names, in which each letter was associated with a word that begins with that sound, continue to be used to varying degrees in Samaritan, Aramaic, Syriac, Hebrew, Greek and Arabic.
670	The names were abandoned in Latin, which instead referred to the letters by adding a vowel (usually e) before or after the consonant (the exception is zeta, which was retained from Greek).
670	In Cyrillic originally the letters were given names based on Slavic words; this was later abandoned as well in favor of a system similar to that used in Latin.
670	Orthography and pronunciation When an alphabet is adopted or developed for use in representing a given language, an orthography generally comes into being, providing rules for the spelling of words in that language.
670	In accordance with the principle on which alphabets are based, these rules will generally map letters of the alphabet to the phonemes (significant sounds) of the spoken language.
670	In a perfectly phonemic orthography there would be a consistent one-to-one correspondence between the letters and the phonemes, so that a writer could predict the spelling of a word given its pronunciation, and a speaker could predict the pronunciation of a word given its spelling.
670	However this ideal is not normally achieved in practice; some languages (such as Spanish and Finnish) come close to it, while others (such as English) deviate from it to a much larger degree.
670	The pronunciation of a language often evolves independently of its writing system, and writing systems have been borrowed for languages they were not designed for, so the degree to which letters of an alphabet correspond to phonemes of a language varies greatly from one language to another and even within a single language.
670	Languages may fail to achieve a one-to-one correspondence between letters and sounds in any of several ways: * A language may represent a given phoneme with a combination of letters rather than just a single letter.
670	Two-letter combinations are called digraphs and three-letter groups are called trigraphs.
670	German uses the tesseragraphs (four letters) "tsch" for the phoneme and "dsch" for, although the latter is rare.
670	Kabardian also uses a tesseragraph for one of its phonemes, namely "кхъу".
670	Two letters representing one sound is widely used in Hungarian as well (where, for instance, cs stands for [č], sz for [s], zs for [ž], dzs for [ǰ], etc.).
670	A language may represent the same phoneme with two different letters or combinations of letters.
670	An example is modern Greek which may write the phoneme in six different ways: ⟨ι⟩, ⟨η⟩, ⟨υ⟩, ⟨ει⟩, ⟨οι⟩, and ⟨υι⟩ (although the last is rare).
670	A language may spell some words with unpronounced letters that exist for historical or other reasons.
670	For example, the spelling of the Thai word for "beer" [เบียร์] retains a letter for the final consonant "r" present in the English word it was borrowed from, but silences it.
670	Pronunciation of individual words may change according to the presence of surrounding words in a sentence (sandhi).
670	Different dialects of a language may use different phonemes for the same word.
670	A language may use different sets of symbols or different rules for distinct sets of vocabulary items, such as the Japanese hiragana and katakana syllabaries, or the various rules in English for spelling words from Latin and Greek, or the original Germanic vocabulary.
670	National languages generally elect to address the problem of dialects by simply associating the alphabet with the national standard.
670	However, with an international language with wide variations in its dialects, such as English, it would be impossible to represent the language in all its variations with a single phonetic alphabet.
670	Some national languages like Finnish, Turkish, Serbo-Croatian (Serbian, Croatian and Bosnian) and Bulgarian have a very regular spelling system with a nearly one-to-one correspondence between letters and phonemes.
670	Strictly speaking, these national languages lack a word corresponding to the verb "to spell" (meaning to split a word into its letters), the closest match being a verb meaning to split a word into its syllables.
670	Similarly, the Italian verb corresponding to 'spell (out)', compitare, is unknown to many Italians because the act of spelling itself is rarely needed: Italian spelling is highly phonemic.
670	In standard Spanish, it is possible to tell the pronunciation of a word from its spelling, but not vice versa; this is because certain phonemes can be represented in more than one way, but a given letter is consistently pronounced.
670	French, with its silent letters and its heavy use of nasal vowels and elision, may seem to lack much correspondence between spelling and pronunciation, but its rules on pronunciation, though complex, are actually consistent and predictable with a fair degree of accuracy.
670	At the other extreme are languages such as English, where the spelling of many words simply has to be memorized as they do not correspond to sounds in a consistent way.
670	For English, this is partly because the Great Vowel Shift occurred after the orthography was established, and because English has acquired a large number of loanwords at different times, retaining their original spelling at varying levels.
670	Even English has general, albeit complex, rules that predict pronunciation from spelling, and these rules are successful most of the time; rules to predict spelling from the pronunciation have a higher failure rate.
670	Sometimes, countries have the written language undergo a spelling reform to realign the writing with the contemporary spoken language.
670	These can range from simple spelling changes and word forms to switching the entire writing system itself, as when Turkey switched from the Arabic alphabet to a Turkish alphabet of Latin origin.
670	The sounds of speech of all languages of the world can be written by a rather-small universal phonetic-alphabet.
670	A standard for this is the International Phonetic Alphabet.
673	In chemistry and physics, the atomic number (also known as the proton number) is the number of protons found in the nucleus of an atom and therefore identical to the charge number of the nucleus.
673	It is conventionally represented by the symbol Z.
673	The atomic number uniquely identifies a chemical element.
673	In an atom of neutral charge, the atomic number is also equal to the number of electrons.
673	The atomic number, Z, should not be confused with the mass number, A, which is the number of nucleons, the total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom.
673	The number of neutrons, N, is known as the neutron number of the atom; thus, A = Z + N.
673	Since protons and neutrons have approximately the same mass (and the mass of the electrons is negligible for many purposes), and the mass defect is usually very small compared to the mass, the atomic mass of an atom is roughly equal to A.
673	Atoms having the same atomic number Z but different neutron number N, and hence different atomic mass, are known as isotopes.
673	Most naturally occurring elements exist as a mixture of isotopes, and the average atomic mass of this mixture determines the element's atomic weight.
673	The conventional symbol Z comes from the German word  meaning number/numeral/figure, which prior to the modern synthesis of ideas from chemistry and physics, merely denoted an element's numerical place in the periodic table.
673	Only after 1915, with the suggestion and evidence that this Z number was also the nuclear charge and a physical characteristic of atoms, did the word  and its English equivalent atomic number come into common use.
673	History Loosely speaking, the existence of a periodic table creates an ordering for the elements.
673	Such an ordering is not necessarily a numbering, but can be used to construct a numbering by fiat.
673	Dmitri Mendeleev claimed he arranged his tables in order of atomic weight ("Atomgewicht") However, in deference to the observed chemical properties, he violated his own rule and placed tellurium (atomic weight 127.6) ahead of iodine (atomic weight 126.9).
673	This placement is consistent with the modern practice of ordering the elements by proton number, Z, but this number was not known or suspected at the time.
673	A simple numbering based on periodic table position was never entirely satisfactory.
673	Besides iodine and tellurium, later several other pairs of elements (such as argon and potassium, cobalt and nickel) were known to have nearly identical or reversed atomic weights, leaving their placement in the periodic table by chemical properties to be in violation of known physical properties.
673	Another problem was that the gradual identification of more and more chemically similar and indistinguishable lanthanides, which were of an uncertain number, led to inconsistency and uncertainty in the numbering of elements at least from lutetium (element 71) onwards (hafnium was not known at this time).
673	In 1911, Ernest Rutherford gave a model of the atom in which a central core held most of the atom's mass and a positive charge which, in units of the electron's charge, was to be approximately equal to half of the atom's atomic weight, expressed in numbers of hydrogen atoms.
673	This central charge would thus be approximately half the atomic weight (though it was almost 25% off the figure for the atomic number in gold (Z  79, A   197), the single element from which Rutherford made his guess).
673	Nevertheless, in spite of Rutherford's estimation that gold had a central charge of about 100 (but was element Z = 79 on the periodic table), a month after Rutherford's paper appeared, Antonius van den Broek first formally suggested that the central charge and number of electrons in an atom was exactly equal to its place in the periodic table (also known as element number, atomic number, and symbolized Z).
673	This proved eventually to be the case.
673	The experimental situation improved dramatically after research by Henry Moseley in 1913.
673	Moseley, after discussions with Bohr who was at the same lab (and who had used Van den Broek's hypothesis in his Bohr model of the atom), decided to test Van den Broek and Bohr's hypothesis directly, by seeing if spectral lines emitted from excited atoms fit the Bohr theory's demand that the frequency of the spectral lines be proportional to a measure of the square of Z.
673	To do this, Moseley measured the wavelengths of the innermost photon transitions (K and L lines) produced by the elements from aluminum (Z  13) to gold (Z   79) used as a series of movable anodic targets inside an x-ray tube.
673	The square root of the frequency of these photons (x-rays) increased from one target to the next in a linear fashion.
673	This led to the conclusion (Moseley's law) that the atomic number does closely correspond (with an offset of one unit for K-lines, in Moseley's work) to the calculated electric charge of the nucleus, i.e.
673	Z.
673	Among other things, Moseley demonstrated that the lanthanide series (from lanthanum to lutetium inclusive) must have 15 members—no fewer and no more—which was far from obvious from the chemistry at that time.
673	The conventional symbol Z possibly comes from the German word  (atomic number).
673	However, prior to 1915, the word Zahl (simply number) was used for an element's assigned number in the periodic table.
673	Chemical properties Each element has a specific set of chemical properties as a consequence of the number of electrons present in the neutral atom, which is Z (the atomic number).
673	The configuration of these electrons follows from the principles of quantum mechanics.
673	The number of electrons in each element's electron shells, particularly the outermost valence shell, is the primary factor in determining its chemical bonding behavior.
673	Hence, it is the atomic number alone that determines the chemical properties of an element; and it is for this reason that an element can be defined as consisting of any mixture of atoms with a given atomic number.
673	New elements The quest for new elements is usually described using atomic numbers.
673	As of 2010, elements with atomic numbers 1 to 118 have been observed.
673	Synthesis of new elements is accomplished by bombarding target atoms of heavy elements with ions, such that the sum of the atomic numbers of the target and ion elements equals the atomic number of the element being created.
673	In general, the half-life becomes shorter as atomic number increases, though an "island of stability" may exist for undiscovered isotopes with certain numbers of protons and neutrons.
674	Anatomy (from the Greek  - anatemnō, "cut up, cut open", from ἀνά - ana, "on, upon", and τέμνω - temnō, "I cut") is a branch of biology and medicine that considers the structure of living things.
674	It is a general term that includes human anatomy, animal anatomy (zootomy), and plant anatomy (phytotomy).
674	In some of its facets anatomy is closely related to embryology, comparative anatomy and comparative embryology, through common roots in evolution.
674	Anatomy is subdivided into gross anatomy (or macroscopic anatomy) and microscopic anatomy.
674	Gross anatomy is the study of anatomical structures that can, when suitably presented or dissected, be seen by unaided vision with the naked eye.
674	Microscopic anatomy is the study of minute anatomical structures on a microscopic scale.
674	It includes histology (the study of tissues), and cytology (the study of cells).
674	The terms microanatomy and histology are also sometimes used synonymously (in which case the distinction between histology and cell biology isn't strictly made as described here).
674	The history of anatomy has been characterized, over time, by a continually developing understanding of the functions of organs and structures in the body.
674	Methods have also improved dramatically, advancing from examination of animals through dissection of cadavers (dead human bodies) to technologically complex techniques developed in the 20th century including X-ray, ultrasound, and MRI.
674	Anatomy should not be confused with anatomical pathology (also called morbid anatomy or histopathology), which is the study of the gross and microscopic appearances of diseased organ (anatomy)gy), which is the study of the|organs.
674	Superficial anatomy  Superficial anatomy or surface anatomy is important in anatomy being the study of anatomical landmarks that can be readily seen from the contours or the surface of the body.
674	With knowledge of superficial anatomy, physicians or veterinary surgeons gauge the position and anatomy of the associated deeper structures.
674	Superficial is a directional term that indicates one structure is located more externally than another, or closer to the surface of the body.
674	Animal anatomy  Insect anatomy  Vertebrate anatomy  Bird anatomy  Reptile anatomy  Fish anatomy  Mammal anatomy  Human anatomy  Human anatomy, including gross human anatomy and histology, is primarily the scientific study of the morphology of the adult human body.
674	Generally, students of certain biological sciences, paramedics, prosthetists and orthotists, physiotherapists, occupational therapists, nurses, and medical students learn gross anatomy and microscopic anatomy from anatomical models, skeletons, textbooks, diagrams, photographs, lectures and tutorials, and in addition, medical students generally also learn gross anatomy through practical experience of dissection and inspection of cadavers.
674	The study of microscopic anatomy (or histology) can be aided by practical experience examining histological preparations (or slides) under a microscope.
674	Human anatomy, physiology and biochemistry are complementary basic medical sciences, which are generally taught to medical students in their first year at medical school.
674	Human anatomy can be taught regionally or systemically; that is, respectively, studying anatomy by bodily regions such as the head and chest, or studying by specific systems, such as the nervous or respiratory systems.
674	The major anatomy textbook, Gray's Anatomy, has recently been reorganized from a systems format to a regional format, in line with modern teaching methods.
674	A thorough working knowledge of anatomy is required by physicians, especially surgeons and doctors working in some diagnostic specialties, such as histopathology and radiology.
674	Academic human anatomists are usually employed by universities, medical schools or teaching hospitals.
674	They are often involved in teaching anatomy, and research into certain systems, organs, tissues or cells.
674	Plant anatomy  Other branches  *Comparative anatomy relates to the comparison of anatomical structures (both gross and microscopic) in different animals.
674	Anthropological anatomy or physical anthropology relates to the comparison of the anatomy of different races of humans.
674	Artistic anatomy relates to anatomic studies for artistic reasons.
675	Affirming the consequent, sometimes called converse error or fallacy of the converse, is a formal fallacy of inferring the converse from the original statement.
675	The corresponding argument has the general form: #If P, then Q.
675	Q.
675	Therefore, P.
675	An argument of this form is invalid, i.e., the conclusion can be false even when statements 1 and 2 are true.
675	Since P was never asserted as the only sufficient condition for Q, other factors could account for Q (while P was false).
675	To put it differently, if P implies Q, the only inference that can be made is non-Q implies non-P.
675	Non-P and non-Q designate the opposite propositions to P and Q.)  Symbolically: (P ⇒ Q) ⇔ (non-Q ⇒ non-P) The name affirming the consequent derives from the premise Q, which affirms the "then" clause of the conditional premise.
675	Examples One way to demonstrate the invalidity of this argument form is with a counterexample with true premises but an obviously false conclusion.
675	For example: If Bill Gates owns Fort Knox, then he is rich.
675	Bill Gates is rich.
675	Therefore, Bill Gates owns Fort Knox.
675	Owning Fort Knox is not the only way to be rich.
675	Any number of other ways exist to be rich.
675	However, one can affirm with certainty that "if Bill Gates is not rich" (non-Q) then "Bill Gates does not own Fort Knox" (non-P) Arguments of rich" (the same form can sometimes seem superficially convincing, as in the following example: If I have the flu, then I have a sore throat.
675	I have a sore throat.
675	Therefore, I have the flu.
675	But having the flu is not the only cause of a sore throat since many illnesses cause sore throat, such as the common cold or strep throat.
676	Andrei Arsenyevich Tarkovsky (; 4 April 1932 – 29 December 1986) was a Soviet and Russian filmmaker, writer, film editor, film theorist, theatre and opera director.
676	Tarkovsky's films include Andrei Rublev, Solaris, The Mirror, and Stalker.
676	He directed the first five of his seven feature films in the Soviet Union; his last two films were produced in Italy and Sweden, respectively.
676	They are characterized by spirituality and metaphysical themes, long takes, lack of conventional dramatic structure, and distinctively authored use of cinematography.
676	Film director Ingmar Bergman said of Tarkovsky: Life Childhood and early life Tarkovsky was born in the village of Zavrazhye in the Yuryevetsky District of the Ivanovo Industrial Oblast to poet and translator Arseny Alexandrovich Tarkovsky, native of Kirovohrad, Ukraine; and Maria Ivanova Vishnyakova, a graduate of the Maxim Gorky Literature Institute.
676	Andrei's grandfather Aleksander Tarkowski was a Polish nobleman who worked as a bank clerk.
676	Tarkovsky spent his childhood in Yuryevets.
676	He was described by childhood friends as active and popular, having many friends and being typically in the center of action.
676	In 1937, his father left the family, subsequently volunteering for the army in 1941.
676	Tarkovsky stayed with his mother, moving with her and his sister Marina to Moscow, where she worked as a proofreader at a printing press.
676	In 1939, Tarkovsky enrolled at the Moscow School № 554.
676	During the war, the three evacuated to Yuryevets, living with his maternal grandmother.
676	In 1943, the family returned to Moscow.
676	Tarkovsky continued his studies at his old school, where the poet Andrey Voznesensky was one of his classmates.
676	He studied piano at a music school and attended classes at an art school.
676	The family lived on Shshipok Street in the Zamoskvorechye District in Moscow.
676	From November 1947 to Spring 1948 he was in the hospital with tuberculosis.
676	Many themes of his childhood — the evacuation, his mother and her two children, the withdrawn father, the time in the hospital — feature prominently in his film The Mirror.
676	Following high school graduation, from 1951 to 1952, Tarkovsky studied Arabic at the Oriental Institute in Moscow, a branch of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR.
676	Although he already spoke some Arabic and was a successful student in his first semesters, he did not finish his studies and dropped out to work as a prospector for the Academy of Science Institute for Non-Ferrous Metals and Gold.
676	He participated in a year-long research expedition to the river Kureikye near Turukhansk in the Krasnoyarsk Province.
676	During this time in the Taiga Tarkovsky decided to study film.
676	Film school student Upon returning from the research expedition in 1954, Tarkovsky applied at the State Institute of Cinematography (VGIK) and was admitted to the film directing program.
676	He was in the same class as Irma Raush whom he married in April 1957.
676	The early Khrushchev era offered unique opportunities for young film directors.
676	Before 1953, annual film production was low and most films were directed by veteran directors.
676	After 1953, more films were produced, many of them by young directors.
676	The Khrushchev Thaw relaxed Soviet cultural restrictions a bit and permitted a limited influx of Western literature, films and music.
676	This allowed Tarkovsky to see films of the Italian neorealists, French New Wave, and of directors such as Kurosawa, Buñuel, Bergman, Bresson, Andrzej Wajda (whose film Ashes and Diamonds was a true experience for him) and Mizoguchi.
676	Tarkovsky absorbed the idea of the auteur as a necessary condition for creativity.
676	Tarkovsky's teacher and mentor was Mikhail Romm, who taught many film students who would later become influential film directors.
676	In 1956, Tarkovsky directed his first student short film, The Killers, from a short story of Ernest Hemingway.
676	The short film There Will Be No Leave Today and the screenplay Concentrate followed in 1958 and 1959.
676	An important influence on Tarkovsky was the film director Grigori Chukhrai, who was teaching at the VGIK.
676	Impressed by the talent of his student, Chukhrai offered Tarkovsky a position as assistant director for his film Clear Skies.
676	Tarkovsky initially showed interest but then decided to concentrate on his studies and his own projects.
676	During his third year at the VGIK, Tarkovsky met Andrei Konchalovsky.
676	They found much in common as they liked the same film directors and shared ideas on cinema and films.
676	In 1959, they wrote the script Antarctica — Distant Country, which was later published in the Moskovskij Komsomolets.
676	Tarkovsky submitted the script to Lenfilm, but it was rejected.
676	They were more successful with the script The Steamroller and the Violin, which they sold to Mosfilm.
676	This became Tarkovsky's graduation project, earning him his diploma in 1960 and winning First Prize at the New York Student Film Festival in 1961.
676	Career Film career in the Soviet Union Tarkovsky's first feature film was Ivan's Childhood in 1962.
676	He had inherited the film from director Eduard Abalov, who had to abort the project.
676	The film earned Tarkovsky international acclaim and won the Golden Lion award at the Venice Film Festival in 1962.
676	In the same year, on September 30, his first son Arseny (called Senka in Tarkovsky's diaries) Tarkovsky was born.
676	In 1965, he directed the film Andrei Rublev about the life of Andrei Rublev, the 15th century Russian icon painter.
676	Andrei Rublev was not immediately released after completion due to problems with Soviet authorities.
676	Tarkovsky had to cut the film several times, resulting in several different versions of varying lengths.
676	A version of the film was presented at the Cannes Film Festival in 1969 and won the FIPRESCI prize.
676	The film was officially released in the Soviet Union in a cut version in 1971.
676	He divorced his wife, Irma Raush, in June 1970.
676	In the same year, he married Larissa Kizilova (née Egorkina), who had been a production assistant for the film Andrei Rublev (they had been living together since 1965).
676	Their son, Andrei Andreyevich Tarkovsky, was born in the same year on August 7.
676	In 1972, he completed Solaris, an adaptation of the novel Solaris by Stanisław Lem.
676	He had worked on this together with screenwriter Fridrikh Gorenshtein as early as 1968.
676	The film was presented at the Cannes Film Festival and won the Grand Prix Spécial du Jury and the FIPRESCI prize and was nominated for the Palme d'Or.
676	From 1973 to 1974, he shot the film The Mirror, a highly autobiographical film drawing on his childhood and incorporating some of his father's poems.
676	Tarkovsky had worked on the screenplay for this film since 1967, under the consecutive titles Confession, White day and A white, white day.
676	From the beginning the film was not well received by Soviet authorities due to its content and its perceived elitist nature.
676	Russian authorities placed the film in the "third category" which meant severe limitations on its distribution, allowing it to be shown only in third class cinemas and workers' clubs.
676	Few prints were made and the filmmakers received no returns.
676	Third category films also placed the filmmakers in danger of being accused of wasting public funds, which could have serious effects on their future productivity.
676	These difficulties are presumed to have made Tarkovsky play with the idea of going abroad and producing a film outside the Soviet film industry.
676	During 1975, Tarkovsky also worked on the screenplay Hoffmanniana, about the German writer and poet E.
676	T.
676	A.
676	Hoffmann.
676	In December 1976, he directed Hamlet, his only stage play, at the Lenkom Theatre in Moscow.
676	The main role was played by Anatoly Solonitsyn, who also acted in several of Tarkovsky's films.
676	At the end of 1978, he also wrote the screenplay Sardor together with the writer Aleksandr Misharin.
676	The last film Tarkovsky completed in the Soviet Union was Stalker, inspired by the novel Roadside Picnic by the brothers Arkady and Boris Strugatsky.
676	Tarkovsky had met the brothers first in 1971 and was in contact with them until his death in 1986.
676	Initially he wanted to shoot a film based on their novel Dead Mountaineer's Hotel and he developed a raw script.
676	Influenced by a discussion with Arkady Strugatsky he changed his plan and began to work on the script based on Roadside Picnic.
676	Work on this film began in 1976.
676	The production was mired in troubles; improper development of the negatives had ruined all the exterior shots.
676	Tarkovsky's relationship with cinematographer Georgy Rerberg deteriorated to the point where Tarkovsky hired Alexander Knyazhinsky as a new first cinematographer.
676	Furthermore, Tarkovsky suffered a heart attack in April 1978, resulting in further delay.
676	The film was completed in 1979 and won the Prize of the Ecumenical Jury at the Cannes Film Festival.
676	In the same year Tarkovsky also began the production of the film The First Day (Russian: Первый День Pervyj Dyen′), based on a script by his friend and longterm collaborator Andrei Konchalovsky.
676	The film was set in 18th Century Russia during the reign of Peter the Great and starred Natalya Bondarchuk and Anatoli Papanov in the main roles.
676	To get the project approved by Goskino, Tarkovsky submitted a script that was different from the original script, leaving out several scenes that were critical of the official atheism in the Soviet Union.
676	After shooting roughly one half of the film the project was stopped by Goskino after it became apparent that the film differed from the script submitted to the censors.
676	Tarkovsky was reportedly infuriated by this interruption and destroyed most of the film.
676	Film career outside the Soviet Union During the summer of 1979, Tarkovsky traveled to Italy, where he shot the documentary Voyage in Time together with his longtime friend Tonino Guerra.
676	Tarkovsky returned to Italy in 1980 for an extended trip during which he and Tonino Guerra completed the script for the film Nostalghia.
676	During 1981 he traveled to the United Kingdom and Swedenthe script for the film Nostalghia.
676	During 1981 he traveled to the.
676	During his trip to Sweden he had considered defecting from the Soviet Union, but ultimately decided to return because of his wife and his son.
676	Tarkovsky returned to Italy in 1982 to start shooting Nostalghia.
676	He did not return to his home country.
676	As Mosfilm withdrew from the project, he had to complete the film with financial support provided by the Italian RAI.
676	Tarkovsky completed the film in 1983.
676	Nostalghia was presented at the Cannes Film Festival and won the FIPRESCI prize and the Prize of the Ecumenical Jury.
676	Tarkovsky also shared a special prize called Grand Prix du cinéma de creation with Robert Bresson.
676	Soviet authorities prevented the film from winning the Palme d'Or, a fact that hardened Tarkovsky's resolve to never work in the Soviet Union again.
676	In the same year, he also staged the opera Boris Godunov at the Royal Opera House in London under the musical direction of Claudio Abbado.
676	He spent most of 1984 preparing the film The Sacrifice.
676	At a press conference in Milan on 10 July 1984, he announced that he would never return to the Soviet Union and would remain in the West.
676	At that time, his son Andrei Jr.
676	Soviet Union and not allowed to leave the country.
676	During 1985, he shot the film The Sacrifice in Sweden.
676	At the end of the year he was diagnosed with terminal lung cancer.
676	In January 1986, he began treatment in Paris and was joined there by his son, who was finally allowed to leave the Soviet Union.
676	The Sacrifice was presented at the Cannes Film Festival and received the Grand Prix Spécial du Jury, the FIPRESCI prize and the Prize of the Ecumenical Jury.
676	As Tarkovsky was unable to attend due to his illness, the prizes were collected by his son, Andrei Jr.
676	In Tarkovsky's last diary entry (15 December 1986), he wrote: "But now I have no strength left — that is the problem".
676	The diaries are sometimes also known as Martyrolog and were published posthumously in 1989 and in English in 1991.
676	Tarkovsky died in Paris on 29 December 1986.
676	His funeral ceremony was held at the Alexander Nevsky Cathedral.
676	He was buried on 3 January 1987 in the Russian Cemetery in Sainte-Geneviève-des-Bois in France.
676	The inscription on his grave stone, which was created by the Russian sculptor Ernst Neizvestny, reads: To the man who saw the Angel.
676	A controversy emerged in Russia in the early 1990s when it was alleged that Tarkovsky did not die of natural causes but was assassinated by the KGB.
676	Evidence for this hypothesis includes testimonies by former KGB agents who claim that Viktor Chebrikov gave the order to eradicate Tarkovsky to curtail what the Soviet government and the KGB saw as anti-Soviet propaganda by Tarkovsky.
676	Other evidence includes several memos that surfaced after the 1991 coup and the claim by one of Tarkovsky's doctors that his cancer could not have developed from a natural cause.
676	As Tarkovsky, his wife Larisa Tarkovskaya and actor Anatoli Solonitsyn all died from the very same type of lung cancer, Vladimir Sharun, sound designer in Stalker, is convinced that they were all poisoned when shooting the film near a chemical plant.
676	Filmography Tarkovsky is mainly known as a director of films.
676	During his career he directed only seven feature films and three short films during his time at the film school.
676	He also wrote several screenplays.
676	He furthermore directed the play Hamlet for the stage in Moscow, directed the opera Boris Godunov in London, and he directed a radio production of the short story Turnabout by William Faulkner.
676	He also wrote Sculpting In Time, a book on film theory.
676	Tarkovsky's first feature film was Ivan's Childhood in 1962.
676	He then directed Andrei Rublev in 1966, Solaris in 1972, The Mirror in 1975 and Stalker in 1979.
676	The documentary Voyage in Time was produced in Italy in 1982, as was Nostalghia in 1983.
676	His last film The Sacrifice was produced in Sweden in 1986.
676	Tarkovsky was personally involved in writing the screenplays for all his films, sometimes with a co-writer.
676	To Tarkovsky, a director who realizes somebody else's screenplay without being involved in it becomes a mere illustrator, resulting in dead and monotonous films.
676	Awards Numerous awards were bestowed on Tarkovsky throughout his lifetime.
676	At the Venice Film Festival he was awarded the Golden Lion.
676	At the Cannes Film Festival he won several times the FIPRESCI prize, the Prize of the Ecumenical Jury and the Grand Prix Spécial du Jury.
676	He was also nominated for the Palme d'Or two times.
676	In 1987, the British Academy of Film and Television Arts awarded the BAFTA Award for Best Foreign Language Film to The Sacrifice.
676	Under the influence of Glasnost and Perestroika, Tarkovsky was finally recognized in the Soviet Union in the Autumn of 1986, shortly before his death, by a retrospective of his films in Moscow.
676	After his death, an entire issue of the film magazine Iskusstvo Kino was devoted to Tarkovsky.
676	In their obituaries, the film committee of the Council of Ministers of the USSR and the Union of Soviet Film Makers expressed their sorrow that Tarkovsky had to spend the last years of his life in exile.
676	Posthumously, he was awarded the Lenin Prize in 1990, one of the highest state honors in the Soviet Union.
676	In 1989 the Andrei Tarkovsky Memorial Prize was established, with its first recipient being the Russian animator Yuriy Norshteyn.
676	Since 1993, the Moscow International Film Festival awards the annual Andrei Tarkovsky Award.
676	In 1996 the Andrei Tarkovsky Museum opened in Yuryevets, his childhood town.
676	A minor planet, 3345 Tarkovskij, discovered by Soviet astronomer Lyudmila Georgievna Karachkina in 1982, has also been named after him.
676	Tarkovsky has been the subject of several documentaries.
676	Most notable is the 1988 documentary Moscow Elegy, by Russian film director Alexander Sokurov.
676	Sokurov's own work has been heavily influenced by Tarkovsky.
676	The film consists mostly of narration over stock footage from Tarkovsky's films.
676	Directed by Andrei Tarkovsky is 1988 documentary film by Michal Leszczylowski, an editor of the film The Sacrifice.
676	Film director Chris Marker produced the television documentary One Day in the Life of Andrei Arsenevich as an homage to Andrei Tarkovsky in 2000.
676	Ingmar Bergman was quoted as saying: "Tarkovsky for me is the greatest [of us all], the one who invented a new language, true to the nature of film, as it captures life as a reflection, life as a dream".
676	Film historian Steven Dillon claims that much of subsequent film was deeply influenced by the films of Tarkovsky.
676	At the entrance to the Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography in Moscow, Russia there is a monument that includes statues of Tarkovsky, Gennady Shpalikov and Vasily Shukshin.
676	Influences Tarkovsky became a film director during the mid and late 1950s, a period during which Soviet society opened to foreign films, literature and music.
676	This allowed Tarkovsky to see films of European, American and Japanese directors, an experience which influenced his own film making.
676	His teacher and mentor at the film school, Mikhail Romm, allowed his students considerable freedom and emphasized the independence of the film director.
676	Tarkovsky was, according to Shavkat Abdusalmov, a fellow student at the film school, fascinated by Japanese films.
676	He was amazed by how every character on the screen is exceptional and how everyday events such as a Samurai cutting bread with his sword are elevated to something special and put into the limelight.
676	Tarkovsky has also expressed interest in the art of Haiku and its ability to create "images in such a way that they mean nothing beyond themselves."
676	In 1972, Tarkovsky told film historian Leonid Kozlov his ten favorite films.
676	The list includes: Diary of a Country Priest and Mouchette, by Robert Bresson; Winter Light, Wild Strawberries and Persona, by Ingmar Bergman; Nazarín, by Luis Buñuel; City Lights, by Charlie Chaplin; Ugetsu, by Kenji Mizoguchi; Seven Samurai, by Akira Kurosawa, and Woman in the Dunes, by Hiroshi Teshigahara.
676	Among his favorite directors were Buñuel, Mizoguchi, Bergman, Bresson, Kurosawa, Michelangelo Antonioni, Jean Vigo, and Carl Theodor Dreyer.
676	With the exception of City Lights, the list does not contain any films of the early silent era.
676	The reason is that Tarkovsky saw film as an art as only a relatively recent phenomenon, with the early film-making forming only a prelude.
676	The list has also no films or directors from Tarkovsky's native Russia, although he rated Soviet directors such as Boris Barnet, Sergei Paradjanov and Alexander Dovzhenko highly.
676	Although strongly opposed to commercial cinema, in a famous exception Tarkovsky praised the blockbuster film The Terminator, saying its "vision of the future and the relation between man and its destiny is pushing the frontier of cinema as an art".
676	He was critical of the "brutality and low acting skills", but nevertheless impressed by this film.
676	Cinematic style Tarkovsky's films are characterised by metaphysical themes, extremely long takes, and memorable images of exceptional beauty.
676	Recurring motifs are dreams, memory, childhood, running water accompanied by fire, rain indoors, reflections, levitation, and characters re-appearing in the foreground of long panning movements of the camera.
676	He once said, “Juxtaposing a person with an environment that is boundless, collating him with a countless number of people passing by close to him and far away, relating a person to the whole world, that is the meaning of cinema.” Tarkovsky included levitation scenes into several of his films, most notably Solaris.
676	To him these scenes possess great power and are used for their photogenic value and magical inexplicability.
676	Water, clouds, and reflections were used by him for their surreal beauty and photogenic value, as well as their symbolism, such as waves or the forms of brooks or running water.
676	Bells and candles are also frequent symbols.
676	These are symbols of film, sight and sound, and Tarkovsky's film frequently has themes of self-reflection.
676	Tarkovsky developed a theory of cinema that he called "sculpting in time".
676	By this he meant that the unique characteristic of cinema as a medium was to take our experience of time and alter it.
676	Unedited movie footage transcribes time in real time.
676	By using long takes and few cuts in his films, he aimed to give the viewers a sense of time passing, time lost, and the relationship of one moment in time to another.
676	Up to, and including, his film Thship of one moment in time to ane Mirror, Tarkovsky focused his cinematic works on exploring this theory.
676	After The Mirror, he announced that he would focus his work on exploring the dramatic unities proposed by Aristotle: a concentrated action, happening in one place, within the span of a single day.
676	Several of Tarkovsky's films have color or black and white sequences, including for example Andrei Rublev which features an epilogue in color of religious icon paintings, as well as Solaris, The Mirror, and Stalker, which feature monochrome and sepia sequences while otherwise being in color.
