676	In 1966, in an interview conducted shortly after finishing Andrei Rublev, Tarkovsky dismissed color film as a "commercial gimmick" and cast doubt on the idea that contemporary films meaningfully use color.
676	He claimed that in everyday life one does not consciously notice colors most of the time.
676	Hence in film color should be used mainly to emphasize certain moments, but not all the time as this distracts the viewer.
676	To him, films in color are like moving paintings or photographs, which are too beautiful to be a realistic depiction of life.
676	Vadim Yusov Tarkovsky worked in close collaboration with cinematographer Vadim Yusov, and much of the visual style of Tarkovsky's films can be attributed to this collaboration.
676	Tarkovsky would spend two days preparing for Yusov to film a single long take, and due to the preparation, usually only a single take was needed.
676	Sven Nykvist In his last film, The Sacrifice, Tarkovsky worked with cinematographer Sven Nykvist, who had worked closely with director Ingmar Bergman on many of Bergman's films.
676	Nykvist complained that Tarkovsky would frequently look through the camera and even direct actors through it.
676	Films about Tarkovsky  * Voyage in Time (1983): documents the travels in Italy of Andrei Tarkovsky in preparation for the making of his film Nostalghia, Tonino Guerra.
676	Tarkovsky: A Poet in the Cinema (1984): directed by Donatella Baglivo * Ebbo Demant (1988): Auf der Suche nach der verlorenen Zeit.Andrej Tarkowskijs Exil und Tod.
676	Documentary.
676	Germany.
676	One Day in the Life of Andrei Arsenevich (1999): French documentary film directed by Chris Marker
677	Ambiguity of information, in words, pictures, or other media, is the ability to express more than one interpretation.
677	It is generally contrasted with vagueness, in that specific and distinct interpretations are permitted (although some may not be immediately apparent), whereas with information that is vague it is difficult to form any interpretation at the desired level of specificity.
677	Context may play a role in resolving ambiguity.
677	For example, the same piece of information may be ambiguous in one context and unambiguous in another.
677	Linguistic forms  The lexical ambiguity of a word or phrase pertains to its having more than one meaning in the language to which the word belongs.
677	"Meaning" hereby refers to whatever should be captured by a good dictionary.
677	For instance, the word "bank" has several distinct lexical definitions, including "financial institution" and "edge of a river".
677	Another example is as in "apothecary".
677	One could say "I bought herbs from the apothecary".
677	This could mean one actually spoke to the apothecary (pharmacist) or went to the apothecary (pharmacy).
677	The context in which an ambiguous word is used often makes it evident which of the meanings is intended.
677	If, for instance, someone says "I buried $100 in the bank", most people would not think someone used a shovel to dig in the mud.
677	However, some linguistic contexts do not provide sufficient information to disambiguate a used word.
677	For example,  Lexical ambiguity can be addressed by algorithmic methods that automatically associate the appropriate meaning with a word in context, a task referred to as word sense disambiguation.
677	The use of multi-defined words requires the author or speaker to clarify their context, and sometimes elaborate on their specific intended meaning (in which case, a less ambiguous term should have been used).
677	The goal of clear concise communication is that the receiver(s) have no misunderstanding about what was meant to be conveyed.
677	An exception to this could include a politician whose "weasel words" and obfuscation are necessary to gain support from multiple constituents with mutually exclusive conflicting desires from their candidate of choice.
677	Ambiguity is a powerful tool of political science.
677	More problematic are words whose senses express closely related concepts.
677	"Good", for example, can mean "useful" or "functional" (That's a good hammer), "exemplary" (She's a good student), "pleasing" (This is good soup), "moral (a good person versus the lesson to be learned from a story), "righteous", etc.
677	" I have a good daughter" is not clear about which sense is intended.
677	The various ways to apply prefixes and suffixes can also create ambiguity ("unlockable" can mean "capable of being unlocked" or "impossible to lock").
677	Syntactic ambiguity arises when a sentence can have two (or more) different meanings because of the structure of the sentence—its syntax.
677	This is often due to a modifying expression, such as a prepositional phrase, the application of which is unclear.
677	"He ate the cookies on the couch", for example, could mean that he ate those cookies that were on the couch (as opposed to those that were on the table), or it could mean that he was sitting on the couch when he ate the cookies.
677	"To get in, you will need an entrance fee of $10 or your voucher and your drivers' license."
677	This could mean that you need EITHER ten dollars OR BOTH your voucher and your license.
677	Or it could mean that you need EITHER ten dollars OR a voucher AND you also need your license.
677	Only rewriting the sentence, or placing appropriate punctuation can resolve a syntactic ambiguity.
677	Spoken language can contain many more types of ambiguities, where there is more than one way to compose a set of sounds into words, for example "ice cream" and "I scream".
677	Such ambiguity is generally resolved according to the context.
677	A mishearing of such, based on incorrectly resolved ambiguity, is called a mondegreen.
677	Semantic ambiguity happens when a sentence contains an ambiguous word or phrase—a word or phrase that has more than one meaning.
677	"We saw her duck" (example due to Richard Nordquist).
677	The word "duck" can refer to the person's bird or to a motion she made.
677	For example, "You could do with a new automobile.
677	How about a test drive?"
677	The clause "You could do with" presents a statement with such wide possible interpretation as to be essentially meaningless.
677	Lexical ambiguity is contrasted with semantic ambiguity.
677	The former represents a choice between a finite number of known and meaningful context-dependent interpretations.
677	The latter represents a choice between any number of possible interpretations, none of which may have a standard agreed-upon meaning.
677	This form of ambiguity is closely related to vagueness.
677	Linguistic ambiguity can be a problem in law, because the interpretation of written documents and oral agreements is often of paramount importance.
677	Intentional application Philosophers (and other users of logic) spend a lot of time and effort searching for and removing (or intentionally adding) ambiguity in arguments, because it can lead to incorrect conclusions and can be used to deliberately conceal bad arguments.
677	For example, a politician might say "I oppose taxes which hinder economic growth", an example of a glittering generality.
677	Some will think he opposes taxes in general, because they hinder economic growth.
677	Others may think he opposes only those taxes that he believes will hinder economic growth.
677	In writing, the sentence can be rewritten to reduce possible misinterpretation, either by adding a comma after "taxes" (to convey the first sense) or by changing "which" to "that" (to convey the second sense), or by rewriting it in other ways.
677	The devious politician hopes that each constituent will interpret the statement in the most desirable way, and think the politician supports everyone's opinion.
677	However, the opposite can also be true - An opponent can turn a positive statement into a bad one, if the speaker uses ambiguity (intentionally or not).
677	The logical fallacies of amphiboly and equivocation rely heavily on tintentionallhe use of ambiguous words and phrases.
677	In Continental philosophy (particularly phenomenology and existentialism), there is much greater tolerance of ambiguity, as it is generally seen as an integral part of the human condition.
677	Martin Heidegger argued that the relation between the subject and object is ambiguous, as is the relation of mind and body, and part and whole.
677	In Heidegger's phenomenology, Dasein is always in a meaningful world, but there is always an underlying background for every instance of signification.
677	Thus, although some things may be certain, they have little to do with Dasein's sense of care and existential anxiety, e.g., in the face of death.
677	In calling his work Being and Nothingness an "essay in phenomenological ontology" Jean-Paul Sartre follows Heidegger in defining the human essence as ambiguous, or relating fundamentally to such ambiguity.
677	Simone de Beauvoir tries to base an ethics on Heidegger's and Sartre's writings (The Ethics of Ambiguity), where she highlights the need to grapple with ambiguity: "as long as philosophers and they [men] have thought, most of them have tried to mask it...And the ethics which they have proposed to their disciples has always pursued thre same goal.
677	It has been a matter of eliminating the ambiguity by making oneself pure inwardness or pure externality, by escaping from the sensible world or being engulfed by it, by yielding to eternity or enclosing oneself in the pure moment.".
677	Ethics cannot be based on the authoritative certainty given by mathematics and logic, or prescribed directly from the empirical findings of science.
677	She states: "Since we do not succeed in fleeing it, let us therefore try to look the truth in the face.
677	Let us try to assume our fundamental ambiguity.
677	It is in the knowledge of the genuine conditions of our life that we must draw our strength to live and our reason for acting".
677	Other continental philosophers suggest that concepts such as life, nature, and sex are ambiguous.
677	Recently, Corey Anton has argued that we cannot be certain what is separate from or unified with something else: language, he asserts, divides what is not in fact separate.
677	Following Ernest Becker, he argues that the desire to 'authoritatively disambiguate' the world and existence has led to numerous ideologies and historical events such as genocide.
677	On this basis, he argues that ethics must focus on 'dialectically integrating opposites' and balancing tension, rather than seeking a priori validation or certainty.
677	Like the existentialists and phenomenologists, he sees the ambiguity of life as the basis of creativity.
677	In literature and rhetoric, ambiguity can be a useful tool.
677	Groucho Marx's classic joke depends on a grammatical ambiguity for its humor, for example: "Last night I shot an elephant in my pajamas.
677	How he got in my pajamas, I'll never know".
677	Songs and poetry often rely on ambiguous words for artistic effect, as in the song title "Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue" (where "blue" can refer to the color, or to sadness).
677	In narrative, ambiguity can be introduced in several ways: motive, plot, character.
677	F.
677	Scott Fitzgerald uses the latter type of ambiguity with notable effect in his novel The Great Gatsby.
677	All religions debate the orthodoxy or heterodoxy of ambiguity.
677	Christianity and Judaism employ the concept of paradox synonymously with 'ambiguity'.
677	Ambiguity within Christianity (and other religions) is resisted by the conservatives and fundamentalists, who regard the concept as equating with 'contradiction'.
677	Non-fundamentalist Christians and Jews endorse Rudolf Otto's description of the sacred as 'mysterium tremendum et fascinans', the awe-inspiring mystery which fascinates humans..
677	Metonymy involves the use of the name of a subcomponent part as an abbreviation, or jargon, for the name of the whole object (for example "wheels" to refer to a car, or "flowers" to refer to beautiful offspring, an entire plant, or a collection of blooming plants).
677	In modern vocabulary critical semiotics, metonymy encompasses any potentially ambiguous word substitution that is based on contextual contiguity (located close together), or a function or process that an object performs, such as "sweet ride" to refer to a nice car.
677	Metonym miscommunication is considered a primary mechanism of linguistic humour.
677	Psychology and management In sociology and social psychology, the term "ambiguity" is used to indicate situations that involve uncertainty.
677	An increasing amount of research is concentrating on how people react and respond to ambiguous situations.
677	Much of this focuses on ambiguity tolerance.
677	A number of correlations have been found between an individual's reaction and tolerance to ambiguity and a range of factors.
677	Apter and Desselles (2001) for example, found a strong correlation with such attributes and factors like a greater preference for safe as opposed to risk-based sports, a preference for endurance-type activities as opposed to explosive activities, a more organized and less casual lifestyle, greater care and precision in descriptions, a lower sensitivity to emotional and unpleasant words, a less acute sense of humor, engaging a smaller variety of sexual practices than their more risk-comfortable colleagues, a lower likelihood of the use of drugs, pornography and drink, a greater likelihood of displaying obsessional behavior.
677	In the field of leadership, David Wilkinson (2006) found strong correlations between an individual leader's reaction to ambiguous situations and the Modes of Leadership they use, the type of creativity, Kirton (2003) and how they relate to others.
677	Music In music, pieces or sections which confound expectations and may be or are interpreted simultaneously in different ways are ambiguous, such as some polytonality, polymeter, other ambiguous meters or rhythms, and ambiguous phrasing, or (Stein 2005, p. 79) any rs or aspect of music.
677	The music of Africa is often purposely ambiguous.
677	To quote Sir Donald Francis Tovey (1935, p. 195), "Theorists are apt to vex themselves with vain efforts to remove uncertainty just where it has a high aesthetic value."
677	Visual art  In visual art, certain images are visually ambiguous, such as the Necker cube, which can be interpreted in two ways.
677	Perceptions of such objects remain stable for a time, then may flip, a phenomenon called multistable perception.
677	The opposite of such ambiguous images are impossible objects.
677	Pictures or photographs may also be ambiguous at the semantic level: the visual image is unambiguous, but the meaning and narrative may be ambiguous: is a certain facial expression one of excitement or fear, for instance?
677	Constructed language Some languages have been created with the intention of avoiding ambiguity, especially lexical ambiguity.
677	Lojban and Loglan are two related languages which have been created with this in mind, focusing chiefly on syntactic ambiguity as well.
677	The languages can be both spoken and written.
677	These languages are intended to provide a greater technical precision over big natural languages, although historically, such attempts at language improvement have been criticized.
677	Languages composed from many diverse sources contain much ambiguity and inconsistency.
677	The many exceptions to syntax and semantic rules are time-consuming and difficult to learn.
677	Mathematical notation Mathematical notation, widely used in physics and other sciences, avoids many ambiguities compared to expression in natural language.
677	However, for various reasons, several lexical, syntactic and semantic ambiguities remain.
677	Names of functions The ambiguity in the style of writing a function should not be confused with a multivalued function, which can (and should) be defined in a deterministic and unambiguous way.
677	Several special functions still do not have established notations.
677	Usually, the conversion to another notation requires to scale the argument and/or the resulting value; sometimes, the same name of the function is used, causing confusions.
677	Examples of such underestablished functions: * Sinc function * Elliptic integral of the third kind; translating elliptic integral form MAPLE to Mathematica, one should replace the second argument to its square, see Talk:Elliptic integral#List of notations; dealing with complex values, this may cause problems.
677	Exponential integral, * Hermite polynomial, Expressions Ambiguous expressions often appear in physical and mathematical texts.
677	It is common practice to omit multiplication signs in mathematical expressions.
677	Also, it is common to give the same name to a variable and a function, for example, .
677	Then, if one sees , there is no way to distinguish whether it means  multiplied by , or function  evaluated at argument equal to .
677	In each case of use of such notations, the reader is supposed to be able to perform the deduction and reveal the true meaning.
677	Creators of algorithmic languages try to avoid ambiguities.
677	Many algorithmic languages (C++ and Fortran) require the character * as symbol of multiplication.
677	The language Mathematica allows the user to omit the multiplication symbol, but requires square brackets to indicate the argument of a function; square brackets are not allowed for grouping of expressions.
677	Fortran, in addition, does not allow use of the same name (identifier) for different objects, for example, function and variable; in particular, the expression f=f(x) is qualified as an error.
677	The order of operations may depend on the context.
677	In most programming languages, the operations of division and multiplication have equal priority and are executed from left to right.
677	Until the last century, many editorials assumed that multiplication is performed first, for example,  is interpreted as ; in this case, the insertion of parentheses is required when translating the formulas to an algorithmic language.
677	In addition, it is common to write an argument of a function without parenthesis, which also may lead to ambiguity.
677	Sometimes, one uses italics letters to denote elementary functions.
677	In the scientific journal style, the expression means product of variables , ,  and , although in a slideshow, it may mean .
677	A comma in subscripts and superscripts sometimes is omitted; it is also ambiguous notation.
677	If it is written , the reader should guess from the context, does it mean a single-index object, evaluated while the subscript is equal to product of variables ,  and , or it is indication to a trivalent tensor.
677	The writing of  instead of  may mean that the writer either is stretched in space (for example, to reduce the publication fees) or aims to increase number of publications without considering readers.
677	The same may apply to any other use of ambiguous notations.
677	Subscripts are also used to denote the argument to a function, as in .
677	Examples of potentially confusing ambiguous mathematical expressions  , which could be understood to mean either  or .
677	In addition,  may mean , as  means  (see tetration).
677	Notations in quantum optics and quantum mechanics It is common to define the coherent states in quantum optics with  and states with fixed number of photons with .
677	Then, there is an "unwritten rule": the state is coherent if there are gle~<more Greek characters than Latin characters in the argument, and photon state if the Latin characters dominate.
677	The ambiguity becomes even worse, if  is used for the states with certain value of the coordinate, and  means the state with certain value of the momentum, which may be used in books on quantum mechanics.
677	Such ambiguities easy lead to confusions, especially if some normalized adimensional, dimensionless variables are used.
677	Expression  may mean a state with single photon, or the coherent state with mean amplitude equal to 1, or state with momentum equal to unity, and so on.
677	The reader is supposed to guess from the context.
677	Ambiguous terms in physics and mathematics Some physical quantities do not yet have established notations; their value (and sometimes even dimension, as in the case of the Einstein coefficients), depends on the system of notations.
677	Many terms are ambiguous.
677	Each use of an ambiguous term should be preceded by the definition, suitable for a specific case.
677	Just like Ludwig Wittgenstein states in Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus: "...
677	Only in the context of a proposition has a name meaning."
677	A highly confusing term is gain.
677	For example, the sentence "the gain of a system should be doubled", without context, means close to nothing.
677	It may mean that the ratio of the output voltage of an electric circuit to the input voltage should be doubled.
677	It may mean that the ratio of the output power of an electric or optical circuit to the input power should be doubled.
677	It may mean that the gain of the laser medium should be doubled, for example, doubling the population of the upper laser level in a quasi-two level system (assuming negligible absorption of the ground-state).
677	The term intensity is ambiguous when applied to light.
677	The term can refer to any of irradiance, luminous intensity, radiant intensity, or radiance, depending on the background of the person using the term.
677	Also, confusions may be related with the use of atomic percent as measure of concentration of a dopant, or resolution of an imaging system, as measure of the size of the smallest detail which still can be resolved at the background of statistical noise.
677	See also Accuracy and precision and its talk.
677	The Berry paradox arises as a result of systematic ambiguity in the meaning of terms such as "definable" or "nameable".
677	Terms of this kind give rise to vicious circle fallacies.
677	Other terms with this type of ambiguity are: satisfiable, true, false, function, property, class, relation, cardinal, and ordinal.
677	Mathematical interpretation of ambiguity In mathematics and logic, ambiguity can be considered to be an underdetermined system (of equations or logic) – for example,  leaves open what the value of X is – while its opposite is a self-contradiction, also called inconsistency, paradoxicalness, or oxymoron, in an overdetermined system – such as , which has no solution – see also underdetermination.
677	Logical ambiguity and self-contradiction is analogous to visual ambiguity and impossible objects, such as the Necker cube and impossible cube, or many of the drawings of M.
677	C.
677	Escher.
677	Pedagogic use of ambiguous expressions Ambiguity can be used as a pedagogical trick, to force students to reproduce the deduction by themselves.
677	Some textbooks give the same name to the function and to its Fourier transform: .
677	Rigorously speaking, such an expression requires that ; even if function  is a self-Fourier function, the expression should be written as ; however, it is assumed that the shape of the function  (and even its norm ) depend on the character used to denote its argument.
677	If the Greek letter is used, it is assumed to be a Fourier transform of another function, The first function is assumed, if the expression in the argument contains more characters  or , than characters , and the second function is assumed in the opposite case.
677	Expressions like  or  contain symbols  and  in equal amounts; they are ambiguous and should be avoided in serious deduction.
679	An animal is a taxonomic member of the Kingdom Animalia.
679	For biologists, this includes human beings, although for the general public the term "animal" means only non-human animals.
679	Animal or Animals may also refer to: Entertainment  Fictional characters  *Animal (Muppet), a drummer character in The Muppet Show band, Dr.
679	Teeth and The Electric Mayhem *Animal, nickname of a regular character in Takeshi's Castle, played by Brad Lesley Movies  *Animal (1977 film), French film (L'Animal) by Claude Zidi with Jean-Paul Belmondo and Raquel Welch *Animal (2001 film), Argentine film by Sergio Bizzio with Carlos Roffé *Animal (2005 film), US film by David J.
679	Burke with Ving Rhames and Terrance Howard *The Animal, 2001 US film by Luke Greenfield with Rob Schneider Music  ;Bands *A.N.I.M.A.L., an Argentinian heavy metal band *Animal Collective, a New York psychedelic pop band *The Animals, a British rock band ; *The Animals (album), 1964 album of the The Animals *Animals (Pink Floyd album), a 1977 concept album by Pink Floyd *Animal, a 1988 album by The Bar-Kays *Animal (Motor Ace album), a 2005 release *Animal (Animosity album), 2007 release *Animal, 2008 album by Far East Movement *Animal!, a 2008 album by Margot & the Nuclear So and So's *Animals (This Town Needs Guns album), a 2008 release *Animal, a 2009 album by the London-based electronic band autoKratz *Animal (Kesha album), 2010 album by American pop singer Ke$ha ;Songs * "Animal" (Conor Maynard song) * "Animal" (Def Leppard song) * "Animal" (DJ Sammy song) * "Animal" (Fuck Like a Beast)" by W.A.S.P.

680	The aardvark ( , Orycteropus afer) is a medium-sized, burrowing, nocturnal mammal native to Africa.
680	It is the only living species of the order Tubulidentata, although other prehistoric species and genera of Tubulidentata are known.
680	Naming and taxonomy It is sometimes colloquially called "antbear", "anteater", or the "Cape anteater" after the Cape of Good Hope.
680	The name comes from earlier Afrikaans and means "earth pig" or "ground pig" (aarde earth/ground, varken pig), because of its burrowing habits (similar origin to the name groundhog).
680	The aardvark is not closely related to the pig; rather, it is the sole recent representative of the obscure mammalian order Tubulidentata, in which it is usually considered to form one variable species of the genus Orycteropus, the sole surviving genus in the family Orycteropodidae.
680	The aardvark is not closely related to the South American anteater, despite sharing some characteristics and a superficial resemblance.
680	The closest living relatives of the aardvark are the elephant shrews, along with the sirenians, hyraxes, tenrecs, and elephants.
680	With their extinct relatives, these animals form the superorder Afrotheria.
680	The scientific name of the aardvark comes from Greek ορυκτερόπους (orykterópous) meaning "digging footed" and afer: from Africa.
680	Description The aardvark is vaguely pig-like in appearance.
680	Its body is stout with an arched back and is sparsely covered with coarse hairs.
680	The limbs are of moderate length.
680	The front feet have lost the pollex (or 'thumb'), resulting in four toes, while the rear feet have all five toes.
680	Each toe bears a large, robust nail which is somewhat flattened and shovel-like, and appears to be intermediate between a claw and a hoof.
680	The ears are disproportionately long, and the tail is very thick at the base and gradually tapers.
680	The greatly elongated head is set on a short, thick neck, and the end of the snout bears a disc, which houses the nostrils.
680	The mouth is small and tubular, typical of species that feed on ants and termites.
680	The aardvark has a long, thin, snakelike, protruding tongue and elaborate structures supporting a keen sense of smell.
680	An aardvark's weight is typically between 40 and(-).
680	An aardvark's length is usually between 1 and(-), and can reach lengths of  when its tail (which can be up to 70 cm) is taken into account.
680	It is the largest member of the proposed clade Afroinsectiphilia.
680	The aardvark is pale yellowish-gray in color and often stained reddish-brown by soil.
680	The aardvark's coat is thin, and the animal's primary protection is its tough skin.
680	The aardvark has been known to sleep in a recently excavated ant nest, which also serves as protection from its predators.
680	One of the most distinctive characteristics of the Tubulidentata is their teeth.
680	Instead of having a pulp cavity, each tooth has a cluster of thin, upright, parallel tubes of vasodentin (a modified form of dentine), with individual pulp canals, held together by cementum.
680	The teeth have no enamel coating and are worn away and regrow continuously.
680	The aardvark is born with conventional incisors and canines at the front of the jaw, which fall out and are not replaced.
680	Adult aardvarks have only cheek teeth at the back of the jaw, and have a dental formula of:  These remaining teeth are peg-like and rootless and are of unique composition.
680	Genetically speaking, the aardvark is a living fossil, as its chromosomes are highly conserved, reflecting much of the early eutherian arrangement before the divergence of the major modern taxa.
680	Ecology and behavior Aardvarks live in sub-Saharan Africa, where there is suitable habitat for them to live, such as savannas, grasslands, woodlands and bushland, and available food (i.e., ants and termites).
680	The aardvark is nocturnal and is a solitary creature that feeds almost exclusively on ants and termites (formicivore); the only fruit eaten by aardvarks is the aardvark cucumber.
680	An aardvark emerges from its burrow in the late afternoon or shortly after sunset, and forages over a considerable home range encompassing 10 to 30 km, swinging its long nose from side to side to pick up the scent of food.
680	When a concentration of ants or termites is detected, the aardvark digs into it with its powerful front legs, keeping its long ears upright to listen for predators, and takes up an astonishing number of insects with its long, sticky tongue—as many as 50,000 in one night have been recorded.
680	It can dig 2 feet in 15 seconds, but otherwise moves fairly slowly.
680	Its claws enable it to dig through the extremely hard crust of a termite or ant mound quickly, avoiding the dust by sealing the nostrils.
680	When successful, the aardvark's long (up to 30 cm) tongue licks up the insects; the termites' biting, or the ants' stinging attacks are rendered futile by the tough skin.
680	Its keen hearing warns it of predators: lions, leopards, hyenas, and pythons.
680	Aside from digging out ants and termites, the aardvark also excavates burrows in which to live; temporary sites are scattered around the home range as refuges, and a main burrow is used for breeding.
680	Main burrows can be deep and extensive, have several entrances and can be as long as 13 m.
680	The aardvark changes the layout of its home burrow regularly, and from time to time moves on a/> The aardvark changes thend makes a new one; the old burrows are then inhabited by smaller animals like the African wild dog.
680	Only mothers and young share burrows.
680	If attacked in the tunnel, it will seal the tunnel off behind itself or turn around and attack with its claws.
680	Aardvarks pair only during the breeding season; after a gestation period of seven months, one cub weighing around 2 kg is born, and is able to leave the burrow to accompany its mother after only two weeks, and is eating termites at 14 weeks and is weaned by 16 weeks.
680	At six months of age it is able to dig its own burrows, but it will often remain with the mother until the next mating season, and is sexually capable by the season after that.
680	Aardvarks live for up to 24 years in captivity.
680	The aardvark's main predators are lions, leopards, hunting dogs and pythons.
680	Some African tribes also hunt aardvarks for meat.
680	Aardvarks can dig fast or run in zigzag fashion to elude enemies, but if all else fails, they will strike with their claws, tail and shoulders, sometimes flipping onto their backs to lash with all fours.
680	Their thick skin also protects them to some extent.
680	Mythology and popular culture In African folklore, the aardvark is much admired because of its diligent quest for food and its fearless response to soldier ants.
680	Hausa magicians make a charm from the heart, skin, forehead, and nails of the aardvark, which they then proceed to pound together with the root of a certain tree.
680	Wrapped in a piece of skin and worn on the chest, the charm is said to give the owner the ability to pass through walls or roofs at night.
680	The charm is said to be used by burglars and those seeking to visit young girls without their parents' permission.
680	The Egyptian god Set is said (by some) to have the head of an aardvark or to be part aardvark.
680	The titular character of Arthur, an animated television series for children based on a book series and produced by WGBH, shown in more than 180 countries, is an aardvark.
681	The aardwolf (Proteles cristata) is a small, insectivorous mammal, native to East Africa and Southern Africa.
681	Its name means "earth wolf" in the Afrikaans / Dutch language.
681	It is also called "maanhaar jackal".
681	The aardwolf is in the same family as the hyenas.
681	Unlike its relatives, the aardwolf does not hunt large animals; instead it eats insects, mainly termites - one aardwolf can eat about 200,000 termites during a single night by using its long, sticky tongue to capture them.
681	The aardwolf is the only surviving species in the mammalian subfamily Protelinae.
681	There are two subspecies: Proteles cristatus cristatus of Southern Africa and Proteles cristatus septentrionalis of East Africa.
681	The aardwolf is usually classified with the Hyaenidae, though it wasthe Hyaenid formerly placed into the family Protelidae.
681	The aardwolf lives in the scrublands of eastern and southern Africa - these are open lands covered with stunted trees and shrubs.
681	Aardwolves usually hide in burrows during the day, and then they come out at night to seek food.
681	Their diet nearly always consists of termites, insect larvae, and the carrion of larger animals.
681	Physical characteristics The aardwolf resembles a very small Striped Hyena, but with a more slender muzzle, sharper ears, black vertical stripes on a coat of yellowish fur, and a long, distinct mane down the midline of the neck and back.
681	The mane is raised during confrontations in order to make the aardwolves appear larger.
681	The aardwolf is about 55 to 80 centimeters long, excluding its bushy tail, which is about 20 to 30 cm long, and stands about 40 to 50 cm tall at the shoulders.
681	An adult aardwolf weighs between 9 and 14 kilograms.
681	The front feet have five toes each, unlike the four-toed hyena.
681	The teeth and skull are similar to those of the hyena, though its cheek teeth are specialised for eating insects.
681	As the aardwolf ages, it will normally lose some of its teeth, though this has little impact on their feeding habits due to the softness of the insects that they eat.
681	The aardwolf has two anal glands that secrete a musky fluid for marking territory and for communicating with other aardwolves.
681	Distribution and habitat Aardwolves live in open, dry plains and bushland, avoiding mountainous areas.
681	Due to specific food requirements, they are only found in regions where termites of the family Hodotermitidae occur.
681	Termites of this family depend on dead and withered grass and are most populous in heavily grazed grasslands and savannahs, including farmland.
681	For most of the year, aardwolves spend time in shared territories consisting of up to a dozen dens, which are occupied for six weeks at a time.
681	There are two distinct populations: one in Southern Africa, and another in East and Northeast Africa.
681	The species does not occur in the intermediary miombo forests.
681	Behavior Aardwolves are shy and nocturnal, sleeping in underground burrows by day.
681	They usually use existing burrows of aardvarks, porcupines or springhares, despite being capable of creating their own.
681	By night, an aardwolf can consume up to 200,000 harvester termites using its sticky, long tongue.
681	They take special care not to destroy the termite mound or consume the entire colony, which ensures that the termites can rebuild and provide a continuous supply of food.
681	They will often memorise the location of such nests and return to them to save the trouble of finding a new one.
681	They are also known to feed on other insects, larvae, and eggs, and occasionally small mammals and birds.
681	Unlike other hyenas, aardwolves do not scavenge or kill larger animals.
681	The adult aardwolf is primarily solitary while foraging for food, necessary because of the scarcity and homogeneous distribution of their insect prey.
681	They have often been mistaken for solitary animals.
681	In fact, they live as monogamous pairs with their young, defending the same territory.
681	Young aardwolves generally achieve sexual maturity at two years of age.
681	The breeding season varies depending on their location, but normally takes place during autumn or spring.
681	During the breeding season, unpaired male aardwolves will search their own territory, as well as others', for a female to mate with.
681	Dominant males will also mate opportunistically with the females of less dominant neighboring aardwolves.
681	This can often result in conflict between two male aardwolves when one has wandered into another's territory.
681	Gestation lasts between 90 and 110 days, producing one to five cubs (most often two or three) during the rainy season, when termites are active.
681	The first six to eight weeks are spent in the den with the mother.
681	After three months, they begin supervised foraging and by four months are normally independent, though they will often share a den with their mother until the next breeding season.
681	They can achieve a lifespan of up to 15 years when in captivity.
681	Interaction with humans Agriculture may create a negative impact on their population due to use of poisons by farmers.
681	They are often considered useful, non-dangerous animals by farmers.
681	However, in some areas the aardwolf is hunted for its fur.
681	Encounters with dogs are another threat.
682	Adobe (,; Arabic: الطوب) is a natural building material made from [etrieved 25 December [sand, clay, water,  and some kind of fibrous or organic material (sticks, straw, and/or manure), which the builders shape into bricks (using frames) and dry in the sun.
682	Adobe buildings are similar to cob and mudbrick buildings.
682	Adobe structures are extremely durable, and account for some of the oldest existing buildings in the world.
682	In hot climates, compared with wooden buildings, adobe buildings offer significant advantages due to their greater thermal mass, but they are known to be particularly susceptible to earthquake damage.
682	Buildings made of sun-dried earth are common in West Asia, North Africa, West Africa, South America, southwestern North America,  Spain (usually in the Mudéjar style), Eastern Europe and East Anglia, particularly Norfolk, known as 'clay lump.
682	Adobe had been in use by indigenous peoples of the Americas in the Southwestern United States, Mesoamerica, and the Andean region of South America for several thousand years, although often substantial amounts of stone are used in the walls of Pueblo buildings.
682	Also, the Pueblo people built their adobe structures with handsful or basketsful of adobe, until the Spanish introduced them to the making of bricks.) Adobe brickmaking was used in Spain starting by the Late Bronze Age and Iron Age, from the eighth century B.C.
682	Its wide use can be attributed to its simplicity of design and manufacture, and the economy of creating it.
682	A distinction is sometimes made between the smaller adobes, which are about the size of ordinary baked bricks, and the larger adobines, some of which may be one to two yards (1–2 m) long.
682	Etymology The word adobe has existed for around 4,000 years, with relatively little change in either pronunciation or meaning.
682	The word can be traced from the Middle Egyptian (c.
682	BC) word dj-b-t "mud [i.e., sun-dried] brick."
682	As Middle Egyptian evolved into Late Egyptian, Demotic, and finally Coptic (c.
682	BC), dj-b-t became tobe "[mud] brick."
682	This was borrowed into Arabic as al-tub (الطّوب al "the" + tub "brick") "[mud] brick," which was assimilated into Old Spanish as adobe, still with the meaning "mud brick."
682	English borrowed the word from Spanish in the early 18th century.
682	In more modern English usage, the term "adobe" has come to include a style of architecture popular in the desert climates of North America, especially in New Mexico.
682	Compare with stucco).
682	Composition An adobe brick is a composite material made of clay mixed with water and an organic material such as straw or dung.
682	The soil composition typically contains clay and sand.
682	Straw is useful in binding the brick together and allowing the brick to dry evenly, thereby preventing cracking due to uneven shrinkage rates through the brick.
682	Dung offers the same advantage and is also added to repel insects.
682	The most desirable soil texture for producing the mud of adobe is 15% clay, 10-30% silt and 55-75% fine sand.
682	Another source quotes 15-25% clay and the remainder sand and coarser particles up to cobbles 2-10 inches with no deleterious effect.
682	Modern adobe is stabilized with either emulsified asphalt or portland cement up to 10% by weight.
682	The clay content should be a mixture of no more that half expansive clays with the remainder non-expansive illite or kaolinite.
682	Too much expansive clay results in uneven drying through the brick and cracking while too much kaolinite will make a weak brick.
682	Typically the soils of the Southwest United States where such construction is use, are an adequate composition.
682	Adobe bricks Bricks are made in an open frame, 25 cm by 36 cm being a reasonable size, but any convenient size is acceptable.
682	The mixture is molded into a frame, and then the frame is removed after initial setting.
682	After drying a few hours, the bricks are turned on edge to finish drying.
682	Slow drying in shade reduces cracking.
682	The same mixture used to make bricks, but without straw, is used for mortar and often for plaster on interior and exterior walls.
682	Some ancient cultures used lime-based cement for the plaster to protect against rain damage.
682	The brick’s thickness is preferred partially due to its thermal characteristics, and partially due to the stability of a thicker brick versus a more standard-sized brick.
682	Depending on the form into which the mixture is pressed, adobe can encompass nearly any shape or size, provided drying is even and the mixture includes reinforcement for larger bricks.
682	Reinforcement can include manure, straw, cement, rebar or wooden posts.
682	Experience has shown straw, cement, or manure added to a standard adobe mixture can all produce a stronger, more crack-resistant brick.
682	A general testing is done on the soil content first.
682	To do so, a sample of the soil is mixed into a clear container with some water, creating an almost completely saturated liquid.
682	After it is sealed, the container is shaken vigorously for at least one minute.
682	It is then allowed to sit on a flat surface for a day or so until the soil has settled into layers or remains in suspension.
682	Heavier particles settle out first, so gravel will be on the bottom, sand above, silt above that and very fine clay and organic matter will stay in suspension for days.
682	After the water has cleared, percentages of the various particles can be determined.
682	Fifty to 60 percent sand and 35 to 40 percent clay will yield strong bricks.
682	The New Mexico State University  Extension Service recommends a mix of not more than 1/3 clay, not less than 1/2 sand, and never more than 1/3 silt.
682	Material properties Adobe walls are load bearing, i.e.
682	In the United States the most building [http://quentinwilson.squarespace.com/storage/adobecode.pdf codes] call for a minimum compressive strength of 300 lbf/in.2 Adobe construction should be designed so as to avoid lateral structural loads that would cause bending loads.
682	The building codes require the building sustain a 1 g lateral acceleration earthquake load.
682	Such a acceleration will cause lateral loads on the walls, resulting in shear and bending and inducing tensile stresses.
682	To withstand such loads, the codes typically call for a tensile modulus of rupture strength of at least 50 lbf/in.2 In addition to being an inexpensive material with a small resource cost, adobe can serve as a significant heat reservoir due to the thermal properties inherent in the massive walls typical in adobe construction.
682	In climates typified by hot days and cool nights, the high thermal mass of adobe averages out the high and low temperatures of the day, moderating the living space temperature.
682	The massive walls require a large and relatively long input of heat from the sun (radiation) and from the surrounding air (convection) before they warm through to the interior.
682	After the sun sets and the temperature drops, the warm wall will then continue to transfer heat to the interior for several hours due to the time lag effect.
682	Thus, a well-planned adobe wall of the appropriate thickness is very effective at controlling inside temperature through the wide daily fluctuations typical of desert climates, a factor which has contributed to its longevity as a building material.
682	Thermodynamic material properties are sparsely quoted.
682	The thermal conductivity of adobe is quoted as as having an R value of R0 0.41 hr*ft2*°F/(Btu*in).[http://www.emnrd.state.nm.us/ECMD/FORMS/documents/MANUAL2.1.pdf] To determine the total R value, multiply R0, by the thickness of the adobe wall.
682	From that, the conductivity is found to be k   0.20 Btu/(hr*ft*°F) or 0.35 W/(m*K).
682	The heat capacity is commonly quoted as cp = 0.20 Btu/(lbm*F) or 840 joules/(kg*K).[http://www.greenhomebuilding.com/QandA/adobe/mass.htm] The density is 95 lbm/ft3 or 1520 kg/m3.
682	The thermal diffusivity is calculated to 0.0105 ft2/hr or 2.72x10-7 m2/s.
682	Adobe wall construction When building an adobe structure, the ground should be compressed because the weight of adobe bricks is significantly greater than a frame house, and foundation settling may cause cracking in the wall.
682	The footing is dug and compressed once again.
682	Footing depth depends on the region and its ground frost level.
682	The footing and stem wall are commonly 24 and 14 inches, much larger than a frame house because  of the weight of the walls.
682	Adobe bricks are laid by course.
682	Each course is laid the whole length of the wall, overlapping at the corners on a layer of adobe mortar.
682	Adobe walls usually never rise above two stories because they are load bearing and have low structural strength.
682	When placing window and door openings, a lintel is placed on top of the opening to support the bricks above.
682	Atop the last courses of brick, bond beams made of reinforced concrete or heavy wood beams are laid to provide a horizontal bearing plate for the roof beams and to redistribute lateral earthquake loads to shear walls more able to carry the forces.
682	To protect the interior and exterior adobe wall, finishes can be applied, such as mud plaster, whitewash or stucco.
682	These finishes protect the adobe wall from water damage, but need to be reapplied periodically, or the walls can be finished with other nontraditional plasters providing longer protection.
682	Bricks made with stabilized adobe generally do not need protection of plasters.
682	Adobe roof The traditional adobe roof has been constructed using a mixture of soil/clay, water, sand, and other available organic materials.
682	The mixture was then formed and pressed into wood forms, producing rows of dried earth bricks that would then be laid across a support structure of wood and plastered into place with more adobe.
682	For a deeper understanding of adobe, one might examine a cob building.
682	Cob, a close cousin to adobe, contains proportioned amounts of soil, clay, water, manure, and straw.
682	This is blended, but not formed like adobe.
682	Cob is spread and piled over the home's frame and allowed to air dry for several months before habitation.
682	Adobe, then, can be described as dried bricks of cob, stacked and mortared together with more adobe mixture to create a thick wall and/or roof.
682	Roof materials Depending on the materials available, a roof may be assembled using wood or metal beams to create a framework to begin layering adobe bricks.
682	Depending on the thickness of the adobe bricks, the framework has been preformed using a steel framing and a layering of a metal fencing or wiring over the framework to allow an even load as masses of adobe are spread across the metal fencing like cob and allowed to air dry accordingly.
682	This method was demonstrated with an adobe blend heavily impregnated with cement to allow even drying and prevent cracking.
682	Traditional adobe roof The more traditional flat adobe roofs are functional only in dry climates that are not exposed to snow loads which would call for a steepled roof.
682	Cement may be introduced into the adobe mixture to stablilize and strengthen the composite of mud and organic matter.
682	The heaviest wooden beams are called Vigas which support smaller members called satias upon which brush is then laid atop which the adobe layer applied.
682	Raising a traditional adobe roof To raise a flattened adobe roof, beams of wood or metal should be assembled and span the extent of the building.
682	The ends of the beams should then be attached  to the tops of the walls.
682	Taking into account the material from which the beams and walls are made, choosing the attachments may prove difficult.
682	A combination of the bricks and adobe mortar that are laid across the beams creates an even load-bearing pressure that can last for many years depending on attrition.
682	Once the vigas, satias and brush are laid, adobe bricks are placed.
682	An adobe roof is often laid with bricks slightly larger in width to ensure a greater expanse is covered when placing the bricks onto the roof.
682	Following each individual brick should be a layer of adobe mortar, recommended to be at least an inch thick to make certain there is ample strength between the brick’s edges and also to provide a relative moisture barrier during rain.
682	Attributes Depending on the materials, adobe roofs can be inherently fire-proof.
682	The construction of a chimney can greatly influence the construction of the roof supports, -proof.
682	Thecreating an extra need for care in choosing the materials.
682	The builders can make an adobe chimney by stacking simple adobe bricks in a similar fashion as the surrounding walls.
682	Adobe around the world The largest structure ever made from adobe (bricks) was the Bam Citadel, which suffered serious damage (up to 80%) by an earthquake on December 26, 2003.
682	Other large adobe structures are the Huaca del Sol in Peru, with 100 million signed bricks, the ciudellas of Chan Chan and Tambo Colorado, both in Peru (in South America).
682	File:RomaniaDanubeDelta MakingMaterialForCOnstructing0003jpg.JPG|Still in production today, Romania's Danube Delta File:RomaniaDanubeDelta MakingMaterialForCOnstructing0002jpg.JPG|Mixing mud and straw in brick frames File:RomaniaDanubeDelta MakingMaterialForCOnstructing0001jpg.JPG|Community effort File:Milyanfan-adobe-brick-house-8039.jpg|Adobe brick house under construction in Kyrgyzstan File: Sa'dah 02.jpg|House in Sa'dah, Yemen File:AdobeHouseVrancea.JPG|Adobe brick house under construction in Romania File:5640-Linxia-City-Dongguan-back-street.jpg|An adobe wall in Linxia City, Gansu, China File:Poeh museum, night.jpg|Poeh Museum tower, the tallest adobe structure in New Mexico, USA File:Great Mosque of Djenné 3.jpg|Great Mosque of Djenné, famous building made from banco, a type of adobe
683	An adventure is an exciting or unusual experience; it may also be a bold, usually risky undertaking, with an uncertain outcome.
683	Adventures may be activities with some potential for physical danger, such as skydiving, mountain climbing or participating in extreme sports.
683	The term also broadly refers to any enterprise that is potentially fraught with physical, financial or psychological risk, such as a business venture, a love affair, or other major life undertakings.
683	Adventurous experiences create psychological and physiological arousal, which can be interpreted as negative (e.g.
683	Yerkes-Dodson law.
683	For some people, adventure becomes a major pursuit in and of itself.
683	According to adventurer André Malraux, in his La Condition Humaine (1933), "If a man is not ready to risk his life, where is his dignity?".
683	Similarly, Helen Keller stated that "Life is either a daring adventure or nothing."
683	Outdoor adventurous activities are typically undertaken for the purposes of recreation or excitement: examples are  adventure racing and adventure tourism.
683	Adventurous activities can also lead to gains in knowledge, such as those undertaken by explorers and pioneers.
683	Adventure education intentionally uses challenging experiences for learning.
683	Adventure in mythology Some of the oldest and most widespread stories in the world are stories of adventure such as Homer's The Odyssey.
683	Mythologist Joseph Campbell discussed his notion of the monomyth in his book, The Hero with a Thousand Faces.
683	Campbell proposed that the heroic mythological stories from culture to culture followed a similar underlying pattern, starting with the "call to adventure", followed by a hazardous journey, and eventual triumph.
683	The knight errant was the form the "adventure seeker" character took in the late Middle Ages.
683	The adventure novel exhibits these "protagonist on adventurous journey" characteristics a adventure novels do many popular feature films, such as Star Wars and Raiders of the Lost Ark.
689	Asia ( or) is the world's largest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres.
689	It covers 8.7% of the Earth's total surface area and comprises 30% of its land area.
689	With approximately 4.3 billion people, it hosts 60% of the world's current human population.
689	Asia has a high growth rate in the modern era.
689	For instance, during the 20th century, Asia's population nearly quadrupled.
689	Asia is defined as comprising the eastwards four-fifths of Eurasia.
689	It is located to the east of the Suez Canal, the Ural river, and the Ural Mountains, and south of the Caucasus Mountains (or the Kuma-Manych Depression) and the Caspian and Black Seas.
689	It is bounded on the east by the Pacific Ocean, on the south by the Indian Ocean and on the north by the Arctic Ocean.
689	Given its size and diversity, Asia – a toponym dating back to classical antiquity – "is more a cultural concept" incorporating diverse regions and peoples than a homogeneous physical entity.
689	Asia differs very widely among and within its regions with regard to ethnic groups, cultures, environments, economics, historical ties and government systems.
689	Definitionic groups, cultures, envir and boundaries  Greek three-continent system The original distinction between Europe and Asia was made by the ancient Greeks.
689	They used the Aegean Sea, the Dardanelles, the Sea of Marmara, the Bosporus, the Black Sea, the Kerch Strait, and the Sea of Azov as the border between Asia and Europe.
689	The Nile was often used as the border between Asia and Africa (then called Libya), although some Greek geographers suggested the Red Sea would form a better boundary.
689	Darius' canal between the Nile and the Red Sea introduced considerable variation in opinion.
689	Under the Roman Empire, the Don River emptying into the Black Sea was the western border of Asia.
689	It was the northernmost navigable point of the European shore.
689	In the 15th century the Red Sea became established as the boundary between Africa and Asia, replacing the Nile.
689	As exploration developed, the border between Asia and Europe had to be redefined, as the borders of the time did not extend to the arctic.
689	Asia-Europe boundary The Don River became unsatisfactory to northern Europeans when Peter the Great, king of the Tsardom of Russia, defeating rival claims of Sweden and the Ottoman Empire to the eastern lands, and armed resistance by the tribes of Siberia, synthesized a new Russian Empire extending to the Ural Mountains and beyond, founded in 1721.
689	The major geographical theorist of the empire was actually a former Swedish prisoner-of-war, taken at the Battle of Poltava in 1709 and assigned to Tobolsk, where he associated with Peter's Siberian official, Vasily Tatishchev, and was allowed freedom to conduct geographical and anthropological studies in preparation for a future book.
689	In Sweden, five years after Peter's death, in 1730 Philip Johan von Strahlenberg published a new atlas proposing the Urals as the border of Asia.
689	The Russians were enthusiastic about the concept, which allowed them to keep their European identity in geography as well as other cultural heritage.
689	Tatishchev announced that he had proposed the idea to von Strahlenberg.
689	The latter had suggested the Emba River as the lower boundary.
689	Over the next century various proposals were made until the Ural River prevailed in the mid-19th century.
689	The border had been moved perforce from the Black Sea to the Caspian Sea into which the Ural River projects.
689	In the maps of the period, Transcaucasia was counted as Asian.
689	The incorporation of most of that region into the Soviet Union tended to push views of the border to the south.
689	It also has many mountainous terrains Asia-Oceania boundary The border between Asia and Oceania is placed somewhere in the Malay archipelago.
689	The terms Southeast Asia and Oceania, devised in the 19th century, have had  vastly different geographic meanings since their inception.
689	Oceania has never been Asia, whatever it may have been defined to be.
689	The chief factor in determining what islands of the Malay Archipelago are Asian has been the location of the colonial possessions of the various empires there (not all European).
689	Lewis and Wigen assert, "The narrowing of 'Southeast Asia' to its present boundaries was thus a gradual process."
689	Ongoing definition Geographical Asia is a cultural artifact, an imprecise concept causing endemic contention about what it means.
689	In contrast to Europe, Asia is the largest and most culturally diverse of the continents in the seven-continent system.
689	It does not exactly correspond to the cultural borders of its various types of constituents.
689	In addition to its general inherited geographical meaning, to which the entire literate world subscribes, Asia has any number of agency-specific meanings organizationally and operationally of use in more restricted fields of interest.
689	For example, the World University Service of Canada uses the administrative divisions of the Middle East and Europe, and South and Southeast Asia—their definition of "Asia" is substantially different from the wider definition, and the same may apply to other agencies worldwide.
689	Some differing uses of "Asia" have been promulgated by the news media reporting on current events.
689	For example, BBC News has an Asia-Pacific section, which acquires news from anywhere in Australasia, Oceania or the Pacific side of the Americas.
689	From the time of Herodotus a minority of geographers have rejected the three-continent system (Europe, Africa, Asia) on the grounds that there is no or is no substantial physical separation between them.
689	For example, Sir Barry Cunliffe, the emeritus professor of European archeology at Oxford, argues that Europe has been geographically and culturally merely "the western excrescence of the continent of Asia".
689	Geographically, Asia is the major eastern constituent of the continent of Eurasia with Europe being a northwestern peninsula of the landmass – or of Afro-Eurasia; geologically, Asia, Europe and Africa make up a single continuous landmass (except for the Suez Canal) and share a common continental shelf.
689	Almost all of Europe and most of Asia sit atop the Eurasian Plate, adjoined on the south by the Arabian and Indian Plate and with the easternmost part of Siberia (east of the Cherskiy Range) on the North American Plate.
689	Etymology  Asia was originally a concept of Western civilization.
689	The place name, "Asia", in various forms in a large number of modern languages is of unknown ultimate provenience.
689	Its etymology and language of origin are uncertain.
689	It appears to be one of the most ancient of recorded names.
689	A number of theories have been published.
689	English Asia can be traced through the formation of English literature to Latin literature, where it has the same form, Asia.
689	Whether all uses and all forms of the name derive also from the Latin of the Roman Empire is much less certain.
689	Classical antiquity Latin Asia and Greek Ἀσία appear to be the same word.
689	Roman authors translated Ἀσία as Asia.
689	The Romans named a province Asia, which was in the location of the then Asia.
689	There was an Asia Minor and an Asia Major (Iraq), of which the name of Minor survived.
689	As the earliest evidence of the name is Greek, it is likely circumstantially that Asia came from Ἀσία, but ancient transitions, due to the lack of literary ely circumstantially that Asia camecontexts, are difficult to catch in the act.
689	The most likely vehicles were the ancient geographers and historians, such as Herodotus, who were all Greek.
689	Roman civilization Hellenized extensively.
689	Ancient Greek certainly evidences early and rich uses of the name.
689	The first continental use of Asia is attributed to Herodotus (about 440 BC), not because he innovated it, but because his Histories are the earliest surviving prose to describe it in any detail.
689	He defines it carefully, mentioning the previous geographers whom he had read, but whose works are now missing.
689	By it he means Anatolia and the Persian Empire, in contrast to Greece and Egypt.
689	Herodotus comments that he is puzzled as to why three women's names were "given to a tract which is in reality one" (Europa, Asia, and Libya, referring to Africa), stating that most Greeks assumed that Asia was named after the wife of Prometheus (i.e.
689	Hesione), but that the Lydians say it was named after Asies, son of Cotys, who passed the name on to a tribe at Sardis.
689	In Greek mythology, "Asia" (Ἀσία) or "Asie" (Ἀσίη) was the name of a "Nymph or Titan goddess of Lydia."
689	Herodotus' geographical puzzlement was perhaps only a form of disagreement, as, having read the earlier Greek poetry along with everyone else literate, he would have known perfectly well why places received female names.
689	Athens, Mycenae, Thebes and many other locations in fact had them.
689	In ancient Greek religion, places were under the care of female divinities, parallel to guardian angels.
689	The poets detailed their doings and generations in allegoric language salted with entertaining stories, which subsequently playwrights transformed into classical Greek drama and became "Greek mythology."
689	For example, Hesiod mentions the daughters of Tethys and Ocean, among whom are a "holy company", "who with the Lord Apollo and the Rivers have youths in their keeping."
689	Many of these are geographic: Doris, Rhodea, Europa, Asia.
689	Hesiod explains:"For there are three-thousand neat-ankled daughters of Ocean who are dispersed far and wide, and in every place alike serve the earth and the deep waters."
689	The Iliad (attributed by the ancient Greeks to Homer) mentions two Phrygians (the tribe that replaced the Luvians in Lydia) in the Trojan War named Asios (an adjective meaning "Asian"); and also a marsh or lowland containing a marsh in Lydia as ασιος.
689	Bronze Age Before Greek poetry, the Aegean Sea area was in a Greek Dark Age, at the beginning of which syllabic writing was lost and alphabetic writing had not begun.
689	Prior to then in the Bronze Age the records of the Assyrian Empire, the Hittite Empire and the various Mycenaean states of Greece mention a region undoubtedly Asia, certainly in Anatolia, including if not identical to Lydia.
689	These records are administrative and do not include poetry.
689	The Mycenaean states were destroyed about 1200 BC by unknown agents although one school of thought assigns the Dorian invasion to this time.
689	The burning of the palaces baked clay diurnal administrative records written in a Greek syllabic script called Linear B, deciphered by a number of interested parties, most notably by a young World War II cryptographer, Michael Ventris, subsequently assisted by the scholar, John Chadwick.
689	A major cache discovered by Carl Blegen at the site of ancient Pylos included hundreds of male and female names formed by different methods.
689	Some of these are of women held in servitude (as study of the society implied by the content reveals).
689	They were used in trades, such as cloth-making, and usually came with children.
689	The epithet, lawiaiai, "captives," associated with some of them identifies their origin.
689	Some are ethnic names.
689	One in particular, aswiai, identifies "women of Asia."
689	Perhaps they were captured in Asia, but some others, Milatiai, appear to have been of Miletus, a Greek colony, which would not have been raided for slaves by Greeks.
689	Chadwick suggests that the names record the locations where these foreign women were purchased.
689	The name is also in the singular, Aswia, which refers both to the name of a country and to a female of it.
689	There is a masculine form, aswios.
689	This Aswia appears to have been a remnant of a region known to the Hittites as Assuwa, centered on Lydia, or "Roman Asia."
689	This name, Assuwa, has been suggested as the origin for the name of the continent "Asia".
689	The Assuwa league was a confederation of states in western Anatolia, defeated by the Hittites under Tudhaliya I around 1400 BC.
689	Alternatively, the etymology of the term may be from the Akkadian word ', which means 'to go outside' or 'to ascend', referring to the direction of the sun at sunrise in the Middle East and also likely connected with the Phoenician word asa meaning east.
689	This may be contrasted to a similar etymology proposed for Europe, as being from Akkadian erēbu(m) 'to enter' or 'set' (of the sun).
689	T.R.
689	Reid supports this alternative etymology, noting that the ancient Greek name must have derived from asu, meaning 'east' in Assyrian (ereb for Europe meaning 'west').
689	The ideas of Occidental (form Latin Occidens 'setting') and Oriental (from Latin Oriens for 'rising') are also European invention, synonymous with Western and Eastern.
689	Reid further emphasizes that it explains the Western point of view of placing all the peoples and cultures of Asia into a single classification, almost as if there were a need for setting the distinction between Western and Eastern civilizations on the Eurasian continent.
689	Ogura Kazuo and Tenshin Okakura are two outspoken Japanese figures on the subject.
689	History The history of Asia can be seen as the distinct histories of several peripheral coastal regions: East Asia, South Asia, Southeast Asia and the Middle East, linked by the interior mass of the Central Asian steppes.
689	The coastal periphery was home to some of the world's earliest known civilizations, each of them developing around fertile river valleys.
689	The civilizations in Mesopotamia, the Indus Valley and the Huanghe shared many similarities.
689	These civilizations may well have exchanged technologies and ideas such as mathematics and the wheel.
689	Other innovations, such as writianged technologies and ideas such as ng, seem to have been developed individually in each area.
689	Cities, states and empires developed in these lowlands.
689	The central steppe region had long been inhabited by horse-mounted nomads who could reach all areas of Asia from the steppes.
689	The earliest postulated expansion out of the steppe is that of the Indo-Europeans, who spread their languages into the Middle East, South Asia, and the borders of China, where the Tocharians resided.
689	The northernmost part of Asia, including much of Siberia, was largely inaccessible to the steppe nomads, owing to the dense forests, climate and tundra.
689	These areas remained very sparsely populated.
689	The center and the peripheries were mostly kept separated by mountains and deserts.
689	The Caucasus and Himalaya mountains and the Karakum and Gobi deserts formed barriers that the steppe horsemen could cross only with difficulty.
689	While the urban city dwellers were more advanced technologically and socially, in many cases they could do little in a military aspect to defend against the mounted hordes of the steppe.
689	However, the lowlands did not have enough open grasslands to support a large horsebound force; for this and other reasons, the nomads who conquered states in China, India, and the Middle East often found themselves adapting to the local, more affluent societies.
689	The Islamic Caliphate took over the Middle East and Central Asia during the Muslim conquests of the 7th century.
689	The Mongol Empire conquered a large part of Asia in the 13th century, an area extending from China to Europe.
689	Geography and climate Asia is the largest continent on Earth.
689	It covers 8.8% of the Earth's total surface area (or 30% of its land area), and has the largest coastline, at 62800 km.
689	Asia is generally defined as comprising the eastern four-fifths of Eurasia.
689	It is located to the east of the Suez Canal and the Ural Mountains, and south of the Caucasus Mountains (or the Kuma-Manych Depression) and the Caspian and Black Seas.
689	It is bounded on the east by the Pacific Ocean, on the south by the Indian Ocean and on the north by the Arctic Ocean.
689	Asia is subdivided into 48 countries, two of them (Russia and Turkey) having part of their land in Europe.
689	Asia has extremely diverse climates and geographic features.
689	Climates range from arctic and subarctic in Siberia to tropical in southern India and Southeast Asia.
689	It is moist across southeast sections, and dry across much of the interior.
689	Some of the largest daily temperature ranges on Earth occur in western sections of Asia.
689	The monsoon circulation dominates across southern and eastern sections, due to the presence of the Himalayas forcing the formation of a thermal low which draws in moisture during the summer.
689	Southwestern sections of the continent are hot.
689	Siberia is one of the coldest places in the Northern Hemisphere, and can act as a source of arctic air masses for North America.
689	The most active place on Earth for tropical cyclone activity lies northeast of the Philippines and south of Japan.
689	The Gobi Desert is in Mongolia and the Arabian Desert stretches across much of the Middle East.
689	The Yangtze River in China is the longest river in the continent.
689	The Himalayas between India and China is the tallest mountain range in the world.
689	Tropical rainforests stretch across much of southern Asia and coniferous and deciduous forests lie farther north.
689	Economy  Asia has the second largest nominal GDP of all continents, after Europe, but the largest when measured in purchasing power parity.
689	As of 2011, the largest economies in Asia are China, Japan, India, South Korea and Indonesia.
689	Based on Global Office Locations 2011, Asia dominated the office locations with 4 of top 5 were in Asia, Hong Kong, Singapore, Tokyo, Seoul and Shanghai.
689	Around 68 percent of international firms have office in Hong Kong.
689	In the late 1990s and early 2000s, the economies of the PRC and India have been growing rapidly, both with an average annual growth rate of more than 8%.
689	Other recent very high growth nations in Asia include Israel, Malaysia, Indonesia, Pakistan, Thailand, Vietnam, Mongolia, Uzbekistan, Cyprus and the Philippines, and mineral-rich nations such as Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Iran, Brunei, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman.
689	According to economic historian Angus Maddison in his book The World Economy: A Millennial Perspective, India had the world's largest economy during 0 BCE and 1000 BCE.
689	China was the largest and most advanced economy on earth for much of recorded history, until the British Empire (excluding India) overtook it in the mid-19th century.
689	For several decades in the late twentieth century Japan was the largest economy in Asia and second-largest of any single nation in the world, after surpassing the Soviet Union (measured in net material product) in 1986 and Germany in 1968.
689	NB: A number of supernational economies are larger, such as the European Union (EU), the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) or APEC).
689	This ended in 2010 when China overtook Japan to become the world's second largest economy.
689	In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Japan's GDP was almost as large (current exchange rate method) as that of the rest of Asia combined.
689	In 1995, Japan's economy nearly equaled that of the USA as the largest economy in the world for a day, after the Japanese currency reached a record high of 79 yen/US$.
689	Economic growth in Asia since World War II to the 1990s had been concentrated in Japan as well as the four regions of South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore located in the Pacific Rim, known as the Asian tigers, which have now all received developed country status, having the highest GDP per capita in Asia.
689	It is forecasted that India will overtake Japan in terms of nominal GDP by 2020.
689	By 2027, according to Goldman Sachs, China will have the largest economy in the world.
689	Several trade blocs exist, with the most developed being the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
689	Asia is the largest continent in the world by a considerable margin, and it is rich in natural resources, such as petroleum, forests, fish, water, rice, copper and silver.
689	Manufacturing in Asia has traditionally been strongest in East and Southeast Asia, particularly in the China, Taiwan, South Korea, Japan, India, the Philippines, and Singapore.
689	Japan and South Korea continue to dominate in the area of multinational corporations, but increasingly the PRC and India are making significant inroads.
689	Many companies from Europe, North America, South Korea and Japan have operations in Asia's developing countries to take advantage of its abundant supply of cheap labour and relatively developed infrastructure.
689	According to Citigroup 9 of 11 Global Growth Generators countries came from Asia driven by population and income growth.
689	They are Bangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, Iraq, Mongolia, Philippines, Sri Lanka and Vietnam.
689	Asia has four main financial centres: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Singapore and Shanghai.
689	Call centres and business process outsourcing (BPOs) are becoming major employers in India and the Philippines due to the availability of a large pool of highly skilled, English-speaking workers.
689	The increased use of outsourcing has assisted the rise of India and the China as financial centres.
689	Due to its large and extremely competitive information technology industry, India has become a major hub for outsourcing.
689	In 2010, Asia had 3.3 million millionaires (people with net worth over US$1 million excluding their homes), slightly below North America with 3.4 million millionaires.
689	Last year Asia had toppled Europe.
689	Citigroup in The Wealth Report 2012 stated that Asian centa-millionaire overtook North America's wealth for the first time as the world's "economic center of gravity" continued moving east.
689	At the end of 2011, there were 18,000 Asian people mainly in Southeast Asia, China and Japan who have at least $100 million in disposable assets, while North America with 17,000 people and Western Europe with 14,000 people.
689	Demographics East Asia had by far the strongest overall Human Development Index (HDI) improvement of any region in the world, nearly doubling average HDI attainment over the past 40 years, according to the report’s analysis of health, education and income data.
689	China, the second highest achiever in the world in terms of HDI improvement since 1970, is the only country on the “Top 10 Movers” list due to income rather than health or education achievements.
689	Its per capita income increased a stunning 21-fold over the last four decades, also lifting hundreds of millions out of income poverty.
689	Yet it was not among the region’s top performers in improving school enrolment and life expectancy.
689	Nepal, a South Asian country, emerges as one of the world’s fastest movers since 1970 mainly due to health and education achievements.
689	Its present life expectancy is 25 years longer than in the 1970s.
689	More than four of every five children of school age in Nepal now attend primary school, compared to just one in five 40 years ago.
689	Japan and South Korea ranked highest among the countries grouped on the HDI (number 11 and 12 in the world, which are in the “very high human development” category), followed by Hong Kong (SAR)(21) and Singapore (27).
689	Afghanistan (155) ranked lowest amongst Asian countries out of the 169 countries assessed.
689	Languages Asia is home to several language families and many language isolates.
689	Most Asian countries have more than one language that is natively spoken.
689	For instance, according to Ethnologue, more than 600 languages are spoken in Indonesia, more than 800 languages spoken in India, and more than 100 are spoken in the Philippines.
689	China has many languages and dialects in different provinces.
689	Religions  Almost all Asian religions have philosophical character and Asian philosophical traditions cover a large spectrum of philosophical thoughts and writings.
689	Indian philosophy includes Hindu philosophy and Buddhist philosophy.
689	They include elements of nonmaterial pursuits, whereas another school of thought from India, Cārvāka, preached the enjoyment of material world.
689	As of 2012, Hinduism has around 1.1 billion adherents.
689	The faith represents around 25% of Asia's population and is the second largest religion in Asia.
689	However, it is mostly concentrated in south Asia.
689	Islam is the largest religion in Asia.
689	Christianity is also present in most Asian countries.
689	Asian mythology is complex and diverse.
689	The story of the Great Flood for example, as presented to Christians in the Old Testament, is first found in Mesopotamian mythology, in the Epic of Gilgamesh.
689	Hindu mythology tells about an Avatar of the God Vishnu in the form of a fish who warned Manu of a terrible flood.
689	In ancient Chinese mythology, Shan Hai Jing, the Chinese ruler Da Yu, had to spend 10 years to control a deluge which swept out most of ancient China and was aided by the goddess Nüwa who literally fixed the broken sky through which huge rains were pouring.
689	Abrahamic  The Abrahamic religions of Judaism, Christianity, Islam and Baha'i Faith originated in West Asia.
689	Judaism, the oldest of the Abrahamic faiths, is practiced primarily in Israel (the birthplace and historical homeland of the Jewish people, whose Jewish population today consists equally of those Israelites who remained in Asia/North Africa and those who returned from exile in the European diaspora), though small communities exist in other countries, such as the Bene Israel in India.
