689	In the Philippines and East Timor, Roman Catholicism is the predominant religion; it was introduced by the Spaniards and the Portuguese, respectively.
689	In Armenia, Cyprus, Georgia and Russia, Eastern Orthodoxy is the predominant religion.
689	Various Christian denominations have adherents in portions of the Middle East, as well as China and India.
689	The world's largest Muslim community (within the bounds of one nation) is in Indonesia.
689	South Asia (mainly Pakistan, India and Bangladesh) holds 30% of Muslims.
689	There are also significant Muslim populations in China, Iran, Malaysia, southern Philippines (Mindanao), Russia and most of West Asia and Central Asia.
689	The Bahá'í Faith originated in Asia, in Iran (Persia), and spread from there to the Ottoman Empire, Central Asia, India, and Burma during the lifetime of Bahá'u'lláh.
689	Since the middle of the 20th century, growth has particularly occurred in other Asian countries, because the Bahá'í Faith's activities in many Muslim countries has been severely suppressed by authorities.
689	Dharmic and Taoist  The religions of Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism and Sikhism originated in India, South Asia.
689	In East Asia, particularly in China and Japan, Confucianism, Taoism and Zen Buddhism took shape.
689	Over 80% of the populations of both India and Nepal adhere to Hinduism, alongside significant communities in Bangladesh, Pakistan, Bhutan, Sri Lanka and Bali.
689	Many overseas Indians in countries such as Burma, Singapore and Malaysia also adhere to Hinduism.
689	Buddhism has a great following in mainland Southeast Asia and East Asia.
689	Buddhism is the religion of the majority of the populations of Cambodia (98%), Thailand (95%), Burma (89%), Japan (84–96%), Bhutan (75%), Sri Lanka (69%), Laos (67%–98%) and Mongolia (50%).
689	Large Buddhist populations also exist in Singapore (42.5%), Taiwan (35.1%–93%), South Korea (23.2%), Malaysia (19.2%), Nepal (10.7%), Vietnam (9.3–80%), China (8–80%), North Korea (4.5%–60%), Indonesia (<2%); and small communities in India and Bangladesh.
689	In many Chinese communities, Mahayana Buddhism is easily syncretized with Taoism, thus exact religious statistics is difficult to obtain and may be understated or overstated.
689	The Communist-governed countries of China, Vietnam and North Korea are officially atheist, thus the number of Buddhists and other religious adherents may be under-reported.
689	Jainism is found mainly in India and in oversea Indian communities such as India and Malaysia.
689	Sikhism is found in Northern India and amongst overseas Indian communities in other parts of Asia, especially Southeast Asia.
689	Confucianism is found predominantly in Mainland China, South Korea, Taiwan and in overseas Chinese populations.
689	Taoism is found mainly in Mainland China, Taiwan, Malaysia and Singapore.
689	Taoism is easily syncretized with Mahayana Buddhism for many Chinese, thus exact religious statistics is difficult to obtain and may be understated or overstated.
689	Modern conflicts Some of the events pivotal in the Asia territory related to the relationship with the outside world in the post-Second World War were: *The Korean War *The Vietnam War *The Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation *The Iranian Revolution *The Soviet War in Afghanistan *The Iran–Iraq War *The Killing Fields in Cambodia *The Sri Lankan Civil War *The Dissolution of the Soviet Union *The 1991 Gulf War *The India-Pakistan Wars *The 2006 Thai coup d'état *The Burmese Civil War *The Arab Spring *The Israel-Palestine conflict *The Civil War in Syria Culture Nobel prizes  The polymath Rabindranath Tagore, a Bengali poet, dramatist, and writer from Santiniketan, now in West Bengal, India, became in 1913 the first Asian Nobel laureate.
689	He won his Nobel Prize in Literature for notable impact his prose works and poetic thought had on English, French, and other national literatures of Europe and the Americas.
689	He is also the writer of the national anthems of Bangladesh and India.
689	Other Asian writers who won Nobel Prize for literature include Yasunari Kawabata (Japan, 1968), Kenzaburō Ōe (Japan, 1994), Gao Xingjian (China, 2000), Orhan Pamuk (Turkey, 2006), and Mo Yan (China, 2012).
689	Some may consider the American writer, Pearl S.
689	Buck, an honorary Asian Nobel laureate, having spent considerable time in China as the daughter of missionaries, and based many of her novels, namely The Good Earth (1931) and The Mother (1933), as well as the biographies of her parents of their time in China, The Exile and Fighting Angel, all of which earned her the Literature prize in 1938.
689	Also, Mother Teresa of India and Shirin Ebadi of Iran were awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for their significant and pioneering efforts for democracy and human rights, especially for the rights of women and children.
689	Ebadi is the first Iranian and the first Muslim woman to receive the prize.
689	Another Nobel Peace Prize winner ise first Iranian and the first Muslim wo Aung San Suu Kyi from Burma for her peaceful and non-violent struggle under a military dictatorship in Burma.
689	She is a nonviolent pro-democracy activist and leader of the National League for Democracy in Burma(Myanmar) and a noted prisoner of conscience.
689	She is a Buddhist and was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991.
689	Most recently, Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for "his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China."
689	He is the first Chinese citizen to be awarded a Nobel Prize of any kind while residing in China.
689	Sir C.
689	V.
689	Raman is the first Asian to get a Nobel prize in Sciences.
689	He won the Nobel Prize in Physics "for his work on the scattering of light and for the discovery of the effect named after him".
689	Amartya Sen, (born 3 November 1933) is an Indian economist who was awarded the 1998 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his contributions to welfare economics and social choice theory, and for his interest in the problems of society's poorest members.
689	Other Asian Nobel Prize winners include Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, Abdus Salam, Robert Aumann, Menachem Begin, Aaron Ciechanover, Avram Hershko, Daniel Kahneman, Shimon Peres, Yitzhak Rabin, Ada Yonath, Yaser Arafat, Jose Ramos Horta and Bishop Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo of Timor Leste, Kim Dae-jung, and 13 Japanese scientists.
689	Most of the said awardees are from Japan and Israel except for Chandrasekhar and Raman (India), Salam (Pakistan), Arafat (Palestinian Territories) Kim (South Korea), Horta and Belo (Timor Leste).
689	In 2006, Dr.
689	Muhammad Yunus of Bangladesh was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for the establishment of Grameen Bank, a community development bank that lends money to poor people, especially women in Bangladesh.
689	Dr.
689	Yunus received his PhD in economics from Vanderbilt University, United States.
689	He is internationally known for the concept of micro credit which allows poor and destitute people with little or no collateral to borrow money.
689	The borrowers typically pay back money within the specified period and the incidence of default is very low.
689	The Dalai Lama has received approximately eighty-four awards over his spiritual and political career.
689	On 22 June 2006, he became one of only four people ever to be recognized with Honorary Citizenship by the Governor General of Canada.
689	On 28 May 2005, he received the Christmas Humphreys Award from the Buddhist Society in the United Kingdom.
689	Most notable was the Nobel Peace Prize, presented in Oslo, Norway on 10 December 1989.
689	Political geography
690	Aruba ( ,) is a 33-kilometer-long (20 mi) island of the Lesser Antilles in the southern Caribbean Sea, located  north of the coast of Venezuela.
690	Together with Bonaire and Curaçao, it forms a group referred to as the ABC islands of the Leeward Antilles, the southern island chain of the Lesser Antilles.
690	Collectively, Aruba and the other Dutch islands in the Antilles are commonly referred to as the Netherlands Antilles or the Dutch Antilles.
690	Along with the Netherlands, Curaçao and Sint Maarten, Aruba is one of the four constituent countries that form the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
690	The citizens of all share a single nationality: Dutch.
690	Aruba has no administrative e Netherlands.
690	The citsubdivisions, but, for census purposes, is divided into eight regions.
690	Its capital is Oranjestad.
690	Unlike much of the Caribbean region, Aruba has a dry climate and an arid, cactus-strewn landscape.
690	This climate has helped tourism as visitors to the island can reliably expect warm, sunny weather.
690	It has a land area of 179 km2 and is densely populated with a total of 101,484 inhabitants at the 2010 Census.
690	It lies outside the hurricane belt.
690	History  Aruba's first inhabitants are thought to have been Caquetíos Amerinds from the Arawak tribe, who migrated there from Venezuela to escape attacks by the Caribs.
690	Fragments of the earliest known Indian settlements date back to 1000 AD.
690	Sea currents made canoe travel to other Caribbean islands difficult, thus Caquetio culture remained closer to that of mainland South America.
690	Europeans first learned of Aruba following the explorations of Amerigo Vespucci and Alonso de Ojeda in the summer of 1499.
690	Though Vespucci boasted of discovering the island, he and Ojeda were likely guided there by natives of nearby islands.
690	Both described Aruba as an "island of giants", remarking on the comparatively large stature of the native Caquetíos compared to Europeans.
690	Ojeda also referred to the island as "Oro Hubo", Spanish for "It Had Gold".
690	Gold was not discovered on Aruba, however, for another 300 years.
690	Vespucci returned to Spain with stocks of cotton and brazilwood from the island and described houses built into the ocean.
690	Vespucci and Ojeda's tales spurred interest in Aruba and Spaniards soon colonized the island.
690	Aruba was colonized by Spain for over a century.
690	The Cacique or Indian Chief in Aruba, Simas, welcomed the first priests in Aruba and received from them a wooden cross as a gift.
690	In 1508, Alonso de Ojeda was appointed as Spain's first Governor of Aruba, as part of "Nueva Andalucía".
690	Another governor appointed by Spain was Juan Martínez de Ampiés.
690	A "cédula real" decreed in November 1525 gave Ampíes, factor of Española, the right to repopulate Aruba.
690	In 1528, Ampíes was replaced by a representative of the House of Welser.
690	Aruba has been under Dutch administration since 1636, initially under Peter Stuyvesant.
690	Stuyvesant was on a special mission in Aruba in November and December 1642.
690	Under the Dutch W.I.C.
690	"New Netherland and Curaçao" from 1648 to 1664 and the Dutch government regulations of 1629, also applied in Aruba.
690	The Dutch administration appointed an Irishman as "Commandeur" in Aruba in 1667.
690	In August 1806, General Francisco de Miranda and a group of 200 freedom fighters on their voyage to liberate Venezuela from Spain stayed in Aruba for several weeks.
690	In 1933 Aruba sent its first petition for Aruba's separate status and autonomy to the Queen.
690	During World War II, Aruba was one of the main suppliers of refined petroleum products to the Allies.
690	Aruba became a British protectorate from 1940 to 1942 and a US protectorate from 1942 to 1945.
690	On 16 February 1942, its oil processing refinery was attacked by a German submarine (U-156) under the command of Werner Hartenstein, but the mission failed.
690	In March 1944, Eleanor Roosevelt briefly visited American troops stationed in Aruba.
690	In attendance were Curaçao Governor P.
690	Kasteel, and U.S.
690	Rear Admiral T.
690	E.
690	Chandler.
690	Move towards independence  In August 1947, Aruba presented its first "Staatsreglement" (constitution), for Aruba's "status aparte" as the status of an autonomous state within the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
690	By 1954, the Charter of the Kingdom of the Netherlands was established, providing a framework for relations between Aruba and the rest of the Kingdom.
690	In 1972, at a conference in Suriname, Betico Croes (MEP) proposed a "sui-generis" Dutch Commonwealth of four states: Aruba, the Netherlands, Suriname and the Netherlands Antilles, each with its own nationality.
690	Mr.
690	C.
690	Yarzagaray, a parliamentary member representing the AVP political party, proposed a referendum for the people of Aruba to determine Aruba's separate status or "Status Aparte" as a full autonomous state under the crown.
690	He proclaimed: "Aruba shall never accept a federation and a second class nationality."
690	Betico Croes worked in Aruba to inform and prepare the people of Aruba for independence.
690	In 1976, a committee appointed by Croes introduced the national flag and anthem as the symbols of Aruba's sovereignty and independence, and he also set 1981 as a target for Aruba's independence.
690	In March 1977, the first Referendum for Self Determination was held with the support of the United Nations and 82% of the participants voted for independence.
690	The Island Government of Aruba assigned the Institute of Social Studies in The Hague to prepare a study of Aruba's independence, which was published in 1978, titled "Aruba en Onafhankelijkheid, achtergronden, modaliteiten en mogelijkheden; een rapport in eerste aanleg" ["Aruba and independence, backgrounds, modalities and opportunities; a preliminary report"].
690	At the conference in The Hague in 1981, Aruba's independence was set for the year 1991.
690	In March 1983 Aruba reached an official agreement within the Kingdom for Aruba's Independence, which would occur in a series of steps granting increasing autonomy.
690	In August 1985 Aruba drafted a constitution that was unanimously approved.
690	On 1 January 1986, after elections were held for Aruba's first parliament, Aruba seceded from the Netherlands Antilles and officially became a country of the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
690	Full independence was projected in 1996.
690	Croes was later proclaimed "Libertador di Aruba" after his death in 1986.
690	At a convention in The Hague in 1990, the governments of Aruba, the Netherlands and the Netherlands Antilles postponed indefinitely Aruba's transition to full independence at the request of its Prime Minister.
690	The article scheduling Aruba's complete independence was rescinded in 1995, although the process can begin again after a referendum.
690	Geography  Aruba is a generally flat, riverless island in the Leeward Antilles island arc of the Lesser Antilles.
690	Aruba is widely known for its white sandy beaches on the western and southern coasts of the island, relatively sheltered from fierce ocean currents, and this is where most tourist development island, relatively shhas taken place.
690	The northern and eastern coasts, lacking this protection, are considerably more battered by the sea and have been left largely untouched by humans.
690	The hinterland of the island features some rolling hills, the best known of which are called Hooiberg at 165 m and Mount Jamanota, the highest on the island at 188 m above sea level.
690	Oranjestad, the capital, is located at .
690	To the east of Aruba are Bonaire and Curaçao, two island territories which once formed the southwest part of the Netherlands Antilles; this group of islands is sometimes called the ABC islands.
690	The Natural Bridge was a large, naturally formed limestone bridge on the island's north shore that was a popular tourist destination until its collapse in 2005.
690	File:ArubaNaturalBabyBridge.JPG|Baby natural bridge in Aruba File:197306 aruba naturalbridge.jpg|Natural bridge in Aruba (collapsed 2 September 2005) Cities and towns  The island, with a population of just over 100,000 inhabitants, does not have major cities.
690	Oranjestad (33,000 in 2006) * Paradera * San Nicolas * Noord * Santa Cruz * Savaneta Fauna The island provides a habitat for the endemic Aruba Island Rattlesnake.
690	Climate  In the Köppen climate classification, Aruba has a semi-arid climate.
690	Temperature varies little from 28 °C to around 33 C, moderated by constant trade winds from the Atlantic Ocean, which comes from north-east.
690	Yearly precipitation barely exceeds 400 mm.
690	Demographics  Aruba is situated in the deep southern part of the Caribbean.
690	Because it has low rainfall, Aruba was saved from the plantation system and the economics of the slave trade.
690	Aruba's population is estimated to be 80% mixed white/Caribbean Amerindian and 20% other ethnicities.
690	Arawaks spoke the "broken Spanish" which their ancestors had learned on Hispaniola.
690	The Dutch took control 135 years after the Spanish, leaving the Arawaks to farm and graze livestock, and used the island as a source of meat for other Dutch possessions in the Caribbean, leading to a depletion of the Arawak population.
690	The Arawak heritage is stronger on Aruba than on most Caribbean islands.
690	Although no full-blooded Aboriginals remain, the features of the islanders clearly indicate their genetic Arawak heritage.
690	Most of the population is descended mostly from Arawak, and to a lesser extent Spanish, Italian, Dutch, and a few French, Portuguese, British, and African ancestors.
690	Recently there has been substantial immigration to the island from neighboring American and Caribbean nations, possibly attracted by the higher paid jobs.
690	In 2007, new immigration laws were introduced to help control the growth of the population by restricting foreign workers to a maximum of three years residency on the island.
690	Demographically, Aruba has felt the impact of its proximity to Venezuela.
690	Many of Aruba's families are descended from Venezuelan immigrants.
690	There is a seasonal increase of Venezuelans living in second homes.
690	Language  Language can be seen as an important part of island culture in Aruba.
690	The official languages are Dutch and – since 2003 – Papiamento.
690	Papiamento is the predominant language on Aruba.
690	A creole language spoken on Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao, it incorporates words from other languages including Portuguese, West African languages, Dutch, and Spanish.
690	English is known by many; its usage has grown due to tourism.
690	Other common languages spoken based on the size of their community are Portuguese, Chinese, German, Spanish, and French.
690	In recent years, the government of Aruba has shown an increased interest in acknowledging the cultural and historical importance of its native language.
690	Although spoken Papiamento is fairly similar among the several Papiamento-speaking islands, there is a big difference in written Papiamento.
690	The orthography differs per island and even per group of people.
690	Some are more oriented towards Portuguese and use the equivalent spelling (e.g.
690	"y" instead of "j"), where others are more oriented towards Dutch.
690	The book The Buccaneers of America, first published in 1678, states through eyewitness account that the IndThe Buccaneers of Amerians on Aruba spoke "Spanish".
690	The oldest government official statement written in Papiamento dates from 1803.
690	Around 12.6% of the population today speaks Spanish.
690	Aruba has four newspapers published in Papiamento: Diario, Bon Dia, Solo di Pueblo and Awe Mainta; and two in English: Aruba Today and The News.
690	Amigoe is the newspaper published in Dutch.
690	Aruba also has 18 radio stations (two AM and 16 FM) and three local television stations (Tele-Aruba, Aruba Broadcast Company and Channel 22).
690	Regions  For census purposes, Aruba is divided into eight regions, which have no administrative functions: Government  As a constituent country of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, Aruba's politics take place within a framework of a 21-member Parliament and an eight-member Cabinet.
690	The governor of Aruba is appointed for a six-year term by the monarch, and the prime minister and deputy prime minister are elected by the Staten (or "Parlamento") for four-year terms.
690	The Staten is made up of 21 members elected by direct, popular vote to serve a four-year term.
690	Together with the Netherlands, the countries of Aruba, Curaçao and Sint Maarten form the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
690	As they share the same Dutch citizenship, these four countries still also share the Dutch passport as the Kingdom of the Netherlands passport.
690	As Aruba, Curaçao and Sint Maarten have small populations, the three countries had to limit immigration.
690	To protect their population, they have the right to control the admission and expulsion of people from the Netherlands.
690	Aruba is designated as a member of the Overseas Countries and Territories (OCT) and is thus officially not a part of the European Union, though Aruba can and does receive support from the European Development Fund.
690	Politics  The Aruban legal system is based on the Dutch model.
690	Instead of juries or grand juries, in Aruba, legal jurisdiction lies with the Gerecht in Eerste Aanleg (Court of First Instance) on Aruba, the Gemeenschappelijk Hof van Justitie van Aruba, Curaçao, Sint Maarten en van Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba (Joint Court of Justice of Aruba, Curaçao, Sint Maarten, and of Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba) and the Hoge Raad der Nederlanden (Supreme Court of Justice of the Netherlands).
690	The Korps Politie Aruba (Aruba Police Force) is the island's law enforcement agency and operates district precincts in Oranjestad, Noord, San Nicolaas, and Santa Cruz, where it is headquartered.
690	Deficit spending has been a staple in Aruba's history, and modestly high inflation has been present as well.
690	As of 2006, the government's debt had grown to 1.883 billion Aruban florins.
690	Aruba received some development aid from the Dutch government each year through 2009, as part of a deal (signed as "Aruba's Financial Independence") in which the Netherlands gradually reduced its financial help to the island each successive year.
690	In 2006 the Aruban government changed several tax laws to reduce the deficit.
690	Direct taxes have been converted to indirect taxes as proposed by the IMF.
690	A 3% tax has been introduced on sales and services, while income taxes have been lowered and revenue taxes for business reduced by 20%.
690	The government compensated workers with 3.1% for the effect that the B.B.O.
690	Education  Aruba's educational system is patterned after the Dutch system of education.
690	There are 68 schools for primary education, 12 schools for secondary education, and 5 universities in Aruba.
690	In 2007, there were 22,930 registered full-time students.
690	The Government of Aruba finances the national education system, except for private schools, such as the International School of Aruba (ISA), which finance their own activities.
690	The percentage of money earmarked for education is higher than the average for the Caribbean/Latin American region.There is also a private Dutch school on the island: Schakel College.
690	Arubans have a primary school system, followed by a segmented secondary school program which includes vocational training, basic education, college preparation and advanced placement.
690	The study of Spanish and French is offered in secondary school and college, since a high percentage of students continue their studies in Europe.
690	Higher education is available through the Professional Education program (EPI), the teachers college (IPA) as well as through the University of Aruba (UA) which offers bachelors and masters programs in law, finance and economics and hospitality and tourism management.
690	Since the choice for programs in la higher education on the island itself is limited, many students choose study in the Netherlands, or abroad in countries in North America, South America as well as the rest of Europe.
690	Aruba is also home to two medical schools: Aureus University School of Medicine and Xavier University School of Medicine.
690	Economy  Aruba has one of the highest standards of living in the Caribbean region.
690	There is a low unemployment rate.
690	The GDP per capita for Aruba was estimated to be $21,800 in 2004; among the highest in the Caribbean and the Americas.
690	Its main trading partners are Venezuela, the United States and the Netherlands.
690	The island's economy has been dominated by five main industries: tourism, gold mining, phosphate mining (The Aruba Phosphaat Maatschappij), aloe export, and petroleum refining (The Lago Oil & Transport Company and the Arend Petroleum Maatschappij Shell Co.).
690	Before the "Status Aparte" (a separate completely autonomous country/state within the Kingdom), oil processing was the dominant industry in Aruba despite expansion of the tourism sector.
690	Today, the influence of the oil processing business is minimal.
690	The size of the agriculture and manufacturing sectors also remains minimal.
690	The inflation on Aruba in 2007 was 8.7%.
690	The exchange rate of the Aruban florin has remained steady in recent years at 1.78 florins to 1 US dollar.
690	Because of this fact, and due to a large number of American tourists, many businesses operate using US dollars instead of florins, especially in the hotel & resort districts.
690	Tourism About three quarters of the Aruban gross national product is earned through tourism or related activities.
690	Most tourists are from (mainland) the Netherlands,Venezuela and the United States (predominantly from eastern and southern states).
690	As part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, citizens of (mainland) the Netherlands can travel with relative ease to Aruba and other islands of the Dutch Antilles.
690	No visas are needed for Dutch citizens, only a passport, and although the currency used in Aruba is different (the Netherlands has the Euro), Euro's are still widely accepted and easily exchanged for Aruban Florins.
690	For the facilitation of the passengers whose destination is the United States, the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS), U.S.
690	Customs and Border Protection (CBP) full pre-clearance facility in Aruba has been in effect since 1 February 2001 with the expansion in the Queen Beatrix Airport.
690	United States and Aruba have had the agreement since 1986.
690	It began as a USDA and Customs post.
690	Since 2008, Aruba has been the only island to have this service for private flights.
690	Foreign military In 1999, the U.S.
690	Department of Defense established a Forward Operating Location (FOL) at the airport.
690	Culture  On 18 March Aruba celebrates its National Day.
690	In 1976, Aruba presented its National Anthem (Aruba Dushi Tera) and Flag.
690	The origins of the population and location of the island give Aruba a mixed culture.
690	According to the Bureau Burgelijke Stand en Bevolkingsregister (BBSB), as of 2005 there are ninety-two different nationalities living on the island.
690	Dutch influence can still be seen, as in the celebration of "Sinterklaas" on 5 and 6 December and other national holidays like 30 April, when in Aruba and the rest of the Kingdom of the Netherlands the Queen's birthday or "Dia di La Reina" (Koninginnedag) is celebrated.
690	Christmas and New Years Eve are celebrated with the typical music and songs for gaitas for Christmas and the Dande for New Year, and the "ayaca", "ponche crema," ham, and other typical foods and drinks.
690	Millions of florins worth of fireworks are burnt at midnight on New Year's Eve.
690	On 25 January, Betico Croes' birthday is celebrated.
690	In June there is the celebration of the "Dia di San Juan", with the song of "Dera Gai".
690	Besides Christmas, the religious holy days of the Feast of the Ascension and Good Friday are holidays on the island.
690	The holiday of Carnival is also an important one in Aruba, as it is in many Caribbean and Latin American countries, and, like Mardi Gras, that goes on for weeks.
690	Its celebration in Aruba started, around the 1950s, influenced by the inhabitants from the nearby islands (Venezuela, St Vincent, Trinidad, Barbados, St.
690	Maarten and Anguilla) who came to work for the Oil refinery.
690	Over the years the Carnival Celebration has changed and now starts from the beginning of January till the Tuesday before Ash Wednesday with a large parade on the last Sunday of the festivities (Sunday before Ash Wednesday).
690	Tourism from the United States has recently increased the visibility of American culture on the island, with such celebrations as Halloween and Thanksgiving Day in November.
690	Infrastructure  Aruba's Queen Beatrix International Airport is located near Oranjestad.
690	According to the Aruba Airport Authority, almost 1.7 million travelers used the airport in 2005, of which 61% were Americans.
690	Aruba has two ports, Barcadera and Playa, which are located in Oranjestad.
690	The Port of Playa services all the cruise-ship lines, including Royal Caribbean, Carnival Cruise Lines, NCL, Holland America Line, Disney Cruise Line and others.
690	Nearly one million tourists enter in this port per year.
690	Aruba Ports Authority, owned and operated by the Aruban government runs these seaports.
690	Arubus is a government owned bus company.
690	Its buses operate from 3:30 am until 12:30 am 365 days a year.
690	Small private vans also provide the transportation services in certain areas such Hotel Area, San Nicolaas, Santa Cruz and Noord.
690	Utilities  Water-en Energiebedrijf (W.E.B.) Aruba NV produces potable industrial water, at the world's third largest desalination plant.
690	Average daily consumption in is about 37000 LT.
690	There are two telecommunications providers: Setar, a government based company and Digicel, which is privately owned.
690	Setar is the provider of services such as Internet, video conference, GSM wireless tech and lanetar id lines and offer the latest in telecom services.
690	Digicel is the Setar competitor in wireless technology using the GSM platform.
690	Places of interest  Arubans
691	The Articles of Confederation, formally the Articles of Confederation and Perpetual Union, was an agreement among the 13 founding states that established the United States of America as a confederation of sovereign states and served as its first constitution.
691	Its drafting by the Continental Congress began in mid-1776, and an approved version was sent to the states for ratification in late 1777.
691	The formal ratification by all 13 states was completed in early 1781.
691	Even when not yet ratified, the Articles provided domestic and international legitimacy for the Continental Congress to direct the American Revolutionary War, conduct diplomacy with Europe and deal with territorial issues and Indian relations.
691	Nevertheless, the weak government created by the Articles became a matter of concern for key nationalists.
691	On March 4, 1789, the Articles were replaced with the U.S.
691	Constitution.
691	The new Constitution provided for a much stronger national government with a chief executive (the president), courts, and taxing powers.
691	Background and context The political push to increase cooperation among the then-loyal colonies began with the Albany Congress in 1754 and Benjamin Franklin's proposed intercolonial collaboration to help solve mutual local problems themselves; the Articles of Confederation would bear some resemblance to it.
691	Over the next two decades, some of the basic concepts it addressed would strengthen and others would weaken, particularly the degree of deserved loyalty to the crown.
691	With civil disobedience resulting in coercive and intolerable acts, and armed conflict resulting in dissidents being proclaimed rebels and outside the King's protection, any loyalty remaining shifted toward independence and how to achieve it.
691	In 1775, with events outpacing communications, the Second Continental Congress began acting as the provisional government to run the American Revolutionary War and gain the colonies their collective independence.
691	It was an era of constitution writing—most states were busy at the task—and leaders felt the new nation must have a written constitution, even though other nations did not.
691	During the war, Congress exercised an unprecedented level of political, diplomatic, military and economic authority.
691	It adopted trade restrictions, established and maintained an army, issued fiat money, created a military code and negotiated with foreign governments.
691	To trle= The Creation of ansform themselves from outlaws into a legitimate nation,  the colonists needed international recognition for their cause and foreign allies to support it.
691	In early 1776, Thomas Paine argued in the closing pages of the first edition of Common Sense that the “custom of nations” demanded a formal declaration of American independence if any European power were to mediate a peace between the Americans and Great Britain.
691	The monarchies of France and Spain in particular could not be expected to aid those they considered rebels against another legitimate monarch.
691	Foreign courts needed to have American grievances laid before them persuasively in a “manifesto” which could also reassure them that the Americans would be reliable trading partners.
691	Without such a declaration, Paine concluded, “[t]he custom of all courts is against us, and will be so, until, by an independence, we take rank with other nations.” Beyond improving their existing association, the records of the Second Continental Congress show that the need for a declaration of independence was intimately linked with the demands of international relations.
691	On June 7, 1776, Richard Henry Lee introduced a resolution before the Continental Congress declaring the colonies independent; at the same time he also urged Congress to resolve “to take the most effectual measures for forming foreign Alliances” and to prepare a plan of confederation for the newly independent states.
691	Congress then created three overlapping committees to draft the Declaration, a Model Treaty, and the Articles of Confederation.
691	The Declaration announced the states' entry into the international system; the model treaty was designed to establish amity and commerce with other states; and the Articles of Confederation, which established “a firm league” among the thirteen free and independent states, constituted an international agreement to set up central institutions for the conduct of vital domestic and foreign affairs.
691	Drafting On June 12, 1776, a day after appointing a committee to prepare a draft of the Declaration of Independence, the Second Continental Congress resolved to appoint a committee of 13 to prepare a draft of a constitution for a union of the states.
691	The committee  met repeatedly, and chairman John Dickinson presented their results to the Congress on July 12, 1776.
691	There were long debates on such issues as sovereignty, the exact powers to be given the confederate government, whether to have a judiciary, and voting procedures.
691	The final draft of the Articles was prepared in the summer of 1777 and the Second Continental Congress approved them for ratification by the individual states on November 15, 1777, after a year of debate.
691	In practice, the Articles were in use beginning in 1777;  the final draft of the Articles served as the de facto system of government used by the Congress ("the United States in Congress assembled") until it became de jure by final ratification on March 1, 1781; at which point Congress became the Congress of the Confederation.
691	Under the Articles, the states retained sovereignty over all governmental functions not specifically relinquished to the national government.
691	The individual articles set the rules for current and future operations of the United States government.
691	It was made capable of making war and peace, negotiating diplomatic and commercial agreements with foreign countries, and deciding disputes between the states, including their additional and contested western territories.
691	Article XIII stipulated that "their provisions shall be inviolably observed by every state" and "the Union shall be perpetual".
691	John Dickinson and Benjamin Franklin's  handwritten drafts of the Articles of Confederation are housed at the National Archives in Washington, DC.
691	Operation The Articles were created by delegates from the states in the Second Continental Congress out of a need to have "a plan of confederacy for securing the freedom, sovereignty, and independence of the United States."
691	After the war, nationalists, especially those who had been active in the Continental Army, complained that the Articles were too weak for an effective government.
691	There were no president, no executive agencies, no judiciary and no tax base.
691	The absence of a tax base meant that there was no way to pay off state and national debts from the war years except by requesting money from the states, which seldom arrived.
691	In 1788, with the approval of Congress, the Articles were replaced by the United States Constitution and the new government began operations in 1789.
691	Ratification Congress began to move for ratification of the Articles of Confederation in 1777: "Permit us, then, earnestly to recommend these articles to the immediate and dispassionate attention of the legislatures of the respective states.
691	Let them be candidly reviewed under a sense of the difficulty of combining in one system the various sentiments and interests of a continent divided into so many sovereign and independent communities, under a conviction of the absolute necessity of uniting all our councils and all our strength, to maintain and defend our common liberties...
691	The document could not become officially effective until it was ratified by all 13 colonies.
691	The first state to ratify was Virginia on December 16, 1777.
691	Dates of ratification are given as follows in American Constitutions: The ratification process dragged on for several years, stalled by the refusal of some states to rescind their claims to land in the West.
691	Maryland was the last holdout; it refused to go along until Virginia and New York agreed to cede their claims in the Ohio River Valley.
691	It took a little over three years for all states to ratify.
691	The Articles provided for a blanket acceptance of Province of Quebec (referred to as "Canada" in the Articles) into the United States if it chose to do so.
691	It did not, and the subsequent Constitution carried no such special provision of admission.
691	Article summaries Even though the Articles of Confederation and the Constitution were established by many of the same people, the two documents are very different.
691	The original five-page Articles contained a preamble, 13 articles, a conclusion, and a signatory section.
691	The preamble states that the signatory states "agree to certain articles of Confederation and perpetual Union" between the 13 states.
691	The following list contains short summaries of each of the 13 articles.
691	Establishes the name of the confederation with these words: "The Style of this confederacy shall be 'The United States of America.'" # Asserts the sovereignty of each state, except for the specific powers delegated to the confederation government, i.e.
691	"Each state retains its sovereignty, freedom, and independence, and every power, jurisdiction, and right, which is not by this Confederation expressly delegated."
691	Not being sovereign, it does not call the United States of America a "nation" or "government," but instead says, "The said States hereby severally enter into a firm league of friendship with each other, for their common defense, the security of their liberties, and their mutual and general welfare, binding themselves to assist each other, against all force offered to, or attacks made upon them, or any of them, on account of religion, sovereignty, trade, or any other pretense whatever."
691	But to instill a national feeling, "[t]he better to secure and perpetuate mutual friendship and intercourse among the people of the different States in this union," it establishes equal treatment and freedom of movement for the free inhabitants of each state to pass unhindered between the states, excluding "paupers, vagabonds, and fugitives from justice."
691	All these people are entitled to equal rights established by the state into which he travels.
691	If a crime is committed in one state and the perpetrator flees to another state, he will be extradited to and tried in the state in which the crime was committed.
691	Allocates one vote in the Congress of the Confederation (the "United States in Congress Assembled") to each state, which is entitled to a delegation of between two and seven members.
691	Members of Congress are appointed by state legislatures.
691	Also, individuals may not serve more than three out of any six years.
691	Only the central government is allowed to conduct foreign political or commercial relations and to declare war.
691	No state or official may accept foreign gifts or titles, and granting any title of nobility is forbidden to all.
691	States are restrained from forming sub-national groups.
691	No state may tax or interfere with treaty stipulations already proposed.
691	No state may engage in war, without permission of Congress, unless invaded or that is imminent on the frontier; no state may maintain a peace-time standing army or navy, unless infested by pirates, but every State is required to keep ready, a well-regulated (meaning well trained), disciplined, and equipped militia, with sufficient public stores of a due number of field pieces, tents, a proper quantity of arms, ammunition and camp equipage.
691	Whenever an army is raised for common defense, colonels and military ranks below colonel will be named by the state legislatures.
691	Expenditures by the United States of America will be paid by funds raised by state legislatures, and apportioned to the states based on the real property values of each.
691	Defines the sole and exclusive right and power of the United States in Congress assembled to determine peace and war; to exchange ambassadors; to enter into treaties and alliances, with some provisos; to establish rules for deciding all cases of captures or prizes on land or water; to grant letters of marque and reprisal (documents authorizing privateers) in times of peace; to appoint courts for the trial of pirates and crimes committed on the high seas; to establish courts for appeals in all cases of captures, but no member of Congress may be appointed a judge; to set weights and measures (including coins), and for Congress to serve as a final court for disputes between states.
691	"The Committee of the States, or any nine of them, shall be authorized to execute, in the recess of Congress, such of the powers of Congress as the United States in Congress assembled, by the consent of the nine States, shall from time to time think expedient to vest them with; provided that no power be delegated to the said Committee, for the exercise of which, by the Articles of Confederation, the voice of nine States in the Congress of the United States assembled be requisite."
691	If "Canada" (as the British-held Province of Quebec was also known) accedes to this confederation, it will be admitted.
691	Reaffirms that the Confederation accepts war debt incurred by Congress befederation}}&ltore the existence of the Articles.
691	Declares that the Articles are perpetual, and can only be altered by approval of Congress with ratification by all the state legislatures.
691	While still at war with Britain, the Founding Fathers were divided between those seeking a powerful, centralized national government (the "federalists"), and those seeking a loosely structured one (the "anti federalists").
691	Jealously guarding their new independence, members of the Continental Congress arrived at a compromise solution dividing sovereignty between the states and the central government, with a unicameral legislature that protected the liberty of the individual states.
691	While calling on Congress to regulate military and monetary affairs, for example, the Articles of Confederation provided no mechanism with which to compel the States to comply with requests for either troops or revenue.
691	At times, this left the military without adequate funding, supplies or even food.
691	The end of the Revolutionary War The Treaty of Paris (1783), which ended hostilities with Great Britain, languished in Congress for months because several state representatives failed to attend sessions of the national legislature to ratify it.
691	Yet Congress had no power to enforce attendance.
691	In September 1783, George Washington complained that Congress was paralyzed.
691	Many revolutionaries had gone to their respective home countries after the war, and local government and self-rule seemed quite satisfactory.
691	Function The Army The Articles supported the Congressional direction of the Continental Army, and allowed the states to present a unified front when dealing with the European powers.
691	As a tool to build a centralized war-making government, they were largely a failure: Historian Bruce Chadwick wrote: The Continental Congress, before the Articles were approved, had promised soldiers a pension of half pay for life.
691	However Congress had no power to compel the states to fund this obligation, and as the war wound down after the victory at Yorktown the sense of urgency to support the military was no longer a factor.
691	No progress was made in Congress during the winter of 1783–84.
691	General Henry Knox, who would later become the first Secretary of War under the Constitution, blamed the weaknesses of the Articles for the inability of the government to fund the army.
691	The army had long been supportive of a strong union.
691	Knox wrote: As Congress failed to act on the petitions, Knox wrote to Gouverneur Morris, four years before the Philadelphia Convention was convened, "As the present Constitution is so defective, why do not you great men call the people together and tell them so; that is, to have a convention of the States to form a better Constitution."
691	Once the war had been won, the Continental Army was largely disbanded.
691	A very small national force was maintained to man the frontier forts and to protect against Native American attacks.
691	Meanwhile, each of the states had an army (or militia), and 11 of them had Navies.
691	The wartime promises of bounties and land grants to be paid for service were not being met.
691	In 1783, George Washington defused the Newburgh conspiracy, but riots by unpaid Pennsylvania veterans forced Congress to leave Philadelphia temporarily.
691	The Congress from time to time during the Revolutionary War requisitioned troops from the states.
691	Any contributions were voluntary, and in the debates of 1788 the Federalists (who supported the proposed new Constitution) claimed that state politicians acted unilaterally, and contributed when the Continental army protected their state's interests.
691	The Anti-Federalists claimed that state politicians understood their duty to the Union and contributed to advance its needs.
691	Dougherty (2009) concludes that generally the States' behavior validated the Federalist analysis.
691	This helps explain why the Articles of Confederation needed reforms.
691	Foreign policy Even after peace had been achieved in 1783, the weakness of the Confederation government frustrated the ability of the government to conduct foreign policy.
691	In 1789, Thomas Jefferson, concerned over the failure to fund an American naval force to confront the Barbary pirates, wrote to James Monroe, "It will be said there is no money in the treasury.
691	There never will be money in the treasury till the Confederacy shows its teeth.
691	The states must see the rod.” Furthermore, the Jay–Gardoqui Treaty with Spain in 1789 also showed weakness in foreign policy.
691	In this treaty — which was never ratified due to its immense unpopularity — the United States was to give up rights to use the Mississippi River for 25 years, which would have economically strangled the settlers west of the Appalachian Mountains.
691	Finally, due to the Confederation's military weakness, it could not compel the British army to leave frontier forts which were on American soil — forts which, in 1783, the British promised to leave, but which they delayed leaving pending U.S.
691	Loyalists and allowing them to seek compensation.
691	This incomplete British implementation of the Treaty of Paris (1783) was superseded by the implementation of Jay's Treaty in 1795 under the new U.S.
691	Constitution.
691	Taxatied by the implementation of Jaon and commerce Under the Articles of Confederation, the central government's power was kept quite limited.
691	The Confederation Congress could make decisions, but lacked enforcement powers.
691	Implementation of most decisions, including modifications to the Articles, required unanimous approval of all thirteen state legislatures.
691	Congress was denied any powers of taxation: it could only request money from the states.
691	The states often failed to meet these requests in full, leaving both Congress and the Continental Army chronically short of money.
691	As more money was printed by Congress, the continental dollars depreciated.
691	In 1779, George Washington wrote to John Jay, who was serving as the president of the Continental Congress, "that a wagon load of money will scarcely purchase a wagon load of provisions."
691	Mr.
691	Jay and the Congress responded in May by requesting $45 million from the States.
691	In an appeal to the States to comply, Jay wrote that the taxes were "the price of liberty, the peace, and the safety of yourselves and posterity."
691	He argued that Americans should avoid having it said "that America had no sooner become independent than she became insolvent" or that "her infant glories and growing fame were obscured and tarnished by broken contracts and violated faith."
691	The States did not respond with any of the money requested from them.
691	Congress had also been denied the power to regulate either foreign trade or interstate commerce and, as a result, all of the States maintained control over their own trade policies.
691	The states and the Confederation Congress both incurred large debts during the Revolutionary War, and how to repay those debts became a major issue of debate following the War.
691	Some States paid off their war debts and others did not.
691	Federal assumption of the states' war debts became a major issue in the deliberations of the Constitutional Convention.
691	Accomplishments of the Confederation Nevertheless, the Confederation Congress did take two actions with long lasting impact.
691	The Land Ordinance of 1785 and Northwest Ordinance created territorial government, set up protocols for the admission of new states, the division of land into useful units, and set aside land in each township for public use.
691	This system represented a sharp break from imperial colonization, as in Europe, and provided the basis for the rest of American continental expansion through the 19th Century.
691	The Land Ordinance of 1785 established both the general practices of land surveying in the west and northwest and the land ownership provisions used throughout the later westward expansion beyond the Mississippi River.
691	Frontier lands were surveyed into the now-familiar squares of land called the township (36 square miles), the section (one square mile), and the quarter section (160 acres).
691	This system was carried forward to most of the States west of the Mississippi (excluding areas of Texas and California that had already been surveyed and divided up by the Spanish Empire).
691	Then, when the Homestead Act was enacted in 1867, the quarter section became the basic unit of land that was granted to new settler-farmers.
691	The Northwest Ordinance of 1787 noted the agreement of the original states to give up northwestern land claims, organized the Northwest Territory and thus cleared the way for the entry of five new states, and part of a sixth to the Union.
691	To be specific, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, Pennsylvania, and Virginia gave up all of their claims to land north of the Ohio River and west of the (present) western border of Pennsylvania.
691	Over several decades a number of new states were formed from this land: Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, and Wisconsin, and the part of Minnesota east of the Mississippi River.
691	The Northwest Ordinance of 1787 also made great advances in the abolition of slavery.
691	New states admitted to the union in said territory would never be slave states.
691	America under the articles The peace treaty left the United States independent and at peace but with an unsettled governmental structure.
691	The Articles envisioned a permanent confederation, but granted to the Congress—the only federal institution—little power to finance itself or to ensure that its resolutions were enforced.
691	There was no president and no national court.
691	Although historians generally agree that the Articles were too weak to hold the fast-growing nation together, they do give credit to the settlement of the western issue, as the states voluntarily turned over their lands to national control.
691	By 1783, with the end of the British blockade, the new nation was regaining its prosperity.
691	However, trade opportunities were restricted by the mercantilism of the British and French empires.
691	The ports of the British West Indies were closed to all staple products which were not carried in British ships.
691	France and Spain established similar policies.
691	Simultaneously, new manufacturers faced sharp competition from British products which were suddenly available again.
691	Political unrest in several states and efforts by debtors to use popular government to erase their debts increased the anxiety of the political and economic elites which had led the Revolution.
691	The apparent inability of the Congress to redeem the public obligations (debts) incurred during the war, or to become a forum for productive cooperation among the states to encourage commerce and economic development, only aggravated a gloomy situation.
691	In 1786–87, Shays' Rebellion, an uprising of farmers in western Massachusetts against the state court system, threatened the stability of state government.
691	The Continental Congress printed paper money which was so depreciated that it ceased to pass as currency, spawning the expression "not worth a continental".
691	Congress could not levy taxes and could only make requisitions upon the States.
691	Less than a million and a half dollars came into the treasury between 1781 and 1784, although the governors had been asked for two million in 1783 alone.
691	When Adams went to London in 1785 as the first representative of the United States, he found it impossible to secure a treaty for unrestricted commerce.
691	Demands were made for favors and there was no assurance that individual states would agree to a treaty.
691	Adams stated it was necessary for the States to confer the power of passing navigation laws to Congress, or that the States themselves pass retaliatory acts against Great Britain.
691	Congress had already requested and failed to get power over navigation laws.
691	Meanwhile, each State acted individually against Great Britain to little effect.
691	When other New England states closed their ports to British shipping, Connecticut hastened to profit by opening its ports.
691	By 1787 Congress was unable to protitle= John Adams: A Life |yeatect manufacturing and shipping.
691	State legislatures were unable or unwilling to resist attacks upon private contracts and public credit.
691	Land speculators expected no rise in values when the government could not defend its borders nor protect its frontier population.
691	The idea of a convention to revise the Articles of Confederation grew in favor.
691	Alexander Hamilton realized while serving as Washington's top aide that a strong central government was necessary to avoid foreign intervention and allay the frustrations due to an ineffectual Congress.
691	Hamilton led a group of like-minded nationalists, won Washington's endorsement, and convened the Annapolis Convention in 1786 to petition Congress to call a constitutional convention to meet in Philadelphia to remedy the long-term crisis.
691	Signatures The Second Continental Congress approved the Articles for distribution to the states on November 15, 1777.
691	A copy was made for each state and one was kept by the Congress.
691	The copies sent to the states for ratification were unsigned, and a cover letter had only the signatures of Henry Laurens and Charles Thomson, who were the President and Secretary to the Congress.
691	The Articles, however, were unsigned, and the date was blank.
691	Congress began the signing process by examining their copy of the Articles on June 27, 1778.
691	They ordered a final copy prepared (the one in the National Archives), and that delegates should inform the secretary of their authority for ratification.
691	On July 9, 1778, the prepared copy was ready.
691	They dated it, and began to sign.
691	They also requested each of the remaining states to notify its delegation when ratification was completed.
691	On that date, delegates present from New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia and South Carolina signed the Articles to indicate that their states had ratified.
691	New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland could not, since their states had not ratified.
691	North Carolina and Georgia also didn't sign that day, since their delegations were absent.
691	After the first signing, some delegates signed at the next meeting they attended.
691	For example, John Wentworth of New Hampshire added his name on August 8.
691	John Penn was the first of North Carolina's delegates to arrive (on July 10), and the delegation signed the Articles on July 21, 1778.
691	The other states had to wait until they ratified the Articles and notified their Congressional delegation.
691	Georgia signed on July 24, New Jersey on November 26, and Delaware on February 12, 1779.
691	Maryland refused to ratify the Articles until every state had ceded its western land claims.
691	On February 2, 1781, the much-awaited decision was taken by the Maryland General Assembly in Annapolis.
691	As the last piece of business during the afternoon Session, "among engrossed Bills" was "signed and sealed by Governor Thomas Sim Lee in the Senate Chamber, in the presence of the members of both Houses...
691	Act to empower the delegates of this state in Congress to subscribe and ratify the articles of confederation" and perpetual union among the states.
691	The Senate then adjourned "to the first Monday in August next."
691	The decision of Maryland to ratify the Articles was reported to the Continental Congress on February 12.
691	The formal signing of the Articles by the Maryland delegates took place in Philadelphia at noon time on March 1, 1781 and was celebrated in the afternoon.
691	With these events, the Articles entered into force and the United States came into being as a united, sovereign and national state.
691	Congress had debated the Articles for over a year and a half, and the ratification process had taken nearly three and a half years.
691	Many participants in the original debates were no longer delegates, and some of the signers had only recently arrived.
691	The Articles of Confederation and Perpetual Union were signed by a group of men who were never present in the Congress at the same time.
691	Signers The signers and the states they represented were: Connecticut * Roger Sherman * Samuel Huntington * Oliver Wolcott * Titus Hosmer * Andrew Adams Delaware * Thomas McKean * John Dickinson * Nicholas Van Dyke Georgia * John Walton * Edward Telfair * Edward Langworthy Maryland * John Hanson * Daniel Carroll Massachusetts Bay * John Hancock * Samuel Adams * Elbridge Gerry * Francis Dana * James Lovell * Samuel Holten New Hampshire * Josiah Bartlett * John Wentworth Jr.
691	New Jersey * John Witherspoon * Nathaniel Scudder New York * James Duane * Francis Lewis * William Duer * Gouverneur Morris North Carolina * John Penn * Cornelius Harnett * John Williams Pennsylvania * Robert Morris * Daniel Roberdeau * Jonathan Bayard Smith * William Clingan * Joseph Reed Rhode Island and Providence Plantations * William Ellery * Henry Marchant * John Collins South Carolina * Henry Laurens * William Henry Drayton * John Mathews * Richard Hutson * Thomas Heyward Jr.
691	Virginia * Richard Henry Lee * John Banister * Thomas Adams * John Harvie * Francis Lightfoot Lee Roger Sherman (Connecticut) was the only person to sign all four great state papers of the United States: the Continental Association, the United States Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation and the United States Constitution.
691	Robert Morris (Pennsylvania) was the only person besides Sherman to sign three of the great state papers of the United States: the United States Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation and the United States Constitution.
691	John Dickinson (Delaware), Daniel Carroll (Maryland) and Gouverneur Morris (New York), along with Sherman and Robert Morris, were the only five people to sign both the Articles of Confederation and the United States Constitution (Gouverneur Morris represented Pennsylvania when signing the Constitution).
691	Presidents of the Congress The following list is of those who led the Congress of the Confederation under the Articles of Confederation as the Presidents of the United States in Congress Assembled.
691	Under the Articles, the president was the presiding officer of Congress,es in Congre chaired the Committee of the States when Congress was in recess, and performed other administrative functions.
691	He was not, however, an executive in the way the successor President of the United States is a chief executive, since all of the functions he executed were under the direct control of Congress.
691	For a full list of Presidents of the Congress Assembled and Presidents under the two Continental Congresses before the Articles, see President of the Continental Congress.
691	Gallery Revision and replacement On January 21, 1786, the Virginia Legislature, following James Madison's recommendation, invited all the states to send delegates to Annapolis, Maryland to discuss ways to reduce interstate conflict.
691	At what came to be known as the Annapolis Convention, the few state delegates in attendance endorsed a motion that called for all states to meet in Philadelphia in May 1787 to discuss ways to improve the Articles of Confederation in a "Grand Convention."
691	Although the states' representatives to the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia were only authorized to amend the Articles, the representatives held secret, closed-door sessions and wrote a new constitution.
691	The new Constitution gave much more power to the central government, but characterization of the result is disputed.
691	The general goal of the authors was to get close to a republic as defined by the philosophers of the Age of Enlightenment, while trying to address the many difficulties of the interstate relationships.
691	Historian Forrest McDonald, using the ideas of James Madison from Federalist 39, describes the change this way: In May 1786, Charles Pinckney of South Carolina proposed that Congress revise the Articles of Confederation.
691	Recommended changes included granting Congress power over foreign and domestic commerce, and providing means for Congress to collect money from state treasuries.
691	Unanimous approval was necessary to make the alterations, however, and Congress failed to reach a consensus.
691	The weakness of the Articles in establishing an effective unifying government was underscored by the threat of internal conflict both within and between the states, especially after Shays' Rebellion threatened to topple the state government of Massachusetts.
691	Historian Ralph Ketcham comments on the opinions of Patrick Henry, George Mason, and other antifederalists who were not so eager to give up the local autonomy won by the revolution: Historians have given many reasons for the perceived need to replace the articles in 1787.
691	Jillson and Wilson (1994) point to the financial weakness as well as the norms, rules and institutional structures of the Congress, and the propensity to divide along sectional lines.
691	Rakove (1988) identifies several factors that explain the collapse of the Confederation.
691	The lack of compulsory direct taxation power was objectionable to those wanting a strong centralized state or expecting to benefit from such power.
691	It could not collect customs after the war because tariffs were vetoed by Rhode Island.
691	Rakove concludes that their failure to implement national measures "stemmed not from a heady sense of independence but rather from the enormous difficulties that all the states encountered in collecting taxes, mustering men, and gathering supplies from a war-weary populace."
691	The second group of factors Rakove identified derived from the substantive nature of the problems the Continental Congress confronted after 1783, especially the inability to create a strong foreign policy.
691	Finally, the Confederation's lack of coercive power reduced the likelihood for profit to be made by political means, thus potential rulers were uninspired to seek power.
691	When the war ended in 1783, certain special interests had incentives to create a new "merchant state," much like the British state people had rebelled against.
691	In particular, holders of war scrip and land speculators wanted a central government to pay off scrip at face value and to legalize western land holdings with disputed claims.
691	Also, manufacturers wanted a high tariff as a barrier to foreign goods, but competition among states made this impossible without a central government.
691	Political scientist David C.
691	Hendrickson writes that two prominent political leaders in the Confederation, John Jay of New York and Thomas Burke of North Carolina believed that "the authority of the congress rested on the prior acts of the several states, to which the states gave their voluntary consent, and until those obligations were fulfilled, neither nullification of the authority of congress, exercising its due powers, nor secession from the compact itself was consistent with the terms of their original pledges."
691	Closing down According to their own terms for modification (Article XIII), the Articles would still have been in effect until 1790, the year in which the last of the 13 states ratified the new Constitution.
691	The Congress under the Articleor SYNTH, thiss continued to sit until November 1788, overseeing the adoption of the new Constitution by the states, and setting elections.
691	By that date, 11 of the 13 states had ratified the new Constitution.
691	On September 13, 1788, it published an announcement that the new Constitution had been ratified by the necessary nine states, set the first Wednesday in February 1789 for the presidential electors to meet and select a new president, and set the first Wednesday of March 1789 as the day the new government would take over and the government under the Articles of Confederation would come to an end.
691	On that same September 13, it determined that New York would remain the national capital.
696	Aa River may refer to: * Aa River (France), a river in northern France * Aa River (Meuse), a river in North Brabant, Netherlands * Aa of Weerijs, a river in North Brabant, Netherlands * Drentsche Aa, a river in Drenthe and Groningen, Netherlands * Aabach (Greifensee), or Ustermer Aa, a river in Switzerland * Sarner Aa, a tributary of Lake Lucerne in Switzerland * Aabach (Afte), formerly called the Große Aa, a river in Germany *Aa (Möhne), a river in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany *Aa (Nethe), a river in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany *Aa (Werre), a river in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany * Aa, a river in Antwerp, Belgium which joins the Nete River * Engelberger Aa, a river in Obwalden and Nidwalden, Switzerland * Große Aa, a river in Lower Saxony, Germany * Münstersche Aa, a river in Germany, one of several Westphalian rivers called Aa * Sarner Aa, a river in Obwalden, Switzerland Former names  * Gauja, a river in Latvia, formerly known as Livländische Aa * Lielupe, a river in Latvia, formerly known as Kurländische Aa
698	The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest of the world's oceanic divisions.
698	With a total area of about , it covers approximately 20 percent of the Earth's surface and about 29 percent of its water surface area.
698	The first part of its name refers to Atlas of Greek mythology, making the Atlantic the "Sea of Atlas".
698	The oldest known mention of "Atlantic" is in The Histories of Herodotus around 450 BC (Hdt.
698	Atlantis thalassa (Greek: Ἀτλαντὶς θάλασσα; English: Sea of Atlas).
698	The term Ethiopic Ocean, derived from Ethiopia, was applied to the southern Atlantic as late as the mid-19th century.
698	Before Europeans discovered other oceans, the term "ocean" itself was synonymous with the waters beyond the Strait of Gibraltar that we now know as the Atlantic.
698	The early Greeks believed this ocean to be a gigantic river encircling the world.
698	The Atlantic Ocean occupies an elongated, S-shaped basin extending longitudinally between Eurasia and Africa to the east, and the Americas to the west.
698	As one component of the interconnected global ocean, it is connected in the north to the Arctic Ocean (which is sometimes considered  a sea of the Atlantic), to the Pacific Ocean in the southwest, the Indian Ocean in the southeast, and the Southern Ocean in the south.
698	Other definitions describe the Atlantic as extending southward to Antarctica.) The equator subdivides it into the North Atlantic Ocean and South Atlantic Ocean.
698	Geography The Atlantic Ocean is bounded on the west by North and South America.
698	It connects to the Arctic Ocean through the Denmark Strait, Greenland Sea, Norwegian Sea and Barents Sea.
698	To the east, the boundaries of the ocean proper are Europe; the Strait of Gibraltar (where it connects with the Mediterranean Sea–one of its marginal seas–and, in turn, the Black Sea, both of which also touch upon Asia) and Africa.
698	In the southeast, the Atlantic merges into the Indian Ocean.
698	The 20° East meridian, running south from Cape Agulhas to Antarctica defines its border.
698	Some authorities show it extending south to Antarctica, while others show it bounded at the 60° parallel by the Southern Ocean.
698	In the southwest, the Drake Passage connects it to the Pacific Ocean.
698	The man-made Panama Canal links the Atlantic and Pacific.
698	Besides those mentioned, other large bodies of water adjacent to the Atlantic are the Caribbean Sea; the Gulf of Mexico; Hudson Bay; the Arctic Ocean; the Mediterranean Sea; the North Sea; the Baltic Sea and the Celtic Sea.
698	Covering approximately 22% of Earth's surface, the Atlantic is second in size to the Pacific.
698	With its adjacent seas, it occupies an area of about 106400000 km2; without them, it has an area of 82400000 km2.
698	The land that drains into the Atlantic covers four times that of either the Pacific or Indian oceans.
698	The volume of the Atlantic with its adjacent seas is 354,700,000 cubic kilometers (85,100,000 cu mi) and without them 323,600,000 cubic kilometres (77,640,000 cu mi).
698	The average depth of the Atlantic, with its adjacent seas, is 3339 m; without them it is 3926 m.
698	The greatest depth, Milwaukee Deep with 8380 m, is in the Puerto Rico Trench.
698	The Atlantic's width varies from 1538 nmi between Brazil and Sierra Leone to over 3450 nmi in the south.
698	Cultural significance Transatlantic travel played a major role in the expansion of Western civilization into the Americas.
698	It is the Atlantic that separates the "Old World" from the "New World".
698	In modern times, some idioms refer to the ocean in a humorously diminutive way as the Pond, describing both the geographical and cultural divide between North America and Europe, in particular between the English-speaking nations of both continents.
698	Many British people refer to the United States and Canada as "across the pond", and vice versa.
698	The "Black Atlantic" refers to the role of this ocean in shaping black people's history, not least in diasporas.
698	Irish migration to the US is meant when the term "The Green Atlantic" is used.
698	The "Red Atlantic" is a relatively new term that refers to seafarers as proletarians and revolutionaries who historically resisted exploitation at sea and forged a new multicultural and polyglot Atlantic working-class.
698	Ocean bottom The principal feature of the bathymetry (bottom topography) is a submarine mountain range called the Mid-Atlantic Ridge.
698	It extends from Iceland in the north to approximately 58° South latitude, reaching a maximum width of about 860 nmi.
698	A great rift valley also extends along the ridge over most of its length.
698	The depth of water at the apex of the ridge is less than 2700 m in most places, while the bottom of the ridge is three times as deep.
698	Several peaks rise above the water and form islands.
698	The South Atlantic Ocean has an additional submarine ridge, the Walvis Ridge.
698	The Mid-Atlantic Ridge separates the Atlantic Ocean into two large troughs with depths from 3700 -.
698	Transverse ridges running between the continents and the Mid-Atlantic Ridge divide the ocean floor into numerous basins.
698	Some of the larger basins are the Blake, Guiana, North American, Cape Verde, and Canaries basins in the North Atlantic.
698	The largest South Atlantic basins are the Angola, Cape, Argentina, and Brazil basins.
698	The deep ocean floor is thought to be fairly flat with occasional deeps, abyssal plains, trenches, seamounts, basins, plateaus, canyons, and some guyots.
698	Various shelves along the margins of the continents constitute about 11% of the bottom topography with few deep channels cut across the continental rise.
698	Ocean floor trenches and seamounts: * Puerto Rico Trench, in the North Atlantic, is the deepest trench at 8605 m * Laurentian Abyss is found off the eastern coast of Canada * South Sandwich Trench reaches a depth of 8428 m * Romanche Trench is located near the equator and reaches a depth of about 7454 m.
698	Ocean sediments are composed of: * Terrigenous deposits with land origins, consisting of sand, mud, and rock particles formed by erosion, weathering, and volcanic activity on land washed to sea.
698	These materials are found mostly on the continental shelves and are thickest near large river mouths or off desert coasts.
698	Pelagic deposits, which contain the remains of organisms that sink to the ocean floor, include red clays and Globigerina, pteropod, and siliceous oozes.
698	Covering most of the ocean floor and ranging in thickness from 60 - they are thickest in the convergence belts, notably at the Hamilton Ridge and in upwelling zones.
698	Authigenic deposits consist of such materials as manganese nodules.
698	They occur where sedimentation proceeds slowly or where currents sort the deposits, such as in the Hewett Curve.
698	Water characteristics On average, the Atlantic is the saltiest major ocean; surface water salinity in the open ocean ranges from 33 to 37 parts per thousand (3.3 – 3.7%) by mass and varies with latitude and season.
698	Evaporation, precipitation, river inflow and sea ice melting influence surface salinity values.
698	Although the lowest salinity values are just north of the equator (because of heavy tropical rainfall), in general the lowest values are in the high latitudes and along coasts where large rivers enter.
698	Maximum salinity values occur at about 25° north and south, in subtropica occur at aboul regions with low rainfall and high evaporation.
698	Surface water temperatures, which vary with latitude, current systems, and season and reflect the latitudinal distribution of solar energy, range from below .
698	Maximum temperatures occur north of the equator, and minimum values are found in the polar regions.
698	In the middle latitudes, the area of maximum temperature variations, values may vary by 7–8 °C (12–15°F).
698	The Atlantic Ocean consists of four major water masses.
698	The North and South Atlantic central waters make up the surface.
698	The sub-Antarctic intermediate water extends to depths of 1000 m.
698	The North Atlantic Deep Water reaches depths of as much as 4000 m.
698	The Antarctic Bottom Water occupies ocean basins at depths greater than 4,000 metres.
698	Within the North Atlantic, ocean currents isolate the Sargasso Sea, a large elongated body of water, with above average salinity.
698	The Sargasso Sea contains large amounts of seaweed and is also the spawning ground for both the European eel and the American eel.
698	The Coriolis effect circulates North Atlantic water in a clockwise direction, whereas South Atlantic water circulates counter-clockwise.
698	The south tides in the Atlantic Ocean are semi-diurnal; that is, two high tides occur during each 24 lunar hours.
698	In latitudes above 40° North some east-west oscillation occurs.
698	Climate Climate is influenced by the temperatures of the surface waters and water currents as well as winds.
698	Because of the ocean's great capacity to store and release heat, maritime climates are more moderate and have less extreme seasonal variations than inland climates.
698	Precipitation can be approximated from coastal weather data and air temperature from water temperatures.
698	The oceans are the major source of the atmospheric moisture that is obtained through evaporation.
698	Climatic zones vary with latitude; the warmest zones stretch across the Atlantic north of the equator.
698	The coldest zones are in high latitudes, with the coldest regions corresponding to the areas covered by sea ice.
698	Ocean currents influence climate by transporting warm and cold waters to other regions.
698	The winds that are cooled or warmed when blowing over these currents influence adjacent land areas.
698	The Gulf Stream and its northern extension towards Europe, the North Atlantic Drift, for example, warms the atmosphere of the British Isles and north-western Europe and influences weather and climate as far south as the northern Mediterranean.
698	The cold water currents contribute to heavy fog off the coast of eastern Canada (the Grand Banks of Newfoundland area) and Africa's north-western coast.
698	In general, winds transport moisture and air over land areas.
698	Hurricanes develop in the southern part of the North Atlantic Ocean.
698	More  local   particular weather examples could be found in examples such as the; Azores High, Benguela Current, Nor'easter.
698	History The Atlantic Ocean appears to be the second youngest of the five oceans.
698	It did not exist prior to 130 million years ago, when the continents that formed from the breakup of the ancestral super continent Pangaea were drifting apart from seafloor spreading.
698	The Atlantic has been extensively explored since the earliest settlements along its shores.
698	The Vikings, the Portuguese, and the Spaniards were the most famous among early explorers.
698	After Columbus, European exploration rapidly accelerated, and many new trade routes were established.
698	As a result, the Atlantic became and remains the major artery between Europe and the Americas (known as transatlantic trade).
