701	Although the country's economy has developed very significantly since achieving political stability in 2002, mainly thanks to the fast-rising earnings of the oil sector, Angola faces huge social and economic problems.
701	These are in part a result of the almost continual state of conflict from 1961 onwards, although the highest level of destruction and socio-economic damage took place after the 1975 independence, during the long years of civil war.
701	However, high poverty rates and blatant social inequality are chiefly the outcome of a combination of a persistent political authoritarianism, of "neo-patrimonial" practices at all levels of the political, administrative, military, and economic apparatuses, and of a pervasive corruption.
701	The main beneficiary of this situation is a social segment constituted since 1975, but mainly during the last decades, around the political, administrative, economic, and military power holders, which has accumulated (and continues accumulating) enormous wealth.
701	"Secondary beneficiaries" are the middle strata which are about to become social classes.
701	However, overall almost half the population has to be considered as poor, but in this respect there are dramatic differences between the countryside and the cities (where by now slightly more than 50% of the people live).
701	An inquiry carried out in 2008 by the Angolan Instituto Nacional de Estatística has it that in the rural areas roughly 58% must be classified as "poor", according to UN norms, but in the urban areas only 19%, while the overall rate is 37%.
701	In the cities, a majority of families, well beyond those officially classified as poor, have to adopt a variety of survival strategies.
701	At the same time, in urban areas social inequality is most evident, and assumes extreme forms in the capital, Luanda.
701	In the Human Development Index Angola constantly ranks in the bottom group.
701	According to The Heritage Foundation, a conservative American think tank, oil production froAccording to corruption: according to a recent Human Rights Watch report, 32 billion US dollars disappeared from government accounts from 2007 to 2010.
701	Before independence in 1975, Angola was a breadbasket of southern Africa and a major exporter of bananas, coffee and sisal, but three decades of civil war (1975–2002) destroyed the fertile countryside, leaving it littered with landmines and driving millions into the cities.
701	The country now depends on expensive food imports, mainly from South Africa and Portugal, while more than 90 percent of farming is done at family and subsistence level.
701	Thousands of Angolan small-scale farmers are trapped in poverty.
701	The enormous differences between the regions pose a serious structural problem in the Angolan economy.
701	This is best illustrated by the fact that about one third of the economic activities is concentrated in Luanda and the neighbouring Bengo province, while several areas of the interior are characterized by stagnation and even regression.
701	One of the economic consequences of the social and regional disparities is a sharp increase in Angolan private investments abroad.
701	The small fringe of Angolan society where most of the accumulation takes place seeks to spread its assets, for reasons of security and profit.
701	For the time being, the biggest share of these investments is concentrated in Portugal where the Angolan presence (including that of the family of the state president) in banks as well as in the domains of energy, telecommunications, and mass media has become notable, as has the acquisition of vineyards and orchards as well as of touristic enterprises.
701	Demographics  Angola's population is estimated to be 18,056,072 (2012).
701	It is composed of Ovimbundu (language Umbundu) 37%, Ambundu (language Kimbundu) 25%, Bakongo 13%, and 32% other ethnic groups (including the Chokwe, the Ovambo, the Mbunda, with the latter having been replaced by Ganguela, a generic term for peoples east of the Central Highlands, which has a slightly derogatory meaning when applied by the western ethnic groups, and the Xindonga) as well as about 2% mestiços (mixed European and African), 1.4% Chinese and 1% European The Ambundu and Ovimbundu nations combined form a majority of the population, at 62%.
701	The population is forecast to grow to over 47 million people to 2060, nearly tripling the estimated 16 to 18 million in 2011.
701	The last official census was taken in 1970, and showed the total population as being 5.6 million.
701	The first post-independence census is to be held in 2014.
701	It is estimated that Angola was host to 12,100 refugees and 2,900 asylum seekers by the end of 2007.
701	Democratic Republic of Congo (Congo-Kinshasa) who arrived in the 1970s.
701	As of 2008 there were an estimated 400,000 DRC migrant workers, at least 30,000 Portuguese, and about 259,000 Chinese living in Angola.
701	Since 2003, more than 400,000 Congolese migrants have been expelled from Angola.
701	Prior to independence in 1975, Angola had a community of approximately 350,000 Portuguese; currently, there are about 120,000 who are registered with the consulates, and increasing due to the debt crisis in Portugal.
701	The Chinese population stands at 258,920, mostly composed of temporary migrants.
701	The total fertility rate of Angola is 5.54 children born per woman (2012 estimates), the 11th highest in the world.
701	Languages  The languages in Angola are those originally spoken by the different ethnic groups plus Portuguese due to the country being a former Portuguese colony.
701	The indigenous languages with the largest usage are Umbundu, Kimbundu, and Kikongo, in that order.
701	Portuguese is the official language of the country.
701	Mastery of the official language is probably more extended in Angola than it is  elsewhere in Africa, and this certainly applies to its use in everyday life.
701	Moreover, and above all, the proportion of native (or near native) speakers of the language of the former colonizer, turned official after independence, is no doubt considerably higher than in any other African country.
701	There are three intertwined historical reasons for this situation.
701	In the Portuguese “bridgeheads” Luanda and Benguela, which existed on the coast of what today is Angola since the 15th and 16th century, respectively, Portuguese was spoken not only by the Portuguese and their mestiço descendents, but—especially in and around Luanda—by a significant number of Africans, although these always remained native speakers of their local African language.
701	Since the Portuguese conquest of the present territory of Angola, and especially since its “effective occupation” in the mid-1920s, schooling in Portuguese was slowly developed by the colonial state as well as by Catholic and Protestant missions.
701	The rhythm of this expansion was considerably accelerated during the late colonial period, 1961–1974, so that by the end of the colonial period children all over the territory (with relatively few exceptions) had at least some access to the Portuguese language.
701	In the same late colonial period, the legal discrimination of the black population was abolished, and the state apparatus in fields like health, education, social work, and rural development was enlarged.
701	This entailed a significant increase in jobs for Africans, under the condition that they spoke Portuguese.
701	As a consequence of all this, the African “lower middle class” which at that stage formed in Luanda and other cities began to often prevent their children from learning the local African language, in order to guarantee that they learned Portuguese as their native language.
701	At the same time, the white and “mestiço” population, where some knowledge of African languages could previously often been found, neglected this aspect more and more, to the point of frequently ignoring it totally.
701	After independence, these tendencies continued, and were even strengthened, under the rule of the MPLA which has its main social roots exactly in those social segments where the mastery of Portuguese as well as the proportion of native Portuguese speakers was highest.
701	This became a political side issue, as FNLA as well as UNITA, given their regional constituencies, came out in favour of a greater attention to the African languages, and as the FNLA favoured French over Portuguese.
701	The dynamics of the language situation, as described above, were additionally fostered by the massive migrations triggered by the Civil War.
701	Ovimbundu, the most populous ethnic group and the most affected by the war, appeared in great numbers in urban areas outside their areas, especially in Luanda and surroundings.
701	At the same time, a majority of the Bakongo who had fled to the Democratic Republic of Congo in the early 1960s, or of their children and grandchildren, returned to Angola, but mostly did not settle in their original "habitat", but in the cities—and again above all in Luanda.
701	As a consequence, more than half the population is now living in the cities which, from the linguistic point of view, have become highly heterogeneous.
701	This means, of course, that Portuguese as the overall language of communication is by now of paramount importance, and that the role of the African languages is steadily decreasing among the urban population—a trend which is beginning to spread into rural areas as well.
701	The exact numbers of those fluent in Portuguese or who speak Portuguese as a first language are unknown, although a census is expected to be carried out in 2013.
701	Quite a number of voices demand the recognition of “Angolan Portuguese” as a specific variant, comparable to those spoken in Portugal or in Brazil.
701	However, while there exists a certain number of idiomatic particularities in everyday Portuguese, as spoken by Angolans, it remains to be seen whether or not the Angolan government comes to the conclusion that these particularities constitute a configuration that justifies the claim to be a new language variant.
701	Religion  There are about 1000 mostly Christian religious communities in Angola.
701	While reliable statistics are nonexistent, estimates have it that more than half of the population are Roman Catholics, while about a quarter adhere to the Protestant churches introduced during the colonial period: the Congregationalists mainly among the Ovimbundu of the Central Highlands and the coastal region to its West, the Methodists concentrating on the Kimbundu speaking strip from Luanda to Malanje, the Baptists almost exclusively among the Bakongo of the Northwest (now massively present in Luanda as well) and dispersed Adventists, Reformed and Lutherans.
701	In Luanda and region there subsists a nucleus of the "syncretic" Tocoists and in the northwest a sprinkling of  Kimbanguism can be found, spreading from the Congo/Zaire.
701	Since independence, hundreds of Pentecostal and similar communities have sprung up in the cities, where by now about 50% of the population is living; several of these communities/churches are of Brazilian origin.
701	The  Muslims, practically all of them immigrants from West African and other countries and belonging to the Sunnite branch, represent only about 1%; because of their diversity, they do not form a community.
701	In 2011, according to the Islamic Community of Angola (Comunidade Islâmica de Angola, COIA) there were more than 80 mosques serving about 500,000 Muslims in Angola, and the number was growing.
701	In a study assessing nations' levels of religious regulation and persecution with scores ranging from 0 to 10 where 0 represented low levels of regulation or persecution, Angola was scored 0.8 on Government Regulation of Religion, 4.0 on Social Regulation of Religion, 0 on Government Favoritism of Religion and 0 on Religious Persecution.
701	Foreign missionaries were very active prior to independence in 1975, although since the beginning of the anti-colonial fight in 1961 the Portuguese colonial authorities expelled a series of Protestant missionaries and closed mission stations based on the belief that the missionaries were inciting pro-independence sentiments.
701	Missionaries have been able to return to the country since the early 1990s, although security conditions due to the civil war have prevented them until 2002 from restoring many of their former inland mission stations.
701	The Roman Catholic and some major Protestant denominations mostly keep to themselves in contrast to the "New Churches" which actively proselytize.
701	The Roman Catholic as well as some major Protestant denominations provide help for the poor in the form of crop seeds, farm animals, medical care and education.
701	Largest cities  Health  Epidemics of cholera, malaria, rabies and African hemorrhagic fevers like Marburg hemorrhagic fever, are common diseases in several parts of the country.
701	Many regions in this country have high incidence rates of tuberculosis and high HIV prevalence rates.
701	Dengue, filariasis, leishmaniasis, and onchocerciasis (river blindness) are other diseases carried by insects that also occur in the region.
701	Angola has one of the highest infant mortality rates in the world and one of the world's lowest life expectancies.
701	A 2007 survey concluded that low and deficient niacin status was common in Angola.
701	Demographic and Health Surveys is currently conducting several surveys in Angola on malaria, domestic violence and more.
701	Education  Although by law, education in Angola is compulsory and free for eight years, the government reports that a certain percentage of students are not attending school due to a lack of school buildings and teachers.
701	Students are often responsible for paying additional school-related expenses, including fees for books and supplies.
701	In 1999, the gross primary enrollment rate was 74 percent and in 1998, the most recent year for which data are available, the net primary enrollment rate was 61 percent.
701	Gross and net enrollment ratios are based on the number of students formally registered in primary school and therefore do not necessarily reflect actual school attendance.
701	There continue to be significant disparities in enrollment between rural and urban areas.
701	In 1995, 71.2 percent of children ages 7 to 14 years were attending school.
701	It is reported that higher percentages of boys attend school than girls.
701	During the Angolan Civil War (1975–2002), nearly half of all schools were reportedly looted and destroyed, leading to current problems with overcrowding.
701	The Ministry of Education hired 20,000 new teachers in 2005, and continued to implement teacher trainings.
701	Teachers tend to be underpaid, inadequately trained, and overworked (sometimes teaching two or three shifts a day).
701	Some teachers may also reportedly demand payment or bribes directly from their students.
701	Other factors, such as the presence of landmines, lack of resources and identity papers, and poor health also prevent children from regularly attending school.
701	Although budgetary allocations for education were increased in 2004, the education system in Angola continues to be extremely under-funded.
701	Literacy is quite low, with 67.4% of the population over the age of 15 able to read and write in Portuguese.
701	Since independence from Portugal in 1975, a number of Angolan students continued to be admitted every year at high schools, polytechnical institutes, and universities in Portugal, Brazil and Cuba through bilateral agreements; in general, these students belong to the Angolan elites.
701	Culture  Portugal has been present in Angola for 400 years, occupied the territory in the 19th and early 20th century, and ruled over it for about 50 years.
701	As a consequence, both countries share cultural aspects: language (Portuguese) and main religion (Roman Catholic Christianity).
701	The substrate of Angolan culture is African,  mostly Bantu, while Portuguese culture has be is African,  meen imported.
701	The diverse ethnic communities  – the Ovimbundu, Ambundu, Bakongo, Chokwe, Mbunda and other peoples – maintain to varying degrees their own cultural traits, traditions and languages, but in the cities, where slightly more than half of the population now lives, a mixed culture has been emerging since colonial times – in Luanda since its foundation in the 16th century.
701	In this urban culture, the Portuguese heritage has become more and more dominant.
701	An African influence is evident in music and dance, and is moulding the way in which Portuguese is spoken, but is almost disappearing from the vocabulary.
701	This process is well reflected in contemporary Angolan literature, especially in the works of Pepetela and Ana Paula Ribeiro Tavares.
701	Leila Lopes, Miss Angola 2011, was crowned Miss Universe 2011 in Brazil on 12 September 2011 making her the first Angolan to win the pageant.
701	Gallery
704	This article is about the demographic features of the population of Angola, including population density, ethnicity, education level, health of the populace, economic status, religious affiliations and other aspects of the population.
704	Ethnically, three main groups have to be distinguished, each speaking a Bantu language: the Ovimbundu who represent 37% of the population, the (Ambundu) with 25%, and the Bakongo 13%.
704	Other numerically important groups include the closely interrelated Chokwe and Lunda, the Ganguela and Nhaneca-Humbe, in both cases classification terms which stand for a variety of small groups, the Ovambo, the Herero,  the Xindonga and scattered residual groups of Khoisan.
704	In addition, mixed race (European and African) people amount to about 2%, with a small (1%) population of whites, mainly ethnically Portuguese (as a former overseas territory of Portugal until 1975, the Portuguese make up currently the largest non-African population, with more than 200,000 in 2012, a number that has been constantly increasing from the 2000s, because of Angola's growing demand for qualified human resources.
704	Besides the Portuguese, significant numbers of people from other European and from diverse Latin American countries (especially Brazil) can be found.
704	From the 2000s many Chinese have settled and started up small businesses, while at least as many have come as workforce for large (construction or other) enterprises.
704	Observers claim that the Chinese community in Angola might include as many as 300,000 persons at the end of 2010, but nothing near to reliable statistics are at this stage available on this point.
704	In 1974/75, up to 250,000 Cuban soldiers arrived in Angola to help the MPLA forces during the decolonisation conflict.
704	Once this was over, a massive development cooperation in the field of health and education brought in numerous civil personnel from Cuba.
704	However, only a very small percentage of all these people has remained in Angola, either for personal reasons (intermarriage) or as professionals (e.g.
704	The largest religious denomination  is Roman Catholicism, to which adheres about half the population.
704	Roughly 26% are followers of traditional forms of Protestantism (Congregationals, Methodists, Baptista, Lutherans, Reformed), but over the last decades there has in addition been a growth of Pentecostal communities and African Initiated Churches.
704	In 2006, one out of 221 people were Jehovah's Witnesses.
704	Blacks from Mali, Nigeria and Senegal are mostly Sunnite Muslims, but do not make up more than 1 - 2% of the population.
704	By now few Angolans retain African traditional religions following different ethnic faiths.
704	Population According to the 2010 revison of the World Population Prospects the total population was 19 082 000 in 2010, compared to only 4 148 000 in 1950.
704	The proprotion of children below the age of 15 in 2010 was 46.6%, 50.9% was between 15 and 65 years of age, while 2.5% was 65 years or older .
704	Vital statistics Registration of vital events is in Angola not complete.
704	The Population Departement of the United Nations prepared the following estimates.
704	CIA World Factbook demographic statistics The following demographic statistics are from the CIA World Factbook, unless otherwise indicated.
704	Population *18,056,072 (July 2012 est.) Population growth The population is growing by 2.184% annually.
704	There are 44.51 births and 24.81 deaths per 1,000 citizens.
704	The net migration rate is 2.14 migrants per 1,000 citizens.
704	The fertility rate of Angola is 5.97 children born per woman as of 2011.
704	The infant mortality rate is 184.44 deaths for every 1,000 live births with 196.55 deaths for males and 171.72 deaths for females for every 1,000 live births.
704	Life expectancy at birth is 37.63 years; 36.73 years for males and 38.57 years for females.
704	Sex ratio *At birth: 1.05 male(s)/female *Under 15 years: 1.02 male(s)/female *15–64 years: 1.03 male(s)/female *65 years and older: .79 male(s)/female *Total population: 1.02 male(s)/female (2011 est.) Health The adult prevalence rate of HIV/AIDS infection is 3.9% as of 2003.
704	There are 240,000 citizens living with AIDS and 21,000 die annually.
704	The risk of contracting disease is very high.
704	There are food and waterborne diseases, bacterial and protozoal diarrhea, hepatitis A, and typhoid fever; vectorborne diseases, malaria, African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness); respiratory disease: meningococcal meningitis, and schistosomiasis, a water contact disease, as of 2005.
704	Ethnic groups 37% of Angolans are Ovimbundu, 25% are Ambundu, 13% are Bakongo, 2% are mestiço, 1-2% are white settlers, and people from other ethnicities make up 22% of Angola's population.
704	Religions Angola is a majority Christian country.
704	Reliable statistics don't exist, but well over 80% belong in principle to a Christian church or community, although many of them don't practice their religion and are in fact non believers.
704	More than half of the Christians (whether practizing or not) are Roman Catholic, the remaining ones comprising members of traditional Protestant churches as well as of new, often Pentecostal communities.
704	Only 1 - 2% are Muslims  - generally immmigrants from other African countries.
704	Traditional indigenous religions are practized by a very small minority, generally in peripheral rural societies; however, some traditional beliefs are held by a substantial number of Christians.
704	Education Literacy is quite low, with 67.4% of the population over the age of 15 able to read and write in Portuguese.
704	Languages Portuguese is the official language of Angola, but Bantu and other African languages are also widely spoken.
704	In fact, Kikongo, Kimbundu, Umbundu, Tuchokwe, Nganguela, and Ukanyama have the official status of "national languages".
704	The mastery of Portuguese is widespread; in the cities the overwhelming majority are either fluent in Portuguese or have at least a reasonable working knowledge of this language; an increasing minority are native Portuguese speakers and have a poor, if any, knowledge of an African language.
705	Since the adoption of a new constitution, early in 2010, the politics of Angola takes place in a framework of a presidential republic, whereby the President of Angola is both head of state and head of government, and of a  multi-party system.
705	Executive power is exercised by the government.
705	Legislative power is vested in the President, the government and parliament.
705	Angola changed from a one-party Marxist-Leninist system ruled by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), in place since independence in 1975, to a multiparty democracy based on a new constitution adopted in 1992.
705	That same year, first parliamentary and presidential elections were held.
705	In the former, the MPLA won an absolute majority.
705	In the latter, President José Eduardo dos Santos won the first round election with more than 49% of the vote to Jonas Savimbi's 40%.
705	A runoff election would have been necessary, but never took place.
705	The renewal of civil war immediately after the elections, which were considered as fraudulent by UNITA, and the collapse of the Lusaka Protocol, created a split situation.
705	On the one hand, the new democratic institutions worked, notably the National Assembly, with the active participation of UNITA's and the FNLA's elected MPs  - while José Eduardo dos Santos continued to exercise his functions without democratic legitimation.
705	An the other hand, the armed forces of the MPLA (now the official armed forces of the Angolan state) and of UNITA fought each other until the leader of UNITA, Jonas Savimbi, was killed in action, in 2002.
705	From 2002 to 2010, the system as defined by the constitution of 1992 functioned in a relatively normal way.
705	The executive branch of the government was composed of the President, the Prime Minister and Council of Ministers.
705	The Council of Ministers, composed of all ministers and vice ministers, met regularly to discuss policy issues.
705	Governors of the 18 provinces were appointed by and served at the pleasure of the president.
705	The Constitutional Law of 1992 established the broad outlines of government structure and the rights and duties of citizens.
705	The legal system was based on Portuguese and customary law but was weak and fragmented.
705	Courts operated in only 12 of more than 140 municipalities.
705	A Supreme Court served as the appellate tribunal; a Constitutional Court with powers of judicial review was never constituted despite statutory authorization.
705	In practice,  power was more and more concentrated in the hands of the President who, supported by an ever increasing staff, largely controlled parliament, government, and the judiciary.
705	The 26-year long civil war has ravaged the country's political and social institutions.
705	The UN estimates of 1.8 million internally displaced persons (IDPs), while generally the accepted figure for war-affected people is 4 million.
705	Daily conditions of life throughout the country and specifically Luanda (population approximately 4 million) mirror the collapse of administrative infrastructure as well as many social institutions.
705	The ongoing grave economic situation largely prevents any government support for social institutions.
705	Hospitals are without medicines or basic equipment, schools are without books, and public employees often lack the basic supplies for their day-to-day work.
705	The 2010 constitution grants the President almost absolute power.
705	Elections for the National assembly are to take place every five years, and the President is automatically the leader of the winning party or coalition.
705	It is for the President to appoint (and dismiss) all of the following: * The members of the government (state ministers, ministers, state secretaries and vice-ministers); * The members of the Constitutional Court; * The members of the Supreme Court; * The members of the Court of Auditors; * The members of the Military Supreme Court; * The Governor and Vice-Governors of the Nacional Angolan Bank; * The General-Attorney, the Vice-General-Attorneys and their deputies (as well as the military homologous); * The Governors of the provinces; * The members of the Republic Council; * The members of the National Security Council; * The members of the Superior Magistrates Councils; * The General Chief of the Armed Forces and his deputy; * All other command posts in the military; * The Police General Commander, and the 2nd in command; * All other command posts in the police; * The chiefs and directors of the intelligence and security organs.
705	The President is also provided a variety of powers, like defining the policy of the country.
705	Even though it's not up to him/her to make laws (only to promulgate them and make edicts), the President is the leader of the winning party.
705	The only "relevant" post that is not directly appointed by the President is the Vice-President, which is the second in the winning party.
705	Executive branch |} Legislative branch The National Assembly (Assembleia Nacional) has 223 members, elected for a four year term, 130 members by proportional representation, 90 members in provincial districts, and 3 members to represent Angolans abroad.
705	The next general elections, due for 1997, have been rescheduled for 5 September 2008.
705	The ruling party MPLA won 82% (191 seats in the National Assembly) and the main opposition party won only 10% (16 seats).
705	The elections however have been described as only partly free but certainly not fair.
705	A White Book on the elections in 2008 lists up all irregularities surrounding the Parliamentary elections of 2008.
705	Political parties and elections Parliamentary elections were held in September 2008.
705	These elections were the first since 1992.
705	Presidential elections are planned for 2009.
705	Judicial branch Supreme Court (or "Tribunal da Relacao") judges of the Supreme Court are appointed by the president.
705	Administrative divisions Angola has eighteen provinces (provincias, singular - provincia); Bengo, Benguela, Bie, Cabinda, Cuando Cubango, Cuanza Norte, Cuanza Sul, Cunene, Huambo, Huila, Luanda, Lunda Norte, Lunda Sul, Malanje, Moxico, Namibe, Uige, Zaire Political pressure groups and leaders Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda or FLEC [N'zita Henriques TIAGO; Antonio Bento BEMBE] * note: FLEC is waging a small-scale, highly factionalized, armed struggle for the independence of Cabinda Province International organization participation  African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, AfDB, CEEAC, United Nations Economic Commission for Africa, FAO, Group of 77, IAEA, IBRD, ICAO, International Criminal Court (signatory), ICFTU, International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, International Development Association, IFAD, IFC, IFRCS, International Labour Organization, International Monetary Fund, International Maritime Organization, Interpol, IOC, International Organization for Migration, ISO (correspondent), ITU, Non-Aligned Council (temporary), UNCTAD, UNESCO, UNIDO, UPU, World Customs Organization, World Federation of Trade Unions, WHO, WIPO, WMO, WToO, WTrO
706	The Economy of Angola is one of the fastest-growing economies in the world, with the Economist asserting that for 2001 to 2010, Angolas' Annual average GDP growth was 11.1 percent.
706	It is still recovering from the Angolan Civil War that plagued Angola from independence in 1975 until 2002.
706	Despite extensive oil and gas resources, diamonds, hydroelectric potential, and rich agricultural land, Angola remains poor, and a third of the population relies on subsistence agriculture.
706	Since 2002, when the 27-year civil war ended, the country has worked to repair and improve ravaged infrastructure and weakened political and social institutions.
706	High international oil prices and rising oil production have led to a very strong economic growth in recent years, but corruption and public-sector mismanagement remain, particularly in the oil sector, which accounts for over 50 percent of GDP, over 90 percent of export revenue, and over 80 percent of government revenue.
706	History Kingdom of Portugal's explorers and settlers, founded trading posts and forts along the coast of Africa since the 15th century, and reached the Angolan coast in the 16th century.
706	Portuguese explorer Paulo Dias de Novais founded Luanda in 1575 as "São Paulo de Loanda", and the region developed as a slave trade market with the help of local Imbangala and Mbundu peoples who were notable slave hunters.
706	Trade was mostly with the Portuguese colony of Brazil; Brazilian ships were the most numerous in the ports of Luanda and Benguela.
706	By this time, Angola, a Portuguese colony, was in fact like a colony of Brazil, paradoxically another Portuguese colony.
706	A strong Brazilian influence was also exercised by the Jesuits in religion and education.
706	War gradually gave way to the philosophy of trade.
706	The great trade routes and the agreements that made them possible were the driving force for activities between the different areas; warlike states become states ready to produce and to sell.
706	In the Planalto (the high plains), the most important states were those of Bié and Bailundo, the latter being noted for its production of foodstuffs and rubber.
706	The colonial power, Portugal, becoming ever richer and more powerful, would not tolerate the growth of these neighbouring states and subjugated them one by one, so that by the beginning of this century the Portuguese had complete control over the entire area.
706	During the period of the Iberian Union (1580–1640), Portugal lost influence and power and made new enemies.
706	The Dutch, a major enemy of Castile, invaded many Portuguese overseas possessions, including Luanda.
706	The Dutch ruled Luanda from 1640 to 1648 as Fort Aardenburgh.
706	They were seeking black slaves for use in sugarcane plantations of Northeastern Brazil (Pernambuco, Olinda, Recife) which they had also seized from Portugal.
706	John Maurice, Prince of Nassau-Siegen, conquered the Portuguese possessions of Saint George del Mina, Saint Thomas, and Luanda, Angola, on the west coast of Africa.
706	After the dissolution of the Iberian Union in 1640, Portugal would reestablish its authority over the lost territories of the Portuguese Empire.
706	The Portuguese started to develop townships, trading posts, logging camps and small processing factories.
706	From 1764 onwards, there was a gradual change from a slave-based society to one based on production for domestic consumption and export.
706	Meanwhile, with the independence of Brazil in 1822, the slave trade was abolished in 1836, and in 1844 Angola's ports were opened to foreign shipping.
706	By 1850, Luanda was one of the greatest and most developed Portuguese cities in the vast Portuguese Empire outside Mainland Portugal, full of trading companies, exporting (together with Benguela) palm and peanut oil, wax, copal, timber, ivory, cotton, coffee, and cocoa, among many other products.
706	Maize, tobacco, dried meat and cassava flour also began to be produced locally.
706	The Angolan bourgeoisie was born.
706	From the 1920s to the 1960s, strong economic growth, abundant natural resources and development of infrastruture, led to the arrival of even more Portuguese settlers.
706	The Portuguese discovered petroleum in Angola in 1955.
706	Production began in the Cuanza basin in the 1950s, in the Congo basin in the 1960s, and in the exclave of Cabinda in 1968.
706	The Portuguese government granted operating rights for Block Zero to the Cabinda Gulf Oil Company, a subsidiary of ChevronTexaco, in 1955.
706	Oil production surpassed the exportation of coffee as Angola's largest export in 1973.
706	A leftist military-led coup d'état, started on April 25, 1974, in Lisbon, overthrew the Marcelo Caetano government in Portugal, and promised to hand over power to an independent Angolan government.
706	Mobutu Sese Seko, the President of Zaire, met with António de Spínola, the transitional President of Portugal, on September 15, 1974 on Sal island in Cape Verde, crafting a plan to empower Holden Roberto of the National Liberation Front of Angola, Jonas Savimbi of UNITA, and Daniel Chipenda of the MPLA's eastern faction at the expense of MPLA leader Agostinho Neto while retaining the façade of national unity.
706	Mobutu and Spínola wanted to present Chipenda as the MPLA head, Mobutu particularly preferring Chipenda over Neto because Chipenda supported autonomy for Cabinda.
706	The ring Chipenda over Angolan exclave has immense petroleum reserves estimated at around 300 million tons (~300 kg) which Zaire, and thus the Mobutu government, depended on for economic survival.
706	After independence thousands of white Portuguese left, most of them to Portugal and many travelling overland to South Africa.
706	There was an immediate crisis because the indigenous African population lacked the skills and knowledge needed to run the country and maintain its well-developed infrastructure.
706	The Angolan government created Sonangol, a state-run oil company, in 1976.
706	Two years later Sonangol received the rights to oil exploration and production in all of Angola.
706	After independence from Portugal in 1975, Angola was ravaged by a horrific civil war between 1975 and 2002.
706	United Nations Angola Verification Mission III and MONUA spent USD1.5 billion overseeing implementation of the Lusaka Protocol, a 1994 peace accord that ultimately failed to end the civil war.
706	The protocol prohibited UNITA from buying foreign arms, a provision the United Nations largely did not enforce, so both sides continued to build up their stockpile.
706	UNITA purchased weapons in 1996 and 1997 from private sources in Albania and Bulgaria, and from Zaire, South Africa, Republic of the Congo, Zambia, Togo, and Burkina Faso.
706	In October 1997 the UN imposed travel sanctions on UNITA leaders, but the UN waited untihttp://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?titleEconomy_of_Angola&action edit&section=1#l July 1998 to limit UNITA's exportation of diamonds and freeze UNITA bank accounts.
706	While the U.S.
706	USD250 million to UNITA between 1986 to 1991, UNITA made USD1.72 billion between 1994 and 1999 exporting diamonds, primarily through Zaire to Europe.
706	At the same time the Angolan government received large amounts of weapons from the governments of Belarus, Brazil, Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, and South Africa.
706	While no arms shipment to the government violated the protocol, no country informed the U.N.
706	Register on Conventional Weapons as required.
706	Despite the increase in civil warfare in late 1998, the economy grew by an estimated 4% in 1999.
706	The government introduced new currency denominations in 1999, including a 1 and 5 kwanza note.
706	An economic reform effort was launched in 1998.
706	Angola ranked 160 out of 174 nations in the United Nations Human Development Index of 2000.
706	In April 2000 Angola started an International Monetary Fund (IMF) Staff-Monitored Program (SMP).
706	The program formally lapsed in June 2001, but the IMF remains engaged.
706	In this context the Government of Angola has succeeded in unifying exchange rates and has raised fuel, electricity, and water rates.
706	The Commercial Code, telecommunications law, and Foreign Investment Code are being modernized.
706	A privatization effort, prepared with World Bank assistance, has begun with the BCI bank.
706	Nevertheless, a legacy of fiscal mismanagement and corruption persists.
706	The civil war internally displaced 3.8 million people, 32% of the population, by 2001.
706	The security brought about by the 2002 peace settlement has led to the resettlement of 4 million displaced persons, thus resulting in large-scale increases in agriculture production.
706	Angola produced over 3 million carats of diamonds per year in 2003, with its production expected to grow to 10 million carats per year by 2007.
706	In 2004 China's Eximbank approved a $2 billion line of credit to Angola to rebuild infrastructure.
706	The economy grew 18% in 2005 and growth was expected to reach 26% in 2006 and stay above 10% for the rest of the decade.
706	The construction industry is another sector taking advantage of the growing economy, with various housing projects stimulated by the government that created various initiatives for this.
706	Examples are the program Angola Investe and the projects Casa Feliz or Meña.
706	However, not all public construction projects are functional; a case in point is Kilamba Kiaxi where a whole new satellite town of Luanda, consisting in the main of housing faclities for several hundreds of thousends of people, remains practically uninhabited, because of prices that are out of reach even for the middle class.
706	ChevronTexaco started pumping 50 koilbbl/d from Block 14 in January 2000, but production has decreased to 57 koilbbl/d in 2007 due to the poor quality of the oil.
706	Angola joined the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries on January 1, 2007.
706	Cabinda Gulf Oil Company found Malange-1, an oil reservoir in Block 14, on August 9, 2007.
706	Overview Despite its abundant natural resources, output per capita is among the world's lowest.
706	Subsistence agriculture provides the main livelihood for 85% of the population.
706	Oil production and the supporting activities are vital to the economy, contributing about 45% to GDP and 90% of exports.
706	Growth is almost entirely driven by rising oil production which surpassed  in late-2005 and which is expected to grow to 2 Moilbbl/d by 2007.
706	Control of the oil industry is consolidated in Sonangol Group, a conglomerate which is owned by the Angolan government.
706	With revenues booming from oil exports, the government has started to implement ambitious development programs in building roads and other basic infrastructure for the nation.
706	In the last decade of the colonial period, Angola was a major African food exporter but now imports almost all its food.
706	Because of severe wartime conditions, including extensive planting of landmines throughout the countryside, agricultural activities have been brought to a near standstill.
706	Some efforts to recover have gone forward, however, notably in fisheries.
706	Coffee production, though a fraction of its pre-1975 level, is sufficient for domestic needs and some exports.
706	In sharp contrast to a bleak picture of devastation and bare subsistence is expanding oil production, now almost half of GDP and 90% of exports, at 800 koilbbl/d.
706	Diamonds provided much of the revenue for Jonas Savimbi's UNITA rebellion through illicit trade.
706	Other rich resources await development: gold, forest products, fisheries, iron ore, coffee, and fruits.
706	This is a chart of trend of nominal gross domestic produThis is a chct of Angola at market prices using International Monetary Fund data; figures are in millions of units.
706	Foreign trade Exports in 2004 reached US$10,530,764,911.
706	The vast majority of Angola's exports, 92% in 2004, are petroleum products.
706	US$785 million worth of diamonds, 7.5% of exports, were sold abroad that year.
706	Nearly all of Angola's oil goes to the United States, 526 koilbbl/d in 2006, making it the eighth largest supplier of oil to the United States, and to the People's Republic of China, 477 koilbbl/d in 2006.
706	In the first quarter of 2008, Angola became the main exporter of oil to China.
706	The rest of its petroleum exports go to Europe and Latin America.
706	U.S.
706	Angola, with Chevron-Texaco leading the way.
706	The U.S.
706	Angola, while principally importing petroleum.
706	Trade between Angola and South Africa exceeded USD 300 million in 2007.
706	From the 2000s many Chinese have settled and started up businesses.
706	Resources Petroleum Angola produces and exports more petroleum than any other nation in sub-Saharan Africa, surpassing Nigeria in the 2000s.
706	In January 2007 Angola became a member of OPEC.
706	By 2010 production is expected to double the 2006 output level with development of deep-water offshore oil fields.
706	Oil sales generated USD 1.71 billion in tax revenue in 2004 and now makes up 80% of the government's budget, a 5% increase from 2003, and 45% of GDP.
706	Chevron Corporation produces and receives 400 koilbbl/d, 27% of Angolan oil.
706	Elf Oil, Texaco, ExxonMobil, Agip, Petrobras, and British Petroleum also operate in the country.
706	Block Zero provides the majority of Angola's crude oil production with 370 koilbbl/d produced annually.
706	The largest fields in Block Zero are Takula (Area A), Numbi (Area A), and Kokongo (Area B).
706	ChevronTexaco operates in Block Zero with a 39.2% share.
706	SONANGOL, the state oil company, Total, and ENI-Agip own the rest of the block.
706	ChevronTexaco also operates Angola's first producing deepwater section, Block 14, with 57 koilbbl/d.
706	The United Nations has criticized the Angolan government for using torture, rape, summary executions, arbitrary detention, and disappearances, actions which Angolan government has justified on the need to maintain oil output.
706	Angola is the third-largest trading partner of the United States in Sub-Saharan Africa, largely because of its petroleum exports.
706	The U.S.
706	Angola, about three times as much as it imported from Kuwait just prior to the Gulf War in 1991.
706	The U.S.
706	Government has invested USD $4 billion in Angola's petroleum sector.
706	Diamonds Angola is the third largest producer of diamonds in Africa and has only explored 40% of the diamond-rich territory within the country, but has had difficulty in attracting foreign investment because of corruption, human rights violations, and diamond smuggling.
706	Production rose by 30% in 2006 and Endiama, the national diamond company of Angola, expects production to increase by 8% in 2007 to 10 million carats annually.
706	The government is trying to attract foreign companies to the provinces of Bié, Malanje and Uíge.
706	The Angolan government loses $375 million annually from diamond smuggling.
706	In 2003 the government began Operation Brilliant, an anti-smuggling investigation that arrested and deported 250,000 smugglers between 2003 and 2006.
706	Rafael Marques, a journalist and human rights activist, described the diamond industry in his 2006 Angola's Deadly Diamonds report as plagued by "murders, beatings, arbitrary detentions and other human rights violations."
706	Marques called on foreign countries to boycott Angola's "conflict diamonds".
706	Iron Under Portuguese rule, Angola began mining iron in 1957, producing 1.2 million tons in 1967 and 6.2 million tons by 1971.
706	In the early 1970s, 70% of Portuguese Angola's iron exports went to Western Europe and Japan.
706	After independence in 1975, the Angolan Civil War (1975–2002) destroyed most of the territory's mining infrastructure.
706	The redevelopment of the Angolan mining industry started in the late 2000s.
708	Transport in Angola comprises: Railways  There are three separate railway lines in Angola: * Luanda Railway (northern) * Benguela Railway (central) * Moçâmedes Railway (southern) Reconstruction of these three lines began in 2005 and is expected to be completed by the end of the year 2012.
708	The Benguela Railway already connects to the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
708	Highways  * total: 52,429 km country comparison to the world: 79 * paved: 5,349 km * unpaved: 46,080 km (2001) Travel on highways outside of towns and cities in Angola (and in some cases within) is often not best advised for those without four-by-four vehicles.
708	Whilst a reasonable road infrastructure has existed within Angola, time and the war have taken their toll on the road surfaces, leaving many severely potholed, littered with broken asphalt.
708	In many areas drivers have established alternate tracks to avoid the worst parts of the surface, although careful attention must be paid to the presence or absence of landmine warning markers by the side of the road.
708	The Angolan government has contracted the restoration of many of the country's roads, though.
708	Many companies are coming into the country from China and surrounding nations to help improve road surfaces.
708	The road between Lubango and Namibe, for example, was completed recently with funding from the European Union, and is comparable to many European main routes.
708	Progress to complete the road infrastructure is likely to take some decades, but substantial efforts are already being made in the right directions.
708	Waterways  * 1,300 km navigable (2008) country comparison to the world: 36 Pipelines  * gas, 2 km; crude oil 87 km (2008) In April 2012, the Zambian Development Agency (ZDA) and an Angolan company signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to build a multi-product pipeline from Lobito to Lusaka, Zambia, to deliver various refined products to Zambia.
708	Angola plans to build an oil refinery in Lobito in the coming years.
708	Ports and harbors  The government plans to build a deep-water port at Barra do Dande, north of Luanda, in Bengo province near Caxito.
708	Merchant marine  * total: 6 country comparison to the world: 128 * by type: cargo 1, passenger/cargo 2, petroleum tanker 2, roll on/roll off 1 * foreign owned: 1 (Spain) * registered in other countries: 6 (Bahamas) (2008) Airports  * 211 (2008) Airports - with paved runways  * total: 30 * over 3,047 m: 5 * 2,438 to 3,047 m: 8 * 1,524 to 2,437 m: 12 * 914 to 1,523 m: 4 * under 914 m: 1 (2008) Airports - with unpaved runways  * total:  181 (2008) * over 3,047 m: 2 * 2,438 to 3,047 m: 5 * 1,524 to 2,437 m: 32 * 914 to 1,523 m: 100 * under 914 m: 42 (2008) National Airlines  * TAAG Angola Airlines * Sonair History  Angola had an estimated total of 43 airports as of 2004, of which 31 had paved runways as of 2005.
708	There is an international airport at Luanda.
708	International and domestic services are maintained by TAAG Angola Airlines, Aeroflot, British Airways, Brussels Airlines, Lufthansa, Air France, Air Namibia, Cubana, Ethiopian Airlines, Emirates, Delta Air Lines, Royal Air Maroc, Iberia, Hainan Airlines, Kenya Airways, South African Airways, TAP Air Portugal and several regional carriers.
708	In 2003, domestic and international carriers carried 198,000 passengers.
708	There are airstrips for domestic transport at Benguela, Cabinda, Huambo, Namibe, and Catumbela.
709	The Angolan Armed Forces (Portuguese: Forças Armadas Angolanas) are the military in Angola that succeeded Forças Armadas de Libertação de Angola (FAPLA) following the abortive Bicesse Accord with UNITA in 1991.
709	As part of the peace agreement, troops from both armies were to be demilitarized and then integrated.
709	Integration was never completed as UNITA went back to war in 1992.
709	Later, consequences for UNITA members in Luanda were harsh with FAPLA veterans persecuting their erstwhile opponents in certain areas and reports of vigilantism.
709	The FAA is headed by Chief of Staff Geraldo Sachipengo Nunda since 2010, who reports to the Minister of Defense, actually Cândido Pereira Van-Dúnem.
709	There are three components, the Army (Forças Armadas), Navy (Marinha de Guerra) and Air Force Força Aérea Nacional Angolana.
709	Total manpower is about 130,500.
709	The army is by far the largest of the services with about 120,000 men and women.
709	The Navy numbers about 2,500 and operates seven small patrol craft and barges.
709	Airforce personnel total about 8,000; its equipment includes eight Russian-manufactured Sukhoi Su-27 fighter aircraft and transport planes.
709	In 2002 one was lost during the civil war with UNITA forces.
709	A small number of FAA personnel are stationed in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Kinshasa) and the Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville).
709	A presence during the unrest in Côte d'Ivoire, 2010–2011, were not officially confirmed.
709	Angola is basically interested in the participation of the FAA operations of the African Union and has formed special units for this purpose.
709	The Angolan army has around 29,000 "ghost workers" who remain enrolled in the ranks of the FAA and therefore receive a salary.
709	Major equipment included over 140 main battle tanks, 600 reconnaissance vehicles, over 320 armored vehicles, infantry fighting vehicles, 298 howitzers carriers.
709	As of 2013, the Army has three military regions and 16 'brigades', comprising infantry, tanks, APC, artillery, and AA units as required.
709	The Angolan Navy (MGA) has been neglected and ignored as a military arm mainly due to the guerrilla struggle against the Portuguese and the nature of the civil war.
709	From the early 1990s to the present the Angolan Navy has shrunk from around 4 200 personnel to around 1 000, resulting in the loss of skills and expertise needed to maintain equipment.
709	In order to protect Angola’s 1 600 km long coastline, the Angolan Navy is undergoing modernisation but is still lacking in many ways.
709	Portugal has been providing training through its Technical Military Cooperation (CTM) programme.
709	With regard to procurement, the Navy has a request for a frigate, three corvettes, three offshore patrol vessel and additional fast patrol boats.
709	In 1991, the Air Force /Air Defense Forces had 8,000 personnel and 90 combat capable aircraft, including 22 fighters, 59 fighter ground attack aircraft and 16 attack helicopters.
709	The defense budget in 2005 totaled 1.16 billion US Dollars.
709	Navy Fleet (Marinha de Guerra)  Most of the craft detailed are from the 1980s or earlier, but the navy acquired new boats from Spain and France in the 1990s.
709	Germany will deliver Fast Attack Craft for border protection from 2011.
709	Fast missile craft ** OSA-II with four SS-N-2 Styx missiles - 6 * Fast torpedo craft ** Shershen class torpedo boat with four 533mm heavyweight torpedo tubes 4 or 5 * Inland-water and coastal patrol boats ** Argos 4 ** Poluchat-I 2 ** Zhuk - 1 or 2 ** Jupiter 1 or 2 ** Bellatrix 4 or 5 ** Mandume Class patrol craft - 4  ** Patrulheiro Class patrol boat - 3 * Mine warfare craft ** Yevgenya class minesweeper MH1 2 * Amphibious vessels ** Polnocny class landing ship 3 ** Alfange - 1 ** Landing craft tank (LCT 1 ** T-4 4 or 5 ** LDM-400 - 9 or 10 * Coastal defense equipment ** SS-C1 Sepal radar system The navy also has several aircraft for maritime patrol: Controversies The Angolan Armed Forces were controverisally involved in training the armed forces of fellow Lusophone states Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau.
709	In the case of the latter, the 2012 Guinea-Bissau coup d'état was cited by the coup leaders as due to Angola's involvement in trying to "reform" the military in connivance with the civilian leadership.
710	The foreign relations of Angola are based on Angola's strong support of U.S.
710	Angolan economy is dependent on U.S.
710	From 1975 to 1989, Angola was aligned with the Eastern bloc, in particular the Soviet Union, Libya, and Cuba.
710	Since then, it has focused on improving relationships with Western countries, cultivating links with other Portuguese-speaking countries, and asserting its own national interests in Central Africa through military and diplomatic intervention.
710	In 1993, it established formal diplomatic relations with the United States.
710	It has entered the Southern African Development Community as a vehicle for improving ties with its largely Anglophone neighbors to the south.
710	Zimbabwe and Namibia joined Angola in its military intervention in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where Angolan troops remain in support of the Joseph Kabila government.
710	It also has intervened in the Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville) to support the existing government in that country.
710	Since 1998, Angola has successfully worked with the United Nations Security Council to impose and carry out sanctions on UNITA.
710	More recently, it has extended those efforts to controls on conflict diamonds, the primary source of revenue for UNITA.
710	At the same time, Angola has promoted the revival of the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries (CPLP) as a forum for cultural exchange and expanding ties with Portugal (its former ruler) and Brazil (which shares many cultural affinities with Angola) in particular.
710	Sub-Saharan Africa Cape Verde Cape Verde signed a friendship accord with Angola in December 1975, shortly after Angola gained its independence.
710	Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau served as stop-over points for Cuban troops on their way to Angola to fight UNITA rebels and South African troops.
710	Prime Minister Pedro Pires sent FARP soldiers to Angola where they served as the personal bodyguards of Angolan President José Eduardo dos Santos.
710	Democratic Republic of the Congo Many thousands of Angolans fled the country after the civil war.
710	More than 20,000 people were forced to leave the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 2009, an action the DR Congo said was in retaliation for regular expulsion of Congolese diamond miners who were in Angola illegally.
710	Angola sent a delegation to DR Congo's capital Kinshasa and succeeded in stopping government-forced expulsions which had become a "tit-for-tat" immigration dispute.
710	"Congo and Angola have agreed to suspend expulsions from both sides of the border," said Lambert Mende, DR Congo information minister, in October 2009.
710	"We never challenged the expulsions themselves; we challenged the way they were being conducted — all the beating of people and looting their goods, even sometimes their clothes," Mende said.
710	Namibia Namibia borders Angola to the south.
710	In 1999 Namibia signed a mutual defense pact with its northern neighbor Angola.
710	This affected the Angolan Civil War that had been ongoing since Angola's independence in 1975.
710	Namibia's ruling party SWAPO sought to support the ruling party MPLA in Angola against the rebel movement UNITA, whose stronghold is in southern Angola, bordering to Namibia.
710	The defence pact allowed Angolan troops to use Namibian territory when attacking Jonas Savimbi's UNITA.
710	Nigeria Angolan-Nigerian relations are primarily based on their roles as oil exporting nations.
710	Both are members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, the African Union and other multilateral organizations.
710	South Africa Angola-South Africa relations are quite strong as the ruling parties in both nations, the African National Congress in South Africa and the MPLA in Angola, fought together during the Angolan Civil War and South African Border War.
710	They fought against UNITA rebels, based in Angola, and the apartheid-era government in South Africa who supported them.
710	Nelson Mandela mediated between the MPLA and UNITA factions during the last years of Angola's civil war.
710	Zimbabwe Angola-Zimbabwe relations have remained cordial since the birth of both states, Angola in 1975 and Zimbabwe in 1979, during the Cold War.
710	While Angola's foreign policy shifted to a pro-U.S.
710	President Robert Mugabe Zimbabwe's ties with the West soured in the late 1990s.
710	Guinea-Bissau Following a request by the government of Guinea-Bissau, Angola sent there a contingent of about 300 troops meant to help putting an end to the political-military unrest in that country, and to reorganize the local military forces.
710	In fact, these troops were perceived as a kinf of Pretorian Guard for the ruling party, PAIGC.
710	In the beginning of April 2012, when a new military Coup d'état was under preparation, the Angolan regime decided to withdraw its military mission from Guinea-Bissau.
710	Europe Bulgaria * Date started: 1975-11-20 * Since 1976, Bulgaria has an embassy in Luanda.
710	Angola is represented in Bulgaria through its embassy in Athens (Greece).
710	Denmark * Denmark is represented in Angola through its embassy in Lusaka (Zambia).
710	Angola is represented in Denmark, through its embassy in Stockholm, (Sweden).
710	France Relations between the two countries have not always been cordial due to the former French government's policy of supporting militant separatists in Angola's Cabinda province and the international Angolagate scandal embarrassed both governments by exposing corruption and illicit arms deals.
710	Following French President Nicolas Sarkozy's visit in 2008, relations have improved.
710	Portugal Angy's visit in 2008, relationsola-Portugal relations have significantly improved since the Angolan government abandoned communism and nominally embraced democracy in 1991, embracing a pro-U.S.
710	Europe foreign policy.
710	Portugal ruled Angola for 400 years, colonizing the territory from 1483 until independence in 1975.
710	Angola's war for independence did not end in a military victory for either side, but was suspended as a result of a coup in Portugal that replaced the Caetano regime.
710	Russia Russia has an embassy in Luanda.
710	Angola has an embassy in Moscow and an honorary consulate in Saint Petersburg.
710	Angola and the precursor to Russia, the Soviet Union, established relations upon Angola's independence.
710	Serbia * Serbia is represented in Angola through its embassy in Luanda (Angola), with ambassador Danilo Milić.
710	Angola is represented in Serbia, through its embassy in Belgrade, (Serbia), with ambassador Toko Diakenga Serao.
710	The Defence Minister of Serbia, Dragan Šutanovac, stated in a 2011 meeting in Luanda that Serbia would negotiate with the Angolan military authorities for the construction of a new military hospital in Angola.
710	Latin America Argentina * Date started: 1977-09-02 * Angola has an embassy in Buenos Aires.
710	Argentina has an embassy in Luanda.
710	Argentine reggae musician Fidel Nadal is descended from Angolan slaves.
710	Argentine Ministry of Foreign Relations: list of bilateral treaties with Angola (in Spanish only)] Brazil Commercial and economic ties dominate the relations of each country.
710	Parts of both countries were part of the Portuguese Empire from the early 16th century until Brazil's independence in 1822.
710	As of November 2007, "trade between the two countries is booming as never before" Cuba During Angola's civil war Cuban forces fought to install a Marxist-Leninist MPLA-PT government,  against Western-backed UNITA and FLNA guerrillas and the South-African army.
710	Mexico Relations between Angola and several Latin American countries, including Mexico, have become of increasing priority due to the geographical proximity and cultural similarities.
710	Angola has an embassy in Mexico City, and Mexico has an embassy in Luanda.
710	United States From the mid-1980s through at least 1992, the United States was the primary source of military and other support for the UNITA rebel movement, which was led from its creation through 2002 by Jonas Savimbi.
710	The U.S.
710	Angola diplomatically during this period.
710	Relations between the United States of America and the Republic of Angola (formerly the People's Republic of Angola) have warmed since Angola's ideological renunciation of Marxism before the 1992 elections.
710	Asia Israel Angola-Israel relations, primarily based on trade and pro-United States foreign policies, are excellent.
710	In March 2006, the trade volume between the two countries amounted to $400 million.
710	The Israeli ambassador to Angola is Avraham Benjamin.[1] In 2005, President José Eduardo dos Santos visited Israel.
710	Itemid47&id 150&optioncom_content&task view Angola/Israel business volume amounted at USD 400 million] Angola Press, 22 March 2006 * [http://www.angolapress-angop.ao/noticia-e.asp?ID=437778 Israeli Ambassador Highlights Relations With Angola] Angola Press Japan As of 2007, economic relations played "a fundamental role in the bilateral relations between the two governments".
710	Japan has donated towards demining following the civil war.
710	People's Republic of China Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao visited Angola in June 2006, offering a US$9 billion loan for infrastructure improvements in return for petroleum.
710	The PRC has invested heavily in Angola since the end of the civil war in 2002.
710	João Manuel Bernardo, the current ambassador of Angola to China, visited the PRC in November 2007.
710	In February 2006, Angola surpassed Saudi Arabia to become the number one supplier of oil to China.[http://codrinarsene.com/2008/10/angola-china-relations/] [http://www.african-politics.com/2008/10/angola-china-relations/] Vietnam Angola-Vietnam relations were established in August 1971, four years before Angola gained its independence, when future President of Angola Agostinho Neto visited Vietnam.
710	Angola and Vietnam have steadfast partners as both transitioned from Cold War-era foreign policies of international communism to pro-Western pragmatism following the fall of the Soviet Union.
711	Albert Sidney Johnston (February 2, 1803 – April 6, 1862) served as a general in three different armies: the Texas Army, the United States Army, and the Confederate States Army.
711	He saw extensive combat during his military career, fighting actions in the Texas War of Independence, the Mexican-American War, the Utah War, and the American Civil War.
711	Considered by Confederate President Jefferson Davis to be the finest (and the second-highest ranking) general officer in the Confederacy before the emergence of Robert E.
711	Lee, he was killed early in the Civil War at the Battle of Shiloh and was the highest-ranking officer, Union or Confederate, killed during the entire war.
711	Davis believed the loss of Johnston "was the turning point of our fate".
711	Early life Johnston was born in Washington, Kentucky, the youngest son of Dr.
711	John and Abigail Harris Johnston.
711	His father was a native of Salisbury, Connecticut.
711	Although Albert Johnston was born in Kentucky, he lived much of his life in Texas, which he considered his home.
711	He was first educated at Transylvania University in Lexington, where he met fellow student Jefferson Davis.
711	Both were appointed to the United States Military Academy, Davis two years behind Johnston.
711	In 1826 Johnston graduated eighth of 41 cadets in his class from West Point with a commission as a brevet second lieutenant in the 2nd U.S.
711	Infantry.
711	Johnston was assigned to posts in New York and Missouri and served in the Black Hawk War in 1832 as chief of staff to Bvt.
711	Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Henry Atkinson.
711	In 1829 he married Henrietta Preston, sister of Kentucky politician and future civil war general William Preston.
711	He resigned his commission in 1834 to return to Kentucky to care for his dying wife, who succumbed two years later to tuberculosis.
711	They had one son, Col.
711	William Preston Johnston, who would also serve in the Confederate Army.
711	Texas Army In April 1834, Johnston took up farming in Texas and enlisted as a private in the Texas Army during the Texas War of Independence against the Republic of Mexico in 1836.
711	One month later, Johnston was promoted to major and the position of aide-de-camp to General Sam Houston.
711	He was named Adjutant General as a colonel in the Republic of Texas Army on August 5, 1836.
711	On January 31, 1837, he became senior brigadier general in command of the Texas Army.
711	On February 7, 1837, he fought in a duel with Texas Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Felix Huston, challenging each other for the command of the Texas Army; Johnston refused to fire on Huston and lost the position after he was wounded in the pelvis.
711	The second president of the Republic of Texas, Mirabeau B.
711	Lamar, appointed him Secretary of War on December 22, 1838.
711	Johnston was to provide the defense of the Texas border against Mexican invasion, and in 1839 conducted a campaign against Indians in northern Texas.
711	In February 1840, he resigned and returned to Kentucky, where he married Eliza Griffin in 1843.
711	They settled on a large plantation he named China Grove in Brazoria County, Texas.
711	U.S.
711	Army Johnston returned to the Texas Army during the Mexican-American War under General Zachary Taylor as a colonel of the 1st Texas Rifle Volunteers.
711	The enlistments of his volunteers ran out just before the Battle of Monterrey.
711	Johnston managed to convince a few volunteers to stay and fight as he himself served as the inspector general of volunteers and fought at the battles of Monterrey and Buena Vista.
711	Johnston remained on his plantation after the war until he was appointed by President Taylor to the U.S.
711	Army as a major and was made a paymaster in December 1849.
711	He served in that role for more than five years, making six tours, and traveling more than 4000 mi annually on the Indian frontier of Texas.
711	He served on the Texas frontier at Fort Mason and elsewhere in the West.
711	In 1855 President Franklin Pierce appointed him colonel of the new 2nd U.S.
711	Cavalry (the unit that preceded the modern 5th U.S.), a new regiment, which he organized.
711	As a key figure in the Utah War, he led U.S.
711	Mormon government in the formerly Mormon territory.
711	He received a brevet promotion to brigadier general in 1857 for his service in Utah.
711	He spent 1860 in Kentucky until December 21, when he sailed for California to take command of the Department of the Pacific.
711	Civil War At the outbreak of the Civil War, Johnston was the commander of the U.S.
711	Army Department of the Pacific in California.
711	Like many regular army officers from the South he was opposed to secession, but resigned his commission soon after he heard of the secession of his adopted state Texas.
711	It was accepted by the War Department on May 6, 1861, effective May 3.
711	On April 28 he moved to Los Angeles where he had family and remained there until May when, suspected by local Union authorities, he evaded arrest and joined the Los Angeles Mounted Rifles as a private, leaving Warner's Ranch May 27.
711	He participated in their trek across the southwestern deserts to Texas, crossing the Colorado River into the Confederate Territory of Arizona on July 4, 1861.
711	Early in the Civil War, Confederate President Jefferson Davis decided that the Confederacy would attempt to hold as much of its territory as possible and he distributed its military forces around its borders and coasts.
711	In the summer of 1861, Davis appointed several generals to defend Confederate lines from the Mississippi River east to the Allegheny Mountains.
711	Maj.
711	Gen.
711	Leonidas Polk and Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Gideon J.
711	Pillow, who had been initially in command in Tennessee as that State's top general.
711	Their impolitic occupation of Columbus, Kentucky on September 3, 1861, two days before Johnston arrived in the Confederacy's capital, Richmond, Virginia, after his cross–country journey, drove Kentucky from its stated neutrality and the majority of Kentuckians into the Union camp.
711	Their action gave Union Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Ulysses S.
711	Grant an excuse to take control of the even more important and strategically located town of Paducah, Kentucky without raising the ire of most Kentuckians and the pro-Union majority in the State legislature.
711	Confederate command in Western Theater On September 10, 1861, Johnston was assigned to command the huge area of the Confederacy west of the Allegheny Mountains, except for coastal areas.
711	He became commander of the Confederacy's western armies in the area often called the Western Department or Western Military Department.
711	After his appointment, Johnston immediately headed for his new territory.
711	He was permitted to call on governors of Arkansas, Tennessee and Mississippi for new troops, although this authority was largely stifled by politics, especially with respect to Mississippi.
711	On September 13, 1861, in view of the decision of the Kentucky legislature to side with the Union after the occupation of Columbus by Polk, Johnston ordered Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Felix Zollicoffer with 4,000 men to occupy Cumberland Gap in Kentucky in order to block Union troops from coming into eastern Tennessee.
711	By September 18, Johnston had Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Simon Bolivar Buckner with another 4,000 men blocking the railroad route to Tennessee at Bowling Green, Kentucky.
711	Johnston had less than 40,000 men spread throughout Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas and Missouri.
711	Of these, 10,000 were in Missouri under Missouri State Guard Maj.
711	Gen.
711	Sterling Price.
711	Johnston's initial call upon the governors for more men did not result in many immediate recruits but Johnston had another, even bigger, problem since his force was seriously short of arms and ammunition even for the troops he had.
711	As the Confederate government concentrated efforts on the units in the East, they gave Johnston only small numbers of reinforcements and minimal amounts of arms and material.
711	Johnston could only keep up his defense by raids and other measures to make it appear he had larger forces than he did, a strategy that worked for several months.
711	Johnston's tactics had so annoyed and confused Union Brig.
711	Gen.
711	William Tecumseh Sherman that he became somewhat unnerved, overestimated Johnston's forces, and had to be relieved by Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Don Carlos Buell on November 9, 1861.
711	Battle of Mill Springs Eastern Tennessee was held for the Confederacy by two unimpressive brigadier generals appointed by Jefferson Davis, Felix Zollicoffer, a brave but untrained and inexperienced officer, and soon to be Maj.
711	Gen.
711	George B.
711	Crittenden, a former U.S.
711	Army officer with apparent alcohol problems.
711	While Crittenden was away in Richmond, Zollicoffer moved his forces to the north bank of the upper Cumberland River near Mill Springs (now Nancy, Kentucky), putting the river to his back and his forces into a trap.
711	Zollicoffer decided it was impossible to obey orders to return to the other side of the river because of scarcity of transport and proximity of Union troops.
711	When Union Brig.
711	Gen.
711	George H.
711	Thomas moved against the Confederates, Crittenden decided to attack one of the two parts of Thomas's command at Logan's Cross Roads near Mill Springs before the Union forces could unite.
711	On January 19, 1862, the ill-prepared Confederates, after a night march in the rain, attacked the Union force with some initial success.
711	As the battle progressed, Zollicoffer was killed, Crittenden was unable to lead the Confederate force since he was probably intoxicated and the Confederates were turned back and routed by a Union bayonet charge, suffering 533 casualties from their force of 4,000.
711	The Confederate troops who escaped were assigned to other units as Crittenden faced an investigation of his conduct.
711	After this Confederate defeat at the Battle of Mill Springs, Davis sent Johnston a brigade and a few other scattered reinforcements, and he sent Gen.
711	P.G.T.
711	Beauregard, who was supposed to attract recruits because of his victories early in the war and give Johnston a competent subordinate.
711	The brigade, however, came with the incompetent Brig.
711	Gen.
711	John B.
711	Floyd, who was to take command at Fort Donelson as the senior general present just before Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Grant attacked the fort.
711	Beauregard's move to the west contributed to the movement of the Union commanders into action against the forts so they could act before, in their view, Beauregard could make a difference in the theater.
711	They had heard that he was bringing 15 regiments with him, but this actually was not true.
711	Fort Henry, Fort Donelson, Nashville Based on the assumption that Kentucky neutrality would act as a shield against a direct invasion from the north, Tennessee initially had sent men to Virginia and concentrated defenses in the Mississippi Valley, circumstances that no longer applied in September 1861.
711	Even before Johnston arrived in Tennessee, two forts had been started to defend the Tennessee River and the Cumberland River which provided avenues into the State from the north.
711	Both had been sited in Tennessee, however, in order to respect Kentucky neutrality and were not in ideal locations.
711	Fort Henry on the Tennessee River was in an especially unfavorable low–lying location commanded by hills on the Kentucky side of the river.
711	Fort Donelson on the Cumberland River, although in a better location, also was not well–sited, had a vulnerable land side and did not have enough heavy artillery for its defense against gunboats.
711	Maj.
711	Gen.
711	Polk ignored the problems of Fort Henry and Fort Donelson when he took command and, after Johnston took command, at first refused to comply with Johnston's order to send an engineer, Lt.
711	Joseph K.
711	Dixon, to inspect the forts.
711	After Johnston asserted his authority, Polk ultimately had to allow Dixon to proceed.
711	Dixon recommended that the forts be maintained and strengthened, even though they were not in ideal locations, because much work had been done on them and the Confederates might not have time to build new ones.
711	Johnston accepted the recommendations.
711	Johnston wanted Major, later Lt.
711	Gen., Alexander P.
711	Stewart to command the forts but President Davis appointed Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Lloyd Tilghman as commander.
711	Then, in order to prevent Polk from dissipating his forces by implementing his proposal to allow some men to join a partisan group, Johnston ordered him to send Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Gideon Pillow and 5,000 men to Fort Donelson.
711	Pillow took up a position at nearby Clarksville, Tennessee and did not move into the fort itself until February 7, 1862.
711	Alerted by a Union reconnaissance on January 14, 1862, Johnston ordered Tilghman to fortify the high ground opposite Fort Henry, which Polk had failed to do despite Johnston's orders.
711	Tilghman also failed to act decisively on these orders, which in any event were now too late to be adequately carried out.
711	Gen.
711	Beauregard arrived at Johnston's headquarters at Bowling Green on February 4, 1862 and was given overall command of Polk's force at the western end of Johnston's line at Columbus, Kentucky.
711	On February 6, 1862, Union Navy gunboats quickly reduced the defenses of ill-sited Fort Henry, inflicting 21 casualties on the small remaining Confederate force.
711	Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Lloyd Tilghman surrendered the 94 remaining officers and men of his approximately 3,000-man force which had not been sent to Fort Donelson before U.S.
711	Grant's force could even take up their positions.
711	Johnston knew he could be trapped at Bowling Green if Fort Donelson fell, so he moved his force to Nashville, the capital of Tennessee and an increasingly important Confederate industrial center, beginning on February 11, 1862.
711	Johnston also reinforced Fort Donelson with 12,000 more men, including those under Floyd and Pillow, a curious decision in view of his thought that the Union gunboats alone might be able to take the fort.
711	He did order the commanders of the fort to evacuate the troops if the fort could not be held.
711	The senior generals sent to the fort to command the enlarged garrison, Gideon J.
711	Pillow and John B.
711	Floyd, squandered their chance to avoid having to surrender most of the garrison and on February 16, 1862, Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Simon Buckner, having been abandoned by Floyd and  Pillow, surrendered Fort Donelson.
711	Colonel Nathan Bedford Forrest escaped with his cavalry force of about 700 men before the surrender.
711	The Confederates suffered about 1,500 casualties with an estimated 12,000 to 14,000 taken prisoner.
711	Union casualties were 500 killed, 2,108 wounded, 224 missing.
711	Johnston, who had little choice in allowing Floyd and Pillow to take charge at Fort Donelson on the basis of seniority after he ordered them to add their forces to the garrison, took the blame and suffered calls for his removal because a full explanation to the press and public would have exposed the weakness of the Confederate position.
711	His passive defensive performance while positioning himself in a forward position at Bowling Green, spreading his forces too thinly, not concentrating his forces in the face of Union advances, and appointing or relying upon inadequate or incompetent subordinates subjected him to criticism at the time and by later historians.
711	The fall of the forts exposed Nashville to imminent attack, and it fell without resistance to Union forces under Brig.
711	Gen.
711	Buell on February 25, 1862, two days after Johnston had to pull his forces out in order to avoid having them captured as well.
