711	Concentration at Corinth Johnston had various remaining military units scattered throughout his territorration ay and retreating to the south to avoid being cut off.
711	Johnston himself retreated with the force under his personal command, the Army of Central Kentucky, from the vicinity of Nashville.
711	With Beauregard's help, Johnston decided to concentrate forces with those formerly under Polk and now already under Beauregard's command at the strategically located railroad crossroads of Corinth, Mississippi, which he reached by a circuitous route.
711	Johnston kept the Union forces, now under the overall command of the ponderous Maj.
711	Gen.
711	Henry Halleck, confused and hesitant to move, allowing Johnston to reach his objective undetected.
711	This delay allowed Jefferson Davis finally to send reinforcements from the garrisons of coastal cities and another highly rated but prickly general, Braxton Bragg, to help organize the western forces.
711	Bragg at least calmed the nerves of Beauregard and Polk who had become agitated by their apparent dire situation in the face of numerically superior forces before the arrival of Johnston on March 24, 1862.
711	Johnston's army of 17,000 men gave the Confederates a combined force of about 40,000 to 44,669 men at Corinth.
711	On March 29, 1862, Johnston officially took command of this combined force, which continued to use the Army of the Mississippi name under which it had been organized by Beauregard on March 5.
711	Johnston now planned to defeat the Union forces piecemeal before the various Union units in Kentucky and Tennessee under Grant with 40,000 men at nearby Pittsburg Landing, Tennessee, and the now Maj.
711	Gen.
711	Don Carlos Buell on his way from Nashville with 35,000 men, could unite against him.
711	Johnston started his army in motion on April 3, 1862, intent on surprising Grant's force as soon as the next day, but they moved slowly due to their inexperience, bad roads and lack of adequate staff planning.
711	Johnston's army was finally in position within a mile or two of Grant's force, and undetected, by the evening of April 5, 1862.
711	Battle of Shiloh and death Johnston launched a massive surprise attack with his concentrated forces against Grant at the Battle of Shiloh on April 6, 1862.
711	As the Confederate forces overran the Union camps, Johnston seemed to be everywhere, personally leading and rallying troops up and down the line on his horse.
711	At about 2:30 p.m., while leading one of those charges against a Union camp near the "Peach Orchard", he was wounded, taking a bullet behind his right knee.
711	He apparently did not think the wound was serious at the time, and so he sent his personal physician to attend to some wounded captured Union soldiers instead.
711	It is possible that Johnston's duel in 1837 had caused nerve damage or numbness to his right leg and that he did not feel the wound to his leg as a result.
711	The bullet had in fact clipped a part of his popliteal artery and his boot was filling up with blood.
711	Within a few minutes, Johnston was observed by his staff to be nearly fainting off his horse.
711	Among his staff was Isham G.
711	Harris, the Governor of Tennessee, who had ceased to make any real effort to function as governor after learning that Abraham Lincoln had appointed Andrew Johnson as military governor of Tennessee.
711	Seeing Johnston slumping in his saddle and his face turning deathly pale, Harris asked: "General, are you wounded?"
711	Johnston glanced down at his leg wound, then faced Harris and replied with his last words: "Yes, and I fear seriously."
711	Harris and other staff officers removed Johnston from his horse and carried him to a small ravine near the "Hornets Nest" and desperately tried to aid the general by trying to make a tourniquet for his leg wound, but little could be done by this point since he had already lost so much blood.
711	He soon lost consciousness and bled to death a few minutes later.
711	Harris and the other officers wrapped General Johnston's body in a blanket so as not to damage the troops' morale with the sight of the dead general.
711	Johnston and his wounded horse, named Fire Eater, were taken to his field headquarters on the Corinth road, where his body remained in his tent until the Confederate Army withdrew to Corinth the next day, April 7, 1862.
711	From there, his body was taken to the home of Colonel William Inge, which had been his headquarters in Corinth.
711	It was covered in the Confederate flag and laid in state for several hours.
711	It is probable that a Confederate soldier fired the fatal round.
711	No Union soldiers were observed to have ever gotten behind Johnston during the fatal charge, while it is known that many Confederates were firing at the Union lines while Johnston charged well in advance of his soldiers.
711	Johnston was the highest-ranking casualty of the war on either side, and his death was a strong blow to the morale of the Confederacy.
711	Jefferson Davis considered him the bestis death general in the country; this was two months before the emergence of Robert E.
711	Lee as the pre-eminent general of the Confederacy.
711	Epitaph Johnston was initially buried in New Orleans.
711	In 1866, a joint resolution of the Texas Legislature was passed to have his body reinterred to the Texas State Cemetery in Austin The re-interment occurred in 1867.
711	Forty years later, the state appointed Elisabet Ney to design a monument and sculpture of him to be erected at his gravesite.
711	The Texas Historical Commission has erected a historical marker near the entrance of what was once his plantation.
711	An adjacent marker was erected by the San Jacinto Chapter of the Daughters of The Republic of Texas and the Lee, Roberts, and Davis Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederate States of America.
711	The University of Texas at Austin has also recognized Johnston with a statue on the South Mall.
713	An android is a robot or synthetic organism designed to look and act like a human, especially one with a body having a flesh-like resemblance.
713	Until recently, androids have largely remained within the domain of science fiction, frequently seen in film and television.
713	However, advancements in robotic technology have allowed the design of functional and realistic humanoid robots.
713	Etymology The word was coined from the Greek root ἀνδρ- 'man' and the suffix -oid 'having the form or likeness of'.
713	The term "droid", coined by George Lucas for the original Star Wars film and now used widely within science fiction, originated as an abridgment of "android", but has been used by Lucas and others to mean any robot, including distinctly non-human form machines like R2-D2.
713	The word "android" was used in Star Trek: The Original Series episode What Are Little Girls Made Of?
713	The abbreviation "andy", coined as a pejorative by writer Philip K.
713	Dick in his novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?, has seen some further usage, such as within the TV series Total Recall 2070.
713	The Oxford English Dictionary traces the earliest use (as "Androides") to Ephraim Chambers' Cyclopaedia, in reference to an automaton that St.
713	Albertus Magnus allegedly created.
713	The term "android" appears in US patents as early as 1863 in reference to miniature human-like toy automatons.
713	The term android was used in a more modern sense by the French author Auguste Villiers de l'Isle-Adam in his work Tomorrow's Eve (1886).
713	This story features an artificial humanlike robot named Hadaly.
713	As said by the officer in the story, "In this age of Realien advancement, who knows what goes on in the mind of those responsible for these mechanical dolls."
713	The term made an impact into English pulp science fiction starting from Jack Williamson's The Cometeers (1936) and the distinction between mechanical robots and fleshy androids was popularized by Edmond Hamilton's Captain Future (1940–1944).
713	Although Karel Čapek's robots in R.U.R.
713	Rossum's Universal Robots) (1921) – the play that introduced the word robot to the world – were organic artificial humans, the word "robot" has come to primarily refer to mechanical humans, animals, and other beings.
713	The term "android" can mean either one of these, while a cyborg ("cybernetic organism" or "bionic man") would be a creature that is a combination of organic and mechanical parts.
713	Authors have used the term android in more diverse ways than robot or cyborg.
713	In some fictional works, the difference between a robot and android is only their appearance, with androids being made to look like humans on the outside but with robot-like internal mechanics.
713	In other stories, authors have used the word "android" to mean a wholly organic, yet artificial, creation.
713	Other fictional depictions of androids fall somewhere in between.
713	Eric G.
713	Wilson, who defines androids as a "synthetic human being", distinguishes between three types of androids, based on their body's composition: * the mummy type - where androids are made of "dead things" or "stiff, inanimate, natural material", such as mummies, puppets, dolls and statues * the golem type - androids made from flexible, possibly organic material, including golems and homunculi * the automaton type - androids which are a mix of dead and living parts, including automatons and robots Although human morphology is not necessarily the ideal form for working robots, the fascination in developing robots that can mimic it can be found historically in the assimilation of two concepts: simulacra (devices that exhibit likeness) and automata (devices that have independence).
713	Projects Japan The Intelligent Robotics Lab, directed by Hiroshi Ishiguro at Osaka University, and Kokoro Co., Ltd.
713	Actroid at Expo 2005 in Aichi Prefecture, Japan.
713	In 2006, Kokoro Co.
713	DER 2 android.
713	The height of the human body part of DER2 is 165 cm.
713	There are 47 mobile points.
713	DER2 can not only change its expression but also move its hands and feet and twist its body.
713	The "air servosystem" which Kokoro Co.
713	As a result of having an actuator controlled precisely with air pressure via a servosystem, the movement is very fluid and there is very little noise.
713	DER2 realized a slimmer body than that of the former version by using a smaller cylinder.
713	Outwardly DER2 has a more beautiful proportion.
713	Compared to the previous model, DER2 has thinner arms and a wider repertoire of expressions.
713	Once programmed, it is able to choreograph its motions and gestures with its voice.
713	The Intelligent Mechatronics Lab, directed by Hiroshi Kobayashi at the Tokyo University of Science, has developed an android head called Saya, which was exhibited at Robodex 2002 in Yokohama, Japan.
713	There are several other initiatives around the world involving humanoid research and development at this time, which will hopefulatives around the world involy introduce a broader spectrum of realized technology in the near future.
713	Now Saya is working at the Science University of Tokyo as a guide.
713	The Waseda University (Japan) and NTT Docomo's manufacturers have succeeded in creating a shape-shifting robot WD-2.
713	It is capable of changing its face.
713	At first, the creators decided the positions of the necessary points to express the outline, eyes, nose, and so on of a certain person.
713	The robot expresses its face by moving all points to the decided positions, they say.
713	The first version of the robot was first developed back in 2003.
713	After that, a year later, they made a couple of major improvements to the design.
713	The robot features an elastic mask made from the average head dummy.
713	It uses a driving system with a 3DOF unit.
713	The WD-2 robot can change its facial features by activating specific facial points on a mask, with each point possessing three degrees of freedom.
713	This one has 17 facial points, for a total of 56 degrees of freedom.
713	As for the materials they used, the WD-2's mask is fabricated with a highly elastic material called Septom, with bits of steel wool mixed in for added strength.
713	Other technical features reveal a shaft driven behind the mask at the desired facial point, driven by a DC motor with a simple pulley and a slide screw.
713	Apparently, the researchers can also modify the shape of the mask based on actual human faces.
713	To "copy" a face, they need only a 3D scanner to determine the locations of an individual's 17 facial points.
713	After that, they are then driven into position using a laptop and 56 motor control boards.
713	In addition, the researchers also mention that the shifting robot can even display an individual's hair style and skin color if a photo of their face is projected onto the 3D Mask.
713	Korea KITECH researched and developed EveR-1, an android interpersonal communications model capable of emulating human emotional expression via facial "musculature" and capable of rudimentary conversation, having a vocabulary of around 400 words.
713	She is  tall and weighs , matching the average figure of a Korean women in her twenties.
713	EveR-1's name derives from the Biblical Eve, plus the letter r for robot.
713	EveR-1's advanced computing processing power enables speech recognition and vocal synthesis, at the same time processing lip synchronization and visual recognition by 90-degree micro-CCD cameras with face recognition technology.
713	An independent microchip inside her artificial brain handles gesture expression, body coordination, and emotion expression.
713	Her whole body is made of highly advanced synthetic jelly silicon and with 60 artificial joints in her face, neck, and lower body; she is able to demonstrate realistic facial expressions and sing while simultaneously dancing.
713	In South Korea, the Ministry of Information and Communication  has an ambitious plan to put a robot in every household by 2020.
713	Several robot cities have been planned for the country: the first will be built in 2009 at a cost of 500 billion won, of which 50 billion is direct government investment.
713	The new robot city will feature research and development centers for manufacturers and part suppliers, as well as exhibition halls and a stadium for robot competitions.
713	The country's new Robotics Ethics Charter will establish ground rules and laws for human interaction with robots in the future, setting standards for robotics users and manufacturers, as well as guidelines on ethical standards to be programmed into robots to prevent human abuse of robots and vice versa.
713	United States Walt Disney and a staff of Imagineers created Great Moments with Mr.
713	Lincoln that debuted at the 1964 New York World's Fair.
713	Hanson Robotics, Inc., of Texas and KAIST produced an android portrait of Albert Einstein, using Hanson's facial android technology mounted on KAIST's life-size walking bipedal robot body.
713	This Einstein android, also called "Albert Hubo", thus represents the first full-body walking android in history (see video at ).
713	Hanson Robotics, the FedEx Institute of Technology, and the University of Texas at Arlington also developed the android portrait of sci-fi author Philip K.
713	Dick (creator of Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?, the basis for the film Blade Runner), with full conversational capabilities that incorporated thousands of pages of the author's works.
713	In 2005, the PKD android won a first place artificial intelligence award from AAAI.
713	United Kingdom In 2001, Steve Grand OBE, creator of the computer game, Creatures, created an android, or anthropoid, he named Lucy.
713	The intention was that she would have to learn everything, including how to use her mechanical vocal chords to speak.
713	Her systems were made to be similar to a human's.
713	Use in fiction Androids are a staple of science fiction.
713	Isaac Asimov pioneered the fictionalization of the science of robotics and artificial intelligence, notably in his 1950s series I, Robot and Foundation and Empire.
713	One thing common to most fictional androids is that the real-life technological challenges associated with creating thoroughly human-like robots – such as the creation of strong artificial intelligence – are assumed to have been solved.
713	Fictional androids are often depicted as mentally and physically equal or superior to humans – moving, thinking and speaking as fluidly as them.
713	The tension between the nonhuman substance and the human appearance – or even human ambitions – of androids is the dramatic impetus behind most of their fictional depictions.
713	Some android heroes seek, like Pinocchio, to becomgt; or Data in Star Trek: The Next Generation.
713	Others, as in the film Westworld, rebel against abuse by careless humans.
713	Android hunter Deckard in Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
713	Blade Runner discovers that his targets are, in some ways, more human than he is.
713	Android stories, therefore, are not essentially stories "about" androids; they are stories about the human condition and what it means to be human.
713	One aspect of writing about the meaning of humanity is to use discrimination against androids as a mechanism for exploring racism in society, as in Blade Runner.
713	Perhaps the clearest example of this is John Brunner's 1968 novel Into the Slave Nebula, where the blue-skinned android slaves are explicitly shown to be fully human.
713	More recently, the androids Bishop and Annalee Call in the films Aliens and Alien Resurrection are used as vehicles for exploring how humans deal with the presence of an "Other".
713	Female androids, or "gynoids", are often seen in science fiction, and can be viewed as a continuation of the long tradition of men attempting to create the stereotypical "perfect woman".
713	Examples include the Greek myth of Pygmalion and the female robot Maria in Fritz Lang's Metropolis.
713	Some gynoids, like Pris in Blade Runner, are designed as sex-objects, with the intent of "pleasing men's violent sexual desires," or as submissive, servile companions, such as in The Stepford Wives.
713	Fiction about gynoids has therefore been described as reinforcing "essentialist ideas of femininity", although others have suggested that the treatment of androids is a way of exploring racism and misogyny in society.
717	Alberta is a province of Canada.
717	It had a population of 3,645,257 in 2011, making it the most populous of Canada's three prairie provinces.
717	Alberta and its neighbour, Saskatchewan, were established as provinces on September 1, 1905.
717	Alberta is located in western Canada, bounded by the provinces of British Columbia to the west and Saskatchewan to the east, the Northwest Territories to the north, and the U.S.
717	Montana to the south.
717	Alberta is one of three Canadian provinces and territories to border only a single U.S.
717	Edmonton, the capital city of Alberta, is located near the geographic centre of the province and is the primary supply and service hub for Canada's oil sands and other northern resource industries.
717	Approximately 300 km south of the capital is Calgary, Alberta's largest city and a major distribution and transportation hub.
717	Calgary and Edmonton centre Alberta's two census metropolitan areas, both of which have populations exceeding 1 million, while the province has 16 census agglomerations.
717	Notable tourist destinations in the province include Banff, Canmore, Drumheller, Jasper and Sylvan Lake.
717	The current Premier of the province is Alison Redford.
717	Etymology Alberta is named after Princess Louise Caroline Alberta (1848–1939), the fourth daughter of Victoria, the Queen of Canada until 1901, and Albert, Prince Consort.
717	Princess Louise was the wife of the Marquess of Lorne, Governor General of Canada from 1878 to 1883.
717	Lake Louise and Mount Alberta were also named in honour of Princess Louise.
717	Geography  Alberta, with an area of 661848 km2 is the fourth largest province after Quebec, Ontario, and British Columbia.
717	To the south, the province borders on the 49th parallel north, separating it from the U.S.
717	Montana, while on the north the 60th parallel north divides it from the Northwest Territories.
717	To the east the 110th meridian west separates it from the province of Saskatchewan, while on the west its boundary with British Columbia follows the 120th meridian west south from the Northwest Territories at 60°N until it reaches the Continental Divide at the Rocky Mountains, and from that point follows the line of peaks marking the Continental Divide in a generally southeasterly direction until it reaches the Montana border at 49°N.
717	The province extends 1223 km north to south and 660 km east to west at its maximum width.
717	Its highest point is 3747 m at the summit of Mount Columbia in the Rocky Mountains along the southwest border, while its lowest point is 152 m on the Slave River in Wood Buffalo National Park in the northeast.
717	With the exception of the semi-arid steppe of the southeastern section, the province has adequate water resources.
717	There are numerous rivers and lakes used for swimming, fishing and a range of water sports.
717	There are three large lakes, Lake Claire (1436 km2) in Wood Buffalo National Park, Lesser Slave Lake (1168 km2), and Lake Athabasca (7898 km2) which lies in both Alberta and Saskatchewan.
717	The longest river in the province is the Athabasca River which travels 1538 km from the Columbia Icefield in the Rocky Mountains to Lake Athabasca.
717	The largest river is the Peace River with an average flow of 2161 m3/s.
717	The Peace River originates in the Rocky Mountains of northern British Columbia and flows through northern Alberta and into the Slave River, a tributary of the Mackenzie River.
717	Alberta's capital city, Edmonton, is located approximately in the geographic centre ol Park Albertaf the province.
717	It is the most northerly major city in Canada, and serves as a gateway and hub for resource development in northern Canada.
717	The region, with its proximity to Canada's largest oil fields, has most of western Canada's oil refinery capacity.
717	Calgary is located approximately 280 km south of Edmonton and 240 km north of Montana, surrounded by extensive ranching country.
717	Almost 75% of the province's population lives in the Calgary–Edmonton Corridor.
717	Most of the northern half of the province is boreal forest, while the Rocky Mountains along the southwestern boundary are largely forested (see Alberta Mountain forests and Alberta-British Columbia foothills forests).
717	The southern quarter of the province is prairie, ranging from shortgrass prairie in the southeastern corner to mixed grass prairie in an arc to the west and north of it.
717	The central aspen parkland region extending in a broad arc between the prairies and the forests, from Calgary, north to Edmonton, and then east to Lloydminster, contains the most fertile soil in the province and most of the population.
717	Much of the unforested part of Alberta is given over either to grain or to dairy farming, with mixed farming more common in the north and centre, while ranching and irrigated agriculture predominate in the south.
717	The Alberta badlands are located in southeastern Alberta, where the Red Deer River crosses the flat prairie and farmland, and features deep canyons and striking landforms.
717	Dinosaur Provincial Park, near Brooks, Alberta, showcases the badlands terrain, desert flora, and remnants from Alberta's past when dinosaurs roamed the then lush landscape.
717	Climate  Alberta has a dry continental climate with warm summers and cold winters.
717	The province is open to cold arctic weather systems from the north, which often produce extremely cold conditions in winter.
717	As the fronts between the air masses shift north and south across Alberta, the temperature can change rapidly.
717	Arctic air masses in the winter produce extreme minimum temperatures varying from  in northern Alberta to  in southern Alberta.
717	In the summer, continental air masses produce maximum temperatures from 32 C in the mountains to 40 C in southern Alberta.
717	Alberta extends for over 1200 km from north to south; its climate, therefore, varies considerably.
717	Average high temperatures in January range from 0 C in the southwest to  in the far north.
717	The climate is also influenced by the presence of the Rocky Mountains to the southwest, which disrupt the flow of the prevailing westerly winds and cause them to drop most of their moisture on the western slopes of the mountain ranges before reaching the province, casting a rain shadow over much of Alberta.
717	The northerly location and isolation from the weather systems of the Pacific Ocean cause Alberta to have a dry climate with little moderation from the ocean.
717	Annual precipitation ranges from 300 mm in the southeast to 450 mm in the north, except in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains where total precipitation including snowfall can reach 600 mm annually.
717	The province is the namesake of the Alberta clipper, a type of intense, fast-moving winter storm that generally forms over or near the province and descends with great speed over the rest of Canada and the northern United States.
717	In the summer, the average daytime temperatures range from around 21 C in the Rocky Mountain valleys and far north, up to around 28 C in the dry prairie of the southeast.
717	The northern and western parts of the province experience higher rainfall and lower evaporation rates caused by cooler summer temperatures.
717	The south and east-central portions are prone to drought-like conditions sometimes persisting for several years, although even these areas can receive heavy precipitation.
717	Alberta is a sunny province.
717	Annual bright sunshine totals range between 1900 up to just under 2600 hours per year.
717	Northern Alberta gets about 18 hours of daylight in the summer.
717	In southwestern Alberta, the cold winters are frequently interrupted by warm, dry chinook winds blowing from the mountains, which can propel temperatures upward from frigid conditions to well above the freezing point in a very short period.
717	During one chinook recorded at Pincher Creek, temperatures soared from  in just one hour.
717	The region around Lethbridge has the most chinooks, averaging 30 to 35 chinook days per year.
717	Calgary has a 56% chance of a white Christmas, while Edmonton has an 86% chance.
717	Northern Alberta is mostly covered by boreal forest and has a subarctic climate.
717	The agricultural area of southern Alberta have a semi-arid steppe climate because the annual precipitation is less than the water that evaporates or is used by plants.
717	The southeastern corner of Alberta, part of the Palliser Triangle, experiences greater summer heat and lower rainfall than the rest of the province, and as a result suffers frequent crop yield problems and occasional severe droughts.
717	Western Alberta is protected by the mountains and enjoys the mild temperatures brought by winter chinook winds.
717	Central and parts of northwestern Alberta in the Peace River region are largely aspen parkland, a biome transitional between prairie to the south and boreal forest to the north.
717	After Southern Ontario, Central Alberta is the most likely region in Canada to experience tornadoes.
717	Thunderstorms, some of them severe, are frequent in the summer, especially in central and southern Alberta.
717	The region surrounding the Calgary–Edmonton Corridor is notable for having the highest frequency of hail in Canada, which is caused by orographic lifting from the nearby Rocky Mountains, enhancing the updraft/downdraft cycle necessary for the formation of hail.
717	Ecology  Flora  In central and northern Alberta the arrival of spring brings the prairie crocus anemone, the three flowered avens, golden bean, wild rose and other early flowers.
717	The advancing summer introduces many flowers of the sunflower family.
717	The southern and east central parts of Alberta are covered by a short, prairie grass, which dries up as summer lengthens, to be replaced by hardy perennials such as the prairie coneflower, fleabane, and sage.
717	Both yellow and white sweet clover can be found throughout the southern and central areas of the province.
717	The trees in the parkland region of the province grow in clumps and belts on the hillsides.
717	These are largely deciduous, typically aspen, poplar, and willow.
717	Many species of willow and other shrubs grow in virtually any terrain.
717	On the north side of the North Saskatchewan River evergreen forests prevail for thousands of square kilometres.
717	Aspen poplar, balsam poplar (or cottonwood), and paper birch are the primary large deciduous species.
717	Conifers include Jack pine, Rocky Mountain pine, Lodgepole pine, both white and black spruce, and the deciduous conifer tamarack.
717	Fauna  The four climatic regions (alpine, boreal forest, parkland, and prairie) of Alberta are home to many different species of animals.
717	The south and central prairie was the land of the bison, commonly known as buffalo, its grasses providing pasture and breeding ground for millions of buffalo.
717	The buffalo population was decimated during early settlement, but since then buffalo have made a comeback, living on farms and in parks all over Alberta.
717	Alberta is home to many large carnivores.
717	Among them are the grizzly and black bears, which are found in the mountains and wooded regions.
717	Smaller carnivores of the canine and feline families include coyotes, wolves, fox, lynx, bobcat and mountain lion (cougar).
717	Herbivorous animals are found throughout the province.
717	Moose, mule deer, elk, and white-tail deer are found in the wooded regions, and pronghorn can be found in the prairies of southern Alberta.
717	Bighorn sheep and mountain goats live in the Rocky Mountains.
717	Rabbits, porcupines, skunks, squirrels and many species of rodents and reptiles live in every corner of the province.
717	Alberta is home to only one variety of venomous snake, the prairie rattlesnake.
717	Central and northern Alberta and the region farther north is the nesting ground of many migratory birds.
717	Vast numbers of ducks, geese, swans and pelicans arrive in Alberta every spring and nest on or near one of the hundreds of small lakes that dot northern Alberta.
717	Eagles, hawks, owls and crows are plentiful, and a huge variety of smaller seed and insect-eating birds can be found.
717	Alberta, like other temperate regions, is home to mosquitoes, flies, wasps, and bees.
717	Rivers and lakes are populated with pike, walleye, whitefish, rainbow, speckled, and brown trout, and even sturgeon.
717	Bull Trout, native to the province, is the Alberta's provincial fish.
717	Turtles are found in some water bodies in the southern part of the province.
717	Frogs and salamanders are a few of the amphibians that make their homes in Alberta.
717	Alberta is the only province in Canada—as well as one of the few places in the world—that is free of Norwegian rats.
717	Since the early 1950s, the government of Alberta has operated a rat-control program, which has been so successful that only isolated instances of wild rat sightings are reported, usually of rats arriving in the province aboard trucks or by rail.
717	In 2006, Alberta Agriculture reports zero findings of wild rats; the only rat interceptions have been domesticated rats that have been seized from their owners.
717	It is illegal for individual Albertans to own or keep Norwegian rats of any description; the animals can be kept in the province by only zoos, universities and colleges, and recognized research institutions.
717	In 2009, several rats were found and captured, in small pockets in southern Alberta, putting Alberta's rat-free status in jeopardy.
717	A colony of rats were subsequently found in a landfill near Medicine Hat in 2012.
717	Paleontology  Alberta has one of the greatest diversities and abundances of Late Cretaceous dinosaur fossils in the world.
717	Taxa are represented by complete fossil skeletons, isolated material, microvertebrate remains, and even mass graves.
717	At least 38 dinosaur type specimens are known from the province.
717	The Foremost Formation, Oldman Formation and Dinosaur Park Formations collectively comprise the Judith River Group and are the most thoroughly studied dinosaur bearing strata in Alberta.
717	The stratigraphy of the Judith River Group has a confusing history due partly to the use of the Montana-Alberta border as an artificial division between equivalent strata.
717	The modern Judith River Group stratigraphy was not finalized until 1993 when Eberth and Hamblin divided the Oldman Formation in two to create the new Dinosaur Park Formation.
717	The resulting paleontological confusion was resolved by Phil Currie who relocated old quarries dinosaurs had been found in and determined their distribution within the modern stratigraphic framework.
717	Dinosaur-bearing strata are distributed widely throughout Alberta.
717	The Dinosaur Provincial Park area contains outcrops of the Dinosaur Park Formation and Oldman Formation.
717	In the central and southern regions of Alberta are intermittent Scollard Formation outcrops.
717	In the Drumheller Valley and Edmonton regions there are exposed Horseshoe Canyon facies.
717	Other formations have been recorded as well, like the Milk River and Foremost Formations.
717	However, these latter two have a lower diversity of documented dinosaurs, primarily due to their lower total fossil quantity and neglect from collectors who are hindered by the isolation and scarcity of exposed outcrops.
717	Their dinosaur fossils are primarily teeth recovered from microvertebrate fossil sites.
717	Additional geologic formations that have produced only few fossils are the Belly River Group and St.
717	Mary River Formations of the southwest and the northwestern Wapiti Formation.
717	The Wapiti Formations contains two Pachyrhinosaurus bone beds that break its general trend of low productivity, however.
717	The Bearpaw Formation represents strata deposited during a marine transgression.
717	Dinosaurs are known from this Formation, but represent specimens washed out to sea or reworked from older sediments.
717	History  The first people in Alberta were Paleo-Indians who arrived in Alberta at least 10,000 years ago, toward the end of the last ice age.
717	They probably migrated from Siberia to Alaska on a land bridge across the Bering Strait, and then may have moved down the east side of the Rocky Mountains through Alberta to settle the Americas.
717	Alternatively they may have migrated down the coast of British Columbia and then moved inland.
717	Over time they differentiated into various First Nations peoples, including the Plains Indian tribes of southern Alberta such as those of the Blackfoot Confederacy and the Plains Cree, who generally lived by hunting buffalo (American bison), and the more northerly tribes such as the Woodland Cree and Chipewyan who hunted, trapped, and fished for a living.
717	After the British arrival in Canada, approximately half of the province of Alberta, south of the Athabasca River drainage, became part of Rupert's Land which consisted of all land drained by rivers flowing into Hudson Bay.
717	This area was granted by Charles II of England to the Hudson's Bay Company (HBC) in 1670, and rival fur trading companies were not allowed to trade in it.
717	After the arrival of French Canadians in the west around 1731, they settled near fur trading posts, establishing communities such as Lac La Biche and Bonnyville.
717	Fort La Jonquière was established near what is now Calgary in 1752.
717	The Athabasca River and the rivers north of it were not in HBC territory because they drained into the Arctic Ocean instead of Hudson Bay, and they were prime habitat for fur-bearing animals.
717	The first explorer of the Athabasca region was Peter Pond, who learned of the Methye Portage, which allowed travel from southern rivers into the rivers north of Rupert's Land.
717	Fur traders formed the North West Company (NWC) of Montreal to compete with the HBC in 1779.
717	The NWC occupied the northern part of Alberta territory.
717	Peter Pond built Fort Athabasca on Lac la Biche in 1778.
717	Roderick Mackenzie built Fort Chipewyan on Lake Athabasca ten years later in 1788.
717	His cousin, Sir Alexander Mackenzie, followed the North Saskatchewan River to its northernmost point near Edmonton, then setting northward on foot, trekked to the Athabasca River, which he followed to Lake Athabasca.
717	It was there he discovered the mighty outflow river which bears his name—the Mackenzie River—which he followed to its outlet in the Arctic Ocean.
717	Returning to Lake Athabasca, he followed the Peace River upstream, eventually reaching the Pacific Ocean, and so he became the first white man to cross the North American continent north of Mexico.
717	The extreme southernmost portion of Alberta was part of the French (and Spanish) territory of Louisiana, sold to the United States in 1803; in 1818, the portion of Louisiana north of the Forty-Ninth Parallel was ceded to Great Britain.
717	Fur trade expanded in the north, but bloody battles occurred between the rival HBC and NWC, and in 1821 the British government forced them to merge to stop the hostilities.
717	The amalgamated Hudson's Bay Company dominated trade in Alberta until 1870, when the newly formed Canadian Government purchased Rupert's Land.
717	Northern Alberta was included in the North-Western Territory until 1870, when it and Rupert's land became Canada's Northwest Territories.
717	The district of Alberta was created as part of the North-West Territories in 1882.
717	As settlement increased, local representatives to the North-West Legislative Assembly were added.
717	After a long campaign for autonomy, in 1905 the district of Alberta was enlarged and givenre added.
717	After a provincial status, with the election of Alexander Cameron Rutherford as the first premier.
717	Demographics  Alberta has experienced a relatively high rate of growth in recent years, mainly because of its burgeoning economy.
717	Between 2003 and 2004, the province had high birthrates (on par with some larger provinces such as British Columbia), relatively high immigration, and a high rate of interprovincial migration when compared to other provinces.
717	Approximately 81% of the population live in urban areas and only about 19% live in rural areas.
717	The Calgary-Edmonton Corridor is the most urbanized area in the province and is one of the most densely populated areas of Canada.
717	Many of Alberta's cities and towns have also experienced very high rates of growth in recent history.
717	Over the past century, Alberta's population rose from 73,022 in 1901 to 2,974,807 in 2001 and 3,290,350 according to the 2006 census.
717	The 2006 census found that English, with 2,576,670 native speakers, was the most common mother tongue of Albertans, representing 79.99% of the province's population.
717	The next most common mother tongues were various Chinese languages with 97,275 native speakers (3.02%), followed by German with 84,505 native speakers (2.62%) and French with 61,225 (1.90%).
717	Other mother tongues (in decreasing order) include: Punjabi, with 36,320 native speakers (1.13%); Tagalog, with 29,740 (0.92%); Ukrainian, with 29,455 (0.91%); Spanish, with 29,125 (0.90%); Polish, with 21,990 (0.68%); Arabic, with 20,495 (0.64%); Dutch, with 19,980 (0.62%); and Vietnamese, with 19,350 (0.60%).
717	The most common aboriginal language is Cree 17,215 (0.53%).
717	Other common mother tongues include Italian with 13,095 speakers (0.41%); Urdu with 11,275 (0.35%); and Korean with 10,845 (0.33%); then Hindi 8,985 (0.28%); Persian 7,700 (0.24%); Portuguese 7,205 (0.22%); and Hungarian 6,770 (0.21%).(Figures shown are for the number of single language responses and the percentage of total single-language responses.) Alberta has considerable ethnic diversity.
717	In line with the rest of Canada, many immigrants originated from England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales, but large numbers also came from other parts of Europe, notably Germans, French, Ukrainians and Scandinavians.
717	According to Statistics Canada, Alberta is home to the second highest proportion (two percent) of Francophones in western Canada (after Manitoba).
717	Despite this, relatively few Albertans claim French as their mother tongue.
717	Many of Alberta's French-speaking residents live in the central and northwestern regions of the province.
717	As reported in the 2001 census, the Chinese represented nearly four percent of Alberta's population, and East Indians represented more than two percent.
717	Both Edmonton and Calgary have historic Chinatowns, and Calgary has Canada's third largest Chinese community.
717	The Chinese presence began with workers employed in the building of the Canadian Pacific Railway in the 1880s.
717	Aboriginal Albertans make up approximately three percent of the population.
717	In the 2006 Canadian census, the most commonly reported ethnic origins among Albertans were: 885,825 English (27.2%); 679,705 German (20.9%); 667,405 Canadian (20.5%); 661,265 Scottish (20.3%); 539,160 Irish (16.6%); 388,210 French (11.9%); 332,180 Ukrainian (10.2%); 172,910 Dutch (5.3%); 170,935 Polish (5.2%); 169,355 North American Indian (5.2%); 144,585 Norwegian (4.4%); and 137,600 Chinese (4.2%).
717	Each person could choose as many ethnicities as were applicable.) Amongst those of British origins, the Scots have had a particularly strong influence on place-names, with the names of many cities and towns including Calgary, Airdrie, Canmore, and Banff having Scottish origins.
717	Alberta is the third most diverse province in terms of visible minorities after British Columbia and Ontario with 13.9% of the population consisting of visible minorities.
717	Nearly one-fourth of the populations of Calgary and Edmonton belong to a visible minority group.
717	Aboriginal Identity Peoples make up 5.8% of the population, about half of whom consist of North American Indians and the other half are Metis.
717	There are also small number of Inuit people in Alberta.
717	The number of Aboriginal Identity Peoples have been increasing at a rate greater than the population of Alberta.
717	As of the Canada 2001 Census the largest religious group was Roman Catholic, representing 25.7% of the population.
717	Alberta had the second highest percentage of non-religious residents in Canada (after British Columbia) at 23.1% of the population.
717	Of the remainder, 13.5% of the population identified themselves as belonging to the United Church of Canada, while 5.9% were Anglican.
717	Lutherans made up 4.8% of the population while Baptists comprised 2.5%.
717	The remainder belonged to a wide variety of different religious affiliations, none of which constituted more than 2% of the population.
717	The Mormons of Alberta reside primarily in the extreme south of the province and made up 1.7% of the population.
717	Alberta has a population of Hutterites, a communal Anabaptist sect similar to the Mennonites (Hutterites represented 0.4% of the population while Mennonites were 0.8%), and has a significant population of Seventh-day Adventists at 0.3%.
717	Alberta is home to several Byzantine Rite Churches as part of the legacy of Eastern European immigration, including the Ukrainian Catholic Eparchy of Edmonton, and the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Canada's Western Diocese which is based in Edmonton.
717	Muslims, Sikhs, and Hindus live in Alberta.
717	Muslims constituted 1.7% of the population, Sikhs 0.8% and Hindus 0.5%.
717	Many of these are recent immigrants, but others have roots that go back to the first settlers of the prairies.
717	Canada's oldest mosque, the Al-Rashid Mosque, is located in Edmonton, whereas Calgary is home to Canada's largest mosque, the Baitun Nur mosque.
717	Jews constituted 0.4% of Alberta's population.
717	Most of Alberta's 13,000 Jews live in Calgary (7,500) and Edmonton (5,000).
717	Municipalities  ;Largest metro areas and municipalities by population as of 2006 Economy  Alberta's economy is one of the strongest in Canada, supported by the burgeoning petroleum industry and to a lesser extent, agriculture and technology.
717	The per capita GDP in 2007 was by far the highest of any province in Canada at C$74,825.
717	This was 61% higher than the national average of C$46,441 and more than twice that of some of the Atlantic provinces.
717	In 2006 the deviation from the national average was the largest for any province in Canadian history.
717	According to the 2006 census, the median annual family income after taxes was $70,986 in Alberta (compared to $60,270 in Canada as a whole).
717	The Calgary-Edmonton Corridor is the most urbanized region in the province and one of the densest in Canada.
717	The region covers a distance of roughly 400 kilometres north to south.
717	In 2001, the population of the Calgary-Edmonton Corridor was 2.15 million (72% of Alberta's population).
717	It is also one of the fastest growing regions in the country.
717	A 2003 study by TD Bank Financial Group found the corridor to be the only Canadian urban centre to amass a U.S.
717	Canadian style quality of life, offering universal health care benefits.
717	The study found that GDP per capita in the corridor was 10% above average U.S.
717	Canadian cities at that time.
717	The Fraser Institute states that Alberta also has very high levels of economic freedom and rates Alberta as the freest economy in Canada, and the second freest economy amongst U.S.
717	Canadian provinces.
717	Industry  Alberta is the largest producer of conventional crude oil, synthetic crude, natural gas and gas products in the country.
717	Alberta is the world’s 2nd largest exporter of natural gas and the 4th largest producer.
717	Two of the largest producers of petrochemicals in North America are located in central and north-central Alberta.
717	In both Red Deer and Edmonton, world class polyethylene and vinyl manufacturers produce products shipped all over the world, and Edmonton's oil refineries provide the raw materials for a large petrochemical industry to the east of Edmonton.
717	The Athabasca oil sands have estimated unconventional oil reserves approximately equal to the conventional oil reserves of the rest of the world, estimated to be 1.6 trillion barrels (254 km3).
717	With the development of new extraction methods such as steam assisted gravity drainage, which was developed in Alberta, bitumen and synthetic crude oil can be produced at costs close to those of conventional crude.
717	Many companies employ both conventional strip mining and non-conventional in situ methods to extract the bitumen from the oil sands.
717	With current technology and at current prices, about 315 billion barrels (50 km3) of bitumen are recoverable.
717	Fort McMurray, one of Canada's fastest growing cities, has grown enormously in recent years because of the large corporations which have taken on the task of oil production.
717	As of late 2006 there were over $100 billion in oil sands projects under construction or in the planning stages in northeastern Alberta.
717	Another factor determining the viability of oil extraction from the oil sands is the price of oil.
717	The oil price increases since 2003 have made it profitable to extract this oil, which in the past would give little profit or even a loss.
717	With concerted effort and support from the provincial government, several high-tech industries have found their birth in Alberta, notably patents related to interactive liquid crystal display systems.
717	With a growing economy, Alberta has several financial institutions dealing with civil and private funds.
717	Agriculture and forestry  Agriculture has a significant position in the province's economy.
717	The province has over three million head of cattle, and Alberta beef has a healthy worldwide market.
717	Nearly one half of all Canadian beef is produced in Alberta.
717	Alberta is one of the top producers of plains buffalo (bison) for the consumer market.
717	Sheep for wool and mutton are also raised.
717	Wheat and canola are primary farm crops, with Alberta leading the provinces in spring wheat production; other grains are also prominent.
717	Much of the farming is dryland farming, often with fallow seasons interspersed with cultivation.
717	Continuous cropping (in which there is no fallow season) is gradually becoming a more common mode of production because of increased profits and a reduction of soil erosion.
717	Across the province, the once common grain elevator is slowly being lost as rail lines are decreasing; farmers typically truck the grain to central points.
717	Alberta is the leading beekeeping province of Canada, with some beekeepers wintering hives indoors in specially designed barns in southern Alberta, then migrating north during the summer into the Peace River valley where the season is short but the working days are long for honeybees to produce honey from clover and fireweed.
717	Hybrid canola also requires bee pollination, and some beekeepers service this need.
717	The vast northern forest reserves of softwood allow Alberta to produce large quantities of lumber, oriented strand board (OSB) and plywood, and several plants in northern Alberta supply North America and the Pacific Rim nations with bleached wood pulp and newsprint.
717	Tourism  Alberta has been a tourist destination from the early days of the twentieth century, with attractions including outdoor locales for skiing, hiking and camping, shopping locales such as West Edmonton Mall, Calgary Stampede, outdoor festivals, professional athletic events, international sporting competitions such as the Commonwealth Games and Olympic Games, as well as more eclectic attractions.
717	There are also natural attractions like Elk Island National Park, Wood Buffalo National Park, and the Columbia Icefield.
717	According to Alberta Economic Development, Calgary and Edmonton both host over four million visitors annually.
717	Banff, Jasper and the Rocky Mountains are visited by about three million people per year.
717	Alberta tourism relies heavily on Southern Ontario tourists, as well as tourists from other parts of Canada, the United States, and many international countries.
717	Alberta's Rocky Mountains include well known tourist destinations Banff National Park and Jasper National Park.
717	The two mountain parks are connected by the scenic Icefields Parkway.
717	Banff is located 128 km west of Calgary on Highway 1, and Jasper is located 366 km west of Edmonton on Yellowhead Highway.
717	Five of Canada's fourteen UNESCO World heritage sites are located within the province: Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks, Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park, Wood Buffalo National Park, Dinosaur Provincial Park and Head-Smashed-In Buffalo Jump.
717	About 1.2 million people visit the of Calgary Stampede, a celebration of Canada's own Wild West and the cattle ranching industry.
717	About 700,000 people enjoy Edmonton's K-Days (formerly Klondike Days and Capital EX).
717	Edmonton was the gateway to the only all-Canadian route to the Yukon gold fields, and the only route which did not require gold-seekers to travel the exhausting and dangerous Chilkoot Pass.
717	Another tourist destination that draws more than 650,000 visitors each year is the Drumheller Valley, located northeast of Calgary.
717	Drumheller, "Dinosaur Capital of The World", offers the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology.
717	Drumheller also had a rich mining history being one of Western Canada's largest coal producers during the war years.
717	The Canadian Badlands has much to offer in the way of attractions, cultural events, celebrations, accommodations and service.
717	Located in east-central Alberta is Alberta Prairie Railway Excursions, a popular tourist attraction operated out of Stettler.
717	It boasts one of the few operable steam trains in the world, offering trips through the rolling prairie scenery.
717	Alberta Prairie Railway Excursions caters to tens of thousands of visitors every year.
717	Alberta is an important destination for tourists who love to ski and hike; Alberta boasts several world-class ski resorts such as Sunshine Village, Lake Louise, Marmot Basin, Norquay and Nakiska.
717	Hunters and fishermen from around the world are able to take home impressive trophies and tall tales from their experiences in Alberta's wilderness.
717	Government and politics The government of Alberta is organized as a parliamentary democracy with a unicameral legislature.
717	Its unicameral legislature—the Legislative Assembly—consists of eighty-seven members elected first past the post (FPTP) from single-member constituencies.
717	Locally municipal governments and school boards are elected and operate separately.
717	Their boundaries do not necessarily coincide.
717	Municipalities where the same body act as both local government and school board are formally referred to as "counties" in Alberta.
717	As Canada's head of state, Queen Elizabeth II is the head of state for the Government of Alberta.
717	Her duties in Alberta are carried out by Lieutenant Governor Donald Ethell.
717	Although the lieutenant governor is technically the most powerful person in Alberta, he is in reality a figurehead whose actions are restricted by custom and constitutional convention.
717	The government is therefore headed by the premier.
717	The current premier is Alison Redford who was elected as leader of the governing Progressive Conservatives on October 1, 2011.
717	Redford was sworn in as the 14th Premier of Alberta on October 7, 2011.
717	The Premier is a Member of the Legislative Assembly, and she draws all the members of her Cabinet from among the members of the Legislative Assembly.
717	The City of Edmonton is the seat of the provincial government—the capital of Alberta.
717	Alberta's elections tend to yield results which are much more conservative than those of other Canadian provinces.
717	Alberta has traditionally had three political parties, the Progressive Conservatives ("Conservatives" or "Tories"), the Liberals, and the social democratic New Democrats.
717	A fourth party, the strongly conservative Social Credit Party, was a power in Alberta for many decades, but fell from the political map after the Progressive Conservatives came to power in 1971.
717	Since that time, no other political party has governed Alberta.
717	In fact, only four parties have governed Alberta: the Liberals, from 1905 to 1921; the United Farmers of Alberta, from 1921 to 1935; the Social Credit Party, from 1935 to 1971, and the currently governing Progressive Conservative Party, from 1971 to the present.
717	Alberta has had occasional surges in separatist sentiment.
717	Even during the 1980s, when these feelings were at their strongest, there has never been enough interest in secession to initiate any major movements or referendums.
717	There are several currently active groups wishing to promote the independence of Alberta in some form.
717	In the 2008 provincial election, held on March 3, 2008, the Progressive Conservative Party was re-elected as a majority government with 72 of 83 seats, the Alberta Liberal Party was elected as the Official Opposition with nine members, and two Alberta New Democratic Party members were elected.
717	The April 23, 2012 election returned the Progressive Conservative Party to government, making leader Alison Redford Alberta's first elected female premier.
717	In the 2012 provincial election, held on April 23, 2012, the Progressive Conservative Party was re-elected as a majority government and party leader Alison Redford retained as premier with 43.9% of the vote and 61 of 87 seats (The Legislative Assembly added 4 seats, increasing the total to 87, with the 2012 election), the Wildrose Party led by Danielle Smith was elected as the Official Opposition with 34.3% of the vote and 17 members (replacing the Liberal Party), five Liberals were elected with 9.9% of the vote and four NDP members were elected with 9.8% of the vote.
717	Taxation  Government revenue comes mainly from royalties on non-renewable natural resources (30.4%), personal income taxes (22.3%), corporate and other taxes (19.6%), and grants from the federal government primarily for infrastructure projects (9.8%).
717	Albertans are the lowest-taxed people in Canada, and Alberta is the only province in Canada without a provincial sales tax (but residents are still subject to the federal sales tax, the Goods and Services Tax of 5%).
717	It is also the only Canadian province to have a flat tax for personal income taxes, which is 10% of taxable income.
717	The Alberta personal income tax system maintains a progressive character by granting residents personal tax exemptions of $16,977, in addition to a variety of tax deductions for persons with disabilities, students, and the aged.
717	Alberta's municipalities and school jurisdictions have their own governments which (usually) work in co-operation with the provincial government.
717	Alberta also privatized alcohol distribution.
717	The privatization increased outlets from 304 stores to 1,726; 1,300 jobs to 4,000 jobs; and 3,325 products to 16,495 products.
717	Tax revenue also increased from $400 million to $700 million.
717	Albertan municipalities raise a significant portion of their income through levying property taxes.
717	The value of assessed property in Alberta was approximately $727 billion in 2011.
717	Most real property is assessed according to its market value.
717	The exceptions to market value assessment are farmland, railways, machinery & equipment and linear property, all of which is assessed by regulated rates.
717	Depending on the property type, property owners may appeal a property assessment to their municipal 'Local Assessment Review Board', 'Composite Assessment Review Board,' or the Alberta Municipal Government Board.
717	Military  Military bases in Alberta include Canadian Forces Base (CFB) Cold Lake, CFB Edmonton, CFB Suffield and CFB Wainwright.
717	The air force is stationed at CFB Cold Lake and has access to the Cold Lake Air Weapons Range.
717	CFB Edmonton is the headquarters for the Land Force Western Area.
717	CFB Suffield hosts British troops and is the largest training facility in Canada.
717	Transportation  Alberta has over 181000 km of highways and roads, of which nearly 41000 km are paved.
717	The main north-south corridor is Highway 2, which begins south of Cardston at the Carway border crossing and is part of the CANAMEX Corridor.
717	Highway 4, which effectively extends Interstate 15 into Alberta and is the busiest U.S.
717	Coutts border crossing and ends at Lethbridge.
717	Highway 3 joins Lethbridge to Fort Macleod and links Highway 4 to Highway 2.
717	Highway 2 travels northward through Fort Macleod, Calgary, Red Deer, and Edmonton.
717	North of Edmonton, the highway continues to Athabasca, then northwesterly along the south shore of Lesser Slave Lake into High Prairie, north to Peace River, west to Fairview and finally south to Grande Prairie, where it ends at an interchange with Highway 43.
717	The section of Highway 2 between Calgary and Edmonton has been named the Queen Elizabeth II Highway to commemorate the visit of the monarch in 2005.
717	Highway 2 is supplemented by two more highways that run parallel to it: Highway 22, west of Highway 2, known as Cowboy Trail, and Highway 21, east of Highway 2.
717	Highway 43 travels northwest into Grande Prairie and the Peace River Country; Highway 63 travels northeast to Fort McMurray, the location of the Athabasca Oil Sands.
717	Alberta has two main east-west corridors.
717	The southern corridor, part of the Trans-Canada Highway system, enters the province near Medicine Hat, runs westward through Calgary, and leaves Alberta through Banff National Park.
717	The northern corridor, also part of the Trans-Canada network and known as the Yellowhead Highway (Highway 16), runs west from Lloydminster in eastern Alberta, through Edmonton and Jasper National Park into British Columbia.
717	One of the most scenic drives is along the Icefields Parkway, which runs for 228 km between Jasper and Lake Louise, with mountain ranges and glaciers on either side of its entire length.
717	Another major corridor through central Alberta is Highway 11 (also known as the David Thompson Highway), which runs east from the Saskatchewan River Crossing in Banff National Park through Rocky Mountain House and Red Deer, connecting with Highway 12 20 km west of Stettler.
717	The highway connects many of the smaller towns in central Alberta with Calgary and Edmonton, as it crosses Highway 2 just west of Red Deer.
717	Urban stretches of Alberta's major highways and freeways are often called trails.
717	For example, Highway 2, the main north-south highway in the province, is called Deerfoot Trail as it passes through Calgary but becomes Calgary Trail (for southbound traffic) and Gateway Boulevard (for northbound traffic) as it enters Edmonton and then turns into St.
717	Albert Trail as it leaves Edmonton for the City of St.
717	Albert.
717	Calgary, in particular, has a tradition of calling its largest urban expressways trails and naming many of them af callinfter prominent First Nations individuals and tribes, such as Crowchild Trail, Deerfoot Trail, and Stoney Trail.
717	Calgary, Edmonton, Red Deer, Medicine Hat, and Lethbridge have substantial public transit systems.
717	In addition to buses, Calgary and Edmonton operate light rail transit (LRT) systems.
717	Edmonton LRT, which is underground in the downtown core and on the surface outside of it, was the first of the modern generation of light rail systems to be built in North America, while the Calgary C-Train has one of the highest number of daily riders of any LRT system in North America.
717	Alberta is well-connected by air, with international airports in both Calgary and Edmonton.
717	Calgary International Airport and Edmonton International Airport are the fourth and fifth busiest in Canada respectively.
717	Calgary's airport is a hub for WestJet Airlines and a regional hub for Air Canada.
717	Calgary's airport primarily serves the Canadian prairie provinces (Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba) for connecting flights to British Columbia, eastern Canada, 15 major US centres, nine European airports, one Asian airport and four destinations in Mexico and the Caribbean.
717	Edmonton's airport acts as a hub for the Canadian north and has connections to all major Canadian airports as well as 10 major US airports, 3 European airports and 6 Mexican and Caribbean airports.
717	There are more than 9000 km of operating mainline railway; the Canadian Pacific Railway and Canadian National Railway companies operate railway freight across the province.
717	Passenger trains include Via Rail's Canadian (Toronto-Vancouver) or Jasper-Prince Rupert trains, which use the CN mailine and pass through Jasper National Park and parallel the Yellowhead Highway during at least part of their routes.
717	The Rocky Mountaineer operates two sections: one from Vancouver to Banff and Calgary over CP tracks, and a section that travels over CN tracks to Jasper.
717	These trains provide some the most scenic train rides in the world.
717	Health care  As with all Canadian provinces, Alberta provides for all citizens and residents through a publicly funded health care system.
717	Alberta became Canada's second province (after Saskatchewan) to adopt a Tommy Douglas-style program in 1950, a precursor to the modern medicare system.
717	Alberta's health care budget is currently $13.2 billion during the 2008–2009 fiscal year (approximately 36% of all government spending), making it the best funded health care system per-capita in Canada.
717	Every hour more than $1.7 million is spent on health care in the province.
717	A highly educated population and burgeoning economy have made Alberta a national leader in health education, research, and resources.
717	Many notable facilities include the Foothills Medical Centre, the Peter Lougheed Centre, Rockyview General Hospital, Alberta Children's Hospital, Grace Women's Health Centre, The University of Calgary Medical Centre (UCMC), Tom Baker Cancer Centre and Libin Cardiovascular Institute of Alberta, in Calgary; In Edmonton, the University of Alberta Hospital, the Royal Alexandra Hospital, the Grey Nuns Hospital, the Misericordia Hospital, the Mazankowski Alberta Heart Institute, the Lois Hole Hospital for Women, the Stollery Children's Hospital, the Alberta Diabetes Institute, the Cross Cancer Institute, and the Rexall Centre for Pharmacy and Health Research in Edmonton.
717	Currently under construction in Edmonton is the new $909 million Edmonton Clinic, which will provide a similar research, education, and care environment as the Mayo Clinic in the United States.
717	All public health care services funded by the Government of Alberta are delivered operationally by Alberta Health Services.
717	AHS is the province's single health authority established on July 1, 2008 which replaced nine local health authorities.
717	AHS also funds all ground ambulance services in the province, as well as the province-wide STARS (Shock Trauma Air Rescue Society) air ambulance service.
717	Education  As with any Canadian province, the Alberta Legislature has (almost) exclusive authority to make laws respecting education.
717	Since 1905 the Legislature has used this capacity to continue the model of locally elected public and separate school boards which originated prior to 1905, as well as to create and/or regulate universities, colleges, technical institutions and other educational forms and institutions (public charter schools, private schools, home schooling).
717	Elementary schools  There are forty-two public school jurisdictions in Alberta, and seventeen operating separate school jurisdictions.
717	Sixteen of the operating separate school jurisdictions have a Catholic electorate, and one (St.
717	Albert) has a Protestant electorate.
717	In addition, one Protestant separate school district, Glen Avon, survives as a ward of the St.
717	Paul Education Region.
717	The City of Lloydminster straddles the Alberta/Saskatchewan border, and both the public and separate school systems in that city are counted in the above numbers: both of them operate according to Saskatchewan law.
717	For many years the provincial government has funded the greater part of the cost of providing K–12 education.
717	Prior to 1994 public and separate school boards in Alberta had the legislative authority to levy a local tax on property, as supplementary support for local education.
717	In 1994 the government of the province eliminated this right for public school boards, but not for separate school boards.
717	Since 1994 there has continued to be a tax on property in support of K–12 education; the difference is that the mill rate is now set by the provincial government, the money is collected by the local municipal authority and remitted to the provincial government.
717	The relevant legislation requires that all the money raised by this property tax must go to the support of K–12 education provided by school boards.
717	The provincial government pools the property tax funds from across the province and distributes them, according to a formula, to public and separate school jurisdictions and Francophone authorities.
717	Public and separate school boards, charter schools, and prPublic school (goverivate schools all follow the Program of Studies and the curriculum approved by the provincial department of education (Alberta Education).
717	Home schoolers may choose to follow the Program of Studies or develop their own Program of Studies.
717	Public and separate schools, charter schools, and approved private schools all employ teachers who are certificated by Alberta Education, they administer Provincial Achievement Tests and Diploma Examinations set by Alberta Education, and they may grant high school graduation certificates endorsed by Alberta Education.
717	Universities  The University of Alberta, established in Edmonton in 1908, is Alberta's oldest and largest university.
717	The University of Calgary, once affiliated with the University of Alberta, gained its autonomy in 1966 and is now the second largest university in Alberta.
717	There is also Athabasca University, which focuses on distance learning, and the University of Lethbridge, both of which are located in their title cities.
717	In early September 2009, Mount Royal University became Calgary's second public university, and in late September 2009, a similar move made MacEwan University Edmonton's second public university.
717	There are 15 colleges that receive direct public funding, along with two technical institutes, Northern Alberta Institute of Technology and Southern Alberta Institute of Technology.
717	There is also a large and active private sector of post-secondary institutions, mostly Christian Universities, bringing the total number of universities to twelve, plus a DeVry University in Calgary, the only location in Canada.
717	Students may also receive government loans and grants while attending selected private institutions.
717	There has been some controversy in recent years over the rising cost of post-secondary education for students (as opposed to taxpayers).
717	In 2005, Premier Ralph Klein made a promise that he would freeze tuition and look into ways of reducing schooling costs.
717	So far, no plan has been released by the government of Alberta.
717	Culture  Summer brings many festivals to the province of Alberta, especially in Edmonton.
717	The Edmonton Fringe Festival is the world's second largest after Edinburgh's.
717	Both Calgary and Edmonton host a number of annual festivals and events including folk music festivals.
717	With a large number of summer and winter events, Edmonton prides itself as being the "Festival City".
717	The city's "heritage days" festival sees the participation of over 70 ethnic groups.
717	Edmonton's Churchill Square is home to a large number of the festivals, including the large Taste of Edmonton & The Works Art & Design Festival throughout the summer months.
717	The City of Calgary is also famous for its Stampede, dubbed "The Greatest Outdoor Show on Earth."
717	The Stampede is Canada's biggest rodeo festival and features various races and competitions, such as calf roping and bull riding.
717	In line with the western tradition of rodeo are the cultural artisans that reside and create unique Alberta western heritage crafts.
717	The Banff Centre hosts a range of festivals and other events including the international Mountain Film Festival.
717	These cultural events in Alberta highlight the province's cultural diversity.
717	Most of the major cities have several performing theatre companies who entertain in venues as diverse as Edmonton's Arts Barns and the Francis Winspear Centre for Music.
717	Both Calgary and Edmonton are home to Canadian Football League and National Hockey League teams.
717	Soccer, rugby union and lacrosse are also played professionally in Alberta.
717	Friendship partners  Alberta has relationships with several provinces, states, and other entities worldwide.
717	Jalisco, Mexico, Special Relationships *  Hokkaido, Japan, Special Relationships *  Gyeongsangnam-do, South Korea, Special Relationships *  Khanty–Mansi, Russia, Special Relationships *  Yamalo-Nenets, Russia, Special Relationships *  Neuquén, Argentina, Economic MOUs *  Mpumalanga, South Africa, Governance Projects *  Heilongjiang, People's Republic of China, Special Relationships *  Tyumen, Russia, Special Relationships *  Montana, United States, Transboundary Partnerships *  Gangwon-do, South Korea, Special Relationships
718	The Arctic Circle is one of the five major circles of latitude that mark maps of the Earth.
718	In 2012, it is the parallel of latitude that runs   north of the Equator.
718	The region north of this circle is known as the Arctic, and the zone just to the south is called the Northern Temperate Zone.
718	The equivalent polar circle in the Southern Hemisphere is called the Antarctic Circle.
718	The Arctic Circle is the southernmost latitude in the Northern Hemisphere at which the sun can remain continuously above or below the horizon for 24 hours (at the June solstice and December solstice respectively).
718	North of the Arctic Circle, the sun is above the horizon for 24 continuous hours at least once per year (and therefore visible at midnight) and below the horizon for 24 continuous hours at least once per year.
718	On the Arctic Circle those events occur, in principle, exactly once per year, at the June and December solstices, respectively.
718	It would therefore seem that the Arctic Circle marks the southern extremity of the northern hemisphere polar day (24-hour sunlit day, often referred to as the midnight sun) and polar night (24-hour sunless night).
718	In fact, because of atmospheric refraction and mirages, and because the sun appears as a disk and not a point, part of the midnight sun may be seen on the night of the northern summer solstice up to about 50′ (90 km) south of the Arctic Circle; similarly, on the day of the northern winter solstice, part of the sun may be seen up to about 50′ north of the Arctic Circle.
718	That is true at sea level; those limits increase with elevation above sea level although in mountainous regions, there is often no direct view of the true horizon.
718	The position of the Arctic Circle is not fixed.
718	It directly depends on the Earth's axial tilt, which fluctuates within a margin of 2° over a 40,000 year period, notably due to tidal forces resulting from the orbit of the Moon.
718	The Arctic Circle is currently drifting northwards at a speed of about 15 m per year; see Circle of latitude for more information.
718	TOC__ Geography Relatively few people live north of the Arctic Circle due to the Arctic climate.
718	The three largest communities above the Arctic Circle are situated in Russia: Murmansk (population 307,257), Norilsk (175,301), and Vorkuta (70,548).
718	Tromsø (in Norway) has about 69,000 inhabitants and Bodø 47,000.
718	In contrast, the largest North American community north of the circle, Sisimiut (Greenland), has approximately 5,000 inhabitants, while between Canada and the USA, Barrow, Alaska is the largest settlement with circa 4,000 inhabitants.
718	Rovaniemi (in Finland), which lies slightly south of the line, has a population of approximately 60,000, and is the largest settlement in the immediate vicinity of the Arctic Circle.
718	Among the people of the Arctic, the Norwegians have the easiest climate, with most ports in North Norway remaining ice-free all the year as a result of the Gulf Stream.
718	The Arctic Circle passes through the Arctic Ocean, the Scandinavian Peninsula, North Asia, Northern America and Greenland.
718	The land on the Arctic Circle is divided among eight countries: Norway, Sweden, Finland, Russia, the United States (Alaska), Canada, Denmark (Greenland), and Iceland (where it passes through the small offshore island of Grímsey).
718	The area north of the Arctic Circle is about  and covers 8% of the Earth.
718	Starting at the Prime Meridian and heading eastwards, the Arctic Circle passes through:

735	Al Gore
736	Albert Einstein (;; 14 March 1879 – 18 April 1955) was a German-born theoretical physicist who developed the general theory of relativity, one of the two pillars of modern physics (alongside quantum mechanics).
736	While best known for his mass–energy equivalence formula  (which has been dubbed "the world's most famous equation"), he received the 1921 Nobel Prize in Physics "for his services to theoretical physics, and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect".
736	The latter was pivotal in establishing quantum theory.
736	Near the beginning of his career, Einstein thought that Newtonian mechanics was no longer enough to reconcile the laws of classical mechanics with the laws of the electromagnetic field.
736	This led to the development of his special theory of relativity.
736	He realized, however, that the principle of relativity could also be extended to gravitational fields, and with his subsequent theory of gravitation in 1916, he published a paper on the general theory of relativity.
736	He continued to deal with problems of statistical mechanics and quantum theory, which led to his explanations of particle theory and the motion of molecules.
736	He also investigated the thermal properties of light which laid the foundation of the photon theory of light.
736	In 1917, Einstein applied the general theory of relativity to model the structure of the universe as a whole.
736	He was visiting the United States when Adolf Hitler came to power in 1933 and did not go back to Germany, where he had been a professor at the Berlin Academy of Sciences.
736	He settled in the U.S., becoming an American citizen in 1940.
736	On the eve of World War II, he helped alert President Franklin D.
736	Roosevelt that Germany might be developing an atomic weapon and recommended that the U.S.
736	Manhattan Project.
736	Einstein was in support of defending the Allied forces, but largely denounced using the new discovery of nuclear fission as a weapon.
736	Later, with the British philosopher Bertrand Russell, Einstein signed the Russell–Einstein Manifesto, which highlighted the danger of nuclear weapons.
736	Einstein was affiliated with the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, until his death in 1955.
736	Einstein published more than 300 scientific papers along with over 150 non-scientific works.
736	His great intellectual achievements and originality have made the word "Einstein" synonymous with genius.
736	Biography Early life and education s with energy hf each, where h is Planck's constant.
736	He does not say much more, because he is not sure how the particles are related to the wave.
736	But he does suggest that this idea would explain certain experimental results, notably the photoelectric effect.
736	Quantized atomic vibrations In 1907 Einstein proposed a model of matter where each atom in a lattice structure is an independent harmonic oscillator.
736	In the Einstein model, each atom oscillates independently – a series of equally spaced quantized states for each oscillator.
736	Einstein was aware that getting the frequency of the actual oscillations would be different, but he nevertheless proposed this theory because it was a particularly clear demonstration that quantum mechanics could solve the specific heat problem in classical mechanics.
736	Peter Debye refined this model.
736	Adiabatic principle and action-angle variables Throughout the 1910s, quantum mechanics expanded in scope to cover many different systems.
736	After Ernest Rutherford discovered the nucleus and proposed that electrons orbit like planets, Niels Bohr was able to show that the same quantum mechanical postulates introduced by Planck and developed by Einstein would explain the discrete motion of electrons in atoms, and the periodic table of the elements.
736	Einstein contributed to these developments by linking them with the 1898 arguments Wilhelm Wien had made.
736	Wien had shown that the hypothesis of adiabatic invariance of a thermal equilibrium state allows all the blackbody curves at different temperature to be derived from one another by a simple shifting process.
