742	"Algorithms" (plural of algorithm) is a peer-reviewed open access scientific journal "of computer science, theory, methods and interdisciplinary applications, data and information systems, software engineering, artificial intelligence, automation and control systems.".
742	It was established in 2008 and is published by MDPI.
746	Azerbaijan ( ; ), officially the Republic of Azerbaijan () is the largest country in the Caucasus region located at the crossroads of Western Asia and Eastern Europe.
746	It is bounded by the Caspian Sea to the east, Russia to the north, Georgia to the northwest, Armenia to the west and Iran to the south.
746	The exclave of Nakhchivan is bounded by Armenia to the north and east, Iran to the south and west, while having a short borderline with Turkey to the northwest.
746	Azerbaijan has an ancient and historic cultural heritage, including the distinction of being the first Muslim-majority country to have operas, theater  and plays.
746	The Azerbaijan Democratic Republic was established in 1918, but was incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1920.
746	Azerbaijan regained independence in 1991.
746	Shortly thereafter, during the Nagorno-Karabakh War, neighboring Armenia occupied Nagorno-Karabakh, its surrounding territories and the enclaves of Karki, Yukhary Askipara, Barkhudarly and Sofulu.
746	The Nagorno-Karabakh Republic, which emerged in Nagorno-Karabakh, continues to be not diplomatically recognized by any nation and the region is still considered a de jure part of Azerbaijan, despite being de facto independent since the end of the war.
746	Azerbaijan is a unitary constitutional republic.
746	It is one of the six independent  Turkic states as well as an active member of the Turkic Council and the TÜRKSOY community.
746	Azerbaijan has diplomatic relations with 158 countries and holds membership in 38 international organizations.
746	It is one of the founding members of GUAM, the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) and  Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.
746	A member of the United Nations since 1992, Azerbaijan was elected to membership in the newly established Human Rights Council by the United Nations General Assembly on May 9, 2006 (the term of office began on June 19, 2006).
746	The country is also a member of the OSCE, the Council of Europe, and the NATO Partnership for Peace (PfP) program.
746	Azerbaijan is a correspondent at the International Telecommunication Union and member of the Non-Aligned Movement and holds observer status in World Trade Organization.
746	The Constitution of Azerbaijan does not declare an official religion, and all major political forces in the country are secular nationalist, but the majority of people and some opposition movements adhere to Shia Islam.
746	Relative to other Eastern European and CIS states, Azerbaijan has reached a high level of human development, economic development and literacy, as well as a low rate of unemployment and intentional homicide.
746	On 1 January 2012, the country started a two-year term as a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council.
746	Etymology  The name "Āzar" () means Fire and baijan was originally known as "Pāyegān" () meaning Guardian/Protector (Āzar Pāyegān = "Guardians of Fire") ().
746	Such name roots back to the Zoroastrianism era of Persia (Iran).
746	After the Muslim conquest of Persia many Persian words lost their original form as in Arabic there are no letter for pronouncing "G / P / ZH / CH"; hence, "Azar Paigān" came to be known as Azarbaijan (e.g., the Persian language in Persian is now both known as Pārsi () and Fārsi due to the Arab invasion of Greater Iran and the great resistance of Iranians around the north.
746	According to an alternate etymology, the name of Azerbaijan derives from that of Atropates, a Persian satrap under the Achaemenid Empire, who was later reinstated as the satrap of Media under Alexander the Great.
746	The original etymology of this name is thought to have its roots in the once-dominant Zoroastrian religion.
746	In the Avesta, Frawardin Yasht ("Hymn to the Guardian Angels"), there is a mention of âterepâtahe ashaonô fravashîm ýazamaide, which literally translates from Avestan as "we worship the Fravashi of the holy Atropatene".
746	Atropates ruled over the region of Atropatene (present Iranian Azerbaijan).
746	The name "Atropates" itself is the Greek transliteration of an Old Iranian, probably Median, compounded name with the meaning "Protected by the (Holy) Fire" or "The Land of the (Holy) Fire".
746	The Greek name is mentioned by Diodorus Siculus and Strabo.
746	Over the span of millennia the name evolved to Āturpātākān then to Ādharbādhagān, Ādharbāyagān, Āzarbāydjān and present-day Azerbaijan.
746	The word is translatable as "The Treasury" and "The Treasurer" of fire or "The Land of the Fire" in Modern Persian.
746	History Antiquity The earliest evidence of human settlement in the territory of Azerbaijan dates to the late Stone Age and is related to the Guruchay culture of the Azykh Cave.
746	The Upper Paleolithic and late Bronze Age cultures are attested in the caves of Tağılar, Damcılı, Zar, Yataq-yeri and in the necropolises of Leylatepe and Saraytepe.
746	Early settlements included the Scythians in the 9th century BC.
746	Following the Scythians, Iranian Medes came to dominate the area to the south of the Aras.
746	The Medes forged a vast empire between 900–700 BC, which was integrated into the Achaemenids Empire around 550 BC.
746	The area was conquered by the Achaemenids leading to the spread of Zoroastrianism.
746	Later it became part of Alexander the Great's Empire and its successor, the Seleucid Empire.
746	The Romans also settled in the area during the time of the Roman empire.
746	Caucasian Albanians, the original inhabitants of the area, established an independent kingdom around the 4th century BC.
746	During this period, Zoroastrianism spread in the Caucasus and Atropatene.
746	Ancient Azerbaijanis spoke the Old Azari language.
746	Feudal era The Sassanids turned Caucasian Albania into a vassal state in AD 252, while King Urnayr officially adopted Christianity as the state religion in the 4th century.
746	Despite numerous conquests by the Sassanids and Byzantines, Albania remained an entity in the region until the 9th century.
746	The Islamic Umayyad Caliphate repulsed both the Sassanids and Byzantines from the region and turned Caucasian Albania into a vassal state after the Christian resistance, led by King Javanshir, was suppressed in 667.
746	The power vacuum left by the decline of the Abbasid Caliphate was filled by numerous local dynasties such as the Sallarids, Sajids, Shaddadids, Rawadids and Buyids.
746	At the beginning of the 11th century, the territory was gradually seized by waves of Turkic Oghuz tribes from Central Asia.
746	The first of these Turkic dynasties established was the Ghaznavids, which entered the area now known as Azerbaijan by 1030.
746	The pre-Turkic Azerbaijani population spoke an Iranian language called the Old Azari language, which was gradually replaced by a Turkic language, now known as the Azerbaijani language from the 11th century onward until it became completely extinct in the 16th century.
746	To distinguish it from the Turkic Azerbaijani or Azeri language, this Iranian language, is designated as the Azari language (or Old Azari language), because the Turkic language and people are also designated as "Azari" in the Persian language.
746	However some linguists people are also designatedhave also designated the Tati dialects of Iranian Azerbaijan and the Republic of Azerbaijan, like those spoken by the Tats, as a remnant of Azari.
746	Locally, the possessions of the subsequent Seljuq Empire were ruled by atabegs, who were technically vassals of the Seljuq sultans, being sometimes de facto rulers themselves.
746	Under the Seljuq Turks, local poets such as Nizami Ganjavi and Khagani Shirvani gave rise to a blossoming of Persian literature on the territory of present-day Azerbaijan.
746	The next ruling state of the Jalayirids was short-lived and fell under the conquests of Timur.
746	The local dynasty of Shirvanshahs became a vassal state of Timur's Empire, and assisted him in his war with the ruler of the Golden Horde Tokhtamysh.
746	Following Timur's death two independent and rival states emerged: Kara Koyunlu and Ak Koyunlu.
746	The Shirvanshahs returned, maintaining a high degree of autonomy as local rulers and vassals from 861 until 1539.
746	During their persecution by the Safavids, the last dynasty imposed Shia Islam upon the formerly Sunni population, as it was battling against the Sunni Ottoman Empire.
746	Modern era After the Safavids, the area was ruled by the Iranian dynasties of Afshar and Zand and briefly by the Qajars.
746	However de facto self-ruling khanates emerged in the area, especially following the collapse of the Zand dynasty and in the early Qajar era.
746	The brief and successful Russian campaign of 1812 was concluded with the Treaty of Gulistan, in which the shah's claims to some of the Khanates of the Caucasus were dismissed by Russia on the ground that they had been de facto independent long before their Russian occupation.
746	The khanates exercised control over their affairs via international trade routes between Central Asia and the West.
746	Engaged in constant warfare, these khanates were eventually incorporated into the Russian Empire in 1813, following the two Russo-Persian Wars.
746	The area to the North of the river Aras, among which the territory of the contemporary republic of Azerbaijan were Iranian territory until they were occupied by Russia.
746	Under the Treaty of Turkmenchay, Persia recognized Russian sovereignty over the Erivan Khanate, the Nakhchivan Khanate and the remainder of the Lankaran Khanate.
746	In 2007, during the construction of a stadium, constructors discovered the Guba mass grave.
746	Studies by Azerbaijani and foreign scientists have confirmed the human remains found there to be of local residents of various nationalities, including Jews and Lezgians who were killed in the 1918 massacre carried out by Armenians.
746	To date, the remains of 600 people have been found, including about 50 children and 100 women.
746	After the collapse of the Russian Empire during World War I, Azerbaijan, together with Armenia and Georgia became part of the short-lived Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic.
746	When the republic dissolved in May 1918, Azerbaijan declared independence as the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic (ADR).
746	The ADR was the first modern parliamentary republic in the Muslim world.
746	Among the important accomplishments of the Parliament was the extension of suffrage to women, making Azerbaijan the first Muslim nation to grant women equal political rights with men.
746	Another important accomplishment of ADR was the establishment of Baku State University, which was the first modern-type university founded in Muslim East.
746	By March 1920, it was obvious that Soviet Russia would attack the much-needed Baku.
746	Vladimir Lenin said that the invasion was justified as Soviet Russia could not survive without Baku's oil.
746	Independent Azerbaijan lasted only 23 months until the Bolshevik 11th Soviet Red Army invaded it, establishing the Azerbaijan SSR on April 28, 1920.
746	Although the bulk of the newly formed Azerbaijani army was engaged in putting down an Armenian revolt that had just broken out in Karabakh, Azeris did not surrender their brief independence of 1918–20 quickly or easily.
746	As many as 20,000 Azerbaijani soldiers died resisting what was effectively a Russian reconquest.
746	On October 13, 1921, the Soviet republics of Russia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia signed an agreement with Turkey known as the Treaty of Kars.
746	The previously independent Naxicivan SSR would also become an autonomous ASSR within the Azerbaijan SSR by the treaty of Kars.
746	On the other hand, Armenia was awarded the region of Zangezur and Turkey agreed to return Gyumri (then known as Alexandropol).
746	During World War II, Azerbaijan played a crucial role in the str (then known as Alexandropol).
746	During Eastern Front being supplied by Baku.
746	By the Decree of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR in February 1942, the commitment of more than 500 workers and employees of the oil industry of Azerbaijan was awarded orders and medals.
746	Operation Edelweiss carried out by the German Wehrmacht targeted Baku because of its importance as the energy (petroleum) dynamo of the USSR.
746	A fifth of all Azerbaijanis fought in the Second World War from 1941 to 1945.
746	Approximately 681,000 people with over 100,000 of them women went to the front, while the total population of Azerbaijan was 3.4 million at the time.
746	Some 250,000 people from Azerbaijan were killed on the front.
746	More than 130 Azerbaijanis were named Heroes of the Soviet Union.
746	Azerbaijani Major-General Azi Aslanov was twice awarded the Hero of the Soviet Union.
746	Republic era Following the politics of glasnost, initiated by Mikhail Gorbachev, civil unrest and ethnic strife grew in various regions of the Soviet Union, including Nagorno-Karabakh, a region of the Azerbaijan SSR.
746	The disturbances in Azerbaijan, in response to Moscow's indifference to already heated conflict, resulted in calls for independence and secession, which culminated in Black January in Baku.
746	Later in 1990, the Supreme Council of the Azerbaijan SSR dropped the words "Soviet Socialist" from the title, adopted the Declaration of Sovereignty of the Azerbaijan Republic and restored flag of the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic as a state flag.
746	On 18 October 1991, the Supreme Council of Azerbaijan adopted a Declaration of Independence which was affirmed by a nationwide referendum in December 1991, when the Soviet Union was officially dissolved.
746	The early years of independence were overshadowed by the Nagorno-Karabakh War with neighboring Armenia.
746	By the end of hostilities in 1994, Armenians controlled up to 16 percent of Azerbaijani territory, including Nagorno-Karabakh itself.
746	An estimated 30,000 people had been killed and more than a million had been displaced.
746	Four United Nations Security Council Resolutions (822, 853, 874, and 884) demands for "the immediate withdrawal of all Armenian forces from all occupied territories of Azerbaijan."
746	Many Russians and Armenians left Azerbaijan during the 1990s.
746	According to the 1970 census, there were 510,000 ethnic Russians and 484,000 Armenians in Azerbaijan.
746	In 1993, democratically elected president Abulfaz Elchibey was overthrown by a military insurrection led by Colonel Surat Huseynov, which resulted in the rise to power of the former leader of Soviet Azerbaijan, Heydar Aliyev.
746	In 1994, Surat Huseynov, by that time a prime minister, attempted another military coup against Heydar Aliyev, but Huseynov was arrested and charged with treason.
746	In 1995, another coup attempt against Aliyev, by the commander of the OMON special unit, Rovshan Javadov, was averted, resulting in the killing of the latter and disbanding of Azerbaijan's OMON units.
746	At the same time, the country was tainted by rampant corruption in the governing bureaucracy.
746	In October 1998, Aliyev was reelected for a second term.
746	Despite the much improved economy, particularly with the exploitations of Azeri-Chirag-Guneshli oil field and Shah Deniz gas field, Aliyev's presidency was criticized due to suspected vote fraud and corruption.
746	Geography Azerbaijan is in the South Caucasus region of Eurasia, straddling Western Asia and Eastern Europe.
746	It lies between latitudes 38° and 42° N, and longitudes 44° and 51° E.
746	The total length of Azerbaijan's land borders is 2648 km, of which 1007 kilometers are with Armenia, 756 kilometers with Iran, 480 kilometers with Georgia, 390 kilometers with Russia and 15 kilometers with Turkey.
746	The coastline stretches for 800 km, and the length of the widest area of the Azerbaijani section of the Caspian Sea is 456 km.
746	The territory of Azerbaijan extends 400 km from north to south, and 500 km from west to east.
746	Three physical features dominate Azerbaijan: the Caspian Sea, whose shoreline forms a natural boundary to the east; the Greater Caucasus mountain range to the north; and the extensive flatlands at the country's center.
746	There are also three mountain ranges, the Greater and Lesser Caucasus, and the Talysh Mountains, together covering approximately 40 percent of the country.
746	The highest peak of Azerbaijan is mount Bazardüzü (4,466 m), while the lowest point lies in the Caspian Sea (−28 m).
746	Nearly half of all the mud volcanoes on Earth are concentrated in Azerbaijan, which was also among nominees for New7Wonders of Nature.
746	The main water sources are the surface waters.
746	However, only 24 of the 8,350 rivers are greater than 100 km in length.
746	All the rivers drain into the Caspian Sea in the east of the country.
746	The largest lake is Sarysu (67 km²), and the longest river is Kur (1,515 km), which is transboundary.
746	Azerbaijan's four main islands in the Caspian Sea have a combined area of over thirty square kilometer.
746	Since the independence of Azerbaijan in 1991, the Azerbaijani government has taken drastic measures to preserve the environment of Azerbaijan.
746	But national protection of the environment started to truly improve after 2001 when the state budget increased due to new revenues provided by the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline.
746	Within four years protected areas doubled and now make up eight percent of the country's territory.
746	Since 2001 the government has set up seven large reserves and almost doubled the sector of the budget earmarked for environmental protection.
746	Landscape Azerbaijan is home to a vast variety of landscapes.
746	Over half of Azerbaijan's land mass consists of mountain ridges, crests, yailas, and plateaus which rise up to hypsometric levels of 400–1000 meters (including the Middle and Lower lowlands), in some places (Talis, Jeyranchol-Ajinohur and Langabiz-Alat foreranges) up to 100–120 meters, and others from 0–50 meters and up (Qobustan, Absheron).
746	The rest of Azerbaijan's terrain consist of plains and lowlands.
746	Hypsometric marks within the Caucasus region vary from about −28 meters at the Caspian Sea shoreline up to 4,466 meters (Bazardüzü peak).
746	The formation of climate in Azerbaijan is influenced particularly by cold arctic air masses of Scandinavian anticyclone, temperate of Siberian anticyclone, and Central Asian anticyclone.
746	Azerbaijan's diverse landscape affects the ways air masses enter the country.
746	The Greater Caucasus protects the country from direct influences of cold air masses coming from the north.
746	That leads to the formation of subtropical climate on most foothills and plains of the country.
746	Meanwhile, plains and foothills are characterized by high solar radiation rates.
746	Azerbaijan.
746	Both the absolute minimum temperature (  ) and the absolute maximum temperature ( 46 °C ) were observed in Julfa and Ordubad.
746	The maximum annual precipitation falls in Lankaran (1,600 to 1,800 mm) and the minimum in Absheron (200 to 350 mm).
746	Rivers and lakes form the principal part of the water systems of Azerbaijan, they were formed over a long geological timeframe and changed significantly throughout that period.
746	This is particularly evidenced by remnants of ancient rivers found throughout the country.
746	The country's water systems are continually changing under the influence of natural forces and human introduced industrial activities.
746	Artificial rivers (canals) and ponds are a part of Azerbaijan's water systems.
746	From the water supply point, Azerbaijan is below the average in the world with approximately 100,000 m³/year of water per km².
746	All big water reservoirs are built on Kur.
746	The hydrography of Azerbaijan basically belongs to the Caspian Sea basin.
746	There are 8,350 rivers of various lengths within Azerbaijan.
746	Only 24 rivers are over 100 kilometers long.
746	The Kura and Aras are the most popular rivers in Azerbaijan, they run through the Kura-Aras Lowland.
746	The rivers that directly flow into the Caspian Sea, originate mainly from the north-eastern slope of the Major Caucasus and Talysh Mountains and run along the Samur-Devechi and Lenkeran lowlands.
746	Biodiversity The first reports on the richness and diversity of animal life in Azerbaijan can be found in travel notes of Eastern travelers.
746	Animal carvings on architectural monuments, ancient rocks and stones survived up to the present times.
746	The first information on the animal kingdom of Azerbaijan was collected during the visits of naturalists to Azerbaijan in 17th century.
746	Unlike fauna, the concept of animal kingdom covers not only the types of animals, but also the number of individual species.
746	There are 106 species of mammals, 97 species of fish, 363 species of birds, 10 species of amphibians and 52 species of reptiles which have been recorded and classified in Azerbaijan.
746	The national animal of Azerbaijan is the Karabakh horse, a mountain-steppe racing and riding horse endemic to Azerbaijan.
746	The Karabakh horse has a reputation for its good temper, speed, elegance and intelligence.
746	It is one of the oldest breeds, with ancestry dating to the ancient world.
746	However today the horse is an endangered species.
746	Azerbaijan's flora consists of more than 4,500 species of higher plants.
746	Due the unique climate in Azerbaijan, the flora is much richer in the number of species than the flora of the other republics of the South Caucasus.
746	About 67 percent of the species growing in the whole Caucasus can be found in Azerbaijan.
746	Politics The structural formation of Azerbaijan's political system was completed by the adoption of the new Constitution on 12 November 1995.
746	According to the Article 23 of Constitution, the state symbols of the Azerbaijan Republic are the flag, the coat of arms and the national anthem.
746	The state power in Azerbaijan is limited only by law for internal issues, but for international affairs is additionally limited by the provisions of international agreements.
746	The government of Azerbaijan is based on the separation of powers among the legislative, executive and judicial branches.
746	The legislative power is held by the unicameral National Assembly and the Supreme National Assembly in the Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic.
746	Parliamentary elections are held every five years, on the first Sunday of November.
746	The Yeni Azerbaijan Party, and independents loyal to the ruling government, currently hold almost all of the Parliament's 125 seats.
746	During the 2010 Parliamentary election, the opposition parties, Musavat and Azerbaijani Popular Front Party, failed to win a single seat.
746	European observers found numerous irregularities in the run up to the election and on election day.
746	The executive power is held by the President, who is elected for a 5-year term by direct elections.
746	The president is authorized to form the Cabinet, an inferior executive body, subordinated to him.
746	The Cabinet of Azerbaijan consists primarily of the Prime Minister, his Deputies and Ministers.
746	The president does not have the right to dissolve the National Assembly, but he has the right to veto its decisions.
746	To override the presidential veto, the parliament must have a majority of 95 votes.
746	The judicial power is vested in the Constitutional Court, Supreme Court and the Economic Court.
746	The President nominates the judges in these courts.
746	The Security Council is the deliberative body under the president, and he organizes it according to the Constitution.
746	It was established on 10 April 1997.
746	The administrative department is not a part of the president's office but manages the financial, technical and pecuniary activities of both the president and his office.
746	Although Azerbaijan has held several elections since regaining its independence and it has many of the formal institutions of democracy, it remains classified as "not free" (on border with "partly free") in Freedom House's Freedom in the World 2009 survey.
746	Human rights Azerbaijan has come under heavy criticism from international bodies such as Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch for its record on human rights: in particular the treatment of homosexuals and the media.
746	Foreign relations The short-lived Azerbaijan Democratic Republic succeeded in establishing diplomatic relations with six countries, sending diplomatic representatives to Germany and Finland.
746	The process of international recognition of Azerbaijan's independence from the collapsing Soviet Union lasted roughly one year.
746	The most recent country to recognize Azerbaijan was Bahrain, on November 6, 1996.
746	Full diplomatic relations, including mutual exchanges of missions, were first established with Turkey, Pakistan, the United States, Iran and Israel.
746	Azerbaijan has placed a particular emphasis on its "Special Relationship" with Turkey.
746	Azerbaijan has diplomatic relations with 158 countries so far and holds membership in 38 international organizations.
746	It holds observer status in the Non-Aligned Movement and World Trade Organization and is a correspondent at the International Telecommunication Union.
746	On 9 May 2006 Azerbaijan was elected to membership in the newly established Human Rights Council by the United Nations General Assembly.
746	The term of office began on 19 June 2006.
746	Foreign policy priorities of Azerbaijan include: first of all, the restoration of its territorial integrity; elimination of the consequences of the loss of Nagorno-Karabakh and seven other regions of Azerbaijan; integration into European and Euro-Atlantic structure; contribution to international security; cooperation with international organizations; regional cooperation and bilateral relations; strengthening of defense capability; promotion of security by domestic policy means; strengthening of democracy; preservation of the ethnic and religious tolerance; scientific, educational and cultural policy and preservation of moral values; economic and social development; enhancing internal and border security; migration, energy and transportation security policy.
746	The Azerbaijani Government, in late 2007, stated that the long-standing dispute over the Armenian-occupied territory of Nagorno-Karabakh is almost certain to spark a new war if it remains unresolved.
746	The Government is in the process of increasing its military budget.
746	Furthermore, economic sanctions by Turkey to the west and by Azerbaijan itself to the east have combined to greatly erode Armenia's economy, leading to steep increases in prices for basic commodities and a great decline in the Armenian state revenues.
746	Azerbaijan is an active member of international coalitions fighting international terrorism.
746	The country is contributing to peacekeeping efforts in Kosovo, Afghanistan and Iraq.
746	Azerbaijan is an active member of NATO's Partnership for Peace program.
746	It also maintains good relations with the European Union and could potentially one day apply for membership.
746	Administrative divisions Azerbaijan is divided into 10 economic regions; 66 rayons (rayonlar, singular rayon) and 77 cities (şəhərlər, singular şəhər) of which 11 are under the direct authority of the republic.
746	Moreover, Azerbaijan includes the Autonomous Republic (muxtar respublika) of Nakhchivan.
746	The President of Azerbaijan appoints the governors of these units, while the government of Nakhchivan is elected and approved by the parliament of Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic.
746	Absheron Economic Region * Absheron (Abşeron) * Baku (Bakı) * Khizi (Xızı) * Sumqayit (Sumqayıt) ;Aran Economic Region * Aghjabadi (Ağcabədi) * Aghdash (Ağdaş) * Barda (Bərdə) * Beylagan (Beyləqan) * Bilasuvar (Biləsuvar) * Goychay (Göyçay) * Hajigabul (Hacıqabul) * Imishli (İmişli) * Kurdamir (Kürdəmir) * Mingachevir (Mingəçevir) * Neftchala (Neftçala) * Saatly (Saatlı) * Sabirabad (Sabirabad) * Salyan (Salyan) * Shirvan (Şirvan) * Ujar (Ucar) * Yevlakh (Yevlax) * Yevlakh (Yevlax) * Zardab (Zərdab) ;Daghlig Shirvan * Aghsu (Ağsu) *  (Yevlax) * Zardab (ZərdGobustan Rayon|Gobustan (Qobustan) * Ismailly (İsmayıllı) * Shamakhy (Şamaxı) ;Ganja-Gazakh * Aghstafa (Ağstafa) * Dashkasan (Daşkəsən) * Gadabay (Gədəbəy) * Ganja (Gəncə) * Gazakh (Qazax) * Goygol (Göygöl) * Goranboy (Goranboy) * Naftalan (Naftalan) * Samukh (Samux) * Shamkir (Şəmkir) * Tovuz (Tovuz) ;Guba-Khachmaz * Guba (Quba) * Gusar (Qusar) * Khachmaz (Xaçmaz) * Shabran (Şabran) * Siyazan (Siyəzən) ;Kalbajar-Lachin * Gubadly (Qubadlı) * Kalbajar (Kəlbəcər) * Lachin (Laçın) * Zangilan (Zəngilan) ;Lankaran * Astara (Astara) * Jalilabad (Cəlilabad) * Lankaran (Lənkəran) * Lankaran (Lənkəran) * Lerik (Lerik) * Masally (Masallı) * Yardimly (Yardımlı) ;Nakhchivan * Babek (Babək) * Julfa (Culfa) * Kangarli (Kəngərli) * Nakhchivan (Naxçıvan) * Ordubad (Ordubad) * Sadarak (Sədərək) * Shahbuz (Şahbuz) * Sharur (Şərur) ;Shaki-Zaqatala * Balakan (Balakən) * Gabala (Qəbələ) * Gakh (Qax) * Oghuz (Oğuz) * Shaki (Şəki) * Shaki (Şəki) * Zaqatala (Zaqatala) ;Yukhari Garabakh * Aghdam (Ağdam) * Fuzuli (Füzuli) * Jabrayil (Cəbrayıl) * Khankendi (Xankəndi) * Khojaly (Xocalı) * Khojavend (Xocavənd) * Shusha (Şuşa) * Shusha (Şuşa) * Tartar (Tərtər) Note: The cities under the direct authority of the republic in italics.
746	Military The history of the modern Azerbaijan army dates back to Azerbaijan Democratic Republic in 1918, when the National Army of the newly formed Azerbaijan Democratic Republic was created on June 26, 1918.
746	When Azerbaijan gained independence after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the Armed Forces of the Republic of Azerbaijan were created according to the Law on the Armed Forces of October 9, 1991.
746	The original date of the establishment of the short-lived National Army is celebrated as Army Day (26 June) in today's Azerbaijan.
746	As of 2002, Azerbaijan had 95,000 active personnel in its armed forces.
746	There are also 17,000 paramilitary troops.
746	The armed forces have three branches: the Land Forces, the Air Forces and the Navy.
746	Additionally the armed forces embrace several military sub-groups that can be involved in state defense when needed.
746	These are the Internal Troops of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the State Border Service, which includes the Coast Guard as well.
746	The Azerbaijan National Guard is a further paramilitary force.
746	It operates as a semi-independent entity of the Special State Protection Service, an agency subordinate to the President.
746	Azerbaijan adheres to the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe and has signed all major international arms and weapons treaties.
746	Azerbaijan closely cooperates with NATO in programs such as Partnership for Peace and Individual Partnership Action Plan.
746	Azerbaijan has deployed 151 of its Peacekeeping Forces in Iraq and another 184 in Afghanistan.
746	The military expenditures of Azerbaijan for 2011 are set at US$4,46 billion.
746	Azerbaijani defense industry manufactures small arms, artillery systems, tanks, armors and noctovision devices, aviation bombs, pilotless vehicles, various military vehicles and military planes and helicopters.&lturl = http://www.today.az/news/business/47845.html| acce;ref> Economy After gaining independence in 1991, Azerbaijan became a member of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Islamic Development Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
746	The banking system of Azerbaijan consists of the Central Bank of Azerbaijan, commercial banks and non-banking credit organizations.
746	The National (now Central) Bank was created in 1992 based on the Azerbaijan State Savings Bank, an affiliate of the former State Savings Bank of the USSR.
746	The Central Bank serves as Azerbaijan's central bank, empowered to issue the national currency, the Azerbaijani manat, and to supervise all commercial banks.
746	Two major commercial banks are the state-owned International Bank of Azerbaijan, which is run by Dr.
746	Jahangir Hajiyev, and the UniBank.
746	Pushed up by spending and demand growth, the 2007 Q1 inflation rate reached 16.6%.
746	Nominal incomes and monthly wages climbed 29% and 25% respectively against this figure, but price increases in non-oil industry encouraged inflation in the country.
746	Azerbaijan shows some signs of the so-called "Dutch disease" because of the fast growing energy sector, which causes inflation and makes non-energy exports more expensive.
746	In the early years of this century the chronically high inflation was brought under control and this led to the launch of a new currency, the new Azerbaijani manat, on January 1, 2006, to cement the acquisition of the economic reforms and erase the vestiges of an unstable economy.
746	In 2008, Azerbaijan was cited as one of the top 10 reformers by the World Bank's Doing Business Report.
746	Azerbaijan is also ranked 57th in the Global Competitiveness Report for 2010–2011, which is above other CIS countries.
746	Energy   Two thirds of Azerbaijan is rich in oil and natural gas.
746	The region of the Lesser Caucasus accounts for most of the country's gold, silver, iron, copper, titanium, chromium, manganese, cobalt, molybdenum, complex ore and antimony.
746	In September 1994, a 30-year contract was signed between the State Oil Company of Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR) and 13 oil companies, among them Amoco, BP, ExxonMobil, Lukoil and Statoil.
746	As Western oil companies are able to tap deepwater oilfields untouched by the Soviet exploitation, Azerbaijan is considered one of the most important spots in the world for oil exploration and development.
746	Meanwhile the State Oil Fund of Azerbaijan was established as an extra-budgetary fund to ensure the macroeconomic stability, transparency in the management of oil revenue, and the safeguarding of resources for future generations.
746	Azeriqaz, a sub-company of SOCAR, intends to ensure full gasification of the country by 2021.
746	Banking The GDP growth rates observed in Azerbaijan during last years made the country one of the fastest growing economies in the world.
746	But the banking sector of Azerbaijan has yet to tap the vast growth potential that should be achievable due to the continuation of the high economic growth.
746	For this reason the banking sector remains small in relation to the size of the Azerbaijani economy.
746	Although in the more advanced countries banking sectors made further visible progress in the catch-up process, the Azerbaijani banking market being in an earlier stage of development, also successes in pushing forward market-oriented reform and the privatization process.
746	Still the bankingng System: An Over system is considered an important element of financial system of Azerbaijan.
746	An advanced two-stepped banking system, which is based on market principles, (the Central Bank of the Republic of Azerbaijan in the first step, in the second one commercial banks and other non-bank credit organizations) functions in the republic.
746	Since 2002 important stage of restructuring of banking system started to be carried out.
746	Taking into consideration entry of big oil revenues in the country, as a logical result of successful oil strategy, and in this base, as the banks were ready to an effective transfer of their financial resources to the strategic goals, development strategy was made for 2002–2005.
746	Far-reaching reforms of the banking sector are conducted in the country.
746	The main challenges are due to the slow privatization rate of the state banks, a weak financial market and a lack of bank transparency.
746	However, the reforms have started showing positive resu lts and competition among the leading banks is increasing.
746	By April 1, 2010, 47 banks, 631 bank branches function in Azerbaijan.
746	One of banks was founded with participation of state capital, 23 of foreign capital.
746	To the same date, 98 non-bank credit organizations operate in the republic along with banks.
746	Growth of real money incomes of population, development of trust in bank system, improving the legal bases of protection of interests of creditors and depositors, in particular launch of ‘Deposits Insurance Fund’ were the criteria characterizing rapid growth of deposits of population.
746	As of April 1, 2010, bank deposits of population were equal to 2,4 billion AZN.
746	Along with population, bank deposits of corporative customers increase dynamically.
746	By April 1, 2010, bank deposits of corporative customers is 2,1 bn AZN.
746	Dynamic development of volume of special and involved funds of the banks has created effective conditions for enlargement of active operations.
746	As of April 1, 2010, the volume of bank assets is 12 bn AZN.
746	Crediting plays special role in structure of bank assets.
746	As of April 1, 2010, bank credits to customers is 8.5 bn AZN, which makes 70.5% of bank assets.
746	Special weight of private sector in structure of credit investments is higher than 82% (7 bn AZN).
746	Agriculture Azerbaijan has the largest agricultural basin in the region.
746	About 54,9 percent of Azerbaijan is agricultural lands.
746	At the beginning of 2007 there were 4,755,100 hectares of utilized agricultural area.
746	In the same year the total wood resources counted 136 million m³.
746	Azerbaijan's agricultural scientific research institutes are focused on meadows and pastures, horticulture and subtropical crops, green vegetables, viticulture and wine-making, cotton growing and medicinal plants.
746	In some lands it is profitable to grow grain, potatoes, sugar beets, cotton and tobacco.
746	Livestock, dairy products, and wine and spirits are also important farm products.
746	The Caspian fishing industry is concentrated on the dwindling stocks of sturgeon and beluga.
746	In 2002 the Azerbaijani merchant marine had 54 ships.
746	Some portions of most products that were previously imported from abroad have begun to be produced locally (among them are Coca Cola by Coca Cola Bottlers LTD, beer by Baki-Kastel, parquet by Nehir and oil pipes by EUPEC Pipe Coating Azerbaijan).
746	Tourism Tourism is an important part of the economy of Azerbaijan.
746	The country was a well-known tourist spot in the 1980s, yet, after the fall of the Soviet Union and the Nagorno-Karabakh War during the 1990s, damaged the tourist industry and the image of Azerbaijan as a tourist destination.
746	It was not until the 2000s that the tourism industry began to recover, and the country has since experienced a high rate of growth in the number of tourist visits and overnight stays.
746	In the recent years, Azerbaijan has also becoming a popular destination for religious, spa, and health care tourism.
746	The Government of Azerbaijan has set the development of Azerbaijan as an elite tourist destination a top priority.
746	It is a national strategy to make tourism a major, if not the single largest, contributor to the Azerbaijani economy.
746	These activities are regulated by the Ministry of Culture and Tourism of Azerbaijan.
746	Transportation The an|Rail transport in Azeconvenient location of Azerbaijan on the crossroad of major international traffic arteries, such as the Silk Road and the South-North corridor, highlights the strategic importance of transportation sector for the country’s economy.
746	The transport sector in the country includes roads, railways, aviation, and maritime transport.
746	Azerbaijan is also an important economic hub in the transportation of raw materials.
746	The Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline (BTC) became operational in May 2006 and extends more than 1,774 kilometers through the territories of Azerbaijan, Georgia and Turkey.
746	The BTC is designed to transport up to 50 million tons of crude oil annually and carries oil from the Caspian Sea oilfields to global markets.
746	The South Caucasus Pipeline, also stretching through the territory of Azerbaijan, Georgia and Turkey, became operational at the end of 2006 and offers additional gas supplies to the European market from the Shah Deniz gas field.
746	Shah Deniz is expected to produce up to 296 billion cubic meters of natural gas per year.
746	Azerbaijan also plays a major role in the EU-sponsored Silk Road Project.
746	In 2002, the Azerbaijani government established the Ministry of Transport with a broad range of policy and regulatory functions.
746	In the same year, the country became a member of the Vienna Convention on Road Traffic.
746	The highest priority being; upgrading the transport network and transforming transportation services into one of the key comparative advantages of the country, as this would be highly conducive to the development of other sectors of the economy.
746	In 2012, the construction of Kars–Tbilisi–Baku railway expected to provide transportation between Asia and Europe through connecting the railways of China and Kazakhstan in the east with Turkey's Marmaray to the European railway system in the west.
746	Broad gauge railways in 2010 stretched for 2918 km and electrified railways numbered 1278 km.
746	By 2010, there were 35 airports and one heliport.
746	Science and technology In the 21st century, a new oil and gas boom helped to improve the situation in the Azerbaijan's science and technology sectors, and the government launched a campaign aimed at modernization and innovation.
746	The government estimates that profits from the information technology and communication industry will grow and become comparable with those from oil production.
746	The country has also been making progress in developing its telecoms sector.
746	Nonetheless, it still faces problems.
746	These include poor infrastructure and an immature telecom regulatory regime.
746	The Ministry of Communications & Information Technologies (MCIT), as well as being an operator through its role in Aztelekom, is both a policy-maker and regulator.
746	Public pay phones are available for local calls and require the purchase of a token from the telephone exchange or some shops and kiosks.
746	Tokens allow a call of indefinite duration.
746	As of 2009, there were 1,397,000 main telephone lines and 1,485,000 internet users.
746	There are five GSM providers: Azercell, Bakcell, Azerfon (Nar Mobile), Aztrank, Catel mobile network operators and one CDMA.
746	In the 21st century a number of prominent Azerbaijani geodynamics and geotectonics scientists, inspired by the fundamental works of Elchin Khalilov and others, designed hundreds of earthquake prediction stations and earthquake-resistant buildings that now constitute the bulk of The Republican Center of Seismic Service.
746	The Azerbaijan National Aerospace Agency launched its first satellite AzerSat 1 into orbit in 7 February 2013 from Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana at orbital positions 46° East.
746	The satellite will cover Europe and significant part of Asian countries and Africa and will have transmission for TV, radio broadcasting and the internet.
746	The launch of its own satellite on orbit is Azerbaijan's first action in realizing prospective projects to turn itself into a country with a space industry.
746	Demographics From the total population of 9,165,000 people as of July 2011, nearly 52% was urban population, the remaining 48% was the rural population.
746	The sex ratio for total population in that year was therefore 0.97 males per female.
746	The 2011 population growth rate was 0.85%, compared to 1.09% worldwide.
746	A significant factor restricting the population growth is rather a high level of migration.
746	An estimated 3 million Azerbaijanis, many of them guest workers, live in Russia.
746	In 2011 Azerbaijan saw migration of −1.14/1,000 persons.
746	With 800,000 ethnic Azerbaijani refugees and IDPs, Azerbaijan has the largest internally displaced population in the region, and, as of 2006, had the highest per capita IDP population in the world.
746	The highest morbidity in 2005 was from respiratory diseases (806.9 diseases per 10,000 of total population).
746	In 2005, the highest morbidity for infectious and parasitic diseases was noted among influenza and acute respiratory infections (4168,2 per 100,000 population).
746	The Azerbaijani diaspora is found in 42 countries and in turn there are many centers for ethnic minorities inside Azerbaijan, including the German cultural society "Karelhaus", Slavic cultural center, Azerbaijani-Israeli community, Kurdish cultural center, International Talysh Association, Lezgin national center "Samur", Azerbaijani-Tatar community, Crimean Tatars society, etc.
746	The ethnic composition of the population according to the 2009 population census: 91.60% Azerbaijanis, 2.02% Lezgians, 1.35% Armenians (almost all Armenians live in the break-away region of Nagorno-Karabakh), 1.34% Russians, 1.26% Talysh, 0.56% Avars, 0.43% Turks, 0.29% Tatars, 0.28% Tats, 0.24% Ukrainians, 0.14% Tsakhurs, 0.11% Georgians, 0.10% Jews, 0.07% Kurds, other 0.21%.
746	Iranian Azerbaijanis are the largest minority in Iran.
746	The CIA World Factbook estimates Iranian Azerbaijanis as comprising nearly 16% of Iran's population.
746	Religion Around 95 percent of the population are Muslims.
746	Muslims are Shia Muslims and 15% Sunni Muslims, and the Republic of Azerbaijan has the Second highest Shia population percentage after Iran.
746	In Baku there is thran.
746	Fire Temple of Baku ("ateshgah") with an "old" structure which, according to travellers, has been a place of visit for Hindu priests for more than a millennium.
746	The place is often "misrepresented as a Zoroastrian fire-temple" due to frequent association of "fire temple" with the Iranian religion of Zoroastrianism.
746	Other faiths are practised by the country's various ethnic groups.
746	Under article 48 of its Constitution, Azerbaijan is a secular state and ensures religious freedom.
746	Of the nation's religious minorities, Christians are mostly Russian and Georgian Orthodox and Armenian Apostolic (almost all Armenians live in the break-away region of Nagorno-Karabakh).
746	In 2003, there were 250 Roman Catholics.
746	Other Christian denominations as of 2002 include Lutherans, Baptists and Molokans.
746	There are also Jewish, Bahá'í, Hare Krishna and Jehovah's Witnesses communities, as well as adherents of the Nehemiah Church, Star in the East Church and the Cathedral of Praise Church.
746	Language The official language is Azerbaijani, which belongs to the Turkic language family, spoken in southwestern Asia, primarily in Azerbaijan and Iranian Azerbaijan.
746	Azerbaijani is member of the Oghuz branch of the Turkic languages and is closely related to Turkish, Qashqa'i and Turkmen.
746	The Azerbaijani language is divided into two varieties, North Azerbaijani  and South Azerbaijani, and a large number of dialects.
746	Turkic Khalaj, Qashqa'i, and Salchuq are considered by some to be separate languages in the Azerbaijani language group.
746	Azerbaijani served as a lingua franca throughout most parts of Transcaucasia (except the Black Sea coast), in Southern Dagestan, eastern Turkey, and Iranian Azerbaijan from the 16th century to the early 20th century.
746	Although Azerbaijani (also called Azeri) is the most widely spoken language in the country and is spoken by about a quarter of the population of Iran, there are 13 other languages spoken natively in the country.
746	Some of these languages are very small communities, others are more vital.
746	Azerbaijani is mutually intelligible with Turkish and Gagauz.
746	The northern variety of the language is written with a modified Latin alphabet today, but was earlier written in the Perso-Arabic alphabet (until 1929), in the Uniform Turkic Alphabet (1929–1939), and in the Cyrillic alphabet (1939–1991).
746	The changes in alphabet have been largely molded by religious and political forces.
746	Education A relatively high percentage of Azerbaijanis have obtained some form of higher education, most notably in scientific and technical subjects.
746	In the Soviet era, literacy and average education levels rose dramatically from their very low starting point, despite two changes in the standard alphabet, from Perso-Arabic script to Latin in the 1920s and from Roman to Cyrillic in the 1930s.
746	According to Soviet data, 100 percent of males and females (ages nine to forty-nine) were literate in 1970.
746	According to the  nine to forty-nine) werUnited Nations Development Program Report 2009, the literacy rate in Azerbaijan is 99.5 percent.
746	Since independence, one of the first laws that Azerbaijan's Parliament passed to disassociate itself from the Soviet Union was to adopt a modified-Latin alphabet to replace Cyrillic.
746	Other than that the Azerbaijani system has undergone little structural change.
746	Initial alterations have included the reestablishment of religious education (banned during the Soviet period) and curriculum changes that have reemphasized the use of the Azerbaijani language and have eliminated ideological content.
746	In addition to elementary schools, the education institutions include thousands of preschools, general secondary schools, and vocational schools, including specialized secondary schools and technical schools.
746	Education through the eighth grade is compulsory.
746	Culture The culture of Azerbaijan has developed as a result of many influences.
746	Today, Western influences, including globalized consumer culture, are strong.
746	National traditions are well preserved in the country.
746	Some of the main elements of the Azerbaijani culture are: music, literature, folk dances and art, cuisine, architecture, cinematography and Novruz Bayram.
746	The latter is the traditional celebration of the ancient New Year.
746	Novruz is a family holiday.
746	Azerbaijan folk consists of Azerbaijanis, the representative part of society, as well as of nations and ethnic groups, compactly living in various areas of the country.
746	Azerbaijani national and traditional dresses are the Chokha and Papakhi.
746	There are radio broadcasts in Russian, Armenian, Georgian, Kurdish, Lezgian and Talysh languages, which are financed from the state budget.
746	Some local radio stations in Balakan and Khachmaz organize broadcasts in Avar and Tat.
746	In Baku several newspapers are published in Russian, Kurdish (Dengi Kurd), Lezgian (Samur) and Talysh languages.
746	Jewish society "Sokhnut" publishes the newspaper Aziz.
746	Music and folk dances Music of Azerbaijan builds on folk traditions that reach back nearly a thousand years.
746	For centuries Azerbaijani music has evolved under the badge of monody, producing rhythmically diverse melodies.
746	Azerbaijani music has a branchy mode system, where chromatization of major and minor scales is of great importance.
746	Among national musical instruments there are 14 string instruments, eight percussion instruments and six wind instruments.
746	According to The Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, "in terms of ethnicity, culture and religion the Azeri are musically much closer to Iran than Turkey."
746	Mugham, meykhana and ashiq art are one of the many musical traditions of Azerbaijan.
746	Mugham is usually a suite with poetry and instrumental interludes.
746	When performing Mugham, the singers have to transform their emotions into singing and music.
746	Mugham singer Alim Qasimov is revered as one of the five best singers of all time.
746	In contrast to the mugham traditions of Central Asian countries, Azeri mugham is more free-form and less rigid; it is often compared to the improvised field of jazz.
746	UNESCO proclaimed the Azerbaijani mugham tradition a Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity on 7 November 2003.
746	Meykhana is a kind of traditional Azeri distinctive folk unaccompanied song, usually performed by several people improvising on a particular subject.
746	Ashiq combines poetry, storytelling, dance and vocal and instrumental music into a traditional performance art that stands as a symbol of Azerbaijani culture.
746	It is a mystic troubadour or traveling bard who sings and plays the saz.
746	This tradition has its origin in the Shamanistic beliefs of ancient Turkic peoples.
746	Ashiqs' songs are semi-improvised around common bases.
746	Azerbaijan’s ashiq art was included in the list of Intangible Cultural Heritage by the UNESCO on September 30, 2009.
746	Azerbaijan made its debut appearance at the 2008 Eurovision Song Contest.
746	The country's Eurovision Song Contest.
746	The country's entry gained the third place in 2009 and fifth the following year.
746	Ell and Nikki won the first place at the Eurovision Song Contest 2011 with the song "Running Scared", entitling Azerbaijan to host the contest in 2012, in Baku.
746	There are dozens of Azerbaijani folk dances.
746	They are performed at formal celebrations and the dancers wear national clothes like the Chokha, which is well preserved within the national dances.
746	Most dances have a very fast rhythm.
746	The national dance shows the characteristics of the Azerbaijani nation.
746	Architecture Azerbaijani architecture typically combines elements of East and West.
746	Many ancient architectural treasures such as the Maiden Tower and Palace of the Shirvanshahs in the Walled City of Baku survive in modern Azerbaijan.
746	Entries submitted on the UNESCO World Heritage tentative list include the Ateshgah of Baku, Momine Khatun Mausoleum, Hirkan National Park, Binegadi National Park, Lok-Batan Mud Volcano, Baku Stage Mountain, Caspian Shore Defensive Constructions, Susha National Reserve, Ordubad National Reserve and the Palace of Shaki Khans.
746	Among other architectural treasures are Quadrangular Castle in Mardakan, Parigala in Yukhary Chardaglar, a number of bridges spanning the Aras River, and several mausoleums.
746	In the 19th and early 20th centuries, little monumental architecture was created, but distinctive residences were built in Baku and elsewhere.
746	Among the most recent architectural monuments, the Baku subways are noted for their lavish decor.
746	Plans have recently been revealed for the building of the Azerbaijan Tower.
746	It will reportedly replace the Burj Khalifa as the tallest building in the world with a planned height of 1050 m.
746	Cinematography The film industry in Azerbaijan dates back to 1898.
746	In fact, Azerbaijan was among the first countries involved in cinematography.
746	Therefore It's not surprising that this apparatus soon showed up in Baku – at the start of the 20th century, this bay town on the Caspian was producing more than 50 percent of the world's supply of oil.
746	Just like today, the oil industry attracted foreigners eager to invest and to work.
746	In 1919, during the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic, a documentary The Celebration of the Anniversary of Azerbaijani Independence was filmed on Azerbaijan's independence day, May 28, and premiered in June 1919 at several theatres in Baku.
746	After the Soviet power was established in 1920, Nariman Narimanov, Chairman of the Revolutionary Committee of Azerbaijan, signed a decree nationalizing Azerbaijan's cinema.
746	This also influenced the creation of Azerbaijani animation.
746	In 1991, after Azerbaijan gained its independence from the Soviet Union, the first Baku International Film Festival East-West was held in Baku.
746	In December 2000, the former President of Azerbaijan, Heydar Aliyev, signed a decree proclaiming August 2 professional holiday of filmmakers of Azerbaijan.
746	Today Azerbaijani filmmakers are again dealing with issues similar to those faced by cinematographers prior to the establishment of the Soviet Union in 1920.
746	Once again, both choice of content and sponsorship of films are largely left up to the initiative of the filmmaker.
746	There are 3 state-owned television channels: AzTV, Idman TV and Medeniyyet TV.
746	One public channel, Ictimai TV and 7 private channels: ANS TV, Space TV, Lider TV, Azad Azerbaijan TV, Xazar TV and Azerbaijan International.
746	Folk art Azerbaijanis have a rich and distinctive culture, a major part of which is decorative and applied art.
746	This form of art is represented by a wide range of handicrafts, such as chasing, jeweler, engraving in metal, carving in wood, stone and bone, carpet-making, lasing, pattern weaving and printing, knitting and embroidery.
746	Each of these types of decorative art, evidence of the and endowments of the Azerbaijan nation, is very much in favor here.
746	Many interesting facts pertaining to the development of arts and crafts in Azerbaijan were reported by numerous merchants, travelers and diplomats who had visited these places at different times.
746	The Azerbaijani carpet is a traditional handmade textile of various sizes, with dense texture and a pile or pile-less surface, whose patterns are characteristic of Azerbaijan’s many carpet-making d a pile or pile-lregions.
746	In November 2010 the Azerbaijani carpet was proclaimed a Masterpiece of Intangible Heritage by UNESCO.
746	Azerbaijan has been since the ancient times known as a center of a large variety of crafts.
746	The archeological dig on the territory of Azerbaijan testifies to the well developed agriculture, stock raising, metal working, pottery and ceramics, and last but not least carpet-weaving that date as far back as to the 2nd millennium BC.
746	Azerbaijani carpets can be categorized under several large groups and a multitude of subgroups.
746	The true scientific research of the Azerbaijani carpet is connected with the name of Latif Kerimov, a prominent scientist and artist.
746	It was his classification that related the four large groups of carpets with the four geographical zones of Azerbaijan, Guba-Shirvan, Ganja-Kazakh, Karabakh and Tabriz.
746	Cuisine The traditional cuisine is famous for an abundance of vegetables and greens used seasonally in the dishes.
746	Fresh herbs, including mint, cilantro (coriander), dill, basil, parsley, tarragon, leeks, chives, thyme, marjoram, green onion, and watercress, are very popular and often accompany main dishes on the table.
746	Climatic diversity and fertility of the land are reflected in the national dishes, which are based on fish from the Caspian Sea, local meat (mainly mutton and beef), and an abundance of seasonal vegetables and greens.
746	Saffron-rice plov is the flagship food in Azerbaijan and black tea is the national beverage.
746	Literature The earliest known figure in Azerbaijani literature was Hasanoghlu or Pur Hasan Asfaraini, who composed a divan consisting of Persian and Turkic ghazals.
746	In Persian ghazals he used his pen-name, while his Turkic ghazals were composed under his own name of Hasanoghlu.
746	Classical literature in Azerbaijani was formed in 14th century based on the various dialect Early Middle Ages dialects of Tabriz and Shirvan.
746	Among the poets of this period were Gazi Burhanaddin, Haqiqi (pen-name of Jahan-shah Qara Qoyunlu), and Habibi.
746	The end of 14th century was also the period of starting literary activity of Imadaddin Nesimi, one of the greatest Turkic Hurufi mystical poets of the late 14th and early 15th centuries and one of the most prominent early Divan masters in Turkic literary history, who also composed poetry in Persian and Arabic.
746	The Divan and Ghazal styles were further developed by poets Qasim al-Anvar, Fuzuli and Khatai (pen-name of Safavid Shah Ismail I).
746	The acclaimed Book of Dede Korkut consists of two manuscripts copied in the 16th century, was not written earlier than the 15th century.
746	It is a collection of 12 stories reflecting the oral tradition of Oghuz nomads.
746	The 16th century poet, Muhammed Fuzuli produced his timeless philosophical and lyrical Qazals in Arabic, Persian, and Azeri.
746	Benefiting immensely from the fine literary traditions of his environment, and building upon the legacy of his predecessors, Fizuli was destined to become the leading literary figure of his society.
746	His major works include The Divan of Ghazals and The Qasidas.
746	In the same century, Azerbaijani literature further flourished with the development of Ashik () poetic genre of bards.
746	During the same period, under the pen-name of Khatāī ( for sinner) Shah Ismail I wrote about 1400 verses in Azeri, which were later published as his Divan.
746	A unique literary style known as qoshma ( for improvization) was introduced in this period, and developed by Shah Ismail and later by his son and successor, Shah Tahmasp I.
746	In the span of the 17th and 18th centuries, Fizuli's unique genres as well Ashik poetry were taken up by prominent poets and writers such as Qovsi of Tabriz, Shah Abbas Sani, Agha Mesih Shirvani, Nishat, Molla Vali Vidadi, Molla Panah Vagif, Amani, Zafar and others.
746	Along with Turks, Turkmens and Uzbeks, Azeris also celebrate the Epic of Koroglu (from  for blind man's son), a legendary folk hero.
746	Several documented versions of Koroglu epic remain at the Institute for Manuscripts of the National Academy of Sciences of Azerbaijan.
746	Modern literature in Azerbaijan is based on the Shirvani dialect mainly, while in Iran it is based on the Tabrizi one.
746	The first newspaper in Azerbaijani, Akinchi was published in 1875.
746	In mid-19th century, it was taught in the schools of Baku, Ganja, Shaki, Tbilisi, and Yerevan.
746	Since 1845, it has also been taught in the University of Saint Petersburg in Russia.
746	Sports Sport in Azerbaijan has ancient roots, and even now, both traditional and modern sports are still practiced.
746	Freestyle wrestling has been traditionally regarded as Azerbaijan's national sport, in which Azerbaijan won up to 14 medals, including 4 golds since joining the National Olympic Committee.
746	Even though today, the most popular sports in Azerbaijan are football and chess.
746	The national football team of Azerbaijan demonstrates relatively low performance in the international arena compared to the nation football clubs.
746	It is mainly because of the foreign footballers playing in the clubs.
746	However, the newly opened Azerbaijan Football Academy in February 2009 is a huge step in the development of the youth football.
746	The most successful Azerbaijani football clubs are Neftchi Baku, FC Baku, Inter Baku, FK Qarabağ and Khazar Lankaran.
746	In 2012, Neftchi Baku became the first Azerbaijani team to advance to the group stage of a European competition, beating APOEL of Cyprus 4-2 on aggregate in the play-off round of the 2012-13 UEFA Europa League.
746	In 2012, country also hosted the 2012 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup.
746	Futsal is another popular sport in Azerbaijan.
746	Azerbaijan national futsal team reached the fourth place in 2010 UEFA Futsal Championship, while domestic club Araz Naxçivan clinched bronze medals at 2009–10 UEFA Futsal Cup.
746	Backgammon plays a major role in Azerbaijani culture.
746	This game is very popular in Azerbaijan and is widely played among the local public.
746	There are also different variations of backgammon developed and analyzed by Azerbaijani experts.
746	Azerbaijan is known as one of the chess superpowers; despite the collapse of the Soviet Union, chess is still extremely popular.
746	Notable Azerbaijani chess players include Teimour Radjabov, Shahriyar Mammadyarov, Vladimir Makogonov, Garry Kasparov, Vugar Gashimov and Zeinab Mamedyarova.
746	Azerbaijan has also hosted many international chess tournaments and competitions and became European Team Chess Championship winners in 2009.
746	Other well-known Azerbaijani athletes are Namig Abdullayev, Toghrul Asgarov, Rovshan Bayramov, Sharif Sharifov, Mariya Stadnik and Farid Mansurov in wrestling, Ramil Guliyev and Hayle Ibrahimov in athletics, Elnur Mammadli and Movlud Miraliyev in judo, Rafael Aghayev in karate, Valeriya Korotenko and Natalya Mammadova in volleyball and K-1 fighter Zabit Samedov.
748	Amateur astronomy, also called backyard astronomy and stargazing, is a hobby whose participants enjoy watching the sky, and the abundance of objects found in it, mainly with portable telescopes and binoculars.
748	Even though scientific research is not their main goal, many amateur astronomers make a contribution to astronomy by monitoring variable stars, tracking asteroids and discovering transient objects, such as comets.
748	The typical amateur astronomer is one who does not depend on the field of astronomy as a primary source of income or support, and does not have a professional degree or advanced academic training in the subject.
748	Many amateurs are beginners or hobbyists, while others have a high degree of experience in astronomy and often assist and work alongside professional astronomers.
748	Amateur astronomy is usually associated with viewing the night sky when most celestial objects and events are visible, but sometimes amateur astronomers also operate during the day for events such as sunspots and solar eclipses.
748	Amateur astronomers often look at the sky using vents such as sunspots and solar eclipses.
748	Amateur astronnothing more than their eyes, but common tools for amateur astronomy include portable telescopes and binoculars.
748	People have studied the sky throughout history in an amateur framework, without any formal method of funding.
748	It is only within about the past century, however, that amateur astronomy has become an activity clearly distinguished from professional astronomy, and other related activities.
748	Amateur astronomy objectives  Collectively, amateur astronomers observe a variety of celestial objects and phenomena.
748	Common targets of amateur astronomers include the Moon, planets, stars, comets, meteor showers, and a variety of deep sky objects such as star clusters, galaxies, and nebulae.
748	Many amateurs like to specialise in observing particular objects, types of objects, or types of events which interest them.
748	One branch of amateur astronomy, amateur astrophotography, involves the taking of photos of the night sky.
748	Astrophotography has become more popular for amateurs in recent times, as relatively sophisticated equipment, such as high quality CCD cameras, has become more affordable.
748	Most amateurs work at visible wavelengths, but a small minority experiment with wavelengths outside the visible spectrum.
748	An early pioneer of radio astronomy was Grote Reber, an  amateur astronomer who constructed the first purpose built radio telescope in the late 1930s to follow up on the discovery of radio wavelength emissions from space by Karl Jansky.
748	Non-visual amateur astronomy includes the use of infrared filters on conventional telescopes, and also the use of radio telescopes.
748	Some amateur astronomers use home-made radio telescopes, while others use radio telescopes that were originally built for astronomy research but have since been made available for use by amateurs.
748	The One-Mile Telescope is one such example.
748	Common tools  Amateur astronomers use a range of instruments to study the sky, depending on a combination of their interests and resources.
748	Methods include simply looking at the night sky with the naked eye, using binoculars, and using a variety of optical telescopes of varying power and quality, as well as additional sophisticated equipment, such as cameras, to study light from the sky in both the visual and non-visual parts of the spectrum.
748	Commercial telescopes are available new and used, but in some places it is also common for amateur astronomers to build (or commission the building of) their own custom telescope.
748	Some people even focus on amateur telescope making as their primary interest within the hobby of amateur astronomy.
748	Although specialized and experienced amateur astronomers tend to acquire more specialized and more powerful equipment over time, relatively simple equipment is often preferred for certain tasks.
748	Binoculars, for instance, although generally of lower power than the majority of telescopes, also tend to provide a wider field of view, which is preferable for looking at some objects in the night sky.
748	Amateur astronomers also use star charts that, depending on experience and intentions, may range from simple planispheres through to detailed charts of very specific areas of the night sky.
748	A range of astronomy software is available and used by amateur astronomers, including software that generates maps of the sky, software to assist with astrophotography, observation scheduling software, and software to perform various calculations pertaining to astronomical phenomena.
748	Amateur astronomers often like to keep records of their observations, which usually takes the form of an observing log.
748	Observing logs typically record details about which objects were observed and when, as well as describing the details that were seen.
748	Sketching is sometimes used within logs, and photographic records of observations have also been used in recent times.
748	The Internet is an essential tool of amateur astronomers.
748	The popularity of CCD imaging among amateurs has led to large numbers of web sites being written by individuals about their images and equipment.
748	Much of the social interaction of amateur astronomy occurs on mailing lists or discussion groups.
748	Discussion group servers host numerous astronomy lists.
748	A great deal of the commerce of amateur astronomy, the buying and selling of equipment, occurs online.
748	Many amateurs use online tools to plan their nightly observing sessions using tools such as the Clear Sky Chart.
748	Common techniques  While a number of interesting celestial objects are readily identified by the naked eye, sometimes with the aid of a star chart, many others are so faint or inconspicuous that technical means are necessary to locate them.
748	Many methods are used in amateur astronomy, but most are variations of a few specific techniques.
748	Star hopping  Star hopping is a method often used by amateur astronomers with low-tech equipment such as binoculars or a manually driven telescope.
748	It involves the use of maps (or memory) to locate known landmark stars, and "hopping" between them, often with the aid of a finderscope.
748	Because of its simplicity, star hopping is a very common method for finding objects that are close to naked-eye stars.
748	More advanced methods of locating objects in the sky include telescope mounts with setting circles, which assist with pointing telescopes to positions in the sky that are known to contain objects of interest, and GOTO telescopes, which are fully automated telescopes that are capable of locating objects on demand (having first been calibrated).
748	Setting circles  Setting circles are angular measurement scales that can be placed on the two main rotation axes of some telescopes.
748	Since the widespread adoption of digital setting circles, any classical engraved setting circle is now specifically identified as an "analog setting circle" (ASC).
748	By knowing the coordinates of an object (usually given in equatorial coordinates), the telescope user can use the setting circle to align the telescope in the appropriate direction before looking through its eyepiece.
748	A computerized setting circle is called a "digital setting circle" (DSC).
748	Although digital setting circles can be used to display a telescope's RA and Dec coordinates, they are not simply a digital read-out of what can be seen on the telescope's analog setting circles.
748	As with go-to telescopes, digital setting circle computers (commercial names include Argo Navis, Sky Commander, and NGC Max) contain databases of tens of thousands of celestial objects and projections of planet positions.
748	To find an object, such as globular cluster NGC 6712, one does not need to look up the RA and Dec coordinates in a book, and then move the telescope to those numerical readings.
748	Rather, the object is chosen from the database and arrow markers appear in the display which indicate the direction to move the telescope.
748	The telescope is moved until the distance value reaches zero.
748	When both the RA and Dec axes are thus "zeroed out", the object should be in the eyepiece.
748	The user therefore does not have to go back and forth from some other database (such as a book or laptop) to match the desired object's listed coordinates to the coordinates on the telescope.
748	However, many DSCs, and also go-to systems, can work in conjunction with laptop sky programs.
748	Computerized systems provide the further advantage of computing coordinate precession.
748	Traditional printed sources are subtitled by the 'epoch year, which refers to the positions of celestial objects at a given time to the nearest year (e.g., J2005, J2007).
748	Most such printed sources have been updated for intervals of only about every fifty years (e.g., J1900, J1950, J2000).
748	Computerized sources, on the other hand, are able to calculate the right ascension and declination of the "epoch of date" to the exact instant of observation.
748	GoTo telescopes GOTO telescopes have become more popular since the 1980s as technology has improved and prices have been reduced.
748	With these computer-driven telescopes, the user typically enters the name of the item of interest and the mechanics of the telescope point the telescope towards that item automatically.
748	They have several notable advantages for amateur astronomers intent on research.
748	For example, GOTO telescopes tend to be faster for locating items of interest than star hopping, allowing more time for studying of the object.
748	GOTO also allows manufacturers to add equatorial tracking to mechanically simpler alt-azimuth telescope mounts, allowing them to produce an over all less expensive product.
748	GOTO telescopes usually have to be calibrated using alignment stars in order to provide accurate tracking and positioning.
748	However, several telescope manufacturers have recently developed telescope systems that are calibrated with the use of built-in GPS, decreasing the time it takes to set up a telescope at the start of an observing session.
748	Remote control telescopes With the development of fast Internet in the last part of the 20th century along with advances in computer controlled telescope mounts and CCD cameras 'Remote Telescope' astronomy is now a viable means for amateur astronomers not aligned with major telescope facilities to partake in research and deep sky imaging.
748	This enables anyone to control a telescope a large distance away in a dark location.
748	The observers can image through the telescopes using CCD cameras.
748	The digital data collected by the telescope is then transmitted and displayed to the user by means of the Internet.
748	An example of a digital remote telescope operation for public use via the Internet is the The Bareket Observatory.
748	Imaging techniques  Amateur astronomers engage in many imaging techniques including film and CCD astrophotography.
748	Because CCD imagers are linear, image processing may be used to subtract away the effects of light pollution, which has increased the popularity of astrophotography in urban areas.
748	Scientific research  Scientific research is most often not the main goal for many amateur astronomers, unlike professional astronomy.
748	Work of scientific merit is possible, however, and many amateurs successfully contribute to the knowledge base of professional astronomers.
748	Astronomy is sometimes promoted as one of the few remaining sciences for which amateurs can still contribute useful data.
748	To recognize this, the Astronomical Society of the Pacific annually gives Amateur Achievement Awards for significant contributions to astronomy by amateurs.
748	The majority of scientific contributions by amateur astronomers are in the area of data collection.
748	In particular, this applies where large numbers of amateur astronomers with small telescopes are more effective than the relatively small number of large telescopes that are available to professional astronomers.
748	Several organizations, such as the American Association of Variable Star Observers, exist to help coordinate these contributions.
748	Amateur astronomers often contribute toward activities such as monitoring the changes in brightness of variable stars and supernovae, helping to track asteroids, and observing occultations to determine both the shape of asteroids and the shape of the terrain on the apparent edge of the Moon as seen from Earth.
748	With more advanced equipment, but still cheap in comparison to professional setups, amateur astronomers can measure the light spectrum emitted from astronomical objects, which can yield high-quality scientific data if the measurements are performed with due care.
748	A relatively recent role for amateur astronomers is searching for overlooked phenomena (e.g., Kreutz Sungrazers) in the vast libraries of digital images and other data captured by Earth and space based observatories, much of which is available over the Internet.
748	In the past and present, amateur astronomers have played a major role in discovering new comets.
748	Recently however, funding of projects such as the Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research and Near Earth Asteroid Tracking projects has meant that most comets are now discovered by automated systems, long before it is possible for amateurs to see them.
748	Societies  There is a large number of amateur astronomical societies around the world that serve as a meeting point for those interested in amateur astronomy, whether they be people who are actively interested in observing or "armchair astronomers" who may simply be interested in the topic.
748	Societies range widely in their goals, depending on a variety of factors such as geographic spread, local circumstances, size, and membership.
748	For instance, a local society in the middle of a large city may have regular meetings with speakers, focusing less on observing the night sky if the membership is less able to observe due to factors such as light pollution.
748	It is common for local societies to hold regular meetings, which may include activities such as star parties or presentations.
748	Societies are also a meeting point for people with particular interests, such as amateur telescope making.
748	Notable amateur astronomers  * George Alcock, discovered several comets and novae.
748	Thomas Bopp, shared the discovery of Comet Hale-Bopp in 1995 with unemployed PhD physicist Alan Hale.
748	Robert Burnham, Jr., author of the Celestial Handbook.
748	Andrew Ainslie Common (1841–1903), built his own very large reflecting telescopes and demonstrated that photography could record astronomical features invisible to the human eye.
748	Robert E.
748	Cox (1917–1989) who conducted the "Gleanings for ATMs" column in Sky and Telescope magazine for 21 years.
748	John Dobson (1915), whose name is associated with the Dobsonian telescope, a simplified design for Newtonian reflecting telescopes.
748	Robert Owen Evans is a minister of the Uniting Church in Australia and an amateur astronomer who holds the all-time record for visual discoveries of supernovae.
748	Clinton B.
748	Ford (1913–1992), who specialized in the observation of variable stars.
748	Will Hay, the famous comedian and actor, who discovered a white spot on Saturn.
748	Walter Scott Houston (1912–1993) who wrote the "Deep-Sky Wonders" column in Sky & Telescope magazine for almost 50 years.
748	Albert G.
748	Ingalls (1888–1958), editor of Amateur Telescope Making, Vols.
748	"The Amateur Scientist".
