748	He and Russell Porter are generally credited with having initiated the amateur telescope making movement in the US.
748	David H.
748	Levy discovered or co-discovered 22 comets including Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, the most for any individual.
748	Sir Patrick Moore, presenter of the BBC's long-running The Sky at Night and author of many books on astronomy.
748	Leslie Peltier was a prolific discoverer of comets and well-known observer of variable stars.
748	John M.
748	Pierce (1886–1958) was one of the founders of the Springfield Telescope Makers.
748	In the 1930s he published a series of 14 artifield Telescope Makerscles on telescope making in Hugo Gernsback's "Everyday Science and Mechanics" called "Hobbygraphs".
748	He is considered one of "the big three behind the amateur telescope making movement in America".
748	Tim Puckett, the principal investigator of the Puckett Observatory World Supernova Search team, which has discovered over 200 supernovae since 1998.
748	Russell W.
748	Porter founded Stellafane and has been referred to as the "founder" or one of the "founders" of amateur telescope making.
748	Albert G.
748	Ingalls is sometime given credit as co-founder of this movement.
748	Isaac Roberts, early experimenter in astronomical photography.
748	Grote Reber (1911–2002), pioneer of radio astronomy constructing the first purpose built radio telescope and conducted the first sky survey in the radio frequency.
748	Prizes recognizing amateur astronomers  * Amateur Achievement Award of Astronomical Society of the Pacific * Chambliss Amateur Achievement Award
751	Japanese martial art developed by Morihei Ueshiba as a synthesis of his martial studies, philosophy, and religious beliefs.
751	Aikido is often translated as "the Way of unifying (with) life energy" or as "the Way of harmonious spirit."
751	Ueshiba's goal was to create an art that practitioners could use to defend themselves while also protecting their awas to create an art that practitionersttacker from injury.
751	Aikido is performed by blending with the motion of the attacker and redirecting the force of the attack rather than opposing it head-on.
751	This requires very little physical strength, as the aikidōka (aikido practitioner) "leads" the attacker's momentum using entering and turning movements.
751	The techniques are completed with various throws or joint locks.
751	Aikido derives mainly from the martial art of Daitō-ryū Aiki-jūjutsu, but began to diverge from it in the late 1920s, partly due to Ueshiba's involvement with the Ōmoto-kyō religion.
751	Ueshiba's early students' documents bear the term aiki-jūjutsu.
751	Ueshiba's senior students have different approaches to aikido, depending partly on when they studied with him.
751	Today aikido is found all over the world in a number of styles, with broad ranges of interpretation and emphasis.
751	However, they all share techniques learned from Ueshiba and most have concern for the well-being of the attacker.
751	Etymology and basic philosophy The word "aikido" is formed of three kanji: *  – ai – joining, unifying, combining, fit *  – ki – spirit, energy, mood, morale *  – dō – way, path The term "aiki" does not readily appear in the Japanese language outside the scope of Budo.
751	This has led to many possible interpretations of the word.
751	There is an idea of reciprocity,  (to get to know one another),  (talk/discussion/negotiation), and  (meet by appointment).
751	I feel', as in terms of thinking but with less cognitive reasoning),  (feeling/sensation), and  (mood/morale).
751	It is used to mean energy or force, as in  (electricity) and  (magnetism).
751	The term  is also found in martial arts such as judo and kendo, and in the more peaceful arts such as Japanese calligraphy (), flower arranging () and tea ceremony ().
751	Therefore, from a purely linguistic point of view, aikido is 'Way of combining forces'.
751	The term  refers to the martial arts principle or tactic of blending with an attacker's movements for the purpose of controlling their actions with minimal effort.
751	One applies  by understanding the rhythm and intent of the attacker to find the optimal position and timing to apply a counter-technique.
751	This then is very similar to the principles expressed by Kanō Jigorō, founder of judo.
751	History Aikido was created by Morihei Ueshiba ( , 14 December 1883 – 26 April 1969), referred to by some aikido practitioners as  ("Great Teacher").
751	Ueshiba envisioned aikido not only as the synthesis of his martial training, but as an expression of his personal philosophy of universal peace and reconciliation.
751	During Ueshiba's lifetime and continuing today, aikido has evolved from the Aiki that Ueshiba studied into a wide variety of expressions by martial artists throughout the world.
751	Initial development Ueshiba developed aikido primarily during the late 1920s through the 1930s through the synthesis of the older martial arts that he had studied.
751	The core martial art from which aikido derives is Daitō-ryū aiki-jūjutsu, which Ueshiba studied directly with Takeda Sōkaku, the reviver of that art.
751	Additionally, Ueshiba is known to have studied Tenjin Shin'yō-ryū with Tozawa Tokusaburō in Tokyo in 1901, Gotōha Yagyū Shingan-ryū under Nakai Masakatsu in Sakai from 1903 to 1908, and judo with Kiyoichi Takagi ( , 1894–1972) in Tanabe in 1911.
751	The art of Daitō-ryū is the primary technical influence on aikido.
751	Along with empty-handed throwing and joint-locking techniques, Ueshiba incorporated training movements with weapons, such as those for the spear (), short staff (), and perhaps the .
751	However, aikido derives much of its technical structure from the art of swordsmanship ().
751	Ueshiba moved to Hokkaidō in 1912, and began studying under Takeda Sokaku in 1915.
751	His official association with Daitō-ryū continued until 1937.
751	However, during the latter part of that period, Ueshiba had already begun to distance himself from Takeda and the Daitō-ryū.
751	At that time Ueshiba was referring to his martial art as "Aiki Budō".
751	It is unclear exactly when Ueshiba began using the name "aikido", but it became the official name clear exactly when Ueshiba began using the name "aikido", but it became the offof the art in 1942 when the Greater Japan Martial Virtue Society () was engaged in a government sponsored reorganization and centralization of Japanese martial arts.
751	Religious influences After Ueshiba left Hokkaidō in 1919, he met and was profoundly influenced by Onisaburo Deguchi, the spiritual leader of the Ōmoto-kyō religion (a neo-Shinto movement) in Ayabe.
751	One of the primary features of Ōmoto-kyō is its emphasis on the attainment of utopia during one's life.
751	This was a great influence on Ueshiba's martial arts philosophy of extending love and compassion especially to those who seek to harm others.
751	Aikido demonstrates this philosophy in its emphasis on mastering martial arts so that one may receive an attack and harmlessly redirect it.
751	In an ideal resolution, not only is the receiver unharmed, but so is the attacker.
751	In addition to the effect on his spiritual growth, the connection with Deguchi gave Ueshiba entry to elite political and military circles as a martial artist.
751	As a result of this exposure, he was able to attract not only financial backing but also gifted students.
751	Several of these students would found their own styles of aikido.
751	International dissemination Aikido was first brought to the rest of the world in 1951 by Minoru Mochizuki with a visit to France where he introduced aikido techniques to judo students.
751	He was followed by Tadashi Abe in 1952 who came as the official Aikikai Hombu representative, remaining in France for seven years.
751	Kenji Tomiki toured with a delegation of various martial arts through 15 continental states of the United States in 1953.
751	Later in that year, Koichi Tohei was sent by Aikikai Hombu to Hawaii, for a full year, where he set up several dojo.
751	This was followed up by several further visits and is considered the formal introduction of aikido to the United States.
751	The United Kingdom followed in 1955; Italy in 1964 by Hiroshi Tada; and Germany 1965 by Katsuaki Asai.
751	Designated "Official Delegate for Europe and Africa" by Morihei Ueshiba, Masamichi Noro arrived in France in September 1961.
751	Seiichi Sugano was appointed to introduce aikido to Australia in 1965.
751	Today there are aikido dojo available throughout the world.
751	Aikido was exhibited in Hollywood films by Steven Seagal in the 1990s.
751	Proliferation of independent organizations The largest aikido organization is the Aikikai Foundation which remains under the control of the Ueshiba family.
751	However, aikido has many styles, mostly formed by Morihei Ueshiba's major students.
751	The earliest independent styles to emerge were Yoseikan Aikido, begun by Minoru Mochizuki in 1931, Yoshinkan Aikido founded by Gozo Shioda in 1955, and Shodokan Aikido, founded by Kenji Tomiki in 1967.
751	The emergence of these styles pre-dated Ueshiba's death and did not cause any major upheavals when they were formalized.
751	Shodokan Aikido, however, was controversial, since it introduced a unique rule-based competition that some felt was contrary to the spirit of aikido.
751	After Ueshiba's death in 1969, two more major styles emerged.
751	Significant controversy arose with the departure of the Aikikai Hombu Dojo's chief instructor Koichi Tohei, in 1974.
751	Tohei left as a result of a disagreement with the son of the founder, Kisshomaru Ueshiba, who at that time headed the Aikikai Foundation.
751	The disagreement was over the proper role of ki development in regular aikido training.
751	After Tohei left, he formed his own style, called Shin Shin Toitsu Aikido, and the organization which governs it, the Ki Society (Ki no Kenkyūkai).
751	A final major style evolved from Ueshiba's retirement in Iwama, Ibaraki, and the teaching methodology of long term student Morihiro Saito.
751	It is unofficially referred to as the "Iwama style", and at one point a number of its followers formed a loose network of schools they called Iwama Ryu.
751	Although Iwama style practitioners remained part of the Aikikai until Saito's death in 2002, followers of Saito subsequently split into two groups; one remaining with the Aikikai and the other forming the independent Shinshin Aikishuren Kai in 2004 around Saito's son Hitohiro Saito.
751	Today, the major styles of aikido are each run by a separate governing organization, have their own  in Japan, and have an international breadth.
751	Training In aikido, as in virtually all Japanese martial arts, there are both physical and mental aspects of training.
751	The physical training in aikido is diverse, covering both general physical fitness and conditioning, as well as specific techniques.
751	Because a substantial portion of any aikido curriculum consists of throws, the first thing most students learn is how to safely fall or roll.
751	The specific techniques for attack include both strikes and grabs; the techniques for defense consist of throws and pins.
751	After basic techniques are learned, students study freestyle defense against multiple opponents, and techniques with weapons.
751	Fitness Physical training goals pursued in conjunction with aikido include controlled relaxation, flexibility, and endurance, with less emphasis on strength training.
751	In aikido, pushing or extending movements are much more common than pulling or contracting movements.
751	This distinction can be applied to general fitness goals for the aikido practitioner.
751	In aikido, specific muscles or muscle groups are not isolated and worked to improve tone, mass, and power.
751	Aikido-related training emphasizes the use of coordinated whole-body movement and balance similar to yoga or pilates.
751	For example, many dojos begin each class with , which may include stretching and ukemi (break falls).
751	Roles of uke and nage Aikido training is based primarily on two partners practicing pre-arranged forms (kata) rather than freestyle practice.
751	The basic pattern is for the receiver of the technique (uke) to initiate an attack against the person who applies the technique—the  tori, or shite  (depending on aikido style), also referred to as  nage (when applying a throwing technique), who neutralises this attack with an aikido technique.
751	Both halves of the technique, that of uke and that of nage, are considered essential to aikido training.
751	Both are studying aikido principles of blending and adaptation.
751	Nage learns to blend with and control attacking energy, while uke learns to become calm and flexible in the disadvantageous, off-balance positions in which nage places them.
751	This "receiving" of the technique is called ukemi.
751	Uke continuously seeks to regain balance and cover vulnerabilities (e.g., an exposed side), while nage uses position and timing to keep uke off-balance and vulnerable.
751	In more advanced training, uke will sometimes apply  to regain balance and pin or throw nage.
751	Good ukemi involves attention to the technique, the partner and the immediate environment—it is an active rather than a passive receiving of aikido.
751	The fall itself is part of aikido, and is a way for the practitioner to receive, safely, what would otherwise be a devastating strike or throw.
751	Initial attacks Aikido techniques are usually a defense against an attack, so students must learn to deliver various types of attacks to be able to practice aikido with a partner.
751	Although attacks are not studied as thoroughly as in striking-based arts, sincere attacks (a strong strike or an immobilizing grab) are needed to study correct and effective application of technique.
751	Many of the  of aikido resemble cuts from a sword or other grasped object, which indicates its origins in techniques intended for armed combat.
751	Other techniques, which explicitly appear to be punches (tsuki), are practiced as thrusts with a knife or sword.
751	Kicks are generally reserved for upper-level variations; reasons cited include that falls from kicks are especially dangerous, and that kicks (high kicks in particular) were uncommon during the types of combat prevalent in feudal Japan.
751	Some basic strikes include: *  a vertical knifehand strike to the head.
751	In training, this is usually directed at the forehead or the crown for safety, but more dangerous versions of this attack target the bridge of the nose and the maxillary sinus.
751	Specific targets include the chest, abdomen, and solar plexus.
751	Same as , and .
751	Same as .
751	Beginners in particular often practice techniques from grabs, both because they are safer and because it is easier to feel the energy and lines of force of a hold than a strike.
751	Some grabs are historically derived from being held while trying to draw a weapon; a technique could then be used to free oneself and immobilize or strike the attacker who is grabbing the defender.
751	The following are examples of some basic grabs: *  one hand grabs one wrist.
751	Same as  *  both hands grab both wrists.
751	Same as .
751	"Both-shoulders-grab" is .
751	It is sometimes combined with an overhead strike as .
751	Same as .
751	Basic techniques The following are a sample of the basic or widely practiced throws and pins.
751	Many of these techniques derive from Daitō-ryū Aiki-jūjutsu, but some others were invented by Morihei Ueshiba.
751	The precise terminology for some may vary between organisations and styles, so what follows are the terms used by the Aikikai Foundation.
751	Note that despite the names of the first five techniques listed, they are not universally taught in numeric order.
751	This grip applies pressure into the ulnar nerve at the wrist.
751	There is an adductive wristlock or Z-lock in ura version.) *  a rotational wristlock that directs upward-spiraling tension throughout the arm, elbow and shoulder.
751	The knuckles (from the palm side) are applied to the recipient's radial nerve against the periosteum of the forearm bone.
751	Common in knife and other weapon take-aways.
751	The hand is folded back past the shoulder, locking the shoulder joint.
751	The classic form superficially resembles a "clothesline" technique.
751	"earth") and the other high ("heaven"), which unbalances uke so that he or she easily topples over.
751	Nage drops his or her hips lower than those of uke, then flips uke over the resultant fulcrum.
751	The kanji for "10" is a cross-shape: 十).
751	Implementations Aikido makes use of body movement (tai sabaki) to blend with uke.
751	For example, an "entering" (irimi) technique consists of movements inward towards uke, while a  technique uses a pivoting motion.
751	Additionally, an  technique takes place in front of uke, whereas an  technique takes place to his side; a  technique is applied with motion to the front of uke, and a  version is applied with motion towards the rear of uke, usually by incorporating a turning or pivoting motion.
751	Finally, most techniques can be performed while in a seated posture (seiza).
751	Techniques where both uke and nage are standing are called tachi-waza, techniques where both start off in seiza are called suwari-waza, and techniques performed with uke standing and nage sitting are called hanmi handachi.
751	Thus, from fewer than twenty basic techniques, there are thousands of possible implementations.
751	For instance, ikkyō can be applied to an opponent moving forward with a strike (perhaps with an ura type of movement to redirect the incoming force), or to an opponent who has already struck and is now moving back to reestablish distance (perhaps an omote-waza version).
751	Specific aikido kata are typically referred to with the formula "attack-technique(-modifier)".
751	For instance, katate-dori ikkyō refers to any ikkyō technique executed when uke is holding one wrist.
751	This could be further specified as katate-dori ikkyō omote, referring to any forward-moving ikkyō technique from that grab.
751	Atemi () are strikes (or feints) employed during an aikido technique.
751	Some view atemi as attacks against "vital points" meant to cause damage in and of themselves.
751	For instance, Gōzō Shioda described using atemi in a brawl to quickly down a gang's leader.
751	Others consider atemi, especially to the face, to be methods of distraction meant to enable other techniques.
751	A strike, whether or not it is blocked, can startle the target and break his or her concentration.
751	The target may become unbalanced in attempting to avoid the blow, for example by jerking the head back, which may allow for an easier throw.
751	Many sayings about atemi are attributed to Morihei Ueshiba, who considered them an essential element of technique.
751	Weapons Weapons training in aikido traditionally includes the short staff (jō), wooden sword (bokken), and knife (tantō).
751	Today, some schools incorporate firearm-disarming techniques.
751	Both weapon-taking and weapon-retention are sometimes taught, to integrate armed and unarmed aspects.
751	Others, such as the Iwama style of Morihiro Saito, usually spend substantial time with bokken and jō, practised under the names aiki-ken, and aiki-jō, respectively.
751	The founder developed much of empty handed aikido from traditional sword and spear movements.
751	Consequently, the practice of these movements both gives insight into tl sword and spear movements.
751	Consequenhe origin of techniques and movements, and reinforces the concepts of distance, foot movement, presence and connectedness with one's training partner(s).
751	Multiple attackers and randori   One feature of aikido is training to defend against multiple attackers, often called taninzudori, or taninzugake.
751	Freestyle (randori, or jiyūwaza) practice with multiple attackers is a key part of most curricula and is required for the higher level ranks.
751	"Randori", literally "chaos", exercises a person's ability to intuitively perform techniques in an unstructured environment.
751	Strategic choice of techniques, based on how they reposition the student relative to other attackers, is important in randori training.
751	For instance, an ura technique might be used to neutralise the current attacker while turning to face attackers approaching from behind.
751	In Shodokan Aikido, randori differs in that it is not performed with multiple persons with defined roles of defender and attacker, but between two people, where both participants attack, defend, and counter at will.
751	In this respect it resembles judo randori.
751	Injuries In applying a technique during training, it is the responsibility of nage to prevent injury to uke by employing a speed and force of application that is commensurate with their partner's proficiency in ukemi.
751	Injuries (especially those to the joints), when they do occur in aikido, are often the result of nage misjudging the ability of uke to receive the throw or pin.
751	A study of injuries in the martial arts showed that while the type of injuries varied considerably from one art to the other, the differences in overall rates of injury were much less pronounced.
751	Soft tissue injuries are one of the most common types of injuries found within aikido, and a few deaths from repetitive "shihōnage" in a Japanese-style hazing context have been reported.
751	Mental training Aikido training is mental as well as physical, emphasizing the ability to relax the mind and body even under the stress of dangerous situations.
751	This is necessary to enable the practitioner to perform the bold enter-and-blend movements that underlie aikido techniques, wherein an attack is met with confidence and directness.
751	Morihei Ueshiba once remarked that one "must be willing to receive 99% of an opponent's attack and stare death in the face" in order to execute techniques without hesitation.
751	As a martial art concerned not only with fighting proficiency but with the betterment of daily life, this mental aspect is of key importance to aikido practitioners.
751	Criticisms The most common criticism of aikido is that it suffers from a lack of realism in training.
751	The attacks initiated by uke (and which nage must defend against) have been criticized as being "weak," "sloppy," and "little more than caricatures of an attack."
751	Weak attacks from uke cause a conditioned response from nage, and result in underdevelopment of the strength and conditioning needed for the safe and effective practice of both partners.
751	To counteract this, some styles allow students to become less compliant over time but, in keeping with the core philosophies, this is after having demonstrated proficiency in being able to protect themselves and their training partners.
751	Shodokan Aikido addresses the issue by practising in a competitive format.
751	Such adaptations are debated between styles, with some maintaining that there is no need to adjust their methods because either the criticisms are unjustified, or that they are not training for self-defence or combat effectiveness, but spiritual, fitness or other reasons.
751	Another criticisurl = http://www.aikidojm is that after the end of Ueshiba's seclusion in Iwama from 1942 to the mid-1950s, he increasingly emphasized the spiritual and philosophical aspects of aikido.
751	As a result, strikes to vital points by nage, entering (irimi) and initiation of techniques by nage, the distinction between omote (front side) and ura (back side) techniques, and the use of weapons, were all de-emphasized or eliminated from practice.
751	Lack of training in these areas is thought to lead to an overall loss of effectiveness by some aikido practitioners.
751	Conversely, there are some who criticize aikido practitioners for not placing enough importance on the spiritual practices emphasized by Ueshiba.
751	The premise of this criticism is that "O-Sensei's aikido was not a continuation and extension of the old and has a distinct discontinuity with past martial and philosophical concepts."
751	That is, that aikido practitioners who focus on aikido's roots in traditional jujutsu or kenjutsu are diverging from what Ueshiba taught.
751	Such critics urge practitioners to embrace the assertion that "[Ueshiba's] transcendence to the spiritual and universal reality was the fundamentals  of the paradigm that he demonstrated."
751	Ki The study of ki is a critical component of aikido, and its study defies categorization as either "physical" or "mental" training, as it encompasses both.
751	The original kanji for ki was , and is a symbolic representation of a lid covering a pot full of rice; the "nourishing vapors" contained within are ki.
751	The character for ki is used in everyday Japanese terms, such as , or .
751	Ki is most often understood as unified physical and mental intention, however in traditional martial arts it is often discussed as "life energy".
751	Gōzō Shioda's Yoshinkan Aikido, considered one of the "hard styles," largely follows Ueshiba's teachings from before World War II, and surmises that the secret to ki lies in timing and the application of the whole body's strength to a single point.
751	In later years, Ueshiba's application of ki in aikido took on a softer, more gentle feel.
751	This was his Takemusu Aiki and many of his later students teach about ki from this perspective.
751	Koichi Tohei's Ki Society centers almost exclusively around the study of the empirical (albeit subjective) experience of ki with students ranked separately in aikido techniques and ki development.
751	Uniforms and ranking Aikido practitioners (commonly called aikidōka outside of Japan) generally progress by promotion through a series of "grades" (kyū), followed by a series of "degrees" (dan), pursuant to formal testing procedures.
751	Some aikido organizations use belts to distinguish practitioners' grades, often simply white and black belts to distinguish lower and higher grades, though some use various belt colors.
751	Testing requirements vary, so a particular rank in one organization is not comparable or interchangeable with the rank of another.
751	Some dojos do not allow students to take the test to obtain a dan rank unless they are 16 or older.
751	The uniform worn for practicing aikido (aikidōgi) is similar to the training uniform (keikogi) used in most other modern martial arts; simple trousers and a wraparound jacket, usually white.
751	Both thick ("judo-style"), and thin ("karate-style") cotton tops are used.
751	Aikido-specific tops are available with shorter sleeves which reach to just below the elbow.
751	Most aikido systems add a pair of wide pleated black or indigo trousers called a hakama (used also in kendo and iaido.) In many schools, its use is reserved for practitioners with (dan) ranks or for instructors, while others allow all practitioners or female practitioners to wear a hakama regardless of rank.
752	Art is a diverse range of human activities and the products of those activities; this article focuses primarily on the visual arts, which includes the creation of images or objects in fields including painting,  sculpture, printmaking, photography, and other visual media.
752	Architecture is often included as one of the visual arts; however, like the decorative arts, it involves the creation of objects where the practical considerations of use are essential—in a way that they are usually not for a painting, for example.
752	Music, theatre, film, dance, and other performing arts, as well as literature, and other media such as interactive media are included in a broader definition of art or the arts.
752	Until the 17th century, art referred to any skill or mastery and was not differentiated from crafts or sciences, but in modern usage the fine arts, where aesthetic considerations are paramount, are distinguished from acquired skills in general, and the decorative or applied arts.
752	Art has been characterized in terms of mimesis, expression, communication of emotion, or other values.
752	During the Romantic period, art came to be seen as "a special faculty of the human mind to be classified with religion and science".
752	Though the definition of what constitutes art is disputed and has changed over time, general descriptions mention an idea of human agency and creation through imaginative or technical skill.
752	The nature of art, and related concepts such as creativity and interpretation, are explored in a branch of philosophy known as aesthetics.
752	Creative art and fine art  By a broad definition of art, artistic works have existed for almost as long as humankind: from early pre-historic art to contemporary art; however, some theories restrict the concept to modern Western societies.
752	The first and broadest sense of art is the one that has remained closest to the older Latin meaning, which roughly translates to "skill" or "craft."
752	A few examples where this meaning proves very broad include artifact, artificial, artifice, medical arts, and military arts.
752	However, there are many other colloquial uses of the word, all with some relation to its etymology.
752	In medieval philosophy, John Chrysostom held that "the name of art should be applied to those only which contribute towards and produce necessaries and mainstays of life."
752	Thomas Aquinas, when treating the adornment of women, gives an ethical justification as to why: "In the case of an art directed to the production of goods which men cannot use without sin, it follows that the workmen sin in making such things, as directly affording others an occasion of sin; for instance, if a man were to make idols or anything pertaining to idolatrous worship.
752	But in the case of an art the products of which may be employed by man either for a good or for an evil use, such as swords, arrows, and the like, the practice of such an art is not sinful.
752	These alone should be called arts."
752	Aquinas held that art is nothing else than "the right reason about certain works to be made," and that it is commendable, not for the will with which a craftman does a work, "but for the quality of the work.
752	Art, therefore, properly speaking, is an operative habit."
752	Aristotle and Aquinas distinguish it from the related habit of prudence.
752	The second and more recent sense of the word art is as an abbreviation for creative art or fine art and emerged in the early 17th century.
752	Fine art means that a skill is being used to express the artist's creativity, or to engage the audience's aesthetic sensibilities, or to draw the audience towards consideration of the finer things.
752	The word art can refer to several things: a study of creative skill, a process of using the creative skill, a product of the creative skill, or the audience's experience with the creative skill.
752	The creative arts (art as discipline) are a collection of disciplines that produce artworks (art as objects) that are compelled by a personal drive (art as activity) and convey a message, mood, or symbolism for the viewer to interpret (art as experience).
752	Art is something that stimulates an individual's thoughts, emotions, beliefs, or ideas through the sert is somethinses.
752	Artworks can be explicitly made for this purpose or interpreted on the basis of images or objects.
752	Although the application of scientific knowledge to derive a new scientific theory involves skill and results in the "creation" of something new, this represents science only and is not categorized as art.
752	Often, if the skill is being used in a common or practical way, people will consider it a craft instead of art.
752	Likewise, if the skill is being used in a commercial or industrial way, it may be considered commercial art instead of fine art.
752	On the other hand, crafts and design are sometimes considered applied art.
752	Some art followers have argued that the difference between fine art and applied art has more to do with value judgments made about the art than any clear definitional difference.
752	However, even fine art often has goals beyond pure creativity and self-expression.
752	The purpose of works of art may be to communicate ideas, such as in politically, spiritually, or philosophically motivated art; to create a sense of beauty (see aesthetics); to explore the nature of perception; for pleasure; or to generate strong emotions.
752	The purpose may also be seemingly nonexistent.
752	The nature of art has been described by philosopher Richard Wollheim as "one of the most elusive of the traditional problems of human culture".
752	Art has been defined as a vehicle for the expression or communication of emotions and ideas, a means for exploring and appreciating formal elements for their own sake, and as mimesis or representation.
752	Art as mimesis has deep roots in the philosophy of Aristotle.
752	Goethe defined art as an other resp.
752	Leo Tolstoy identified art as a use of indirect means to communicate from one person to another.
752	Benedetto Croce and R.G.
752	Collingwood advanced the idealist view that art expresses emotions, and that the work of art therefore essentially exists in the mind of the creator.
752	The theory of art as form has its roots in the philosophy of Immanuel Kant, and was developed in the early twentieth century by Roger Fry and Clive Bell.
752	More recently, thinkers influenced by Martin Heidegger have interpreted art as the means by which a community develops for itself a medium for self-expression and interpretation.
752	George Dickie has offered an institutional theory of art that defines a work of art as any artifact upon which a qualified person or persons acting on behalf of the social institution commonly referred to as "the art world" has conferred "the status of candidate for appreciation".
752	History Sculptures, cave paintings, rock paintings and petroglyphs from the Upper Paleolithic dating to roughly 40,000 years ago have been found, but the precise meaning of such art is often disputed because so little is known about the cultures that produced them.
752	The oldest art objects in the world—a series of tiny, drilled snail shells about 75,000 years old—were discovered in a South African cave.
752	Containers that may have been used to hold paints have been found dating as far back as 100,000 years.
752	Many great traditions in art have a foundation in the art of one of the great ancient civilizations: Ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, Persia, India, China, Ancient Greece, Rome, as well as Inca, Maya, and Olmec.
752	Each of these centers of early civilization developed a unique and characteristic style in its art.
752	Because of the size and duration of these civilizations, more of their art works have survived and more of their influence has been transmitted to other cultures and later times.
752	Some also have provided the first records of how artists worked.
752	For example, this period of Greek art saw a veneration of the human physical form and the development of equivalent skills to show musculature, poise, beauty, and anatomically correct proportions.
752	In Byzantine and Medieval art of the Western Middle Ages, much art focused on the expression of Biblical and religious truths, and used styles that showed the higher glory of a heavenly world, such as the use of gold in the background of paintings, or glass in mosaics or windows, which also presented figures in idealized, patterned (flat) forms.
752	Nevertheless a classical realist tradition persisted in small Byzantine works, and realism steadily grew in the art of Catholic Europe.
752	Renaissance art had a greatly increased emphasis on the realistic depiction of the material world, and the place of humans in it, reflected in the corporeality of the human body, and development of a systematic method of graphical perspective to depict recession in a three-dimensional picture space.
752	In the east, Islamic art's rejection of iconography led to emphasis on geometric patterns, calligraphy, and architecture.
752	Further east, religion dominated artistic styles and forms too.
752	India and Tibet saw emphasis on painted sculptures and dance, while religious painting borrowed many conventions from sculpture and tended to bright contrasting colors with emphasis on outlines.
752	China saw the flourishing of many art forms: jade carving, bronzework, pottery (including the stunning terracotta army of Emperor Qin), poetry, calligraphy, music, painting, drama, fiction, etc.
752	Chinese styles vary greatly from era to era and each one is traditionally named after the ruling dynasty.
752	So, for example, Tang Dynasty paintings are monochromatic and sparse, emphasizing idealized landscapes, but Ming Dynasty paintings are busy and colorful, and focus on telling stories via setting and composition.
752	Japan names its styles after imperial dynasties too, and also saw much interplay between the styles of calligraphy and painting.
752	Woodblock printing became important in Japan after the 17th century.
752	The western Age of Enlightenment in the 18th century saw artistic depictions of physical and rational certainties of the clockwork universe, as well as politically revolutionary visions of a post-monarchist world, such as Blake's portrayal of Newton as a divine geometer, or David's propagandistic paintings.
752	This led to Romantic rejections of this in favor of pictures of the emotional side and individuality of humans, exemplified in the novels of Goethe.
752	The late 19th century then saw a host of artistic movements, such as academic art, Symbolism, impressionism and fauvism among others.
752	The history of twentieth century art is a narrative of endless possibilities and the search for new standards, each being torn down in succession by the next.
752	Thus the parameters of Impressionism, Expressionism, Fauvism, Cubism, Dadaism, Surrealism, etc.
752	Increasing global interaction during this time saw an equivalent influence of other cultures into Western art, such as Pablo Picasso being influenced by African sculpture.
752	Japanese woodblock prints (which had themselves been influenced by Western Renaissance draftsmanship) had an immense influence on Impressionism and subsequent development.
752	Later, African sculptures were taken up by Picasso and to some extent by Matisse.
752	Similarly, the west has had huge impacts on Eastern art in the 19th and 20th centuries, with originally western ideas like Communism and Post-Modernism exerting a powerful influence on artistic styles.
752	Modernism, the idealistic search for truth, gave way in the latter half of the 20th century to a realization of its unattainability.
752	Theodor W.
752	Adorno said in 1970, "It is now taken for granted that nothing which concerns art can be taken for granted any more: neither art itself, nor art in relationship to the whole, nor even the right of art to exist."
752	Relativism was accepted as an unavoidable truth, which led to the period of contemporary art and postmodern criticism, where cultures of the world and of history are seen as changing forms, which can be appreciated and drawn from only with irony.
752	Furthermore the separation of cultures is increasingly blurred and some argue it is now more appropriate to think in terms of a global culture, rather than regional cultures.
752	Forms, genres, media, and styles The creative arts are often divided into more specific categories, each related to its technique, or medium, such as decorative arts, plastic arts, performing arts, or literature.
752	Unlike scientific fields, art is one of the few subjects that are academically organized according to technique [http://www.rchoetzlein.com/quanta/theory/theory-new-media.htm].
752	An artistic medium is the substance or material the artistic work is made from, and may also refer to the technique used.
752	For example, paint is a medium used in painting, and paper is a medium used in drawing.
752	An art form is the specific shape, or quality an artistic expression takes.
752	The media used often influence the form.
752	For example, the form of a sculpture must exist in space in three dimensions, and respond to gravity.
752	The constraints and limitations of a particular medium are thus called its formal qualities.
752	To give another example, the formal qualities of painting are the canvas texture, color, and brush texture.
752	The formal qualities of video games are non-linearity, interactivity and virtual presence.
752	The form of a particular work of art is determined by the formal qualities of the media, and is not related to the intentions of the artist or the reactions of the audience in any way whatsoever as these properties are related to content rather than form.
752	A genre is a set of conventions and styles within a particular medium.
752	For instance, well recognized genres in film are western, horror and romantic comedy.
752	Genres in music include death metal and trip hop.
752	Genres in painting include still life and pastoral landscape.
752	A particular work of art may bend or combine genres but each genre has a recognizable group of conventions, clichés and tropes.
752	One note: the word genre has a second older meaning within painting; genre painting was a phrase used in the 17th to 19th centuries to refer specifically to paintings of scenes of everyday life and is still used in this way.) The style of an artwork, artist, or movement is the distinctive method and form followed by the respective art.
752	Any loose brushy, dripped or poured abstract painting is called expressionistic.
752	Often a style is linked with a particular historical period, set of ideas, and particular artistic movement.
752	So Jackson Pollock is called an Abstract Expressionist.
752	A particular style may have specific cultural meanings.
752	For example, Roy Lichtenstein—a painter associated with the American Pop art movement of the 1960s—was not a pointillist, despite his use of dots.
752	Lichtenstein used evenly spaced Ben-Day dots (the type used to reproduce color in comic strips) as a style to question the "high" art of painting with the "low" art of comics, thus commenting on class di"high"stinctions in culture.
752	Pointillism, a technique in late Impressionism (1880s) developed especially by the artist Georges Seurat, employs dots to create variation in color and depth in an attempt to approximate the way people really see color.
752	Both artists use dots, but the particular style and technique relate to the artistic movement adopted by each artist.
752	These are all ways of beginning to define a work of art, to narrow it down.
752	"Imagine you are an art critic whose mission is to compare the meanings you find in a wide range of individual artworks.
752	How would you proceed with your task?
752	One way to begin is to examine the materials each artist selected in making an object, image video, or event.
752	The decision to cast a sculpture in bronze, for instance, inevitably effects its meaning; the work becomes something different from how it might be if it had been cast in gold or plastic or chocolate, even if everything else about the artwork remains the same.
752	Next, you might examine how the materials in each artwork have become an arrangement of shapes, colors, textures, and lines.
752	These, in turn, are organized into various patterns and compositional structures.
752	In your interpretation, you would comment on how salient features of the form contribute to the overall meaning of the finished artwork.
752	But in the end] the meaning of most artworks...
752	Most interpretations also include a discussion of the ideas and feelings the artwork engenders."
752	Skill and craft Art can connote a sense of trained ability or mastery of a medium.
752	Art can also simply refer to the developed and efficient use of a language to convey meaning with immediacy and or depth.
752	Art is an act of expressing feelings, thoughts, and observations.
752	There is an understanding that is reached with the material as a result of handling it, which facilitates one's thought processes.
752	A common view is that the epithet "art", particular in its elevated sense, requires a certain level of creative expertise by the artist, whether this be a demonstration of technical ability, an originality in stylistic approach, or a combination of these two.
752	Traditionally skill of execution was viewed as a quality inseparable from art and thus necessary for its success; for Leonardo da Vinci, art, neither more nor less than his other endeavors, was a manifestation of skill.
752	Rembrandt's work, now praised for its ephemeral virtues, was most admired by his contemporaries for its virtuosity.
752	At the turn of the 20th century, the adroit performances of John Singer Sargent were alternately admired and viewed with skepticism for their manual fluency, yet at nearly the same time the artist who would become the era's most recognized and peripatetic iconoclast, Pablo Picasso, was completing a traditional academic training at which he excelled.
752	A common contemporary criticism of some modern art occurs along the lines of objecting to the apparent lack of skill or ability required in the production of the artistic object.
752	In conceptual art, Marcel Duchamp's "Fountain" is among the first examples of pieces wherein the artist used found objects ("ready-made") and exercised no traditionally recognised set of skills.
752	Tracey Emin's My Bed, or Damien Hirst's The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living follow this example and also manipulate the mass media.
752	Emin slept (and engaged in other activities) in her bed before placing the result in a gallery as work of art.
752	Hirst came up with the conceptual design for the artwork but has left most of the eventual creation of many works to employed artisans.
752	Hirst's celebrity is founded entirely on his ability to produce shocking concepts.
752	The actual production in many conceptual and contemporary works of art is a matter of assembly of found objects.
752	However there are many modernist and contemporary artists who continue to excel in the skills of drawing and painting and in creating hands-on works of art.
752	Value judgment Somewhat in relation to the above, the word art is also used to apply judgments of value, as in such expressions as "that meal was a work of art" (the cook is an artist), or "the art of deception", (the highly attained level of skill of the deceiver is praised).
752	It is this use of the word as a measure of high quality and high value that gives the term its flavor of subjectivity.
752	Making judgments of value requires a basis for criticism.
752	At the simplest level, a way to determine whether the impact of the object on the senses meets the criteria to be considered art is whether it is perceived to be attractive or repulsive.
752	Though perception is always colored by experience, and is necessarily subjective, it is commonly understood that what is not somehow aesthetically satisfying cannot be art.
752	However, "good" art is not always or even regularly aesthetically appealing to a majority of viewers.
752	In other words, an artist's prime motivation need not be the pursuit of the aesthetic.
752	Also, art often depicts terrible images made for social, moral, or thought-provoking reasons.
752	For example, Francisco Goya's painting depicting the Spanish shootings of 3rd of May 1808 is a graphic depiction of a firing squad executing several pleading civilians.
752	Yet at the same time, the horrific imagery demonstrates Goya's keen artistic ability in composition and execution and produces fitting social and political outrage.
752	Thus, the debate continues as to what mode of aesthetic satisfaction, if any, is required to define 'art'.
752	The assumption of new values or the rebellion against accepted notions of what is aesthetically superior need not occur concurrently with a complete abandonment of the pursuit of what is aesthetically appealing.
752	Indeed, the reverse is often true, that the revision of what is popularly conceived of as being aesthetically appealing allows for a re-invigoration of aesthetic sensibility, and a new appreciation for the standards of art itself.
752	Countless schools have proposed their own ways to define quality, yet they all seem to agree in at least one point: once their aesthetic choices are accepted, the value of the work of art is determined by its capacity to transcend the limits of its chosen medium to strike some universal chord by the rarity of the skill of the artist or in its accurate reflection in what is termed the zeitgeist.
752	Art is often intended to appeal to and connect with human emotion.
752	It can arouse aesthetic or moral feelings, and can be understood as a way of communicating these feelings.
752	Artists express something so that their audience is aroused to some extent, but they do not have to do so consciously.
752	Art may be considered an exploration of the human condition; that is, what it is to be human.
752	Purpose of art Art has had a great number of different functions throughout its history, making its purpose difficult to abstract or quantify to any single concept.
752	This does not imply that the purpose of Art is "vague", but that it has had many unique, different reasons for being created.
752	Some of these functions of Art are provided in the following outline.
752	The different purposes of art may be grouped according to those that are non-motivated, and those that are motivated (Levi-Strauss).
752	Non-motivated functions of art The non-motivated purposes of art are those that are integral to being human, transcend the individual, or do not fulfill a specific external purpose.
752	In this sense, Art, as creativity, is something humans must do by their very nature (i.e., no other species creates art), and is therefore beyond utility.
752	Basic human instinct for harmony, balance, rhythm.
752	Art at this level is not an action or an object, but an internal appreciation of balance and harmony (beauty), and therefore an aspect of being human beyond utility."Imitation, then, is one instinct of our nature.
752	Next, there is the instinct for 'harmony' and rhythm, meters being manifestly sections of rhythm.
752	Persons, therefore, starting with this natural gift developed by degrees their special aptitudes, till their rude improvisations gave birth to Poetry."
752	Aristotle # Experience of the mysterious.
752	Art provides a way to experience one's self in relation to the universe.
752	This experience may often come unmotivated, as one appreciates art, music or poetry."The most beautiful thing we can experience is the mysterious.
752	It is the source of all true art and science."
752	Albert Einstein # Expression of the imagination.
752	Art provide a means to express the imagination in non-grammatic ways that are not tied to the formality of spoken or written language.
752	Unlike words, which come in sequences and each of which have a definite meaning, art provides a range of forms, symbols and ideas with meanings that are malleable."Jupiter's eagle [as an example of art] is not, like logical (aesthetic) attributes of an object, the concept of the sublimity and majesty of creation, but rather something else – something that gives the imagination an incentive to spread its flight over a whole host of kindred representations that provoke more thought than admits of expression in a concept determined by words.
752	They furnish an aesthetic idea, which serves the above rational idea as a substitute for logical presentation, but with the proper function, however, of animating the mind by opening out for it a prospect into a field of kindred representations stretching beyond its ken."
752	Immanuel Kant # Ritualistic and symbolic functions.
752	In many cultures, art is used in rituals, performances and dances as a decoration or symbol.
752	While these often have no specific utilitarian (motivated) purpose, anthropologists know that they often serve a purpose at the level of meaning within a particular culture.
752	This meaning is not furnished by any one individual, but is often the result of many generations of change, and of a cosmological relationship within the culture."Most scholars who deal with rock paintings or objects recovered from prehistoric contexts that cannot be explained in utilitarian terms and are thus categorized as decorative, ritual or symbolic, are aware of the trap posed by the term 'art'."
752	Silva Tomaskova Motivated functions of art Motivated purposes of art refer to intentional, conscious actions on the part of the artists or creator.
752	These may be to bring about political change, to comment on an aspect of society, to convey a specific emotion or mood, to address personal psychology, to illustrate another discipline, to (with commercial arts) to sell a product, or simply as a form of communication.
752	Communication.
752	Art, at its simplest, is a form of communication.
752	As most forms of communication have an intent or goal directed toward another individual, this is a motivated purpose.
752	Illustrative arts, such as scientific illustration, are a form of art as communication.
752	Maps are another example.
752	However, the content need not be scientific.
752	Emotions, moods and feelings are also communicated through art."[Art is a set of] artefacts or images with symbolic meanings as a means of communication."
752	Steve Mithen # Art as entertainment.
752	Art may seek to bring about a particular emotion or mood, for the purpose of relaxing or entertaining the viewer.
752	This is often the function of the art industries of Motion Pictures and Video Games.
752	The Avante-Garde.
752	Art for political change.
752	One of the defining functions of early twentieth century art has been to use visual images to bring about political change.
752	Art movements that had this goal—Dadaism, Surrealism, Russian Constructivism, and Abstract Expressionism, among others—are collectively referred to as the avante-garde arts."By contrast, the realistic attitude, inspired by positivism, from Saint Thomas Aquinas to Anatole France, clearly seems to me to be hostile to any intellectual or moral advancement.
752	I loathe it, for it is made up of mediocrity, hate, and dull conceit.
752	It is this attitude which today gives birth to these ridiculous books, these insulting plays.
752	It constantly feeds on and derives strength from the newspapers and stultifies both science and art by assiduously flattering the lowest of tastes; clarity bordering on stupidity, a dog's life."
752	André Breton (Surrealism) # Art for psychological and healing purposes.
752	Art is also used by art therapists, psychotherapists and clinical psychologists as art therapy.
752	The Diagnostic Drawing Series, for example, is used to determine the personality and emotional functioning of a patient.
752	The end product is not the principal goal in this case, but rather a process of healing, through creative acts, is sought.
752	The resultant piece of artwork may also offer insight into the troubles experienced by the subject and may suggest suitable approaches to be used in more conventional forms of psychiatric therapy.
752	Art for social inquiry, subversion and/or anarchy.
752	While similar to art for political change, subversive or deconstructivist art may seek to question aspects of society without any specific political goal.
752	In this case, the function of art may be simply to criticize some aspect of society.
752	Graffiti art and other types of street art are graphics and images that are spray-painted or stencilled on publicly viewable walls, buildings, buses, trains, and bridges, usually without permission.
752	Certain art forms, such as graffiti, may also be illegal when they break laws (in this case vandalism).
752	Art for social causes.
752	Art can be used to raise awarehey break laws (ness for a large variety of causes.
752	A number of art activities were aimed at raising awareness of autism, cancer, human trafficking, and a variety of other topics, such as ocean conservation, human rights in Darfur, murdered and missing Aboriginal women, elder abuse, and pollution.
752	Trashion, practiced by artists such as Marina DeBris is one example of using art to raise awareness about pollution.
752	Art for propaganda, or commercialism.
752	Art is often utilized as a form of propaganda, and thus can be used to subtly influence popular conceptions or mood.
752	In a similar way, art that tries to sell a product also influences mood and emotion.
752	In both cases, the purpose of art here is to subtly manipulate the viewer into a particular emotional or psychological response toward a particular idea or object.
752	Art as a fitness indicator.
752	It has been argued that the ability of the human brain by far exceeds what was needed for survival in the ancestral environment.
752	One evolutionary psychology explanation for this is that the human brain and associated traits (such as artistic ability and creativity) are the human equivalent of the peacock's tail.
752	The purpose of the male peacock's extravagant tail has been argued to be to attract females (see also Fisherian runaway and handicap principle).
752	According to this theory superior execution of art was evolutionary important because it attracted mates.
752	The functions of art described above are not mutually exclusive, as many of them may overlap.
752	For example, art for the purpose of entertainment may also seek to sell a product, i.e.
752	Public access Since ancient times, much of the finest art has represented a deliberate display of wealth or power, often achieved by using massive scale and expensive materials.
752	Much art has been commissioned by rulers or religious establishments, with more modest versions only available to the most wealthy in society.
752	Nevertheless, there have been many periods where art of very high quality was available, in terms of ownership, across large parts of society, above all in cheap media such as pottery, which persists in the ground, and perishable media such as textiles and wood.
752	In many different cultures, the ceramics of indigenous peoples of the Americas are found in such a wide range of graves that they were clearly not restricted to a social elite, though other forms of art may have been.
752	Reproductive methods such as moulds made mass-production easier, and were used to bring high-quality Ancient Roman pottery and Greek Tanagra figurines to a very wide market.
752	Cylinder seals were both artistic and practical, and very widely used by what can be loosely called the middle class in the Ancient Near East.
752	Once coins were widely used these also became an artform that reached the widest range of society.
752	Another important innovation came in the 15th century in Europe, when printmaking began with small woodcuts, mostly religious, that were often very small and hand-coloured, and affordable even by peasants who glued them to the walls of their homes.
752	Printed books were initially very expensive, but fell steadily in price until by the 19th century even the poorest could afford some with printed illustrations.
752	Popular prints of many different sorts have decorated homes and other places for centuries.
752	Public buildings and monuments, secular and religious, by their nature normally address the whole of society, and visitors as viewers, and display to the general public has long been an important factor in their design.
752	Egyptian temples are typical in that the most largest and most lavish decoration was placed on the parts that could be seen by the general public, rather than the areas seen only by the priests.
752	Many areas of royal palaces, castles and the houses of the social elite were often generally accessible, and large parts of the art collections of such people could often be seen, either by anybody, or by those able to pay a small price, or those wearing the correct clothes, regardless of who they were, those abas at the Palace of Versailles, where the appropriate extra accessories (silver shoe buckles and a sword) could be hired from shops outside.
752	Special arrangements were made to allow the public to see many royal or private collections placed in galleries, as with the Orleans Collection mostly housed in a wing of the Palais Royal in Paris, which could be visited for most of the 18th century.
752	In Italy the art tourism of the Grand Tour became a major industry from the Renaissance onwards, and governments and cities made efforts to make their key works accessible.
752	The British Royal Collection remains distinct, but large donations such as the Old Royal Library were made from it to the British Museum, established in 1753.
752	The Uffizi in Florence opened entirely as a gallery in 1765, though this function had been gradually taking the building over from the original civil servants' offices for a long time before.
752	The building now occupied by the Prado in Madrid was built before the French Revolution for the public display of parts of the royal art collection, and similar royal galleries open to the public existed in Vienna, Munich and other capitals.
752	The opening of the Musée du Louvre during the French Revolution (in 1793) as a public museum for much of the former French royal collection certainly marked an important stage in the development of public access to art, transferring ownership to a republican state, but was a continuation of trends already well established.
752	Most modern public museums and art education programs for children in schools can be traced back to this impulse to have art available to everyone.
752	Museums in the United States tend to be gifts from the very rich to the masses (The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, for example, was created by John Taylor Johnston, a railroad executive whose personal art collection seeded the museum.) But despite all this, at least one of the important functions of art in the 21st century remains as a marker of wealth and social status.
752	There have been attempts by artists to create art that can not be bought by the wealthy as a status object.
752	One of the prime original motivators of much of the art of the late 1960s and 1970s was to create art that could not be bought and sold.
752	It is "necessary to present something more than mere objects" said the major post war German artist Joseph Beuys.
752	This time period saw the rise of such things as performance art, video art, and conceptual art.
752	The idea was that if the artwork was a performance that would leave nothing behind, or was simply an idea, it could not be bought and sold.
752	"Democratic precepts revolving around the idea that a work of art is a commodity impelled the aesthetic innovation which germinated in the mid-1960s and was reaped throughout the 1970s.
752	Artists broadly identified under the heading of Conceptual art...
752	" In the decades since, these ideas have been somewhat lost as the art market has learned to sell limited edition DVDs of video works, invitations to exclusive performance art pieces, and the objects left over from conceptual pieces.
752	Many of these performances create works that are only understood by the elite who have been educated as to why an idea or video or piece of apparent garbage may be considered art.
752	The marker of status becomes understanding the work instead of necessarily owning it, and the artwork remains an upper-class activity.
752	"With the widespread use of DVD recording technology in the early 2000s, artists, and the gallery system that derives its profits from the sale of artworks, gained an important means of controlling the sale of video and computer artworks in limited editions to collectors."
752	Controversies Art has long been controversial, that is to say disliked by some viewers, for a wide variety of reasons, though most pre-modern controversies are dimly recorded, or completely lost to a modern view.
752	Iconoclasm is the destruction of art that is disliked for a variety of reasons, including religious ones.
752	Aniconism is a general dislike of either all figurative images, or often just religious ones, and has been a thread in many major religions.
752	It has been a crucial factor in the history of Islamic art, where depictions of Muhammad remain especially controversial.
752	Much art has been disliked purely because it depicted or otherwise stood for unpopular rulers, parties or other groups.
752	Artistic conventions have often been conservative and taken very seriously by art critics, though often much less so by a wider public.
752	The iconographic content of art could cause controversy, as with late medieval depictions of the new motif of the Swoon of the Virgin in scenes of the Crucifixion of Jesus.
752	The Last Judgment by Michelangelo was controversial for various reasons, including breaches of decorum through nudity and the Apollo-like pose of Christ.
752	The content of much formal art through history was dictated by the patron or commissioner rather than just the artist, but with the advent of Romanticism, and econonomic changes in the production of art, the artists' vision became the usual determinant of the content of his art, increasing the incidence of controversies, though often reducing their significance.
752	Strong incentives for perceived originality and publicity also encouraged artists to court controversy.
752	Théodore Géricault's Raft of the Medusa (c.
752	Manet's Le Déjeuner sur l'Herbe (1863), was considered scandalous not because of the nude woman, but because she is seated next to men fully dressed in the clothing of the time, rather than in robes of the antique world.
752	John Singer Sargent's Madame Pierre Gautreau (Madam X) (1884), caused a controversy over the reddish pink used to color the woman's ear lobe, considered far too suggestive and supposedly ruining the high-society model's reputation.
752	The gradual abandonment of naturalism and the depiction of realistic representations of the visual appearance of subjects in the 19th and 20th centuries led to a rolling controversy lasting for over a century.
752	In the twentieth century, Pablo Picasso's Guernica (1937) used arresting cubist techniques and stark monochromatic oils, to depict the harrowing consequences of a contemporary bombing of a small, ancient Basque town.
752	Leon Golub's Interrogation III (1981), depicts a female nude, hooded detainee strapped to a chair, her legs open to reveal her sexual organs, surrou female nude, hoodnded by two tormentors dressed in everyday clothing.
752	Andres Serrano's Piss Christ (1989) is a photograph of a crucifix, sacred to the Christian religion and representing Christ's sacrifice and final suffering, submerged in a glass of the artist's own urine.
752	The resulting uproar led to comments in the United States Senate about public funding of the arts.
752	Theory In the nineteenth century, artists were primarily concerned with ideas of truth and beauty.
752	The aesthetic theorist John Ruskin, who championed what he saw as the naturalism of J. M. W.
752	Turner, saw art's role as the communication by artifice of an essential truth that could only be found in nature.
752	The definition and evaluation of art has become especially problematic since the 20th century.
752	Richard Wollheim distinguishes three approaches to assessing the aesthetic value of art: the Realist, whereby aesthetic quality is an absolute value independent of any human view; the Objectivist, whereby it is also an absolute value, but is dependent on general human experience; and the Relativist position, whereby it is not an absolute value, but depends on, and varies with, the human experience of different humans.
752	The arrival of Modernism in the late nineteenth century lead to a radical break in the conception of the function of art, and then again in the late twentieth century with the advent of postmodernism.
752	Clement Greenberg's 1960 article "Modernist Painting" defines modern art as "the use of characteristic methods of a discipline to criticize the discipline itself".
752	Greenberg originally applied this idea to the Abstract Expressionist movement and used it as a way to understand and justify flat (non-illusionistic) abstract painting:  After Greenberg, several important art theorists emerged, such as Michael Fried, T. J. Clark, Rosalind Krauss, Linda Nochlin and Griselda Pollock among others.
752	Though only originally intended as a way of understanding a specific set of artists, Greenberg's definition of modern art is important to many of the ideas of art within the various art movements of the 20th century and early 21st century.
752	Pop artists like Andy Warhol became both noteworthy and influential through work including and possibly critiquing popular culture, as well as the art world.
752	Artists of the 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s expanded this technique of self-criticism beyond high art to all cultural image-making, including fashion images, comics, billboards and pornography.
752	Duchamp once proposed that art is any activity of any kind- everything.
752	However the way that only certain activities are classified today as art is a social construction.
752	There is evidence that there may be an element of truth to this.
752	The Invention of Art: A Cultural History is an art history book which examines the construction of the modern system of the arts i.e.
752	Fine Art.
752	Shiner finds evidence that the older system of the arts before our modern system (fine art) held art to be any skilled human activity i.e.
752	Ancient Greek society did not possess the term art but techne.
752	Techne can be understood neither as art or craft, the reason being that the distinctions of art and craft are historical products that came later on in human history.
752	Techne included painting, sculpting and music but also; cooking, medicine, horsemanship, geometry, carpentry, prophecy and farming etc.
752	Classification disputes Disputes as to whether or not to classify something as a work of art are referred to as classificatory disputes about art.
752	Classificatory disputes in the 20th century have included cubist and impressionist paintings, Duchamp's Fountain, the movies, superlative imitations of banknotes, conceptual art, and video games.
752	Philosopher David Novitz has argued that disagreement about the definition of art are rarely the heart of the problem.
752	Rather, "the passionate concerns and interests that humans vest in their social life" are "so much a part of all classificatory disputes about art" (Novitz, 1996).
752	According to Novitz, classificatory disputes are more often disputes about societal values and where society is trying to go than they are about theory proper.
752	For example, when the Daily Mail criticized Hirst's and Emin's work by arguing "For 1,000 years art has been one of our great civilising forces.
752	Today, pickled sheep and soiled beds threaten to make barbarians of us all" they are not advancing a definition or theory about art, but questioning the value of Hirst's and Emin's work.
752	In 1998, Arthur Danto, suggested a thought experiment showing that "the status of an artifact as work of art results from the ideas a culture applies to it, rather than its inherent physical or perceptible qualities.
752	Cultural interpretation (an art theory of some kind) is therefore constitutive of an object's arthood."
752	Anti-art is a label for art that intentionally challenges the established parameters and values of art; it is term associated with Dadaism and attributed to Marcel Duchamp just before World War I, when he was making art from found objects.
752	One of these,  Fountain (1917), an ordinary urinal, has achieved considerable prominence and influence on art.
752	Anti-art is a feature of work by Situationist International, the lo-fi Mail art movement, and the Young British Artists, though it is a form still rejected by the Stuckists, who describe themselves as anti-anti-art.
